BC-Philippines-Marrying Priests
Priest who officiated at wedding of another priest also wants to
marry
MANILA, Philippines (AP) _ A Catholic priest who officiated at the wedding of another priest has told his bishop that he too plans to get married later this year, church officials said Friday. The Rev. Jesus Siva officiated at the May 31 wedding of Hector Canto, who defiantly wore his priest's robes when he exchanged vows with engineer Cynthia Diamante in the town of Lambunao in central Iloilo province. Canto was defrocked after the wedding, and Siva is awaiting punishment for having participated. Now, however, because of his wedding plans, Siva will also be asked to leave the priesthood, said Msgr. Pedro Quitorio, assistant secretary-general of the Catholic Bishops' Conference of the Philippines. Quitorio said Siva had informed the bishop of his diocese about his desire to get married. ``It leaves a bad taste in the mouth,'' Quitorio said of the weddings. He said the Church is not ``buckling'' to calls to accept married priests. Very few Filipino priests ask permission to leave the priesthood to get married, he said. ``It is a matter of the law of the Church,'' he said. ``Once a priest does (marry) he is dismissed.'' A priest who wants to marry can ask permission from his bishop, who in turn asks for dispensation from Pope John Paul II to recognize the wedding. The priest is then asked to leave the priesthood because of the end of his vow of celibacy. If he fails to do that, the wedding is not recognized by the Church. There are about 6,000 priests in the Philippines, serving about 60 million Filipino Catholics. Siva is assistant parish priest of Lambunao, about 420 kilometers (260 miles) south of Manila. Canto was assistant parish priest of Dumangas, a town about 40 kilometers (25 miles) from Lambunao.

BC-Sports-Baseball-AL Roundup,0512
Blue Jays, White Sox post wins
TORONTO (AP) _ Shawn Green and Carlos Delgado hit two-run homers and Ed Sprague had a three-run double as the Toronto Blue Jays beat the Detroit Tigers 9-6 on Thursday, Detroit's fifth straight losses. Woody Williams (7-2) won his fourth straight decision despite giving up six runs and seven hits in six innings. Randy Myers pitched the ninth for his 14th save. Brian Moehler (5-5) took the loss. Tony Clark and Damian Easley homered for Toronto. Athletics 6, Rangers 1 In Oakland, California, Rickey Henderson homered for the third time in as many games and Jimmy Haynes and Bill Taylor combined on a five-hitter, leading the Athletics past the Rangers. Haynes (4-2) allowed one run on five hits in 7 1-3 innings. Taylor got five outs for his 10th save. Rick Helling (7-3) failed in his third try for his eighth victory, allowing four runs on eight hits in seven innings. White Sox 7, Royals 1 In Kansas City, Missouri, Jamie Navarro pitched a complete game eight-hitter and Jeff Abbott hit a three-run home run as Chicago beat Kansas City, the White Sox's 11th straight victory at Kauffman Stadium. Navarro (5-6) snapped a personal three-game losing streak, walking two and striking out one. He benefited from inning-ending double plays in the first, second, sixth and seventh. Glendon Rusch (3-8) took the loss. Red Sox 9, Orioles 1 In Boston, Bret Saberhagen allowed one run in seven innings and Darren Lewis drove in three runs as the Red Sox rebounded from its only shutout loss of the season with a victory over the Orioles. Saberhagen (7-3) allowed seven hits, walked one and struck out three in his longest outing of the season. Lewis went 3-for-5 with an RBI single that put Boston ahead 3-0 in the second and his third homer of the season, a two-run shot that made it 5-0 in the sixth. B.J. Surhoff homered for the Orioles. Sidney Ponson (0-3) took the loss. Yankees 6, Devil Rays 1 In New York, Hideki Irabu held Tampa Bay to one run in 7 1-3 innings and Bernie Williams was 3-for-4 with two RBIs as New York beat the expansion Devil Rays to extend its winning streak to four games. Irabu (5-1), who lowered his league-leading ERA to 1.45, had six strikeouts and four walks. Graeme Lloyd got the final five outs. Paul O'Neill homered off Dennis Springer (2-9). Indians 3, Twins 2 In Minneapolis, Dwight Gooden won for the first time with Cleveland, making Jim Thome's three-run homer stand up against Minnesota. Gooden (1-2) allowed one run and six hits in six innings, allowing the lone run to score on Marty Cordova's second-inning home run. The 33-year-old right-hander was making his third start of the season after opening the year on the disabled list because of biceps tendinitis in his pitching shoulder. Mike Jackson pitched the ninth for his 13th save. Thome hit his 14th homer of the season off Brad Radke (7-4) in the fourth. Otis Nixon also homered for Minnesota. MORE

BC-Philippines-Inflation, 1st Ld-Writethru
Philippine inflation rises to 10.3 percent in May
Eds: ADDS background on new consumer price index in grafs 6-9, CORRECTS day in 1st graf to Friday
MANILA, Philippines (AP) _ Philippine consumer prices rose 10.3 percent in May from a year earlier using a new base year of 1994 instead of the previous 1988, the government said Friday. The consumer price index was also recalibrated to reflect changing consumer spending patterns over the past decade, with different weightings given to the goods and services that make up the index. Food, beverage and tobacco continue to have the heaviest weighting, but were reduced to 55.1 percent from 58.5 percent. Using the old index, inflation in May was 9.2 percent after April inflation was revised to 7.8 percent from 7.9 percent. The May figure was the highest since June 1996, when inflation was 9.8 percent. The government has set an inflation target of between 7.5 percent and 8.5 percent for this year. The government said the food, beverage and tobacco component of the new CPI rose 8.9 percent in May from a year earlier while services jumped 15.9 percent. Fuel, light and water rose 5.0 percent. The National Statistics Office is expected to issue two separate inflation figures until August, after which it will use only the 1994-based CPI data. NSO administrator Tomas Africa earlier said the new CPI may prompt the government to review its economic targets because of the higher inflation figures. Inflation data are a factor in determining interest rates and money supply. ``But we are leaving that decision to the new economic team,'' said Africa, referring to the economic managers of newly elected President Joseph Estrada, who assumes office June 30. Average inflation between January and April based on the new CPI was 8.175 percent compared with 7.2 percent under the old index.

BC-Mexico-Torture Death,0229
Experts confirm suspect in Mexican police custody died of head
wound
TOLUCA, Mexico (AP) _ Forensics experts have confirmed that a prisoner whose body was found being dumped by Mexican police on a highway died a severe brain injury brought on by a beating. The scandal that erupted after Morelos state police were caught with the body of Jorge Nava Aviles in January forced the state governor, Jorge Carrillo Olea, to resign last month. Criminologist Alejandro Benitez told a district judge Thursday that Nava died from grave brain inflammation, and the body had multiple internal and external bruises indicating torture. The former Morelos state attorney general and the former leader of the state's judicial police have been accused of covering up the killing by officers. Several other people, including top law enforcement officials, also have been charged. Former Morelos Judicial Police Chief Jesus Miyazawa admitted knowing about the torture killing of a prisoner by his officers. Miyazawa said he accompanied officers involved in the killing to a January meeting with Carlos Peredo Meredo, then attorney general for Morelos. Miyazawa said the prosecutor not only failed to open a criminal investigation of the case, but told police to remove the body from the police station and get rid of it.

BC-Sports-Baseball-Nomo Trade,0458
Nomo traded to Mets in four-player deal
By JOHN NADEL AP Sports Writer
LOS ANGELES (AP) _ ``Nomomania'' is moving to the Big Apple. Hideo Nomo, whose career with the Los Angeles Dodgers came to a sudden end early this week when he was designated for assignment, was traded to the New York Mets late Thursday in a deal involving four right-handed pitchers. Nomo will be reunited in New York with former Dodgers catcher Mike Piazza and pitcher Masato Yoshii, a teammate with the Kintetsu Buffaloes in Japan before Nomo joined the Dodgers in 1995. Nomo and Yoshii are both represented by Don Nomura. The Mets will also receive 27-year-old reliever Brad Clontz, who has been pitching for the Dodgers' Albuquerque farm club of the Pacific Coast League. Clontz was 2-0 with a 5.66 ERA in 18 games with the Dodgers before being farmed out last month. Moving to Los Angeles are starter Dave Mlicki, who turns 30 Monday, and 31-year-old reliever Greg McMichael. Mlicki is 1-4 with a 5.68 ERA in 10 games, all starts. McMichael is 1-2 with a 3.97 ERA in 22 games, all in relief. Nomo, 29, the NL Rookie of the Year in 1995, was 2-7 with a 5.05 ERA before the Dodgers cut him loose after the Japanese pitcher asked for a trade. He has lost his last four decisions, allowing 18 earned runs in 26 2-3 innings. When the Dodgers designated Nomo for assignment on Monday, that left them with 10 days to make a move. They only needed three. The trade marked another change for the Dodgers, who have a much different look in the 2 1/2 months since the Fox Group purchased them from the O'Malley family. Piazza and third baseman Todd Zeile were traded to the Florida Marlins on May 15 for outfielders Gary Sheffield and Jim Eisenreich, third baseman Bobby Bonilla, catcher Charles Johnson and a minor league pitcher. Piazza was traded to the Mets a week later for three prospects. Nomo reportedly was unhappy about the trade of Piazza, and apparently asked to be traded several times before Dodgers general manager Fred Claire acted Monday. Nomo's popularity among Asian fans in Los Angeles was similar to the kind of fan support _ ``Fernandomania'' _ generated in the Mexican community after the emergence of left-hander Fernando Valenzuela, who pitched for the Dodgers from 1980-90. Nomura met with Claire on Sunday and requested a move be made. A day later, Claire obliged. Nomo, who underwent arthroscopic surgery on his pitching elbow last fall, was booed during his last start as a Dodger on Saturday during a 7-3 loss to Cincinnati in which he allowed seven hits and six runs in 3 2-3 innings.

BC-Mexico-Grandmother Killed,0136
Mexican woman kidnapped by grandson suffocates to death
MEXICO CITY (AP) _ A 65-year-old woman suffocated to death after she was gagged by a band of kidnappers, one of whom was her own grandson, police in the central Mexican state of Hidalgo said. Luz Maria Amado Palomo died Thursday while she was being held by her 21-year-old grandson, Norberto Palomo Aguirre, and three other young men, the government Notimex news agency quoted police as saying. The men had kidnapped the woman early Thursday and demanded a ransom of 1 million pesos, or dlrs 115,000. The made the demand in a telephone call from a restaurant in Pachuca, 60 miles (95 kilometers) northeast of Mexico City. Police traced the call and caught the men. They then found the woman dead.

BC-SKorea-President
With BC-SKorea-Politics
Korean president to try to forge new partnership with U.S.
SEOUL, South Korea (AP) _ President Kim Dae-jung said Friday he will seek more economic assistance and propose a new policy of engagement toward North Korea when he meets President Clinton next week. The first opposition leader to take power in South Korea, Kim leaves for the United States Saturday for a nine-day visit. It will be his second overseas trip since taking office in February. He visited London in April to attend an Asia-Europe summit. ``I will stress that Korea-U.S. relations should be developed beyond the partnership in security and trade to a new partnership on a higher level based on a shared belief in the principles of democracy and a free market economy,'' Kim told a nationally televised news conference marking his first 100 days in office. Kim said his talks with Clinton in Washington on June 9 will focus on U.S. assistance to help rebuild South Korea's battered economy and measures to lead North Korea to open its closed communist society. He also said he will appeal for U.S. and other international investment in South Korea, whose economy was bailed out by the International Monetary Fund in December. Kim said Seoul would support any moves by the United States to promote political and economic detente with North Korea. ``As was shown in the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, the engagement policy of the United States and the sunshine policy of the new South Korean government will be more effective for North Korea,'' he said. Kim's remarks were a departure from the policy of past South Korean governments which tried to contain North Korea rather than engage it. Inter-Korea relations remain chilly because of military and political tensions on the peninsula. The North has shunned South Korea as a dialogue partner while pushing vigorously to improve ties with Washington. Kim said he would not oppose a move by Washington to ease or lift U.S. economic sanctions on North Korea. Under the Trading With the Enemy Act, U.S. companies are prohibited from doing business with North Korea. The United States fought on South Korea's side in the 1950-53 Korean War. ``I'm not pessimistic at all about our relations with North Korea,'' Kim said. The president said there were signs that North Korea would change its hard-line policy toward South Korea but declined to elaborate. Kim said South Korea has largely succeeded in overcoming a foreign exchange crisis but the country still has a long way to go to rebuild its shattered economy. To restore investor confidence, Kim said he would accelerate reforms in the latter part of this year to restructure the economy. The reforms, he said, will include faster liquidation of financially weak banks and companies and a disintegration of South Korea's bloated, family-oriented conglomerates, or chaebol. Chaebol, which typically control 40 to 50 subsidiaries, are largely blamed for causing South Korea's financial crisis. At least eight of them collapsed in the past year, saddling banks with billions of dollars in bad loans.

BC-Japan-Big Bang
Japan's Parliament approves ``Big Bang'' deregulation bills
TOKYO (AP) _ Japan's Parliament approved four financial deregulation bills Friday, intensifying the nation's ``Big Bang'' program of opening financial markets to greater competition. The measures are designed to make Japanese financial institutions more efficient and globally competitive, while offering foreign financial companies wider access to the Japanese market. Friday's action by the upper house followed similar approval of the four bills in the more powerful lower house last month. Finance Minister Hikaru Matsunaga told a news conference that the enactment of the reform legislation will help create a ``favorable environment'' for Japan's economy by revitalizing the slumping Tokyo markets and benefiting consumers as well. But the Big Bang reforms, nicknamed after similar British financial reforms in the 1980s, come at a tough time for Japan's weakening economy. Stock prices remain far below record highs, and banks and other financial institutions are saddled with massive bad debts left over from a 1980s speculative land price boom that went bust. Unemployment and corporate bankruptcies are at record highs. Among measures endorsed by the 252-member House of Councilors: _ Non-life insurance premium rates will be liberalized starting July 1. _ Banks can sell investment trust funds from their own windows from December 1. _ A ban on trading derivatives will be lifted Dec. 1. _ Brokers' commission fees will be completely liberalized by the end of 1999, while further liberalizing sales of mutual funds and securities. _ Greater disclosure of corporate management information. _ A registration system will be introduced for securities firms, from the current license system. As part of the sweeping financial deregulation program, Japan put a revised foreign exchange law into effect on April 1, allowing Japanese individuals and businesses for the first time to handle foreign currencies freely. BC-Sports-Ice Hockey-Humbled Hasek,0561
Juneau ends Hasek's long but successful season
BUFFALO, New York (AP) _ Just like that, the ride ended for Dominik Hasek. It was one rebound he could not control, one scramble in front of the net he did not win. The all-world goaltender who led the Czech Republic to the Olympic gold medal and brought the Buffalo Sabres one series victory away from the NHL Stanley Cup Finals skated off the ice defeated and exhausted. ``Always if you lose the last game of the season, it's disappointing,'' said Hasek after Joe Juneau scored in overtime to give the Washington Capitals the Eastern Conference title. ``We were close, but I have to give the Capitals credit.'' Brian Bellows moved around Darryl Shannon and and set up the game-winner when he tried stuffing the puck past Hasek. Once, twice, three times, the puck stayed in the crease before Juneau picked it up and sent it under the fallen goaltender's glove. ``I saw Juneau sneak in,'' Hasek said. ``I had a feeling he had lots of time so I put my catching glove a little bit up. He put it in under my glove. I knew right away it was over.'' It was swift, sudden, and decisive. Gone was Hasek's opportunity for a rare double _ an Olympic gold medal and a Stanley Cup. Former New York Islanders defenseman Ken Morrow remains the only player in history to accomplish the feat. After establishing a team record with 13 shutouts during the regular season, Hasek did so only once in the playoffs. He still is the favorite to become the first goaltender in history to be named most valuable player in consecutive years. He's also expected to be named top goalie for the fourth time in five years. ``I was awfully nervous about Game 7 if we lost,'' Capitals coach Ron Wilson said. ``If you had to pick a goalie for a Game 7, it would probably be pretty unanimous that Dominik would be the choice.'' Hasek played well but was beatable against the Capitals. Washington's top line of Peter Bondra, Richard Zednik, and Andrei Nikolishin combined for seven of Washington's 13 goals in the series. Bondra's goal Thursday night with 5:59 remaining in the third period sent the game to overtime. ``They were probably the best line in the series,'' said Hasek, who allowed three overtime goals in the series after giving up none in the regular season. ``You play 60 minutes, it's a tie game, you come in the locker room and think if you get a goal you win the game,'' Hasek said. ``Unfortunately, three times they won the overtime game. Buffalo had taken a 2-1 lead 7:40 into the third on Paul Kruse's first playoff goal. In the second period, Michael Peca gave the Sabres a 1-0 lead with 5:56 to go with his third playoff goal. Esa Tikkanen tied the game 22 seconds later with his third. ``You can't fault (Hasek) for any of the goals,'' said Sabres coach Lindy Ruff. ``I'm extra proud of the way we played. It wasn't meant to be.'' Hasek was the guy who many thought caused the offseason problems surrounding the Sabres. He denounced former coach Ted Nolan, who was given a one-year contract he immediately rejected. He was booed at home to start the season and revered after returning a hero in the Olympics. Almost everybody understands the Sabres would not have been in the conference finals without Hasek.

BC-Australia-Deep Sea Park
Volcanic sea mountains could be Australia's first deep sea marine
park
HOBART, Australia (AP) _ A recommendation to protect unique marine life on undersea mountains south of Tasmania may lead to Australia's first deep-sea marine protected area. The recommendation follows a three-year study by Australia's federal science agency, the Commonwealth Scientific Industrial Research Organization, announced Friday, on the life on the seamounts and the impact of deep sea trawling. Research leader Tony Koslow said the study, on extinct undersea volcanoes that rise 650-1,650 feet (200-500 meters) above the sea floor at depths of 3,200-6,500 feet (1,000-2,000 meters), found a rich diversity of life forms which were highly vulnerable to trawling. They are about 60 miles (100 km) south of Tasmania. Koslow said a single research cruise found 259 species of invertebrates such as coral, seastars and crabs, about a third of which were new to science. About 40 percent of the new species are thought to live only on these seamounts. Thirty-seven species of fish were also found. Fishing for orange roughy has occurred over shallower seamounts in the area. But the bigger mounts have never been fished, partly because of a 1995 interim moratorium on fishing over a 143-square-mile (370 sq. km.) area that includes the bigger mounts. The research showed a greatly reduced coral cover and species variety in heavily trawled areas outside the protected region. The report recommends that the interim protected area be permanently protected from all fishing and other activities that could disturb the sea life. Neville Exon of the Australian Geological Survey Organization said the seamounts made up the most extensive cluster known to occur in any one place anywhere within Australia's Exclusive Economic Zone.

BC-Philippines-Muslim Rebels
Two die as ex-Muslim rebel leader resists arrest in southern
Philippines
ZAMBOANGA, Philippines (AP) _ A former Muslim rebel leader and his followers resisted his arrest by 200 government agents Friday in a clash that left two people dead and two wounded, including a 4-month-old baby girl, officials said. Police said about 200 soldiers and police were sent to the village of Taluksangay near Zamboanga to serve an arrest warrant on Kamlon Awolon, who faces kidnapping, extortion, murder and robbery charges. Awolon, who was expected to resist arrest, is a former commander of the Moro National Liberation Front, which signed a peace pact with the government in 1996. Brig. Gen. Dominador Resos said Awolon and his men shot at the arresting officers. In an exchange of gunfire, a former rebel and the wife of another ex-rebel were killed and a 4-month-old baby girl being carried by her mother was wounded. A government agent who led the police to Awolon's house was also wounded, police said. Awolon and the rest of his men broke through the security cordon and escaped, Resos added. They were being pursued by police, he said. Two smaller Muslim rebel groups _ the fundamentalist Abu Sayyaf and the Moro Islamic Liberation Front _ are still fighting the government. The government has begun peace talks with the MILF but the talks have been put on hold until President-elect Joseph Estrada takes office on June 30.

BC-Vietnam-Cashews
Vietnam floats cashew nut price
HANOI, Vietnam (AP) _ Vietnam has floated the price of cashews due to a shortage of nuts to keep processing plants running, an executive of the Vietnam Cashew Nuts Association said Friday. Cashews have been trading at 8,000 dong to 10,000 dong (62-80 cents) per kilogram (2.2 pounds), well up from the ceiling price of 6,500 dong (50 cents) set by the government, the executive said. The executive, speaking on condition he not be identified, said foreign sellers have raised their offer for raw nuts to more than dlrs 700 per ton from dlrs 650 earlier. He said the price has been pushed up because there aren't enough cashews available to run the 60 nut-processing plants, which have a capacity of more than 200,000 tons per year. Vietnam produced about 110,000 tons in the February-May crop, down from the average of 150,000-180,000 tons, largely because of the country's worst drought in a century. Cashews are planted only in southern Vietnam, which was particularly parched. Vietnam never has imported cashews for processing for re-export but plans to import 30,000 tons this year to fill the shortfall. Vietnam exported 33,000 processed cashew nuts last year, fetching dlrs 133 million. About 4.5 kilograms of raw cashews can produce one kilogram (2.2 pounds) of refined nuts. The cashew association has 50 members.

BC-Indonesia-US
Protesters stage demonstration at US Embassy in Indonesia
AP Photos Staffing By IRWAN FIRDAUS Associated Press Writer
JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ Shouting ``Allah is great,'' about 100 Muslim protesters and shook the gates of the U.S. Embassy in the capital Friday, accusing Washington of interfering in the internal affairs of crisis-ridden Indonesia. The demonstration follows similar anti-American protests in recent days as Indonesia's worst economic crisis in 30 years continues to spiral. On Thursday, in the second largest city of Surabaya, a group pulled down the U.S. flag from outside the U.S. consulate and tore it up. On Friday in Jakarta, a group calling themselves the ``Young Generation for Indonesian Development'' sat outside the embassy as a small group of police and soldiers looked on. ``The United States should not intervene in our sovereignty because we are not a beggar nation,'' said protest organizer Mohamad Rudi. The group alleged that Washington was trying to delay the restarting of a dlrs 43 billion economic bailout plan put together for Indonesia by the International Monetary Fund. It also accused the United States government of funding anti-government groups, a charge flatly denied by Washington. An IMF team is scheduled to arrive in Jakarta on Monday to assess Indonesia's crisis in the wake of last month's resignation by former leader President Suharto. Suharto ended 32 years of authoritarian rule on May 21 after the world's fourth most populous nation was shaken by a wave of protests and riots triggered by soaring inflation and mass unemployment. An estimated 1,188 people died in the violence. About 90 percent of Indonesia's 202 million people are Muslim, making it the world's largest Islamic nation. On Thursday, visiting U.S. Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, Stanley Roth, categorically denied that Washington had dabbled in Indonesia's political turmoil. However, he called on new President B.J. Habibie to carry on with promises to reform Indonesia's rigid political system and to hold free elections. Roth also warned that international economic assistance for Indonesia would be fruitless unless political stability was established. Meanwhile, American diplomats evacuated from Indonesia last month are not going back despite a decline in violence, the State Department said Thursday. And American travelers were advised to avoid travel to the Southeast Asian country unless the trip is essential. Many employees of the U.S. Embassy in Jakarta and the U.S. Consulate in Surabaya were evacuated in May, leaving only essential American government workers behind. Hundreds of U.S. expatriates and other foreigners also left the country.

BC-India-Nuclear,0548
India studying demands by five nuclear powers
With UN-India-Pakistan By ASHOK SHARMA Associated Press Writer
NEW DELHI, India (AP) _ India on Friday was closely studying demands by the five original nuclear powers that it and Pakistan give up their nuclear ambitions and instead sit down together to resolve issues fueling their rivalry, including the dispute over the border region of Kashmir. India will give its response after ``closely examining'' the Thursday's joint statement by the foreign ministers of Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States, the Press Trust of India news agency quoted foreign ministry spokesman K.C. Singh as saying. Last month India conducted a series of nuclear tests, citing its fear of Pakistan and China. Pakistan responded with its own tests, setting off fears the long-standing South Asian rivalry could culminate with nuclear war. Meeting Thursday in Geneva, the foreign ministers of the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council offered to help India and Pakistan resolve their differences, especially their competing claims to the Himalayan territory of Kashmir. But the main responsibility for making peace is theirs, said Tang Jiaxuan of China, who chaired the meeting. New Delhi has in the past rejected any outside pressure to settle the Kashmir dispute, the flash point of two of India's three wars with Pakistan in the past 50 years. Pakistan, though, has pressed for it to be taken up in international fora, believing it is at a disadvantage in one-on-one talks with its larger and more powerful neighbor. Indian Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee told Parliament on Thursday that his government was prepared to discuss the contentious issue bilaterally with Pakistan. The Geneva statement also asked India and Pakistan to sign the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty without conditions. Soon after conducting its tests, India said it planned no more but wouldn't sign the treaty in its present form because it allows Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States to keep their nuclear arsenals. Pakistan, which responded with nuclear tests of its own, says it will sign the CTBT only if India adhered to it. Though India and Pakistan now claim to be capable of building nuclear bombs, the five nations who were the first to perfect weapons of mass destruction refused to welcome any new members into their club, the U.N. Security Council. U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright told reporters they could not let any other nation on the nuclear threshold believe it ``can test its way in.'' Pakistan and India, Albright and the other ministers said, should refrain from any more tests, from building or deploying nuclear weapons, or from testing missiles to carry nuclear bombs. Many fear the next stage of the costly, potentially catastrophic South Asian nuclear arms race will be developing delivery systems. The ministers did not threaten sanctions, which the United States has been alone among the five in imposing. Sanctions only hurt the people and neighboring countries and ``have little effect on leaders who often act in isolation and sometimes unpredictably,'' said Russia's Yevgeny Primakov.

BC-Sports-Baseball-Nomo Trade, 2nd Ld-Writethru,0668
Nomo traded to Mets in four-player deal
Eds: UPDATES with Nomura, Phillips quotes By JOHN NADEL AP Sports Writer
LOS ANGELES (AP) _ ``Nomomania'' is moving to New York. Hideo Nomo, whose career with the Los Angeles Dodgers came to a sudden end early this week when he was designated for assignment, was traded to the New York Mets late Thursday in a deal involving four right-handed pitchers. Nomo will be reunited in New York with former Dodgers catcher Mike Piazza and pitcher Masato Yoshii, a teammate with the Kintetsu Buffaloes in Japan before Nomo joined the Dodgers in 1995. Nomo and Yoshii are both represented by Don Nomura. The Mets will also receive 27-year-old reliever Brad Clontz, who has been pitching for the Dodgers' Albuquerque farm club of the Pacific Coast League. Clontz was 2-0 with a 5.66 ERA in 18 games with the Dodgers before being farmed out last month. Moving to Los Angeles are starter Dave Mlicki, who turns 30 Monday, and 31-year-old reliever Greg McMichael. Mlicki is 1-4 with a 5.68 ERA in 10 games, all starts. McMichael is 1-2 with a 3.97 ERA in 22 games, all in relief. ``I think it's an outstanding trade for us,'' Dodgers general manager Fred Claire said. ``In Dave Mlicki, we get a starting pitcher with outstanding ability. In Greg McMichael, we get one of the league's top setup men. ``I think we've helped our pitching staff to a large degree by getting two experienced guys. They have experience, they have ability, they'll fit in great.'' When the Dodgers designated Nomo for assignment on Monday, that left them with 10 days to make a move. They only needed three, and announced the deal after beating the St. Louis Cardinals 3-2. Claire said the Dodgers were contacted by 20 teams following Monday's announcement, and that Nomo and Nomura ``were very happy'' about going to the Mets. ``He's very excited to become a Met,'' Nomura said. ``The Mets are one of the teams he's wanted to play for.'' Said Mets general manager Steve Phillips: ``The obvious questions are about his health and performance this year. Once we looked at eveything, we were easily able to work up a justifcation for bringing him in and expecting him to do well.'' Claire said Mlicki will join the Dodgers in Seattle during a three-game weekend series, but didn't say whether Mlicki would pitch against the Mariners. McMichael was given permission to join the team Monday in Los Angeles when it opens a three-game series against Oakland. Nomo, 29, the NL Rookie of the Year in 1995, was 2-7 with a 5.05 ERA before the Dodgers cut him loose after the Japanese pitcher asked for a trade. He has lost his last four decisions, allowing 18 earned runs in 26 2-3 innings. The trade marked another change for the Dodgers, who have a much different look in the 2 1/2 months since the Fox Group purchased them from the O'Malley family. Piazza and third baseman Todd Zeile were traded to the Florida Marlins on May 15 for outfielders Gary Sheffield and Jim Eisenreich, third baseman Bobby Bonilla, catcher Charles Johnson and a minor league pitcher. Piazza was traded to the Mets a week later for three prospects. Nomo reportedly was unhappy about the trade of Piazza, and apparently asked to be traded several times before Claire acted Monday. Nomo's popularity among Asian fans in Los Angeles was similar to the kind of fan support _ ``Fernandomania'' _ received in the Mexican community after the emergence of left-hander Fernando Valenzuela, who pitched for the Dodgers from 1980-90. Nomura met with Dodgers general manager Fred Claire on Sunday and requested a move be made. A day later, Claire obliged. Nomo, who underwent arthroscopic surgery on his pitching elbow last fall, was booed during his last start as a Dodger on Saturday during a 7-3 loss to Cincinnati in which he allowed seven hits and six runs in 3 2-3 innings.

Man jailed 15 years for slavery, rape of wife
AUCKLAND, New Zealand (AP) _ A man convicted of enslaving, raping and torturing his wife for more than four years was sentenced Friday by the High Court to serve 15 years in jail. The man, a 31-year-old former bus driver and pastor, was found guilty last month after a two-week trial. He had denied all counts. The court has suppressed publication of his name and the names of his wife and children. During the trial, prosecutor Richard Marchant said the woman, now 24, was held in ``two homes of horror'' for four years until she escaped in March 1997. The woman testified that she was confined in her room with her three children for up to 22 hours a day. She said she had boiling water poured over her, had salt rubbed in her wounds, had her head rammed against a door jamb and cigarettes stubbed out on her. The man maintained his innocence and claimed the injuries were caused when he tried to prevent the woman from harming herself. The High Court sentenced the man to concurrent 10-year terms on slavery and rape charges, and added additional sentences ranging from five years to one year on 12 other charges involving violent offenses. The judge said the case brought to public attention the issue of battered women's syndrome, which was still not widely understood despite being accepted by the courts in recent years. Justice Tony Randerson said the man had regarded the woman as his personal property and had exercised almost total control over her. ``It is hard to credit that this state of affairs could exist in a modern society.'' he said. The judge said the psychiatric report noted that the man had not accepted the jury's verdicts against him and had failed to show any remorse. The prosecutor said the woman and her children had been undergoing counseling and she was ``freaking out'' over the freedom she now had to do even simple things.

BC-Germany-Train Derails, 1st Ld-Writethru
Dozens of Germany's fast trains idled after crash
Eds: UPDATES with confirmed death toll at 95; CORRECTS style for network to n-tv, sted NTV. AP Photos ESC101,104,113 By TONY CZUCZKA Associated Press Writer
ESCHEDE, Germany (AP) _ Dozens of Germany's fastest trains were idled Friday for inspections after investigators pointed to a wheel failure as a possible cause of the country's worst rail accident in more than 50 years. The confirmed death toll rose to 95 after rescue crews recovered two additional bodies early Friday from the last major part of wreckage to be excavated, a dining car that was buried when an overpass collapsed during Wednesday's pileup. Police spokesman Peter Hoppe said rescuers did not expect to find additional bodies. State authorities originally had estimated that as many as 100 or more were killed when the Hamburg-bound InterCity Express 884 derailed near the small town of Eschede, 50 kilometers (35 miles) north of Hanover. There has been no indication of human error, but a break in a wheel is emerging as the possible cause of the accident, said Horst Stuchly, president of the federal railway office. After jumping the tracks at 200 kilometers (125 miles) an hour, the ICE crashed into part of the bridge and sparked a smash-up of train cars. ``I remember only that people and seats were all over the place,'' an unidentified woman told n-tv television in one of the first interviews with one of the scores of injured survivors evacuated to hospitals in helicopters. ``A glass pane fell on me, and I was lying on top of somebody, and all around was chaos,'' said the bandaged woman, speaking softly from a hospital bed. ``As I later lay there in silence, the door was open and I watched the sky, until the first helicopter came.'' State officials said 200 people were injured, of whom 95 were treated in hospitals. Ninety-two bodies were recovered at the scene, and three people had died in hospitals. Rescue crews managed to reach parts of the dining car only after carefully lifting a huge chunk of the collapsed concrete bridge with cranes overnight. Some train parts remained under the bridge, but not an entire first-class car as previously had been reported, and no additional bodies were expected, officials said. Further excavation of the bridge was halted until later Friday to give exhausted crews a break, crisis management spokesman Klaus Weswe said. Deutsche Bahn said it was removing all 60 of its first-generation InterCity Express trains, introduced in 1991, from service after they finished their runs Thursday, idling more than half of the nation's fastest trains. Forty-three trains built since 1996 remained in service. It was unclear how quickly normal service would resume. ``We are going to do everything possible to make sure that this tragic accident won't happen again,'' rail spokesman Martin Katz said. Earlier, officials had lowered the speed limit for all ICE trains from 280 kilometers (175 miles) per hour to 160 kph (100 mph) until the entire fleet could be inspected. There were one- to three-hour delays Thursday along the 2,175-mile ICE system, which links Germany's key cities and give business commuters a convenient alternative to the country's clogged autobahns. A spokeswoman for the federal transport ministry told The Associated Press that a broken wheel on the first car behind the lead locomotive may have been a factor in the accident. She did not elaborate. Stuchly also cited a broken wheel, and said that part of the train derailed 300 meters (yards) before the train reached the overpass. Police in Celle said parts from a train were found on the track six kilometers (3.7 miles) from the bridge, but they gave no details on the parts and were uncertain whether they were from the crashed train. Officials said it appeared that the fifth car of the 12-car train hit the bridge as it went through. The back end of the car was broken off; the fourth car veered off the rails and rolled onto its side, while three other cars jackknifed further up the line. The lead locomotive remained on the tracks and the driver apparently was unaware of the incident, coming to a stop only after the station master at Eschede activated an emergency brake. The rest of the train was squashed beneath or against the collapsed overpass. Officials said a detailed, forensic investigation would begin only after all victims had been removed the debris. Authorities set up a reception center for worried relatives in a sports hall in Eschede. The window shades were drawn and a sign warning ``No Press'' was attached to plastic sheets covering the door. Bodies and body parts were taken to Hanover for identification. ``I've never seen so many injured, so much destruction and so many dead. I believe this is what all of us are experiencing,'' Rev. Cristoph Kuenkel told a few hundred people who gathered Thursday evening for a memorial service at the town's Lutheran church, the Johanniskirche. Germany's deadliest train accident prior to Wednesday's derailment came in 1967, when 94 people were killed after a barrier closed on a rail tanker filled with gasoline, causing it to explode. (im)

BC-Japan-Peacekeeping
Japan approves law to allow troops more peacekeeping activity
TOKYO (AP) _ Japan approved Friday a bill that would revise its current peacekeeping law to expand the international peacekeeping activities of the nation's military. The law, approved by the upper house of Parliament, is scheduled to take effect next month. The revision was already passed by the more powerful lower house in May. Under the revised Peacekeeping Law, Japanese troops can be sent to a disputed area where there is no ceasefire, which is banned under the current law. The revision also allows the nation's military, called the Self-Defense Forces, to participate in election monitoring organized by various organizations other than the United Nations, the only organization under which Japan can send its troops according to the current law. Japan has sent members of its Self-Defense Forces to Cambodia, Mozambique, Zaire and the Israeli-occupied Golan Heights under the 1992 law that permitted Japanese troops to go abroad for the first time since its defeat in World War II _ but only for peacekeeping missions and never for combat. Opposition lawmakers and pacifist activists criticized the law as a step toward the nation's military expansion overseas. Japan's postwar pacifist Constitution prohibits use of military force as a means of settling international disputes. Also, unlike the current law that left the decision to use weapons for self-defense up to individual soldiers, the revision gives a troop commander the right to make decisions for his entire men in case of danger. BC-NKorea-Japan
North Korea says no missing Japanese in its territory
SEOUL, South Korea (AP) _ North Korea said Friday a lengthy investigation found no evidence that missing Japanese citizens are in its territory, despite allegations of kidnappings by its agents. Acting on Japanese requests, North Korea's Red Cross and government have conducted an ``intensive'' five-month search for 10 missing Japanese since early this year, said the North's official Korean Central News Agency. But none of those sought by Japan was found, a North Korean Red Cross spokesman told KCNA. ``The results of the search finally proved that the persons wanted by Japan do not exist in the (North Korean) territory and that they never entered nor temporarily stayed here,'' the spokesman said. The status of the 10 missing Japanese is a key pending issue between Japan and North Korea, which have no diplomatic ties. Talks aimed at normalizing Tokyo-Pyongyang relations have stalled over the issue of the missing persons. Japan believes that North Korean agents abducted the Japanese, including a 13-year-old girl, over the past two decades to use them as language teachers for their spies. North Korea has dismissed the alleged kidnappings as ``faked-up cases.'' But during talks with a delegation of Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto's ruling coalition last November, Pyongyang's ruling (communist) Workers Party agreed to launch an investigation. Police and other officials conducted the search throughout North Korea ``in a responsible way from the humanitarian point of view,'' the Red Cross spokesman told KCNA. They investigated the personal data of all foreign citizens staying in North Korea and naturalized people as well as their families overseas, comparing them with identities of the 10 people sought by Japan, he said. North Korea resents Japan's colonial rule of the Korean Peninsula from 1910 to 1945, support for the United States in the 1950-53 Korean War, and close ties to the rival South Korean government. After tortuous negotiations, North Korea allowed 15 Japanese women married to North Korean men to visit Japan late last year and early this year. Their visits were the first of their kind. On Friday, North Korea demanded that the Japanese Red Cross help find out the fates of many Korean women forced to work as sex slaves in front-line brothels run by the Japanese Imperial Army during World War II.

BC-Universe-Missing Mass
Scientists may have found some of the universe's `missing mass'
Eds: PMs. RECAPS previous cycle and UPDATES with fresh quotes and detail By TODD ZAUN Associated Press Writer
TOKYO (AP) _ An international team of scientists working from a revamped mineshaft in central Japan said Friday they may have unlocked one of the biggest mysteries of physics _ evidence that an infinitesimally small subatomic particle called the neutrino has mass. The finding would be revolutionary because it would force physicists to rethink a central theory of modern science: That the universe began expanding at the Big Bang and will keep expanding forever. The Super-Kamiokande Experiment research team, a group of 120 scientists from around the world, presented their findings Friday at a physics conference in Takayama, a city in central Japan. The findings had the physicists almost giddy. `I think they have definitely made a discovery,'' said Paul Langacker, chairman of the department of physics and astronomy at the University of Pennsylvania. He said he has never seen physicists so excited about a discovery in his 20-year career. ``Everybody just senses that this is a winner and that it's right,'' he said. But Arthur McDonald, who is professor of physics at Queen's University in Kingston, Ontario and heads another team conducting similar research, cautioned that it will take time to verify the Japanese results. Neutrinos are one of nature's basic building blocks but they are very tricky to track. They have no charge and are so small that they pass right through matter. The Kamiokande group, which includes researchers from Japan, the United States, Germany and Poland, used a 50,000-ton tank filled with purified water to catch a glimpse of some of the trillions of particles that pass through the earth every second. Collisions between neutrinos and atoms in the tank create a spark detected by equipment surrounding the tank. The equipment was buried in a kilometer (half-mile) of rock to block cosmic rays and radiation. Though the scientists have not measured neutrino mass, they say they detected that some neutrinos oscillate, or change type, as they pass through space or matter. A widely accepted theory says anything that oscillates must have mass. ``We are very confident that this proves it,'' said Chang Kee Jung, member of the project team and a professor of Physics and Astronomy from the State University of New York at Stony Brook. Physics' ``standard model'' theory of how fundamental particles work decrees that neutrinos should weigh nothing at all. But if the findings presented Friday can be repeated independently, researchers say they'll have firm evidence the theory needs to be reconsidered. ``This is definitely something new beyond our standard theory,'' said the University of Pennsylvania's Langacker. Langacker said he believes the finding will eventually give more credence to the unified theory. The unified theory is an effort to combine in one set of mathematical equations all of the fundamental forces in nature: gravity; electromagnetic energy, such as light; and the interactions between subatomic particles. The concept was first proposed by Albert Einstein. The search for a unified theory has failed so far because of uncertainties _ such as the mass of neutrinos. Neutrino mass could help explain why astonomers can't find 90 percent of the matter that's supposed to exist in the universe. Given the speed at which the universe is expanding, physicists think the universe should be of a certain mass. But when they add up the weight of the planets, stars and all other known stuff in the cosmos they get a number only 10 percent as large as their theory predicts. That inconsistency has lead many to conclude either that much more of the universe is hidden in mysterious dark spots or that the theory is seriously flawed. The mass of an individual neutrino is perhaps billions of times less than an electron, the particle with the smallest known mass. But together all the neutrinos could account for a big part the universe's mysteriously missing mass. If the universe has enough mass, it must contract at some point because of the pull of its own gravity. (tz-et)

Dollar climbs above 139 yen on rumors, stocks finish lower
Eds: UPDATES with closing Nikkei, mid-afternoon dollar and bond prices
TOKYO (AP) _ The U.S. dollar climbed back above 139.00 yen Friday, bought on a series of unfounded rumors about crises in the Japanese political and financial world. Tokyo stocks finished the day's trading lower. The dollar bought 139.24 yen, up 1.08 yen from late Thursday in Tokyo and also above its late New York level of 138.27 yen overnight. The dollar held firm throughout the day through cross trading, in which foreign and Japanese institutional investors bought the German mark against the yen, after fresh data showed robust German economic performance in the first quarter. But traders said the dollar's advance was accelerated when several groundless rumors circulated in Tokyo around midday, prompting U.S. hedge funds and Japanese trust funds to buy the U.S. currency. One of the rumors was that Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto may resign on charges of receiving illegal political donations when he was finance minister, and another that a Japanese long-term credit bank might go bankrupt. ``The rumors seem totally unfounded, but nonetheless provided another reason for players to close dollar-short positions,'' said Yukihiko Hashimoto, a senior trader at Sanwa Bank. Earlier in the morning, Finance Minister Hikaru Matsunaga said finance authorities will carefully watch the dollar-yen rate, and if necessary may make the yen's weakness a topic of discussion at the G-7 meeting. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, pessimism over Japan's economy continued to weigh on sentiment, traders said, in continued light activity. The benchmark 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 103.04 points, or 0.67 percent, closing the week at 15,323.43 points. On Thursday, the index had gained 79.47 points, or 0.52 percent. On Thursday, Mitsui Wharf Co., a harbor-transport company, applied to the Yokohama District Court for protection from creditors, increasing pessimism about the health of Japan's companies. The broader Tokyo Stock Price Index of all issues listed on the first section was down 5.56 points, or 0.46 percent, to 1,201.94. The TOPIX closed up 2.17 points, or 0.18 percent, the previous day. Meanwhile, the yield on the benchmark No. 182 10-year Japanese government bond rose to 1.160 percent from Thursday's finish of 1.135 percent, driving its price down to 112.35 yen from 112.54 yen. India studying demands by five nuclear powers
Eds: SUBS 12th graf to CORRECT that club defined by nonproliferation treaty sted UN Security Council. With UN-India-Pakistan By ASHOK SHARMA Associated Press Writer
NEW DELHI, India (AP) _ India on Friday was closely studying demands by the five original nuclear powers that it and Pakistan give up their nuclear ambitions and instead sit down together to resolve issues fueling their rivalry, including the dispute over the border region of Kashmir. India will give its response after ``closely examining'' the Thursday's joint statement by the foreign ministers of Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States, the Press Trust of India news agency quoted foreign ministry spokesman K.C. Singh as saying. Last month India conducted a series of nuclear tests, citing its fear of Pakistan and China. Pakistan responded with its own tests, setting off fears the long-standing South Asian rivalry could culminate with nuclear war. Meeting Thursday in Geneva, the foreign ministers of the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council offered to help India and Pakistan resolve their differences, especially their competing claims to the Himalayan territory of Kashmir. But the main responsibility for making peace is theirs, said Tang Jiaxuan of China, who chaired the meeting. New Delhi has in the past rejected any outside pressure to settle the Kashmir dispute, the flash point of two of India's three wars with Pakistan in the past 50 years. Pakistan, though, has pressed for it to be taken up in international fora, believing it is at a disadvantage in one-on-one talks with its larger and more powerful neighbor. Indian Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee told Parliament on Thursday that his government was prepared to discuss the contentious issue bilaterally with Pakistan. The Geneva statement also asked India and Pakistan to sign the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty without conditions. Soon after conducting its tests, India said it planned no more but wouldn't sign the treaty in its present form because it allows Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States to keep their nuclear arsenals. Pakistan, which responded with nuclear tests of its own, says it will sign the CTBT only if India adhered to it. Though India and Pakistan now claim to be capable of building nuclear bombs, the five nations who were the first to perfect weapons of mass destruction refused to welcome any new members into their club of nuclear powers, as defined by the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. Israeli doctors petition Supreme Court to deem tobacco ``dangerous
drug''
JERUSALEM (AP) _ Nicotine and tobacco should be declared and treated as a ``dangerous drugs,'' Israeli doctors and citizens allegedly sickened or killed by cigarettes said in a petition filed to the Supreme Court. ``We are saying that nicotine and tobacco are dangerous drugs no less addictive than heroine or cocaine,'' said Shlomo Erdman, the lawyer who filed the petition Thursday on behalf of the Israeli Medical Association, citing a similar 1988 declaration by the U.S. Surgeon General. In the petition, the Israeli Medical Association has asked the judges to instruct the Health Ministry to clamp down restrictions on the production and marketing of cigarettes and other tobacco products as they would on any other health threatening substance. The IMA has been forced to turn to the courts for a ruling on the matter in light of strong resistance it has encountered by the powerful tobacco lobby in Israel's legislature, Erdman said. ``Because of the economic interests posed by the tobacco companies we see the Knesset is not dealing with the issue so we are turning to the court to force the Health Ministry to take action,'' said Erdman. Also targeted in the petition is the Israeli cigarette manufacturer Dubek as well as overseas cigarette manufacturers and importers. The IMA seeks limit the importation and distribution of cigarettes as a dangerous substance in an attempt to reduce smoking among Israelis overall. According to the IMA some 5,000 Israelis die every year from smoking related illnesses and the habit costs the economy over 500 million dollars a year in lost work days and damage caused by fires started by cigarettes. Twenty-eight percent of Israel's 5.6 million citizens smoke. A spokesman for the the Health Ministry said the petition was under review and no comment was available.

BC-Indonesia-Chinese
Long ostracized, Indonesian Chinese found political party
With Indonesia-US AP Photo JAK103-104 By CHRISTOPHER TORCHIA Associated Press Writer
JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ Emboldened by the new openness sweeping Indonesia, a group of ethnic Chinese launched a political party Friday to battle the ostracism they have suffered for decades. The Chinese minority has long been a scapegoat in Indonesia, largely because it dominates the economy. Last month, rioters angry over price increases burned and looted hundreds of Chinese shops in Jakarta, the capital, and other big cities. But with Indonesia's new government pledging democratic reform, a small coalition of Chinese entrepreneurs said that now was the time to carve out a political niche. Chinese make up only 4 percent of Indonesia's 202 million people. ``All of us have to rise, to defend our rights,'' said Ponijan Liaw, a language school director and a founder of the Indonesian Chinese Reform Party. At a news conference, organizers said they planned to back their own candidates in general elections which new President B.J. Habibie has said he will stage next year. It was a startling turnabout from Chinese who kept a low profile under former authoritarian leader Suharto, ousted last month amid riots and student protests that were fueled by Indonesia's worst economic crisis in decades. Many other political parties are springing up in the new climate of freedom. Anxious to avoid ethnic conflict, Suharto suppressed the Chinese minority's culture, banning Chinese New Year celebrations and newspapers and closing down their schools in the 1960s. At the same time, the president crafted close ties with wealthy Chinese tycoons, helping his children build business empires which now face corruption allegations. ``Not all of us are economic animals,'' Liaw said. ``Just because of a few conglomerates which colluded with the government, we get the blame as scapegoats.'' The new party wants to promote harmony between Chinese and indigenous Indonesians, and although anybody can join, its ethnic exclusivity may hinder the task. The party ideology is based on Pancasila, the national philosophy enshrined in the 1945 constitution, which mandates a belief in God and respect for democracy and social justice. A Chinese political party existed early this century under Dutch colonial rule, but political participation faded after Suharto, a former army general, rose to power. ``We realize we're a minority, but it's better to do something than nothing,'' said Julianus Juta, a computer scientist and co-founder of the new Chinese party. ``We just want the goverment to treat us fairly.''

BC-SKorea-Crisis Probe
Korean prosecutors indict two former top officials
SEOUL, South Korea (AP) _ Prosecutors indicted two top economic advisers to former President Kim Young-sam on Friday for allegedly lying to cover up their mishandling of South Korea's economy. Former Finance Minister Kang Kyong-shik and former presidential economic secretary Kim In-ho were arrested and jailed in mid-May pending trial. Wrapping up a two-month investigation, prosecutors said Friday they have found enough evidence to charge that the two lied to the ex-president about the severity of the nation's financial problems. Their indictment was expected to be followed later this year by a separate parliamentary probe into the origins of the collapse of what had been the world's 11th-largest economy. The two denied the charges of negligence, arguing that they kept their boss properly informed and a policy failure or misjudgment cannot be subject to criminal punishment. Charges against the two ex-presidential aides also included influence-peddling in connection with millions of dollars in preferential bank loans extended to three insolvent companies last year. If found guilty, they could face a prison term of up to three years. Both were fired two days before South Korea was forced to accept a dlrs 58 billion bailout fund from the International Monetary Fund late last year. Prosecutors said that inefficiency and negligence of duty by officials had worsened the crisis. They said former President Kim was kept in the dark about the full scale of the financial crisis and was warned of its severity by sources outside his presidential Blue House. The new government of President Kim Dae-jung, inaugurated in February, openly held the two former aides responsible for the economic collapse. Thousands of South Korean companies have collapsed since then, driving more than 1.5 million people out of their jobs.

The APEC telecommunications and information ministers released a declaration specifying dates for 16 of the 18 member nations to put the agreement into effect. Chile and New Zealand indicated that their regulations for telecommunications equipment are simple enough that they do not need to change them. Testing and certification are expensive procedures for exporters, importers and regulators, and those costs are often passed to buyers and users. Simplified procedures reduce costs. ``At the same time, regulators need to have confidence in the quality of testing that provides the basis for certification of equipment,'' the U.S. Trade Representative said. The Mutual Recognition Arrangement sets up a framework for that confidence to be given, and provides remedies for when something goes wrong. The arrangement covers all equipment subject to telecommunication regulations, including wireline and wireless, terrestrial and satellite equipment. Telecommunications is one of the nine sectors targeted for early action in the first half of this year. APEC trade ministers will meet in Kuching, Malaysia, on June 22-23 to discuss the remaining eight target sectors: environmental goods and services, medical equipment and instruments, chemicals, energy sector, forest products, fish, gems and jewelry, and toys. APEC comprises Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand and the United States. Candidate members are Russia, Vietnam and Peru.

Yeltsin promises to hold down inflation, but urges Russians to pay
taxes By MAURA REYNOLDS Associated Press Writer
MOSCOW (AP) _ President Boris Yeltsin promised his countrymen Friday that he won't let Russia's financial crisis fuel new inflation, but said they must be prepared to do something in return: pay their taxes. ``The financial crisis threatens to destabilize the Russian ruble,'' Yeltsin warned in his weekly radio address to the nation. ``And that means a return to rising prices and a higher cost of living. That is something we simply can't allow.'' But Yeltsin said that unless Russian businesses and individuals start accepting their responsibility to pay taxes, there could be a return to Soviet-style ration cards and lines in the stores. ``The government exists on the money paid by taxpayers,'' he said. ``And you are right to demand effective work from the executive, legislative and judicial powers.'' ``But the government is right to expect citizens to have a responsible attitude to their obligation to pay taxes voluntarily.'' Russia's financial crisis has eased this week, in part because the government has taken aggressive actions to raise revenue, including a surprise bond offering and issuing extremely short-term treasury bills. In a sign of confidence, the Central Bank lowered two key interest rates late Thursday after hiking them to an unprecedented 150 percent last week. All the same, the new rates of 60 percent are still double what they were before the crisis intensified two weeks ago. And while the stock market has gained this week, it is still down about 50 percent since the beginning of the year. Russia's tax collection troubles are at the heart of the crisis. The country's new tax chief has said that fewer than 3 percent of Russian citizens filed income tax declarations last year, and tax evasion is the norm among Russian businesses. ``The time has come to demand and punish, including filing criminal charges,'' Yeltsin said ominously. ``If we don't collect taxes, we can't pay salaries.'' The government's chronic inability to pay wages to state workers has led to labor protests, including strikes by coal miners last month that shut down parts of the country's rail system. (mr/ren)

BC-Cambodia-Defectors' Ceremony
Khmer Rouge guerrillas mark official return to the fold
AP Photos expected By OU NEAKIRY Associated Press Writer
ANLONG VENG, Cambodia (AP) _ More than 1,000 former Khmer Rouge rebels on Friday changed out of their communist-style olive drab gear and into the uniforms of the Royal Cambodian Armed Forces, marking their official return to the government fold. The ceremony went peacefully, despite what a government officer described as an attempt at disruption by some of the few hardcore guerrillas still holding out along the border with Thailand. Chea Sarun, armed forces chief of operations, said there had been sporadic fighting with seven or eight Khmer Rouge rebels about 15-20 kilometers (9-12 miles) west of the former guerrilla base of Anlong Veng where the reintegration ceremony was held. He said the fighting involved an exchange of automatic weapons fire and the detonation of a land mine, but did not provide further details. The incident did little to dampen hopes that the ceremony may stand as a funeral for the bloody Khmer Rouge movement, shattered by defections and the loss of its last stronghold. The guerrilla group held power from 1975 to 1979, killing as many as two million Cambodians with overwork, illness, starvation and systematic execution during a reign of terror. After years of failed government attempts to defeat the Maoist-inspired rebels directly on the battlefield following their fall from power, the end of resistance at Anlong Veng was triggered by a mutiny in March by disgruntled guerrillas. The defectors, supported by government troops, were able to drive out hard-liners loyal to Ta Mok, the tough and wily successor to the late Pol Pot, their longtime leader. Ta Mok and a handful of loyalists are believed to be hanging on somewhere along the Thai border, though their exact numbers and whereabouts are unknown. Chea Sarun told reporters Friday that he had no idea where Ta Mok was, but he suspected he might be on Thai territory, since he could not be found inside Cambodia. Thailand denies harboring Ta Mok and his forces. More than 1,000 former guerrillas took part in Friday's celebration, discarding their old uniforms as they were inducted into the government armed forces. They were accompanied by 3,000 civilian followers. Chea Sarun said the guerrillas stood in for a total of 3,665 defecting fighters, and that in total, 20,000 people were being officially welcomed back to the government side. The ceremony marked the beginning of three days of celebrating with music and dance, but Anlong Veng is a reminder of the brutality of the Khmer Rouge, who carried out widespread atrocities when they held power. The ceremony included a speech by Yim Phanna, former commander of Khmer Rouge division 980, who led the March mutiny and is thus credited for what many believe will prove to be the final unraveling of the guerrilla movement. He vowed that they be determined not to allow a recurrence of the ``killing fields'' of the Khmer Rouge. He also urged the crowd to follow the ways of the government, obey the rules of the Royal Cambodian Armed Forces, and support the election upcoming in July in order to reduce poverty.

BRISBANE, Australia (AP) _ Former Australian fly-half Michael Lynagh has helped plot England's downfall in Saturday's test as the Wallabies continue their search to properly replace him. Australia will gamble on fullback Stephen Larkham in the fly-half position against a much-maligned and inexperienced English side. Australian coach Rod Macqueen said Lynagh, the Wallaby's last outstanding fly-half who retired in 1995, had warned his team about complacency against an English side missing several regulars and featuring five new caps. Lynagh made a timely return home after two years with the Saracens club in London and he has been on vacation just a short drive up the highway from the Wallaby team's base at Caloundra. He was grilled about the side of virtual unknowns while Wallaby coach Rod Macqueen sifted through various videos trying to get a handle on the young Englishmen. ``The main difficulty is the unknown,'' Macqueen said Friday. ``Normally you've got a known combination where you can plan and prepare. The reality is that we haven't been able to do that. ``The people who do know about these players, like Lynagh, are the people who are putting out the warning bells.'' Of particular interest was Lynagh's young Saracens teammate Ben Sturnham, a big flanker who has the speed of a winger and regularly joins the backline. Sturnham is one of the new caps along with flanker Pat Sanderson, scrum half Scott Benton, winger Spencer Brown and center Steve Ravenscroft. Both teams are gambling at fly-half, with England's Jonny Wilkinson given the role despite just four minutes of test rugby. ``Larkham is new in that position so that's an unanswered question,'' Macqueen said. ``I don't think short term it's as big a punt as some of the younger players we could have put in there. One of those questioned, Zhou Jianhe, was last seen being taken from his home by police at 8 p.m. and is presumed to still be in custody, the group said. In spite of the warning, Yao later met with six others to share memories of the protest movement. The military assault ended six weeks of demonstrations and killed hundreds if not thousands of people. Thousands more were arrested across China in the crackdown. The Communist Party has never provided a full accounting of the assault nor divulged the death toll. Party leaders have feared ever since that the anniversary will be used to rally opposition. Police rounded up about two dozen dissidents nationwide this year to prevent commemorations. One Beijing dissident, Xu Wenli, was detained on his way to visit his sister in southeastern Shenzhen city, next to Hong Kong, the Information Center said. Police held him at a hotel in Guangdong province for several days and sent him back to Beijing on Thursday. In eastern Zhejiang province, some one painted ``Don't Forget the '89 Democracy Movement'' and ``Redress June 4'' in meter- (three-foot-) tall red characters across a bridge in Anji county, the group said. It said about 100 police were seen scouring the bridge, and passersby were ordered not to read the slogans.

BC-APEC-Communications, 1st Ld-Writethru
APEC adopts mutual recognition for telecoms equipment
URGENT Eds: COMBINES urgent series; ADDS details; DELETES 2nd graf reference to APEC's claim of an industry first; INSERTS new 3rd graf with U.S.-EU agreement in May. By LAURINDA KEYS Associated Press Writer
SINGAPORE (AP) _ Pacific Rim nations on Friday agreed to trim the testing requirements for imported telecom equipment in a pact aimed at cutting costs and bringing new products to the market more quickly. The Mutual Recognition Arrangement, adopted by government ministers of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, is part of a program aimed at eliminating tariffs on all information technology products by 2000. A similar agreement between the United States and the European Union was signed May 18. The APEC agreement allows already tested and certified products to be exported without requirements for retesting in the import country and will speed up marketing of technologies and products that are rapidly updated. The agreement ``will boost trade in telecommunications and information equipment goods among members of APEC, affecting roughly dlrs 45 billion in current trade flows, or one-third of the global market,'' the U.S. Trade Representative office said in a statement from Washington, D.C. The arrangement sets up a framework for manufacturers and exporters to test according to the standards of the importing country, and provides remedies for when something goes wrong. The arrangement covers all equipment subject to telecommunication regulations, including wireline and wireless, terrestrial and satellite equipment. The APEC telecommunications and information ministers released a declaration specifying dates for 16 of the 18 member nations to put the agreement into effect. Chile and New Zealand indicated they would not put the agreement into effect because their regulations are already simple enough for imports. Usually, testing and certification are expensive procedures for exporters, importers and regulators, and those costs are often passed to buyers and users. Simplified procedures reduce costs. ``At the same time, regulators need to have confidence in the quality of testing that provides the basis for certification of equipment,'' the U.S. Trade Representative said. The agreement is part of a voluntary liberalization process that APEC leaders launched last November in Vancouver. Telecommunications is one of the nine sectors targeted for early action in the first half of this year. APEC trade ministers will meet in Kuching, Malaysia, on June 22-23 to discuss the remaining eight target sectors: environmental goods and services, medical equipment and instruments, chemicals, energy sector, forest products, fish, gems and jewelry, and toys. APEC comprises Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand and the United States. Candidate members are Russia, Vietnam and Peru.

Air France strike into fifth day, labor unrest spreads
Eds: UPATES with talks ending, new talks planned Friday evening. AP Photos Planned By IAN PHILLIPS Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ With the World Cup approaching, Air France officials and pilots worked early Friday to end a strike that has threatened to disrupt the global soccer tournament. The third round of talks between Air France and pilots' unions began at the company's Paris headquarters about 7 p.m. Thursday and ended at 4:30 a.m. (0230 GMT). There were no signs of an immediate breakthrough as the strike entered its fifth day Friday. After the talks, Rene Philippeau, a pilot's spokesman, said the proposals made by Air France were ``much too vague'' and thus ``unacceptable.'' Air France spokesman Francois Brousse, speaking to reporters after Thursday's meeting began, said there were ``constructive foundations'' for an agreement to prosper. The pilots are prepared to strike for at least 15 days, coinciding with the start of the June 10-July 12 soccer championship which will attract an estimated 1 million visitors. Despite the strike, Air France, the World Cup's official carrier, has guaranteed transport for the 32 teams taking part. With just six days until the World Cup begins, France is plagued by labor disputes. Rail workers were set to begin a strike Friday which was to last through the weekend, seriously hampering rail travel through France. Paris subway drivers and railway workers in southern France staged minor strikes Thursday, heaping further misery on visitors already in France for the World Cup, as well as other tourists. Baggage handlers have been on strike for three days at Charles de Gaulle airport in Paris, and airline mechanics also planned a walkout. The transport woes were causing embarrassment and anger among French officials who feared for the country's image. Michel Charasse, a Socialist senator, accused the pilots of being ``egotistical, and not loving their country'' in an interview with Europe 1 radio. Leading conservative lawmaker Philippe Seguin said the strike risked making France ``the laughing stock of the entire world.'' The highly paid pilots are protesting planned salary cuts. The company wants to give them stock in exchange for 500 million francs (dlrs 83 million) in pay cuts. The strike posed a big test for the Socialist-government of Lionel Jospin. But the government was standing firm. The airline ``has the full support of the government,'' the Socialist Finance Minister, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, told the National Assembly. The company said it planned 17 percent of its long-distance flights Friday, 30 percent of its short and medium-distance routes from Charles de Gaulle Airport and 40 percent from Orly. (dgs)
