BC-India-Nuclear, 2nd Ld-Writethru,0621
India studying demands by five nuclear powers
Eds: ADDS Pakistani comment in new grafs 7-8. With UN-India-Pakistan By ASHOK SHARMA Associated Press Writer
NEW DELHI, India (AP) _ India on Friday was closely studying demands by the five original nuclear powers that it and Pakistan give up their nuclear ambitions and instead sit down together to resolve issues fueling their rivalry, including the dispute over the border region of Kashmir. India will give its response after ``closely examining'' the Thursday's joint statement by the foreign ministers of Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States, the Press Trust of India news agency quoted foreign ministry spokesman K.C. Singh as saying. Last month India conducted a series of nuclear tests, citing its fear of Pakistan and China. Pakistan responded with its own tests, setting off fears the long-standing South Asian rivalry could culminate with nuclear war. Meeting Thursday in Geneva, the foreign ministers of the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council offered to help India and Pakistan resolve their differences, especially their competing claims to the Himalayan territory of Kashmir. But the main responsibility for making peace is theirs, said Tang Jiaxuan of China, who chaired the meeting. New Delhi has in the past rejected any outside pressure to settle the Kashmir dispute, the flash point of two of India's three wars with Pakistan in the past 50 years. Pakistan, though, has pressed for it to be taken up in international fora, believing it is at a disadvantage in one-on-one talks with its larger and more powerful neighbor. In Geneva, the local government of Pakistan-held Kashmir welcomed the mention of Kashmir by the five foreign secretaries, saying in a resolution that ``without a permanent solution of the Kashmir issue peace in the region cannot be guaranteed.'' Pakistan's national government did not immediately react to the Geneva deliberations. Indian Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee told Parliament on Thursday that his government was prepared to discuss Kashmir bilaterally with Pakistan. The Geneva statement also asked India and Pakistan to sign the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty without conditions. Soon after conducting its tests, India said it planned no more but wouldn't sign the treaty in its present form because it allows Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States to keep their nuclear arsenals. Pakistan, which responded with nuclear tests of its own, says it will sign the CTBT only if India adhered to it. Though India and Pakistan now claim to be capable of building nuclear bombs, the five nations who were the first to perfect weapons of mass destruction refused to welcome any new members into their club of nuclear powers, as defined by the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright told reporters they could not let any other nation on the nuclear threshold believe it ``can test its way in.'' Pakistan and India, Albright and the other ministers said, should refrain from any more tests, from building or deploying nuclear weapons, or from testing missiles to carry nuclear bombs. Many fear the next stage of the costly, potentially catastrophic South Asian nuclear arms race will be developing delivery systems. The ministers did not threaten sanctions, which the United States has been alone among the five in imposing. Sanctions only hurt the people and neighboring countries and ``have little effect on leaders who often act in isolation and sometimes unpredictably,'' said Russia's Yevgeny Primakov.

BC-UN-India-Pakistan, 1st Ld-Writethru,0529
Few incentives, no sanctions as nuclear club keeps out India,
Pakistan Eds: RECASTS and UPDATES with comments from India and Pakistan AP Photo NY108 By GEIR MOULSON Associated Press Writer
GENEVA (AP) _ Foreign ministers of the world's five major nuclear powers are urging India and Pakistan to meet at the bargaining table and refrain from intensifying their dangerous nuclear arms race. ``We have no illusions,'' Secretary of State Madeleine Albright told reporters after an emergency meeting Thursday with her counterparts from Britain, China, France and Russia. ``But the process has begun.'' A joint statement demanded the South Asian neighbors refrain from further nuclear tests and resolve their differences with direct talks. India, followed by Pakistan, set off a series of nuclear tests last month, escalating tensions on the subcontinent. Albright said such testing left the people of India and Pakistan less secure and cost both nations respect around the world. ``They might not have expected this kind of very widespread condemnation of what they have done,'' she said. The ministers said the two nations also didn't make it into the so-called ``nuclear club,'' which is restricted to the five nations by the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty signed by 186 nations, not including India or Pakistan. To allow them into the club would, in effect, reward them for testing nuclear weapons and encourage other nations to defy global arms reduction efforts, the ministers said. ``India and Pakistan do not have the status of nuclear weapons states,'' the statement said. The ministers called for direct negotiations between India and Pakistan on such issues as the hotly disputed northern territory of Kashmir. The countries have fought two wars over Kashmir. Chinese Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan said India and Pakistan must take the lead in solving their own differences. In a pointed reference to India's role in setting off the exchange of nuclear tests, Tang said, ``It is up to the one who tied the knot to untie it.'' The communique threatened no new sanctions but urged the two nations to sign the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty and to refrain from exporting nuclear weapons and missile technology or expanding their own nuclear arsenals. ``We are prepared to help India and Pakistan maintain peace if they are prepared to do the right thing,'' said Albright. The ministers didn't discuss sanctions, which the United States has been alone in imposing. U.S. officials said Albright wanted to make sure Russia's traditional lean toward India and China's support for Pakistan did not prevent the five powers from producing a strong joint statement. The statement, hammered out Wednesday night by experts from the five countries, was approved ``without change or controversy'' by the ministers, according to British Foreign Secretary Robin Cook. India will respond after ``closely examining'' the statement, Press Trust of India quoted foreign ministry spokesman K.C. Singh as saying. Pakistan had no immediate comment.

PHNOM PENH, Cambodia (AP) _ A top United Nations human rights envoy said Friday that leaders of the Khmer Rouge guerrilla movement could be tried by an international tribunal as early as next year for crimes against humanity. Thomas Hammarberg, a special representative of the U.N. secretary general, said at a press conference that the momentum for an international trial has picked up pace and he is increasingly ``optimistic about the possibilities.'' ``If there is political will (in Cambodia), it could happen within the next year,'' Hammarberg said, adding that there appears to be a consensus across Cambodia's political spectrum that an internationally-assisted trial should take place. As many as 2 million Cambodians were killed during the guerrilla group's 1975-79 regime through overwork, illness, disease and execution. The longtime leader of the group, Pol Pot, died of a reported heart attack in April but an estimated 20 influential Khmer Rouge leaders who scholars and legal experts believe should be tried are still at large. The findings could be raised before the U.N. General Assembly this December, Hammarberg said, adding, that it is crucial that Cambodia make clear that they want to see the Khmer Rouge leaders tried. ``Political unity internationally will be very weak if there are any question marks here,'' he said. Hammarberg said that if the Cambodian parliament adopts a legal act calling for the trial of the top Khmer Rouge leaders, and accepts an invitation by the U.N. to provide the judges and prosecution, ``the Security Council will not be able to block'' the proceedings. Fears have previously been expressed that China, a permanent member of the Security Council with veto power, would stand in the way of the U.N.'s efforts to try Khmer Rouge leaders. It has in the past said it would protest such a tribunal as interference in Cambodia's internal affairs. Hammarberg said that he thought, if possible, Cambodia should be the venue for the trial. ``I don't think it is appropriate to come and hijack (suspected war criminals) and put them in a Dutch prison,'' Hammarberg said, adding that the process of trying genocide suspects could serve as a healing process for survivors. ``I think participation here is important.'' Ironically, as Hammarberg spoke at the Royal Phnom Penh hotel, Ieng Sary, who was deputy prime minister during the Khmer Rouge's 1975-79 regime, was strolling the hotel's hallways. Ieng Sary defected to the government in 1996 with some 10,000 war-weary guerrillas. In exchange, he received a royal pardon for a 1979 death sentence handed down in absentia by a Phnom Penh court. That pardon does not, however, protect him from prosecution before an international tribunal. Until trials are held, said Hammarberg, ``possible suspects will walk around free, and we just have to live with that.'' Asked what it was like eating breakfast a few tables down from Ieng Sary, one of the people experts agree should stand trial, he smiled, and said, ``I wondered if that could happen in any country other than this one.''

Aid workers to begin counting Afghan survivors
AP Photos FBD101-102 By JUDITH INGRAM Associated Press Writer
FAISABAD, Afghanistan (AP) _ With thousands of people still going hungry, relief efforts were again delayed by rain Friday, but officials said that once the clouds lift food will begin flowing faster to earthquake-ravaged villages in the mountains of northern Afghanistan. The region still rumbled daily with aftershocks of the horrific quake that struck six days ago _ the second in four months in this forlorn and undeveloped region. Local officials estimate the death toll at 4,700 people. International aid agencies have still not reached dozens of damaged and isolated villages. The relief effort received a major boost Thursday when aircraft fuel was flown into the regional center of Faisabad. The fuel was caught in a standoff with customs authorities in Tajikistan that delayed the stationing of fuel barrels here by at least a day. But the fuel arrived Thursday evening, too late to stop the four small helicopters on relief patrols from returning to Tajikistan to refuel. On Friday, a rainstorm kept them grounded there and once again paralyzed the operation. A U.S. promise to lease two big Russian helicopters brought cheer to relief workers. The planes, operated by a private company in Russia, will have 10 times the capacity of the aged fleet of four choppers that the United Nations and the Red Cross scraped together. Once the flow of food resumes, aid workers hope to begin reaching outlying areas of the 1,750-square-kilometer (700-square-mile) quake zone to begin counting survivors and assessing needs. In the 15-minute stops to unload food packages, aid workers have not had time to take an accurate reading of the death toll, concentrating instead on the needs of the living and the evacuation of injured. So far, 91 severely injured people were flown out on the tiny helicopters to local clinics or to the two-story hospital in Faisabad, which is struggling with shortages of medicine and food. Patients have beds, but the wards and corridors are crammed with relatives. In their brief stops, aid workers have found many injured people who have not come forward for help or treatment, said Red Cross official Juan Martinez. In one village, one team found a woman with severe bruises over half her face. But she did not want to be touched by a male doctor, he said.

Eds: UPDATES with with quotes from Al Fayed spokesman in 19-20th grafs, eight witnesses appearing in 14th graf AP Photos Planned By JOCELYN NOVECK Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ A simple, tragic car accident, caused by a drunk driver. Is that the whole answer? That's what Judge Herve Stephan wants to find out Friday from the key witnesses in the Princess Diana case: the photographers under investigation, their lawyers, and Mohamed Al Fayed. Stephan summoned the parties for a closed-door hearing to try to clarify the main question in the case: Who was at fault? The crash in a Paris traffic tunnel Aug. 31 killed Diana, her boyfriend Dodi Fayed, and driver Henri Paul. Tests showed Paul was drunk at the time. But what was the responsibility of the paparazzi trailing Diana's Mercedes that night? Nine photographers and a press motorcyclist have been placed under formal investigation _ one step short of being charged _ for both manslaughter and failing to come to the aid of a person in danger. The hearing which brings together nearly all of the major figures in the case was likely to stand as an important step. Even Diana's mother, Frances Shand Kydd, showed up for the hearing. Al Fayed drew up to the main courthouse in a Mercedes, surrounded by four other cars and about 10 body guards. ``I hope that God will find the truth for us,'' Al Fayed said as he left the Ritz Hotel for the courthouse. Nikolas Arsov, of the Sipa photo agency, said he felt annoyed. ``It's the 40th time we have answered the same questions,'' said Arsov. ``It's annoying, but what can you do? They have to do their job.'' Arsov was supposed to be shooting pictures Friday at the French Open tennis tournament. Police with two lists, one bearing the names of the photographers, the other 10 witnesses, checked off the arrivals. Eight of the witnesses showed up. In contrast to previous hearings, television cameras were kept outside the grounds of the Palais de Justice surrounded by police. Those close to the case believe the photographers will soon be exonerated _ at least on the manslaughter charge. Al Fayed, the father of Dodi Fayed, has filed as a civil party in the case, and therefore has access to documents and proceedings. It isn't just his son's death that connects Al Fayed to the case. Driver Paul was an employee of the Ritz Hotel, which Al Fayed owns. ``This is a process to decide if the paparazzi should go to trial,'' said Al Fayed spokesman Lawrie Meyer at the Palais de Justice on Friday. Mr. Al Fayed ``is still a grieving parent and is here to find out what happened to his son,'' said Meyer. In a statement issued by Meyer in London on Thursday, Al Fayed said he was ``determined to get to the truth'' about whether the crash was an accident or a plot to kill Diana and his son. But French judicial sources said recently Al Fayed has backed off his contention that the crash stemmed from a plot, and now thinks the paparazzi are to blame. Although the probe is not complete, investigators long have believed it was Paul's drunken condition and the Mercedes' excessive speed that probably caused the crash. They also are still looking for a white Fiat Uno believed to have brushed the Mercedes before it crashed. But they are said to have given up any real hope of finding the Fiat. Tests are still being conducted on the wrecked Mercedes Diana was traveling in, but aren't likely to be finished before October _ meaning the case can't be closed until then. Investigators also recently conducted road tests on a race track near Paris to reconstruct the crash. Police revealed no details of those tests. One person who wasn't attending Friday's session: bodyguard Trevor Rees-Jones, the sole survivor of the crash. He was invited on an ``informational basis,'' but decided not to come. (jn-dgs)

Now more than 870,000 English-born people live in Australia _ almost as many as the next five biggest migrant groups combined _ New Zealanders, Italians, Vietnamese, Scots and Greeks. But unlike many other new settlers, the English had no organization to represent them. Until now. On Monday, the Queen's birthday holiday, The English in Australia _ TEA _ organization will be launched at an afternoon tea party complete with scones, jam, cream and cucumber sandwiches. TEA is the brainchild of Claire Haines, 30, who left Devon seven years ago with a one-way plane ticket, 50 British Pounds and a backpack. After half a dozen trips home she eventually settled in Canberra with her English husband and infant daughter. ``So many immigrant groups openly celebrate their cultural heritage, yet the English disappear into the wallpaper,'' she said Friday. ``We don't get together, we don't do anything.'' Since writing to newspapers and airing her views on radio, Haines said she has been inundated with calls of support from throughout Australia. ``There are so many of us we could become a powerful lobby group,'' Haines said. ``We could probably change the result of elections.'' But TEA is non-political, Haines said. It will be a non-profit group that encourages social networks around the country, helps new migrants and organizes cultural events. Launches in other capitals will include lunches with roast beef and Yorkshire pudding. Academics will give talks on Jane Austen and Shakespeare. In Berrima, on New South Wales state's south coast, a festival with double-decker buses, London cabs and a speaker's corner is planned. Also in the pipeline are Wimbledon parties and FA Cup Final nights. ``We feel that embracing multiculturalism should mean accepting and respecting that English migrants also have a distinct set of beliefs and cultural practices to celebrate,'' Haines said.

LONDON (AP) _ Dogged by Scottish nationalists and antinuclear campaigners, Britain's Labor Party government announced Friday it will shut a nuclear processing plant which just months ago accepted spent nuclear fuel from Georgia, a restive Soviet republic. In a surprise announcement, the government said the Dounreay plant on the coast of northern Scotland will accept no more foreign nuclear material, and the facility with 1,300 people will be rundown over several decades that it will take to process material already there. ``There is no economic case for supporting commercial reprocessing over the longer term,'' Energy Minister John Battle said in a statement. Dounreay, which opened in 1957 and produced electricity for 30 years, will complete the reprocessing of its own material, including nuclear waste from its reactors, the Georgia material, and existing commercial contracts. The independence-seeking Scottish National Party, running neck-and-neck with Labor in opinion polls in Scotland, claimed victory. ``We have objected to any idea that this plant was fit enough to deal with its own waste far less taking on anyone else's,'' said Winifred Ewing , a Scottish nationalist lawmaker whose Highlands and Islands constituency includes sparsely populated Caithness where Dounreay is located. The shipment of the Georgia material in April _ 4.3 kilograms (9.46 pounds) of highly enriched uranium and 0.8 kilograms (1.76 pounds) of spent nuclear fuel _ caused a particular stir, partly because the story broke in the United States. Prime Minister Tony Blair said Britain was helping to prevent the threat of nuclear proliferation by taking material that might wind-up with terrorists or would-be nuclear powers, and argued that the United States and Russia have accepted far more. Two days ago, Blair accused the Scottish nationalists of being ``irresponsible and extreme'' during another flap over reports that enough uranium to make a half-dozen nuclear warheads was missing from Dounreay. The United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority, which runs the plant, confirmed that an internal inquiry listed 170 kilograms (374 pounds) of uranium as missing from work in the mid-60s, but said it was a paper technicality _ the amount of material that went into the plant was overestimated by one percent. SNP leader Alex Salmond taunted the government with making a ``huge turnaround.'' ``Anyone with an interest in these matters has known for some considerable time that Dounreay is not in a condition where it is safe to take any extra nuclear material to it,'' said Salmond. In the 13 months since Labor won a landslide victory over the previous Conservative Party government, the party's popularity has eroded in its Scottish strongholds, largely because of disappointment with Blair's centrist policies. The SNP has been the chief beneficiary of disgruntled left-wing Laborites. (mj)

TOKYO (AP) _ A slew of unfounded rumors about political and financial crises in Japan pushed the U.S. dollar back above 139.00 yen on Friday. Tokyo stocks prices fell in continued light trading. The dollar bought 139.42 yen in late afternoon, up 1.26 yen from late Thursday in Tokyo and also above its late New York level of 138.27 yen overnight. It ranged between 138.38 yen and 139.50 yen in Friday's trading. The dollar initially gained ground through cross trading, in which foreign and Japanese institutional investors bought the German mark against the yen, after new data showed robust German economic performance in the first quarter. But traders said the dollar's rise was accelerated when several groundless rumors circulated in Tokyo around midday, prompting U.S. hedge funds and Japanese trust funds to buy dollars. Among the rumors were that Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto may resign on charges of receiving illegal political donations when he was finance minister, and another that a Japanese long-term credit bank may go under. ``The rumors seem totally unfounded, but nonetheless provided another reason for players to close dollar-short positions,'' said Yukihiko Hashimoto, a senior trader at Sanwa Bank. Earlier in the morning, Finance Minister Hikaru Matsunaga said finance authorities will carefully watch the dollar-yen rate, and if necessary may make the yen's weakness a topic of discussion at a meeting of the G-7 meeting. Fear of Japanese intervention to stem the yen's slide and speculation that deputy finance ministers of the G-7 industrialized nations meeting in Paris next Tuesday will may agree to joint action were holding the dollar below 139.00 yen level until early Friday. Meanwhile, the persistent pessimism over the health of Japan's economy continued to weigh on sentiment on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The benchmark 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 103.04 points, or 0.67 percent, closing the week at 15,323.43 points. On Thursday, the index had gained 79.47 points, or 0.52 percent. In another sign of pessimism over the economy, Mitsui Wharf Co., a harbor-transport company, applied to the Yokohama District Court on Thursday for protection from creditors. Also hurting sentiment was a yen's weakening, which is seen bearish for Japanese stocks as it reduces value of yen-denominated assets against assets in foreign currencies. The broader Tokyo Stock Price Index of all issues listed on the first section was down 5.56 points, or 0.46 percent, to 1,201.94. The TOPIX closed up 2.17 points, or 0.18 percent, the previous day. Meanwhile, the yield on the benchmark No. 182 10-year Japanese government bond rose to 1.165 percent from Thursday's finish of 1.135 percent, driving its price down to 112.31 yen from 112.54 yen. By The Associated Press PUERTO RICO: Dam break in Puerto Rico forces evacuations
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) _ A dam lock at a lake that supplies most of San Juan's drinking water smashed open Thursday, sending powerful torrents of water downstream and forcing hundreds of people to abandon their homes. A steel gate at the 35-year-old Lake Carraizo reservoir broke shortly after noon (16:00 GMT), pouring water into a tributary of the Loiza River. There were no immediate reports of injuries at the dam, in suburban Trujillo Alto. By late Thursday, officials said the danger had passed. More than 2 million gallons of water poured from the break in 3 1/2 hours, Puerto Rico's water authority said. Police and civil defense workers checked homes in low-lying areas of the river basin to urge residents to move to higher ground, said authority spokeswoman Zaima Negron. PUERTO RICO: Independence activist can't renounce U.S. citizenship SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) _ Puerto Rican independence activists can't renounce their U.S. citizenship if they insist on living in Puerto Rico and won't register as aliens, the U.S. State Department has concluded. Since Juan Mari Bras will do neither, Washington won't recognize his 1994 renunciation of citizenship, Katherine H. Peterson, acting deputy assistant secretary of overseas citizens services, told Mari Bras in a letter. The finding, released by Mari Bras on Thursday, is sure to anger a host of Puerto Rican independence activists who have renounced their citizenship, arguing that they are Puerto Rican citizens instead. Their cause was strengthened last year by Puerto Rico's Supreme Court, which ruled that a local citizenship does exist in this U.S. territory and that it entitled Mari Bras to vote in local elections. BAHAMAS: Striking hotel workers flood onto bridge, blocking traffic NASSAU, Bahamas (AP) _ Chanting ``more money,'' hundreds of striking hotel workers flooded onto a bridge linking Nassau to Paradise Island resort area Thursday, backing up traffic for miles (kilometers). Police, some armed with machine guns, tried to persuade the strikers to stop. The protesters finally left the bridge after 90 minutes. About 4,000 workers at five of Nassau's biggest hotels joined a wildcat strike Wednesday to demand higher pay. Wednesday night, the union rejected hotel owners' offer of an 18 percent raise over five years. Workers staged what they called a ``sit-in'' at the 1,250-room Atlantis Resort belonging to Sun International and the Marriott's Crystal Palace resort, both on Paradise Island. By Thursday, many workers at the Sheraton British Colonial, the Nassau Marriott and other hotels on Cable Beach, a Nassau resort district, joined the strike. UNITED STATES: Coast Guard allows Big Red Boat to sail CAPE CANAVERAL, Florida (AP) _ The U.S. Coast Guard gave the green light for the Big Red Boat to sail Thursday, three days after the cruise ship was grounded because it couldn't prove that it met new fire codes. The Coast Guard suspended cruises on Premier Cruise Lines' 32-year-old vessel Monday as it prepared to sail to Nassau and Port Lucaya in the Bahamas. Premier Cruise Lines failed to turn in the proper inspection documents on time, said Marilyn Barnett, a company spokeswoman. Inspectors have since confirmed that the ship meets new fire safety standards. ``It was something that was of great disappointment to our passengers and certainly to ourselves,'' Barnett said. Ramos advances resignation of prosecutor who urged reversal of
Marcos conviction
MANILA, Philippines (AP) _ President Fidel Ramos on Friday ordered the resignation of the government's top prosecutor, who had recommended that a graft conviction of former first lady Imelda Marcos be overturned. Last week, Solicitor General Romeo de la Cruz submitted a courtesy resignation to Ramos effective June 30, the president's last day in office. Such resignations allow new administrations a freer hand in making appointments and are often not accepted. But Ramos approved de la Cruz's resignation on Friday and made it effective next Monday. ``I have exercised my prerogative to make the effective date earlier,'' he said in a letter to de la Cruz. Ramos gave no reason, but there has been widespread criticism of de la Cruz's recommendation to the Supreme Court on Wednesday that it overturn the conviction of Mrs. Marcos, the widow of former dictator Ferdinand Marcos. Mrs. Marcos was convicted of graft in 1993 and sentenced to up to 12 years in prison. De la Cruz said he became convinced after reviewing the case that there was no strong evidence proving Mrs. Marcos was guilty of the charge. President-elect Joseph Estrada has indicated he favors a pardon or dismissal of the case against Mrs. Marcos, and some analysts speculate that de la Cruz's abrupt turnaround was an attempt to stay on as solicitor general in Estrada's administration. The case is the only one in which Mrs. Marcos, 68, has been convicted of graft, although she faces numerous other criminal and civil cases related to the 20-year rule of her husband. She and her husband have been accused of stealing billions of dollars during his presidency. They were ousted in a 1986 ``people power'' revolt and Marcos died three years later in exile in Hawaii. Mrs. Marcos was convicted of having granted leases on government-owned land at improperly low rates to the Philippine General Hospital Foundation, which she headed. The land was then sublet to another company at much higher rates. Mrs. Marcos _ who insists she did not personally benefit from the deal _ said the money gained from the leases helped finance construction of the Philippine Heart Center. Prosecutors did not challenge this, but maintained that the foundation should have been charged more. A five-judge Supreme Court panel upheld her conviction in January, but ruled that she could appeal one more time to the entire court before going to prison. It sentenced her to nine to 12 years in prison and ordered her to pay 189 million pesos (dlrs 4.9 million) in damages to the government. The Supreme Court has up to two years to decide the appeal.

DARWIN, Australia (AP) _ A British university student thought he was being mugged as four rangers grabbed him to stop the tourist falling several hundred yards (meters) to the base Ayers Rock _ and almost certain death. JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ Pressure on President B.J. Habibie to speed up an election timetable mounted on Friday after a presidential adviser quit saying the pace of reform was too slow. Habibie has pledged to push through democratic reforms in the wake of the ouster last month of his mentor, former President Suharto. The new leader inherited a nation wracked by political and economic turmoil after three decades of autocratic rule. Opposition figure Emil Salim, who agreed to guide Habibie on policy decisions from time to time, said he was backing out of an advisory panel because the 61-year-old technocrat was waffling. Bowing to calls for new leadership, Habibie promised to stage general elections as soon as possible. Then he said the poll would take place by the end of 1999 after Parliament overhauls rigid electoral laws from the Suharto era. ``He's taking a very long time,'' Salim said in a speech Friday at Jakarta's Atma Jaya University. He urged Habibie to hold the general elections in December. Indonesians, meanwhile, tested their newfound political freedoms, staging a string of rallies for separate causes. A group of ethnic Chinese launched a political party to battle the ostracism they have suffered for decades. Chinese are resented because they dominate the economy, and rioters burned and looted hundreds of Chinese-owned shops during unrest in Jakarta and other cities last month. Uncertainty about Indonesia's political and economic future lingers, and Salim and others say a new president, untainted by the association with Suharto, is needed. Habibie, a former Cabinet minister, was a close friend and ally of Suharto, who quit amid a swell of protest against his long rule. The fate of Habibie's advisory panel, made up of half a dozen government critics, was in doubt. Prominent opposition leader Amien Rais pulled out of it last month, saying he did not want to be coopted by the government and could work better outside its parameters. In a meeting Thursday with university rectors, Habibie reportedly appealed to them to curb political activity on campuses, which were the focal point of opposition to Suharto. The Jakarta Post on Friday quoted Habibie as saying he would ask education officials ``not to allow campuses to be turned into political arenas.'' In one Jakarta protest Friday, dozens of protesters shook the gates of the U.S. Embassy, accusing Washington of interfering in the internal affairs of their crisis-ridden country. About 30 demonstrators also marched to a toll road in a protest against its owner, Siti Hardiyanti Rukmana, the eldest daughter of Suharto. They urged motorists not to pay the toll, saying Suharto family businesses are corrupt and have sapped the economy of much of its wealth. About 150 people also rallied against Environment Minister Panangian Siregar outside his office, saying he was a lackey of the old government.

BC-Germany-Train Derails, 2nd Ld-Writethru
Dozens of Germany's fast trains idled after crash
Eds: UPDATES with police details on investigation, report of wheel part found near crash, comment from survivor, edits and trims throughout AP Photos ESC101,104,113 By TONY CZUCZKA Associated Press Writer
ESCHEDE, Germany (AP) _ Dozens of Germany's fastest trains were idled Friday for inspections after investigators pointed to a wheel failure as a possible cause of the country's worst rail accident in more than 50 years. The confirmed _ possibly final _ death toll rose to 95 after rescue crews recovered two bodies early Friday from the last major part of wreckage to be excavated, a dining car that was buried when an overpass collapsed during Wednesday's pileup. ``It would appear that the restaurant car was closed for some reason, otherwise there would have been more people in it,'' Eschede police spokesman Joachim Haack told reporters Friday. Police spokesman Peter Hoppe said rescuers did not expect to find more bodies. Ninety-two were recovered at the scene, and three people died in hospitals. A special commission of police, rail and other experts, supervised by prosecutors, were working to identify the cause of the disaster, and investigators were aggressively searching for evidence in an area extending 6 kilometers (3.7 miles) down the line, Haack said. ``I think at this moment we can say it's a mechanical reason,'' Haack said. Horst Stuchly, president of the federal railway office, said Thursday that a break in a wheel was emerging as a possible cause. Attention centered on the steel ``tires'' which are fitted to the wheels, and which must be replaced from time to time. The flanged tire is the part of the wheel which is in direct contact with the rail. The mass-circulation Bild daily quoted Johannes Ludewig, director of the federal railways, as saying that a piece of a wheel was found 6 kms (3.7 miles) from the bridge. Police in Celle said parts from a train were found six kilometers (3.7 miles) from the bridge, but they gave no details. State authorities originally estimated that as many as 100 or more were killed when the Hamburg-bound InterCity Express 884 derailed at 200 kilometers (125 miles) an hour near the small town of Eschede, 50 kilometers (35 miles) north of Hanover. Whatever caused the accident set off a catastrophic chain of events: part of the train knocked down a highway overpass, the collapsing bridge crushed some of the trailing cars, and the rest of the train jackknifed against the concrete. State officials said 200 people were injured, of whom 95 were treated in hospitals. Survivors have told of loud noises or vibrations for a minute or more before the accident. ``Before everything happened, I felt a rumbling and suddenly a horrible cracking. The lights went out and the carriage sprang from the tracks,'' said Angelika Hauser, 32, a pharmacist from Augsburg. Hauser, who was quoted in Bild, suffered a fractured skull and broken back. ``I remember only that people and seats were all over the place,'' an unidentified woman told n-tv television in one of the first interviews with one of the scores of injured survivors evacuated to hospitals in helicopters. Police found nicks in concrete ties and trackside signal equipment which confirms that some part of the train had derailed before reaching the bridge. Five cars got through the overpass, though the back end of the fifth car was torn off. The lead locomotive broke free of its cars and the driver apparently was unaware of any mishap until the station master at Escheden activated an emergency brake. Deutsche Bahn removed all 60 of its first-generation InterCity Express trains, introduced in 1991, from service after they finished their runs Thursday, idling more than half of the nation's fastest trains. Forty-three trains introduced since 1996 remained in service. It was unclear how quickly normal service would resume. ``We are going to do everything possible to make sure that this tragic accident won't happen again,'' rail spokesman Martin Katz said. Earlier, officials lowered the speed limit for all ICE trains from 280 kilometers (175 miles) per hour to 160 kph (100 mph) until the entire fleet could be inspected. BC-World Court-West Africa
U.N. court to rule in Cameroon-Nigeria border dispute
THE HAGUE, Netherlands (AP) _ The World Court said Friday it will rule next week whether it has the authority to decide a bitter territorial dispute between feuding West African neighbors Nigeria and Cameroon. Cameroon has asked the court, the United Nations' highest judicial body, to resolve a quarrel over the oil-rich Bakassi peninsula that once brought the two nations to the brink of war and has led to scattered armed clashes. Cameroon, which took the case to the World Court in early 1996 after a series of bloody skirmishes, has asked the 15-judge panel to order an immediate and unconditional withdrawal of Nigerian troops and has demanded reparations. But Nigeria, a West African political and petroleum giant, contends the countries should settle all boundary disputes themselves. It has challenged the court's authority to get involved, claiming it has no jurisdiction. The court will release its decision on June 11 on whether to proceed further with the merits of the case, and on whether Cameroon's case is admissible. If so, a definitive ruling would not come for several more years. Both nations claim ownership of the peninsula jutting into the Gulf of Guinea where their borders meet. They laid out their preliminary arguments before the court in March. The neighbors almost went to war over Bakassi in 1981, and there have been scattered hostilities ever since. Last month, Nigeria accused Cameroon of trying to enlarge its borders and provoke war by amassing more than 2,000 troops on Bakassi, and by allegedly attacking unarmed villagers in the disputed section of the peninsula. Unconfirmed clashes between Nigerian and Cameroonian soldiers in the region reportedly flared in April, resulting in the deaths of at least 18 people. At least 87 people have been killed in sporadic clashes since 1994, in open defiance of a 1996 World Court order to cease hostilities. The court, formally known as the International Court of Justice, has no enforcement powers and relies on nations to voluntarily comply with its rulings. (bk)

Settlers intensify campaign against West Bank troop pullback
By KARIN LAUB Associated Press Writer
JERUSALEM (AP) _ Senior members of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's Likud Party flew over the West Bank on Friday in planes chartered by Jewish settlers trying to scuttle an Israeli troop pullback in the disputed territory. Settler leaders have intensified their campaign among growing signs that Netanyahu is close to accepting a U.S. plan that would leave 40 percent of the West Bank under full or partial Palestinian control and restrict Jewish settlement expansion. Netanyahu's senior adviser, David Bar-Illan, said the prime minister would present a possible agreement to parliament, even though he is not required to do so. ``Even if there is a risk of coalition problems, if he feels that the package deal is good, he will present it,'' Bar-Illan said. An agreement is likely to pass with the votes of the dovish opposition. However, far-right lawmakers have said that if Netanyahu agrees to a withdrawal, they would try to bring him down at the next opportunity, in this case the next motion of no confidence in the government. The opposition would vote against the government in such a motion, and would be joined by at least 10 legislators from the hawkish Land of Israel Front, enough to deprive Netanyahu's 66-member coalition of a majority in the 120-member parliament. Israeli media speculated Friday that Netanyahu would soon try to form a national unity government in which the opposition Labor Party would serve as a junior partner. Such a coalition would have to be formed immediately after a parliament vote on a troop withdrawal and before the next motion of no confidence. The Jewish settlement movement, however, stepped up efforts to block a withdrawal. On Friday, dozens of members of the Likud Central Committee were flown across the West Bank in planes chartered by settlers trying to persuade them to oppose any pullback as a danger to Israel's security. Maps in hand, they were given explanations by settler guides, said settler spokesman Aharon Domb. Last week, settlers began mailing 1 million brochures containing West Bank maps to Israeli homes in hopes of turning public opinion against a troop pullback. In diplomatic activity, two senior Palestinian negotiators returned Friday from two days of meetings in London with the U.S. envoy, Dennis Ross, and were to brief Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat. Details on London talks were not immediately available. Israel army radio said Ross asked the two Palestinians, Arafat deputy Mahmoud Abbas and Parliament Speaker Ahmed Qureia, to accept some changes in the original U.S. proposal that had been approved by the Palestinians. Abbas and Qureia reportedly said they would not agree to deviations from the original plan.

Philippine peso slips; stocks end mixed
MANILA, Philippines (AP) _ The Philippine peso slipped against the dollar in thin trading Friday, with the local currency underpinned by slack corporate demand for the U.S. currency, dealers said. However, participants closely watched pressure building on the Thai baht and the Japanese yen, they said. The dollar averaged 39.154 pesos for the day, up from 39.098 pesos on Thursday. Considerably worse-than-expected May inflation data had little direct impact on the peso-dollar rate, although the sharp rise in consumer prices is expected to break the declining interest-rate trend of recent weeks. Dealers said the peso market will be closely monitoring next week's meeting of deputy finance ministers from the Group of Seven industrialized nations, and whether the yen tests the sensitive level of 140 yen to the dollar early next week. However, peso losses are expected to be cushioned by the market's reluctance to buy the dollar at around 39 pesos. In stock trading, shares closed mixed as selective buying offset the negative impact of the higher-than-expected inflation data, market participants said. Sharp increases in food prices caused by the El Nino drought pushed inflation in May to 9.2 percent from 7.8 percent in April. The May data was based on the 1988 inflation series which will soon be phased out. The new inflation series introduced Friday uses 1994 as the base year and showed inflation in May higher at 10.3 percent. The 30-share Philippine Stock Exchange Index edged up 3.88 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,957.76 after gaining 24.89 points on Thursday. Losers, however, were ahead of gainers 41 to 35, with 47 issues unchanged. Analysts said the absence of fresh market incentives coupled by the damping effect of the inflation data forced many investors further to the sidelines. ``The trend is still down,'' said Nestor Aguila, president of Market Capital and Securities Inc. ``We're more negative than neutral at this time, particularly when it comes to external factors,'' he added. Aguila advised against bargain-hunting for the moment, warning that the market hasn't reached bottom. ``It's like catching a falling knife,'' he said.

BC-Council of Europe-Human Rights Prize,0277
Rights prize goes jointly to Italian, Turkish, Ulster activists
STRASBOURG, France (AP) _ The Council of Europe has awarded its 1998 European human rights prize jointly to two organizations _ one Turkish and one Northern Irish _ and an Italian activist. The prize was awarded Thursday to the Human Rights Foundation of Turkey, the Belfast-based Committee on the Administration of Justice in Northern Ireland and Chiara Lubich, an Italian human rights activist. They will get the award at a Sept. 2 ceremony commemorating the 50th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Lubich founded the Focolare Movement in 1943. Present in 180 countries, it ``works for unity among people through dialogue and concrete action in favor of peace without frontiers,'' the Council of Europe said. It lauded the Turkish group for its ``outstanding'' contribution to the protection of human rights in Turkey since 1990 and said the Northern Irish group, set up in 1980, ``has worked impartially to defend the human rights of all in Northern Ireland.'' The award is intended to ``uphold the merits of a person, group of persons, institution or non-governmental organization which has been active in promoting or protecting human rights in accordance with the principles of individual freedom, political liberty and the rule of law.'' Past winners include former Polish president Lech Walesa and Russia's former human rights commissioner Sergei Kovalyov. The Council of Europe was created in 1949 and is best known for its European Human Rights Convention.

BC-Russia-Economy, 1st Ld-Writethru
Yeltsin promises to hold down inflation, but urges Russians to pay
taxes Eds: UPDATES with stock market steady Friday, tax chief to crack down on rich and famous. By MAURA REYNOLDS Associated Press Writer
MOSCOW (AP) _ President Boris Yeltsin promised his countrymen Friday that he won't let Russia's financial crisis fuel new inflation, but said they must be prepared to do something in return: pay their taxes. ``The financial crisis threatens to destabilize the Russian ruble,'' Yeltsin warned in his weekly radio address to the nation. ``And that means a return to rising prices and a higher cost of living. That is something we simply can't allow.'' But Yeltsin said that unless Russian businesses and individuals start accepting their responsibility to pay taxes, there could be a return to Soviet-style ration cards and lines in the stores. ``The government exists on the money paid by taxpayers,'' he said. ``And you are right to demand effective work from the executive, legislative and judicial powers.'' ``But the government is right to expect citizens to have a responsible attitude to their obligation to pay taxes voluntarily.'' Russia's financial crisis has eased this week, in part because the government has taken aggressive actions to raise revenue, including a surprise bond offering and issuing extremely short-term treasury bills. In a sign of confidence, the Central Bank lowered two key interest rates late Thursday after hiking them to an unprecedented 150 percent last week. All the same, the new rates of 60 percent are still double what they were before the crisis intensified two weeks ago. Stocks were steady in early trading Friday after regaining some ground earlier in the week. Traders said the market appeared to be awaiting the outcome of a Tuesday meeting when Russia's financial woes will top the agenda at a meeting of G-8 finance officials. All together, Russia's stock market is down about 50 percent since the beginning of the year. Russia's tax collection troubles are at the heart of the crisis. The country's new tax chief has said that fewer than 3 percent of Russian citizens filed income tax declarations last year, and tax evasion is the norm among Russian businesses. ``The time has come to demand and punish, including filing criminal charges,'' Yeltsin said ominously. ``If we don't collect taxes, we can't pay salaries.'' The tax chief, Boris Fyodorov, has announced plans to crack down on Russia's 1,000 richest citizens. ``Well-known people should be examples for other citizens,'' Fyodorov told the Kommersant daily in an interview published Friday. The government's chronic inability to pay wages to state workers has led to labor protests, including strikes by coal miners last month that shut down parts of the country's rail system. (mr/ren/ml)

BC-EU-People's Europe
Big pre-EU summit gathering highlights `democratic' face of Europe
By MAUREEN JOHNSON Associated Press Writer
LONDON (AP) _ A Romanian gypsy describing discrimination. A Bosnian telling a north England town councilor how things got turned round in Tuzla. A Belgian talking greater autonomy with a Welsh nationalist. This is the People's Europe, a gathering of some 1,200 voluntary workers, trade unionists, businessmen, youth organizers, groups for the elderly, local government officials and a smattering of lawmakers. They all meet this weekend ahead of a European Union summit that takes place in the Welsh capital of Cardiff shortly before the union's six-month rotating presidency passes from Britain to Austria. Politically, the 1,200 delegates coming to London scarcely rank with the prime ministers and presidents going to Cardiff. But, emotionally, many feel they are the democratic, real face of a wealthy 15-nation club that can seem both remote and interfering to its 370 million citizens. ``There's a whole level of cooperation going on within Europe ... literally thousands of people from desperately energetic civic bodies who are organizing themselves on a European basis,'' said Shirley Williams, a British former Cabinet minister who is co-chairwoman of the London meeting. Delegates include people from the EU's would-be members _ 10 East European nations and Cyprus. And some are coming from further afield, including ethnic Albanian students from the troubled Serb province of Kosovo showing up for sessions on conflict resolution. Lady Williams, a Liberal Democrat lawmaker dismayed by Britain's increasing isolation in Europe under Conservative Party governments, considers Britain an appropriate host: The onetime EU loner turned European again _ although cautiously _ following the Labor Party's national election victory 13 months ago. ``On the continent, there was a sense of despair about the Conservative government in the last year,'' she said. ``So when the Labor government came and said, `We're going to be polite now. We're going to stop rubbishing everything you do' ... even if the Labor government had done nothing at all, it would have seemed an agreeable alternative.'' Not that Prime Minister Tony Blair's Britain is a fully paid-up Euro-enthusiast. Britain is one of four EU countries that won't adopt the EU's single currency, the euro, next year. Organizers of this weekend's meeting, being funded by the EU and the British government, hope a People's Europe gathering will be a permanent feature associated with EU summits. What critics might see as merely talking shop, enthusiasts regard as a vital reflection of the building of a pan-European identify for the next century on a continent that tore itself apart in two world wars during this one. Take, for example, the gypsies. ``We can learn from each other,'' said Lady Williams, noting that many West European countries provide sites with utilities for gypsies. ``If this is not solved in East Europe, the gypsies actually will have a strong case for saying they are political refugees, because they are suffering discrimination.'' The meeting ends Sunday with participants questioning British Foreign Secretary Robin Cook. (mj-kg)

APEC adopts mutual recognition for telecoms equipment
Eds: INSERTS new grafs 4-5 with other items agreed and some countries not implementing agreement until 2006. Picks up 6th graf, `Industry executives ... By LAURINDA KEYS Associated Press Writer
SINGAPORE (AP) _ Pacific Rim nations on Friday agreed to trim the testing requirements for imported telecom equipment in a pact aimed at cutting costs and bringing new products to the market more quickly. The Mutual Recognition Arrangement, adopted by government ministers of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, is part of a program aimed at eliminating tariffs on all information technology products by 2000. A similar agreement between the United States and the European Union was signed May 18. The APEC agreement allows already tested and certified products to be exported without requirements for retesting in the import country and will speed up marketing of technologies and products that are rapidly updated. In a statement called ``The Singapore Declaration,'' the APEC ministers adopted an action plan to promote electronic commerce within the group and also called for transparent, non-discriminatory interconnection of telecoms services from one country to another at rates that reflect costs. Industry executives, many of them attending the CommunicAsia '98 trade show that ran concurrently with the APEC meeting, praised the agreement but regretted that some countries will not implement it until 2006. The agreement ``will boost trade in telecommunications and information equipment goods among members of APEC, affecting roughly dlrs 45 billion in current trade flows, or one-third of the global market,'' the U.S. Trade Representative office said in a statement from Washington, D.C. The arrangement sets up a framework for manufacturers and exporters to test according to the standards of the importing country, and provides remedies for when something goes wrong. The arrangement covers all equipment subject to telecommunication regulations, including wireline and wireless, terrestrial and satellite equipment. The APEC telecommunications and information ministers released a declaration specifying dates for 16 of the 18 member nations to put the agreement into effect. Chile and New Zealand indicated they would not put the agreement into effect because their regulations are already simple enough for imports. Usually, testing and certification are expensive procedures for exporters, importers and regulators, and those costs are often passed to buyers and users. Simplified procedures reduce costs. ``At the same time, regulators need to have confidence in the quality of testing that provides the basis for certification of equipment,'' the U.S. Trade Representative said. The agreement is part of a voluntary liberalization process that APEC leaders launched last November in Vancouver. Telecommunications is one of the nine sectors targeted for early action in the first half of this year. APEC trade ministers will meet in Kuching, Malaysia, on June 22-23 to discuss the remaining eight target sectors: environmental goods and services, medical equipment and instruments, chemicals, energy sector, forest products, fish, gems and jewelry, and toys. APEC comprises Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand and the United States. Candidate members are Russia, Vietnam and Peru.

Yeltsin promises to hold down inflation, but urges Russians to pay
taxes Eds: UPDATES with premier saying crisis is over; TRIMS. By MAURA REYNOLDS Associated Press Writer
MOSCOW (AP) _ President Boris Yeltsin promised his countrymen Friday that he won't let Russia's financial crisis fuel new inflation, but said they must be prepared to do something in return: pay their taxes. His prime minister, meanwhile, declared the crisis over. ``The financial crisis threatens to destabilize the Russian ruble,'' Yeltsin warned in his weekly radio address to the nation. ``And that means a return to rising prices and a higher cost of living. That is something we simply can't allow.'' But Yeltsin said that unless Russian businesses and individuals start accepting their responsibility to pay taxes, there could be a return to Soviet-style lines and ration cards. ``The government exists on the money paid by taxpayers,'' he said. ``And you are right to demand effective work from the executive, legislative and judicial powers.'' ``But the government is right to expect citizens to have a responsible attitude to their obligation to pay taxes voluntarily.'' Russia's financial crisis has eased this week, in part because the government has taken aggressive actions to raise revenue, including a surprise bond offering and issuing extremely short-term treasury bills. In a sign of confidence, the Central Bank lowered two key interest rates late Thursday after hiking them to an unprecedented 150 percent last week. ``We have stopped the crisis and reached a turning point,'' Russian premier Sergei Kiriyenko said Friday at a conference in Ukraine, according to the Interfax news agency. All the same, the new rates of 60 percent are still double what they were before the crisis intensified two weeks ago. Stocks were steady in early trading Friday after regaining some ground earlier in the week. Traders said the market appeared to be waiting for Tuesday when Russia's financial woes will top the agenda at a meeting of G-8 finance officials. All together, Russia's stock market is down about 50 percent since the beginning of the year. Russia's tax collection troubles are at the heart of the crisis. The country's new tax chief has said that fewer than 3 percent of Russian citizens filed income tax declarations last year. ``The time has come to demand and punish, including filing criminal charges,'' Yeltsin said ominously. ``If we don't collect taxes, we can't pay salaries.'' The tax chief, Boris Fyodorov, has announced plans to crack down on Russia's 1,000 richest citizens. ``Well-known people should be examples for other citizens,'' Fyodorov told the Kommersant daily in an interview published Friday. The government's chronic inability to pay wages to state workers has led to labor protests, including strikes by coal miners last month that shut down parts of the country's rail system. (mr/ren/ml)

Witnesses, paparazzi, Al Fayed converge on Paris courthouse
Eds: UPDATES throughout with details of hearing; quotes. AP Photos PAR107-110 By JOCELYN NOVECK Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ A simple, tragic car accident, caused by a drunk driver. Is that the whole answer? That's what Judge Herve Stephan was trying to find out Friday as he gathered the key parties in the Diana case for a closed-door hearing. Grouped together for the first time were the photographers under investigation in the case; eight witnesses to the crash; Mohamed Al Fayed; and, according to defense lawyers in the room, Diana's mother, Frances Shand Kydd. They were accompanied by a platoon of lawyers. The crash in a Paris traffic tunnel Aug. 31 killed Diana, her boyfriend Dodi Fayed, and driver Henri Paul. Tests showed Paul was drunk at the time. But what was the responsibility of the paparazzi trailing Diana's Mercedes that night? Nine photographers and one press motorcyclist have been placed under investigation _ a step short of being formally charged. They have remained in legal limbo for almost a year, continuing their work. In what was seen as a last-ditch effort to clarify their roles, Stephan was examining each photographer one by one Friday. Lawyers emerging from the courtroom described the process. Two hours into the hearing, the judge had already dealt with two photographers: Romuald Rat and Stephane Darmon. Each gave an account of their activities that night. The judge then questioned them, questioned witnesses as to what they had seen, then opened questions to other lawyers. Stepping outside for a break, Al Fayed, Dodi's father, would say only: ``It's going fine. Great judge.'' He is a civil party in the case, meaning he has access to documents and proceedings. Diana's mother was also there but said nothing, said lawyer Virginie Bardet. Ten witnesses were summoned, but only eight showed up. They included the first emergency doctor on the scene, Frederic Mailliez, and the first two policemen on the scene. ``It's very well organized. It's calm, thorough, and clear. I am persuaded it will serve a purpose,'' said lawyer Jean-Louis Pelletier, who represents photographers David Ker and Fabrice Chassery. The policemen said during the hearing that Rat had hindered their work, lawyers said on condition of anonymity. The photographers are being investigated on two charges: manslaughter, and failing to come to the aid of a person in danger. Many close to the case believe they will soon be exonerated, at least on the manslaughter charge. Nikolas Arsov, of the Sipa photo agency, said the hearing was inconvenient, but that he understood the need for it. ``It's the 40th time we have answered the same questions,'' said Arsov. ``It's annoying, but what can you do? They have to do their job.'' Arsov was supposed to be shooting pictures Friday at the French Open tennis tournament. In contrast to previous hearings, all cameras were kept outside the grounds of the Palais de Justice. The gates were heavily guarded by police. Al Fayed drew up to the main courthouse in a Mercedes, surrounded by four other cars and about 10 bodyguards. It isn't just his son's death that connects Al Fayed to the case. Driver Paul was an employee of the Ritz Hotel, which Al Fayed owns. ``I hope that God will find the truth for us,'' he said as he left the Ritz in the morning. His spokesman, Lawrie Meyer, said ``This is a process to decide if the paparazzi should go to trial.'' Mr. Al Fayed ``is still a grieving parent and is here to find out what happened to his son,'' he said. In a statement issued in London on Thursday, Al Fayed said he was ``determined to get to the truth'' about whether the crash was an accident or a plot to kill Diana and his son. But French judicial sources said recently Al Fayed has backed off his contention that the crash stemmed from a plot, and now blames the paparazzi. Although the probe is not complete, investigators long have believed it was Paul's drunken condition and the Mercedes' excessive speed that probably caused the crash. They also are still looking for a white Fiat Uno believed to have brushed the Mercedes before it crashed. But they are said to have given up any real hope of finding the Fiat. Tests are still being conducted on the wrecked Mercedes Diana was traveling in, but aren't likely to be finished before October _ meaning the case can't be closed until then. Investigators also recently conducted road tests on a race track near Paris to reconstruct the crash. Police revealed no details of those tests. One person who wasn't attending Friday's session: bodyguard Trevor Rees-Jones, the sole survivor of the crash. He was invited on an ``informational basis,'' but decided not to come. (jn-dgs)

BC-Spain_Garcia Lorca centennial
Federico Garcia Lorca: small-town poet with worldwide following
By MAR ROMAN Associated Press Writer
FUENTEVAQUEROS, Spain (AP) _ Federico Garcia Lorca is the most translated Spanish poet ever, but the people in the white-painted village where he was born 100 years ago on Friday just call him Federico. ``Federico is like one of the family,'' said Celia Ramos, who has a portrait of Garcia Lorca hanging in her living room. The village ``family'' prepared to host a battery of Spanish artists and political figures for the nighttime celebrations Friday that were expected to attract up to 20,000 people, and surviving friends and relatives were invited to an intimate gathering in the house were Garcia Lorca grew up. While Spaniards and intellectuals around the world analyze his lyrical creations, the villagers claim a personal link with the legendary poet who was killed in 1936 by Gen. Francisco Franco's Nationalist troops during the opening days of the Spanish Civil War. ``Federico was an excellent and very open person with a very good sense of humor, although he was also a clumsy and rather fearful child,'' recalled Ramos, 58, repeating the words of her aunt and his nanny, Carmen Ramos. Like the majority of the 4,000 habitants of Fuentevaqueros, Ramos can recite some of Garcia Lorca's poems by heart, although she has read little of his work. ``Because of Franco we didn't know about the great talent of Federico,'' said Amparo Garcia, 82, a distant relative of the poet, ``the foreigners who came to the town knew more about of him than we did''. Relegated to the cultural shadows during Franco's 40-year regime, the first anniversary celebration in Fuentevaqueros did not take place until 1976, a year after the dictator died. Residents recall how police watched from rooftops as the crowd clapped and wept when one of the poet's nephews shouted, ``Federico lives! He is still with us.'' Two decades on, the Spanish cultural mainstream no longer fears the poet's compassion for the poor, and 1998 has been designated ``Lorca year.'' Publishing houses have printed new biographies and reprinted the old, including the seminal work ``Federico Garcia Lorca: A Life,'' written by Irish writer-historian Ian Gibson. Gibson was so attracted by his study of the poet's life that he adopted Spanish citizenship and moved to the nearby city of Granada, where he lives today. Lorca, as he is more commonly referred to in English (dropping his first surname), abandoned his law studies to immerse himself in literature, painting and music. By his early 20s he was rubbing shoulders with the artistic vanguard of his generation, and was friends with surrealist painter Salvador Dali, filmmaker Luis Bunuel and poet Rafael Alberti. International fame, but not happiness, came in 1928 with the publication of ``Romancero Gitano'' (``Gypsie Ballads''). The poet fled to the United States and Cuba in 1929-30, and wrote ``Poeta en Nueva York'' (Poet in New York), published posthumously in 1940. The Lorca centennial has also filled Spanish theaters with productions of his famous dramatic trilogy that began in 1933 with ``Bodas de Sangre (Blood Wedding) and was followed by ``Yerma'' in 1934 _ that focuses on the social stigma suffered by a sterile woman. Two years later, Lorca rounded off the trio with a tragic tale of repressed sexuality in a house dominated by a strong-willed mother in ``La Casa de Bernarda Alba'' (The House of Bernarda Alba). Love and lust, death, motherhood and above all, cruelty and violence are running themes throughout his work. Lorca's own homosexuality, outcried by the Franco's fascist regime, is still controversial today among the villagers. ``I don't believe it, although my aunt said she found him quite effeminate'' said Ramos. Lorca returned frequently to Fuentevaqueros, an inspiration and solitary refuge surrounded by tobacco fields and orchards in the fertile Granada plain in Andalusia. About eight million people have visited his former house since it was turned into a museum in 1986 _ the pilgrims ranging from British/Indian writer Salman Rusdhie, American singer Leonard Cohen to former Portuguese premier Mario Soares. Celebrations to mark the 100th anniversary of his death, 38 years from now, will be less easy to organize than this year's centennial. The exact date and place of his murder are still a mystery. ``The fascists killed him because they were jealous of him, he didn't deserve to be killed, he was not politically minded and he helped everyone in need,'' Ramos said. Japan's Parliament approves ``Big Bang'' deregulation bills
Eds: ADDS more comments from finance minister, other details, byline By KOZO MIZOGUCHI Associated Press Writer
TOKYO (AP) _ Japan's Parliament approved four financial deregulation bills Friday, accelerating the country's ``Big Bang'' program of opening financial markets to greater competition. The measures are designed to make Japanese financial institutions more efficient, globally competitive and on par with those in New York and London by 2001. The reforms also will offer foreign financial companies wider access to the Japanese market. Friday's action by the upper house followed similar approval of the bills in the more powerful lower house last month. Finance Minister Hikaru Matsunaga told a news conference that the reform legislation will help create a ``favorable environment'' for Japan's economy by revitalizing slumping Tokyo markets and benefiting consumers as well. ``It will become even more important for firms and individuals to make their own investment judgments, based on full recognition of risks and characteristics of each product and service,'' Matsunaga said in a separate statement. The Big Bang reforms, nicknamed after similar British financial reforms in the 1980s, come at a tough time for Japan's weakening economy. Stock prices remain far below record highs, and banks and other financial institutions are saddled with massive bad debts left over from a 1980s speculative land price boom that went bust. Unemployment and corporate bankruptcies are at record highs. One key reform bill approved Friday is the liberalization of non-life insurance premium rates that will take place July 1. The United States and Japan agreed in 1996 on steps to open Japan's dlrs 341 billion insurance market to greater competition to U.S. and other foreign companies. Japan's insurance market has been tightly regulated. Premiums rates are set by industry panels, ruling out price competition, and the types of policies that can be offered are also very limited. Among other measures approved by the 252-member House of Councilors: _ Banks can sell investment trust funds from their own windows from Dec. 1. _ A ban on trading derivatives will be lifted Dec. 1. _ Brokers' commission fees will be completely liberalized by the end of 1999, while further liberalizing sales of mutual funds and securities. _ Greater disclosure of corporate management information. _ A registration system will be introduced for securities firms. Matsunaga also said an independent Finance Supervisory Agency will be set up June 22, a move that will wrest supervision of financial institutions from the scandal-plagued Finance Ministry. GEORGE, South Africa (AP) _ An angry Desmond Tutu on Friday objected to the suggestion that apartheid-era killings of black activists were the work of ``bad apples'' _ or rogues _ in the State Security forces. ``How many `bad apples' are you going to concede?'' the Nobel Laureate minister asked during cross examination by defense lawyers for former President P.W. Botha. ``No, no. We cannot now say that these are `bad apples.' They are people who were sitting on the State Security Council.'' Botha is on trial for snubbing the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, which is probing atrocities committed during white rule. But the case has focused on allegations that Botha and the shadowy State Security Council he headed coordinated a crackdown on anti-apartheid activists and directly ordered bombings and killings during the 1980s. Grilling Tutu, who heads the Truth Commission, defense lawyer Lappe Laubscher said there were no direct assassination orders in any of the Council's minutes, indicating the killings were the work of ``bad apples'' in the police and army who misunderstood orders. Prosecution witnesses, including police death squad commander Eugene de Kock, testified earlier this week that the council's use of phrases like ``eliminate'' and ``neutralize'' sanctioned the murder of the white-run state's opponents. Botha and other top members of the SSC claim they only meant people should be arrested. Botha has been implicated by a former national police commissioner who in earlier Truth Commission hearings alleged that he ordered the 1988 bombing of the Johannesburg headquarters of an anti-apartheid group. Since his trial began Monday, Botha sat impassively throughout the exchange, occasionally looking behind him at members of his legal team and family. Botha, 82, ignored three subpoenas to testify before the commission on the role of the SSC, which Botha chaired during 11 years as head of state. Due to his age and frail health the trial is being held in the southern coastal city of George, near Botha's retirement home. The former hard-liner has called the Truth Commission ``a circus,'' claiming it is victimizing him by wanting him to appear in person when he has submitted more than 1,700 pages of written answers to commission questions. If convicted, Botha likely faces a hefty fine. Apartheid ended after Botha's successor, President F.W. de Klerk, negotiated with the ANC, which had been waging a guerrilla campaign against apartheid. The talks culminated in all-race elections in 1994, which the ANC won.

MOSCOW (AP) _ Russia's lower house of parliament passed a bill Friday designed to encourage Russians to adopt more children and tighten control over foreign adoptions. The State Duma voted 337-0 in favor of the bill, which needs to be approved by parliament's upper house and President Boris Yeltsin before it becomes law. Alevtina Aparina, a Communist deputy who initiated the bill, has said the restrictions are needed to better protect Russian children. Communists and their hard-line allies who dominate the Duma have accused foreign agencies of bribing Russian officials to arrange illegal adoptions. The bill has been strongly criticized by adoption workers and human rights activists in Russia and abroad. They have warned that it could discourage prospective adoptive parents and leave most Russian orphans with no hope of finding a home. Currently there are many more Russian orphans than prospective Russian parents. The critics specifically assailed a proposal that adoption procedures must be codified in formal agreements between Russia and each country with prospective parents. They argued that would result in a bureaucratic quagmire that would effectively freeze most foreign adoptions. However, that provision appeared to be eased in the final version of the bill. Unlike the original draft which set a deadline of Sept. 1, 1999 for other nations to reach such agreements with Russia, the current bill contains no time limit. That means currently pending adoptions will not be stalled by the measure. Still, adoption advocates said the new bill still might leave loopholes which would allow local officials to block adoptions. ``Some regional authorities are strongly against any adoptions by foreigners and they may use some vague clauses of the bill to stall them,'' said Boris Altshuller, a Russian human rights activist who runs the Child's Rights pro-adoption program. He cited one recent example of officials in the Orenburg region in southern Ural Mountains banning U.S. citizens from adopting a hemophiliac child. ``They would rather have him die in his native land than live on foreign soil,'' Altshuller said in a telephone interview. The bill would allow foreign adoption agencies to operate in Russia only after their nation signs an agreement with Russia setting out the rules. In the interim, prospective foreign parents can use the services of proxies and interpreters. According to parliamentary estimates, there are about 80 foreign adoption agencies, mostly American, currently operating in Russia, usually operating through Russian intermediaries. (vi/mr)

Koraim declined to say if the ``final touches'' were related to the number or names of prisoners to be released or to give an exact number of those expected to be freed. The body of Hadi Nasrallah, the eldest son of Hezbollah Secretary-General Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, would be among the dead returned, Koraim said. Hadi Nasrallah, 18, was killed in fighting with Israeli troops on Sept. 12. The International Committee of the Red Cross has been relaying messages between Israel and Lebanon for months on a possible swap, but Hezbollah has pushed for freeing a greater number of prisoners. Sheik Nasrallah said in a TV interview Wednesday that a deal was near involving more than 30 Lebanese prisoners. Beirut's leftist daily As-Safir on Friday quoted unidentified Lebanese sources as saying a prisoner swap will take place ``within a few days.'' Agreement has been reached in principle on the release of 10 prisoners held in Israel and 30 others from the Khiam detention camp in the Israeli-occupied zone in south Lebanon, the paper said. In Israel, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu appeared less optimistic. Asked if there was progress, Netanyahu told reporters Thursday: ``I hope so, but it's hard to say that it's a closed matter.'' Israel wants back the body parts of more than one Israeli soldier left behind after botched operation in southern Lebanon Sept. 5 in which a total of 12 Israeli commandos were killed. Nasrallah, whose group is fighting to oust Israeli forces from the occupied zone, said Israel holds about 210 Lebanese, 60 of them in Israel and the rest in Khiam. The prisoners are mostly held on suspicion of being guerrillas or aiding in attacks against Israeli forces. hd-ggl

BC-Latvia-Citizenship
Latvia says citizenship vote will improve Russian relations
RIGA, Latvia (AP) _ Latvia's parliament has given preliminary approval to changes in the citizenship which have so angered Russia that it has threatened trade sanctions against the small Baltic state. The Saeima passed the changes late Thursday by a vote of 57-16 after nine hours of often-heated debate. The measure must pass a final reading before becoming law. Russia, which accounts for about 20 percent of Latvia's foreign trade, in April said it would impose sanctions against Latvia unless it took quick and substantial steps to improve the status of Latvia's ethnic Russians, about 400,000 of whom do not have citizenship. Russia's complaint was couched in harsh words _ Moscow Mayor Yuri Luzhkov even accused Latvia of ``genocide'' _ raising fears in Latvia that its giant neighbor was becoming increasingly domineering. ``This vote was pivotal ... and we believe the decision to change the law will improve our relations with Russia,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Andrejs Pildegovics said Friday. President Guntis Ulmanis has called on the parliament take a final vote on the bill before the start of summer recess in two weeks. When Latvia became independent of the Soviet Union in 1991, it granted citizenship to people who had lived there before World War II and to their descendants. That left nearly a third of the country's residents stateless _ most of them ethnic Russians who had moved there under Josef Stalin's Russification drive or their descendants. The current citizenship law requires many of them to wait up to several years before being allowed to apply for naturalization. The proposed changes would grant citizenship to all children born in Latvia since independence and would elimnate the waits for other aspirants. But naturalization would still require a proficiency test in the Latvian language _ a sensitive issue for the ethnic Russians, many of whom lived and worked in communities where Russian was the only language.
