BC-Sports-Soccer-Sepp's Quest,0632
World Cup: FIFA presidential hopeful says he's near victory
By LARRY SIDDONS AP Sports Writer
PARIS (AP) _ When Sepp Blatter launched his last-minute bid for the biggest job in the world's biggest sport 2 1/2 months ago, he was a longshot at best. Even he said so. But on Friday, three days before FIFA elects a new president to run international soccer, Blatter said something much different. He said he was ready to win. ``On Monday, I shall have enough votes to be president,'' he said. ``Right now, I may have a little bit less. But I am very confident.'' At a news conference with Michel Platini, the former French soccer star and co-chairman of the World Cup that begins in a gleaming new stadium north of Paris next Wednesday, Blatter refused to estimate his votes or whether he could defeat Lennart Johansson, the president of the European soccer union UEFA, on the first ballot. But he said a globe-trotting campaign that drained his bankbook of almost dlrs 300,000 had won him virtually all the votes from Asia and the Americas, gained solid support in Oceania and cut deeply into Johansson's strongholds in Europe and Africa. In a separate interview, Blatter said he was certain he had at least 20 of the 51 votes from Europe, once virtually conceded to Johansson. In a surprise move, the English Football Association announced Friday its support for Blatter, after initially backing Johansson's candidacy. Blatter said that the support of Platini and other officials from France, reportedly including phone calls from President Jacques Chirac, had swayed voters in French-speaking African nations. A candidate needs two-thirds of the expected 190 votes to win on the first ballot and a simple majority on subsequent rounds. Blatter's supporters have talked recently of a second-ballot victory Blatter is an insider, the secretary general of FIFA for 17 years and a high-ranking member of the staff for almost the entire length of Joao Havelange's 24-year tenure as president. But when he spoke of his plans if he wins, the man who often has been soccer's televised face and voice sounded like a rebel. Without criticizing Havelange, who urged him to battle Johansson, Blatter said that FIFA's top job had to change, from a part-time president to a full-time CEO. ``FIFA is a company,'' he said. ``It is an industry. It is a commercial endeavor. It is above all dedicated to those who play football.'' While Havelange, a wealthy Brazilian industrialist, and his predecessors served as non-paid presidents with hefty expense accounts and accompanying hints of corruption, Blatter said his CEO-style leader should be paid up front. ``It's cleaner and clearer,'' he said. ``It's transparent.'' Platini, who would be head of soccer events in Blatter's streamlined administration, said FIFA has become too remote from the world's 300 million players and must do more at the grassroots level. ``What does FIFA mean to today's players? Nothing!'' Platini said. ``The people they see are figureheads, staying in 5-star hotels and eating in expensive restaurants. We want to change that.'' Platini's organizing committee paid for the news conference, held in a meeting room of a 4-star hotel and offering champagne and ritzy hor d'oeurves afterward. The Blatter-Johansson campaign has been an unusually dirty one for international sports, where political decisions often are made behind closed doors. Blatter said he was hopeful that, once the votes were cast, the two sides would make peace. ``I am sure that all will return to calm and the backhanded tactics will be put away once this is over,'' he said.

England 321 for four at lunch on the second day
BIRMINGHAM, England (AP) _ South Africa produced two crucial blows Friday before lunch, but not before England had consolidated its position on day two of the first cricket test at Edgbaston. Resuming at 249 for one, England lost the former skipper Mike Atherton who failed to add to his overnight 103, new captain Alec Stewart, and Nasser Hussain to be 321 for four at lunch. After losing Atherton to the 10th ball of the day, Stewart and Hussain continued to frustrate the South Africans by scoring 60 runs in 93 minutes. But with lunch in sight, medium paceman Lance Klusener and left-arm wrist spinner Adams removed the third wicket pair in the space of five balls. Stewart (49), edged Klusener to Daryll Cullinan at first slip and Adams trapped Hussain (35) leg before wicket with a ball that hardly bounced. The pair had hit five boundaries apiece. Graham Thorpe and Mark Ramprakash survived 15 minutes before the break to remain unbeaten on four and two respectively. Fast bowler Allan Donald, who remained a doubtful starter on the second day due to an ankle injury, took the field and had Atherton caught behind with the fourth ball of his first over. Atherton, having remained characteristically impassive on the first day, edged a catch to wicket keeper Boucher. His 12th century lasted six minutes over six hours and he hit 12 boundaries off 279 balls. According to South African team physiotherapist Craig Smith, Donald took the field after an injection on a troubled left ankle, a recurrence of an injury that had troubled him in Australia early this year. Adams has been the most successful bowler so far with 2-49 in 21 overs, while Klusener's wicket cost him 63 runs. (ik/scw)

THE HAGUE, Netherlands (AP) _ Serb forces involved in the violent crackdown on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo are using an armored personnel carrier stolen from Dutch troops, the Dutch government admitted Friday. Current affairs program Nova made the claim Thursday night after studying video images of a recent Serbian attack on a Kosovo village. Foreign Affairs Ministry spokesman Peter Mollema said the Dutch ambassador in Belgrade would request the return of the vehicle Friday. ``We will await the outcome of this and then see what other steps are necessary,'' Mollema added. A defense analyst told Nova he was 95 percent certain that one of the armored personnel carriers was a YPR765 taken by Bosnian Serb forces from Dutch United Nations forces during the July 1995 attack on eastern Bosnia's Srebrenica enclave. ``We expected that they would turn up somewhere,'' Defense Ministry spokesman Bert Kreemers said. ``It is regrettable ... but we have known for three years that these were stolen.'' Kreemers said that Bosnian Serbs stole 14 of the armored vehicles following the fall of Srebrenica. Five have since been recovered by NATO forces in Bosnia, but nine are still missing. Most of the 900,000-guilder (dlrs 450,000) APCs were armed with a heavy machine gun, and Kreemers said Serb forces could easily add extra armaments to the vehicles. More than 250 people have been killed since March, when Serbs stepped up efforts to destroy the pro-independence Kosovo Liberation Army, which now claims to control about 40 percent of Kosovo's territory. Court throws out demand for ticket redistribution
Eds: UPDATES with case thrown out on technical legal grounds; CORRECTS spelling to Jenkinson; ADDS background, byline By RAF CASERT Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ A court on Friday threw out a demand by a group of European lawmakers to redistribute 700,000 World Cup tickets they claim were unfairly allocated in favor of French fans. The court said it could not rule in the case on legal grounds. ``It was thrown out on a technical grounds. The court has not dealt with the matter as such,'' said Phillip Jenkinson, attorney for the 32 lawmakers who brought the case. The court ruled that under French law, there can be no class action-style suit involving the tickets. To take the ticket matter to court, one can only seek tickets for oneself, Jenkinson said, explaining the court's decision to throw out the case. ``By asking the court for 700,000 tickets, we were asking the court to change the law,'' he said. The French Organizing Committee (CFO) for the World Cup sold 961,000 of the 2.5 million tickets for the soccer championship to French residents. A further 673,000, about 26 percent, went to national federations and tour operators, while sponsors grabbed 436,000, or 17 percent. The European lawmakers went to court May 20 to argue that the allocation left too few reasonably-priced tickets for ordinary fans. The court had deferred its ruling until Friday. The CFO's ticket policy breaks three clauses in the Treaty of Rome, Jenkinson said at the first hearing -- those that outlaw discrimination on grounds of nationality, restraint of movement of goods and services, and abuse of dominant position. The parliamentarians also asked that the Paris court pass on the complaint to the European Court of Justice, which could ensure that future event organizers make no discrimination between EU nationalities on ticket allocation. They also sought ``symbolic'' damages of 250,000 francs (dlrs 41,600). (rc-eg)

BC-Indonesia-Fires
World environmentalists stress prevention over fire-fighting
SINGAPORE (AP) _ International environmentalists said Friday that no amount of fire-fighting will solve the problem of burning Indonesian jungles, only concerted and comprehensive prevention. ``If there is a resurgence of fires with the continuation of the drought ... it is unlikely that any sort of emergency measures to put those fires out will work,'' said Jeffrey Sayer, Director General of the Indonesian-based Centre for International Forestry Research. He was speaking to reporters in Singapore at the end of a two-day meeting of non-governmental environmental organizations on the Southeast Asian fires. Fires last year swept through millions of hectares of Indonesian forest, and caused billions of dollars in damage globally as haze shrouded the region and greenhouse gases spread into the atmosphere. Simon Tay, a chairman at the Singapore Environment Council, said there was a tendency to only react to the problem after the fires have been set and when haze spreads across the region. Tay said that ``when the haze shifts ... our attention shifts,'' and that a lack of consistent focus on the problem was a key failure of governments and inter-governmental groups hoping to combat the haze. You can't simply ``throw water at the problem,'' but must come up with a comprehensive, long-term solution, he said. Experts at the meeting said efforts must center on promoting alternatives to clearing land by fire, both by large industries and small farmers in Indonesia, and on enforcing existing environmental laws there and reforming outdated ones. They also mentioned the need to tie current international aid for Indonesia, such as packages from the International Monetary Fund, to environmental considerations. The various groups attending the conference agreed that more international aid earmarked for preventative measures, rather than fire fighting, would be required to avoid massive fires and ensuing haze in the future. Although their recommendations were focused at medium- to long-term solutions, they admitted the need to start now, as the region enters its traditional dry season and the chance of more fires in Indonesia rises. ``There is concern that the fires are still burning in places where the weather conditions might not improve as hoped, and that we are all at risk, and that we need therefore to get working yesterday,'' said Nicholas Robinson, a chairman at the Swiss-based International Union for the Conservation of Nature. The non-governmental organizations said they have been invited to future environmental meetings of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, and hope to be present at the next ASEAN gathering on June 18 and 19 in Singapore.

Dai-ichi Kangyo to buy shares in Kankaku Securities
Eds: UPDATES throughout with announcement of purchase, details, quotes
TOKYO (AP) _ Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd. will buy 300 million new shares in Kankaku Securities Co. for 30 billion yen (dlrs 215.8 million), boosting its share in the brokerage to 37.1 percent, Kankaku announced Friday. DKB, one of Japan's biggest banks, is already the largest shareholder of the second-tier securities company. With the July 17 payment, the DKB group of companies will hold a 54 percent stake in Kankaku. The DKB-Kankaku deal is the first case of a major bank acquiring a securities as a subsidiary since Japan's Antimonopoly Law was revised last year to allow such holdings by banks. Kankaku's president, Chuichi Numata, said the fund injection was part of efforts to strengthen its financial position as the Japanese government moves forward with financial deregulation and market reform. Numata said the increase in DKB's share in Kankaku will also serve to clarify to investors the already-strong relationship between the bank and the securities company. Kankaku announced a restructuring program in November last year, under which it will withdraw from overseas operations, restructure its domestic retail network, cut costs, and reduce staff. Kankaku also said Friday it will reduce its capital by 20 billion yen (dlrs 143.9 million) by transferring some funds to its capital reserves. The company's capital will stand at 46 billion (dlrs 331 million) after the fund injection from DKB. Kankaku said its capital-adequacy ratio will rise to 330 percent after receiving the new funds from DKB. The company's capital-adequacy ratio was 215 percent at the close of the fiscal year ended March. Friday's news comes only a few weeks after Dai-Ichi Securities, another second-tier Japanese brokerage house, said it will issue 80 million new shares worth 8 billion yen (dlrs 57.6 million) in July to five group companies of the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan. Numata said that Kankaku and DKB Securities, a fully-owned subsidiary of DKB, would concentrate on different segments of the securities industry. (apdj-jc)

BC-UN-Ethiopia-Refugees
U.N. refugee agency says five year refugee return operation ends
GENEVA (AP) _ The last of thousands of Ethiopian refugees who fled to Sudan to escape fighting in their country are leaving for home Friday, the U.N. refugee agency said. Around 680 refugees are due to travel back to Ethiopia in convoys organized by the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees, UNHCR spokeswoman Judith Kumin said in Geneva. Some of the refugees have been in exile in Sudan for 20 years after fleeing fighting which broke out between Ethiopian government forces and Eritrean independence fighters. The Eritreans gained formal independence in 1993 after helping Ethiopian rebels end 17 years of harsh military rule in Ethiopia. The final convoys bring to an end a five year UNHCR repatriation program which has helped some 71,000 Ethiopian refugees to return to Ethiopia. An additional 8,500 still in Sudan have told UNHCR they want to stay there and are having their cases reviewed, agency spokesman Paul Stromberg said. UNHCR has also discussed with Eritrea's government the possibility of returning some 150,000 Eritrean refugees still in Sudan, Stromberg said. If all goes well, the return could take place this autumn. Meanwhile, another UNHCR repatriation program in Africa was completed this week, the agency said. Some 370 Tuareg refugees, described by UNHCR as ``mostly nomadic people,'' were returned from Algeria to Niger, the last of some 4,000 who have returned after fleeing armed conflict and drought in Niger in the early 1990s. BC-Yugoslavia-Kosovo
Kosovo Albanians talk of 50 deaths, destroyed villages
By ISMET HAJDARI Associated Press Writer
PRISTINA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ More than 50 Kosovo Albanians have been killed and about 200 are missing since Serbian government forces started an offensive in the independence-minded province a week ago, an ethnic Albanian leader said Friday. In Geneva, the United Nations refugee agency said some of the 400 or so Kosovo Albanians who trekked into neighboring Albania overnight had reported five deaths en route _ two elderly people, said to have died of exhaustion, and three small children. About 10,000 refugees are now gathered around Tropoja in northern Albania. In the reported government offensive in Kosovo, four villages populated by ethnic Albanians were destroyed, and another eight badly damaged, said Osman Cacaj, an official of the Democratic League of Kosovo, the ethnic Albanians' main party. Sixteen other villages are deserted as residents fled, Cacaj added. He listed more than 50 dead and some 200 missing from the latest offensive, concentrated around Decani, some 70 kilometers (45 miles) west of Kosovo's capital, Pristina. In Novi Poklek, a village much closer to Pristina, residents said Serbian police attacked on Sunday, taking away some 25-30 men after a four-hour blitz, Associated Press photographer Santiago Lyon reported. Three-quarters of the homes in the village, some 25 kilometers (12 miles) west of Pristina, were burned and destroyed, Lyon said. Residents said women and children had been allowed to flee. Only about 15 people, mostly men, could be seen in the razed settlement Friday. Ethnic Albanians form 90 percent of Kosovo's 2 million people and demand independence from Serbia and the Yugoslav federation it forms with tiny Montenegro. Accounts such as Cacaj's are impossible to verify independently, as both Serbian police forces and gunmen from the Kosovo Liberation Army _ fighting for independence _ block adequate access to journalists and even humanitarian workers. Kosovo Albanian leaders say information comes from individuals who manage to pass Serbian roadblocks and reach Pristina. Telephone access to the area of the offensive has been cut for days. Cacaj described the area around Decani as a deserted wasteland, with some 45 bodies left unburied, farm animals roaming wild and several thousand civilians hiding in the woods, trying to cross the border into neighboring Albania or to Montenegro, which with Serbia, forms Yugoslavia. Late Thursday, an unidentified elderly Albanian in the area who had remained in his village shot dead three Serbian policemen trying to loot his house, Cacaj said. The Serb Media Center in Pristina, close to the Serbian authorities, said meanwhile that a Yugoslav army general, Nebojsa Pavkovic, made a surprise visit to a still-inhabited village in the area, Batusa, inviting any Albanians who fled to return on condition armed men turn in weapons and halt attacks on police and army. During Bosnia's 1992-95 war, such warnings were often a prelude to a Serb attack on grounds that the community in question failed to comply. More than 250 people have died since March 1 in escalating clashes between government forces and the Kosovo Liberation Army, the armed wing of the Albanian independence movement, which Albanian political leaders say acts independently from them. The clandestine KLA, which first surfaced in 1996, says the peaceful principles of the top Kosovo Albanian leader, Ibrahim Rugova, are futile. A delegation picked by Rugova and officials chosen by Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic, who stripped Kosovo of its broad autonomy in 1989, opened a dialogue under Western pressure last month. Agreement appears unlikely. The ethnic Albanians canceled a meeting scheduled Friday in Pristina, saying they could not talk with the Serbs while the latest offensive lasts. The Serbs showed up anyway for the talks, to which Christopher Hill, U.S. ambassador to neighboring Macedonia, is serving as unofficial mediator. Hill noted that it is ``extremely difficult'' to get a true picture of events around Decani. ``The problem is you talk to one side, you get one view, you talk to the other side, you get a view of 180 degrees,'' he said. Rugova's aides are showing more and more sympathy for the KLA, which only weeks ago they shunned. ``Serbs systematically shell the villages in the war zone, burn and destroy Albanian settlements,'' said Rugova's spokesman Xhemail Mustafa. ``The Serb regime has declared and imposed war on ethnic Albanians.'' ``Therefore, we understand the people's self-organizing on the ground and their efforts to defend from aggression,'' Mustafa added. Kosovo men take families across border, then return to fight
AP Photos planned By MERITA DHIMGJOKA Associated Press Writer
TROPOJA, Albania (AP) _ Men taking their families across the border from Kosovo to Albania to escape a Serb artillery offensive are purchasing arms and other supplies _ and then are returning to fight the enemy. They all have the same objective: to fight the Serbs and defend what is left of their homes in Kosovo, a province in the Serb republic of Yugoslavia where ethnic Albanians overwhelmingly outnumber Serbs. ``This is not a surrender,'' said a 30-year-old man as he registered his wife and four children as refugees at the town's mosque. ``All men will go back and fight,'' he said, on condition of anonymity. The men say they are tired of waiting for foreign powers to force Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic to stop the assault on their villages, which have caused tens of thousands to flee. ``We waited for years for the international community to prevent the outbreak of this war,'' said Shaban Lukja, 48, from Decani, a battlefield town in Kosovo. ``But now that there is little hope left, we shall take care of it ourselves.'' Horses and mules loaded with guns, vans without license plates transporting young men in camouflage uniforms and the sound of sporadic gunfire make this border town look like a military base. While thousands of women, children, and elderly have found refuge with families or in makeshift shelters, the men, with few exceptions, are gearing up for war. Youths under age 20 are being trained to handle guns, and no attempt is being made to hide the military preparations. The Kosovo Liberation army, an underground guerrilla force fighting for Kosovo's independence, is not much in evidence. Only a few men believed to be KLA members have been seen in the area. But whether or not the Kosovo men are members of the clandestine army seems irrelevant. They all have one and the same objective: to fight back the Serbs and defend what's left of their homes. In Tropoja, guns are changing hands in the central piazza. One Kalashnikov sells for 350 German marks (almost dlrs 200), whereas a camouflage uniform costs 50 marks (30 dlrs). The parties in the business are happy _ the Albanians who make money so crucial to survive in Europe's poorest country, and Kosovo Alabanians who get weapons needed desperately in order to resist what they call ``ethnic cleansing,'' _ the Serbian attempt to drive out ethnic Albanians, at least from the border region. Tropoja is a small town in the impoverished north of Albania, where about 10,000 ethnic Albanian refugees fled to escape a Serb offensive that has devastated dozens of villages in the besieged region of Decani. Newcomers are directed to other towns because Tropoja is overflowing. The Albanian government can do little to stop the Kosovo men from organizing and arming on Albanian territory. About a million guns were looted in Albania last year when the country descended into chaos and lawlessness following the collapse of pyramid schemes in which most people lost their life savings. ``The government cannot stop the arms smuggling, guns are out there,'' said Capt. Astrit Madani, a border police commander. The Albanian government has called for a NATO presence along its northern border, admitting it cannot stop or control all the traffic across its northern border. It lacks both equipment and trained personnel.

BC-Germany-Train Derails, 4th Ld - Writethru
Broken wheel confirmed; body of 96th victim found
Eds: UPDATES with authorities confirming that metal tire on passenger car wheel fractured before crash, is focus of investigation; trims, edits AP Photos ESC101,104,113 By TONY CZUCZKA Associated Press Writer
ESCHEDE, Germany (AP) _ Dozens of Germany's fastest trains were idled Friday for inspections as investigators confirmed that a wheel failure appeared to be the most likely cause of the country's worst rail accident in more than 50 years. The confirmed death toll rose to 96 at midday Friday after rescue crews found a body beneath a 10-meter-long section of a collapsed bridge. Ninety-three bodies have been recovered at the scene of Wednesday's disaster, and three people died in hospitals. ``We have to fear that we will find more bodies under here as we go along,'' said Eschede police spokesman Joachim Haack. In addition to the train passengers, rescue workers are also looking for two maintenance men who were working on an adjoining track at the time of the crash. Deutsche Bahn took all of its its first-generation InterCity Express trains, introduced in 1991, out of service Thursday night for urgent inspections. Ten of the 59 surviving trains returned to duty Friday. In Bonn, federal railway authority spokesman Jens Boehlke confirmed that a steel tire encircling the wheel disc on the first car behind the lead locomotive had broken. A piece of the tire _ which forms the rolling surface of the wheel _ was found wedged into the chassis of the coach, Boehlke said. There was no indication whether the tire failed because of metal fatigue or because of damage from an outside force, Boehlke said. There had been no similar failure since the high-speed InterCity Express trains went into service, Boehlke said. Damage to track and ties indicated the wheel apparently fractured about 6 kms (3.7 miles) from the overpass in Eschede. That tallied with reports from survivors that they heard a loud noise and felt vibrations minutes before the crash. Boehlke indicated that the damaged tire was torn away, which meant there was nothing to prevent the disc from straying off the rail. It is possible that the damaged first car struck the bridge, but that several cars got through in the moment before the massive concrete deck crushed the train, Boehlke said. The first car broke away from the locomotive, but came to rest upright with the second and third cars. Officials say the greatest number of dead were in the fourth car, which got through the bridge but flipped over on its side. Two bodies were recovered earlier in the day from the last major part of wreckage to be excavated, a dining car flattened by the overpass. ``It would appear that the restaurant car was closed for some reason, otherwise there would have been more people in it,'' Haack said earlier. A special commission of police, rail and other experts, supervised by prosecutors, were working to identify the cause of the disaster, and investigators were aggressively searching for evidence in an area extending 6 kilometers (3.7 miles) down the line, Haack said. Attention centered on the steel ``tires'' which are fitted to the wheel discs. The tires must be replaced from time to time because of wear. State authorities originally estimated that as many as 100 or more were killed when the Hamburg-bound InterCity Express 884 derailed at 200 kilometers (125 miles) an hour near the small town of Eschede, 50 kilometers (35 miles) north of Hanover. On Thursday, officials lowered the speed limit for all ICE trains from 280 kilometers (175 miles) per hour to 160 kph (100 mph) until the entire fleet could be inspected. Whatever caused the accident set off a catastrophic chain of events: part of the train knocked down a highway overpass, the collapsing bridge crushed some of the trailing cars, and the rest of the train jackknifed against the tangle of steel and concrete. State officials said 200 people were injured, of whom 95 were treated in hospitals. ``Before everything happened, I felt a rumbling and suddenly a horrible cracking. The lights went out and the carriage sprang from the tracks,'' said Angelika Hauser, 32, a pharmacist from Augsburg. Hauser, who was quoted in Bild, suffered a fractured skull and broken back. ``I remember only that people and seats were all over the place,'' an unidentified woman told n-tv television in one of the first interviews with one of the scores of injured survivors evacuated to hospitals in helicopters. Sabah election a test of Dompok's ability to lead Barisan Nasional, NEW STRAITS TIMES-MANAGEMENT TIMES
Sabah election a test of Dompok's ability to lead Barisan Nasional, NEW STRAITS TIMES-MANAGEMENT TIMES June 04, 1998 NEW STRAITS TIMES-MANAGEMENT TIMES MALAYSIA ENGLISH Joniston BangkuaiASIA WorldSources, Inc. 201 PENNSYLVANIA AVENUE, S.E., 2nd Floor

FOR Tan Sri Bernard Giluk Dompok, his appointment as Sabah's new Chief Minister for a two-year term under the rotation system is significant. This is because he will have to lead the State Barisan Nasional into the next State election, scheduled to be held by next March. As head of the State Government and chairman of the nine-member State BN, Dompok has to demonstrate his vigour and vitality to ensure a victory for his party in the election. With less than a year for the current term of the State Assembly to expire, and with analysts saying Parti Bersatu Sabah is slowly gaining momentum, especially with the Kadazandusun community, the election is seen as an opportunity for Dompok to prove that he commands the majority support. Already questions have been asked about whether Dompok is capable of leading the BN into the next State election considering he has yet to prove his political strength after leaving PBS to form Parti Demokratik Sabah. Dompok and the 10 Assemblymen from the PDS won their State Assembly seats as PBS candidates in the 1994 State elections. This will be the first State election under the rotation system of the Chief Ministership introduced by the BN in 1994 after it took over the State administration from the PBS. Under the system, the Chief Ministership will be rotated for a two-year term among the Bumiputera Muslims, Chinese and non-Muslim Bumiputeras. Tun Sakaran Dandai, who is now the Yang di-Pertua Negri of Sabah, became the first Chief Minister under the system, and Dompok's appointment last week completes the first phase of the rotation. It is said that Dompok's surprise defeat to unknown Paul Nointien of PBS in the 1995 parliamentary elections was because the constituents were unhappy with him. And some say it was due to his decision to leave the PBS. The State BN expects Dompok's appointment as Chief Minister to strengthen the support and belief of the Kadazandusun community of the BN's power-sharing concept. If Dompok hopes to gain the respect and confidence of the other component parties, it would be important that he provide leadership based on consultation and trust. It will be wise to take heed of the advice of Sabah Umno liaison committee chief, Datuk Osu Sukam, that the fulfilment of the promise to rotate the Chief Ministership should not be allowed to overshadow efforts to win the State elections. He said what matters was the ability of the State BN Government to unite the people and to bring about progress. It is imperative that Dompok recognises the fact that it is crucial for the BN Government to provide an effective administration to gain the confidence of the people. Shortly after Deputy Prime Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim announced his appointment, Dompok acknowledged that he would be shouldering a ``very heavy burden''. Dompok said he would have the difficult task of putting Sabah's economy back on track as the State had not been spared the current economic problems affecting the country. To ensure continuity in the smooth implementation of policies and programmes that had been laid out by the BN, Dompok retained all the Ministers and his predecessor Datuk Yong Teck Lee in his new Cabinet line- up. Dompok will, however, have to appoint a new Muslim Bumiputera Finance Minister and Deputy Chief Minister to fill the vacancy left by Datuk Abdul Ghapur Salleh who declined re-appointment. It was a wise decision for Dompok to retain all the Ministers because to do otherwise would be disruptive to the State administration. However, there had been questions as to why Dompok made the unprecedented move of including Yong into the Cabinet. Yong is now the Minister in the Chief Minister's Department and he is to oversee the State Economic Planning Unit. Nevertheless, Yong's inclusion did not come as a surprise as on his last day as Chief Minister he told a Press conference that he was ready to continue serving the Government. Perhaps, Dompok sees Yong as an asset because he could share his experience as the immediate pastChief Minister and provide input to accelerate economic development. Dompok needs a reliable and action-oriented Cabinet to deal with the many complex and controversial problems and issues affecting the State, such as the problems posed by illegal immigrants and foreign workers. While the smooth transition of power between Yong and Dompok was seen as proof of maturity, it remains to be seen if the people at the grassroots have the same level of understanding. The next State election will determine whether or not the rotation of the Chief Minister's position is well-received by the people.

BC-Sri Lanka-Fighting, 1st Ld-Writethru,0412
Rebels say they killed 100 Sri Lankan soldiers; 400 wounded
Eds: RAISES reference to 400 injured. UPDATES with censorship. No pickup By NIRESH ELIATAMBY Associated Press Writer
COLOMBO, Sri Lanka (AP) _ Separatist Tamil Tiger rebels claimed Friday to have killed at least 100 soldiers in the latest fighting in northern Sri Lanka, and army officers said over 400 soldiers were wounded. Also Friday, President Chandrika Kumaratunda ordered all news reports on Sri Lanka's civil war be cleared by military censors. The government gave no reason for the measure, which it has used in the past. It also did not say how long censorship would last. The guerrillas' clandestine radio said they lost 20 fighters as they beat back a government offensive Thursday. The military spokesman would not confirm the casualties, but reported heavy fighting after government troops attacked rebel defenses near Kilinochchi, 170 miles to the north. The two-pronged assault aimed to wrest the region's main highway from guerrilla control. Some army officers, speaking on condition of anonymity, said 34 soldiers were killed and 420 wounded in 24 hours of fighting that saw troops advance only a half mile. In Colombo, state-run radio announced that hospitals were in urgent need of blood donations for the wounded. On Thursday, ambulances raced to hospitals in the Sri Lankan capital with wounded soldiers who had been airlifted from Kilinochchi. Government forces have been battling since May 1997 to capture a vital highway connecting the Jaffna Peninsula with the rest of Sri Lanka. The army captured the peninsula in 1996 from the Tamil rebels, who had run the area like a mini-state for five years. So far, the troops have captured about two-thirds of the highway, with 17 miles to go. At present, Jaffna's 500,000 people rely on air and sea deliveries of food and other supplies. The clandestine radio, Voice of Tigers, said the rebels found the bodies of 40 Sri Lankan soldiers and plan to hand them over to the Red Cross later today. It also said government troops carried away nearly 60 bodies. Their claims could not be verified, since the military has sealed the area off. The rebels, who are fighting for a separate homeland in the north and east, accuse the Sinhalese majority of oppressing the Tamil minority. The war has claimed 52,000 lives since it began in 1983.

Senior EU official calls on Japan to jump-start its economy
TOKYO (AP) _ Concerned that Japan has not done enough to bolster its sagging economy, a senior European Union official on Friday urged Tokyo to stimulate domestic demand with permanent tax cuts and more deregulation. ``Our overall interest is to avoid a major crisis in Japan,'' said Hans Friedrich Beseler, EU director general for external relations, after two days of talks between European economic officials and Japanese counterparts. Nurturing the Japanese economy back to good health is vital for helping the rest of the Asian region recover from its recent financial crisis, added Beseler, the head of the EU delegation. Beseler called on Japan to speed planned economic reforms designed to deregulate its economy and suggested that permanent tax cuts could provide a needed boost to lift consumer spending. The Japanese government has implemented a series of temporary income tax cuts, but has been reluctant to make these permanent due to fears of a ballooning budget deficit. The European trade official expressed concern over Japan's mounting trade surplus with EU member nations and the dramatic weakening of the yen in recent months, which makes Japanese imports less expensive in Europe. During the two-day talks, the EU team met with Eisuke Sakakibara, Japan's vice finance minister for international affairs, and Sakuya Fujiwara, deputy governor of the Bank of Japan, among other Japanese officials. Latvia says citizenship vote will improve Russian relations
Eds: Restores word `laws' in first graf.
RIGA, Latvia (AP) _ Latvia's parliament has given preliminary approval to changes in the citizenship laws which have so angered Russia that it has threatened trade sanctions against the small Baltic state. The Saeima passed the changes late Thursday by a vote of 57-16 after nine hours of often-heated debate. The measure must pass a final reading before becoming law. Russia, which accounts for about 20 percent of Latvia's foreign trade, in April said it would impose sanctions against Latvia unless it took quick and substantial steps to improve the status of Latvia's ethnic Russians, about 400,000 of whom do not have citizenship. Russia's complaint was couched in harsh words _ Moscow Mayor Yuri Luzhkov even accused Latvia of ``genocide'' _ raising fears in Latvia that its giant neighbor was becoming increasingly domineering. ``This vote was pivotal ... and we believe the decision to change the law will improve our relations with Russia,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Andrejs Pildegovics said Friday. President Guntis Ulmanis has called on the parliament take a final vote on the bill before the start of summer recess in two weeks. When Latvia became independent of the Soviet Union in 1991, it granted citizenship to people who had lived there before World War II and to their descendants. That left nearly a third of the country's residents stateless _ most of them ethnic Russians who had moved there under Josef Stalin's Russification drive or their descendants. The current citizenship law requires many of them to wait up to several years before being allowed to apply for naturalization. The proposed changes would grant citizenship to all children born in Latvia since independence and would elimnate the waits for other aspirants. But naturalization would still require a proficiency test in the Latvian language _ a sensitive issue for the ethnic Russians, many of whom lived and worked in communities where Russian was the only language. KUALA LUMPUR, Wed. - Consortiums operating the public transport service at the Kuala Lumpur International Airport have submitted a separate fare structure for passengers travelling between the airport and the Federal capital's outer limits. Similar to the zone system being implemented at the Sultan Abdul Aziz Shah International Airport in Subang, KLIA's zone fare structure would cover a minimum radius of 15km and a maximum of 105km. It is learnt the respective demarkations have been identified and submitted to the Entrepreneur Development Ministry for approval. The proposed zones are surrounding KLIA Sepang and Salak Tinggi (Zone 1); Banting, Beranang, Dengkil, Labu, Mantin and Sepang (Zone 2); Bangi, Beranang, Nilai, Subang Jaya and USJ (Zone 3); Kajang, Morib, Serdang, Seremban, Sungei Besi and Shah Alam (Zone 4). The remaining proposed zones are Bangsar, Cheras, Damansara, KL City Centre, Klang, Jalan Klang Lama, Petaling Jaya, Port Dickson and Taman Tun Dr Ismail (Zone 5); Jalan Duta, Linggi, Sungai Buloh (Zone 6); Ampang, Kuala Pilah, Segambut, Teluk Kemang (Zone 7); Setapak, Kuala Selangor, Wangsa Maju (Zone 8) and Batu Caves, Jinjang, Kepong, Selayang, Genting Highlands (Zone 9). It was learnt the proposed fare structure, under the zone system, ranged from RM30 to RM120 for a one-way trip for those using the limousine service. It could not be immediately established if executive coaches would be introduced to service them. This afternoon, Entrepreneur Development Minister Datuk Mustapa Mohamed announced a fare structure, ranging from RM6.50 to RM88 one-way, from KLIA to the Klang Valley, including the city centre. Although the Minister affirmed the trial runs would commence tomorrow, an industry source expected problems. ``While the Minister may have announced the rates, one wonders what the midnight charges would be,'' the source said. Explaining, the source said there were late flights at Subang and once the passenger checks out past midnight, a different rate is imposed. ``KLIA Sepang would also have late flights ... what would the rates be then?'' Besides this, the source added, KTM Bhd's Komuter service and stage bus services begin at dawn and end at midnight. ``What options would passengers have between midnight and dawn,'' he said.

KUALA LUMPUR, Wed. - KUB Holdings Bhd has suspended its operation of Somatel (Malaysia) Sdn Bhd's office in Mogadishu, Somalia, following the murder of its Malaysian manager on Monday. In the incident, Lt Commander (Rtd) Mohamed Rashid Musa, 40, was walking to a mosque to perform the Magrib prayers when three men dragged him to a van. He was shot in the head when he resisted and died at the Digfair Hospital, about 30 minutes later. KUB Holdings corporate communications general manager Natrah Abdullah said today the company had decided to suspend Somatel's operations and had recalled two other Malaysians working with the firm. ``We have directed our staff, Sabri Hashim and Azhar Othman, to return to Malaysia before a decision on Somatel is made. ``At this juncture, we cannot say when Somatel will resume operation.'' KUB Holdings is the majority shareholder of the telecommunication company while the remaining 30 per cent is held by Somali Telecommunications Services. Somatel has a staff of 96, of whom four are Malaysians. The other Malaysian with the company returned about two weeks ago. On the funeral arrangements, Natrah said Rashid's remains, accompanied by Sabri and Azhar, had been flown to Dubai and would be brought to Kuala Lumpur tomorrow. While describing Rashid as a ``committed and dedicated man'', Natrah said he was the first Malaysian to be based in Somalia, on completion of the United Nations Operations in Somalia (Unosom) peacekeeping mission in 1995. Rashid was Malaysia's naval representative for the Special Technical Team which planned and co-ordinated the withdrawal of about 20,000 multinational soldiers from Somalia, following the end of the UN's mandate in the country. In Klang, Rashid's mother, Hasnah Mohamad, 57, said he had called four times on Monday, speaking to her thrice, and once to his wife, Hasnah Mohamed Sharkan. ``Rashid told me that he intended to return to Malaysia in two weeks as he had several matters to attend to,'' she said, when met at her home in Taman Sri Andalas today. Rashid's wife, Hasnah, said her husband had advised her to look after their four children and ensure that they did not miss their daily prayers. The children are Masturah, 14, Abu Bakar, 13, Mohamed Ali, 10, and Ahmad Umar, six.

BC-Britain-Rolls-Royce, 3rd Ld-Writethru
Volkswagen apparently wins control of Rolls-Royce
Eds: UPDATES with BMW reaction, enthusiast group's bid also rejected; combines previous By DIRK BEVERIDGE AP Business Writer
LONDON (AP) _ Volkswagen AG apparently won shareholder approval Friday to buy Rolls-Royce Motor Cars Ltd. for 430 million pounds (dlrs 700 million), despite angry bursts of nationalism from small investors who wanted to keep the luxury carmaker British. Proxy votes and votes from big institutional shareholders apparently made the approval a done deal, but Vickers PLC, the corporation selling Rolls-Royce, delayed any announcement to formally count the ballots from the little shareholders who made the big noise. ``Should I call it now a Rolls-wagen?'' shareholder Rodney Crowe asked during Vickers' special meeting. ``What are we going to have? A flying lady on the front of the Beetle?'' Crowe said later. Some investors sounded like they were ready to refight World War II in a session where they first rejected a bid of 340 million pounds (dlrs 554 million) from rival German automaker BMW. ``For God's sake, try and take a broad view for the country,'' said Desmond Lake, drawing cheers in the packed auditorium when he referred to Volkswagen's history in Nazi Germany. Volkswagen faces not just vocal objections but some real potential hurdles at it moves to take over production of luxury Rolls-Royce and Bentley cars, which cost about dlrs 250,000 each. The jilted suitor, BMW, supplies some engines to Rolls-Royce and has threatened to cut off deliveries. BMW spokesman Uwe Mahla said in Munich that Friday's developments were ``for us a very suprising situation,'' and BMW sources said executives were holding an emergency meeting. Rolls-Royce PLC, a separate company that makes jet engines, controls the brand name and logo and has made it clear it would rather see the deal go to BMW, which happens to be its partner in a jet engine venture. Rolls-Royce PLC has not said whether it will negotiate with Volkswagen or try to block its use of the brand name. Asked about that, the Vickers chairman, Sir Colin Chandler, insisted that a 25-year-old contract that would let Rolls-Roye PLC veto the purchase of Rolls-Royce Motors Cars Ltd. by a foreign buyer is legally unenforceable. ``The trademark can't go anywhere else,'' Chandler said. ``We exclusively own the radiator, the Flying Lady and Bentley.'' But some shareholders expressed worries that the Rolls production line could be halted by the dispute. And at least one expressed disgust at the fight over a name that epitomizes handmade British luxury. ``It's harmful for Rolls-Royce PLC and it's harmful for Vickers and they don't seem to care,'' Carol Day said. ``They're behaving like 6-year-old children.'' The takeover announcement also was delayed by a Rolls-Royce enthusiasts group, Crewe Motors, which claimed it was on the verge of putting together a 500 million pound (dlrs 815 million) offer from private backers. Its chairman, Michael Shrimpton, who has failed to put together previous bids, forced Vickers to adjourn the meeting for nearly one hour, but the Vickers chairman was unconvinced and refused any further delays. KUALA LUMPUR, Wed. - Terrestrial television stations have been given a grace period of six months from now to fully abide by the Information Ministry's recent directive to air only local programmes during prime time. However, Information Minister Datuk Mohamed Rahmat said today the stations had to enforce the ruling partially. He made the decision following an appeal from the stations. ``They are willing to adhere but they are facing many problems. At this stage, they can only implement the ruling partially,'' he told reporters after attending the Cabinet meeting. Among the problems cited by the stations' officials were getting local programmes. This is because many production houses are facing economic problems. Mohamed said the television stations also stated that they needed time to reschedule their programmes. Last month, Mohamed had announced that all terrestrial television stations must air local programmes during prime time from 8pm to 10pm beginning from Monday or face having their licences revoked.

KUALA LUMPUR, Wed. - The Cabinet today ordered the National Disaster Management and Relief Committee to call for an immediate meeting with Indonesia for steps to tackle forest fires and the haze to be implemented fast. Committee chairman Datuk Mohamed Rahmat said this was to allay fears among participants of Sukom '98 and convince them that measures were being taken to prevent the haze during the event. ``There are less than 100 days to the Games. Steps have to be taken to convince them,'' he said after the Cabinet meeting. As such, he would arrange for the meeting to be held in Indonesia this month. The meeting, to be the first for the recently formed joint action committee, is to discuss the implementation of measures stipulated under the memorandum of understanding on disasters between Malaysia and Indonesia. The MoU was signed by Mohamed and Indonesia's then National Disaster Management Co-ordinating Board chairman Azwar Anas on Dec 11. The initial objective of the MoU was for Malaysia and Indonesia to collectively tackle the haze problem but it was later decided to include other areas of co-operation. It now covers all natural or man-made disasters. Indonesia will be represented by its Minister for People's Welfare and Poverty Alleviation Haryono Suyono and Mohamed will lead Malaysia's delegation. ``We have to implement the measures under the MoU so that Indonesia's open burning problems can be tackled collectively to prevent a recurrence of the haze,'' said Mohamed, who is also the Information Minister. Mohamed said a change in wind direction, from northeasterly to southwesterly, would bring smoke to Malaysia if there were fires in Indonesia. Therefore, early measures need to be taken to prevent a haze. Mohamed said latest satellite images showed several hotspots in Sumatra. Meanwhile, France has agreed to assist Malaysia with expertise in fighting land and forest fires. This was made possible with the disaster management and relief agreement signed between Mohamed and French Home Minister Jean Pierre Chevenement in Paris last Monday. Among others, Malaysia is planning to make use of France's training institutes to train local fire-fighters. Mohamed said he had seen France's sophisticated fire-fighting equipment. Asked if Malaysia had to purchase or borrow the equipment, he said: ``They are willing to negotiate terms.'' Malaysia is also planning to purchase aircraft, not necessarily from France, which can be used to fight land and forest fires locally and across the border.

KUALA LUMPUR, Wed. - The Cabinet today approved public transportation fares ranging from RM6.50 to RM88 for a one-way trip to the Kuala Lumpur International Airport in Sepang. The fares structure for KTM Bhd Komuter trains, executive coaches, limousine and multi-purpose vehicle service was comparatively lower than that of airports in the region and globally, Entrepreneur Development Minister Datuk Mustapa Mohamed said. ``After numerous reviews, we have concluded that this would be the most appropriate fare structure,'' he said. Speaking to reporters after opening the Ministry's Small Entrepreneur Service Centre at Mara headquarters in Jalan Raja Laut, he said: ``When compared to similar services offered at airports in the region, it (fare structure at KLIA) is among the lowest.'' For limousines, passengers who pay for the budget service will travel in a Proton Wira, while those who opt for the premier service will ride in a Proton Perdana, Mercedes Benz or the Fiat Ulysses MPV. ``The consortium overseeing the limousine service has prepared 350 Wiras, 200 Perdanas, 150 Mercedes Benz and 100 MPVs to complement the fleet,'' Mustapa said. ``An added incentive for passengers who opt for the limousine service is the chance to purchase a return trip ticket at RM98 and RM140 for the budget and premier services respectively,'' he said. Asked to comment on the reduction in the number of vehicles complementing the fleet from the previous figure of 1,100, Mustapa said: ``They (the consortium) revised the figures based on their forecast of passenger traffic.'' However, he gave the assurance that there would be sufficient public transportation at KLIA. Red-and-white taxis operating in the Klang Valley will also allowed to ferry passengers to the new airport at RM46. ``A surcharge, which is yet to be decided, will be imposed as these the drivers are not allowed to fetch passengers from the airport,'' he said. Mustapa said the executive coaches, to be operated by Kuala Lumpur City Bus, would offer two types of service. ``The dedicated service between KLIA and KLCB's temporary terminal in Jalan Duta will operate semi-luxury and luxury fleets,'' he said. ``Those travelling from KLIA to the city aboard the executive coach (luxury service) will be given the option to alight at the temporary terminal or at any six designated hotels along the route.'' Mustapa said KLCB would also operate a stage bus service from its temporary terminal to KLIA to cater to the needs of employees there. Charging RM7.70 per trip, the stage bus will pick up passengers at Subang and Kampung Subang before proceeding to KLIA. It is also available to the public. Those using the KTM Komuter service will board at the Kuala Lumpur station and alight at the Batang Benar station (Nilai) before boarding a KLCB shuttle service to the airport. ``We have instructed the companies to commence trial runs for the respective services this Friday and Saturday,'' Mustapa said. A final trial run will be carried out about four days before the KLIA's official opening on June 29.

Lebed inaugurated as governor of Siberian region
Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 6th graf, `All the ...,' to UPDATE with Lebed vowing to reorganize administration.
MOSCOW (AP) _ Former Russian security chief Alexander Lebed was sworn in Friday as governor of a huge region in central Siberia _ a post seen by many as a springboard to the presidency. During the solemn inauguration ceremony, Lebed took an oath on the Bible and was blessed by Bishop Antoniy, leader of the Russian Orthodox Church in the Krasnoyarsk region. He dressed in a tuxedo for the occasion _ a significant choice of clothes in a country where tuxedos were once deemed unacceptably ``bourgeois.'' Lebed, a gravel-voiced former paratroop general, ran for president in 1996 and has long said he plans to run again. However, he played down those ambitions during the gubernatorial race, saying he would only run for president in 2000 if he succeeds in improving the economy in Krasnoyarsk. Speaking to reporters after his inauguration, he criticized Moscow for keeping the lion's share of the country's money, but said he hoped to reach agreement with the federal government over funding rather than provoke a confrontation. ``All the blood is in the head. I fear the country may suffer a heart attack,'' he said, in one of his typically homespun aphorisms. Returning to a campaign theme, he promised a dramatic reorganization of the regional administration, and said all government workers in the region will have to prove their worth or face dismissal, the ITAR-Tass news agency reported. Boris Berezovsky, a controversial Russian business mogul who supported Lebed's run for governor, attended his inauguration and hailed him as a ``serious Russian politician.'' However Berezovsky, now serving in government as executive secretary of the alliance former Soviet republics, quickly added that Lebed would be a ``big problem for the nation'' if elected Russian president. Berezovsky has previously said that he helped Lebed's election in Krasnoyarsk so he would get bogged down in the region's problems and be less able to run for president in 2000. Lebed has denied he received any financial assistance from Berezovsky. Lebed finished a strong third in Russia's last presidential election in 1996. Later that year he received nationwide acclaim for his role in negotiating the end to the deeply unpopular war in secessionist Chechnya. (vi/ml/mr/ls)

BC-Yugoslavia-Kosovo,0684
Kosovo Albanians talk of 50 deaths, destroyed villages
By ISMET HAJDARI Associated Press Writer
PRISTINA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ More than 50 Kosovo Albanians have been killed and about 200 are missing since Serbian government forces started an offensive in the independence-minded province a week ago, an ethnic Albanian leader said Friday. In Geneva, the United Nations refugee agency said some of the 400 or so Kosovo Albanians who trekked into neighboring Albania overnight reported five deaths en route _ two elderly people, said to have died of exhaustion, and three small children. About 10,000 refugees have gathered around Tropoja in northern Albania. In the reported government offensive in Kosovo, four villages populated by ethnic Albanians were destroyed, and another eight badly damaged, said Osman Cacaj, an official of the Democratic League of Kosovo, the ethnic Albanians' main party. Sixteen other villages are deserted as residents fled, Cacaj added. He listed more than 50 dead and some 200 missing from the latest offensive, concentrated around Decani, some 70 kilometers (45 miles) west of Kosovo's capital, Pristina. Ethnic Albanians form 90 percent of Kosovo's 2 million people and demand independence from Serbia and the Yugoslav federation it forms with Montenegro. Accounts such as Cacaj's are impossible to verify independently, as both Serbian police forces and gunmen from the Kosovo Liberation Army _ fighting for independence _ block adequate access to journalists and even humanitarian workers. Kosovo Albanian leaders say information comes from individuals who manage to pass Serbian roadblocks and reach Pristina. Telephone access to the area of the offensive has been cut for days. Cacaj described the area around Decani as a deserted wasteland, with some 45 bodies left unburied, farm animals roaming wild and several thousand civilians hiding in the woods, trying to cross the border into neighboring Albania or to Montenegro. The Serb Media Center in Pristina, close to the Serbian authorities, said meanwhile that a Yugoslav army general, Nebojsa Pavkovic, made a surprise visit to a still-inhabited village in the area, Batusa, inviting any Albanians who fled to return on condition armed men turn in weapons and halt attacks on police and army. During Bosnia's 1992-95 war, such warnings were often a prelude to a Serb attack on grounds that the community in question failed to comply. More than 250 people have died since March 1 in escalating clashes between government forces and the Kosovo Liberation Army, the armed wing of the Albanian independence movement, which Albanian political leaders say acts independently from them. The clandestine KLA, which first surfaced in 1996, says the peaceful principles of the top Kosovo Albanian leader, Ibrahim Rugova, are futile. A delegation picked by Rugova and officials chosen by Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic, who stripped Kosovo of its broad autonomy in 1989, opened a dialogue under Western pressure last month. Agreement appears unlikely. The ethnic Albanians canceled a meeting scheduled Friday in Pristina, saying they could not talk with the Serbs while the latest offensive lasts. The Serbs showed up anyway for the talks, to which Christopher Hill, U.S. ambassador to neighboring Macedonia, is serving as unofficial mediator. Hill noted that it is ``extremely difficult'' to get a true picture of events around Decani. ``The problem is you talk to one side, you get one view, you talk to the other side, you get a view of 180 degrees,'' he said. Rugova's aides are showing more and more sympathy for the KLA, which only weeks ago they shunned. ``Serbs systematically shell the villages in the war zone, burn and destroy Albanian settlements,'' said Rugova's spokesman Xhemail Mustafa. ``The Serb regime has declared and imposed war on ethnic Albanians. Therefore, we understand the people's self-organizing on the ground and their efforts to defend from aggression.''

Twenty-eight-year-old sun bear Tina cuddling her healthy newborn, Juma, at Zoo Negara yesterday. Juma was named after the day and month (in Bahasa Malaysia) she was born. She was delivered on Friday, March 27, and is the first surviving sun bear (helarctos malayanus malayanus) cub at Zoo Negara in 21 years. Juma's birth was a pleasant surprise as her mother's pregnancy was not known to any of the zoo keepers. There are seven sun bears at the zoo, two males and five females. Zoo keeper Ishak Bakar said it was by chance that the mother was separated from the rest of the sun bears before she gave birth. Cubs born in a group have little chance of survival. Sun bears are solitary animals, preferring to be alone, except for mating. In a group they often fight over territory dominance. Cubs born in a group are usually eaten or stepped on by their mother to protect them from other bears. ``One morning, I found her cuddling her newborn. They have since remained isolated in a cubicle,'' Ishak said. Sun bears are one of the smallest of the world's eight bear species and are affectionately known as the ``honey bears'', which refers to their favourite food. They stand less than a metre at the shoulder and weigh between 25 and 65 kilogrammes. Besides honey, they feed on carrots, papayas, milk, sugar cane, bananas and eggs.

BC-UN-Ethiopia-Refugees,0270
U.N. refugee agency says five year refugee return operation ends
GENEVA (AP) _ The last of thousands of Ethiopian refugees who fled to nearby Sudan to escape fighting in their country are leaving for home Friday, the U.N. refugee agency said. Around 680 refugees are due to travel back to Ethiopia in convoys organized by the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees, UNHCR spokeswoman Judith Kumin said in Geneva. Some of the refugees have been in exile in Sudan for 20 years after fleeing fighting which broke out between Ethiopian government forces and Eritrean independence fighters. The Eritreans gained formal independence in 1993 after helping Ethiopian rebels end 17 years of harsh military rule in Ethiopia. The final convoys bring to an end a five-year UNHCR repatriation program, which has helped some 71,000 Ethiopian refugees to return to Ethiopia. An additional 8,500 still in Sudan have told UNHCR they want to stay there and are having their cases reviewed, agency spokesman Paul Stromberg said. UNHCR has also discussed with Eritrea's government the possibility of returning some 150,000 Eritrean refugees still in Sudan, Stromberg said. If all goes well, the return could take place this autumn. Meanwhile, another UNHCR repatriation program in Africa was completed this week, the agency said. Some 370 Tuareg refugees, described by UNHCR as ``mostly nomadic people,'' were returned from Algeria to Niger, the last of some 4,000 who have returned after fleeing armed conflict and drought in Niger in the early 1990s.

VENDORS dealing in illegal software will soon find it more difficult to set up operations in Selangor as the State authorities go ahead with their plan to ramp up enforcement activities. Specifically, the State Consumer Affairs Department (SCA) will start mounting operations to nab illegal software vendors and manufacturers after June 14, said State Executive Councillor Datuk Tang See Hang. He added that the use of illegal software is still rampant, and the State's aim is to ensure that all commercial vendors are aware of the legal aspects of using pirated software. ``Even with the Copyright Act 1997, many commercial vendors and manufacturers still seemed to be unaware of the implications of using illegal software,'' he said. Before the enforcement drive takes place, Tan said the SCA would first try to raise awareness on the matter through an educational campaign in the form of a seminar. The seminar aims to create awareness on the importance of using legal software among traders, manufacturers and software developers. ``In addition to that, software developers as well as members of the public can also learn about their rights in using legal software from the seminar,'' Tang said. The seminar, to be held in Petaling Jaya on June 14, is being organised by the SCA, the Selangor MCA Youth High Tech Bureau and Malaysia Cyber Youth.

BC-India-Religious Riots,0202
Pamphlets spark Hindu-Muslim rioting
HYDERABAD, India (AP) _ Muslims incensed by pamphlets denigrating their religion stormed from Friday prayers to attack Hindus, police in the southern city of Hyderabad said. Twenty-five people were injured. The mob dispersed when police fired into the air. Hyderabad police chief Ram Pratap Singh said several hundred worshippers emerged from the main weekly prayers at the city's historic Mecca Masjid, or Mecca Mosque, protesting the pamphlet. Some in the crowd began throwing stones at city buses carrying Hindus, and three Hindus were stabbed, Singh said. Four shops belonging to Hindus were burned, Singh said. Pamphlets that first turned up on the streets of Hyderabad earlier this week included a drawing of Islamic holy places under the foot of the Hindu god Ganesh, with Hindi-language text claiming Ganesh as the god of all. It was unclear who has been distributing the pamphlets. Hyderabad, about 1,300 kilometers (about 800 miles) south of New Delhi, has a history of religious tension. Its population of nearly 4.5 million people is half Muslim, while Hindus are the overwhelming majority elsewhere in India.

BUTTERWORTH, Wed. - Lack of co-operation among the various State fisheries departments' enforcement units has been identified as the major cause for the rampant smuggling of cockle spats from several west coast States to a neighbouring country. State Agriculture, Fisheries and Environment Committee chairman Datuk Abdul Rashid Abdullah said today by failing to liaise with one another, efforts to check the smuggling of the shellfish, which have run into several million ringgit over the past few years, had proved futile. ``For example, we have found out that some State fisheries department's enforcement units had failed to alert their counterparts in another State when several lorry-loads of cockle spats had left for another State enroute to its destination. ``The errant units might have learnt about the attempted smuggling of late, but they should still inform their counterparts in other States to nab the perpetrators,'' he said without naming the errant State fisheries departments' enforcement units. Abdul Rashid was asked to comment on a memorandum submitted to him recently by the Seberang Prai Fishermen's Association over the rampant smuggling of cockle spats from several States in the west coast to a neighbouring country. He said checks also showed that the smugglers, preferring to carry out their activity by land, travelled through special routes in Perak and Kelantan to reach their final destination, usually Hatyai in southern Thailand. ``Consumption of cockles in Thailand is very high and the people there prefer our cockles to their home-bred shellfish. ``The smugglers usually cart away several hundred gunny sacks of cockle spats at any one time. ``It is a very lucrative activity which, if left unchecked, could adversely affect the local cockle-breeding industry,'' he said. Abdul Rashid also said lack of enforcement by the units had contributed to the rampant encroachment of fishermen from other States in Penang waters.

U.N. refugee agency says five year refugee return operation ends

GENEVA (AP) _ The last of thousands of Ethiopian refugees who fled to nearby Sudan to escape fighting in their country are leaving for home Friday, the U.N. refugee agency said. Around 680 refugees are due to travel back to Ethiopia in convoys organized by the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees, UNHCR spokeswoman Judith Kumin said in Geneva. The final convoys bring to an end a five year UNHCR repatriation program which has helped some 71,000 Ethiopian refugees to return to Ethiopia. Some of the refugees have been in exile in Sudan for 20 years after fleeing fighting, which broke out between Ethiopian government forces and Eritrean independence fighters. The Eritreans gained formal independence in 1993 after helping Ethiopian rebels end 17 years of harsh military rule in Ethiopia. An additional 8,500 still in Sudan have told UNHCR they want to stay there and are having their cases reviewed, agency spokesman Paul Stromberg said. UNHCR has also discussed with Eritrea's government the possibility of returning some 150,000 Eritrean refugees still in Sudan, Stromberg said. If all goes well, the return could take place this autumn. Meanwhile, another UNHCR repatriation program in Africa was completed this week, the agency said. Some 370 Tuareg refugees, described by UNHCR as ``mostly nomadic people,'' were returned from Algeria to Niger, the last of some 4,000 who have returned after fleeing armed conflict and drought in Niger in the early 1990s.

GALLE, Sri Lanka (AP) _ Sri Lanka's latest batting discovery Mahela Jayawardena frustrated New Zealand with an unbeaten 88 as his team overtook the touring side's first innings total of 193 Friday, the third day of the second Test at the Galle cricket stadium. The home team ended the day at 197 for 3. The 21-year old Jayawardena occupied the crease for 177 minutes, hitting eight fours for his third successive half century in the series. Although reducing New Zealand to a low total, Sri Lanka did not produce the best of starts. Opener Sanath Jayasuriya was back in the pavilion in the 13th over of the innings for just 21 runs. But Jayawardena and Marvan Atapattu lifted the side with a 62-run stand for the second wicket before off-spinner Paul Wiseman broke the alliance by having the latter caught by Vettori at short fine-leg for 36. Earlier in the day off-cutter Kumara Dharmasena made inroads into the New Zealand batting when he plucked three quick wickets in the morning session to leave the tourists at a lunch time score of 162 for 8 from an overnight 122 for 5. Bowling his first over for the day, Dharmasena had Nathan Astle picked up by short-leg Hashan Tillekaratne for 53 and in his following over got rid of Chris Cairns who glanced a ball into leg-slip Sanath Jayasuriya without scoring. Dharmasena then sent back Chris Harris, caught at mid-on for four runs, and wrapped up the New Zealand innings shortly after lunch by claiming the wickets of Adam Parore for 30 and Paul Wiseman for 23. Parore top-edged at sweep shot and was caught at fine-leg after which fell Wiseman who was stumped while attempting a big hit. Dharmasena finished with career-best figures of 6 for 72, the best by a Sri Lankan against New Zealand. More than eight hours of play has been lost in the match so far due to wet conditions. (str,db)

Poland will not make Auschwitz memorial extraterritorial
WARSAW, Poland (AP) _ Poland will not consider a suggestion by a Jewish leader to grant extraterritorial status to the memorial of the former Nazi death camp of Auschwitz, an official said Friday. Krzysztof Sliwinski, a foreign ministry official for dialogue with the Jewish Diaspora, said in a telephone interview that the suggestion is an isolated idea that was never made or discussed officially. ``It does not mean, when a place is listed on the UNESCO list as an historic heritage, that the sovereignty of the state can be limited,'' Sliwinski said. Kalman Sultanik, deputy head of the World Jewish Congress, said on Polish private Radio Plus Thursday that ``a way must be found to make Auschwitz extraterritorial.'' He said that local authorities do ``not always remember what Auschwitz means to the Jews. Auschwitz is the symbol of Shoah and the Holocaust.'' Some 1.5 million people, mostly Jews, died in the camp's gas chambers or from hunger, disease and forced labor there between 1940-45. Jewish protests have led to the removal of a convent from the museum's neighborhood and to changing plans to build a mini mall across from the museum to a visitors' center. Jewish leaders continue to protest the presence of a tall cross in the former camp's vicinity. A special committee of Jewish leaders, Auschwitz survivors, historians and Polish officials was formed three years ago to advise on decisions concerning the museum's future. (ms-gb)

Thais rely on eggs to gauge the state of the economy, or more precisely the parity between their pocketbooks and price levels. The public went up in arms when the price of an egg rose beyond the Bt1-mark -- the first time in the country's history -- during the Kriangsak Chamanan administration in 1977-1980. A little over a decade later, former prime minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh was called a feeble leader when egg prices rose beyond Bt2. Now, after spending barely seven months in office, Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai probably wishes to trade places with an egg since he's in the frying pan already. In the last month egg prices leapt from Bt3 to a record high of Bt5 for the largest egg. ''Eggs are off the menu now; prices are not only high, they are unbelievable,'' commented a food vendor in Praves market. However, to be only fair, there are cheaper eggs than the Bt5 variety. Smaller eggs, size one to five could cost between Bt2.3 and Bt3. A mid-size egg, the most popular, would be slightly over Bt3 while the smallest one is most sought after due to its low price. Even though consumers choose sizes to match their budget they sometimes have to do without because the smaller eggs are often out of supply. Chachoengsao Chicken Cooperatives' president Manoch Chutaptim reasoned that the sudden jump in prices had probably been triggered by the 40-per cent rise in the cost for chicken feed and this year's severe dry season which stopped hens from laying eggs. A worker wryly posed the question of what the underprivileged should eat. ''Pla Thu and egg used to be the favourite food for the poor. The fish got out of reach years ago. Now eggs are becoming expensive,'' she said.

MORE than 40,000 people rallied in driving rain to commemorate the anniversary of the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown for the first time under Chinese rule. The turnout at the candlelight vigil was smaller than last year's 55,000 but organisers said it was the spirit and not the numbers that mattered. Torrential rain was blamed by organisers for the smaller crowd. The annual vigil, at which exiled Chinese dissidents Wang Dan and Wei Jingsheng appealed to Hong Kong to continue the fight for democracy in the mainland, started under an amber rainstorm signal and a thunderstorm warning. The rainstorm forced the organisers _ the Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movement in China _ to cut the vigil back to just over one hour. The Democratic Party's Szeto Wah, who heads the alliance, said: ``This (crowd) shows Hong Kong people's consistency in supporting the June 4 (memorial). ``It proves that there is a wish for democracy.'' Sitting under umbrellas, the demonstrators sang along with pro-democracy legislators Mr Szeto, Andrew Cheng Kar-foo, Lee Cheuk-yan, Lee Wing-tat, Albert Ho Chun-yan and Lau Chin-shek, to mourn those killed in Tiananmen Square on June 4, 1989. Under a banner that read ``Vindication of June 4'', the crowd lit candles after university students from the Hong Kong Federation of Students lit a flame. The vigil started after a giant wreath was presented in front of a stage to remember those killed. Wreaths were also placed under the ``Pillar of Shame''. In Victoria Park, prominent dissidents Mr Wang and Mr Wei, who were freed by Beijing on medical parole, addressed the crowd via telephone link from the US. Speaking from New York Mr Wang said the vigil meant a lot to the democracy movement in China and wished he could be there. ``Within China, only people in Hong Kong can enjoy freedom and democracy. It is very important that Hong Kong people keep this up,'' he said. Mr Wei said: ``Now Hong Kong is part of China, the democratic movement of Hong Kong determines the future of China. If people in Hong Kong protect their democracy, it will set an example to the whole of China.'' Democratic Party leader Martin Lee Chu-ming said the rain had never dampened the people's faith in democracy. ``It does not matter that it is raining. The quest for democracy in Hong Kong was born in the rain,'' he said. In Japan, visiting Chief Secretary for Administration Anson Chan Fang On-sang said the vigil proved the government was determined to maintain the rights and freedoms of Hong Kong people. ``There has been no attempt whatsoever on the part of leaders in Beijing to interfere in any way in the exercise of these rights and freedoms,'' Mrs Chan said. In the US, Chinese dissidents and US legislators marked the event by urging President Clinton to avoid Tiananmen Square during his upcoming visit to China.

MR A, who received a master's degree in finance from a famous university in the United States, was fired last year when the finance and securities company he worked for was shut down. After receiving a salary of Bt45,000 a month from the company, Mr A, a former investment banker, now earns only Bt7,700 per month from a state agency. Mr A would certainly be unable to command the same high salary if he still worked for the private company due to the bearish stock market sentiment which has caused reductions in the securities companies' brokerage fees and other income. According to a recent report of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the 22 finance and securities companies' annual overhead was Bt429,908 for each of the 7,051 employees. Meanwhile, 21 securities companies' annual overhead was Bt588,564 for each of 3,689 employees, or Bt49,047 a month. Data released by the report indicated operators of the securities businesses are in deep trouble. Revenue of all finance and securities companies dropped sharply from 1996 levels. In 1996, they earned a total of Bt51.3 billion, while last year the 25 companies earned only Bt12.3 billion, a 76 per cent drop. The revenue generated by the suspended companies was negative Bt7 billion, mainly because of the shorter interest accrual period and investment losses. Securities companies' revenue also dropped sharply from Bt4.8 billion a year earlier to minus Bt6.124 billion last year due to lower broking fees, fee-based income, as well as net interest and dividend income and investment losses. Last year, operating securities companies earned only Bt11.6 billion in net interest and dividend income while the suspended companies' was minus Bt7.3 billion. In 1996, their interest and dividend income reached Bt39 billion. Their broking fees were only Bt7.4 billion -- Bt5.6 billion generated by still-operating companies and Bt1.8 billion by the suspended companies. In 1996, broking fees were Bt11.1 billion. Of the 43 operating companies, there were only nine whose broking fees were between Bt200 and Bt550 million, while the other 34 companies recorded broking fees below Bt200 million. The fee-based income of the 43 companies was only Bt1.5 billion, compared to Bt5.1 billion a year earlier. Their investments also generated much less revenue. The 23 finance and securities companies had an outstanding investment value in the stock market of Bt41 billion at the end of last year. They recorded a loss of Bt6 billion.Securities companies performed much more poorly. While their outstanding investment in the corresponding period was Bt17 billion, their investment churned out Bt11.8 billion in losses. No one in the securities business dares say when the black cloud hovering over the industry will disappear. What they fear most is their deteriorating conditions, which could make them attractive targets for foreign investors. If he had remained in the closed company, Mr A might have benefitted from his fluent English but he would not be able to command the same salary he once received.
