Taxi fares in Tokyo high by international standards
TOKYO (AP) _ When you have the chance to take a cab in Tokyo, check your wallet first. A new survey shows Japan's taxis are the priciest in the industrialized world. The Transport Ministry compared fares in Japan in October with those in Britain, France, Germany and the United States _ and found Japan's taxis sometimes charge twice as much, a news report said. Against a base figure of 100 for Japan, daytime taxi fares over a distance of 5 kilometers (3 miles) stood at 59 in the United States, 72 in Germany, 73 in Britain _ and less than half at 45 in France, Kyodo News reported. A majority of taxi drivers in France, Germany and the United States are immigrants or part-time workers receiving low wages, contributing to lower fares, the ministry said. But the subways in Japan are a steal _ compared to some countries. The ministry reported subway fares came to 86 in Paris, 96 in New York, 123 in Frankfurt and 156 in London against 100 for Tokyo. Taxi fares, however, are getting cheaper for international travelers, thanks to the depreciation of the yen against the U.S. dollar. The ministry's fare comparisons were made at an exchange rate of 121 yen to the dollar, which on Friday bought 139 yen _ meaning a 1,000-yen fare that cost dlrs 8.25 in October is now only dlrs 7.19. TWELVE mega-projects which have a potential of generating 53,000 jobs cannot be brought forward despite high unemployment, according to Secretary for Works Kwong Hon-sang. He made his comments as he unveiled five projects to be accelerated by at least two to five months to create an additional 531 jobs late this year. ``Accelerating major infrastructure projects is not always possible because some key activities do take time, such as authorisation of works under statutory requirements, thorough investigation and design works,'' Mr Kwong said. Among the mega-projects which will not be advanced are Kowloon Canton Railway's West Rail Phase 1 and Ma On Shan Line, Mass Transit Railway Tseung Kwan O Extension, Route 10 from North Lantau to Yuen Long, and Route 9 from Tsing Yi and Cheung Sha Wan. Financial Secretary Sir Donald Tsang Yam-kuen pledged on Wednesday to advance public works projects as part of the 12-point package to solve unemployment. The package which will generate 100,000 jobs in the next 18 months was criticised by trade unionists and academics because it will have a small effect on reducing unemployment. Chief Secretary for Administration Anson Chan Fang On-sang said in Tokyo that the government was concerned over the steady increase in unemployment. Mr Kwong was worried that the construction industry could suffer from a labour shortage if the major infrastructure projects are accelerated at the same time. ``We learned that developers may have a problem if these major projects are advanced,'' he said. Mr Kwong guaranteed that there would be more infrastructure projects within the next few years after the completion of new airport projects. ``Hong Kong will not come to a standstill in 20 months,'' Mr Kwong said. ``I can assure you that there will be more infrastructure projects within the next five to 10 years.'' Independent legislator-elect Raymond Ho Chung-tai was disappointed with the government's decision not to accelerate some major infrastructure projects. ``Infrastructure projects should be speeded up in preparation for the increase in population,'' he said. Head of the department of economics at Lingnan College Ho Lok-sang said accelerating projects would not really solve unemployment. ``You are just advancing the creation of jobs but it will not have an effect on the jobs available in the long term,'' he said.

THE drop in domestic car sales has caused Swedish Motors Corporation Plc (SMC), distributor of Volvo, to adopt a downsizing policy which includes closing down five of its eight service centres in Bangkok and 27 nationwide. Geoffrey Rowe, SMC's senior executive vice president, said the economic downturn had forced the company to concentrate more on customer satisfaction. After it experienced a 70 per cent year-on-year slowdown in sales last September, Auto Technic (Thailand) Co, distributor of Saab, closed down all but one showroom and service centre in the country. Rowe said SMC's restructuring would not only help increase its sales by 10 per cent per annum but would also keep it on track to become a market leader in the European car segment in the millennium. Volvo has currently captured around 25 per cent of the market. However, to hold the first rank SMC would have to outdo Mercedes Benz's coverage of 30 per cent. Although, the closure of SMC's service centres has helped reduce costs by Bt10 million per month it has not helped stimulate sales. To compensate SMC has shifted its focus on improvement of services and efficiency, particularly in the area of workshop planning and a reduction in repeat repair jobs. SMC has also adopted a pricing policy to bring its component prices down to the same level as its competitors. In addition, it has increased its stocks by ordering parts worth Bt60 million in a bid to offer quick service. Its stock at present, worth Bt185 million, is only able to cover 85 per cent of SMC's capacity. The company plans to raise its capacity to 93 per cent in the near future, which would increase the value of its stocks to around Bt200 to Bt210 million. SMC also plans to become a one-stop-shop by providing products like engine oil, brake oil, car wax, shampoo and carpeting. Under the new structure SMC expects to generate sales of 1,200 units this year, a 70 per cent drop when compared to last year's sale of 2.843 units. ''Although we recorded the sales of this year's first five months at 334 units, we believe we will be able to reach the sales target this year since new products would surge our revenue,'' said Rowe. In the fourth quarter of this year SMC also plans to launch the S40 and the V40 models. The sale of European cars is expected to drop to 3,000 units this year against last year's 5,000 units. Volvo's monthly sales have fallen to around 10 units per showroom compared to around 30 to 40 units last year.

THE Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) on Thursday charged Thai Modern Plastic Industry Plc (TM) with falsifying its 1997 financial statement. A statement released by the watchdog said the company doctored the amount of its outstanding loans in its annual financial statement for the fiscal year ending Dec 31, 1997. The charge has already been reported to inspectors of the Economic Crime Suppression Unit for further investigation, the statement noted. The SEC found the actual amount of outstanding loans extended by 31 banks and financial institutions stood at Bt4.7 billion. However, the audited financial statement reported only Bt2.2 billion. Company executives could not be reached for comment. ''We are not ready to give any details right now. The investigation process is now ongoing,'' a public relations officer said. Auditors of the company will also be investigated. According to a filing to the Stock Exchange of Thailand, TM's financial statement was audited by Dr Virat Apimateethamrong whose licence number is 1378. Trading was suspended in TM shares on Thursday. Its latest share price was Bt1.50. The SEC has also informed the SET of the matter in order that the information be disclosed to investors. TM is a manufacturer and distributor of plastic products, including plastic film and sheets, containers, foam flooring, cushion material and fibreglass insect screens. The company's paid-up capital is Bt450 million. The Pannamaneechot family is a major shareholder in the company with its 36 per cent stake. Other shareholders include Thailand Securities Depository Co Ltd for foreign and local depositors.

KARACHI, Pakistan (AP) _ The bound and tortured bodies of four men were found Friday in the violent eastern district of Pakistan's largest city, which has been dominated by an ongoing feud between rival factions of an ethnic group, police said. Police believe the deaths were linked to the feud in Karachi, where 30 people have been killed in the past one month, police said. Two of the victims found Friday belonged to the smaller Haqiqi faction of the Mohajir Qami Movement, which represents Muslims who came to Pakistan when it was created from a larger India in 1947 by the departing British. The other two bodies have not been identified. The Movement split several years ago. The larger faction is led by Altaf Hussein, who lives in self-imposed exile in Britain. The government is trying to negotiate with the two factions to try to curb the violence, officials in Karachi said. Other government officials have gone to Britain to meet Hussein to ask him to rein in his activists. The violence accelerated in April after a bloody night of fighting killed 21 people, many of them Hussein activists. Since then, activists from both factions have been kidnapped, their bodies found days or hours later often badly mutilated, said police. The latest round of killings is the bloodiest since Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's Pakistan Muslim League won elections in February 1997. Both factions are adamantly opposed to former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto. Many people hoped Sharif would have been able to curb the violence.

Private farmers call for government support
AP Photo available.
MOSCOW (AP) _ Independent farmers picketed outside the main government building Friday, demanding long-promised loans to help start private businesses in a country where most land is still farmed collectively. ``Russian farmers have lost patience,'' the Russian Farmers Union said in a statement. ``For three years, farmers have been denied the credits allotted to them in the budget.'' Farmers' representatives later met with deputy prime minister Boris Nemtsov who promised to extend 700 million rubles (dlrs 113 million) in credits to the private farmers. Private farms are still rare in Russia, and they are struggling for survival. While criticizing the government for failing to come through with promised loans, the farmers praised President Boris Yeltsin for vetoing a restrictive land bill passed by the parliament. The issue of land ownership in Russia remains highly controversial. Since the Soviet breakup, Russians have been permitted to own land in urban areas, but most agricultural plots remain state property and are farmed collectively as in Soviet times. Yeltsin considers land privatization to be essential for Russia's economic growth, but Communists and other hard-liners in parliament have balked at allowing the free sale of land. They argue that would allow foreigners and rich Russians to buy huge tracts of land and take them out of agriculture use. The bill, drafted by Communists and other hard-liners, prohibits most real estate deals, including inheritance, grants and other forms of transferring ownership. Yeltsin's veto of the law can be overridden by a two-thirds majority in both houses of parliament. (vi/ls)

FOREIGN Minister Surin Pitsuwan will hand over ''aide memoirs'' to Bangkok-based ambassadors of India and Pakistan when he meets them on Friday to express Thailand's deep concern over their series of nuclear tests last month, a government source said on Thursday. ''The aide memoirs are to reflect Thailand's deep concern regarding the tests as they have badly affected the security of South Asia and the region as a whole,'' the source said. The nuclear tests have led to economic sanctions on India and Pakistan by major donors including the United States and Japan. Meanwhile, Foreign Ministry spokesman Kobsak Chutikul said the nuclear tests conducted by Pakistan in retaliation for India's nuclear tests are likely to affect the country's application for membership of the Asean Regional Forum (ARF). ''Senior Asean foreign ministry officials, meeting in Moscow, discussed how to deal with Pakistan's application for membership of the ARF following the country's nuclear tests,'' Kobsak said. Bangkok was represented by permanent foreign secretary Saroj Chavanaviraj. However, it they have not yet reached a common stand on the issue, pending discussion with other ARF members, including Asean's dialogue partners and consultative partners -- China, the US, Russia and Germany. Asked about Asean's reaction to the tests, Kobsak said the grouping would wait for the conclusion of a meeting between eight economic powers in London. He added that before the nuclear tests by Pakistan, Asean seemed ready to fully welcome Pakistan into the ARF, but following the incidents Asean has to reconsider its position. Meanwhile, when Asean's leaders meet at a summit in Vietnam later this year they will determine a ''Hanoi Plan of Action'' to outline the cooperation needed to achieve ''Asean Vision 2000'', Kobsak said. The Hanoi Plan of Action will comprise cooperation in various fields, including sustainable development, personnel development, Mekong River basin development and economic integration. THE ROYAL Forestry Department (RFD) recently rejected the Zoological Park Organisation plan to send 12 female elephants to China in exchange for the country's indigenous species after opposition by elephant lovers, a department source said. ''The RFD rejected the proposal because there were many things that were not transparent. Why is the park organisation willing to send only female elephants,'' asked the source from the Asean Elephant Foundation of Thailand. The source, who asked not to be named, said in the past the organisation has sent many female elephants to China and Japan and all reproduced in their new environment.''It was reported that they were already impregnated before being sent. Therefore, it was suspected that involved officials might have been granted tangible benefits because the receiving countries gained both the female elephants and their calves,'' the source said. The organisation wants to exchange the 12 female elephants for two pairs of red pandas, a yak and a couple of snow leopards from China. Zoological Park Organisation director general Usum Nimmanahaeminda, who initiated the proposal, was not available for comment on Thursday. According to the department source, state officials and private sector interests involved have operated an illegal elephant trade for more than a decade. He said they use a loophole in the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (Cites) which states that elephants can only be transferred to another country on a non-profit basis and under an agreement made on a government-to-government basis. TOKYO (AP) _ The Nippon Ham Fighters edged the Chiba Lotte Marines 5-4 Friday night at Tokyo Dome to climb into first place in the Pacific League standings. Trailing by two runs in the seventh inning, veteran slugger Hiromitsu Ochiai hit a bases-loaded double to tie the game. The Fighters added three more runs in the inning to take the lead. In Fukuoka, Akira Okamoto tossed a three-hitter to lead the Kintetsu Buffaloes to a 6-0 win over the Fukuoka Daiei Hawks, who slipped to second place with the loss. Kintetsu infielder Phil Clark, formerly with the Boston Red Sox, batted in two runs in the sixth to open the scoring for the Buffaloes. Seibu Lions slugger Brian Raabe smashed a solo homerun in the third and Domingo Martinez batted in two runs in the eighth as the Lions beat the last-place Orix Bluewave 4-2 at Seibu Dome. Raabe played formerly with Colorado Rockies and Martinez played with Triple-A Rochester. In the Central League, Yomiuri Giants pitcher Hiromi Makihara gave up no runs over eight-plus innings as the Giants blanked the Chunichi Dragons 1-0 at Nagoya Dome. Hiroo Ishii batted in the Giants' only run in the first off a sacrifice fly. With the win, Yomiuri climbed into second place, while the Dragons slipped to third. No other Central League games were scheduled for Friday. (js)

HONG KONG people should take heart at the opportunity to voice their feelings over the June 4 crackdown on Chinese soil, many who attended last night's vigil said. They also said the Tiananmen Square crackdown on the pro-democracy movement was ``very wrong''. Chung Ching-kei, 46, who has participated in the vigil since 1990, said it was special this year. ``This is the first time such a large scale vigil commemorating June 4 has been held within China. ``It bears special meaning which shows democracy is possible for the mainland,'' he said. Mr Chung was delighted to see the SAR government being tolerant towards the vigil at Victoria Park. ``I thought this activity would not be allowed and the Alliance for the Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China would be forced to disband,'' he said. This view was shared by Li Kwok-kin, 23, who said he had thought last year's vigil would be the last. ``The most important thing is that Beijing has to admit the 1989 crackdown was wrong,'' Mr Li said. He was disappointed by the result of a survey that indicated more people had a neutral attitude towards the event. A 33-year-old female clerk, said the vigil on Chinese soil indicated it was impossible for Beijing to suppress people's freedom of expression. Another female participant, aged 45, said Hong Kong people should treasure this opportunity to express their anger over the crackdown. Meanwhile, the Hong Kong Polytechnic University Student's Union issued a statement calling on the Central Government to admit it was wrong in ordering the crackdown and to investigate who should be held responsible for the tragedy. They also urged the mainland to end the ``single party rule''. Students keep memories alive with giant torchesLED by two torches held aloft, about 80 college students joined thousands of others at the June 4 memorial vigil last night to keep the fire of the 1989 democratic movement ablaze. Organised by the Hong Kong Federation of Students, participants from eight higher-education institutions set off from the University of Hong Kong and the Hong Kong Polytechnic University in two groups at 5 pm. They merged at Queen's Pier in Central at 6.30 pm. The students arrived in Victoria Park at 8 pm. The two torches, symbolising the spirit of democracy and liberty pursued by the student movement, hovered in the air throughout the night as the students passed them round. University of Hong Kong social work student Peter Tang, 24, said he joined the rally because he wanted to make mainland officials aware that people believed the crackdown was a crime. ``The students might have made mistakes, but those were only strategic mistakes. ``But what the government did were moral mistakes.'' KUALA LUMPUR, Wed. - Indah Water Konsortium is likely to reduce its commercial charges by between 30 and 40 per cent while its 28-year concession period to upgrade the sewerage system nationwide may be extended for at least another 10 years. Department of Sewerage Service director-general Lum Weng Kee told the New Straits Times the move was to placate disgruntled consumers while at the same time ensure the business of providing sewerage service was still economically viable for IWK. ``These are among the proposals submitted to the Economic Planning Unit following the Government's directive to IWK to review its commercial charges two months ago.'' This will be the second review of IWK rates since it took over the sewerage service from the local authorities in December 1993. While declining to reveal the exact percentage cut for the commercial sector, Lum said it would be between 30 and 40 per cent and not 50 per cent as previously reported. The reduction was reached after taking into account the costs needed to maintain and upgrade the sewerage plants IWK inherited from the 144 local authorities, he said. Under IWK's 1997 charges, commercial customers pay their monthly sewerage bills based on their property value and the amount of water consumed, which could range between RM10 and RM15,000. Industrial customers, on the other hand, pay according to the number of employees. Premises with individual septic tank services, for instance, pay RM2 per head per month. For residential customers, the monthly rates are between RM2 and RM8, depending on type of houses. Lum also disclosed that the 1993 Sewerage Services Act would be amended to empower water authorities to disconnect water supply of customers who fail to settle their sewerage bills. Assessing the situation, Lum felt that IWK's commercial customers had no grounds to complain about the previous charges. ``We did an analysis comparing IWK's 1994 and 1997 charges and found the amount incurred by its customers to be insignificant.'' In the department's survey involving hotels, coffeeshops, restaurants, laundries, petrol stations, government offices, office building and shopping complexes, it was found that the increase was negligible. Coffeeshop owners, for instance, paid an average of RM0.02 per customer per day under the 1997 charges and RM0.08 under the 1994 rates. The difference of RM0.06, said Lum, was negligible. For large hotels, the difference was only RM0.70, restaurants (RM0.02), laundries (RM0.35), petrol stations (RM0.005), government offices (RM0.001), office buildings (RM0.007) and shopping complexes (RM0.062) Initially, IWK was to take over only 1,800 sewerage plants. But due to local authorities' poor data collection, IWK is now faced with the task of refurbishing 5,300 plants and another 2,700 by the year 2002 at the cost of RM1.5 billion. More than 70 per cent of them are malfunctioning, hence, the inability to meet the Department of Environment's standards for waste water discharge. Another sum of RM17 billion is needed to build new treatment plants in Penang, Langkawi, Labuan and Kuala Lumpur, add new sewer lines, improve existing sewerage system and increase manpower. All in, IWK is serving 11 million users.

Ethiopian jets bomb Eritrean air base; no injuries reported
Eds: UPDATES with Eritrean government statement; RECASTS; ADDs details on evacuation of U.S. nationals, incorporating Eritrea-US; no pickup By JULIA STEWART Associated Press Writer
ASMARA, Eritrea (AP) _ As Eritrea vowed that it would never give in ``to the language of force and intimidation,'' two Ethiopian military aircraft twice bombed an Eritrean air force base Friday in Asmara. On the first run, the bombers hit two hangers used as workshops, the tarmac and a nearby junkyard. No injuries were reported although heavy smoke billowed from the hangar. Hundreds of people on bicycle and on foot rushed to the airbase, attracted by the sound of the explosions and the heavy smoke in the air. Eritrean soldiers moved in to clear civilians out of the base which is right next to Asmara's international airport about 2 kilometers (1.2 miles) southwest of the capital. As far as could be determined, the airport itself was not hit. A U. S. Embassy spokeswoman said plans to evacuate 200 U.S. citizens, mainly dependents of government employees, non-essential embassy staff and Peace Corps volunteers, later Friday to Frankfurt were going ahead as scheduled. The attacks came a day after Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi warned that his country's patience with Eritrea was wearing thin because of Asmara's refusal to withdraw from territory Ethiopia claims it occupied a month ago. ``I am not declaring war in Eritrea. I am only saying enough is enough to Eritrean aggression,'' Meles said after announcing that the army had orders to ``take all necessary measures against repeated Eritrean aggression.'' Shortly before the bombing, the government of Eritrean President Isaias Afwerki had issued a statement expressing ``its firm commitment to a peaceful resolution of the crisis.'' But it said it would never ``acquiesce to the language of force and intimidation and weill, if necessary, resolutely defend its hard-won right to live in peace and freedom.'' Meles was speaking Thursday to reporters to announce acceptance of a four-point proposal by the United States and Rwanda to end a festering border conflict peacefully. One of the recommendations of the proposal was that Eritrea withdrawn to positions held before May 6. The Eritrean government statement Friday characterized the four points as ``not controversial'' but said Eritrea believed there were ``still serious issues of detail and implementation to be worked out.'' Eritrea has always claimed it remains inside its own territory as determined by Italian colonial boundaries. (js/sl)

Conclusions and suggestions by the Thailand Development Research Institute's Working Group on Economic Structure. Problems 1. The working group has concluded that the major problem confronting the economy is that the country's real sector is experiencing a lack of competitiveness. This sorry state of affairs has been reached because Thailand can no longer compete in the international arena for cheap labour and raw materials. It needs new factors that will render it competitive again: that is better productivity in marketing, in agriculture, in industry, in commerce and in service that is based on technology, skills and knowledge that increase efficiency and create innovations in response to demands in the domestic and international markets. During the past three decades the Thai economy has undergone changes from an agrarian to an industrial economy. Industrial production has accounted for almost three times as much as agricultural production. The changes, however, had one important characteristic: the combination of imported technology and local labour and natural resources. The products which resulted from the combination were then exported to be marketed abroad by the trading arm of foreign corporations. They (the foreign corporations) function as if they were our ''partners'' in business. But the globalisation process has changed all that. Thailand's former foreign ''partners'' have eyed other developing countries for their partners under the pull of cheap labour and fertile natural resources. They have changed positions from ''partners'' to ''rivals''. There were no longer justifications for them to convey to Thailand technology and international marketing facilities. Under some fortunate circumstances, Thailand could sweeten its incentives to make such foreign partners stay with enactment of better legislation that boost employees rights and benefits in par with international standards. All told, if Thailand is to retain its competitiveness into the next century it must have all of the above three capabilities and have them in place quick as time for the transition is running out. 2. Another major problem is that the real sector has not worked to ensure that its developments are permanent in terms of their impact on the environment and on the wasteful use of raw materials injurious to natural resources. These two problems are inter-dependent because they not only cause the scarcity of raw materials but make international commerce contingent on one important condition -- products and services must be supplied from sources that are persistent. Tackling these two problems needs a revamp of the manufacturing and distribution structures. Main Strategy 3. Since restructuring of such structures is too wide a scope for this working group to tackle completely given the time constraint, it has concluded that emphasis should be given only to areas that become problems. The scope of work covered by the working group includes making suggestions under the relevant structural adjustment loan (SAL) and other loan programmes. Planning and implementing an entire macro-economic restructuring are areas undertaken by the government. Government agencies directly responsible for these jobs like the Economic and Social Development Commission is known to be doing just that. This aside, the government has created a commission for restructuring and boosting competitiveness and a commission for national industrial development. These two commissions, headed by deputy prime ministers, are aimed at dealing with overall structure. This working group will make suggestions on major issues that lead to a coordinated effort between the agencies routinely responsible for the jobs and the (special) commissions created by the government. 4. The working group has come of the opinion that competitiveness needs to be created from quality human resources, fundamental structures, good governance, management and science and technology. These factors comprise many constituents. But the most vital determining factor that would establish permanent competitiveness for Thailand for now is innovation. An innovation not only means a technological invention but also introduction of any new product and process that would bring in advances to activities. An innovation may be a method, a notion, or an innovative technology arrived at locally or imported and adapted to suit local needs. Innovations are divided into two kinds: an improvement and a breakthrough. An improvement is an innovation where industrial productivity is improved by introducing improved machinery. A breakthrough is where a new product or service is created, a new brand name or a new product is developed. Not less important is where improvement has been made on the process Thailand was traditionally adept at like growing fragrant jasmine rice and producing jewellery to a standard accepted internationally. This kind of effort needs both kinds of innovation. Apart from product and process, innovation will include the marketing and distribution system. 5. In introducing innovation to streamlining the economy, the working group has concluded that three vital policy tools should be used. The first tool involves continuous education and training needed to construct the base on which to build manufacturing capabilities and the capabilities to innovate. Capabilities to innovate lead to the application of the other two tools -- the development of technology and the development of management. The working group came of the opinion that the agricultural, the industrial, the commerce and the service sectors need technological development and that management development is vital to the restructuring. Besides, conservation of the environment, in a way consistent with the sustenance of a variety of activities, needs to be taken simultaneously. 6. Economic streamlining under the SAL programme calls for huge spending because it involves revamps on manufacturing and distribution in the real sector. An administrative mechanism is therefor called for. To ensure efficiency in its implementation, a special fund should be created, called the ''Fund for Economic Streamlining for the Administration of the Restructuring'' according to the funds allocated by the government disbursing them from SAL and other loans, (which may include a portion of the social sector loans). Since the funds are foreign loans whose principal amount and interest need to be paid from taxpayers money, they need to be managed according to a strict rule so the funds are effectively spent. The management of the funds should be done at two levels -- policy and allocation. 6.1 At policy level. A fund policy commission is to be created, for streamlining the economy. The commission is headed by a deputy prime minister or finance minister, with ministers or their deputies at relevant ministries being its directors (Finance, Science, Agriculture, Industry, Commerce and Labour ministries) and up to five experts serving as its expert directors. The Office of Fiscal Economy of the Finance Ministry and the Office of the National Economic and Social Development Board will act as its secretaries with the authority to define policies, guidelines, and scope of the government economic policy. 6.2 At fund management level. A commission is to be created for restructuring the economy, comprising a minimum of five but up to seven social elites who have earned public trust and who hold no public or bureaucratic office. The Office of Fiscal Economy and the Office of National Economic and Social Development Board act as its secretaries with the authority of allocating funds within the scope defined by the fund policy commission under 6.1. 7. For the sake of continuity of the work, a fund committee should be set up under a provision of the law, like the Science and Technology Development Act of 1991. The committee's work will have to be transparent and subject to monitoring by the mass media and public. Sectoral Strategy 8. The working committee sees that the operation should be divided according to economic sectors. That is, there should be the agricultural sector, industrial sector, business sector and service sector. There should also be projects to sustain development and competitiveness in all regions. The projects should be on environment, education and training. Projects in each region will not be aimed at solving all problems in the region, but will seek to tackle the main and critical problems and should serve as an example of how to create competitiveness and sustenance with innovations. 9. In the agricultural sector, the main question is how to increase income to farmers by encouraging them to produce products which are in demand by both consumers and by industry as raw materials. To achieve this, both the private sector and the government should try to develop better species and productive procedures. There should be a system to guarantee investment risks for farmers and the system to provide loans to farmers should be overhauled. The loans should be expanded to cover activities besides farming so that the communities could be developed in a comprehensive cycle. A system of future markets should be developed to reduce the uncertainty on prices and amount of products in the markets. 10. In the industrial sector, the main question is how to re-engineer companies so that they can produce more efficiently and can make products which are in demand. The solution is to restructure management, administration, technology and machinery of companies as well require them to provide training to staff so that staff could adjust to the new system. The government and private sector should cooperate in setting up new institutions or launching pioneer projects to create new skills, like designing, information technology, development on rubber and foods products. 11. In the commercial sector, the main question is how to restructure the sector so that farm products could be competitive in the world and Asean markets. Companies should be prompted to shift their focus on domestic markets to Asean markets by using Afta as a tool as well as to the world market using regulations of World Trade Organisation as tools. The companies should develop their IT expertise to create an efficient consumer response system as well as applying electronic data exchange to facilitate trade, which needs fast and efficient transfer of data. The bar code system should be promoted as a common practice among businesses. Companies should be prompted to create and develop their own brands. 12. For the service sector, the working committee sees that the management and technological aspects of the sector should be restructured. An institute and mechanism should be created to permit privatisation of telecom, transport and state enterprises. There should be projects to protect consumers and measures against monopoly as well as projects for distribution of tourism income to local communities as well as projects to reduce congestion at tourist spots and to rehabilitate tourism spots. 13. All the re-engineering plans will depend on a key factor -- ability and quality of people at all levels. As a result, education and teaching new skills should be employed as a tool to develop the quality of an employee. As an example, the working committee proposes a tele-education system to train those who already have jobs. The tele-education could be a virtual system in which trainees could receive training at any time. Trainees could learn from real problems. The training system should receive cooperation from the private sector, educational institutions and the government. 14. To ensure the sustenance of natural resources and society, measures need to be taken to protect the environment and to prevent pollution from industry as well as to treat industry and community waste. To do this, a system to collect fees for waste treatment and environment protection should be laid down as well as prompting the private sector to be more competitive in business. New investment policies should be adjusted as ''green policies'' which should screen out environmentally unfriendly projects. The working committee has suggested some projects, like ''green loans'' which will provide incentives to investors to employ environmentally-friendly measures; projects to support medium-sized and small companies to employ environmentally-friendly measures; projects to treat agricultural chemical wastes; and the re-engineering of government agencies in line with environmental management. 15. The working group has based its proposals on the preceding suggestions. The suggestions are divided, according to their contents, into: (1) agriculture; (2) industry; (3) commerce; (4) service; (5) continued education and refresher training and (6) natural resources and the environment. Each sector has its own action plans, project proposals and the prioritisation of such plans and proposals, in a bid to clarify the contents of the proposals and the specific plans. In selecting a proposal it is believed the fund managing commissions under points 6 and 7 would invite comments widely from the public and private sectors so the most beneficial and most appropriate project would be selected. The said plans have not been complete. Working papers containing the basic plan of action that cannot be freely called comprehensive or even strategic are used as pilot plans that have the potential of being upgraded into a concrete national plan. Apart from proposed plans, the working group has considered factors vital to restructuring, the improvement to legislation, the reforming of the duties and roles of the bureaucrats, the boosting of rights and the welfare of workers. All these factors contribute towards creating a Thailand that is permanently competitive in the global market and are issues that need continuous tackling by the government, on top of the plans proposed. Additional information is available in appendices 1 and 2. Appendix 1 is working papers compiled as part of the suggestions proposed. Appendix 2 is a compilation of papers intended as background information for relevant issues.

Volkswagen wins control of Rolls-Royce
Eds: COMBINING previous and SUBBING 14th graf to show date Vickers hopes to close deal, SUBBING 5th graf to add context to Crowe's quote; minor editing By DIRK BEVERIDGE AP Business Writer
LONDON (AP) _ Volkswagen AG won shareholder approval Friday to buy Rolls-Royce Motor Cars Ltd. for 430 million pounds (dlrs 700 million), despite angry bursts of nationalism from small investors who fought to keep the luxury carmaker British. Vickers PLC, the corporation that owns Rolls-Royce, announced at the end of a stormy meeting that investors had agreed to sell Rolls-Royce to Volkswagen, the German company that is Europe's biggest automaker. Proxy votes and votes from big institutional shareholders had made the approval a done deal, but Vickers held off the announcement until it had counted ballots from the little shareholders who made the big noise. ``Should I call it now a Rolls-wagen?'' shareholder Rodney Crowe asked during the special meeting. ``What are we going to have? A flying lady on the front of the Beetle?'' Crowe said later, conjuring up an image of the distinctive Rolls-Royce hood ornament placed on a Volkswagen Bug. Some investors sounded like they were ready to refight World War II in a session where they first rejected a bid of 340 million pounds (dlrs 554 million) from rival German automaker BMW. ``For God's sake, try and take a broad view for the country,'' said Desmond Lake, drawing cheers in the packed auditorium when he referred to Volkswagen's history in Nazi Germany. Volkswagen faces not just vocal objections but some real potential hurdles at it moves to take over production of luxury Rolls-Royce and Bentley cars, which cost at minimum around dlrs 250,000 each. The jilted suitor, BMW, supplies some engines to Rolls-Royce and has threatened to cut off deliveries. BMW spokesman Uwe Mahla said in Munich that Friday's developments were ``for us a very suprising situation,'' and BMW sources said executives were holding an emergency meeting. Rolls-Royce PLC, a separate company that makes jet engines, controls the brand name and logo and has made it clear it would rather see the deal go to BMW, which happens to be its partner in a jet engine venture. Rolls-Royce PLC has not said whether it will negotiate with Volkswagen or try to block its use of the brand name. Asked about that, the Vickers chairman, Sir Colin Chandler, insisted that a 25-year-old contract that would let Rolls-Roye PLC veto the purchase of Rolls-Royce Motors Cars Ltd. by a foreign buyer is legally unenforceable. ``The trademark can't go anywhere else,'' Chandler said. ``We exclusively own the radiator, the flying lady and Bentley.'' But some shareholders expressed worries that the Rolls production line could be halted by the dispute. Vickers hopes to close the deal by July 3. And at least one expressed disgust at the fight over a name that epitomizes handmade British luxury. ``It's harmful for Rolls-Royce PLC and it's harmful for Vickers and they don't seem to care,'' Carol Day said. ``They're behaving like 6-year-old children.'' The takeover announcement also was delayed by a Rolls-Royce enthusiasts group, Crewe Motors, which claimed it was on the verge of putting together a 500 million pound (dlrs 815 million) offer from private backers. Its chairman, lawyer Michael Shrimpton, who has failed in previous attempts to put together a bid, forced Vickers to adjourn the meeting for nearly one hour, but the Vickers chairman was unconvinced and refused any further delays. PENANG, Wed. - An expert on Malay traditional performing arts today urged the authorities and interested parties to stop making an issue out of the temporary ban on dikir barat in Kelantan. In making the call, former Universiti Sains Malaysia associate professor Dr Ghulam-Sarwar Yousof suggested that steps be taken to preserve the authenticity of the dikir barat. Ghulam, a noted authority on traditional Malay theatre, is director of the newly established The Asian Centre in Penang and lecturer at the National Academy of Arts under the Ministry of Culture, Arts and Tourism in Kuala Lumpur. He was commenting on Culture, Arts and Tourism Minister Datuk Sabbaruddin Chik's statement that Kelantan's decision to ban the dikir barat might affect tourist arrivals and that it was too early to determine the impact of the ban. The Kelantan Government banned the dikir barat on May 28. Ghulam said the inclusion of pop culture and pop songs would certainly threaten whatever little authenticity was left in the dikir barat. He said it was orginally religious in character but over the years became secularised and a tool for propaganda. ``However, as the ban is temporary and a policy regarding dikir barat is being formulated, let us wait for the policy and study it first.'' He said there were certain elements in traditional Malay theatre which contravened Islamic culture and the issue should be how far such elements should be tolerated. ``There are also such elements in wayang kulit, mak yong and menora but the matter can be resolved rationally by determining the acceptable limits to modification within these art forms,'' said Ghulam.

THANKS to two Americans and the Internet, Maitai, a stray dog, will find a new home in the United States. Linda Kiel from Madison, Wisconsin, will fly to Thailand in order to adopt the bitch on June 10 after learning of its misfortune which was posted on a web site by Mina Sharpe, 18. In January, Maitai was hit by a car in Prachuap Khiri Khan's Hua Hin district, resulting in a broken back. Fortunately, Sharpe learned of the accident shortly after it occurred. After learning that Thonglor Veterinary Hospital was likely the best facility for Maitai, the American woman took the dog there. She left an initial US$300 with staff for Maitai's treatment before leaving the country, maintaining contact with the hospital to keep paying the fees. At the same time, she posted Maitai's story on a web site where she asked for a new home for the dog. Sharpe said Kiel agreed on May 21 to adopt Maitai and take her to the US for further treatment.

THE Kulim Hi-Tech Park (KHTP) multi-million IT Centre in Kedah is set to serve as a platform to bring information technology to both users and providers of technology in the northern region of the country. Targeted to be officially launched by Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad in August, the IT Centre will also serve as the IT hub for Kedah, while providing IT consultancy and other services to the neighbouring States and the Asean region. The IT Centre is managed by KTM which is a joint venture between Kulim Technology Park Corporation (KTPC) - the developer of KHTP - and Universiti Sains Malaysia (USM). Group general manager of Kulim Technology Management Sdn Bhd (KTM) Mazlee Md Ramli said the RM13 million IT Centre will be offering services like training, turnkey projects, sale of hardware, software development and incubation centres. Soon, he said, the IT Centre will also house the Network Excellence Centre - a joint networking development project involving KTM, 3Com Asia Ltd (M) and Stacks Technology Sdn Bhd - aimed at providing networking solutions for KHTP. The three parties signed a teaming agreement in Kuala Lumpur on Tuesday, with KTM represented by its director Ahmad Shukri Tajuddin and Mazlee, 3Com by its South Asia managing director Marcel Jacobs and country manager Pang Yee Beng, and Stacks Technology by its managing director Dr Nah Soo Hoe and Penang branch manager Liew Chin Hock. Under the agreement, 3Com will provide the hardware, technical knowledge and training to KTM while Stacks Technology, a 3Com authorised network systems integrator, will serve as network integrator for the installation of network cabling systems within the local area network (LAN) and wide area network (WAN) of KHTP. Stacks Technology will also provide network-related training to KTM's personnel and KHTP's tenants. The Network Excellence Centre which involves an initial investment of RM1.5 million, will be the first site in Malaysia to implement 3Com's Gigabit Ethernet solution for its LAN requirements. A Gigabit Ethernet environment, said Mazlee, will enable effective high- bandwidth delivery within the LAN which, in this case, comprises anyone who is connected to the IT Centre. In addition, Gigabit Ethernet also delivers class of service (CoS) capabilities which allow traffic prioritisation according to business needs. The investment covers the first phase of the project, that is, the setting up of the hardware and software infrastructure, due to be completed by the end of next month. Under this set-up, the network will illustrate the concept of a collapsed backbone topology that provides a centralised management information system (MIS) for higher performance interconnectivity. The system is made up of 3Com's SuperStack II Switch 9300 which serves as the backbone supporting seven collapsed Gigabit Ethernet segments and servers that are integrated with 3Com's CoreBuilder 7000HD Asynchronous Transfer Mode (ATM) connectivity. For the LAN, 3Com's SuperStack II Switch 3900, 3000 and 1100 will provide 10/100 megabits per second (Mbps) Ethernet to the desktop. KHTP will engage 3Com's NetBuilder router - offering flexibility and high bandwidth - for the WAN. KHTP, the country's first hi-tech park and regarded as ``the science city of the future'', has to date attracted more than RM15 billion worth of investments from 27 multinational hi-tech companies.

The Business Desk examines the Thailand Development Research Institute's far-reaching reform proposal. The goal is to upgrade the competitiveness of Thai industries and sustain it. The target is manpower and education development. The mechanism is a permanent national committee which does not rise or fall with politics of the day. The vision is to create a more innovative society. Is it practical and achievable? The researchers at Thailand Development Research Institute (TDRI), which has presented the proposal to the government, said there is no other choice because Thailand is no longer competitive in many export sectors while the management and labour skills have to be rebuilt from scratch if they are to move the country forward. The TDRI study is the first of its kind to take a holistic approach to solving the country's competitiveness problems. Former science minister Phaichitr Uathavikul was the chairman of a working group on this study. Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai on Wednesday asked his deputy, Supachai Panitchpakdi, to oversee the implementations. It is a challenge ahead for the coalition government to put it into effect speedily as the TDRI has pointed out that the rebuilding of Thai industries is already five years late. The government will also need to find a massive US$2.4 billion to finance the economic restructuring. The money made available earlier for industrial restructuring has already been spent elsewhere, making it necessary to find new funding sources. TDRI has suggested that the national committee to oversee the restructuring process should be a permanent one. It should also be staffed with professionals with the relevant knowledge. The think-tank also warned that the industries must be rebuilt with awareness not to create environmental problems which would defeat the purpose. The task ahead is a gigantic one in many respects. The restructuring is very much a bottom-up process because the real weakness is in the quality of Thai workers. Seventy per cent of the workers in the industrial sector have primary education or less and will be difficult to upgrade without retraining. The roadmap to sustainable competitiveness for the Thai economy with more quality manpower will henceforth be made up of innovation, then science and technology development and eventually management improvement. The TDRI study said that Thailand has insufficient human and social capital to sustain the entire system in the era of globalisation. Human resources are not lacking in volume but in the skills essential to compete in the modern industrial world. The lack of social capital, on the other hand, is due to the inability of various institutions' work culture and the standards and values which society places in accumulating wisdom, responsibility and ethics. ''We also need new human and social capital which can increase the knowhow in technology transfer and management development. These are factors vital in making the Thai society a sustainable one,'' said the study. TDRI suggested revamping the entire agriculture, industry, commerce and service sectors. The entire process is too large to undertake given the limited resources. The think-tank proposed that there ought to be new capabilities for the private sector built up in production, distribution and services. This also includes the ability of the public sector to support the private sector and the people in general to acquire new capabilities.

A GOLD rush is anticipated when collectors hurry to buy a coin commemorating the opening of the new airport at Chek Lap Kok _ at more than three times its face value. Bomb rips through theater killing three, injuring 13
Eds: UPDATES with details, comments from people in the theater. ADDS byline. No pickup AP Photos LHR101-2 By MUNIR AHMED Associated Press Writer
LAHORE, Pakistan (AP) _ A bomb ripped through a theater in the heart of the Punjab capital on Friday, killing three people and injuring 13 others, authorities said. The bomb went off during a matinee movie in a congested central district of Lahore, the ancient capital of Pakistan's Punjab province, they said. About 50 people were in the theater. Eyewitnesses said 30 seats were blown apart. No one immediately claimed responsibility. Pakistan's government blamed neighboring India. Pakistan and India routinely accuse each other of sabotage. Relations between the two countries have been particularly tense since both exploded nuclear devices. ``This act was done by Indians,'' said Miraj Din, a spokesman for the ruling Pakistan Muslim League. ``We were expecting something like this.'' Din said his government received prior warning from its intelligence agencies that India sent secret service agents into Pakistan ``to disrupt law and order.'' There was no evidence to substantiate Din's accusations. Police say they believe the bombers died in the explosion. However, it was unclear whether it was a suicide bomber or someone unknowingly carried the parcel into the theater, said Police Chief Wahab Ali. Ahmed Raza, 33, who was sitting next to the men who carried in the bomb and died when it exploded, said he had left his seat to get a drink of water when he heard a powerful noise. ``I didn't know what it was,'' he said. ``I looked back, and the two boys were dead. There was blood and body parts.'' The guard outside the Mubarak Theater said he checked patrons as they entered the theater. India and Pakistan have fought three wars since the Asian subcontinent gained independence in 1947.

IT won't be until August before Malaysians will know whether Olympic 100m champion Donovan Bailey and other top Canadian athletes will be competing in the Commonwealth Games in September. Canadian team manager for the KL Games, Debbie Bryant, who is on a 10- day pre-Games visit in Kuala Lumpur, said Canada's athletics squad would only be announced on Aug 3 by their respective trainers. ``We won't know if Bailey will be coming until after the selection process,'' said Debbie. ``Some of these athletes would compete in both the World Cup in Johannesburg and the Kuala Lumpur Games while others may compete in only one of the events. ``It's up to the individual athlete and their coaches to decide in relation to their respective training programmes. ``We won't know until they finalise the list,'' said Debbie after being briefed on the Games' progress by Sukom Ninety-Eight at Bukit Jalil yesterday. She said that about 150 of the expected 277-member Canadian contingent will be stationed in Penang from Aug 31 to get acclimatised to local conditions while the rest will arrive in batches. ``In North America, the Commonwealth Games are only second to the Olympics. ``Canada will definitely send their best for all the events. ``Besides, KL is a stepping stone for some of our athletes in anticipating the Sydney 2000 Olympics.'' She said the Canadian Commonwealth Games Federation (CGF) delegates were impressed by the state-of-the-art facilities at the Bukit Jalil Sports Complex. ``We are extremely pleased with what we've seen. I think the facilities are good enough to host the Olympics. ``Malaysia has certainly established a very high standard for future Commonwealth Games.'' The Canadian delegation also praised Malaysia in their preparations to ensure that competitors are received in a comfortable environment. However, their main concern is adapting to the hot and humid conditions. ``We are not too concerned about the haze but more on the tropical weather. We understand that the haze is difficult to control. It's all part of the environment and we must learn to live with it,'' she added.

ALPHATEC Electronics Plc on Thursday won court approval for its financial rehabilitation, proposed by six of its major creditors, becoming the country's first approval under the new bankruptcy law. The court appointed Price Waterhouse, an international auditing firm, as the ''planner'' who would ensure that the rehabilitation is conducted as projected. The six creditors assured the Civil Court on Thursday that they were able to rehabilitate the firm despite its outstanding loans of Bt15 billion. The company's creditors are Bangkok Bank, Credit Agricole Indosuez Thailand, ING NV's BIBF in Chon Buri, Nakornthon Bank, Standard Chartered Bank Thailand, and Sumitomo Bank's BIBF. Over 30 representatives of Alphatech's creditors attended the hearing on Thursday. Now that the petition has been approved, creditors will now have to file for repayments with the ''receiver'' within a month after a planner has been appointed. The planner would then give the receiver a rehabilitation plan within three months after its been appointed. Creditors will then hold a meeting to consider endorsement of the rehabilitation plan and the receiver will then report the result to the court. Chutiporn Chomphuphol, ING Bank's loan department manager who also acted as chief of the creditors' panel, said she believed that the firm could be rehabilitated because ''Alphatech was known for its impressive performance. However, it suffered huge net losses in 1997 due to the economic slowdown, liquidity crunch, management problems, excessive short-term loans and huge expenditure''. Last year, Alphatec's net loss was Bt15.4 billion while outstanding loans exceeded US$450 million. Chutiporn said rehabilitation would be easier if the creditors could change short-term debts to long-term ones and inject more cash into the company. ''Without rehabilitation, the company will record a rise in debts and will go bankrupt eventually, affecting many parties, namely creditors, debtors, the state which cannot collect taxes and unemployed workers,'' she said in court. She added that so far it appears that Alphatech can be rehabilitated because its factories are ready for production and a customer base. Earlier, the creditors could not inject loans into the company because their was no law supporting the move. ''We filed the petition because the Alphatec's management did not oppose the move,'' she said. The creditors' petition was approved despite opposition from Industrial Finance Corp of Thailand (IFCT), another Alphatec creditor, which was filed on Wednesday saying that the rehabilitation plan should protect all creditors and should be supported by all parties. Since the petition had been filed by only six creditors it would never succeed, IFCT said in its affidavit, adding that the planner was not yet ready with the plan. In the preliminary plan, the six creditors did not mention how much would be written off in bad debts. IFCT claimed that suggested conversion of debts to equity would affect collaterals because it would prevent creditors from protecting themselves. Another reason for opposition put forward by IFCT was that the rehabilitation move did not receive cooperation from creditors of collateralised loans. Price Waterhouse (Thailand) director Siriphong Supakijjanusorn defended his company saying it had previously rehabilitated 150 companies worldwide. Thaweesak na Takuathung, a lawyer with Kanung Partners, led the creditors' support for the rehabilitation plan. He told reporters that IFCT had filed the opposition because it was afraid it might not win support in the rehabilitation plan. ''IFCT is afraid that its loan to Alphatec will be written off,'' he said. Senator Sansern Kraijitti, chairman of the House Committee screening the fourth Bankruptcy Act, said that the court's procedures were quick and complied with legal requirements. He added that IFCT did not understand the procedures even though it was a state enterprise.

Reunited Bosnian soccer teams enter Europe
Eds: story will be briefly updated after the end of the game, around 2000 GMT AP Photo By SRECKO LATAL Associated Press Writer
SARAJEVO, Bosnia-Herzegovina (AP) _ Blowing horns and whistles, waving flags and banners, thousands of fans streamed towards Kosevo stadium Friday for the final of Bosnia's soccer championship. The duel featured eternal rivals Zeljeznicar and Sarajevo _ but the real prize is something Bosnia's disunited soccer teams have not known: a ticket to the European Championship League for the winner. ``This may not be a World Cup match, but it is incredibly important for the Bosnian football,'' said Liam McDowall, a U.N. spokesman. Almost all of the 40,000 tickets were sold out in a match that served as a final preparation for monitoring the World Cup from armchairs in front of TV screens. Neighboring Yugoslavia and Croatia are competing in France, but Bosnia's soccer has been as disunited as the country itself and the national team had no chance of qualifying. This year, for the first time since war erupted in 1992, soccer teams from Bosnian Croat- and Muslim-dominated regions competed for the national championship. Four from the Muslim regions and two Croat sides competed in two groups. Claiming security concerns, teams from the Bosnian Serb substate _ Republika Srpska _ refused to participate. But everybody expects them aboard in the next season. It has taken three years for international sports organizations and foreign diplomats charged with implementing peace to negotiate a solution for Bosnia's disunited sports. The 4-2 Muslim-Croat combination was also adopted for this year's Bosnian basketball championships _ which the Serbs are also expected to join in 1999. The Croat side Siroki Brijeg defeated Sarajevo's Bosna, former European champions, for the local basketball crown. In recent weeks, the two groups in soccer played in Sarjaevo and the tense southwestern town of Mostar. Hundreds of fans traveled back and forth without incident _ to the delight of Western diplomats still trying to overcome ethnic tensions. ``Even a year ago ... it would have been very difficult to imagine such games take place in Mostar without any trouble,'' said Martin Garrod, senior international official in Mostar. Fearing ethnic riots, U.N. police closely monitored each game. Fans simply want to see the best players. ``There was the war, but it's over now,'' said Sead Beric, a Zeljeznicar fan, heading for the stadium. ``Now, without all good players, whether they are Bosnian Serbs, Croats, Muslims, Jews, Eskimos or others, we cannot hope to become something in world soccer and participate in the next World Cup.'' WHILE many Thai companies are struggling with recapitalisation, Songkhla Canning Plc (SC) said all of its 18 million capital increase shares were subscribed to by its existing shareholders. ''The success of the company's capital increase is partially due to the company's consecutive growth on its performances; particularly this year in which the company has increased its exports to markets worldwide,'' Cheng Niruttinanon, SC chairman, said. SC, a major manufacturer and exporter of canned seafood, earlier announced it would double its registered capital to Bt360 million via the issue of 18 million new shares. The new shares were offered to existing shareholders at the ratio of one old share to one new share at Bt20. The share price of SC closed unchanged at Bt67. According to Cheng, the new money will increase cash flow for exports and help the company expand its markets. He said 80 per cent of its main revenue was generated by the sale of canned tuna while the remaining 20 per cent was derived from the sale of canned shrimp, crab and clams. The company ranks as one of the top three canned tuna exporters in Thailand. Almost all of its products are exported to the United States, Europe, Japan and the Middle East. The domestic raw materials, including shrimp, crab and clams, also helps to reduce the company's production costs. Only tuna, which is the main raw material, has to be imported. The two sources of tuna for the company are the Indian and Pacific Oceans. Cheng said in 1997, SC was able to pay a dividend of Bt13.50 per share. In the first quarter of this year, the company and its subsidiaries together posted Bt144.48 million in profit, 111.9 per cent higher than its profit of Bt76.29 million in the same period a year earlier. Songkhla Canning is a subsidiary of Thai Union Frozen Products Plc, which recently completed its recapitalisation. The parent company realised around Bt180 apiece from the offering.

TOKYO (AP) _ The Nippon Ham Fighters edged the Chiba Lotte Marines 5-4 Friday night at Tokyo Dome to climb into first place in the Pacific League standings. Trailing by two runs in the seventh inning, veteran slugger Hiromitsu Ochiai hit a bases-loaded double to tie the game. The Fighters added two more runs in the inning to take the lead. In Fukuoka, Akira Okamoto tossed a three-hitter to lead the Kintetsu Buffaloes to a 6-0 win over the Fukuoka Daiei Hawks, who slipped to second place with the loss. Kintetsu infielder Phil Clark, formerly with the Boston Red Sox, batted in two runs in the sixth to open the scoring for the Buffaloes. Seibu Lions slugger Brian Raabe smashed a solo homerun in the third and Domingo Martinez batted in two runs in the eighth as the Lions beat the last-place Orix Bluewave 4-2 at Seibu Dome. Raabe played formerly with Colorado Rockies and Martinez played with Triple-A Rochester. In the Central League, Yomiuri Giants pitcher Hiromi Makihara gave up no runs over eight-plus innings as the Giants blanked the Chunichi Dragons 1-0 at Nagoya Dome. Hiroo Ishii batted in the Giants' only run in the first off a sacrifice fly. With the win, Yomiuri climbed into second place, while the Dragons slipped to third. No other Central League games were scheduled for Friday. (js)

Rajasekaran said today he stood by his statements at a forum in the United States two years ago that some employers were engaged in anti-union activities. Saying that he would continue to raise shortcomings of the country's industrial relations at local and international forums, Rajasekaran said Human Resources Minister Datuk Lim Ah Lek was lying when he accused him of spreading lies about the country while abroad. Speaking at a Press conference at the MTUC headquarters in USJ following Lim's move last week to make public a video tape of the forum, Rajasekaran said: ``I have not been telling lies as claimed by Lim because I have forwarded to the Ministry the identity of the company - a textile firm operating from the Prai Free Trade Zone - which had created its in-house union before appointing its personnel manager as the president. ``Naturally, I am surprised that the Minister has accused me of not being able to back up my claim. Either he has not read the letter we sent to the Ministry or he pretended not to know.'' Rajasekaran said he was prepared for a public debate over the matter if Lim continued to ``misrepresent'' the matter. ``Anti-union activities by employers have happened in the past and are still happening,'' he said, adding that he was prepared to name the companies involved if requested by the Ministry. This included a firm at the Teluk Panglima Garang Industrial Zone which concluded a collective agreement with its in-house union, which turned out to be a sports club whose chairman was the company's personnel officer. On May 28, Lim made public a video tape as proof that Rajasekaran had been spreading lies about the country's labour movement at the forum, organised by the World Bank and International Labour Organisation. Lim said Rajasekaran's claims that there were companies which had created in-house unions and appointed their personnel managers as presidents were baseless. Rajasekaran was also said to have criticised the role of the National Labour Advisory Council, claiming that the Human Resources Minister had implemented decisions contrary to those endorsed by the council. To this, Rajasekaran said the remark was made by the forum's chairman when summing up input from participants. He said Lim was also wrong when he said that he (Rajasekaran) had retracted his claims about the NLAC via a letter to the organiser. ``It was to the contrary. I sent the letter to the forum's chairman, informing her that she had erred in her summary and requested that the records be corrected accordingly.'' He expressed surprise that Lim continued to make an issue out of the video tape although the NLAC had considered the controversy resolved in 1996 following his explanation. When approached by reporters at his office today, Lim said he might reply to the latest claims by Rajasekaran.

FIVE major oil companies have agreed to increase the number of petrol stations selling 91 octane gasoline this month in support of the government's policy to promote the use of lower octane gasoline products, an official from the National Energy Policy Office said on Thursday. Nepo's Deputy Secretary General Metta Banturngsuk said that every petrol station in Bangkok and the metropolitan area operated by PTT, Esso, Caltex and Bangchak will soon start selling 91 octane gasoline. Shell will increase the number of its stations supplying the product to 75 per cent of the total from the present 50 per cent. The five companies dominate the retail petrol industry with 81 per cent of the market. A month ago, Nepo kicked off a campaign to promote the use of lower rated petrol products in order to save valuable foreign exchange. ''Previously, the use of 91 octane petrol was confined to motorcycles, which discouraged petrol station operators from selling it. But as a result of the government's campaign, many motorists have now switched to it, prompting oil companies to adjust their marketing policies,'' Metta said. Shell, however, could not sell 91 octane at all of its retail outlets as some have relatively small oil storage capacities, he said. Within one month of the campaign, Metta said consumption of octane-95 gasoline had fallen by 8 per cent to 65 per cent while the share of 91 gasoline increased by 7 per cent to 34 per cent. However, the market share of 87 octane, a new product, amounted to a low 1 per cent. The changes, he said, helped the country and consumers to save Bt30 million for the month -- Bt25 million from the higher sales of 91 octane and Bt5 million from the 87 octane. If this continues, it will save Bt192 million a year through the government's two mandatory measures implemented earlier, including the withdrawal of super petrol (premium gasoline with soft value protection additive) and the abolishment of additives in 87 octane petrol. The 91 petrol is usually Bt0.60 per litre cheaper than 95 petrol. The saving, however, is still far below the government's target as Nepo has set out to increase the share of 91 and 87 gasoline products to 65 per cent and 10 per cent while reducing the share of 91 petrol to 25 per cent. Ninety-seven per cent of PTT stations in Bangkok were selling the 91 petrol, compared with 75 per cent of Shell, 72 per cent of Esso and 100 per cent in case of Bangchak and Caltex as of May 25. There were 157 stations in the city selling 87 petrol. PTT, Shell, Esso, Caltex and Bangchak have 223, 237, 205, 185 and 164 outlets respectively in the city.

ABOUT 100 mostly young people last night braved torrential rain to attend Macau's annual candlelight vigil in commemoration of the 1989 Tiananmen crackdown. The New Democratic Macau Association, which organised the event blamed the low number of participants on the rain. ``In spite of the rain, we carry on,'' said head of the association, Ng Kuok-cheong. ``The most important point is not to forget the pro-democracy fighters who died in Beijing nine years ago.'' Last night's number of participants was the lowest since the annual candlelight vigil was launched by Macau's pro-democracy movement in 1990. About 300 people attended last year. About a dozen uniformed policemen monitored the vigil, which also included a video presentation of the events preceding and following the 1989 pro-democracy clampdown. There was also a photo exhibition about the incident. Several participants at the vigil told reporters on condition of anonymity that the Chinese government should revise its verdict on the Tiananmen incident. They also appealed to Beijing to respect human rights. Mr Ng said he was determined to continue the annual Tiananmen candlelight vigil even after the enclave's reversion to Chinese rule in December next year. The vigil took place at the Sao Domingos square in the city centre. Mr Ng is the only deputy to Macau's 23-member legislature who openly supported the Tiananmen democracy movement in 1989. Mr Ng's pro-democracy association garnered 8 per cent of the direct votes in the legislative election in September 1996.

THE Industry Ministry has told the Petroleum Authority of Thailand (PTT) to suspend its plans for injecting additional capital into the cash-strapped oil-refining subsidiary Thai Oil Co. Plagued by debts worth US$1.5 billion and a capital base as low as Bt20 million, Thai Oil is said to be in dire straits. Industry Minister Somsak Thepsuthin said on Thursday that PTT should look into other alternatives apart from its capital increase plan because it is preparing to privatise and meet the government's austerity policy for state enterprises. ''PTT is restructuring after which it might not need to increase capital for Thaioil itself since other sources of funding may be available,'' Somsak said. PTT had proposed to inject between Bt3 to Bt5 billion into Thai Oil. The country's largest oil refinery is currently conducting a number of salvage programmes, mainly negotiating with buyers for a 25 per cent stake, currently held by the Chowkwanyun group, and restructuring its ownership structure with subsidiaries, namely Thai Paraxylene Co, Independent Power (Thailand) Co, Thaioil Power Co, Thai Carbon Products Co and Thai Lubebase Oil Co. Thai Oil's paid-up capital has been kept low because its previous attempts to increase capital had been stalled by politicians and by conflicts between shareholders. The Chowkwanyun group, burned badly by its finance company which was one of the 56 closed down last year, was unable to increase its 25 per cent stake in Thai Oil due to a lack of resources. PTT holds a 49 per cent stake in Thai Oil, Shell Petroleum NV holds 15.05 per cent and Caltex Trading and Transport 4.75 per cent. Meanwhile, PTT governor Pala Sookawesh said PTT did not plan to sell its 24 per cent holding in Bangchak, due to the low prices quoted in the stock market, unless there were investors proposing to pay appropriate prices. However, Pala said he had asked Bangchak to do a report on clearly separated accounts on assets, oil sales and supplementary businesses as well as the oil market situation since these would inform investors about Bangchak stocks. Bangchak currently produces 120,000 barrels per day in Bangkok and operates 1,200 oil retailing networks.

BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP) - The EU approved Friday plans by the French engineering company Alcatel-Alsthom and the French defense electronics firm of Thomson CSF to take joint control of a satellite firm, Societe Commune de Satellites. The European Commission cleared the takeover of after the two parties made concessions reducing the risk of Thomson gaining a dominant position in the satellite components market. ``SCS will operate the business activities of its parent companies, as well as those of (state-controlled aerospace group) Aerospatiale in the satellites sector,'' a Commission statement said. The plan by Alcatel and Thomson CSF to take joint control of SCS was notified to the Commission in April. At the same time, Alcatel said it planned to buy a minority stake in Thomson CSF, a unit of the state-owned Thomson SA. The Commission approved the sale to Alcatel on May 26. Under EU law it can veto alliances or mergers if it judges these hinder fair competition in the 15-nation EU. The French government said last year it intended to sell a minority share of Thomson CSF to Alcatel. The move is part of a plan to privatize Thomson CSF. (as-dj)

INSOLVENCY experts from Britain are coming to crisis-hit Asia in increasing numbers, particularly Thailand. According to a Financial Times report, more than 120 of Britain's leading experts in company rescues -- 10 per cent of the senior insolvency profession -- are working in the stricken economies of Southeast Asia on behalf of international banking syndicates and financial regulators. FT said the confidential assignments, representing an investment of up to US$245 million a year in partner and staff time, range from assessing the repercussions of the current crisis for developed nations to rescuing companies from failure. The London-based business newspaper said the experts are also beginning to pick up specific corporate rescue work here in Thailand as businesses struggle with bad debts from dollar-denominated borrowings, and a sharp contraction in local demand. Murdoch McKillop, president of the Society of Practitioners of Insolvency was quoted as saying: ''There's a lot of the UK profession out there. We have learnt a lot about rescue culture. We've moved a long way from shutting doors and getting the auctioneers in. We have been able to act as a bridge between the international banking community and local corporates.'' The ''Big Six'' accountancy firms, including Price Waterhouse, Coopers and Lybrand, Arthur Andersen, and Ernst and Young, are said to have had up to 800 staff in Southeast Asia in the past six to nine months including legal back-up from London-based firms. FT said the insolvency profession expects more work as companies that have so far survived on operating cashflow turn to overseas banks for new money.
