SHOP rentals at Housing Authority commercial premises might be cut to benefit about 9,200 business owners but only if they apply for a reassessment. Speaking at the authority's annual special meeting, chairman Rosanna Wong Yick-ming said the authority was proposing to reassess the rent for the leases signed or renewed when the property market was at its peak. The period referred to was between 1 January 1996 and 31 January this year. The aim of the move is to ease the financial hardship of owners of businesses whose leases are up for renewal from next year. Back in January, the Housing Department took a similar step by allowing a one-year freeze on rents. That applied to owners of businesses whose leases were up for renewal this year. The concession was estimated to have cost the authority $29 million. The rent cut proposal will be discussed by the Commercial Properties Committee of the authority today. Ms Wong said the reassessment would only be carried out on the request of individual tenants. The Housing Authority (HA) would decide the size of the rent cuts for individual shops, she added. Applications for reassessment will probably be accepted between July and September. Ms Wong said she expected the new rents could be backdated to July. She estimated more than 9,200 business owners would benefit from the new measure. Ms Wong explained a reassessment would be fairer than a rigid standard rent cut for all tenants because different factors like the location of the shops and the nature of the businesses would also be taken into consideration. The Housing Department has recorded $52.6 million in uncollected rent from its commercial premises between October last year and March. A total of 204 tenants withdrew from their tenancies in the six-month period. Secretary for Housing Dominic Wong Shing-wah said the proposed rent cut could help relieve the financial burden of business owners. Meanwhile HA member Michael Choi Ngai-min, managing director of Hong Kong Property Services (Agency), said the proposal would give tenants of private commercial premises a strong argument to bargain with landlords for rent cuts. Another member Chan Kam-man slammed the Housing Bureau for taking over the role of the HA in deciding policy on public housing rentals.

THE Government Lottery Office (GLO) plans to conduct an opinion poll to legitimise plans to increase the number of lottery tickets in circulation through automatic lottery dispensing machines, an official said on Thursday. GLO deputy director Chaiwat Pasokpakdi said Rajabhat Suan Dusit Poll would complete the survey of 100,000 respondents this month to determine public sentiment over the introduction of automatic ticketing machines, dubbed ''huay (lottery) online''. Consumers will be able to choose numbers and purchase tickets through the electronic medium. Chaiwat said that if introduced the new distribution system would not affect the jobs of lottery sellers because it would handle additional tickets on top of the 31 million in circulation for each of the fortnightly draws. He did not say how many new tickets the GLO plans to add to the system. The plan to introduce the dispensing machines, on the drawing board since 1996, has been shelved many times because of strong opposition from lottery vendors and academics. The vendors view the plan as a threat to their jobs while academics oppose it on the grounds that it could increase gambling. Despite the protests, the GLO has steadily pushed for the introduction of an electronic lottery system, and succeeded in appointing a Thai-US joint venture to operate it. Before the system got started, the Chavalit administration had to suspend it following a noisy demonstration by handicapped lottery vendors. Although the Thailand Development Research Institute concluded that the system would not serve its purpose of controlling lottery prices and that it would further spread gambling, the government ruled against abolishing the distribution contract for fear of affecting investor confidence. In its latest bid to revive the plan, the GLO is following two key government guidelines -- that the automatic lottery dispensing machines must not have an impact on vendors' jobs and that they be accepted by the public.

Ms Man said the rent was now $35,000 a month for the shop of 72 square metres. She estimated the rent should now be 40 per cent lower or $20,000 a month according to current market prices. She said she would not join the reassessment if it proved expensive. Another tenant, May Cheong Mei-yi, shared the same view. Ms Cheong, who is running a beauty parlour on the third floor, said she preferred an immediate rent cut to a reassessment. Ms Cheong said her business had dropped by half since the financial turmoil hit Hong Kong. Democrat Lee Wing-tat, also a member of the authority and a newly elected legislator, called for a 30 per cent rent cut across the board.

THE Election Commission, at the national and local levels, will be the sole authority to organise, administer and supervise future elections, while civil servants, previously in charge of the polls, will assume a role on the sidelines, EC member Yuwarat Kamolvej said on Thursday. Yuwarat, speaking at a seminar for provincial officials about new electoral rules mandated by the new Constitution, reminded government officials they have an important duty to facilitate voting although they are no longer in charge of the elections. ''Provincial and local officials are the core staff to ensure smooth casting of votes, but the public will not tolerate it if they interfere to fix the election outcome,'' he said. He pointed out that political reforms, including changes in electoral rules, were aimed at staging free and fair elections and doing away with money politics. He called for government officials, especially interior authorities, to render their utmost cooperation to run a clean election and absolve themselves from past public criticism that they had acted as vote canvassers. The EC member emphasised that although the EC will oversee the polls, it had to rely on about 1 million officials mobilised from various agencies to help run the polling stations. Police will be in charge of public safety; interior officials in charge of administrative works; transport officials in charge of moving ballot boxes; and postmen in charge of delivering absentee votes, he said. He also mentioned that although the drawing of 400 constituencies would take some time, the EC was empowered to speed up the process if there should be a snap election.

ROME (AP) _ The European Union intends to send a ``very clear and very strong'' message to Yugoslavia that peace must be restored in Kosovo, British Prime Minister Tony Blair said Friday. Britain currently hold the rotating presidency of the EU and Blair spoke to reporters in Rome after talks with Premier Romano Prodi. Many fear the explosive situation in Kosovo could lead to another Balkan war. ``We are well aware of the fact that we can't allow the situation to develop as we did in Bosnia,'' Blair said. ``We are examining every possible option.'' He said the EU intends to send ``a very clear and very strong message'' that it wants stability in the region. ``It would be a very serious mistake for people to underestimate our resolve and determination,'' he said. Tens of thousands of people have fled a fierce Serbs offensive in Kosovo, a Yugoslav province where ethnic Albanians make up 90 percent of the population. About 12,000 refugees have already reached Albania and as many as 7,000 others have made it to Montenegro. Serbia and much smaller Montenegro are the only republics left in the Yugoslav federation. Wooing back the necessary capital back to Asia, NATION June 05, 1998 NATION THAILAND ENGLISH ASIA WorldSources, Inc. 201 PENNSYLVANIA AVENUE, S.E., 2nd Floor
WASHINGTON, D.C. 20003 Tel: 202-547-4512 Fax: 202-546-4194 COPYRIGHT 1998 BY WORLDSOURCES, INC., A JOINT VENTURE OF FDCH, INC. AND WORLD TIMES, INC. In his remarks delivered before the recent meeting of Apec finance ministers in Canada, Sarasin Viraphol proposed policies to encourage a recovery of private capital inflows to Asia. ASIA is unlikely to witness a repeat of the extraordinary private capital flows during the decade preceding the current financial crisis in the region anytime soon, particularly given the ongoing prospect of Japanese deflation, growing signs of further economic contraction elsewhere in Asia, and the sustained American economic boom which has absorbed much of the world capital. In fact, the IMF predicts that for 1998, net private capital flows to the affected Asian economies, namely Thailand, South Korea and Indonesia, will be zero, while that to China will also decline significantly. The next round of capital flows into Asia, when it occurs, will mainly depend on how the regional economies are able to inspire confidence regarding their ability in expeditiously and effectively dealing with the unprecedented economic crisis and setting clear directions. Notwithstanding the resultant severe outback in their growth, these economies have demonstrated their readiness to move ahead with the globalisation processes, for which they have benefitted and suffered. While the cycle of boom and bust is a normal economic occurrence, the one Asia has been confronting is seen as directly caused by excesses associated with the new phenomenon of globalisation -- which the erstwhile frenzied pace of capital flows is one distinct manifestation. It may be relevant to recap the tale of Asia's boom and bust here. In the heyday of the Asian boom, particularly during the first half of the 1990s, private capital, encouraged by the requirement of Asian economies to grow rapidly, was flowing in profusion into the region's ''real sector'' -- especially in manufacturing -- as well as speculative sector, seeking rich returns on interest and exchange rates. But excessive investment in various business ventures often hastily generated from the regional bourses or financed by short-term loans -- so-called ''hot money'' -- subsequently strained the capacity of the region's financial market, leading to the ignominious burst, the flight of external private capital, and leaving Asia saddled with hundreds of billions of dollars in private debts. Now 10 months into the Asian financial crisis, the general picture of the corporate health in the region remains precarious and is showing signs of further deterioration. Corporate bankruptcies are now increasing steadily as tight liquidity and high interest rates are now familiar features in the affected regional economic landscape. In such a dire situation, a requisite for the return of private capital flows is the encouragement and facilitation of foreign participation in trade and investment among the concerned Asian economies. This may smack of heresy to those who regard the present economic turmoil as a direct result of over liberalisation, of the overexposure to external capital flows. According to this nationalist sentiment, to advocate further indiscriminate liberalisation would be tantamount to calling for the surrender of one's autonomy and sovereignty. The truth is the rapidly-growing Asian economies have long forfeited their ''independence'' in international economic transactions when they opted for globalisation and went on to achieve fame with ''Asian miracle'' during the past decades. As has subsequently been discovered, the new liberalised economic environment has -- as would be expected under other different circumstances -- its benefit and cost. Among the emerging market economies of Asia that won international accolades for their ''miracle growth'', more often than not one would find businesses that were highly leveraged with the readily-available external capital. Without fully appreciating the implications of the new economic order with its stress on rapid and high-yield growth, governments and enterprises alike threw caution to the wind and pursued expansion with a vengeance. Under these circumstances then, the affected economies need to examine a number of policies and measures which the Asian governments may consider adopting in meeting the challenge of encouraging the return of private capital flows. First, expeditious structural reforms of the financial sector are essential. Laws, regulations, procedures and practices aimed at inducing foreign participation in the manners of equity or management must be urgently implemented. The restructuring of the many troubled finance companies will involve the foreclosure laws being put in place. Thailand has enacted the long-awaited bankruptcy law for facilitating the resolution of failed enterprises along the line of the similar US legislation. This move should bring benefits to the creditor and the debtor. The country has also facilitated full foreign participation in its financial sector, which would permit a full takeover of a troubled finance company or bank, albeit for a limited period of time. Further liberalisation measures should be instituted to include the issuance of new banking licences to prospective foreign banks seeking to set up in Thailand. Such a practice would help Thailand meet the challenges of globalisation of the financial business in terms of infusions of fresh capital and management technology. And that is not to mention benefits befalling clients and customers of the Thai financial sector. Second, the revival of the imploded property sector is a matter of great urgency. It is sad legacy that the frenzied property development, especially over the past decade, has resulted in the massive creation of outstanding debts. One effective way of inducing private capital from abroad is to further liberalise foreign ownership of commercial and residential buildings. Hence, such legislation as the 40 per cent ownership limit of condominiums, the one-rai ownership of land, and the 30-year limit on leaseholds of commercial buildings, should be reviewed. Foreign property developers are willing to purchase office complexes even on a temporary basis through an arrangement of continual rental/occupation and an eventual buy-back by their original owners. It is important to remind oneself that in such cases, the observance of local laws remains paramount. Third, serious efforts must be made to reform the inefficient and corrupt bureaucracy. The bureaucracy's role is too vital to the recovery and eventual growth of the national economy to be overlooked. The attractiveness of a career in the bureaucracy must be enhanced, which should include more attractive incentives such as adequate remuneration. In an increasingly globalised environment, the bureaucracy must be sensitised about growing competition as well as accountability. Efficiency, integrity, and a sense of pride in, and dedication to, work for the public are indispensable qualities. Bureaucratic efficiency and integrity is essential for assuring the proper operation and management of foreign capital at least from the perspective that the bureaucracy will not be adversely intrusive. Fourth, promoting exports will inevitably induce the flow of capital. Much of the growth of the Asian economies over the past decade is attributable to the dedication to export-led manufacturing by both the government and private sector. At this juncture when reliance on export is greater than before, it would be imperative for the government to provide adequate export financing -- including loans to purchase raw materials and packing credits to exporters -- and facilitate export procedures. Now that agriculture-led exports appear to be Thailand's mettle, the Thai government should undertake necessary measures -- including providing farmers/growers and exporters with attractive incentives and fewer impediments. In this respect, the Thai government could eventually use some of the projected Bt70-billion bonds to be floated in Thailand and abroad over the next several months for this purpose, which would invariably benefit the welfare of most Thais who work in the agricultural sector as well. In addition, the government's efforts to maintain reasonable currency exchange and interest rates will enable agribusiness exporters to secure necessary capital in order to export and generate the much-needed revenue from abroad. The projections about the zero net inflows of private capital to the affected Asian economies, and the anticipated severe contraction of growth throughout the region for 1998 will aggravate corporate bankruptcies and worsen the unemployment situation with major social implications. In 1998, Thailand is facing the prospect of a negative economic growth projected at 5-6 per cent, and an unemployment pool of more than three million. In such a situation, the primacy of restoring private capital flows back to the region cannot be emphasised enough. The government and corporate sector, therefore, must work together to lower and eliminate barriers to trade and investment in a new nexus of mutual interests. By way of an analogy, it behooves the Asian countries to try to adjust the railway gauge of their respective economies to conform with the standard gauge of the globalised economies, so that the train of development may run on one harmonised track. -------------- Dr Sarasin Viraphol is executive vice president of Charoen Pokphand Group.

KUALA LUMPUR, Wed. - The Inland Revenue Board cannot disclose matters pertaining to investigations of defaulting taxpayers or whether those who bought properties beyond their means had declared their taxes correctly as these are confidential. Deputy Finance Minister Datuk Wong See Wah said this when asked by reporters whether the board will investigate former Selangor Menteri Besar Tan Sri Muhammad Muhammad Taib who recently admitted that he had bought properties in Australia and New Zealand under his wife's name. The Income Tax Act 1967 empowers the board to investigate individuals, among others, who buy luxury cars or properties beyond their means to see if these individuals had declared their income tax correctly. ``The Inland Revenue (Board) knows what to do ... the law applies to all,'' he told reporters after launching the IRB's new logo at the Jalan Duta Government Complex. Last week, Anti-Corruption Agency director-general Datuk Shafee Yahaya said it had completed part of its investigation of Muhammad, which started the moment Muhammad was detained for failing to declare more than A$1.2 million (RM2.95 million) when he left Brisbane International Airport on Dec 26, 1996. The Brisbane District Court had last Friday, acquitted Muhammad on two charges of falsely declaring the money he took into Australia in December 1996 and failing to declare more than A$1.2 million when he left the country. During his trial, Muhammad told the court that he had used his wife's name, Puan Sri Asbi Rohani Hasnan, to purchase assets in Australia and New Zealand. This included a plot of land valued at A$460,000 and a A$460,000 bungalow at Sovereign Island, Gold Coast; a farm in Currajong valued at A$3.7 million, a NZ$500,000 house (RM1.05 million) and two plots of land valued at about NZ$4 million in New Zealand. Asked whether the IRB will work with the ACA to pursue investigations against Muhammad, Wong said: ``I think we should let them (Inland Revenue Board) do the job.'' Citing an example, Wong said the IRB had also queried him on income tax matters previously. On another note, Wong said the IRB will not investigate individuals who bring in money from overseas following the move by the Government to allow them to do so two weeks ago. This, he said, means that these individuals need not declare these monies when submitting their income tax documents to the board for assessment. Wong said those interested are given until Dec 31 to bring in the monies. Asked if action would be taken if there was proof that those who had taken the money out of the country earlier were now contemplating to bring it back, he said: ``We are not bothered from where or how they had obtained the money. The IRB will not investigate.'' He said the money brought in will help increase liquidity in the market and this will help the country tide over this difficult period. He said the ministry has, so far, received about 30 queries from people wishing to bring in their monies from overseas. ``There is an individual who wishes to bring back about RM20 million. The others have between half a million and one million ringgit,'' he said. Wong said the Government was also glad that the IRB has managed to collect RM10.3 billion in the first four months of this year compared to RM9.1 billion in the same corresponding period of last year. He congratulated the IRB for having collected higher taxes despite the anticipated reduction in collection due to the economic slowdown. Earlier in his speech, Wong said the Finance Ministry has received 232 applications from companies and individuals seeking to reschedule their tax payments. He said of these 104 were individuals, businesses (78), companies (48), and property gains tax (two). Together, they owed the IRB RM36.7 million. Wong said the IRB has also recovered RM117 million after investigating 209 cases in the first four months of this year. In the same corresponding period last year, the board recovered RM210.3 million after solving 193 cases. Also present at the launch of the new logo were Treasury secretary- general Datuk Dr Aris Othman, who is also IRB chairman and IRB chief executive officer Najirah Mohd Tassaduk Khan.

OWNERS of apartments and households in many Bangkok districts have complained about the Metropolitan Electricity Authority's call for them to pay their power bills in advance, saying the demand is unfair given the economic situation. In letters sent to them since February, the MEA says they must pay an amount equivalent to twice their average monthly bills in advance. It calls the extra figure ''a deposit for future fees'' which it claims is necessary to prevent loss of income if power users move and leave their power bills unpaid. It promises to return the money after power users give up their right to power or transfer their right to others. Defending the much-maligned policy, MEA's Bang Khen district office chief Samit Nilphai said the MEA had lost several hundred millions of baht in uncollected bills after residents moved out without giving the MEA notice. Asked about the MEA's demand, Sirithat Klankhwamdee, a Provincial Electricity Authority assistant governor, said he had no comment but added he thought the MEA is probably having financial and cash flow problems.

FINANCIAL Secretary Sir Donald Tsang Yam-kuen has come under increasing pressure to raise public spending in a bid to stimulate the economy. Democratic Alliance for the Betterment of Hong Kong chief Tsang Yok-sing urged Sir Donald yesterday to relax his stance and post a deficit budget. Mr Tsang said he believed the people would not mind increased spending if it was necessary for the revival of the economy. The DAB legislator said the Financial Secretary should abandon his strict interpretation of Article 107 of the Basic Law, which forbids overspending by the government. Mr Tsang said letting government expenditure increase at a pace faster than the gross domestic product growth rate would not violate the SAR's mini-constitution. Deficit spending was necessary in times of economic recession, he stressed. Increasing government expenditure means the government should either raise taxes or prepare for a deficit budget, Mr Tsang said, adding that he ``believed the people would be more ready to accept a deficit''. But the pro-Beijing party leader admitted that a deficit budget would have adverse effects on the international community's confidence in Hong Kong as it would think the SAR was abandoning its traditionally prudent fiscal policies. He stressed, though: ``This is a very special time and we have to make a choice between two undesirable alternatives.'' Article 107 of the Basic Law stipulates that ``Hong Kong shall follow the principle of keeping expenditure within the limits of revenues in drawing up its budget, and strive to achieve a fiscal balance, avoid deficits and keep the budget commensurate with the growth rate of its gross domestic product''. The DAB stressed that the term ``commensurate'' did not indicate whether the growth rate of expenditure should be higher or lower than GDP growth. Mr Tsang said his party also believed the economy would improve in the near future, which means the rise in expenditure would not exceed GDP growth. As the government's method of calculating GDP growth was based on a specific period of time, it would be inappropriate to restrict the rise in expenditure to a year's GDP growth, he said. Mr Tsang hoped government expenditure would be used to create jobs to help the unemployed. Independent newly re-elected legislator Eric Li Ka-cheng, from the Accountancy constituency, also proposed a deficit budget last week by introducing a ``hardship-easing tax return'' measure. This suggests allowing firms that suffer losses this year and individuals who lose their jobs to claim back taxes paid in the previous two years from the government to help ease their hardship.

IPOH, Wed. - The High Court today upheld the decision of a lower court to sentence former electronics plant assembly employee Chow Chung Neng to four years' jail after he was found guilty of reckless driving which resulted in the deaths of seven people last year. Judge Datuk Kang Hwee Gee, after hearing submissions from the defence and prosecution, said Sessions Court Judge Abdul Aziz Khaliddin, who sat as magistrate, did not err when he arrived at the decision. ``Seven lives were lost and two people were seriously injured. As a result of the accident, one of the injured women who was four months' pregnant had a miscarriage,'' he said when dismissing the appeal against sentence and conviction by Chow. Chow, who had been serving his jail sentence from March 6, appeared calm and composed when Kang dismissed his appeal. The lower court on March 6 (this year) also ordered Chow's driving licence be suspended for 10 years. Chow, 28, was convicted under section 41(1) of the Road Transport Act 1987. He committed the offence at 7.20am on March 31, last year at KM9.5 Jalan Ipoh-Chemor. The crash caused the deaths of workers Sodma Othman, 39, N. Suppamah, 45, N. Ramlai Dewi, 37, Kung Mooy Lan, 40, S. Walliamah, 36, Liew Ah Kan, 34, and Rukibah Lop, 37. The offence is punishable with a jail term of up to five years or a maximum fine of RM10,000 or both. Defence counsel C.K. Leong earlier submitted that the magistrate had erred in law as nobody witnessed the accident. Leong said the magistrate was also wrong in rejecting the evidence of two defence witnesses who testified that Chow was an epileptic. He said Chow was in a state of epilepsy when he was driving the car on the fateful day. Deputy Public Prosecutor Chew Soo Ho said Chow was reckless as adduced evidence showed that he (Chow) was travelling at high speed.

BC-Diana-Investigation, 4th Ld-Writethhru
Witnesses, paparazzi, Al Fayed converge on Paris courthouse
Eds: UPDATES with interrogation of photographer. AP Photos PAR107-110 By JOCELYN NOVECK Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ A French judge on Friday brought together for the first time the main parties in the Diana investigation to try to finally clarify the role of the photographers in the crash. Grouped together were the photographers under investigation in the case; eight witnesses to the crash; Mohamed Al Fayed; and, according to defense lawyers in the room, Diana's mother, Frances Shand Kydd. They were accompanied by a platoon of lawyers. Judge Herve Stephan was trying to find out whether it was a simple car accident, caused by a drunk driver. The crash in a Paris traffic tunnel Aug. 31 killed Diana, her companion Dodi Fayed, and driver Henri Paul. Tests showed Paul was drunk at the time. But what was the responsibility of the paparazzi trailing Diana's Mercedes that night? Nine photographers and one press motorcyclist have been placed under investigation _ a step short of being formally charged. They have remained in legal limbo for almost a year, continuing their work. In what was seen as a last-ditch effort to clarify their roles, Stephan was questioning each photographer one by one. Lawyers emerging from the courtroom described the process. Two hours into the hearing, the judge had already dealt with two photographers: Romuald Rat and Stephane Darmon. Each gave an account of their activities that night. The judge then questioned them, questioned witnesses as to what they had seen, then opened questions to other lawyers. According to lawyers in the room, Rat also was harshly questioned by lawyers for Al Fayed, who tried to establish he pursued the Mercedes that night. ``I followed it. I did not pursue it,'' Rat responded, according to lawyers. Stepping outside for a break, Al Fayed, Dodi's father, would say only: ``It's going fine. Great judge.'' He is a civil party in the case, meaning he has access to documents and proceedings. Diana's mother was also there but said nothing, said lawyer Virginie Bardet. Ten witnesses were summoned, but only eight showed up. They included the first emergency doctor on the scene, Frederic Mailliez, and the first two policemen on the scene. ``It's very well organized. It's calm, thorough, and clear. I am persuaded it will serve a purpose,'' said lawyer Jean-Louis Pelletier, who represents photographers David Ker and Fabrice Chassery. The policemen said during the hearing Rat hindered their work, lawyers said on condition of anonymity. The photographers are being investigated on two charges: manslaughter, and failing to come to the aid of a person in danger. Many close to the case believe they will soon be exonerated, at least on the manslaughter charge. Nikolas Arsov, of the Sipa photo agency, said the hearing was inconvenient, but he understood the need for it. ``It's the 40th time we have answered the same questions,'' said Arsov. ``It's annoying, but what can you do? They have to do their job.'' Arsov was supposed to be shooting pictures Friday at the French Open tennis tournament. In contrast to previous hearings, all cameras were kept outside the Palais de Justice. The gates were heavily guarded by police. Al Fayed drew up to the main courthouse in a Mercedes, surrounded by four other cars and about 10 bodyguards. It isn't just his son's death that connects Al Fayed to the case. Driver Paul was an employee of the Ritz Hotel, which Al Fayed owns. ``I hope that God will find the truth for us,'' he said as he left the Ritz in the morning. His spokesman, Lawrie Meyer, said ``This is a process to decide if the paparazzi should go to trial.'' Mr. Al Fayed ``is still a grieving parent and is here to find out what happened to his son,'' he said. In a statement issued in London on Thursday, Al Fayed said he was ``determined to get to the truth'' about whether the crash was an accident or a plot to kill Diana and his son. French judicial sources said recently Al Fayed has backed off his contention that the crash stemmed from a plot, and now blames the paparazzi. Although the probe is not complete, investigators long have believed it was Paul's drunken condition and the Mercedes' excessive speed that probably caused the crash. They also are still looking for a white Fiat Uno believed to have brushed the Mercedes before it crashed. But they are said to have given up any real hope of finding the Fiat. Tests are still being conducted on the wrecked Mercedes Diana was traveling in, but aren't likely to be finished before October _ meaning the case can't be closed until then. Investigators also recently conducted road tests on a race track near Paris to reconstruct the crash. Police revealed no details of those tests. One person who wasn't attending Friday's session: bodyguard Trevor Rees-Jones, the sole survivor of the crash. He was invited on an ``informational basis,'' but decided not to come. (jn-dgs)

BC-Sports-Soccer-World Cup Tickets, 2nd Ld
Court throws out demand for ticket redistribution
Eds: UPDATES with court comment showing it appears to back complaint but can't rule; parliamentarians say individuals can seek redress By RAF CASERT Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ A court on Friday suggested a demand by a group of European lawmakers to redistribute World Cup tickets they claim were unfairly allocated to French fans was not unfounded, but threw out the case on technical grounds. The court said that under French law there can be no class action suit involving the tickets. The group of 32 European Parliament deputies had sought to have 700,000 tickets redistributed. The soccer championships start June 10 and run to July 12. They claimed the way was now open for individuals to file suits for tickets. ``The distribution system is likely to affect the rights of the ensemble of citizens of the (European) Community,'' the court said. It noted that the largest part of the tickets was reserved for ``French citizens, groups and businesses ... with an address on French national territory,'' but said it could not rule in the case. ``It was thrown out on a technical grounds. The court has not dealt with the matter as such,'' said Phillip Jenkinson, attorney for the lawmakers. To take the ticket matter to court, one can only seek tickets for oneself, Jenkinson said, explaining the court's decision to throw out the case. ``The way is open for other challenges from EU citizens,'' said Luc Misson, for 32, ``the court said that the access was not equitable to all the fans.'' `We are one nil down at half-time, but the courts have given us a penalty,'' said Graham Watson, of the Liberal Democrats of Britain, referring to the possibility for citizens to seek redress individually. UNIVERSITIES will have to struggle to make ends meet to comply with the government's request to expand post-graduate courses by 20 per cent, a leading university head said. Vice-Chancellor Arthur Li Kwok-cheung of the Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK) said his institution would have to dig into private funds and internal resources as the University Grants Committee (UGC) was unlikely to fund the extra places. ``We are willing to support the government,'' Mr Li said. ``However, it's not a matter of one more set of desks and chairs when it comes to teaching post-graduate students. ``We need more quality lecturers to teach quality students, but the government has not promised us more money. ``If we're to support the proposal, we will have to reallocate internal resources and pull out private funds.'' Prof Li said the university might be left holding the bag. ``During the good times, the government has cut our funding by 10 per cent, whereas during the bad times, we are asked to pay our own bill,'' he said. ``I'm worried that the government will not reimburse us even when the economy revives.'' It costs $20,000 a year to teach a post-graduate student. The expansion is one of the measures unveiled by Financial Secretary Sir Donald Tsang Yam-kuen to create more jobs. Under the plan, there will be 1,000 additional places for post-graduate courses in tertiary institutions this year. In a letter issued to all local higher education institutions, the UGC urged the school heads to ``consider and implement the proposal urgently''. They are given two weeks to decide what faculties should be granted the additional places. The new programs will start this autumn.

DEPUTY Prime Minister and Commerce Minister Supachai Panitchpakdi will fly to Japan in August to ask for an additional loan from the Japan Import-Export Bank, a Commerce Ministry official said. A crucial decision lies ahead for finance authorities on when and how interest rates should be brought down, the Finance Desk reports. THE time bomb is ticking as the worsening economic situation tightens its grip on coporate Thailand. Local firms are sinking like the Titanic. But the ''Thai-tanic'' could be salvaged if the government makes a right decision to cut interest rates. MR Chatu Mongol Sonakul, governor of the Bank of Thailand, said the move hinges mainly on market mechanism and the period of time, after a meeting between key finance officials and the country's think-tank, Thailand Development and Research Institute (TDRI), on the issue. ''Everyone agreed in principle with TDRI's proposal, but when and how remain big questions.'' ''I understand the TDRI tries to do the best thing for the country. But it still don't understand how the market works,'' he said. Chatu Mongol was referring to the dollar/baht exchange rates and inflationary pressure, the two crucial factors in any decision to slash interest rates. Finance Minister Tarrin Nimmanahaeminda, speaking at a symposium in Tokyo recently, said he would not hesitate to tighten monetary policy should there be increased pressure on the exchange rate. He noted that the Finance Ministry is in the process of ''cautiously easing monetary policy,'' increasing money supply and allowing growth in monetary reserve. The TDRI, led by president Anand Panyarachun, proposed to the economic team that fiscal and monetary policies should be mixed, giving some breathing space to cash-strapped companies. Former deputy prime minister Virabongsa Ramangkura, one of the TDRI delegation, said the government should pump a massive amount of money into the system, given an adequate amount of foreign reserves. ''Such a move will help raise exports, boost liquidity, rekindle foreign investments and increased purchasing power, and also lead to a reduction of interest rates,'' a source quoted Anand as saying. Analysts said that printing new money will accelerate the rate of inflation. According to the source, Virabongsa admitted that the negative impact of such a measure is a depreciation of the baht against the US dollar. ''But it is still acceptable if the baht does not fall beyond Bt45 to the greenback,'' he was quoted as saying. Dru Narwani, chief executive officer of Standard Chartered Bank, agreed that a range of Bt42-Bt45 per dollar is appropriate as the regional economic environment remains unfavourable. The baht yesterday declined to Bt42.60 against the US dollar from Wednesday's close of Bt42.20, its lowest level in 12 weeks. Despite the baht weakness, analysts said that the government cannot adopt a 'buy-time' strategy in cutting interest rates as most of companies are in a 'life-and-death' situation due to the severe shortage of liquidity. ''If they [the government] are afraid to bring down interest rates or postpone their decision, most companies would be dead. There is not much time left. This boils down to whether you should save currency or let the country die,'' an analyst of a leading local securities house said. But Chatu Mongol does not think so. He said that a cut in interest rates may lead to a deterioration of foreign investor confidence given the region's economic problems. Thailand's miracle economy lurched into a crisis as a result of the baht flotation last year when foreign capital started flowing out of the country. Offshore money was a major force to country's economic growth in the past. ''We cannot live with that [capital outflows],'' Chatu Mongol said. He admitted that the country is going through a difficult period and Thai companies need to consolidate to strengthen their financial position. So far, there has been no answer when interest rates will be reduced as companies close down one after the other. The reality is when the government decides on a reduction, there might be no company left to save.

A PUBLICITY campaign will be launched soon to raise the awareness among local computer users of the problem and prevention of the potentially devastating Y2K millennium bug. When 1999 becomes 2000, most computers will turn their two-digit internal clocks back to 00, causing conflicts with date-dependant programs. ``Seventy per cent of businesses have no idea that the millennium bug exists,'' according to Daniel Lai, president of the Hong Kong Computer Society and acting director of Information Technology of the Hong Kong Jockey Club. ``So the Industry Department has provided $70,000 in funds for the development of millennium bug awareness.'' The campaign will involve an educational video and CD-rom that will explain to small to medium-size businesses, the nature of the computer glitch. According to computer programmer and consultant Red Reid-Pitcher, the millennium bug is not going to pose that much of a problem to the technologically advanced SAR. He believes the problem can be rectified on three levels. ``The millennium bug is just a technical glitch, which can be easily solved.'' He states that the first area of concern is non-compliant computer chips. ``People just have to check with manufacturers of their hardware to see if they need to replace their chips.'' The second is store-bought and in-house software. ``Again, people with old programs such as Office 4.5 or Windows 3.1 have to call the software companies or programmers to see if their software is compliant.'' Mr Reid-Pitcher said software companies were likely to replace non-compliant products with improved copies. The third and ``most difficult'' area is the administration aspect. ``In large networks of hundreds of computers, all the computers must be checked for the bug.'' He believes computer chips in some home appliances and cars will be affected but disagrees that a global computer meltdown will occur on New Year's Eve 1999 because most companies will solve the problem by then. ``But you won't see me on any planes on New Year's Eve,'' he said.

BC-Sports-Olympics-Samaranch
IOC president to push for change in Olympic soccer format
By STEPHEN WILSON AP Sports Writer
SEVILLE, Spain (AP) _ The head of the International Olympic Committee said Friday he will urge the next FIFA president to drop the under-23 format for Olympic soccer and open up the competition to all the world's best players. IOC president Juan Antonio Samaranch said he will discuss scrapping the restrictions with the winner of next Monday's FIFA presidential election in Paris. Lennart Johansson, head of the European federation UEFA, and FIFA secretary general Sepp Blatter are the two candidates to succeed outgoing president Joao Havelange. ``This is something we have in our agenda _ to discuss with the new president the possibility to increase the number of players without the age limit,'' Samaranch said. FIFA, eager to guard the supremacy of its World Cup, has restricted the Olympic soccer competition to players under the age of 23 _ resulting in what amounts to an amateur or youth tournament. The rule was relaxed for the 1996 Atlanta Games and the 2000 Sydney Games to allow teams to field three players over 23. ``Maybe this figure can be increased,'' Samaranch said. ``Our dream is to have an open football tournament, but we think we need some years to (achieve) this aim.'' Samaranch said the IOC enjoyed close relations with FIFA and Havelange, a Brazilian who has been an IOC member since 1963. ``We are sure the next president will follow the same way and that relations with the IOC will be very friendly,'' he said. On a related matter, Samaranch said he plans to appoint the next FIFA president as an IOC member. ``FIFA is maybe the most important federation in the world,'' he said. ``To have the president of FIFA inside the IOC is something we would like to have.'' Samaranch spoke at a news conference at the close of a joint meeting of the IOC executive board and the Association of National Olympic Committees, which represents the world's 198 national governing bodies. Samaranch repeated his message, delivered earlier this week to the U.S. Olympic Committee, that American athletes must improve their medal performance to ensure the success of the 2002 Winter Games in Salt Lake City. The United States won 13 medals, including six gold, at the Nagano Games in February. The total matched the best ever U.S. performance at a winter games but was still below expectations. ``All the home teams must get good results, because if not, the people they are very much disappointed,'' Samaranch said. ``We reminded the USOC ... they must have an effort to improve their results. The results were good results but maybe they must be excellent, not only good.'' Samaranch also virtually ruled out the possibility of adding women's ski jumping for the Salt Lake Games, saying the event has not yet been established on a world-class level. ``The Olympic Games can not be an experiment,'' he said. ``The event must be tested in world championships. Many countries must have participation. I think it's too early for this event.'' On an issue affecting the 2000 Sydney Games, Samaranch said the IOC was powerless to stop price gouging by hotels which are not contracted by the local organizing committee. A delegate at this week's meetings complained that three-star hotels in Sydney could charge up to dlrs 550 a night for a room. ``That is the market,'' Samaranch said. ``The market is free. We can do nothing. We can only ask to respect the prices for the Olympic family. I'm sure these prices will be respected.'' On doping, Samaranch said the IOC could not force international federations to carry out year-round drug testing programs, and he ruled out calls for sports to be thrown out of the Olympics unless they comply. ``We are doing our best to convince them,'' Samaranch said. ``The most important federations are doing their best. We will follow this way. To say you must do this or you are not in the Olympics, that is not the way to do things. We prefer to convince, not to impose.'' Samaranch sided with the national Olympic committees in their dispute with international federations over who has control over athletes' uniforms during the games. The federations have pushing to change the Olympic Charter to give them more control. ``It's very simple,'' Samaranch said. ``We have an Olympic Charter. We have rules and we will abide by these rules.'' (sw)

SOME of us have been fortunate to watch our mothers and grandmothers grow old without any complaints pertaining to menopausal symptoms. They just seemed to age gracefully. In retrospect, they probably had symptoms but as prevailing culture and customs demanded, they must have just suffered in silence. But times have changed and women are more educated and aware. Besides, technology and advanced medical science have given women a better quality of life, better health and more effective treatment for menopausal discomforts. Women too, on their part, speak up, complain and ask questions about their health. Doctors say menopause is not a disorder or a disease, even though it has several clear symptoms. It is only a time of physical and emotional changes, and it affects all women who live up to that age. As many know, most women start to experience menopausal symptoms between the ages of 40 and 45, although the actual menopause occurs at about age 50. As the female body ages, the ovaries become unresponsive to the hormones produced by the pituitary gland. As a result, oestrogen and progestogen (the two most important female hormones produced by the ovaries) decrease and the menstrual cycle becomes irregular, slows down and then ceases altogether. Naturally, such important changes show themselves in a range of symptoms (but not all of which are experienced by every woman). Some of the changes that can affect women in menopause, doctors say, are headaches, insomnia, dizziness, anxiety, irritability, sweating, heart palpitations, depression, hot flushes, reduced sex drive, vaginal itch and lack of secretion. They can also experience urinary problem, mood swings, emotional changes, poor sleeping patterns, pains in the joints and temper outburts. Dr Eckehard Liske, head of gynaecological endocrinology at the medical department of pharmaceutical company Schaper Brummer, Salzgitter- Ringelheim, said the pattern of symptoms have been noted to differ slightly between Caucasian and Asian women. ``Headaches, dizziness, insomnia, heartbeat palpitations and pains in joints are more common symptoms among Asians. A diet high in soyabean content is widely believed to have generally reduced the incidence of hot flushes and night sweats among Asian women, which are prevalent in the majority of Caucasian women,'' said the 51-year-old German, who came to Kuala Lumpur recently. Previously, the only relief from these symptoms for women here was to undergo hormone replacement therapy (HRT). This is the replacement of oestrogen and progestogen through tablet intake. While HRT does, no doubt, alleviate menopausal symptoms, it poses a number of health risks. ``Women on intensive HRT face a higher risk of developing breast cancer. Moreover, of concern among Muslim women, is the fact that the oestrogenic component of HRT is mainly sourced from animal extract, which may not be what you consider halal.'' Dr Liske, who has a wry sense of humour, also commented on an article entitled Oestrogen Therapy: Should Women Go For It Despite The Risks? where author Isaac Schiff, chief of obstetrics and gynaecology at Massachusetts general hospital, puts the HRT dilemma in a refreshing light. ``Basically, you're presenting women with the possibility of increasing the risk of getting breast cancer at age 60, in order to prevent a heart attack at age 70 and a hip fracture at age 80,'' he said. (HRT, while alleviating the menopausal symptoms, reduces the risk of heart attack and bone thinning or osteoporosis, both due to hormone deficiency. However, it apparently increases the risk of breast cancer.) So would you rather have a quick death from heart attack or a slow agonising death from breast cancer? Fortunately, Malaysian women today have other options. There is now a proven herbal alternative to HRT in relieving menopausal symptoms. There is also a means of complementing HRT with the herbal remedy enabling the use of very low dosage of hormones in HRT. In general, says Dr Liske, a lower dosage in HRT means lesser side- effects in the future. That is what many doctors are doing in Germany, he adds, and ``they are working out well''. Dr Liske's visit to Kuala Lumpur recently was to meet medical professionals here regarding this herbal remedy. It is made from the roots of a plant called black cohosh (Cimicifugae racemosa) which has its origins in North America. The North American Indians used it to treat a variety of ailments, like women's cramps, menstrual ills and menopause problems. Then the American colonists used it further. In Germany, it has been in use for more than 40 years and it has been exported to the United States, Australia, Sweden, Luxembourg and Switzerland, amongst others, in recent years. Introduced in Singapore and Malaysia last year, it will soon be launched in neighbouring Asian countries. This black cohosh root preparation has been approved and registered by the Ministry of Health here as a herbal medicine for treatment of symptoms associated with menopause. ``So it is safe to use and can be bought over the counter,'' says Dr Liske. ``This preparation has good pharmaceutical quality, meaning, each tablet has consistency in quality and efficacy. There are no known side-effects and it is also non-addictive. It relieves the symptoms without interfering with hormone levels.''

Tunisian airline opens route to Lebanon
BEIRUT, Lebanon (AP) _ Tunisia's national airline began flights to Beirut for the first time Friday. A Tunisair Airbus 320 plane landed at Beirut airport at 8:30 a.m. (0530GMT), with Tunisian Transport Minister Hussein al-Shouk and a 40-member delegation on board. They were received by Lebanese Transport Minister Omar Miskawi. Tunisair will operate a direct flight to Beirut weekly, Beirut airport officials said. Tunisair brings to 32 the number of foreign airlines flying to Beirut. Most foreign airlines shunned Beirut airport during the 1975-90 civil war when it became a haven for hijackers and kidnappers.

BC-Japan-Bullet Train Inspections
Japan railway to check axles, wheels of 1,100 bullet train cars
TOKYO (AP) _ East Japan Railway Co. will carry out emergency inspections of the axles and wheels on all 1,100 of its high-speed bullet train cars following the deadly train crash in Germany, a news report said Friday. The inspections come after German federal railway authorities confirmed that a wheel failure was the most likely cause of the accident this week that killed at least 96 people, Kyodo News reported. East Japan Railway officials were unavailable for comment late Friday. The inspections will be completed by Monday, the report said. Tokyo-based East Japan Railway operates three main ``Shinkansen'' lines with trains which run up to 270 kilometers (168 miles) per hour. It is the biggest part of the former national railway company, which was split up in 1987. JR East sister companies Central Japan Railway Co. and West Japan Railway Co. operate separate bullet train networks. The two sister companies did not have immediate plans Friday for emergency inspections of their bullet trains' axles and wheels, Kyodo said. (cd)

THE first major financial study of Hong Kong's public health service has been launched to tackle costs, which have increased sixfold in the last 10 years. Financial Secretary Sir Donald Tsang Yam-kuen said last night the Domestic Health Account would be completed by the end of the year. The study, which is being carried out by experts from the Harvard University School of Public Health, will show what resources are available and how they are distributed. Sir Donald warned that people could not carry on taking public services for granted indefinitely. He was speaking at the joint annual dinner of the Public Doctors' Association and Government Doctors' Association. ``We must define the level of subsidy and set it within clear boundaries which the economy can sustain over the long term. ``As our population ages and increases, with greater numbers of people seeking treatment from the public sector, we will simply not be able to afford it.'' He said the finance study had been launched after figures showed that in 1988-89, the government spent $5 billion or 10.6 per cent of its total recurrent public expenditure on health. But in the current financial year, health expenditure is estimated to be $29 billion, 14.6 per cent, of the budget, he added. Sir Donald said the elderly population was growing as people lived longer. At present, 10 per cent of the population is 65-years old or over but by 2015, it will reach 13 per cent, he said. ``Elderly people need four or five times as much medical attention and treatment as younger people. Added to this, consumers demand constant improvements in the quality of services and facilities, as well as access to new technology, which pushes up the cost of healthcare,'' he said. The world had shown that there were ``no easy answers'' to healthcare financing, he added. ``There is no single `right' formula. We may find that our system operates best with a mix of different approaches. ``Healthcare is an issue that concerns every member of society.''

A SENIOR police officer on Thursday denied allegations in a Canadian court that he had tried to extort money from Rakesh Saxena, wanted for embezzlement charges related to the Bangkok Bank of Commerce scandal. The denial from Pol Maj Gen Chalermdej Jomunud, deputy commissioner of the Immigration Bureau, followed allegations by Vancouver accountant Les Hammond, who said the officer had asked for Bt60 million, for bribe and bail, from Saxena just before the Indian-born banker was arrested. However, Chalermdej said it was not possible for him to demand a bribe because he had coordinated with Canadian police before he met Saxena in Vancouver. He added that his meeting with Saxena had been monitored by plain-clothes Canadian policemen who sat next to their table in a restaurant. Agence France-Presse reported on Thursday that Hammond, Saxena's former partner, made the allegations while testifying in Saxena's hearing for extradition in Vancouver on Wednesday. ''Thai police will ask for bribes regularly,'' said Hammond. Hammond told the British Columbia Supreme Court that the policeman had used the bank scandal to try and extort money from Saxena and others charged with embezzlement. He said payments were discussed during meetings with Thai police at a ski resort in Whistler, north of Vancouver. ''You may not get a fair trial in Thailand but you can always buy your way out of trouble,'' Hammond said. The latest testimony, under questioning from Saxena's lawyer, helped portray the fugitive banker as a victim. During questioning by prosecutors last week, the crown witness revealed the inner workings of Saxena's financial holdings around the world and his dubious accounting practices. Saxena, 44, apart from being linked to a US$2 billion bank loan scandal also faces charges of embezzling $60 million from the Bangkok Bank of Commerce (BBC), where he was once the treasury adviser. Saxena said that the charges had been filed in revenge after he had successfully prevented a hostile takeover of the BBC four years ago. Hammond testified that Saxena had arranged for the money to be paid in bribes so he could secure bail if he returned to Bangkok. He added that a suitcase containing $100,000 worth of currency was to be given to Chalermdej and another officer who had travelled to Vancouver in July 1996 to meet Saxena and convince him to return to Thailand. Saxena was arrested in Whistler while having lunch with two Thai policemen in July 1996. Canadian police seized the briefcase containing the cash. Hammond and Saxena had a falling out later and now Saxena is suing Hammond for the return of corporate documents which Saxena claims are his. Hammond is suing Saxena for $138,000 in severance pay. Saxena fled Thailand on May 18, 1996, one day after the country's finance minister took control of the bank. He had also been linked to the so-called ''Arms to Africa'' scandal that has rocked the British government. Reports from London say Saxena admitted to paying $1.55 million to a private British military firm which was instrumental in staging a military counter-coup in the African nation of Sierra Leone.

TO HELP corporates enhance their liquidity position and manage their cashflow, Standard Chartered Bank has recently launched a cheque collection programme, called National Collection Service (NCS), which will provide funds faster than through the normal procedures. A corporation, from now on, could receive outstanding monies within three days of the date indicated on the cheque depending on the agreement with the bank. Cheques from the provinces may currently take some seven to 15 days to process. However, NCS will charge customers 0.2 per cent of the amount due, which is the regular fee local banks charge their customers. After receiving cheques from customers, NCS will be responsible for the cheque clearing process with its corresponding banks, Siam Commercial Bank and Bank of Ayudhya, until the money has been collected from the cheque issuers.However, in the case of bounced cheques, NCS would go through the clearing process again. Should the cheque bounce again, NCS would reject the cheque and debit the cash it advanced to its customers. ''With increasing competition, most businesses are focusing on streamlining their operations and on increasing efficiency and productivity. Standard Chartered Bank understands this need and the new service will enable companies in Thailand to maximise available cash resources in order to increase their competitiveness,'' said Dru Narwani, Standard Chartered Bank's chief executive officer. Meanwhile, Anthony Solimini, the bank's senior product manager under Corporate and Institutional Banking, said that due to the sluggish regional economies, it is the perfect time to launch such a product. The service would help client's manage liquidity and the use of funds, particular in Thailand where there are number of cheque clearing zones, and there remains a problem of transit and clearing time. He added that the service would help customers to predict the inflow of cash. The service was launched in Malaysia and India early last year and the bank claims that it has been a successful operation. Despite the bank having less exposure in Thailand due to the economic downturn, Narwani insisted that the bank has retained its relationship with its customers and is now concentrating its business on trade financing and retail businesses such as credit card operations. The bank's local-currency deposit accounts currently stand at Bt7-8 billion and while Bt5-10 billion is tied up with retail and corporate customers. At least 60 per cent of the bank's customers are multinational corporations, the remainder being local corporations. According to Mike Wood, the bank's head of Corporate and Institutional Banking, so far, the bank is focusing on small and medium-sized exporters and importers. As local banks struggle to boost their capital to cover rising non-performing loans, several foreign banks, particularly those that are retail and business-oriented, are shopping around for cheap stakes in Thai bank's. Standard Chartered Bank is no exception. According to Narwani, the bank has set three key stipulations which must be met in acquiring stakes in local banks. The three factors are high quality books, pricing and strategy. At present, the bank is in negotiations with some of the domestic banks. ''We've got a lot of work to do since we're talking about a potentially huge loss in the future. Pricing is also important. And we want to extend branches, so we're looking for branch network. ''Currently, I would say there is a 50:50 chance of the deal going through,'' he said. As the industrial sector is suffering from a liquidity crunch, the bank has urged the government to ease its monetary policy. Thippaporn Gertphol, the bank's treasurer, said that the central bank has been attempting to keep the baht stable since the beginning of 1997. Currently, she said that there should be a balance between baht stability and boosting liquidity. ''To ease [monetary policy] a little and inject money into the industrial sector would be the ideal situation. However, the monetary policy should not be dropped. The baht has become weaker and inflation has reached a controllable level. This will make more cash flow into the market,'' she said.

LIBERAL Party chief Allen Lee Peng-fei was yesterday appointed to the Commission on Strategic Development in what was seen as a move by the government to guard against ``grassroots pressures'' in the new legislature. The commission is a think-tank that advises Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa on a wide spectrum of long-term development issues. ``Mr Lee's wide experience and experience in the business sector will be most useful to the work of the commission,'' a government spokesman said. But an academic believes Mr Lee, a veteran politician, was named to the commission to maintain his high visibility in public and keep his pro-business party on the side of the government. James Sung Lap-kung, a lecturer in the department of public and social administration at the City University, said Liberal lawmakers could ally themselves with the two major blocs, the Democratic Party and the Democratic Alliance for the Betterment of Hong Kong, in the new legislature. Both the Democrats and DAB support grassroot interest, particularly on livelihood issues. Mr Lee lost in his bid for a Legislative Council seat in the direct election but 10 of his party members made it through the functional constituencies and Election Committee. Mr Sung said that with a close relationship between Mr Lee and Mr Tung in the commission it will be easier for Mr Tung to win over the 10 LP lawmakers. He said Mr Tung could lobby Mr Lee to prevent the party from allying with the DP and DAB. Mr Sung added: ``While the Liberal Party advocates an economic-led strategy, which is in line with the government's policy, it is important for the government to keep Mr Lee within its political circle.'' He believes Mr Lee was not appointed to the Executive Council because the government did not want to cause conflicts among political parties. It would be better for Mr Lee to exert his influence in the commission, which covers various issues including education, human resources, housing and relations between the SAR and Beijing, Mr Sung said. He said the commission was like a ``super-Exco''. He added Mr Lee's stint with the commission would serve as a transition to the next polls, which will be held in 2000. Coincidentally, Mr Lee's appointment is from 2 June this year to 31 January 2000.

REAL estate markets in Asia are currently facing a severe downturn with rentals and capital values falling significantly, according to the Asia-Pacific Property Digest and the European Office Index, two recently-published research reports prepared by international property consultants Jones Lang Wootton (JLW). Craig Plumb, director of Research at JLW (Thailand), commented that a contrast between the Asian and European office markets is a clear example of the cyclical nature of the property markets. Asian office markets are suffering from higher vacancies, lower rents and capital values. According to JLW's Asia-Pacific Property Digest, the office markets in most Asian cities are witnessing increasing vacancy rates as many companies in these cities implement rationalisation and downsizing strategies in response to the regional economic downturn. During the first quarter of 1998, the Bangkok CBD and Jakarta office markets experienced negative occupancies, leading vacancy rates to rise to 26.7 per cent and 13.6 per cent, respectively. The Kuala Lumpur market witnessed the largest jump among all cities from 3.7 per cent to 10.6 per cent over the same period. Makati in the Philippines recorded the lowest rate at 3.5 per cent. Rents fell by 14.2 per cent in Kuala Lumpur, 7.6 per cent in Hong Kong and 6.6 per cent in Shanghai. Bangkok saw a modest fall in rents (-4 per cent) over the first quarter. Other cities seeing a slight drop in rents were Singapore (-3.4 per cent), and Makati (-3.3 per cent). Tenants in most markets are very cautions about the expansion of space and relocation though landlords are offering more incentives. Sales activity has slowed down throughout region. Office capital values fell in all Asian office markets over the first quarter. The largest decline in capital values among Asian office markets was in Jakarta (-30.8 per cent). The Bangkok market saw a drop of only 1.1 per cent during the last quarter due to a lack of open market volume. In other cities, capital values fell by 14.6 per cent in Hong Kong, 10.2 per cent in Singapore, 10 per cent in Kuala Lumpur and 5.2 per cent in Makati. The depreciation of most Asian currencies also have a negative impact on rents and capital values in the Asian markets. Plumb noted that Thailand was the first country in Asia to experience the economic downturn and the property market was one of the first to react with rentals and values falling sharply during the second half of 1997. ''The rapid economic growth in most Asian countries over the past five to 10 years generated strong demand for office space in those countries' major cities, resulting in rapid increase in rentals and capital values,'' said Plumb. High levels of construction activity followed the market boom, resulting in significant over-building in most markets. The situation has been exacerbated by reduced demand as most Asian countries have been negatively affected by the regional economic crisis. ''On the other hand, the office markets in Europe are now emerging from their previous downturn following oversupply and economic recession, most cities are now experiencing an upturn in their cycle with rents and capital values picking up,'' he said.

THAILAND-BASED Better CNM International Ltd is set to start trading in Vietnam, supplying raw materials to five industrial sectors. Chayanon Kitayachaweng, senior general manager, said the company will replace its representative office in Ho Chi Minh City with a head office this year, aiming to boost business through direct marketing. Founded in 1996, Better CNM is a subsidiary of Thailand's leading agribusiness conglomerate, Betagro Group. BC-Lebanon-Economy,0310
Lebanon announces Eurobond issue, financial rating downgraded
BEIRUT, Lebanon (AP) _ Lebanon has named Merrill Lynch as lead manager in a dlrs 500 million Eurobond issue to be launched by the end of September, newspapers said Friday. State Minister for Finance Fuad Saniora said the bond issue is part of a plan approved by Parliament to borrow dlrs 2 billion abroad to restructure part of the dlrs 14 billion national debt. He said the bond will have a minimum seven-year maturity. The announcement was made at a joint press conference Thursday with Winthrop Smith, chairman of Merrill Lynch International, who is on his first visit to Lebanon. Another dlrs 500 million Eurobond issue will be announced later this year, Saniora said. So far, the government has issued five bonds with total value of about dlrs 1 billion to finance the rebuilding of Lebanon's infrastructure, which was devastated in the 1975-90 civil war. Merrill Lynch has lead-managed issues by the Lebanese government and banks since 1994. Meanwhile, Fitch IBCA, one of the top international rating agencies, said it was downgrading the country's financial outlook, which is a blow to Lebanon's effort to improve economic performance. The agency said in London that it was lowering Lebanon's long-term currency rating from BB to BB-, citing a deterioration in the country's fiscal position in 1997 and a high deficit. ``Post-war growth remains below initial expectations, reflecting continued regional instability,'' said the agency's report carried Friday by the English-language Daily Star. Merrill Lynch Chairman Smith, speaking Friday after a meeting with Lebanese President Elias Hrawi, said he disagreed with Fitch's decision. A day earlier, Smith said he was impressed with Lebanon's reconstruction drive.

BC-Norway-Mexico-Oil
Mexico predicts further cuts to boost oil prices
OSLO, Norway (AP) _ Mexico's Energy Minister Luis Tellez on Friday said he expected at least two OPEC nations to announce further production cuts next week to help reduce a global oil glut that has kept prices low. He declined to specify which countries he expected to make the reductions. Tellez met briefly with Norwegian Oil Minister Marit Arnstad in Oslo, one day after Mexico, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela announced plans to cut their total oil production by 450,000 barrels a day as of July 1 to boost prices. OPEC cut its production quotas by 1.5 million barrels per day in March. Combined with the expected 150,000-barrel cut by the unspecified countries, ``this is enough to restore the balance in the market,'' Tellez said at a news conference. Norway, the world's second-largest oil exporter after Saudi Arabia, reduced its roughly 3-million-barrel daily production by 100,000 barrels to help OPEC reduce supplies but said further cuts were not immediately planned. PHATRA Thanakit Plc will today sign an agreement to welcome Merrill Lynch International Holding Inc as the main partner in its securities company, Phatra Securities Ltd. Sources in the securities industry said Phatra Thanakit will sell 127.5 million shares to the US company -- or 51 per cent of its total capital of Bt2.5 billion -- at Bt20.80 apiece. Merrill Lynch International Holding will buy the shares directly from Phatra Thanakit, which will receive Bt2.65 billion from the sale, or $63 million. Phatra Securities is 100 per cent owned by Phatra Thanakit, and the parent company is 49 per cent owned by Thai Farmers Bank. Merrill Lynch conducted the due diligence in May. The sources said although Phatra Securities has a two-year partnership with Goldman Sachs, it decided to sell the stake to Merrill Lynch because it offered a better price. ''Phatra is also impressed with Merrill Lynch's active operations in securities trading,'' a source said. It has been a vision of Phatra Thanakit chairman Viroj Nualkhair to build a regional securities house, starting with the selection of a foreign partner with a worldwide network to strengthen its securities business. In Thailand, Phatra Securities is among the top five brokerage houses. Last year it ranked second in terms of broking transactions, valued at Bt130.5 billion, which drove its market share to 8.99 per cent. It was second only to Securities One Plc, which recorded a volume of Bt139 billion, or a 9.59 per cent market share. But for Viroj the local ranking means nothing if the company cannot find new markets outside the country so that revenue from overseas operations can substitute for losses at home. He has been proven right as the economy plunges into recession. From an annual economic growth of 8 per cent in the past 10 years, Thailand recorded zero growth last year but the worst is expected to come this year, with predicted negative growth of 5 per cent. The securities industry is being severely battered as foreign investors, a major driving force in the local market, disappear due to a lack of confidence. According to the Securities and Exchange Commission, last year the revenue of 22 operating securities companies dropped sharply from Bt4.8 billion a year earlier to minus Bt6.12 billion last year due to lower broking fees, fee-based income and net interest and dividend income as well as investment losses. ''We need a strong global broker to strengthen our regional perspective,'' Viroj said three years ago. However, sources in the industry said Phatra might not have embraced a foreign broker this quickly if the local securities business remained upbeat.

OUTSPOKEN legislator Chim Pui-chung may be ``pig-headed, reckless or irresponsible'' but he is not dishonest, his lawyer told a jury yesterday. John Griffiths, SC, said prosecutors had failed to show the wealthy politician was guilty of any crime over an allegedly crooked $350 million property deal. Chim, 50, will take the witness stand today, the 90th day of his trial on six charges relating to bribery, forgery and conspiracies to defraud. Mr Griffiths said Chim would explain his actions even though the defence believed prosecutors had failed to prove criminal wrongdoing on his part. Introducing the defence case to the jury, Mr Griffiths said Chim was a well-known personality with a reputation. ``If I said he was outspoken with the radio and press it would be under-exaggerating.'' Chim had a good character, with his only conviction 18 years ago when he admitted to being drunk and disorderly during a spat with a taxi driver on his way home from a night out. Mr Griffiths said a theme of alleged dishonesty ran through all charges Chim faced. But he added: ``In 89 days we have not heard a single piece of direct evidence that Chim was dishonest. ``You can do things because you're reckless, because you're pig-headed, because you're stupid or you misunderstood the position. ``But none of these states of mind are good enough to constitute an intention to commit a crime to defraud.'' Jurors may decide Chim was ``pig-headed, reckless, irresponsible, but not criminal'', Mr Griffiths said. Chim is standing trial with Nelson Chan Kai-fung, a director of Chim's Silver Mountain Company, who denies five charges of fraud and forgery. Prosecutors allege Chim weaved a massive web of lies out of ``personal greed'' to make tens of millions of dollars illegally. It centres around the build-up to the 1993 sale of Fairmount Terrace in Repulse Bay, a four-tower block of residential flats. Chim is accused of deceiving minority shareholders of two companies he controlled _ Mandarin Resources and Lucky Man. The businessman allegedly kept secret an increase in the the size of building allowed _ making it prime for redevelopment _ and concealed a $350 million offer from a prospective buyer. He is then said to have snapped up most shares in Lucky Man, which went on to sell Fairmount Terrace for a massive profit. Mr Griffiths urged jurors not to view the facts with hindsight, but as they appeared to Chim at the time. The legislator was a wealthy man, but ``it is certainly not a crime in Hong Kong to make money'', he said. The trial, before Justice Pang Kin-kee, continues.

Dutch government intercepts suspect Pakistan-bound shipments
THE HAGUE, Netherlands (AP) _ The Dutch government has blocked five export shipments bound for Pakistan because they were suspected of being destined for ``strategic uses,'' a spokeswoman said Friday. The government released no details of what was in the shipments or which companies were trying to export them without the necessary permits. ``We expected that they would be used for strategic uses,'' said spokeswoman Paula de Jonge of the Ministry of Economic Affairs. The shipments were intercepted over the past year she said, refusing to be more specific. They are still being held in the Netherlands, Austria and Belgium, Dutch media reported Friday. The suspect shipments came to light this week when Dutch magazine Vrij Nederland reported that they were destined for Pakistan's weapons programs. Vrij Nederland reported that the shipments were made by a Dutch company with links to Dr. Abdul Qadeer Khan, the mastermind of Pakistan's nuclear program. Khan was convicted in absentia and sentenced to four years in prison by Amsterdam district court in November 1983 for stealing confidential information from Urenco, a Dutch-British-German consortium that enriches uranium for the nuclear power industry. Khan's conviction was later overturned on a legal technicality. He worked at Urenco in the 1970s. (mc/bk)
