Britain publishes early release bill for sectarian prisoners
Eds: AMs. New throughout with prison bill published
BELFAST, Northern Ireland (AP) _ As part of the Northern Ireland peace settlement, Britain published a bill Friday providing for the release of up to 400 prisoners belonging to the IRA and pro-British Protestant paramilitary groups by mid-2000. Reflecting the sensitivity of the issue, Northern Ireland Secretary Mo Mowlam stressed that the Irish Republican Army and two pro-British groups will have to maintain cease-fires and cooperate with a commission charged with supervising weapons handovers in order for their supporters to qualify. ``There will be no general amnesty. The gates of the Maze Prison will not suddenly be thrown open,'' said Mowlam, referring to the jail near Belfast where most paramilitary prisoners are held. Early releases are a key provision of the peace agreement endorsed in a May 22 referendum. The accord provides for this British province to have a Protestant-Catholic power-sharing assembly and formal links with the Irish Republic. The bill stipulated that each prisoner's case will be reviewed individually, that prisoners deemed still dangerous to the public would be kept inside, and that those released will be jailed again if they commit new violence. The IRA and two Protestant-based groups, the Ulster Defense Association and Ulster Volunteer Force, have maintained cease-fires and their political allies endorsed the agreement. Members of dissident groups that have not declared cease-fires, including the Irish National Liberation Army and Loyalist Volunteer Force, are not eligible for parole. The province's largest Protestant party, the Ulster Unionists, whose support was vital for the agreement, said it accepted the wording of the bill, but would suggest some amendments in the House of Commons ``to try to make it watertight.'' ``I accept that for many, particularly the victims and their families, this is a difficult issue,'' Mowlam said. About 3,400 people have died in nearly 30 years of violence in Northern Ireland. Publishing the bill is the first step toward introduction in Parliament. (mj-kg)

A WOMAN was caught red-handed with pirated compact discs when they spilled out of a box in front of a Customs and Excise officer. The officer arrested Wong Hung-fan and subsequently searched her home in Tai Kok Tsui where he found 10,173 pirated discs _ 7,817 video CDs and 2,330 musical CDs. Wong, 45, was convicted in the District Court yesterday of four counts of possession of copied discs for business purposes without being licensed by the copyright owner. Judge Bernard Whaley said that under the new ordinance, each CD could carry a fine of $50,000 and Wong would have to pay a staggering total of $500 million. Wong's lawyer Newman Wong, however, said his client had to raise money to support her daughter who was studying at Oxford University in England. Wong had $20,000 to $30,000 in her account, the court heard. After considering Wong's financial situation, Judge Whaley imposed a 12-month jail term instead of imposing a fine. The court was told that Customs and Excise officers placed the Tai Kok Tsui area under surveillance last July. Wong had been pushing a trolley carrying 12 boxes when a box tipped scattering the CDs in front of an officer involved in the surveillance operation.

Moya reaches men's final by defeating Mantilla
Eds: UPDATES with Moya defeating Mantilla By ROB GLOSTER AP Sports Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Carlos Moya, overcoming muggy conditions and a patient Spanish compatriot, defeated Felix Mantilla 5-7, 6-2, 6-4, 6-2 Friday in the men's semifinals at the French Open. Moya will face yet another Spaniard, Alex Corretja, or Cedric Pioline in Sunday's final. Pioline is trying to become the first Frenchman to win at Roland Garros since Yannick Noah in 1983. Moya mixed his powerful groundstrokes with delicate drop shots to throw off Mantilla, who preferred to rally patiently from the baseline. The Spaniards split the first two sets and Mantilla took a 4-1 lead in the third set. But Moya won the next five games, losing just four points during that span, to take control of the match. Moya got to match point with a 205-kph (127-mph) serve that handcuffed Mantilla, then hit a 197-kph (122-mph) service winner to finish off the 2-hour, 42-minute match. On Thursday, Monica Seles advanced to the French Open final for the first time since 1992 and won for the first time against Martina Hingis, yet showed none of the giddy enthusiasm she had as a teen-ager. Though Seles flashed a big smile after her 6-3, 6-2 victory in the semifinals of the event she won three straight times in the early 1990s, her success was tempered by playing in her first tournament since her father died of cancer on May 14. ``I do feel happy. I mean, it's really great. But I've tried to keep a sense of balance,'' said Seles, who pumped her fist in triumph after Thursday's win over the world's top-ranked woman. ``I'm still going to be missing people. Some things in my life are not going to be better.'' She'll face Arantxa Sanchez Vicario in Saturday's final. Sanchez Vicario celebrated her 6-3, 7-6 (7-5) win over second-seeded Lindsay Davenport by blowing a kiss to her Yorkshire terrier in the VIP box. Seles is 14-2 against Sanchez Vicario, a two-time French Open champion. Seles is wearing her father's ring on a chain around her neck and has worn black throughout the French Open. Although the outfit was chosen before her father's death, she said the color is fitting. ``I'm really glad it's not a bright color, because it just feels more appropriate,'' Seles said. ``I try to give respect to Dad.'' Seles, who slammed two-handed winners within inches of the lines, lost all five previous matches against Hingis _ including a loss in the semifinals here last year. Hingis was overpowering in her run to the semifinals, not losing a set in the tournament and having little trouble with eighth-seeded Venus Williams in the quarterfinals. But the sixth-seeded Seles was in control throughout, moving Hingis all over the court with shots that skimmed just over the net. ``She just hits everything very hard and very aggressively from every place on the court,'' Hingis said. ``Usually she makes more mistakes or she gets a little bit tired, but today she just didn't.'' Seles was the aggressor from the start, showing her intensity by walking back on court first after every changeover. Hingis, normally composed, scolded herself and bounced her racket on the clay in frustration. ``I knew I had to come out and be really aggressive,'' Seles said. ``I knew I had that in me. I wasn't sure if I could do that today, but I really believed I could.'' Hingis won every Grand Slam tournament title last year except the French Open, losing in the final to Iva Majoli. She said Seles, who at 24 is seven years older than Hingis, ran her to exhaustion. ``I was probably getting a little bit tired. She just made me run, and she didn't make any mistakes,'' Hingis said. ``I guess she surprised everybody. ``I mean, she was around for quite a while, then all of a sudden she was gone for years,'' Hingis added. ``And here she is back, in better shape and probably better than ever.'' Seles was 17 when she won her first Grand Slam tournament title at the 1990 French Open, the first of three straight championships at Roland Garros. She ruled women's tennis in those years, her victories punctuated with high-pitched grunts. Off the court, she was a teen-ager with an infectious giggle. But all that changed in April 1993, when a spectator came out of the stands at a tournament in Hamburg, Germany, and stabbed her in the back. Seles didn't return to the tennis tour until August 1995, and even then she was subdued and emotionally strained. The last two years have been even tougher because of the failing health of her father, Karolj, who until shortly before his death was her only coach. She was at his side in Sarasota, Fla., when he died. ``Obviously, the last five years have been very difficult in terms of walking on the court, while before I only had to worry about winning or losing the tennis match,'' she said. ``It's not the same as it was before the stabbing. It never will be, and I don't want it to be.'' The other women's semifinal included 15 service breaks in 21 games. Davenport held her serve just twice in 10 attempts and also was inconsistent with her groundstrokes. ``I know she was very tired, and I just had to just hang in there,'' said Sanchez Vicario, whose dog lapped up a lunch of ham and bread chunks while sitting with Sanchez Vicario's mother in the stands. Leading 6-5 in the tiebreaker, Sanchez Vicario made one of her trademark remarkable saves and sent back a high defensive lob. Davenport had an easy putaway, but her overhead slam sailed wide, ending the match. ``I guess I beat myself,'' Davenport said, ``but she kind of forced it on me.''

SEEMINGLY feeling secure in his new-found role as a reformist, Indonesian President Bachuraddin Habibie indicated [on Wednesday] that he plans to remain in office for a long time yet. Elections are now unlikely to be held before the end of next year and the new president hinted he may be a candidate. Habibie has even taken to comparing himself with Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji and Russian President Boris Yeltsin in an effort to show that rising to power through an autocratic system is no bar to being a radical reformer. The rapid release of political prisoners, coupled with promises to repeal repressive laws have certainly played their part in consolidating his position far faster than anyone expected, with even opposition leader Megawati Sukarnoputri now offering qualified support. The president has also shown himself to have some political skills, continually using the nation's economic woes as an excuse to distract attention from the need for political reform, while apparently forgetting his part in the failed policies that brought such chaos to Indonesia. But the most crucial factor has been the continued backing of powerful military chief General Wiranto. If Habibie continues to make concessions at regular intervals, he may survive in office far longer than anyone initially expected. Having originally been written off as a stop-gap solution, the new president seems to have acquired a surprisingly firm grip on the reins of power. US empty threatsTHE Clinton administration has said time and again that it won't permit Serb leader Slobodan Milosevic to extend his brutal ethnic-cleansing tactics to the independence-minded province of Kosovo. Now Milosevic's troops are conducting precisely such atrocities in Kosovo, and the administration's response so far: more talk. US policy on all this has been pretty clear -- at least in words. The United States doesn't support Kosovo independence, but it does support legitimate aspirations for more autonomy. It favours peaceful dialogue and opposes armed conflict. President Bush warned in 1992 that the US would use force if necessary to block ethnic cleansing in Kosovo. The Clinton administration embraced that warning in 1993. And as recently as three months ago, Secretary of State Madeleine Albright said the US would not ''stand by and watch the Serbian authorities do in Kosovo what they can no longer get away with doing in Bosnia.'' US policy in the past three months has been a confusing mixture of sanctions threatened, imposed and withdrawn. Such sanctions are in any case mostly beside the point; only the credible threat of force, and the use of force if necessary, can deter Milosevic. The US can intervene now, as it has said it would. Or, as in Bosnia, it can be forced to intervene later, after much damage has been done and any solution is far more difficult. The Washington Post No more officialese A MODEST revolution is under way in Washington, aimed at getting the federal government to stop using needlessly dense language when it talks to ordinary people. From now on, official statements, rules and directives are supposed to be written briefly and in plain language. Redundancy and jargon are out. The passive voice must yield to the active. Thus we might one day see President Clinton step forward to concede ''I screwed up,'' instead of reporting obliquely in the classically Reaganesque phrase that ''mistakes were made.'' Using plain English is an effort not to dumb down government but rather to make it more accessible, comprehensible and efficient -- in short, to have it serve the citizenry better. Constant vigilance will be needed to prevent backsliding, for there is something in the bureaucratic soul that apparently cannot abide directness and clarity in language, that shies from using a single simple word when three or four polysyllabic ones come to mind.

Last week's decision by the Sangha Supreme Council to curb Buddhist temples profiteering from funeral rites is not enough. The Buddhist monastic hierarchy desperately needs drastic reform, Thana Poopat writes. THE proposal that the Religious Affairs Department submitted last Friday to the Sangha Supreme Council was unusually audacious; the Sangha's reaction was predictably defensive. The Religious Affairs Department, prodded by Deputy Education Minister Arkhom Engchuan, proposed a curb on profiteering and commercialisation of Buddhism by monks and lay management committees of temples. The council meeting, chaired by the Supreme Patriarch, resolved to make it compulsory for all Buddhist temples to provide funeral rites free of charge to the destitute and to refrain from profiteering from funerals. But the council, the governing body of Buddhist monks, baulked at Arkhom's aim to have assets of all Buddhist temples audited as part of efforts to suppress corruption and ensure transparency in the management of monasteries. The council said it wants a public hearing on the proposal first so that it can gauge public opinion before it considers the proposal. What do ordinary Buddhists have to say about the proposal to promote good governance in Buddhist temples? Probably, not much -- judging from the prevailing apathy towards religious affairs. Most Buddhists have an extraordinary amount of tolerance for monastic authorities, who are allowed to run their own affairs as they see fit. Profiteering, commercialisation, misuse of funds, cheating by monks and lay management committees are widespread. The public continues to give the Buddhist monastic order the benefit of the doubt and to hope that things will get better. But things won't get better unless the Sangha, which has been criticised for inaction and moral vacillation, changes its ways. There are compelling reasons why the public should care more about how temples are run. It is true that few people making donations to temples consider it an investment in the business sense. That's why they feel they don't need to know what the temples are doing with their money. Not even the Buddhists who consider their donations an investment for their next incarnation care where their money goes. In good times, people made merit by giving a lot of money to temples because it made them feel good contributing to Buddhism. Until recently, people have not felt that temples had any role except to propagate and teach Buddhism. Only a handful of idealistic monks, concerned for people and the world around them, have been doing what they could to improve people's lives. As Thailand slides deeper into the worst economic crisis in modern history, more and more Buddhists are looking to temples for solace. It is common knowledge that much of the money donated by Buddhists has been squandered on building bigger and more elaborately-designed chanting halls and other buildings. Many Buddhist temples compete among themselves in their outward, material pursuits. In these difficult times, should temples that have accumulated great wealth during the economic boom do nothing to relieve the suffering of the people? People no longer have as much money as they used to for donations to temples. And even those who still have some money to spare expect temples to make better and more efficient use of donations, such as helping the poor. The Sangha has no justification for blocking or delaying the reform proposal. At present, the law requires Buddhist temples to keep account books and report their balances to higher authorities. But few temples observe it, and monastic authorities do not enforce it. Apart from the corrupt activities of some monks and temple lay management committees, the generally low education of monks is cited as a reason for the mismanagement and financial fraud at many monasteries. According a 1996 Religious Affairs Department survey, almost 80 per cent of abbots as well as tambon, district, provincial and regional Buddhist monastic chiefs have had only four years of formal schooling, or up to Prathom 4 level. For ordinary monks, a low education may be made up for with Buddhist scholastic attainment. But four years of formal schooling is grossly inadequate for abbots and monastic chiefs who are supposed to manage their temples and supervise people in their charge. The Religious Affairs Department is implementing a programme to train abbots and other monastic chiefs in modern management to help improve the way temples are run. Arkhom forwarded his proposal following an outcry after a temple in Bangkok last month refused to provide funeral rites for a man whose relatives could not afford the price demanded by the temple. The deputy education minister has proposed that the 30,377 temples throughout the country adopt a more transparent management to prevent ''exploitation'' of Buddhism and to promote financial prudence of temples in handling donations. A lack of compassion on the part of many Buddhist temples seems to have come into sharper focus in the economic crisis. The Bangkok Metropolitan Administration has complained of the lack of cooperation of Bangkok temples in its campaign to persuade them to provide funeral services free of charge for the destitute. Only 21 out of 426 temples in the capital city participated in the programme over the past year. Buddhism has always been regarded as the main pillar of society, the guarantor of public morality. The question that needs answering by the Sangha and the public is: Why should the public be content with anything less than moral uprightness, compassion and transparency from the Buddhist monastic authorities?

Volkswagen wins control of Rolls-Royce
Eds: LEADS with BMW canceling engine deal; background on Volkswagen's history in Nazi Germany, quotes from Vickers chairman, EDITS to tighten; no pickup By DIRK BEVERIDGE AP Business Writer
LONDON (AP) _ Volkswagen AG won shareholder approval Friday to buy Rolls-Royce Motor Cars Ltd. for 430 million pounds (dlrs 700 million), despite angry bursts of nationalism from small investors who fought to keep the luxury carmaker British. Vickers PLC, the engineering group that owns Rolls-Royce, announced at the end of a stormy meeting that investors had agreed to sell Rolls-Royce to Volkswagen, the German company that is Europe's biggest automaker. ``Should I call it now a Rolls-wagen?'' shareholder Rodney Crowe asked during the special meeting. ``What are we going to have? A flying lady on the front of the Beetle?'' Crowe said later, conjuring up an image of the distinctive Rolls-Royce hood ornament placed on a Volkswagen Bug. Some investors sounded like they were ready to refight World War II in a session where they first rejected a bid of 340 million pounds (dlrs 554 million) from rival German automaker BMW. ``For God's sake, try and take a broad view for the country,'' said Desmond Lake, drawing cheers in the packed auditorium when he referred to Volkswagen's origins in Nazi Germany. Volkswagen was founded under Adolf Hitler's guidance in the late 1930s and manufactured weapons during the war. Volkswagen faced not just vocal objections but some real potential hurdles at it moves to take over production of luxury Rolls-Royce and Bentley cars, which cost at minimum around dlrs 250,000 each. The jilted suitor, BMW, supplies some engines to Rolls-Royce but said Friday it was terminating the contract as it had previously threatened. BMW spokesman Jurg Dinner would not disclose how long it will still have to deliver the engines. Volkswagen sought to remedy the problem at least in part by agreeing to also purchase the auto engine maker Cosworth, also from Vickers, for 120 million pounds (dlrs 196 million). Rolls-Royce PLC, a separate company that makes jet engines, controls the Rolls-Royce brand name and logo and has made it clear it would rather see the deal go to BMW, which happens to be its partner in a jet engine venture. Rolls-Royce PLC has not said whether it will negotiate with Volkswagen or try to block its use of the brand name. Asked about that, the Vickers chairman, Sir Colin Chandler, insisted that a 25-year-old contract that would let Rolls-Roye PLC veto the purchase of Rolls-Royce Motors Cars Ltd. by a foreign buyer is legally unenforceable. ``The trademark can't go anywhere else,'' Chandler said. ``We exclusively own the radiator, the flying lady and Bentley.'' But some shareholders expressed worries that the Rolls production line could be halted by the dispute. Vickers hopes to close the deal by July 3. One investor expressed disgust at the fight over a name that epitomizes handmade British luxury. ``It's harmful for Rolls-Royce PLC and it's harmful for Vickers and they don't seem to care,'' Carol Day said. ``They're behaving like 6-year-old children.'' The takeover announcement also was delayed by a Rolls-Royce enthusiasts group, Crewe Motors, that wanted to keep Rolls-Royce British. The group claimed it was on the verge of putting together a 500 million pound (dlrs 815 million) offer from private backers. Its chairman, lawyer Michael Shrimpton, who has failed in previous attempts to put together a bid, forced Vickers to adjourn the meeting for nearly one hour, but the Vickers chairman was unconvinced and refused any further delays. Chandler said he understood the small shareholders' emotional reaction to the sale, but stressed it was in their best interests as well as in the interest of Rolls-Royce, which he said needs a strong automotive owner to compete in the increasingly global industry. After it was all over, Chandler said: ``For Rolls-Royce Motor Cars, Volkswagen provides a parent with engineering capability, resources, expertise in brand management, and a global reach that matches BMW.'' World Cup: French resort welcomes Japanese team _ and tourists
AP Photos By YURI KAGEYAMA Associated Press Writer
AIX-LES-BAINS, France (AP) _ The road signs are in Japanese. Flags of red and white are on every other street corner. Shop windows have suddenly taken on an Oriental motif with decorative fans and folding screens. The southeastern town of Aix-les-Bains was prepared when Japan's World Cup squad arrived Friday. The picturesque lakeside resort, which will serve as the team's base training camp during the tournament, also has its eyes on the thousands of Japanese travelers who are expected to follow. About 45 students from Lamartine elementary school were waiting at the four-star Park Hotel for the team's bus from Switzerland and broke into a Japanese song about cherry blossoms called ``Sakura.'' The players looked on, some with smiles on their faces. Coach Takeshi Okada received an honorary medal from the region's leaders. Nine-year-old Cyril Medard was excited to see the Japanese stars. ``I like Ihara because he is the captain,'' he said, referring to defender Masami Ihara, 30. He shouted a cheer in Japanese with his classmates, ``Ganbare Nippon!'' meaning ``Go Japan!'' Aix-les-Bains, with a population of 25,000, has spent 800,000 francs (dlrs 136,000) to prepare for the anticipated onslaught of Japanese soccer fans, estimated to run as high as 10,000 this month. Besides a telephone information service in Japanese and crash courses for restaurant owners and shopkeepers on how to serve them, the city has printed brochures in Japanese about the region and hired interpreters. An additional 1.5 million francs (dlrs 254,000) went into renovating the J. Forestier municipal stadium, where the Japanese team will practice. Michel Albert, director of the Aix-les-Bains tourism office, believes the publicity the town will get is worth every franc. ``Word of mouth is the best promotion,'' he said. ``It's very important everything will be good, the best, for the Japanese team.'' To make sure the players get some peace, other Japanese guests will not be staying at the Park Hotel, said hotel spokeswoman Nathalie Gagnier. The players will have the indoor swimming pool and Jacuzzi to themselves during part of the day. The city has even built a Japanese garden in front of the hotel. ``It's quiet here,'' said Japan Football Association spokesman Hiroshi Onozawa. ``It's a place where they can focus on their training.'' Marianne Daune, 53, who owns a clothing store near the Park Hotel, doesn't care much for soccer but was nevertheless glad the team had chosen her town. ``But I hope it'll be a plus for business,'' she said. SINCE India and Pakistan began their nuclear testing, there have been a number of serious earthquakes. One of the largest, registering a massive 7.0 on the Richter scale, took place in Afghanistan on the same day Pakistan conducted its last nuclear test, and aid officials put the ''total death toll at more than 4,000''. The site of the earthquake is a few hundred kilometres from the nuclear testing ground close to Pakistan's border with Afghanistan. On May 28 when Pakistan conducted five nuclear tests, a series of eight tremors hit the Russian Kamchatka Peninsular on the north Pacific coast, registering up to magnitude seven. Minor quakes registering 3.1 were also felt in Beijing. There is, I am sure, considerable undisclosed evidence that nuclear weapons do cause earthquakes. One example that they do, though doubtless not the best, is given in ''Natural Disasters -- Acts of God or Acts of Man?'', a report prepared by the Swedish Red Cross and the International Institute for Environment and Development. It says that following ''an underground nuclear test in Nevada in 1968, which registered 6.3 on the Richter scale, was followed by a series of tremors of up to 5.0. Another seismic event linked to nuclear testing was the eruption of a large volcano in New Zealand shortly after the French nuclear tests in the Pacific a few years ago. If the nuclear weapon tests by India and Pakistan did precipitate the earthquake in neighbouring Afghanistan, or trigger a far greater earthquake than would otherwise have happened -- with the resultant deaths of thousands of innocent people, who is to be held responsible? If another war -- God forbid a nuclear one -- were to break out as a result of the resumption of the arms race in South Asia, itself sparked by right-wing nationalist chest beating, who could we hold responsible? Will there ever be an end to this kind of militant insanity, and what further extremes will it lead to? Could it lead to China deciding that the Indian finger-pointing is justified enough to resume an overt nuclear weapon testing programme, which in turn could result in Japan's right wing gaining political power to initiate the construction of a Japanese nuclear arsenal? I can imagine a scene not too far in the future where a group of scientists are being showered with rose petals and accorded national hero status for developing miniature nuclear bombs that can easily be smuggled into the capitals of other countries, thus making billion-dollar nuclear submarines, supersonic jet bombers and ballistic missiles and other weapons delivery systems redundant. Nuclear weapons at a fraction of the price! Who would need an army? You too could be sleeping with a nuclear bomb in your backyard! Anyway, don't worry, our wise leaders will sort things out. After all, isn't it a sign of enlightenment that we haven't been subjected to a ''major'' war in 50 years now? Sorry if that disturbs anyone's sleep, but maybe a little prodding will help us all to act when needed.

UNDETERRED by Malaysia's credit crunch, Deraya Corp Sdn Bhd chief executive Abdul Baith Azman has pressed ahead with plans to launch a four- star beach resort in Port Dickson, Negri Sembilan. ``We are very confident that we will be able to attract buyers to take up ownership of the Mayang Sari Beach Resort even during the economic slowdown. Research showed that the timeshare industry is still doing well in the country,'' he told reporters at a preview of the beach resort in Petaling Jaya yesterday. Abdul Baith is selling the units of the Mayang Sari Beach Resort based on a concept similar to that of the timeshare industry. ``Unlike the timeshare programme which entitles buyers to the right of use, however, our joint ownership programme entitles them to actually own the unit. ``In addition, buyers will enjoy two weeks stay in the unit as opposed to timeshare's one week stay,'' he said, adding that the special features give it a competitive advantage over the timeshare programme. ``For this reason, we believe the response will be good,'' he said. On top of that, buyers will be entitled to a free membership to its seasports club known as the Straits Flippers Club, which is being offered to outsiders for RM2,500. Mayang Sari Beach Resort is located 3.2km away from Port Dickson town, and requires an hour drive from Kuala Lumpur and 20 minutes from Seremban. Deraya Corp, which is 100 per cent owned by Abdul Baith, is currently managing the beach resort through its subsidiary Deraya Resort Sdn Bhd. Construction of the RM135 million beach resort is divided into two phases. ``We have begun construction on one of the three apartment blocks for phase one a year ago. It is expected to be completed by the end of the year. ``Construction work on the remaining two apartment blocks will start in three months and is expected to be operational by the end of next year,'' he said. In phase one, there will be a total of 480 one-, two- and three- bedroom units. But the fate of the second phase, which will comprise 300 corporate units, will depend on the condition of the economy, Abdul Baith said. ``With the corporate market still weak, we expect to start work on phase two only next year,'' he said. On the price of the one-, two- and three-bedroom units of the Mayang Sari Beach Resort, he said, it is being offered at RM9,500, RM11,500 and RM13,800 respectively. On top of that, buyers are also expected to pay an additional RM500 management fees per year. ``To date, we have already sold 50 per cent of the total units for phase one to personal users,'' he said, adding that he is eyeing families, local holiday-goers and middle income people.

Hanson fans racism, Howard adds fuelAustralian Prime Minister John Howard may moan and whine about how he personally abhors racism, as he did this week, but few people will believe him. For when Pauline Hanson warned that Australia risked being swamped by Asians in her maiden parliamentary speech two years ago, Howard could have easily knocked the wheels off her racist bandwagon. He didn't. Instead he chose to remain silent, claiming that Hanson was exercising her freedom of speech. But surely if he was truly opposed to racism, he should have exercised his own freedom of speech to condemn her. It was this abrogation of political leadership that led to the call for Howard's resignation by senator Mechai Viravaidya in a speech he made at Melbourne University soon after Hanson unleashed her racist diatribe. Clearly Howard's silence speaks volumes for his unwillingness to alienate the support of those within his own Liberal Party, many of whom share Hanson's views. After all, Hanson was a member of the party before she became a political liability and was unceremoniously expelled.Howard's folly has now boomeranged into his face. Since her election as an MP in 1996, Hanson has become a household name, not only in Australia but in Asia. She has built her One Nation party with the support of disgruntled conservatives who would normally back Howard. Which is why Howard is actively wooing One Nation's supporters, especially in keenly-contested elections such as next Saturday's polls in the northern Australian state of Queensland. Last week Howard's Liberals resolved to ask voters to direct their preferences to Hanson before arch-rival Labor in the election. And if there is any doubt about this decision, there can be none after Queensland Tourism Minister Bruce Davidson uncategorically said he would give his vote to a Nazi candidate before Labor. Every few years or so, Australia embroils itself in a ritual of self-flagellation -- one involving a bitter debate on race, and in particular, Asian immigration. In 1984, Prof Geoffrey Blainey, the dean of arts at Melbourne University, sparked an uproar when he cast aspersions on Asians in a speech made in a small country town. Five years later, John Howard, lobbed another racist bomb when he called for a curb in Asian immigration. And now there is Hanson. But the Hanson phenomenon, unlike past racist hyper-ventilation, will not go away. Indeed, Hansonmania has now become a permanent feature in the political landscape of Australia. And that spells trouble for a country which prides itself on its multiculturalism. Like her racist predecessors, Hanson has given a certain sheen and respectability to racism. After all, if an MP can openly maligned Asians and Aborigines, there can't be anything wrong for middle Australia to do likewise. Hanson has no doubt successfully tapped into the hidden fears of white Australia and become a lightning rod for the serious concerns about the country's social and economic problems. According to her homespun philosophy, these complex problems stem from Asians inundating Australia and from Aborigines sponging off welfare. Apparently, a sizable proportion of Australians have bought such Hansonisms. This week, a poll found One Nation commanding the support of 15 per cent of voters in redneck Queensland -- enough to give it several seats and the momentum for the upcoming federal election which Howard must call by mid-next year. This will make One Nation the third force in Australian politics behind the conservatives and Labor. On Tuesday, Howard said One Nation was a party which seeks to attract racists. He is right. And apparently he is one of them. How else then to explain why he attacks Hanson and yet crawls into bed with One Nation when it comes to directing preferences? There is little difference separating Howard from Hanson. Both want cuts in Asian immigration, to roll back Aboriginal native titles and to slash social welfare. But while many have no qualms in calling Hanson a bigot, few dare call Howard a racist. Deputy Labor leader Gareth Evans himself doesn't believe that Howard is a racist. Howard, he said, was just being ''insensitive'' to racial issues. But his colleague, John Della Bosca, is not so magnanimous. At a party conference this week, the influential secretary of Labor's New South Wales branch inferred that Howard was a racist pandering to Hanson. We couldn't agree more.

IT'S a mammoth task for Sukom Ninety-Eight, the Kuala Lumpur Commonwealth Games organisers, to raise the final 10 per cent of the RM310 million budget with less than 100 days to go. JAPANESE trading house Nissho Iwai Corp and its Thai subsidiary will increase their stake in fertiliser company Thai Central Chemical Plc (TCCC) to almost 42 per cent from the current 25 per cent. Subjected to shareholders' approval, Nissho Iwai and Thai Sunrock Co will raise their combined stake in TCCC to 41.78 per cent by purchasing capital increase shares issued by TCCC at Bt5 apiece. Thai Sunrock will also provide a US$60 million, five-year loan to TCCC at an interest rate of one percentage point above the London Interbank Offered Rate, according to a TCCC report filed on Thursday with the Stock Exchange of Thailand. Nissho Iwai has a 49 per cent direct and indirect holding in Thai Sunrock. However, a TCCC executive said the Japanese stake increase will not change management and controlling rights in the company. Nissho Iwai representatives on the TCCC 20-member board of directors will remain at five. TCCC has a long-established management agreement with Nissho Iwai for Japanese involvement in management of the company. TCCC's current president and director Takashi Hirabayashi is from Nissho Iwai. After the capital increase, the executive said, the Japanese firms will have a similar stake as Metro Group companies have in TCCC. TCCC, a Metro Group company, is a leading manufacturer and distributor of chemical fertiliser. TCCC will use the long-term loan provided by Thai Sunrock as working capital to support operations and as a reserve for its US$60 million Euro Convertible Debentures that some holders might exercise their options on this October. The loan will come with a two-and-a-half-year grace period. TCCC is currently 24.99-per cent owned by Nissho Iwai, with 23.13 per cent held by the Metro Group, 13.61 per cent by Bangkok Steel Industry Plc and Bangkok Steel Marketing Co, and 8.33 per cent by United Flour Mill Plc. The latter three are under the Metro Group.Metro Group has 10 per cent in Thai Sunrock, which is a trading company. The loan agreement will be presented for TCCC shareholders' approval in a meeting scheduled for June 30. Also to be put forward for approval will be the allocation of 40 million capital increase shares to Nissho Iwai, Thai Sunrock, and Central Glass Co, another Japanese firm, at Bt5 apiece. TCCC shares traded on the local stock market closed at Bt3.50 apiece on Thursday, up Bt0.10 on Tuesday. Central Glass will continue to have three representatives on the TCCC board of directors.

POLICE are preparing for the onslaught of ``cyber terrorism'' as crime moves off the streets and onto the world-wide web. And illegal Internet gambling may increase with the advent of the World Cup, which begins next Wednesday. But the law is still unclear on bets placed on the network and no prosecutions have yet been made. Newspapers and magazines carrying advertisements for online gambling dens could also be breaking the law, but legislation is undefined on this point. Police chiefs are preparing a research paper which will be presented to the Legal Department to give guidance on the issue. Although it is illegal to launch a betting site in Hong Kong there is no legislation preventing a site being set up abroad to serve Hong Kong. Police are aware of at least one local man operating a site registered in the United States. And the World Cup may be a timely excuse for operators to open shop over the web, say police. New technology in electronic cash transfers may make tracing gamblers and bookmakers difficult. Also of concern is the threat of loanshark activities. ``Loansharking activity follows gambling _ it is just a matter of time,'' said Superintendent Jeff Herbert of the criminal intelligence bureau. He said the police would continue to observe the situation and collect evidence. ``More and more police officers will be walking the electronic beat rather than the street beat,'' he said. The law does not specify whether an offence is made when the computer bet is placed or when it is accepted. No-one has yet been charged with Internet betting offences, and the police are urging service providers to monitor such sites. Supt Herbert said: ``We are very concerned because the local population is very pro-gambling by nature and we do not want to see a proliferation. I can foresee people buying computer equipment specifically for gambling.'' Off-line electronic cash-cards require no third party in a transaction. Technology is currently being produced to enable electronic cash-card users to transfer money via the Internet, and it is feared this might be used for gambling purposes. This has given rise to fears of an increase in cyber crime as cash transactions can be carried out with complete anonymity. The Hong Kong Police will join with the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology and computer companies later this month for a seminar on computer crime.

THE Department of Industrial Promotion is preparing a Bt224 million rural industrial development project which it said will create sustainable jobs for 3,000 people in rural areas over a three-year period. Funding for the project, which is part of the Bt10 billion social investment programme, is expected to come from the World Bank this July, said an Industry Ministry official. The Promotion of Rural Industrial Development project (PRID) will be implemented jointly by the government, private sector and rural communities. Corporations will be given incentives to subcontract production to rural areas. The workers in these areas will also be trained to carry out the allocated work. Companies participating in the programme will have the incentive of a loan at a low interest rate of between six and eight per cent. Export-oriented manufacturing sectors, such as garments, jewellery, ornaments, footware, and leatherware are targeted. ONE of the most valuable lessons that we can learn from the present economic problems is the importance of institutions in both the private and public sectors adhering strictly to the ethics and principles governing their work and conduct. If certain commercial banks for instance had stuck to the rules and regulations governing their lending policies, and were not overawed by the illustrious connections of some of their big borrowers, there may not be such a serious financial problem today. Likewise, if some of our politicians had more respect for professional ethics in the banking sector, they would not have used their influence, however subtly, to persuade certain banks to set aside prudence and lend huge amounts to certain individuals. The inability of professionals in the banking sector to resist pressure and the readiness with which political elites wield influence is a problem that is linked to not only the nature and structure of power in our society, but also to a culture and history that venerate authority. It has created an environment in which the devoted professional determined to defend the ethical principles fundamental to his job, in the face of the pulls and pressure of power, is often perceived as an oddity. This situation is more common in the public sector than in the private sector. And yet it is institutions associated with the public sector - the Treasury, the Securities Commission, the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange and Bank Negara - which have been put to the severest test in the defence of professional ethics as they grapple with the vicissitudes of the economic problems. These institutions will have to make even tougher decisions in the coming months as new ethical issues come to the fore. As a case in point, a number of ethical considerations have already begun to loom large as the Government attempts to save national and strategic assets buffeted by the financial problem. A strictly professional approach to the problem would be to articulate the criteria used to determine which assets are of national and strategic importance and how these assets would be protected. The mechanism employed for this purpose would be independent of Executive control and decision-making processes would be as transparent as possible. If such an approach had been adopted at the very outset, it would have been more difficult for a segment of the public to accuse the ruling elites of bias and favouritism in the selection of companies that deserved financial support. Given its experience with saving national and strategic assets, it is vital that the Government ensure that the recently announced Asset Management Company is run in a professional manner. The AMC, established to take over some of the non-performing loans from financial institutions, should be free of political influence and should be transparent in its operations if it is to win the confidence of the local and foreign business communities. In this regard, the firm commitment given by the Governor of Bank Negara, Tan Sri Ahmad Mohd Don, that the AMC would uphold professional ethics, is reassuring. Bank Negara itself - one of the few institutions in the public realm that cherishes its professional integrity - has, right through the present situation, shown that it is capable of sound judgement and competent management of the nation's finances. Its handling of interest rates is an example of this. The bank realises that the question of whether interest rates should be raised or reduced is a complex one. While it is cognisant of the danger of a recession setting in if interest rates remain too high, it is equally aware that any attempt to reduce them drastically at this point could lead to a flight of capital. Because it has to weigh the pros and cons in a rational manner without being influenced by extraneous factors, the bank is in the best position to make a decision about interest rates. All sectors of society should recognise and respect this as a fundamental right of a nation's central bank. Recognising the determination of interest rates as the domain of Bank Negara is acknowledging the supreme importance of professional ethics in Malaysia's economic life. It is becoming increasingly obvious that only if ethical principles are observed and professional standards upheld in public and private institutions do we stand a chance of getting out of the current economic quagmire. Singaporean says SE Asian leaders' actions escalated crisis
TOKYO (AP) _ Missteps by leaders in Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand destroyed market confidence in Southeast Asia and worsened its economic crisis, Singaporean Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew was quoted as saying Friday. ``Really it was a lack of understanding by the leaders that this was a crisis of confidence,'' Lee was quoted by Kyodo News as telling an international conference in Tokyo. ``The actions were not confidence-building, they were confidence-destroying,'' said Lee, a former prime minister. ``That was the simple reason why it began tumbling down finally.'' Lee told a Nihon Keizai newspaper-sponsored conference on the future of Asia that a different reaction from the governments of the region could have quelled the crisis and cut the damage in half. For example, the government of then-Thai Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh failed to heed international bankers' warnings in 1996 that Thailand could not maintain a current account balance that was 8 percent in deficit, Lee said When the financial crisis hit, Thailand unsuccessfully tried to defend the baht, at a huge loss of 30 billion U.S. dollars. Lee said Chavalit also failed to act on the International Monetary Fund's recommendation to close down 56 weak banks and finance houses because the election of his seven-party coalition government was financed by those same banks and finance houses. ``So they dilly-dallied and as a result the market lost confidence and the baht sank through the floor,'' he said. Lee also criticized Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir for trying to blame his country's problems on international currency traders, and former Indonesian President Suharto for delaying and half-implementing painful reforms required by the IMF. ``So it was a generation of leaders that did not understand the world around them had changed and they were not operating in the 1960s but in the 1990s,'' Lee said. ``All this need never have happened.''

PERMODALAN Nasional Bhd (PNB) registered a group pre-tax profit of RM1.97 billion for the year ended December 31 1997 against RM2.57 billion achieved in the previous year. Group turnover for last year was slightly higher at RM3.033 billion compared with RM2.98 billion recorded in 1996. Group profit after tax was RM1.96 billion from RM2.57 billion previously. At the company level, pre-tax profit was RM1.95 billion against RM2.56 billion in 1996 while turnover was RM2.83 billion from RM2.78 billion previously. For the whole of last year, PNB had invested some RM6.37 billion in shares, warrants and transferable subscription rights in 148 companies compared with RM3.61 million in 124 companies in 1996. Among its substantial investments were purchases of shares in Pos Malaysia Bhd and BIMB Holdings Bhd, says PNB's chairman Tan Sri Ahmad Sarji Abdul Hamid in PNB's annual report. Of the total investments, RM483.01 million represented additional investments from existing portfolios, he noted. Ahmad Sarji added that of the RM483.01 million, RM463.95 million or 96.06 per cent was attributed to the subscription of rights issues of shares and warrants, while RM18.52 million or 3.83 per cent was through offer for sale of shares. The remaining RM0.54 million or 0.11 per cent was additional investments made through the conversion of loan stocks and transferable subscription rights into ordinary shares. He also said that as at December 31 1997, PNB had invested RM13.85 billion in 261 companies of which 221 were public listed companies as compared with an investment of RM9.38 billion the year before in 222 companies, of which 184 companies were quoted. Ahmad Sarji noted that until the end of last year, PNB had in its portfolios, investments in quoted companies and unquoted companies, various venture capital projects as well as investments in mutual funds. ``Investments in these companies and funds were made for long-term strategic purposes to take advantage of superior growth and long-term profits,'' he said. Touching on its four unit trusts namely, Skim Amanah Saham Bumiputera (ASB); Skim Amanah Saham Nasional (ASN); Amanah Saham Wawasan 2020 (ASW 2020); and Amanah Harta Tanah PNB (AHB); Ahmad Sarji said the unit trusts throughout 1997 had continued to receive encouraging response from unitholders. For 1997, ASB had registered 216,608 new unitholders and new investments of RM3.93 billion, comprising RM954.41 million from net investments and RM2.97 billion from dividends and bonuses re-invested by unitholders. As at December 31 1997, 4.7 million Bumiputera individuals had participated in ASB with investments of RM29 billion compared with 4.6 million in 1996 with total investments of RM25 billion. Meanwhile, ASN as at December 31 1997 had 1.3 million unitholders with investments totalling 1.1 billion units. ASN as at the end of last year had invested RM836.5 million in 51 companies listed on the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange, two unit trusts and one unquoted company. The balance of RM363.34 million was invested in money market instruments, said Ahmad Sarji. With regards to its ASW 2020, as at December 31 1997, a total of 827,094 unitholders had subscribed to 1.7 billion units in the unit trust. ASW 2020 had declared its maiden dividend of 10.1 per cent in 1997 amounting to RM152 million. AHB meanwhile continued to acquire shop premises to help diversify its property portfolio, said Ahmad Sarji, adding that currently AHP has invested in 10 properties throughout the country at a total acquisition cost of RM81.7 million representing 81.7 per cent of the fund totalling RM100 million. For AHP, total income received in 1997 was RM20.18 million, a decrease of 14.04 per cent from RM23.48 million recorded in 1996 while total income before tax was RM10.94 million, a decrease of 35.58 per cent from RM16.98 million earned in 1996. The fall was mainly due to the loss of rental income from its property in Taman Tun Dr Ismail.

WITH his ''main mission'' accomplished, now it's time for Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai to visit the Northeast to stop criticism that he only intends to help the rich and ignore the plight of the poor. The prime minister has suspended his planned overseas trips for three months and during that period he will travel to the Northeast, the country's poorest region, to meet locals and obtain first-hand information, Amnuay Patise, the premier's deputy secretary-general, said on Thursday. ''The prime minister will visit the entire Northeast,'' said Amnuay, who is drawing up a travel plan for the premier. He will primarily go for one-day visits which are expected to begin before Parliament reconvenes this month. ''The prime minister wants to monitor the work of provincial officials and the problems to be solved concretely and more quickly at the provincial level. He also wants to keep in touch with locals and listen to their problems,'' Amnuay said. Several groups, including farmers, activists and opposition politicians, have accused the government of trying to solve problems only of the wealthy and failing to address the hardships of the poor. Observers say the prime minister's mission to the Northeast was not only to hit back at his critics but also to win popularity in the region which is dominated by the New Aspiration Party, the major rival of Chuan's Democrat Party. Government spokesman Akapol Sorasuchart said the prime minister had suspended his overseas visits because Parliament was going to reconvene and there was work to do in the country. ''The prime minister wants to spend time with Thais as much as he can,'' said the spokesman. Chuan cancelled a trip to Hong Kong where he was to deliver a speech at the 50th anniversary celebration of the Hong Kong-based Far Eastern Economic Review on June 10 and 11. He has also cancelled a trip to Manila to participate in centenary celebrations marking the independence of the Philippines, scheduled for June 12-13. His first overseas trip after the three-month suspension will be to attend a Non-Aligned Movement meeting in August.

IT's a pity that there are still a few ``bad apples'' among taxi drivers who enjoy exploiting the public! It is an even greater pity that it is so difficult to bring these people to task. In the early hours of last Monday, June 1, I was quoted RM15 flat for taxi fare from ``Carlos'' in Jalan Tun Razak to the ParkRoyal Hotel in Jalan Sultan Ismail. When I asked that the meter must be used, the driver refused, turned away and sat down with his colleagues. I then approached two others who were talking and was told to ``go away and stop disturbing them''. About 20 yards away I approached a uniformed policeman at the premises for assistance but was told that it was up to the taxi drivers to decide and that he could not interfere. I was most surprised and asked if I could note his number in order to check on the validity of such a statement (which, I noted, he was very reluctant to provide)! ------ KINSHASA, Congo (AP) _ The European Union will expand aid to help Congo rebuild decayed hospitals and roads, the leader of a visiting EU delegation said. Speaking to journalists on Thursday, Tony Lloyd, Britain's foreign office minister for Africa, said the EU would increase earlier grants worth dlrs 100 million earmarked for roads and health facilities. ``The EU is ready to do more,'' said Lloyd without giving details of the new contribution. The British official was accompanied on the Congo visit by representatives of Austria and Luxembourg. Responding to questions of Congo's human rights record, Lloyd said President Laurent Kabila personally assured him that Congo was committed to uphold rights and hold democratic elections in future. After ousting the late President Mobutu Sese Seko a year ago, Kabila pledged to hold elections by 1999. Since then, Congo has outlawed political activities and stepped up a campaign to jail and beat opponents, human rights activists and journalists. ----- VICTORIA, Seychelles (AP) _ The Ministry of Agriculture has called on Seychellois to be on the alert for locusts _ insects not normally found in the vast Indian Ocean archipelago. The advisory came earlier this week when a locust was found eating banana leaves on the main island, Mahe. The ministry said it knew of two recent cases where locusts were found on flights arriving from Kenya on the African mainland. Heavy rains throughout northeastern Africa have encouraged the spread of locusts, which are indigenous to that area. Locusts have only been sighted only a few times in Seychelles this century and never in sufficient numbers to endanger crops. ------ MBABANE, Swaziland (AP) _ The government has closed the search for a government hangman or hangwoman after being swamped by applications from around the world. Swaziland Justice Minister Chief Moweni Simulani on Thursday said his ministry had received hundreds of applications _ although the post was never advertised. Letters and phone calls came from men and women in France, Britain, South Africa, Zambia, Malawi and other countries. ---- BLANTYRE, Malawi (AP) _ A new voting law will limit the number of ballot papers given voters to a single sheet, to curb abuses that emerged in 1994's first democratic elections. Under the Presidential and Parliamentary Bill passed by Malawi's Parliament this week, voters will in future receive a single ballot paper with all candidates' names listed on it. The next elections are in 1999. In 1994, voters were each given a fistful of ballot slips, one for each rival candidate. Observers reported that parties were paying voters to bring them uncompleted slips for the candidates they did not vote for. President Bakili Muluzi was elected in 1994, ending 30 years of dictatorship of the late Hastings Kamuzu Banda. ------ KAMPALA, Uganda (AP) _ Police are investigating a private radio station that has campaigned against a controversial land reform bill proposed by President Yoweri Museveni, police sources said Friday. Press reports said police have questioned a popular broadcaster on the Central Broadcasting Service (CBS) three times over the past three weeks. Museveni has publicly accused the broadcaster of inciting the public against the bill. ``The CBS has engaged in invectives against me trying to use the lack of information of the population to incite them to rise up against the constitution,'' Museveni said Monday in Parliament. CBS is owned by the traditional monarchy of the Baganda people, whose land holdings would be most affected if the bill were passed. The Baganda own land in central and southern Uganda, the richest and most strategic area of the East African nation. They fear that outsiders would be able to buy their land, including that seized by the state from a former Kabaka, as the monarch is called. ----- BLANTYRE, Malawi (AP) _ Malawi's Controller of Customs and Excise Ernest Mtingwi has warned the nation's government ministers they are not exempt from paying duty just because they are given ``VIP'' facilities at airports. The Finance Ministry had complained earlier it was falling behind on customs revenue collection, following political pressure. Donor agencies funding Malawi's economic reconstruction have urged President Bakili Muluzi's Government to keep tight reins on state spending and ensure income collection is both efficient and equitable. Mtingwi said ministers and those accompanying them had been avoiding filling in required forms while others had undervalued goods they brought into the country. MORE

ECONOMIES in other regions will begin to feel the affects of Asia's financial crisis within the next three months, economists warned. Dr Somkiat Osotsapa, an economist at Chulalongkorn University, predicted countries which will be badly affected by the crisis will seek about US$300 billion in financial aid from the International Monetary Fund (IMF). He said the global economy is then expected to enter a deep recession. Somkiat said asset prices across the globe are expected to fall markedly in the third quarter of 1998. Thailand has already seen its asset prices decline sharply and value in its equity market drop by $120 billion. ''There would be no more $150 billion a year pouring into Asian countries for investment expansion,'' he added. Somkiat said Opec countries are feeling the pain as world oil prices fall sharply. This will cause a spill-over into Australia, Europe and the United States. Under the worsening economic situation, Somkiat said the Thai government is likely to face an uphill task in selling its bonds internationally. The government plans to issue global bonds in July in an effort to ease liquidity pressure in the country. PM's Office Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva said a global recession is very likely. Thailand should maintain adequate foreign reserves to protect it in case an emergency arises. However, Dr Aporn Chewakrengkai, economic adviser to Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai, disagreed, saying while some countries face capital outflows, some countries should benefit from those flows. ''Thus, the economic crisis should not spread into the entire world,'' she said. For Thailand, Aporn said corporates should maintain monetary discipline and not borrow heavily from foreign sources. She is worried about export industries, dubbed a major engine to drive Thailand's economic growth. Exporters are facing fierce competition. So far, the sharp depreciation of the baht has failed to boost exports as earlier hoped because of other weak currencies. Kiattisak Meechareon, assistant governor of the Bank of Thailand, is optimistic Asia's economies will recover if industrialised countries are willing to provide financial help. ''That will help strengthen the Japanese yen and send other currencies to stability,'' he said. Economists said the government needs to inject fresh money into the system in order to boost the stalling economy. Grand restructuring in every sector should also be taken into account. ''We still have to face a further struggle,'' they said.

A RECENT news report estimated that there are about 300 Thai women working as sex slaves in Sydney's brothels alone. And last year, in just a single raid, a joint Malaysian-Thai police team rescued 39 Thai girls and women from a brothel in Kuala Lumpur. In a country that has the dubious distinction of having a flourishing sex industry, Thai women are still being duped into sexual slavery after being trafficked abroad, believing they will be given legitimate jobs. ``Migration is normal because of the economic situation in Thailand. A few years ago when the economy was good, we had women and children trafficked over from Myanmar. ``To overcome the problem of trafficking in women and children, governmental and non-governmental organisations have to work hand-in-hand with grassroots women,'' said Usa Lerdsrisantad, co-ordinator of the Women's Information Network which is the main project under the Bangkok- based Foundation for Women (FFW). An NGO, the foundation started in 1984 when its Women's Information Centre provided advice and information to women seeking a better life abroad following the collapse of the Thai economy. Two years later, it opened a women's shelter for victims of domestic violence. Wanting to stem the flow of women into the sex industry, the foundation later expanded its activities with the launch of a village-based education project. ``We inform people about the sex industry in order to give women an informed choice and counter the activities of recruiters.'' The project worked with women and children in the north and north- eastern parts of the country where recruiters were most active. Using various forms of media including video tapes about the lives of Thai women trafficked abroad and forced into the sex trade, FFW publicises the issue of trafficking right down to the village level. ``While it is important to respect women's right to self-determination and their desire to travel abroad, we think that they should be informed about the risks involved. We produced a video on Thai women who were trafficked into Germany to let people know that things overseas are not as rosy as they seem. Many of these women just wanted to send money home to help their families,'' said Usa who shared the experiences of her organisation with participants at a recent four-day workshop on trafficking in women and children held in Kuala Lumpur. The event was jointly organised by Tenaganita and the Global Alliance Against Traffic in Women. The Women's Information Network that Usa co-ordinates provides the community with information to help them make informed decisions about migrating. ``We closed down our shelter a few years ago to concentrate on gathering and distributing information and campaign work.'' How successful has the foundation's work been? ``We've built up a network of NGOs that works on domestic violence and encourages more people to campaign against child prostitution. There's also more awareness on the issue of trafficking in women and children. ``We're also seeing more children stay in school for up to nine years whereas previously, they would drop out after only six years of education,'' added Usa. For social activists like Usa, all the hard work would be worth it if only one woman or child is saved from the clutches of the highly-organised traffickers.

------ BUJUMBURA, Burundi (AP) _ The National Assembly has taken steps to facilitate transition to a fully representative government a week before all-party peace talks on Burundi are to begin in neighboring Tanzania. It amended the 1992 constitution and a decree passed after President Pierre Buyoya took power in a July 1996 military coup. The changes cement the legitimacy of the mainly Hutu FRODEBU and the multi-ethnic Uprona parties to pave the way for their participation in the peace-process. Fighting between minority Tutsis and majority Hutus has claimed more than 200,000 lives since 1993. FRODEBU holds a majority of the 81 seats in the largely non-functional parliament. A number of its members have either been killed or are in exile following Buyoya's coup. Buyoya is expected to participate for the first time in peace talks that have been held intermittently since his takeover. ----- KINSHASA, Congo (AP) _ A cholera outbreak has claimed at least 80 lives in Congo's eastern province of North Kivu, state radio reported Friday. In recent weeks more than 2,200 cholera cases have been registered by North Kivu health officials and another 700 people have been infected in other provinces, the radio report said. Cholera is common in parts of West and Central Africa, where sources of clean drinking water are scarce and people are often forced to drink and bathe in the same polluted water. ------ MONROVIA, Liberia (AP) _ The head of the U.N. refugee agency has asked some 55,000 Sierra Leonean refugees in a northern Liberia border village to relocate to a more accessible _ and safer _ town in Liberia's interior. UNHCR director Soren Jessen-Petersen said at the end of a three-day visit to Liberia on Thursday that the Sierra Leoneans had fled to the Liberian border town of Vahun early this year to escape rebel attacks in northwestern Sierra Leone. Roads linking Vahun with Liberia's major centers have been washed away during the rainy season, forcing aid trucks to discontinue trips to the town, which is also vulnerable to rebel attacks, Jessen-Petersen said. UNHCR workers had asked the refugees to trek some 70 kilometers (45 miles) to Kailahun, a Liberian town accessible by road. Jessen-Petersen visited Sierra Leone earlier this week for talks aimed at eventually repatriating more than a half-million Sierra Leonean refugees living mainly in Liberia and Guinea. ------- JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (AP) _ South Africa may participate in developing Yemen's port of Aden and the Aden Free Zone, a government statement said Friday. The port development was among subjects discussed by a South African technical team that arrived back after a week in Yemen, where they explored cooperation in agriculture, mining, construction, electricity supply and commerce. During the first 10 months of 1997, South Africa's total trade with Yemen increased by 75 percent to 230 million rand (dlrs 44 million) over the previous year. The two governments said in a joint statement that they hoped discussions with a cross-section of businessmen would lead to a substantial trade increase.

Filly trying to make English Derby history
EPSOM, England (AP) _ Cape Verdi will make English Derby history just by racing at Epsom Saturday. But but winning England's most famous flat race would nudge her into a class of her own. The 1,000 Guineas winner is striving to become the first filly to win the Derby since 1916. But even if she fails, her place in history is already secured. For the first time since 1917, the winners of the two Newmarket classics _ the 1,000 Guineas and the 2,000 Guineas _ will go head-to-head in the Derby, with Cape Verdi and 2.000 Guineas winner King of Kings both in the field of 15. Cape Verdi, entered late by the Godolphin syndicate at a cost of 75,000 pounds (dlrs 122,250) last Saturday, will join an elite group of females in racing if she wins. Only six fillies have won the English Derby in its 218-year history, the last being Fifinella in 1916. In 1912, Tagalia set a record as the only filly to have won the 1,000 Guineas prior to winning the Derby, a feat Cape Verdi is trying to match. While Cape Verdi is a sentimental favorite, bookmakers have listed Greek Dance as the favorite. British bookmakers Coral said a flood of money bet on Greek Dance Friday saw the odds shorten on Michael Stoute's runner from 7-2 to 3-1. Coral spokesman Simon Clare said betting on early favorite Second Empire had slowed down and the odds had lengthened from 3-1 to 4-1. FOUR foreign parties are interested in acquiring a stake in Binariang Bhd, the operator of the Maxis Mobile network said. The four parties are Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp (NTT), Cable Wireless Plc of UK, British Telecoms and Singapore Telecommunications Ltd (SingTel). Binariang executive director (sales and marketing), Mr C.Y. Chin, said the company is still in negotiations and has not arrived at any decision yet. ``Many foreign companies have expressed their interest to us in many ways,'' he told reporters in Kuala Lumpur yesterday after a ceremony to celebrate Maxis' 400,000th subscriber. Ananda Krishnan. The company, however, will concentrate on being a mobile service operator. The company, Chin said, is expecting a 10 per cent revenue growth and a RM1.1 billion in turnover this year. Binariang is said to be the second largest telecommunication service provider, holding 19 per cent of the market share with 77 per cent coverage in populated areas. For the mobile service alone, Maxis commands a 15.4 per cent share of the 2.6 million subscribers in the mobile phone market. ``The industry is based on a long-term investment and we are confident that the economic situation will not affect the business much as we are in a growing market. JAKARTA (JP): Actor and director Rano Karno was declared Indonesia's first national ambassador for the United Nations Children's Fund (Unicef) yesterday. Rano, 38, a member of the People's Consultative Assembly, received the honorary title from Coordinating Minister of People's Welfare and Poverty Eradication Haryono Suyono. Recognized largely by Indonesians for his highly rated TV drama Si Doel Anak Sekolahan (Doel the College Kid), the actor wept during his acceptance speech. ``I have officially become a servant of the people,'' the president director of Karnos Film said. Unicef chief representative for Indonesia Stephen J. Woodhouse said Rano's task would be to help increase awareness on children's health. Unicef also focuses on the welfare of pregnant women, both in remote villages and in urban areas. Indonesia has the highest maternal mortality rate and mortality rate of children under five in Southeast Asia. Woodhouse said Indonesia's mortality rate of children under five was 80 per 1,000 live births. He said Rano's selection as national Unicef representative was mainly because of his role in the national anti-polio drive through television commercials. Characters of Si Doel were depicted in the commercials. ``Si Doel has played a critical role in immunizing all children against polio over the last three years,'' Woodhouse said. Woodhouse said that during his travels across the country, mothers have told him what ``really encouraged them'' to get their children immunized was Si Doel and his family. Woodhouse further said that there would also be greater focus on encouraging husbands to give ``utmost attention to wives during pregnancy''. ``In villages, I still see pregnant women with huge stomachs drawing pails of water, carrying them and carrying several heavy things,'' Woodhouse said. ``Husbands eat good food and wives eat less. No nutrition. They should be educated on prevention rather than emergency cures which are rare.'' Unicef is the leading development agency working for the interest of children in over 140 countries worldwide. Advocating the protection of children's rights with governments and civil societies, its global income in 1996 totaled US$944 million, with 64 percent from government funds and 36 percent from non-governmental funds. Our child workers getting a raw deal, NEW STRAITS TIMES-MANAGEMENT TIMES June 04, 1998 NEW STRAITS TIMES-MANAGEMENT TIMES MALAYSIA ENGLISH Merina HewASIA WorldSources, Inc. 201 PENNSYLVANIA AVENUE, S.E., 2nd Floor

NO PORTION OF THE MATERIALS CONTAINED HEREIN MAY BE USED IN ANY MEDIA WITHOUT ATTRIBUTION TO WORLDSOURCES, INC. AS far as Dr B. Sinniah, head of the National Task Force on Working Children is concerned, the Malaysian brand of child labour more often than not constitutes abuse and aggression (intended or otherwise). ``Children are constantly employed to perform work intended for adults. Employers prefer them over adults because children are generally more compliant, and they don't expect much renumeration. ``For example, the employers do not have to contribute towards the Employees Provident Fund, they do not worry about the medical and social service coverage of the children, and as child workers do not have any form of collective representation (a union), they do not demand higher wages,'' says Sinniah. He argues that child labour is often associated with poor health as children are a lot more susceptible to occupational hazards. He says that although cases of children maimed or injured at their workplace receive considerable media attention, they are quicky forgotten. Take, for example, the 1994 case of 15-year-old Chan Yuen Hin whose right hand was crushed by a pump machine. Conversely, others argue that the extent of exploitation and the nature of child labour in Malaysia are blown out of proportion. Says Wahab Saleh, director of labour standards at the Human Resources Ministry: ``What many these days see as exploitative child labour must be brought back into the cultural context. ``From time immemorial, children have been working to help their parents. If they lived on plantations, they would help their parents with plantation jobs. ``Generally, children do light work and this way, they help their parents earn. They are not directly employed. In urban or suburban areas, on the other hand, it is not unusual for a child to help their parents in the latter's enterprises. ``They learn a trade. Children, after school, would help their mothers to `jual kuih' (sell home-made cakes), for example.'' As far as Wahab is concerned, the stipulations of the Children's and Young Person's Employment Act (1966) adequately protect our children. ``If you look at the Act closely, you'd see that the hours a child is allowed to work in a day are very limited. A child is not allowed to work for more than six hours a day. ``If the child is attending school, she or he is not to work - including the time spent at school - for more than seven hours. So, you see, in essence, if the child attends school, he or she is not allowed to work for more than an hour a day,'' Wahab explains. Those who disagree with Wahab's view point to the abysmal gap between the ideals stipulated in the Act and reality. In a 1994 case study of the family circumstances of child workers in Malaysia, anti-child labour activist Ganesh Rasagam highlighted the fundamental problems social workers and those against child labour face in raising awareness. ``Child workers are employed in scattered areas, often hidden from public view. There's also a lack of awareness on the part of employers, parents, families, schools, and the authorities. ``Many are unable or unwilling to distinguish between the sort of light work that is within the child's capacity and which helps in her personal growth and the high-risk, exploitative work that is detrimental to the well-being of the child,'' Ganesh elucidates. Just because a child works for her parents, it does not necessarily mean that she is not exploited or overworked. Take, as a case in point, the `jual kuih' profile of 10-year-old Ahmad from Butterworth who is afraid to go home for fear of being beaten on days when his cakes do not sell. (See Page 1) Aside from parents and employers who cannot or will not recognise exploitative child labour, one of the largest obstacles social workers face is the child workers themselves. ``The child workers do not share the same concerns as we who are trying to help them. Their primary aim is to earn some money either for themselves or for their families. ``Very often, they feel grateful towards their employers. School has no real relevance in their lives; they often view going to school as a hindrance to their work and are only too willing to drop out of school at the earliest opportunity,'' says Ganesh. To this, Jalaldin Sahul Hameed, secretary of the National Task Force on Working Children, who also runs a child welfare centre in Batang Berjuntai, Selangor, says: ``It is really difficult to reach out to these children. The general response you get from their employers is `dia mau cari wang, mengapa kacau sama dia?' (he wants to earn money, why are you interfering?). Usually, the child workers express the same sentiment.'' So where have our society and policies gone awry if the child workers are themselves conspirators in their own exploitation? Those against child labour in Malaysia feel the need to consistently state the obvious: our present welfare and educational systems are clearly inadequate. ``Schools are generally not concerned with working children or children who drop out. Readmitting a child who has missed school for some time is a long and arduous task. ``When they are readmitted, they are placed in the class according to their age group where they are unable to follow the lessons and end up being miserable and bored,'' Ganesh explains. And, says Sinniah, school should be mandatory until a certain age. He also suggests that certain poor families be paid to keep their children in school. While the government policy of not creating a welfare-dependence mentality is laudable, Ganesh feels that it is equally important to have effective support policies and programmes that encourage independence. Currently, the monthly welfare grant of less than RM100 for a destitute family with a disabled, alcoholic or drug dependent parent does not allow this. ``Child labour laws also need to be revamped and enforcement strengthened. As long as there are employers willing to hire children. there will be child labour. ``A more practical approach would be to recognise and regulate the child workers through a registration system that permits them to work under supervised conditions. It can be made mandatory for employers of children to ensure that their child workers are registered and regularly attend an informal education programme while being guaranteed minimum wages,'' says Ganesh.
