A RECENT Press report highlighted a situation where the opening of an ``unlicensed'' food and entertainment outlet in Penang was graced by no less than one Deputy Minister and three State executive councillors. Only the VIPs know the rationale for choosing to be present at the occasion though they were informed of its status by the Penang Island Municipal Council before the event. Certainly, this is not the only outlet in Penang which is operating without a licence. No less than 20 other food and entertainment establishments in Georgetown are prospering despite being unlicensed. The real issue appears to be the State's near-impotency in regulating and controlling the activities of such places of entertainment. It has no authority to close down an illegal entertainment outlet. The best the authorities can do is to mount ``harassment'' action against the operators and impose fines. The good news, however, is that the ``Viagra'' for this malady, in the form of The Entertainment and Places of Entertainment Bill 1997, is on the cards, although like the super-drug which has been hailed as the miracle cure for male sexual impotency, its promises have yet to be fully tested. More powers are to be given to the authorities to control entertainment activities under the new enactment which will replace the obsolete Theatres and Places of Public Amusement Enactment 1958. The Bill was tabled by Chief Minister Tan Sri Dr Koh Tsu Koon at the previous meeting of the Penang State Assembly last December. It is expected to become law at the current meeting. Indeed, the would-be law promises to be a ``Viagra'' for the authorities as it will for the first time give them power to close down any entertainment outlet found in contravention of the regulations or in breach of licencing conditions. It also seeks to provide heavier penalties for offences committed against the proposed enactment, including imprisonment for up to five years, fines of up to RM50,000 as well as seizure and forefeiture of documents and equipment. This will certainly be an improvement, given the weaknesses of the outdated 1958 Enactment which did not give authorities the power to close down unlicensed entertainment outlets. Moreover, the penalties provided for by the 1958 enactment are paltry, with a maximum fine of RM500, and no provisions for imprisonment or for the authorities to seize anything. Although the basic features of the 1958 enactment have been retained, the Bill defines in greater detail the activities to be controlled and seeks to confer upon authorised officers the powers of enforcement previously given only to police officers. Under the proposed enactment, any person found providing entertainment without a valid licence or at a place which does not have a licence to provide entertainment will be liable to a fine of up to RM20,000 or up to three years jail, or both, for a first time offender. For second or subsequent convictions, the offender will be liable to a fine of up to RM50,000 or to imprisonment for up to five years, or both. Under the proposed enactment, entertainment includes beauty contests and displays in which living persons take part; exhibition of models, exhibition of films, video movies and puppet shows; pin-table, billards, snooker and video games; competitions of games of skill or chance; machines and devices which give players a chance to obtain prizes in money or kind. Authorised police and enforcement officers will also have the right to enter and conduct investigations at these places without a warrant. The Bill provides for certain offences to be compoundable at a sum of up to half the stipulated fines, and forfeiture of documents and items even if there is no prosecution for the offence. Where an offence is committed by a body of persons, whether corporate or not, any person responsble for its management, be it a director or manager, shall be deemed guilty of the offence unless he proves that it was committed without his consent, knowledge or connivance, or that he had exercised diligence to prevent its commission. The real test as to the effect of this Bill is, however, in its implementation and enforcement once it becomes law. Will it be used to its full potential without fear or favour, or will it become a ``nuclear bomb'' which some corrupt licensing or enforcement official can use to threaten the operators for bigger bribes? An indication will probably be available from what happens, whether unlicensed outlets are closed down, still prosper or suddenly turn legitimate.

IF Spice has always been part of your musical diet, then you would probably be totally devastated by the recent news that Ginger is no longer an ingredient. Yes, saucy Ginger Spice (Geri Halliwell) has left the girls and keen observers feel that like a chair with a broken leg, the popular Spice Girls will crumble with the departure of a vital memer. Reports of strife in the band, famed for hits like Wannabe and Spice Up Your World, surfaced after Halliwell failed to appear with the group at the televised National Lottery Draw. The former model and Turkish quiz show host also missed concerts in Oslo, Norway. The official line was that Halliwell had suffered a bout of stomach pain and was recuperating. But in a statement read Sunday by lawyer Julian Turton, the 25-year-old Halliwell said: ``Sadly, I would like to confirm that I have left the Spice Girls.'' But Ginger nonetheless wishes the group success and has hinted that she ``will be back'' (whatever that means!). While on the subject of farewells, fans of Innuendo should keep their fingers crossed that singer Sam will not leave the group after all. Although talk about a split surfaced some time ago, the group is reportedly ironing out their differences amicably, like true professionals. Well done, guys! Innuendo, which grabbed six awards at this year's AIM awards, have just had their album remixed. On top of that, it's been confirmed that their debut album will be released in six European countries - Norway, Denmark, Finland, Sweden, Britain and Holland. Said Ahmad Izham, the managing director of their recording company Positive Tone: ``Yes, the agreement has been signed and sealed. Finally their album is going places. Their remix album, which will be released locally next month, will have a couple of dance remixes while the rest are RB remixes. ``All in all, we will have 10 remix numbers which were originally done by a few up-and-coming rhythm and blues producers namely Illegal, G-Soul, Paul Moss, Audimok and Hari.'' Among the tracks are Belaian Jiwa, Selamanya, Just For You, Tell Me, etc. Positive Tone's other artistes like Poetic Ammo will also find their albums on the racks in Britain soon. OAG has already released their single, Name Of The Game in Germany, Austria, Lichtenstein and Switzerland. The group which has really lost one member is all-girl outfit, Elite. It's been two months since Abby said sayonara. She was rumoured to have some personal problems. While Elite is toying with the idea of getting a replacement, their album sales have not been a slap in the face. Some 25,000 copies have been snapped up - not bad considering the economic climate.

BC-Sports-Olympics-2008 Race
USOC chief doesn't rule out 2008 bid
By STEPHEN WILSON AP Sports Writer
SEVILLE, Spain (AP) _ The race for the 2008 Summer Olympics is suddenly getting crowded. And the United States, which has been concentrating on a bid for 2012, is not ruling out jumping into the 2008 fray. The candidates so far include Toronto; Osaka, Japan; Istanbul, Turkey; Seville, Spain, and Buenos Aires, Argentina. Paris, Rio de Janeiro and China are among others weighing possible bids. Officially, the race hasn't even begun yet. The International Olympic Committee won't open the bidding process until next year, and the selection of the host city will take place in 2001. But this week's meeting of the Association of National Olympic Committees in Seville provided an early glimpse into the campaign. Bid officials from Osaka and Toronto were busy lobbying delegates, and Seville used the occasion to announce and promote its candidacy. The activity did not go unnoticed by U.S. Olympic Committee president William Hybl. The USOC decided last year not to pursue a 2008 candidacy, saying it had little chance of winning so soon after summer games in Atlanta in 1996 and winter games in Salt Lake City in 2002. The USOC elected instead to bid for the 2012 games. Nine American candidates are seeking to become the USOC's choice: Los Angeles; Arlington, Texas; Tampa, Fla.; Cincinnati; Houston; New York; San Francisco; Seattle, and a joint bid from Baltimore and Washington. But the recent entry of Toronto into the 2008 race has changed the landscape. If Toronto gets the games, a U.S. city would have virtually no chance in 2012 because the International Olympic Committee would be reluctant to return to North America so soon. For that reason, Hybl leaves open the possibility of a U.S. bid for 2008. ``We're committed for 2012 but the USOC continues to monitor what options might be available in other years,'' he said. ``Right now, we are concentrating on 2012.'' Hybl might have trouble winning support for a 2008 bid. Among those staunchly opposed is Anita DeFrantz, an IOC vice president and member of the USOC's executive committee. DeFrantz was among those who insisted the United States should not bid for the 2008 games. Asked the chances of a switch from 2012 to 2008, she said. ``I think none.'' DeFrantz said the United States should stay out of the race, regardless of Toronto's candidacy. ``I don't believe a U.S. city could win under any circumstances in 2008,'' she said. DeFrantz said the USOC started the bidding process for 2012 too early. ``I felt very strongly we should have waited awhile,'' she said. Also missing from the 2008 race is South Africa. Cape Town mounted a strong bid for the 2004 games, finishing third in the voting behind winner Athens and Rome. IOC president Juan Antonio Samaranch, eager to take the games to Africa for the first time, encouraged South Africa to bid again for 2008. But the country is now concentrating its efforts on bidding for the 2006 World Cup. ```It's most unlikely we will bid,'' said Sam Ramsamy, head of the South African national Olympic committee. ``We felt we learned a lot from the first bid. Ramsamy said the decision was not related to the World Cup bid, though he acknowledged that staging the soccer showpiece would be simpler than holding the Olympics. ``It's a proven fact that it's easier to organize one world championship over one month than 28 world championships over 16 days,'' he said. England 382 for six at tea
Eds: UPDATES with tea score By IHITHISHAM KAMARDEEN Associated Press Writer
BIRMINGHAM, England (AP) _ England gradually took control of the first cricket test at Edgbaston Friday despite South Africa hitting back with five wickets before tea. The home side rallied around a brilliant 103 by former captain Mike Atherton to progress to 382 for six at tea on the second day, virtually shutting South Africa out. Resuming the day at 249 for one, England lost Atherton without any addition to the score and then built on a 60-run stand between skipper Alec Stewart and Nasser Hussain. South African bowlers, culpable and costly on the first day, were far more disciplined Friday and were rewarded with five wickets in the first two sessions, including 3-29 in a 10-over spell. Left-arm wrist spinner Paul Adams was the pick of South Africa's bowlers, sending down 17 overs to claim Hussain (35) and Mark Ealham (five) at the cost of 26 runs. He had outstanding figures of 3-73 from 35 overs. An overcast day made run scoring difficult, especially against Shaun Pollock. None of the batsmen could make much of the ginger-haired medium paceman, who moved the bowled alarmingly. Mark Ramprakash, who came of age as a test player during the recent tour of the West Indies, held the middle-order together with a resolute unbeaten 41 while Dominic Cork was 10 not out in 44 minutes. After the loss of Atherton with the 10th delivery of the morning, Stewart (49) and Hussain, further frustrated the South African attack in a 93-minute stand. But England's hopes of getting the third wicket pair to take them to an imposing position took a crucial blow just before lunch. In the space of five balls, Stewart and Hussain fell to Lance Klusener and Adams. Stewart, edged Klusener to Daryll Cullinan at first slip and Adams trapped Hussain leg before wicket with a delivery that hardly bounced. Batting after lunch became increasingly difficult and Pollock produced the ball of the match so far, uprooting Graham Thorpe's middle stump with a swinging yorker. Left hander Thorpe was out for five. Ealham stayed at the wicket with Ramprakash for almost and added 27 runs, but an outstanding ball by Adams unsettled his stumps. Ramprakash continued to blossom, four exquisitely timed boundaries crowning his 115-ball innings that has lasted 136 minutes. Fast bowler Allan Donald, who remained a doubtful starter on the second day, took the field and had Atherton caught behind with his fourth ball of his first over. Atherton, having remained characteristically impassive on the first day, failed to add to his overnight 103, and edged a catch to 'keeper Mark Boucher. Atherton's 12th century lasted six minutes over six hours and hit a dozen boundaries off 279 balls. According to South African team physiotherapist Craig Smith, Donald took the field after an injection on a troubled left ankle, a recurrence of an injury that had troubled him in Australia early this year. BC-Norway-Antarctic
Antarctic Treaty nations agree on environmental rules
OSLO, Norway (AP) _ The 26 countries that manage Antarctica announced Friday that they settled key rules for protecting the frozen continent's fragile environment. Concern about increased human activity on the vast area surrounding the South Pole was a main topic for the 22nd Antarctic Consultative Meeting, in the northern city of Tromsoe. ``Now we have in place a unique and comprehensive set of regulations for an entire continent. This is important not in the least because the global significance of the Antarctic has become greater at the same time as pressure on its resources increases,'' Norwegian delegation leader Dagfinn Stenset was quoted as telling the national news agency NTB. Norwegian polar expert Arne Orheim was elected to as chairman of the new environmental committee and said it already set up five working groups to identify the threats to the Antarctic. ``The most important working group will approve environmental impact assessments for all projects of significant scope in the Antarctic,'' he was quoted as telling NTB. He said the committee will also present an environmental status report for the region to the Antarctic Conference in 2000. The meeting failed to agree on which nation would be the site of its Antarctic secretariat, a problem that has lingered for decades. Under the treaty, nations put aside territorial claims in the Antarctic, and agreed to use it only for peaceful, nonmilitary purposes. (dm-jh)

BC-South Africa-Botha Trial, 1st Ld-Writethru
Tutu begs Botha to apologize
AP Photos GEO 101 102 EDS: UPDATES in lede and throughout with comments by Tutu, Botha; RECASTS throughout; DOUBLE use of ``deep'' in 3rd graf is accurate By PAUL HARRIS Associated Press Writer
GEORGE, South Africa (AP) _ Desmond Tutu made one last bid on Friday to extract an apology from apartheid's last hard line president, ending a week of courtroom drama over ultimate responsibility for atrocities under white rule. The Nobel Laureate and retired Anglican archbishop who was for decades the moral spokesman against apartheid asked former President P.W. Botha to apologize for the bombings and killings against black activists. ``The government that he headed caused many of our people deep deep anguish and suffering,'' Tutu said. ``Can he bring himself to say he's sorry?'' Botha sat stonefaced during Tutu's speech, as he has during most of the week that saw a simple contempt case turn into a moral inquest. Since apartheid ended with the first democratic elections in 1994, Botha has insisted he has nothing to apologize for. Botha, 82, is charged with ignoring three subpoenas to appear before the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, which is probing atrocities committed during white rule. But the case has focused on allegations that Botha and the shadowy State Security Council he headed coordinated a crackdown on anti-apartheid activists and directly ordered bombings and killings during the 1980s. Grilling Tutu, who heads the Truth Commission, defense lawyer Lappe Laubscher said there were no direct assassination orders in any of the council's minutes, indicating the killings were the work of ``bad apples'' in the police and army who misunderstood orders. An angry Tutu objected. ``How many bad apples are you going to concede?'' he asked. ``No, no. We cannot now say that these are bad apples. They are people who were sitting on the State Security council.'' The case was adjourned until June 15, when both sides will summarize their findings. Botha faces a hefty fine or even two years in prison if found guilty. Afterwards, Botha had an animated and angry conversation with prosecutor Bruce Morrison out of hearing distance of reporters. He then turned to reporters, citing three books they should read to understand his point of view, including his biography, ``Voice from the Wilderness.'' He refused further comment. Prosecution witnesses, including police death squad commander Eugene de Kock, testified earlier this week that the council's use of phrases like eliminate'' and ``neutralize'' sanctioned the murder of the white-run state's opponents. Botha and other top members of the SSC claim the words meant that opponents should be arrested. Botha has been implicated by testimony elsewhere by top police officials, who have claimed he gave direct orders for violent acts. After Botha's 11 years as head of state, his successor, President F.W. de Klerk, negotiated with the group that spearheaded the anti-apartheid struggle, President Nelson Mandela's African National Congress. The talks culminated in the 1994 elections won by the ANC. (ph-pr-tl)

BC-Russia-Economy, 3rd Ld-Writethru
Premier says crisis over, but Yeltsin says tax collection must
improve Eds: AMs. RECASTS and UPDATES thruout with market close, oil companies ordered to pay debts, analysts' comments, tycoons supporting government. CHANGES byline. AP Photos MOSB102-3,105-7 By MITCHELL LANDSBERG Associated Press Writer
MOSCOW (AP) _ Russia's new prime minister claimed Friday that the country had emerged from its economic crisis, but President Boris Yeltsin warned that renewed stability depended on his government's ability to collect taxes. The country's new tax chief announced plans for a crackdown on the country's 1,000 richest citizens, whose rapid accumulation of wealth since the Soviet period has been largely unimpeded by taxpaying. ``Well-known people should be examples for other citizens,'' Boris Fyodorov told the Kommersant daily. The government also ordered five large oil companies to pay their tax debts by July 1 or face confiscation of their property, the Interfax news agency said. Russian financial markets collapsed late last month, and only began to recover this week as rumors mounted of an emergency bailout by the International Monetary Fund or the Group of Eight industrial nations. Top officials, including the new prime minister, Sergei Kiriyenko, have repeatedly said there was no ``official'' request for such aid _ sometimes stressing the word ``official.'' At a conference in Ukraine on Friday, Kiriyenko insisted the financial crash was over. ``We have stopped the crisis and reached a turning point,'' he said, according to the Interfax news agency. But some Western investors said the markets had regained strength only on the assumption that a bailout was imminent. ``Russia needs an infusion of capital,'' said James Fenkner, managing partner of CentreInvest Capital Management in Moscow. ``If it gets a big bucket of money, everything will be OK.'' After regaining ground earlier in the week, stocks declined slightly Friday on extremely thin trading, with most investors lying low until next week. Many investors believe a bailout package will be unveiled Tuesday, when G-8 deputy finance ministers meet in Paris. ``If nothing is announced in Paris, you are going to see a little bit of panic here,'' said Alex Pitaleff, a trader at Creditanstalt Investment Bank. No one disagrees that Russia needs cash, but some Russian officials have been insisting the country could get by with commercial loans and an improvement in tax collection. In a radio address, Yeltsin implored Russians to pay their taxes. The government says fewer than 3 percent filed income tax declarations last year. ``The financial crisis threatens to destabilize the Russian ruble,'' the president warned. ``And that means a return to rising prices and a higher cost of living. That is something we simply can't allow.'' ``The time has come to demand and punish, including filing criminal charges,'' Yeltsin added. ``If we don't collect taxes, we can't pay salaries.'' Yeltsin called on parliament and Russian regional governments to trim their staffs to save money, and promised to shrink his own staff by 30 percent. Russia's top business tycoons, who met with Yeltsin earlier in the week to discuss ways out of the crisis, issued a statement saying they were ready to support ``all sensible steps'' to revive the economy, ITAR-Tass reported. JAKARTA (JP): Sempati Air's shareholders meeting scheduled yesterday to decide the future of the ailing private airline was canceled because many of the shareholders could not attend. Sempati spokeswoman Rima Novianti said the new date for the shareholders meeting had not been fixed. The airline is partly owned by former president Soeharto's youngest son Hutomo ``Tommy'' Mandala Putra. ``Many of our shareholders had not confirmed their presence as of last night (Wednesday) while some others said that they could not attend the meeting due to various reasons,'' Rima told The Jakarta Post. Sempati, founded in 1989, is owned by the Malaysian-Indonesian joint venture Asian Aviation Inc. (40 percent), the Indonesian Army's PT Tri Usaha Bhakti (Truba) (25 percent), the Humpuss Group, controlled by Tommy (15 percent), and Soeharto's close friend Mohammad ``Bob'' Hasan (20 percent). She said the company's shareholders were to meet yesterday to discuss whether it should completely halt operations and resulting actions to take on workers and fleets. On Monday, Minister of Communications Giri Suseno Hadihardjono said Sempati Air would stop operations as rising costs resulting from the sharp drop in the rupiah against the U.S. dollar had eaten up most the company's revenues. Rima said Sempati's flight operations would be halted as of this Saturday, but administration service would remain to collect proceeds from agents until the end of June. ``After that we don't know what to do. It depends on the shareholders meeting,'' she said. She said that a sharp plunge in the value of the rupiah against the U.S dollar had caused serious turbulence for Sempati since 80 percent of its operating costs were in dollars, including for lease payments, spare parts purchases and airport service. Rima said Sempati operated a fleet of 25 leased aircraft and employed 3,500 workers at its peak in 1996, a time when it was labeled the country's largest private air carrier. Currently, it uses five Boeing 737 aircraft and has about 700 employees. It had slashed its former service to 31 international and domestic destinations to just seven domestic domestic destinations. The five other scheduled air carriers are state owned Garuda Airlines, Garuda's subsidiary Merpati Nusantara, Bouraq Airlines, Mandala Airlines and Dirgantara Air Service. Except for Dirgantara, which only operates its own aircraft, the carriers lease many of their aircraft. (gis)

JAKARTA (JP): The Ministry of Industry and Trade said yesterday it would speed up the allocation of new export quotas for textile and textile products. The ministry's export director, Sudar, said yesterday the early allocation of new quotas was aimed at grasping market opportunities from rival countries. The ministry would monitor the supplies of certain products in competing countries and, when supply was running low, the ministry would allocate a quota for the category of goods for local exporters, he said. This might lead international buyers to find products, which are running out in other countries, in Indonesia, he added. ``Even if certain quota categories were not usually allocated at this time, we would do so if our competitors' supply of this category was running out,'' he was quoted by Antara as saying. Sudar said not all orders for textiles and textile products had been canceled by international buyers, but last month's riots had affected some orders. Orders under contract have not been canceled, he said. ``Orders for which no contract had been signed were the ones that got canceled,'' he said. Sudar said the country's exports of textile and textile products in the first four months of this year reached US$911.09 million, up 9.58 percent compared to the same period last year of $831.46 million. The United States was the biggest importer of Indonesian textiles during the period, totaling at $503.32 million. It was followed by the European Union with $388.55 million, Canada $18.82 million and Norway $390,930. Export volumes in this year's first quarter reached 556.73 million square meters, a 27.1 percent rise year-on-year from 438.02 million square meters. The European Union exported the largest volume of textile and textile products from the country, totaling 334.72 million square meters. The United States followed with total exports of 216.3 million square meters, Canada 5.66 million square meters and Norway 38,920 square meters. The number of categories of products exported to textile buyers amount to 108, including 81 categories imported by the United States, 14 categories by the European Union, 11 categories by Canada and two categories by Norway. With traffic, the team didn't arrive until 6:45 p.m., made a presentation of a replica World Cup Trophy to the park, answered two questions from a throng of reporters and left within a half hour. Still, many team members and others associated with the team were angered that Nike, which signed a 10-year deal in 1996 worth a reported dlrs 200 million deal with the U.S. company, has such influence over the training schedule. Nike spokeswoman Lilian Bours said the company has discussed the appearance of Brazil at the park for months and denied the company imposed a schedule on the Brazilian team. ``We accomodated the whole opening around their schedule,'' Bours said. ``They really wanted to come. They insisted they wanted to come as a whole team, so we accomodated them around their schedule. ``Whenever the ending of the training session was. We do not dictate their training schedule.'' The sponsorship deal, which also gives Nike the right to stage five exhibition matches a year, has been criticized before. Brazil played two matches in Asia in three days in August last year, in Japan and South Korea, a tour that some criticized as meaningless. Tostao, a star on Brazil's 1970 World Cup champions, said that Nike had a hand in the choice of Spain's Atletico Bilbao and tiny Andorra as Brazil's sparring partners in its final warmup games for the Cup. He called Thursday's media event ``absurd.'' ``The team isn't training enough, and it has to attend the interests of a sponsor?'' he said. ``In my time the sponsor supplied the jersey _ now it owns the schedule. It's a paradox. We need sponsors, but we risk this problem of losing control.'' Rivelino, another star of the '70 Cup team, charged that the Brazilian confederation (CBF) had sold out the team. ``I'm totally against a team being at the mercy of a sponsor. A partnership is fine, but it has to have limits,'' he said. ``We must separate commercial interests and the World Cup, but it seems the CBF is more interested in its sponsors than in the team. And if they lose the Cup, who will want them?'' Coach Mario Zagallo downplayed the imposition but made it clear he knew who's calling the shots. ``If your boss pays you millions and millions of dollars to go somewhere and you say no, what happens? He says bye-bye,'' Zagallo said. ``When your boss says go, you go.''

JAKARTA (JP): The government is to invite international bidders to buy part of the country's largest steel producer, PT Krakatau Steel, next week, State Minister of the Empowerment of State Enterprises Tanri Abeng said yesterday. ``The competitive bidding process will be held next week after we appoint the investment advisor tomorrow (today),'' he told reporters following a meeting with Coordinating Minister for Economy, Finance and Industry Ginandjar Kartasasmita. He said that the 10 foreign investment banks which would back up the privatization of the country's 12 state-owned companies in the 1998/1999 fiscal year would be announced today. The bidding process for Krakatau Steel would be handled by an appointed investment bank which must have expertise in the steel industry, he said. He explained that after the investment bank selected the best investor candidates for Krakatau Steel, a one-month due diligence period, which would include technical and economic evaluations, would be conducted. The company's management would be involved in this process. After that, another one-week evaluation process would be undertaken to come up with an economic-technical recommendation which would be handed over to the country's privatization team. This is headed by Coordinating Minister for Development Supervision and State Administrative Reforms Hartarto Sastrosoenarto. Together with the Minister of Finance, Tanri is a member of the privatization team. ``The final decision is in the hands of Coordinating Minister Hartarto,'' Tanri said, adding that Hartarto would consider all issues, including the sociopolitical aspects of the deal. He promised that the stratified privatization process would be done in a transparent manner. Tanri was strongly criticized by Krakatau's management early this week about allegations that he had quietly made a deal with the Netherlands-based Ispat International to sell 49 percent of Krakatau's shares for the relatively low price of US$400 million. The deal would have given Ispat a monopoly in the domestic steel wire and rod industry. Tanri denied the accusations, saying that it was not a final deal. He also said that the government would make sure the Krakatau privatization deal would not create a monopoly in the steel wire and rod market. ``We will negotiate (with the potential investor),'' he said, pointing out that to prevent a monopoly the government may handle the marketing side. Tanri also said that the nation would gain by selling a larger stake of Krakatau because it would get a better price. The 1998/1999 privatization program is expected to raise a total of Rp 15 trillion (US$1.3 billion), mainly to support the state budget which is heavily burdened by huge subsidy commitments caused by the economic crisis. THERE have been an increasing number of cases this season where Premier League coaches and team officials confront match officials for what they consider ``poor'' decisions. But after learning of Kedah coach Fisol Razak's punishment meted out by the FA of Malaysia's (FAM) Disciplinary Board yesterday, most will likely think twice before acting rashly. Fisol was yesterday suspended for three matches by the board for his actions during the match against Pahang in Alor Star on May 26. The board, chaired by Senator Datuk Abdul Aziz Abdul Rahman, found Fisol guilty of confronting referee Ishak Ghani after the match at the Darulaman Stadium which ended in a 3-3 draw. Also punished were assistant coach Azman Eusoff and assistant manager Saaban Ismail who have each been suspended for two matches for their action which also included confronting Ishak after the match. The suspensions mean the three will not be allowed to sit on the Kedah bench when they are on suspension. They will have to convey instructions from the terraces but will be allowed to be with the team before and after the match and at halftime. Kedah FA were let off with a warning as the board felt they had done adequately in providing security during and after the match. That aspect probably saved Fisol and his colleagues from a heavier punishment as had security personnel not been out in full force, their actions could have caused severe damage. The situation was already bad enough during the match where players and officials approached Ishak after Pahang equalised for the third time in the match. That saw the Kedah fans rip out the bucket seats in the stadium and throw them onto the track and playing area. To make matters worse, the fans gathered outside the stadium and continued to abuse Ishak and his assistants who needed police escort out of the stadium area. The board found the action of Fisol and his colleagues hard to accept as there are proper avenues to lodge a complaint against match officials. Confronting them doesn't serve any purpose and Fisol's suspension can't come at a worse time. With Kedah staging a revival of sorts and closing the gap on Premier One leaders Pahang, they need their coach and his assistant on the bench, not sitting on the terrace with the supporters serving a suspension. Perhaps the suspension will help him from repeating his actions in the future. If it doesn't, stiffer punishment will await him.

German chancellor admonishes nuclear power operators
ESSEN, Germany (AP) _ Chancellor Helmut Kohl sharply criticized the German power industry Friday for covering up leaky nuclear waste transports in a scandal uncovered last month. Speaking at the 100th anniversary of Germany's largest power company RWE in Essen, Kohl said that more than any other sector, the nuclear power sector is dependent on the public trust. ``That trust and the acceptance of this technology is regretfully ... very much damaged,'' the chancellor said. Last month, French and British authorities complained that nuclear containers arriving at treatment plants from Germany were emitting more radiation than permitted, renewing debate about the industry's safety. Kohl charged that nuclear power companies should have known how sensitive the public is to nuclear power safety, but neglected to report the deficiencies in waste transport. The shipments have been suspended. The chancellor stopped short of reading a prepared part of his speech that said the nuclear power companies had severely damaged Germany's image, but said he expected nuclear operators to fully support a program developed by the evironment ministry aimed at tighening security and reporting procedures on nuclear waste. Friedel Neuber, RWE's supervisory board chairman, assured Kohl that the company ``along with those responsible public officials will take all measures to prevent a recurrence,'' of the safety lapses. While officials said the radiation posed no threat to people, the issue sparked an election-year scandal for Kohl's government and finger-pointing about who was to blame. (gb-me)

THERE is still a need to enhance usage of high technology among Malaysians although the present level is satisfactory, Chief Secretary to the Government Tan Sri Halim Ali said yesterday. ``Over the years, we have made substantial progress in the area of high technology. However, technology keeps on changing. ``And to develop high technology locally, we need to bring together the private sector as well as the Government,'' Halim said in Kuala Lumpur yesterday after launching the Malaysian High-Tech Directory. Halim also stressed the important role played by the Malaysian Industry- Government Group for High Technology (Might), a non-profit company limited by guarantee. Might is a smart partnership between the Government and private sector working in synergy, prospecting primarily for business and investment opportunities for industry, policy options for the Government and research priorities for public and private sector institutions. Halim also attended a briefing by Might's chief executive Dr Ahmed Tasir Lope Pihie, enabling him to understand the role and responsibility of Might in the promotion of high technology. When asked at what level of high tech the country is in, Halim said that it is rather difficult to describe. Meanwhile, Might co-chairman and Science Advisor to the Government Tan Sri Dr Omar Abdul Rahman said high technology can be divided into two aspects - the product and the process of making the product. ``Somethings the product itself is of high technology ... sometimes the product may be of low technology but the process of making the product, like garments for instance, is of high technology. ``Although the use of technology is satisfactory in Malaysia, we want to push and encourage more Malaysian companies to go into high technology,'' Dr Omar explained. He added that for conventional companies and small- and medium-scale industries, the usage of high tech is a major constraint due to lack of human resource and capital. JAKARTA (JP): The government is to review the country's rice import arrangements, including the overseas procurement contracts signed by the State Logistics Agency (Bulog), in anticipation of a declining supply in the international market. Minister of Trade and Industry Rahardi Ramelan said that the review was essential to make sure existing import deals would not only rely on certain countries. He pointed out that the query emerged because many of the traditional rice-exporting countries had started to import following the long drought induced by the El Nio weather phenomenon. A substantial supply is likely to be available only in China and Pakistan since only those two countries are expected to have successful harvests this year. ``We're studying these issues,'' he said, adding that the import contracts which had been signed by Bulog would also have to be reviewed to make sure that the suppliers had access to international rice resources. Bulog said earlier this week that Indonesia may have to import up to 3.1 million tons of rice this year because domestic procurement is expected to reach only 250,000 metric tons, the lowest level in 20 years. The agency said that rice stocks on May 28 stood at 2.5 million tons, sufficient for just three months. Several countries have pledged to provide the country's 202 million people with staple food. Japan pledged to supply 500,000 tons of rice in soft loans and 100,000 tons as a grant, Taiwan has promised to sell 200,000 tons, China 250,000 tons and Vietnam 10,000 tons, while Thailand is to donate 5,000 tons. Rahardi's comments seemed to contradict those of Bulog chief Beddu Amang. He said told a House of Representatives (DPR) briefing that the world rice market has a surplus this year following higher production in Thailand, Pakistan and India. He predicted a 500,000-ton surplus that would make the worldwide supply 21.5 million tons this year. Trade financing Indonesia is facing another serious problem in importing essential food items including rice, sugar, wheat flour and soybeans due to its letters of credit (L/Cs) problems and the alarmingly low level of foreign exchange reserves. Recent reports have said that Thai rice and sugar exporters are not accepting Indonesia's L/Cs if they're not opened by state banks and endorsed by foreign banks in Singapore. The Singapore government has committed itself to guaranteeing a total of US$3 billion in Indonesian L/Cs on the condition that the International Monetary Fund disburses its bailout funding for Indonesia. The agency is expected to soon disburse another $1 billion in bailout money to Jakarta; the funding was delayed due to the recent political unrest. Rahardi, however, said that he would renegotiate the terms offered by Singapore because Indonesia is finding them hard to implement. ``Even though we're in a crisis, we should not take terms which will be a disadvantage to us,'' he said, but declined to give details. He also said that similar renegotiating would also be done with the 300 million deustchemark L/C guarantee offered by Germany. More than $2 billion in L/C guarantees provided by the U.S., Japan, and Australia have also started to work. Following the closing down of 16 private banks in November and plunging confidence in the banking sector, overseas banks began to reject Indonesian L/Cs. This caused a serious blow to the country's ability to export non-oil and gas products. Solving the trade financing problem is key to reviving the export industry as it largely depends on imported raw materials, Rahardi said. He added that boosting exports was one of the government's main priorities because it would provide foreign exchange that was badly needed, especially for importing the five essential foodstuffs. He also said that priority would be given to labor-intensive export industries like garments and textiles. Some economists have forecast that the country's economic crisis will cause a 10 percent contraction in the economy and unemployment of 20 million this year. (rei)

KUALA LUMPUR, Thurs. - Pengurusan Danaharta Nasional Bhd, the national asset management company, may need about RM25 billion to take up the non- performing loans of the banking system. Deputy Prime Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim revealed this estimate when he announced the guidelines for the AMC at the Treasury today. Anwar, who is also the Finance Minister, said the AMC would initially raise RM10 billion via the issue of bonds locally and abroad. He said the equivalent of US$1 billion to US$2 billion (RM3.94 billion to RM7.88 billion) would be raised in the international bond market by the AMC in the form of Government-guaranteed bonds. The rest of the initial quantum will be raised in the domestic market when liquidity improves. Seed capital for the establishment of the AMC will be in the form of a RM50 million grant from the Government, which will initially hold the entire stake in the statutory company. Eventually, local and foreign investors will be invited to take up equity in the AMC - leaving the Government with only a minority stake. When asked about Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad's statement in Tokyo that the Government will provide 60 per cent of the funds required, Anwar said funding would be raised from all sources. ``The Government's equity may be substantially less than 60 or 40 per cent, but this will have to be looked into at a later stage,'' he said. On the AMC's operations, Anwar said two international firms - Arthur Andersen and JP Morgan - had been appointed financial advisers. Anwar added a consortium of local banks had expressed interest in taking up equity in the AMC. But, they will be allowed to do so only later to prevent any possibility of a conflict of interest during the AMC negotiations to take over the NPLs. Anwar also said the AMC's assistance to the banks would be only in the form of taking over the NPLs. Any recapitalisation would have to be done by the shareholders. Asked if government institutions like the Employees' Provident Fund and Khazanah Nasional Bhd would take up equity in the AMC, Anwar said it was possible but no decision has yet been made. The AMC chief executive officer and managing director, Azman Yahya, said the appointment of another eight independent non-executive directors to the board would be announced later. It will be for the posts of chairman, three Malaysian directors, two directors representing the international community and two directors to represent the Government. To facilitate the operations of the AMC, Anwar said legislation pertaining to bankruptcy, foreclosure and taxation would be amended and the amendements tabled in Parliament next month. The AMC is expected to start operations by the end of July. Further information will be posted on the Internet at http://www.bnm.gov.my.

It is now being tested on fruits, vegetables, flowers and rice by the Malaysian Agricultural and Research Development Institute. Mardi director-general Datuk Dr Md Sharif Ahmad, said this today after signing the MoU with BOSS president Paul Duane Jr. Its Bio-Plus Activator, made up of 16 micro-organisms, is used to transform agricultural compost into organic fertiliser. BOSS had approached Mardi last year to test its products. The first demonstration involved chicken dung, sawdust and burnt rice husk. The Bio-Plus Activator has been tested over the past 27 years by Dr Eliseo L. Ruiz, a scientist from the Philippines and vice president (technical) of BOSS. ``The BPA has been used in the production of organic fertilisers in the Philippines for the past 15 years,'' said Duane in his address. ``It will eliminate all foul smells within the first four days of the biofermentation process. PENANG, Thurs. - The State Government is preparing ``an action plan'' to effectively resolve the problem of squatters and illegal structures on Government land. ROMPIN, Thurs. - Risda will be commercialising its cattle ranching projects to cater to local demands for beef. At present, demand for the meat is about 117,500 tonnes per year and only 20 per cent of this is supplied locally. The remaining 94,000 tonnes have to be imported from countries like India and Australia. Risda chairman Datuk Abu Zahar Nika Ujang said the authority is pioneering the use of techniques such as ranching and ``advanced reproductive biotechnology'' in the country. ``With the combination of ranching and ARB, which is used to breed the cows in oil palm estates, we hope to produce enough to meet demand and thus, reduce the import of beef,'' he said. He said the cattle ranching was initially started in Risda estates through its subsidiary Smallholders Estate Sdn Bhd (Espek) in 1987 to control the growth of weeds and grass in the oil palm estates. To date, Risda has about 8,922 cows from the Kedah-Kelantan, Brahman, and also Droughtmaster breeds, in 19 Risda oil palm estates nationwide. Abu Zahar was speaking to reporters after visiting the Ulu Keratong oil palm estate yesterday. Also present were Risda director general Datuk Nik Kamaruddin Nik Kadir, Espek manager Yahya Ahmad and ARB specialist Dr Tengku Azmi Tengku Ibrahim. ``The ranching system has been found to be effective and the maintenance cost of estates has been reduced by 20 per cent. Furthermore, rearing of cows also generates extra income to the estates through the sales of live cows and also beef,'' he said. Abu Zahar said the 187 cows bred through ARB, were being reared in Risda oil palm estates in Terengganu Tengah, Terengganu and Ulu Keratong. ARB is to be used on another 350 cows. ARB, is the latest breeding technology by Mardi, which involves estrus synchronisation, artificial insemination and embryo transfer. ``We have also included a long-term strategy to increase commercial ranching activity to new areas under Risda which includes mini-estates identified to be suitable to be integrated with ranching,'' he said. Risda, Abu Zahar added, would also be working together with the Veterinary Department, Universiti Putra Malaysia and also Mardi to boost ranching in oil palm estates. ``Furthermore, Risda is also planning to venture into other downstream activities such as slaughtering, processing meat products and also marketing of such products within the next five years. ``Other plans also include production of cattle feed using palm fronds which will be developed together with Mardi.''

KUALA LUMPUR, Thurs. - The High Court today recorded an out-of-court settlement in a defamation suit by former Johor MIC chairman Tan Sri G. Pasamanickam against a New Straits Times journalist and three others. The consent judgment for the settlement was recorded before judge Datin Paduka Rahmah Hussain. Pasamanickam, who is MIC treasurer, had filed the action claiming that he was defamed in an article titled ``13 Johor MIC division heads stage walk out'' written by journalist Ravi Nambiar in the New Straits Times on Aug 24, 1995. Pasamanickam named Ravi, New Straits Times Sdn Bhd group editor Datuk A. Kadir Jasin, NST production and technical general manager Tun Ibrahim Jafri and publisher New Straits Times Press (M) Sdn Bhd as defendants. In his statement of claim, Pasamanickam claimed the article meant he had committed criminal breach of trust and was not fit to hold any post and claimed for damages with interest and costs. In their statement of defence, the defendants denied that the article was defamatory and said it was fair comment and justified statements. The defendants had also stated that another article was published on Aug 28, 1995, in which Pasamanickam was given an opportunity to refute allegations contained in the first article. Details of the settlement were not disclosed. The case was first heard on March 16 when Pasamanickam gave evidence. Among others, he said he had not diverted any money into a private scholarship fund as alleged in the article, adding that the money was always deposited into an account of a fund set up by the State MIC. The court subsequently postponed the case to March 17.

KUALA LUMPUR, Thurs. - Businessman Datuk Soh Chee Wen today announced his resignation from all his political positions in the MCA. A statement faxed by his special assistant Lee Chai Huat said that Soh had resigned as deputy chairman of MCA Selangor, chairman of the Selangor Councillor Selection Committee and MCA divisional chairman for Petaling Jaya Selatan. Lee, when contacted, said that the State Assemblyman for Subang Jaya, Lee Hwa Beng, accompanied by MCA PJ Utara division deputy chairman, Wong Leong, handed over Soh's resignation to a staff member at Dr Ling's office at Wisma Perdana this afternoon. He was appointed a central committee member after the party's last triennial election held in 1996. He has also resigned from the post. In mid-January this year, the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange had ordered all brokerages to report their exposure and information - direct or indirect - to Soh. The information include the securities transacted, the quantity of shares, value of exposure, identities of related person or corporation, the relationship and name of related nominee accounts. Soh is currently the president and chief executive officer of Promet Bhd, executive chairman of Uniphoenix Corporation Bhd, executive director and chief executive officer of Plantation and Development Bhd, and managing director of Kelanamas Bhd and Inno-Pacific Holdings Ltd.

THE Civil Court on Thursday accepted a lawsuit filed by 12 dissident Prachakorn Thai Party MPs calling for a denunciation of a party resolution which endangered their memberships, one of the 12 said on Thursday. Thanusak Lek-uthai said the group was also considering lodging a complaint with the Constitutional Court to call for the denunciation of the Civil Court's ruling if it does not favour his group. The group lodged the lawsuit in March calling for a ruling against the Dec 29 resolution, an attempt by Prachakorn Thai leader Samak Sundaravej to oust the 12 dissidents who supported the Democrat-led government. Last year's decision resolved that eight more members serve on the 57-member executive board and that 11 others be appointed, resulting in the pro-Samak faction outnumbering the 12 dissidents. Thanusak also dismissed Samak's earlier remarks that the Civil Court's ruling would use its own standard, saying the Prachkorn Thai leader had attempted to pressure the court to rule against his group. Chalong Riewraeng, a dissident group member, expressed his opposition to Samak's remarks on Wednesday when he compared his group to a nail piercing the Prachakorn Thai leader's foot. ''The nail has stayed put all along but it's the owner of the foot that has harassed the nail and now been loudly complaining about his foot being pierced,'' he said. Chalong also said he and a few group members may set up a new political party after the Democrat Party decided its executive board would decide whether it would accept him and a few others, despite an earlier invitation by Democrat secretary-general Sanan Kachornprasart. Man Pattanothai, a dissident member, said the other option was to join a new party to be set up by former Palang Dharma Party member Thaksin Shinawatra, or the Rassadorn Party or Labour Party at the request of leader Chin Thapplee. On Thursday evening a ceremony was held to introduce the new, but as yet unnamed, political party of Thaksin Shinawatra, at his residence off Soi Charan Sanitwong 69, which several leading political figures attended. Among them were former prime ministers Anand Panyarachun and Banharn Silapa-archa, Bank of Thailand Governor Chatu Mongol Sonakul, Deputy Prime Minister Supachai Panitchpakdi and Communications Minister Suthep Thaugsuban.

JOHOR BARU, Thurs. - The National Unity and Social Development Ministry will take disciplinary action against a welfare officer alleged to have sexually abused two inmates at a welfare home here. Minister Datin Zaleha Ismail said as the State Welfare Department had already reported the matter to the police, the Ministry would wait for the outcome of the investigations before acting. She said the Ministry viewed the case very seriously and would take steps to prevent similar incidents in the future. She welcomed the department's move to review the operations and procedures at the five Government-run welfare institutions in the State. ``Whenever such cases occur, it is important that we do a review to ascertain that whatever weaknesses in the system are immediately identified and remedied. ``In running our welfare homes which offer shelter for abused children, women and other unfortunate people, we practise tight security by imposing strict procedures.'' She added the movement of staff and visitors within the homes was strictly monitored to ensure no untoward incidences occur within the premises. Speaking after closing a refresher course for Southern Region Rukun Tetangga leaders, Zaleha said Rukun Tetangga centres in the country had become very active now. She said the 1,800 RT centres had last year carried out 17,355 social, educational, recreational and welfare activities. She added with a total of 4.5 million RT members, the sector was also being mobilised to assist in promoting programmes to help the country's economic recovery.

Rwandan rebels kill four in attack on main highway
By HRVOJE HRANJSKI Associated Press Writer
TARE, Rwanda (AP) _ Hutu rebels killed four people, burned two trucks and looted a local health center along the main highway in northern Rwanda, witnesses said Friday. The attack on midnight Thursday at Tare, 47 kilometers (25 miles) north of Kigali on the main road to northwestern Rwanda, came a week after a shadowy rebel group warned of violence in areas previously untouched by attackers. Witnesses in Tare said a group of armed men ran shouting and firing guns down the hills, surrounding houses and a restaurant along the main road, before throwing petrol bombs at two parked trucks. The two drivers, who were apparently asleep inside, died instantly. Another man was shot dead, and a local health worker later died of gunshot wounds. ``It lasted maybe 10 minutes,'' said Gerard Minigashura, a local official. ``This is the first time they attacked here.'' Authorities in the capital, Kigali, were not available for comment. Last week, a rebel group calling itself People in Arms for the Liberation of Rwanda warned of more attacks in a previously unknown newspaper. Umucinguzi, or Savior, said the group was fighting the Tutsi occupiers of Rwanda and their allies and urged Hutus to take up arms. PALIR was first heard of in June 1996 when it issued a typewritten leaflet placing a bounty on the heads of Americans in Rwanda. Tutsi fighters took power in July 1994, ousting an extremist Hutu government responsible for the genocide of more than 500,000 minority Tutsis. Issue No. 4 of the Kinyarwanda language newspaper printed a map showing half of Rwanda as rebel-controlled and said attacks would spread to the central Gitarama and northeastern Byumba prefectures. Last week, attacks were reported in Gitarama, Byumba and the western Kibuye prefectures, but no details were available. On Sunday, rebels killed a Presbyterian pastor and his family of five in the northwestern Gisenyi region. Meanwhile, a U.N. commission of inquiry into the illegal flow of arms into the Great Lakes region arrived in Kigali. The four-man comission was reactivated in April to investigate how Hutu rebels were receiving weapons. The rebels are believed to be based in northeastern Congo from where they cross easily in and out of Rwanda. U.N. officials believe the rebels may be assisted by a network of Hutu exiles and businessmen in Africa and Europe. (hh/dmc)

World Cup: Spanish injury list smaller but veteran keeper
Zubizarreta still a worry By CIARAN GILES Associated Press Writer
CHANTILLY, France (AP) _ With just a week to go before its first World Cup game, Spain's previously lengthy injury list looks to be gradually getting smaller with only veteran goalkeeper and team captain Andoni Zubizarreta still a cause for concern. Thirty-six-year-old Zubizarreta stood out from his colleagues Friday at the team's first training session in France because of the exclusive attention he received from the team trainer owing to a week-old left leg muscle problem. While the rest of the team played passing and tackling exercises at the Borgogones sports complex and coach Javier Clemente pumped shots at substitute keepers Santiago Canizares and Paco Molina, Zubizarreta carried out light reflex tests on his own in a corner of the pitch. ``The calendar for my recovery is in order, I'm responding as expected,'' said Zubizarreta who will be taking part in his fourth World Cup and who plans to retire from soccer once the tournament is over. The latest injury comes hot on the heels of another involving his right leg. That sparked fears he would not be able to make it to France. Given his age and experience, Zubizarreta represents something of a father figure for many on the side and his absence would be a major blow at this stage. The Basque keeper, who has played for such Spanish clubs as Valencia, FC Barcelona and Atheltic de Bilbao, is confident of being fit for the side's opening Group D game against Olympic champion Nigeria on June 13 in the western city of Nantes. But he is not sure when he will be able to take part fully in training. ``I'm playing it by the day,'' he said. ``Today I feel better than yesterday but I haven't got a set a date for being totally recovered.'' Spain, which will also face Bulgaria and Paraguay, already is missing one of its regular play-makers in Barcelona midfielder Josep Guardiola who scratched himself off the team list due to knee problems. But other players hit by injury recently _ Real Madrid stars, Raul Gonzalez, Fernando Hierro and Fernando Morientes and Barcelona's Abelardo Fernandez _ were all reported to be on the mend. Most worrying was Raul who suffered from groin pains all season and had to rest for several days last week because of it. ``I feel much better than I expected,'' said the 20-year-old who many believe could prove to be one of the tournament's stars. ``I'm now back training with the rest and that's good.'' KUALA LUMPUR, Thurs. - All commercial space inside the arrival and departure terminals of the new Kuala Lumpur International Airport in Sepang had been allocated, Transport Minister Datuk Seri Dr Ling Liong Sik said today. ``The entrepreneurs are now putting the finishing touches,'' he said, adding that he had been shown artist's impressions of what some of these duty-free shops and outlets would look like. He said most of the businessmen had come up with imaginative ideas and shoppers would feel like they were shopping in exotic destinations such as Geneva, Rome and Venice. BATU PAHAT, Thurs. - The Health Ministry has decided to forbid the sale of Viagra pill in the country until it gets an assurance from the manufacturer that it will not be excessively priced. Health Minister Datuk Chua Jui Meng said the Ministry had informed the manufacturer, Pfizer Inc, based in the United States, of its intention and urged the company to reconsider its price options. Said Chua: ``We can do without Viagra if the company is going to exploit the market to take advantage of the hype on the product. ``Of course, there is also the uncertain health risk attached to the usage of the pill to be considered,'' he said after opening the Batu Pahat Rotary Club Haemodialysis Centre here today. He said he had also discussed with Pfizer the possible health risk involved for those taking the pill. ``We categorically told the company that we would not allow the distribution of the pill in the country until the company complies to our conditions,'' he said. On reports that the Viagra pill was already in circulation in the country, Chua said it could be fakes. ``It is illegal to distribute the pill in the country and we believe consumers may be tricked into buying another pill which bears a similar name to Viagra.'' ``Consumers are warned not to take the risk of using such pills as such sex enhancement pills should be consumed only by doctors' prescription,'' he said. ``They should understand that while the pill has proven to cure impotency in men, it can be harmful if improperly prescribed.''

Nuclear processing plant that took Georgia material to shut down
Eds: AMs, recasts, updates, adds quotes.
LONDON (AP) _ Prime Minister Tony Blair's government, under attack from anti-nuclear activists, announced Friday it will shut down the nuclear processing plant in Scotland that just accepted a controversial shipment from the former Soviet republic of Georgia. ``The whole of Scotland is going to be breathing one massive sigh of relief,'' said Lorraine Mann, a longtime critic of the Dounreay plant on the coast of northern Scotland, which was built in 1957. Dounreay, which shut down its fast reactor in 1994 and stopped producing electricity, will take no new nuclear shipments but will finish reprocessing 15 tonnes (16.5 tons) of material from its own reactor, the 0.8 kilogram (1.76 pounds) of nuclear material from Georgia, and its existing commerical contracts, Energy Minister John Battle said. Battle said he hoped that all would be completed by 2006. The cleaning-up process at the site could take up to 100 years, said John McKeown, chief executive of Dounreay's operators, the United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority. The government insisted the decision was based on economics, not safety, although an audit of plant safety is under way. The independence-seeking Scottish National Party, a close competitor of Blair's Labor Party in the search for Scottish votes, opposed the operation of Dounreay and claimed Friday's announcement as a victory. SNP leader Alex Salmond taunted the government, saying, ``Anyone with an interest in these matters has known for some considerable time that Dounreay is not in a condition where it is safe to take any extra nuclear material to it.'' The Georgian shipment in April _ 4.3 kilograms (9.46 pounds) of highly enriched uranium and 0.8 kilograms (1.76 pounds) of spent nuclear fuel _ was controversial in part because it was kept secret in Britain and the story broke in the United States. Blair said then, and his office repeated Friday, that the decision was taken in the interests of nuclear non-proliferation, to keep it out of the hands of terrorists or would-be nuclear powers. Earlier this week, Blair had accused the Scottish nationalists of being ``irresponsible and extreme'' during another flap over reports that enough uranium to make a half-dozen nuclear warheads was missing from Dounreay. The atomic energy authority said an internal inquiry listed 170 kilograms (374 pounds) of uranium as missing from work in the mid-1960s, but contended it was a paper technicality, calculating that the amount of material that went into the plant was overestimated by 1 percent. ``The concern now is to ensure that we pass on to future generations a safe environment,'' said Donald Dewar, the government's Cabinet secretary for Scotland. Talks between the Executive and Legislative branch continued on Thursday with the first meeting of a commission that will follow the progress of nation's most important legislation through Congress, Notimex reported. At the meeting of the Intermediary Commission, the members agreed to ask congressional committees to release information on the status of proposals such as the financial package and the Indigenous Rights Proposal. Representing the Legislative side were Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI) Deputy Enrique Jackson, Party of the Democratic Revolution (PRD) Deputy Demetrio Sodi, and National Action Party (PAN) Senator Ricardo Garcia Cervantes while Deputy Interior Secretary Jorge Alcocer represented the Executive. Alcocer said that the commission will meet again next Thursday when the 15 Chamber of Deputies and Senate committees have reported on the status of the pertinent bills. The Intermediary Commission was formed by the Interior Secretariat (Gobernacion) and Congress in order to make sure the proposals to be discussed in a possible extraordinary session and September's regularly-scheduled ordinary session do not get lost in committee. The Gobernacion official said that a date for the extraordinary session will be determined in one of the upcoming commission meetings. ``Right now we are only in agreement on the mechanism we will use to move our work forward,'' Alcocer said after the meeting. But even agreeing on the mechanism was a task that required several meetings between Interior Secretary Francisco Labastida and the congressional delegation coordinators. The fact that Mexico's two most important governmental powers are a testament to how relations have improved since Labastida took office. PAN Senator Ricardo Garcia Cervantes said the commission also agreed to solicit ``detailed information'' from the Finance Secretariat and the Banco de Mexico about the financial reform package which is expected to be discussed and approved during the extraordinary session. Although Garcia Cervantes recognized that part of the commission's work was to make sure the financial reforms were ready for a special session, he said the bills would not be rushed through Congress. ``We are aware that there are important pending issues like the financial package, but there is no haste that can justify irresponsibility. The economy would run greater risks if it is governed by irresponsible measures,'' the panista said. PRD Deputy Demetrio Sodi added that the Intermediary Commission hopes to ``convert 15 of the nation's most important laws into constitutional changes by the end of the year.''

Witnesses, paparazzi, Al Fayed converge on Paris courthouse
Eds: UPDATES with Al Fayed, witness quotes; detail on Diana's mother, Paul's parents also present. NEW photo numbers. AP Photos PAR107-110, PAR114-116 By JOCELYN NOVECK Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ A French judge on Friday brought together for the first time the main parties in the Diana investigation, in an effort to finally clarify the role of photographers in the crash. Grouped together were the photographers under investigation in the case; eight witnesses to the crash; Mohamed Al Fayed; Diana's mother, Frances Shand Kydd, and the parents of driver Henri Paul. They were accompanied by a platoon of lawyers. The crash in a Paris traffic tunnel last Aug. 31 killed Diana, her companion Dodi Fayed, and driver Paul. Tests showed Paul was drunk at the time. But was it merely a case of a drunk driver, or was there responsibility on the part of the paparazzi trailing Diana's Mercedes that night? Nine photographers and one press motorcyclist have been placed under investigation _ a step short of being formally charged. They have remained in legal limbo for almost a year, continuing their work. In what was seen as a last-ditch effort to clarify their roles, Stephan was questioning each photographer one by one. Lawyers and witnesses emerging from the courtroom described the process. The judge asked each photographer to give an account of their role that night. He then questioned them, questioned witnesses as to what they had seen of the photographer's behavior, and opened questions to other lawyers. According to lawyers, photographer Romuald Rat was harshly questioned by lawyers for Al Fayed, who tried to establish that he pursued the Mercedes that night. ``I followed it. I did not pursue it,'' Rat responded. During an afternoon break, Al Fayed railed against the paparazzi. ``If I was not in a courtroom, I would hang them all,'' he said. ``The immorality, the inhumanity of what they did. They were like vultures around the bodies.'' Al Fayed also had harsh words for Diana's mother. ``She won't talk to me,'' he said. ``She thinks she's in the royal family. ``I'm just an ordinary guy, a working-class guy. It's snobbery.'' Mrs. Shand Kydd emerged from the courtroom during a break, but waved away journalists. She, Al Fayed, and Paul's family are civil parties in the case, meaning they have access to documents and proceedings. Ten witnesses were summoned, but only eight showed up. They included the first emergency doctor on the scene, Frederic Mailliez, and the first two policemen on the scene. ``It's so painstaking,'' Mailliez told The Associated Press of the meeting. ``It's thorough, but it's taking a long time.'' Lawyers said the policemen who spoke accused Rat of hindering their work. Another witness, private chauffeur Clifford Gooroovadoo, said he'd told the judge he saw Rat and another photographer, Christian Martinez, fighting just after the accident. He said Rat, after taking his own pictures, was telling Martinez to stop. The photographers are being investigated on two charges: manslaughter, and failing to come to the aid of a person in danger. Many close to the case believe they will soon be exonerated, at least on the manslaughter charge. Nikolas Arsov, of the Sipa photo agency, said the hearing was inconvenient, but he understood the need for it. ``It's the 40th time we have answered the same questions,'' Arsov told The AP. ``It's annoying, but what can you do? They have to do their job.'' In contrast to previous hearings, all cameras were kept outside the Palais de Justice. The gates were heavily guarded by police. Al Fayed drew up to the main courthouse in a Mercedes, surrounded by four other cars and about 10 bodyguards. It isn't just his son's death that connects Al Fayed to the case. Driver Paul was an employee of the Ritz Hotel, which Al Fayed owns. ``I hope that God will find the truth for us,'' he said as he left the Ritz in the morning. Although the probe is not complete, investigators long have believed it was Paul's drunken condition and the Mercedes' excessive speed that probably caused the crash. They also are still looking for a white Fiat Uno believed to have brushed the Mercedes before it crashed. But they are said to have given up any real hope of finding the Fiat. Tests are still being conducted on the wrecked Mercedes Diana was traveling in, but aren't likely to be finished before October _ meaning the case can't be closed until then. One person who wasn't attending Friday's session: bodyguard Trevor Rees-Jones, the sole survivor of the crash. He was invited on an ``informational basis,'' but decided not to come. (jn-dgs)

Saudi arms tycoon reaches deal with Ritz over 8-million pound
gambling debt
LONDON (AP) _ Saudi arms tycoon and high-roller Adnan Khashoggi on Friday reached an out-of-court settlement with London's Ritz Casino over a multimillion pound (dlr) losing streak in the spring of 1986. Lawyers announced on the fourth day a High Court hearing that the casino had settled its 8-million pound (dlrs 13.2 million) claim, and Khashoggi withdrew charges that the Ritz let him gamble on credit, which is illegal. Neither side gave details of the settlement. Witnesses testified that Khashoggi, who lives in Paris and did not show up in court, gambled 10.1 million pounds (then dlrs 14 million) on the tables at the Ritz Hotel in Piccadilly between the end of January and April 10, 1986. At first he was winning and his checks for chips were honored. But then the tables turned, Khashoggi kept buying, and 16 checks for 200,000 pounds (then dlrs 280,000) each bounced. The checks were drawn on an account with Swiss Banking Corporation of Geneva on three days at the end of March and were rejected April 10. The casino sued to recover the checks plus interest since 1986 which had run up to about 5 million pounds (dlrs 8.15 million). Lawyers for Khashoggi, 63, claimed the debt was unenforceable because he had an arrangement with the casino to continue gambling on credit, illegal under Britain's Gaming Act. The casino said it sued as a last resort. ``Casinos don't want to be seen to be suing their clients. It's extremely bad PR,'' Max Kingsley, former managing director of the Ritz Casino's parent company, told the court. Judge Richard Rougier said he was happy to hear of the deal. ``It seemed to me preeminently an action which was better compromised on acceptable terms than fought to a finish. It had quite a few complexities and wrinkles,'' he commented. (mj)

KUANTAN, Thurs. - Universiti Teknologi Malaysia has proposed three sites in Pekan for the development of its branch campus. The locations are in Peramu Jaya, Kota Inderapura and Sungai Miang. Menteri Besar Tan Sri Mohd Khalil Yaakob is expected to hold further discussions with Education Minister Datuk Seri Najib Tun Razak soon before deciding on the site. State Education and Religious Affairs Committee chairman Datuk Adnan Yaakob said the State Government would also liaise with the Pekan district and land office and State Land and Mines Department. ``This is to ensure that the proposed sites do not belong to anyone or have been pledged to other government agencies,'' he said. UTM vice-chancellor Datuk Dr Ahmad Zaharuddin Idrus had earlier called on Khalil to brief him on the development plans and propose the locations. He was accompanied by deputy vice-chancellor (development) Prof Zainal Abidin Ahmad, executive director Aziruddin Razak and treasurer Mohamad Abdullah. Today's meeting was a follow-up to an announcement by Najib last month that a UTM branch campus would be developed in Pekan. Meanwhile, Ahmad Zaharuddin said the cost of the project would depend on the size of land provided by the State Government. He said the first batch of 300 students to study at the branch campus was being housed at the main campus in Skudai, Johor. They will move to a temporary branch campus in Jalan Bukit Ubi here for the second semester of the present academic year. The branch campus will offer degree courses in automotive, petro- chemical, electrical and electronic engineering as well as information technology. On a request by the Education Ministry that universities increase their intake to accommodate deserving students who have failed to enter local public institutes of higher learning, Ahmad Zaharuddin said UTM could accommodate 200 more students.

BC-Russia-Caucasus
Yeltsin concerned Russians leaving Caucasus
MOSCOW (AP) _ President Boris Yeltsin said Friday he is concerned that ethnic Russians are leaving the often restive regions of the North Caucasus. ``This is a very alarming signal,'' Yeltsin told regional leaders at a meeting in the Kremlin. The North Caucasus includes Chechnya, which has declared independence, and neighboring Ingushetia and Dagestan, all of which are mainly Muslim. It also includes predominantly Orthodox Christian North Ossetia, which has maintained warmer relations with the Kremlin than other places in the region and served as a launching base for Moscow's 1994-96 campaign against Chechen separatists. ``Russians are leaving the Northern Caucasus almost as quickly as they are leaving former U.S.S.R. republics,'' Yeltsin said, according to the ITAR-Tass news agency. He gave no figures or reason for the exodus. Many people of all ethnic groups have fled the former Soviet republics in Central Asia and the Caucasus, either to seek a better life in more prosperous Russian cities, or to escape rampant crime and ethnic conflicts. Yeltsin also met Friday with Magomedali Magomedov, the leader of Dagestan, where recent clashes between police and Muslim militants took place. Magomedov again said that the unrest didn't grow into a full-scale war because most Dagestani people have no intention of seceding from Russia, and their protests are aimed against social and economic troubles in the region, Yeltsin spokesman Sergei Yastrzhembsky said. WASHINGTON -- U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS) Commissioner Doris Meissner on Thursday called the murder of a border agent near Nogales, Ariz., an ''ironic tragedy,'' noting the agent had arrived in the United States as a refugee only 10 years ago. ''It's very compelling,'' Meissner said. ''It's a terrible thing, and we're working closely with Mexican officials on the case.'' Border patrol agent Alexander Kirpnic, 27, a Ukranian refugee whose family emigrated from the former Soviet Union less than a decade ago, died Wednesday after being shot in the head by suspected drug traffickers. Kirpnic was shot west of Nogales, when five backpackers were stopped by two U.S. border agents. One suspect took out his gun, Meissner said, and killed Kirpnic. Agents recovered two backpacks filled with marijuana. ''We have some people in custody,'' Meissner said. ''But we don't know if we have them all.'' INS records showed one of five suspects in custody by Thursday afternoon, but officials did not reveal the suspect's name. ''The timing is terrible,'' said M. Delal Baer, director of the Mexico project of the Center for Strategic and International Studies. ''This was a violent act, but Mexico-U.S. relations were already strained, and it may make cooperation difficult.'' Kirpnic's killing was the first border patrol agent murder this year.
