Interior Secretary Francisco Labastida Ochoa denied Thursday that a raid on a small Chiapas town was an act of political persecution, Notimex reported. ``The governor asked us to carry out this action due to a clear violation of the law,'' Labastida said about the raid on San Nicholas Ruiz that netted 167 prisoners. Original reports said 147 were arrested. ``What we Mexicans have to see clearly is that the law has to be applied to all Mexicans without any discrimination.'' Labastida was especially proud that not a single shot was fired during the raid and said using children as human shields -- as the San Nicolas Ruiz villagers allegedly did -- was ``cowardly.'' The head of the Interior Secretariat (Gobernacion) confidently predicted that the raid -- similar to ones conducted on villages sympathetic to the Zapatista Army of National Liberation (EZLN) would not affect peace negotiations with the rebel Zapatistas. Unlike Taniperlas and Agua Tinta, San Nicolas Ruiz was strongly allied with the opposition Party of the Democratic Revolution (PRD). Chiapas Gov. Roberto Albores Guillen requested the military action because the town's PRD majority had allegedly violently expelled 33 families that support the Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI). In his explanation of the raid, Labastida said the village ``had already experienced agitation,'' and that such conflicts in the region were frequently solved by the ``Law of the Jungle,'' not by law and justice. Interviewed again later Thursday, Labastida insisted that the action was simply ``the application of the law,'' not the ``persecution of anyone for their ideology.'' ``The government is obliged to make sure the law is followed and respected by all Mexicans,'' the Gobernacion chief said. If one group is allowed to be expelled because they think differently than a minority group, the individual guarantees and human rights of the minority have been violated, Labastida said. ``In our country, Mexicans have the right to act and think according to what each person has decided for themselves. But this freedom should never be allowed to represent a violation of the law and of the rights of other people,'' said the Interior Secretary. Meanwhile, the Chiapas Attorney General's Office (PGJE) said Thursday that another 10 people arrested in San Nicolas Ruiz were arraigned on charges of disobedience and resistance. Of the 167 people arrested during Wednesday's raid, 151 were released for lack of evidence. A PGJE official said the high number of arrests was due to the villagers' attempt to prevent soldiers and policemen from carrying out 12 arrest warrants.

BC-Pakistan-Nuclear,0448
Pakistan promises restraint, but won't fall behind India
By ARTHUR MAX Associated Press Writer
ISLAMABAD, Pakistan (AP) _ Faced with a demand for nuclear restraint, Pakistan promised Friday to act responsibly but said it won't allow itself to fall behind neighboring rival India. ``While we will not provoke escalation, our responses will be carefully calibrated to respond to any provocation or escalation by India,'' said a government statement. On Thursday, the foreign ministers of the five established nuclear powers called on India and Pakistan to step back from the brink of nuclear confrontation after both tested atomic devices last month. The Pakistani statement did not address the specifics of the foreign ministers' demand to refrain from deploying nuclear weapons, conducting more missile tests or producing fissile material. Nor did Pakistan say if it would consider joining the nonproliferation regimes that have kept a lid on the spread of nuclear technology. India calls those treaties discriminatory since they do not ask the nuclear powers to disarm. Pakistan says it will sign them only if India does. ``We will continue to conduct ourselves with restraint and responsibility,'' said the statement issued by the Foreign Ministry. ``However, Pakistan will not allow itself to be placed in a position of strategic vulnerability or inequality.'' In Geneva, the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain, Russia, China and France offered their help in ``promoting reconciliation and conciliation.'' But they stopped short of proposing mediation on the disputed territory of Kashmir, which has triggered two of the three Indo-Pakistan wars. Pakistan would welcome such mediation. Its statement said the Geneva initiative should be the beginning of international involvement in the Indian subcontinent. In the past, India has said the Kashmir problem must be sorted out by the two countries alone. The statement also offered to resume talks between the top foreign ministry officials of India and Pakistan that were suspended last year. ``But it is evident now that the bilateral dialogue needs to be supplemented by a broader multilateral process to promote durable peace and security in South Asia,'' it said. India detonated a series of devices starting May 11. Rejecting international attempts to forestall a Pakistani test, Islamabad demonstrated its own nuclear capability on May 28. ``We are not interested in a nuclear or conventional arms race,'' the statement said, noting Pakistan had previously called for regional and bilateral nonproliferation agreements.

WHILE it may not be the perfect solution for a lethargic economy, the creation of the Asset Management Company (AMC) to take over the banking system's non-performing loans (NPLs), will provide a much needed breathing space for bankers and borrowers alike. The main aim, however, is to ensure that given the tight economic situation, any adverse effects from the grossly weakened Malaysian economy will not push the country too far into the corner and hamper recovery efforts. Before the concept of establishing the AMC emerged, all the dreaded indications of an economy pinned down and helpless were clearly visible. The banking system has been central to all these concerns and the Government as well as the economic policymakers have been striving to protect the sector. The spotlight may turn to the private business sector next since it has also suffered greatly from the current economic turmoil. The declining ringgit adversely affected the earnings of corporations as well as their foreign debt exposure. This later translated into tightening cashflows which in turn affected their loan servicing schedules. Bankers, on their part, were faced with the tightening liquidity in the financial system, which came about as the Government moved to check the exposure of banks to loans, especially to non-productive sectors. To top it all, due to borrowers' problems in servicing their debts, the level of NPLs in the banking system was expected to increase steadily. This was considered an unhealthy development and one which demanded pre-emptive corrective measures. The problem was compounded by the fact that the NPLs needed to be funded and provisions had to be made for them. This consumed most of the available funds - meant for lending purposes - in the banking system. The mountain of NPLs also demanded more management time on the part of banks, making it difficult for many to juggle their normal banking practices such as lending and managing deposits with allocating resources to unproductive activities such as managing bad loans. As for the affected borrowers, the spectre of legal proceedings to recover loans and the foreclosure of collateral was ever present. With such overhanging threats, companies were also preoccupied with their own loan exposure, causing them tp pay less attention to everyday business. While one may point out the option of traditional debt-reconstruction exercises, such moves will cost an already burdened company more as it will have to appoint advisers and inevitably prolong the period of interest payments. With the seemingly reduced options, the creation of the AMC was necessary as a pre-emptive measure in preventing the NPL situation from completely choking the economy. While the 9.1 per cent level of NPLs in the banking system as at the end of March this year was still manageable, the effects of the steadily rising level are becoming apparent in the shape of increasingly scarce credit facilities and the many debt-ridden companies. The Government simply cannot ignore the situation as the price will be a stagnant economy, without the necessary avenues for any form of recovery at all. Placing the NPLs and assets pledged against such loans with the AMC should not put any party in a disadvantageous position. These assets will be nurtured back to viability before being sold in the open market. In other words, they will not be left idle, but will undergo an almost similar exercise to the one that a business under corporate recovery and turnaround management would go through. There is also nothing to stop the initial owners from acquiring these assets after they have met their loan committments. As in debt reconstruction exercises, the benefit to borrowers is apparent in the extension of time given to them to service their debts. Meanwhile, the assets they pledged are managed by professionals. The banks in turn, will now have their funds freed from the stringent provisions they had to make for the acquired NPLs. All this translates into a much needed injection of liquidity into the financial system to revitalise a slowly choking economy.

IPOH, Thurs. - Residents of Kampung Tersusun Jelapang Jaya have lodged a police report against an ironwork factory located near their homes for causing dust and noise pollution which is affecting their health. The report was made by the residents action committee chairman A. Sebastian at the Jelapang police station at 10am. He was accompanied by about 10 residents. Sebastian said the residents were disappointed with the authorities for not taking any action despite various complaints forwarded to the Ipoh City Council and the Department of Environment. The committee had also sent letters of complaint to State Health and Environment Committee chairman Datuk Lee Chee Leong and State Industrial and Entrepreneur Development Committee chairman Datuk Seri Junus Wahid. BC-Norway-Antarctic,0259
Antarctic Treaty nations agree on environmental rules
OSLO, Norway (AP) _ The 26 countries that manage Antarctica announced Friday that they settled key rules for protecting the frozen continent's fragile environment. Concern about increased human activity on the vast area surrounding the South Pole was a main topic for the 22nd Antarctic Consultative Meeting, in the northern city of Tromsoe. ``Now we have in place a unique and comprehensive set of regulations for an entire continent. This is important not in the least because the global significance of the Antarctic has become greater at the same time as pressure on its resources increases,'' Norwegian delegation leader Dagfinn Stenset was quoted as telling the national news agency NTB. Norwegian polar expert Arne Orheim was elected as chairman of the new environmental committee and said it already set up five working groups to identify threats to Antarctic. ``The most important working group will approve environmental impact assessments for all projects of significant scope in the Antarctic,'' he was quoted as telling NTB. He said the committee will also present an environmental status report for the region to the Antarctic Conference in 2000. The meeting failed to agree on which nation would be the site of its Antarctic secretariat, a problem that has lingered for decades. Under the treaty, nations put aside territorial claims in the Antarctic, and agreed to use it only for peaceful, nonmilitary purposes.

Bosnian Croats apparently pressured to shelve plans for new party
ZAGREB, Croatia (AP) _ Bosnian Croat leaders met Friday with their patron, Croatian President Franjo Tudjman, amid indications that he might pressure them to back off on plans to form a new political party. A terse statement issued after the closed meeting said the unity of the existing main party _ the Croatian Democratic Union _ should be preserved and it should ``act united'' at the upcoming Sept. elections, according to the state news agency HINA. The new party is to be led by Kresimir Zubak, the Bosnian Croat member of the tripartite Bosnian presidency. It is to be formed next Sunday, effectively splitting the Croatian Democratic Union, the Bosnian branch of Tudjman's governing party, and breaking its near monopoly on Bosnian Croat votes. In announcing the planned new party, Zubak said he wanted to distance himself from he old party leadership, composed of people ``who amassed wealth during the war ... and who want to divide Bosnia.'' In an interview Friday with the daily Vjesnik, Zubak suggested the old party's leadership still wants to annex south-western Bosnia, which they control, to Croatia proper, thereby neglecting Bosnian Croats elsewhere. Zubak, a moderate, pledged to fully respect the peace plan, which envisages a united country and unimpeded return of refugees of all ethnic groups _ something hard-line Croat nationalists in the old party oppose. International officials signaled their support on Thursday by allowing Zubak's new party to run in September elections, even though the deadline for registering had expired. (sv/gj)

U.S. financial group The Principal's Mexican affiliate Afore Confia-Principal, presented a letter of intent to buy Afore Atlantico-Promex, Confia-Principal announced Thursday. The news followed hard on the heels of Banco Bilbao Viscaya (BBV)'s announcement this week that it will increase its capital stake in the private pension fund administrator Afore Profuturo from 25 to 30.2 percent. BBV bank upped its stake in Profuturo to secure a place in the growing pension fund administrator (Afore) system in Latin America, the bank said, where Mexico, after Brazil has the most potential in terms of dimension and growth. Analysts are also optimistic about Mexico's future in the industry. ``The concept of pension funds under management is so new,'' the developing market will offer great potential growth, said Patrick Boucher, Santander brokerage house banking analyst. ``We will see less money in bank savings and more in mutual funds,'' to accumulate pension savings, he said. BBV's move comes after the bank started closing a precedent-setting transaction to acquire Afore Previnter, the first Afore merger. The Previnter acquisition makes Profuturo the second ranking Afore operator in affiliates, with 1.8 million, and third in potential affiliate base, with 15 percent of the market. Confia-Principal says its move will increase its market share 1.52 percent and increase the number of workers in its scheme to more than 260,000. The government estimates the potential market for pension fund affiliates at 17 million people. To date, 96 percent of the potential market has joined an Afore. BBV is a market leader in Afore investment, generating about 3.78 billion dollars in funds, owned by 3.8 million participants.

THE University College London in Gower Street will provide 34 scholarships for Asian students in the coming academic year. UCL registrar Martin Butcher said in a statement yesterday current or prospective students from Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand and South Korea were eligible to apply. The scholarships, under the British Scholarship Scheme, will provide funds of between STG1,600 (about RM10,000) and STG4,000 each. Butcher said the scholarships would be made on the basis of academic merit and financial need. He said the scheme was in addition to the recently-established Shell Centenary Scholarship and the Overseas Research Student Scholarship Scheme, which provide some form of financial support for overseas students at UCL, in excess of STG400,000 annually. ``The college is determined that economic and political difficulties should not prevent the best and brightest graduates and undergraduates from studying here,'' he said. British authorities, through the British Council, recently set up an emergency scholarship fund for needy students from the four countries. The STG6.6 million fund is supported by the British Council, the Foreign and Commonwealth Office, British universities and British companies through the Department of Trade and Industry. The scholarship scheme under the fund is a one-time issue and only covers the 1998/99 academic year. British companies which have contributed to the fund include Standard Chartered, British Gas International, ICI, and Prudential Corporation Asia.

BANDAR Utama Development Sdn Bhd re-opened the western ramp of the Bandar Utama overhead bridge leading to Tropicana Golf and Country Club today, succumbing to pressure from residents and motorists inconvenienced by the closure. The ramp will, however, only remain open until the completion of the Damansara-Puchong Highway's (LDP) Damansara Utama underpass. Bandar Utama special projects manager Paul Tong said the Petaling Jaya Municipal Council had agreed with the proposal. ``We made a proposal to MPPJ and it was agreed that the ramp will be opened for traffic heading to the New Klang Valley Expressway toll plaza and Tropicana Golf and Country Club only until the completion of the LDP's Damansara Utama underpass,'' he said. ``We believe that the opening of the ramp is a win-win situation for all parties concerned especially the public which is the main reason for our decision as advised by MPPJ president Datuk Mohamad Nor Bador.'' The western ramp, which is only meant for temporary usage, was closed on April 23 as Bandar Utama felt that the permanent access should have been built by Tropicana Golf and Country Resorts Bhd. TGCR had, however, said the closure was not proper as the right to close the ramp was within its jurisdiction, not Bandar Utama's, according to an agreement entered by both parties in 1993. TGCR had also explained that it had completed its part of the permanent access road but that it could not be connected to Lebuh Bandar Utama due to the fact that Tenaga Nasional Berhad and Selangor Islamic Religious Department reserve land stood between the two areas. Currently, the underpass which was opened early last month, only allows free flow to motorists from Section 17 heading towards Kelana Jaya, from Kelana Jaya to Damansara Jaya, from Damansara Jaya to Taman Tun Dr Ismail and Taman Tun Dr Ismail to Section 17. He said traffic from Taman Tun Dr Ismail and Bandar Utama heading towards the toll plaza was not allowed to turn right at the underpass to go to the toll plaza. ``Currently, they need to use the overhead bridge, turn left and make a U-turn before the pedestrian bridge or head into Damansara Utama and make a turn back to the main road at the roundabout near the mosque,'' he said. He hoped that with the opening of the ramp, the traffic congestion at SS21/64 linking the New Klang Valley Expressway toll plaza will be reduced considerably,'' he said. He also hoped that Bandar Utama residents would be tolerant and patient for the wider interest of the public until the completion of the underpass.

BC-Greece-Turkey, 1st Ld-Writethru
Aegean security depends on Turkey, Greece says
Eds: UPDATES with Bulgarian reaction in 12th graf, Istanbul meeting last graf
ATHENS, Greece (AP) _ The success of NATO-backed confidence-building measures on sharing the Aegean Sea depends on Turkey upholding its end of the bargain, Greece's foreign minister said Friday. ``From our side, I have confidence that we will do everything possible to uphold the agreement,'' Foreign Minister Theodoros Pangalos said. ``As for the other side, I hope _ because that's all I can do _ that they display equivalent behavior.'' The measures, presented by NATO Secretary-General Javier Solana in Brussels on Thursday, are based on a 1988 Greek-Turkish agreement that was never fully implemented. At the time, both countries agreed to respect each other's sovereignty, territorial integrity and rights to use Aegean waters and international airspace. The accord also called for a moratorium on military maneuvers in the Aegean during July and August. Both Turkey and Greece hold regular exercises in the area, where they have come to the brink of war twice in the past 11 years over territorial disputes. Pangalos blamed Turkey for the breakdown of the original confidence-building measures. ``There is a troubled past,'' the foreign minister said, adding that the failure of the 1988 agreement stemmed ``from an attempt to tie other disputes into the specific issues being discussed.'' The accord collapsed following accusations of air and sea space violations by both sides. The only part upheld was a moratorium on military exercises during the summer tourist season. This time, success depends on Turkey putting into practice what it has signed, Greek government spokesman Dimitris Reppas said. ``This is a good first step, but it's not enough,'' he explained. ``It has to be put into practice with respect for the national integrity and independence of both countries.'' The Turkish foreign ministry on Thursday welcomed the agreement, saying it could ``contribute to a peaceful solution to all problems between the two countries.'' Bulgaria, which neighbors Greece and Turkey, also praised the accord. ``The political will demonstrated by the Greek and Turkish governments is a further major step towards building confidence and stability in the region,'' Bulgarian Foreign Ministry Spokesman Radko Vlaikov said. UN inspectors seek to rally Security Council support
Eds: LEADS to UPDATE with Iraq agreeing to work with UNSCOM but rejects ``road map,'' TRIMS By ROBERT H. REID Associated Press Writer
UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ Iraq agreed Friday to work with U.N. arms inspectors ``to finalize work quickly'' to ending sanctions but rejected a ``road map'' of disarmanent steps which the chief inspector will carry to Baghdad next week. Chief inspector Richard Butler travels to Iraq next week to spell out specific measures Iraq must take so the U.N. Special Commission can certify that Iraq is free of illegal weapons. That is the main condition for the Security Council to lift sanctions imposed in 1990 after President Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait, touching off the Guld War. Following a two-day briefing to the council, Butler said Thursday that experts have nearly accounted for all Iraqi chemical artillery shells but ``fairly large gaps'' remain in other weapons areas. He said he was taking along a ``road map'' of specific measures. They include release of documents pertaining to Iraq's long-range missiles as well as chemical and biological weapons production. During a press conference, Iraq's foreign minister, Mohammed Saeed al-Sahhaf, said Baghdad was prepared to work with the commission and the Security Council based on a ``professional, scientific and technical approach which confines itself to the requirements of disarmanent.'' But he said the inspectors ``keep insisting on the same `non-starter' approach of casting doubts, building their understanding on assumptions, suspicions and not on facts and figures,'' al-Sahhaf said. Iraq claims it has destroyed all illegal weapons but that the United States and Britain are manipulating the commission to maintain sanctions indefinitely. Al-Sahhaf's remarks indicate the Iraqis still insist that the inspectors should simply verify what Baghdad has already disclosed about its weapons programs, accepting Iraqi declarations as fact. The inspectors claim they have the authority to conduct more far-reaching inspections and not simply base their estimates of Iraqi capabilities on information Baghdad has supplied. ``A `road map' is something that shows the way from `Point A' to `Point B,''' said an Iraqi source on condition of anonymity. ``We say we are already at `Point B.''' That raises doubts whether the Iraqis will be prepared to provide new documentation when they meet Butler in Baghdad on June 12-13. ``It's really just an excuse to ask for a new slogan, that of access to documents,'' Amir al-Saadi, an Iraqi presidential adviser. ``All the documents relevant to disarmanent have been provided.'' Butler's two-day briefing to the council was aimed at easing pressure from France, Russia and China to justify his claims that Iraq may still be holding illegal weapons. U.S. Ambassador Bill Richardson said Butler's briefing proved that ``Iraq is deceiving ... the Security Council'' and ``this must stop if it expects to get sanctions lifted.'' U.N. sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the briefing was part of a ``power struggle'' within the council between the Americans and Britons _ who have been strongly critical of Iraq _ and the Russians, French and Chinese who have been sympathetic to Baghdad's position. Those five countries are permanent council members and have strongly entrenched positions regarding Iraq. Each faction is trying to win support among the 10 non-permanent members.

Settlers intensify campaign against West Bank troop pullback
Eds: For AMs, UPDATES with settlers saying they will establish new settlements if a decision is reached on a troop withdrawal By KARIN LAUB Associated Press Writer
JERUSALEM (AP) _ Fearing that government approval of a West Bank troop withdrawal is imminent, Jewish settlers on Friday took senior members of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's Likud Party on flights over the disputed land in hopes of scuttling a pullback. Settlers also threatened to establish at least two new Jewish settlements if Netanyahu accepts a U.S. withdrawal proposal that would leave 40 percent of the West Bank under Palestinian control and restrict settlement expansion. As a result of the withdrawal, ``the settlements are turning into enclaves in Palestinian areas and in our view, this is a life-and-death battle,'' said settler spokesman Aharon Domb. Under the American plan, Israel would withdraw from 13 percent of the West Bank over a 12-week period, in exchange for Palestinian security measures, such as collecting illegal weapons. Negotiations on a permanent peace agreement would begin with the first pullback. Two senior Palestinian negotiators were to brief Arafat later Friday on their talks with the U.S. Mideast envoy, Dennis Ross. Israel army radio said Ross asked the Palestinians to accept several changes in the original U.S. proposal, but that report could not be confirmed. A remaining sticking point is the scope of an additional pullback promised by Israel. Netanyahu wants assurances now that he will not have to hand over more than 2 percent at the time, a demand rejected by the Palestinians. Despite continued disagreements, both Netanyahu and Arafat seemed mildly optimistic in their assessments. Netanyahu said Thursday that ``some progress'' had been made, while Arafat said he was assured by U.S. mediators that a deal would be wrapped up by mid-June. Netanyahu's senior adviser, David Bar-Illan, said the prime minister would present a withdrawal agreement to parliament, even though he is not required to do so. The plan is likely to pass with the votes of the dovish opposition. However, far-right lawmakers have said that if Netanyahu agrees to a withdrawal, they would try to bring him down at the next possible opportunity by voting against the government in a no-confidence motion. Israeli media speculated Friday that faced with defections by the far right, Netanyahu would soon try to form a national unity government with the opposition Labor Party as a junior partner. Such a coalition would have to be formed immediately after a parliament vote on a troop withdrawal. The Jewish settlement movement, meanwhile, stepped up efforts to block a withdrawal. On Friday, dozens of members of the Likud Central Committee were flown across the West Bank in planes chartered by settlers trying to persuade them to oppose any pullback as a danger to Israel's security. Maps in hand, they were given explanations by settler guides. Settler leader Yehiel Leiter said that should the government go ahead with a withdrawal, settlers would set up two new settlements within 24 hours. Leiter said the protest would likely by symbolic, with a few tents or mobile homes on West Bank hilltops. kl

KUALA LUMPUR, Thurs. - Several residents associations today voiced their dissatisfaction over the the police decision to withdraw a permit granted to the Federation of Malaysians Consumer Associations for a public forum on the water problem. They said there was no good reason for the decision as the matter was of national interest and, more importantly, was not a threat to security. The forum, titled ``Krisis Air Pada Masa Kini'' (Current Water Crisis) was to be held at the Bandar Tun Razak Sports Complex at 8pm yesterday. Police cited security reasons for withdrawing the permit. The Selangor Menteri Besar's office also requested Fomca to cancel the public forum. Bukit Bandaraya deputy president Mumtaz Ali described the move as strange. ``They only wanted to discuss an important problem which has in recent weeks become a national problem. ``If the issue can be highlighted daily in the media, why did the police find it necessary to revoke the permit,'' he asked. Mumtaz said the forum was a platform for the people to discuss the matter with the authorities in an appropriate manner. ``We are only interested to find solutions and not to point fingers at anyone. ``Fomca is a responsible federation and it is not fair on the part of the police to revoke the permit,'' he said. There are 1.8 million consumers in 702 areas in the Klang Valley where water supply is rationed. Bangsar Baru Residents Association vice-president George Joseph shared similar sentiments, adding that the forum was also a place for the authorities to advise people to save water. ``The forum was not only meant to discuss the water problem. It was also to allow the relevant authorities to advise the people on the importance of saving water,'' he said. Joseph said the forum was also a meeting to allow the relevant agencies to explain to the people the causes of the water problem and steps being taken to address the issue. ``Malaysians are very understanding people and there was no need for the police to revoke the permit. ``When you have a discourse like this, all parties will gain,'' he said. Joseph said by withdrawing the permit, the people could not rule out the possibility that the authorities were trying to ``hide something''. Kajang Jaya residents Association secretary K. Ratnam said the forum should have been used to explain to the people the reasons for the problem. ``Some of the residents here find it rather amusing as to why there is a sudden water shortage in certain parts of the country.'' Ratnam said all parties could have used the forum to their advantage.

LEAVING a bank after a 10-year tenure as a treasury executive to set up her own image consultancy, was a drastic change for Mei Foo. Indeed, she left a secured position to set up a business which was alien to her. But her strong belief in giving her best in all that she does has pulled her through. ``It was a drastic change ... the job at the bank was demanding,'' she told Business Times. ``It was different ... the new job required a lot of my time and effort. ``I had to do everything on my own. For the first six months, I did everything single-handedly ... answering the phone, cleaning the shop and servicing the clients,'' Foo said. She said when people found out that she wanted to leave the bank to start a beauty shop, she was discouraged from doing so. ``They thought it was a `peanut' business,'' she added. Foo, who is the managing director and image consultant of IEM Studio de Beaute, had never been involved with the beauty industry. ``When I was a treasury executive in a financial institution, I had to entertain corporate clients and met many people. ``Two of them happened to be from Lancome and Christian Dior. The turning point came in 1990 when I was approached by both Lancome and Christian Dior to start my own business. ``I could not leave immediately because of the gratuity I had to pay the company if I left but after two years, I decided to leave,'' Foo said. She decided to work with Lancome and operate an exclusive Lancome studio. After spending six months in London and Paris, training under Ms Anne-Marie Jouvensal, director of Lancome's Training Centre in Paris, Foo returned home to open up her own shop. Her first studio was located at City Square in Jalan Ampang. She opened the shop with a capital of RM50,000. Then she moved to Faber Towers. Three years ago, she moved into her own premise at Taman Desa in Jalan Klang Lama. Renovation cost her RM250,000 for the beauty salon and another RM400,000 for the hair salon. IEM Studio de Beaute, which is now a private company with shareholders, offers multi-sensorial facial programme, bridal make-up, day and night make up, manicure/pedicure, and reflexology. The multi-sensorial treatment programme is only available in a handful of salons. Foo believes women have to invest in themselves to feel and look good. ``For example, even if the economy is not so good, we still have to invest in ourselves. This will enhance our self-confidence and well-being. ``In fact, due to the economic slowdown and water problems, more people frequent the shop because they want to maintain their looks,'' she said. A member of the British Association of Beauty Therapy and Cosmetology, Foo said that her studio at Taman Desa offers grooming sessions for financial institutions. She has already organised workshops and practical sessions for Arthur Andersen and Hongkong Bank. Her business bloomed by word of mouth. Her clients keep coming back and often bring new customers with them. ``This has to do a lot with the service at IEM. We have done well in terms of quality service. Besides that, we update our techniques and ensure that the environment at our shop is comfortable,'' Foo emphasised.

Chernobyl official says sarcophagus continues to deteriorate
KIEV, Ukraine (AP) _ The concrete shell covering the ruined nuclear reactor at Chernobyl is deteriorating and there is not enough money to even start repairs, a plant official said Friday. The dlrs 150,000 the government has provided so far this year is not enough to even check for radiation leaks or determine what is happening to the tons of radioactive dust and other material under the shell, said Chernobyl deputy director Valentyn Kupny. Kupny is responsible for the sarcophagus that was hastily built over reactor No. 4 after it exploded in April 1986 in the world's worst nuclear accident. The shell continues to ``deteriorate,'' he told the Interfax news agency. Ukraine secured a dlrs 120 million grant from the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development last month for repairing the sarcophagus. But there was no announcement as to when the funds would be disbursed. The total cost of the required repairs to the sarcophagus is estimated at dlrs 750 million, of which Western nations have so far contributed dlrs 387.5 million. Ukraine has pledged to shut Chernobyl by 2000, but wants dlrs 1.2 billion first to complete two new nuclear reactors. (vl/sms/ls)

LONDON (AP) _ England Coach Glenn Hoddle held a closed-door meeting Friday with striker Teddy Sheringham after front-page photos in several newspapers showed him in a Portuguese night club with a cigarette in his mouth and his arm around a young woman. The accompanying stories said Sheringham _ one of England's top players _ spent two straight nights in the club on the southern Algarve coast drinking and dancing with witnesses saying he was wobbly and staggering at 6:45 a.m. Hoddle had told his players they were to spend three days at home between breaking training camp in Spain earlier this week and assembling in England on Friday. The Sun said Sheringham followed the woman pictured in the front page photographs into the women's toilet ``and made a pass'' at her. The woman confirmed the incident. ``Glenn Hoddle has spoken to Teddy Sheringham now that England's World Cup squad is together again,'' F.A. spokesman David Davies said Friday after the club reconvened. ``He is establishing all the facts of the situation that was reported in some of today's newspapers. ``The players have trained this afternoon as part of their preparations for France. Glenn and Teddy will speak again tomorrow before any further comment is made.'' On Sunday, Hoddle dropped midfielder Paul Gascoigne from the 22-man team, saying he was out of shape. Gascoigne admitted at the time he had been drunk the night before at a team party. Meanwhile, one of England's greatest players _ Sir Bobby Charlton _ ripped Sheringham. ``I am really disappointed about Teddy and I hope he feels suitably embarrassed,'' said Charlton, a director at Sheringham's Manchester United team. ``He has been given the responsibility of being one of our 22 players for the World Cup but is just not acting his age. ``Any foreign media watching what has happened here in the last couple of weeks, what with this and the Paul Gascoigne saga, would say forget about England's chances in France because they don't even have any self-discipline.'' ``Players should realize the World Cup is so important that you cannot do anything in the few weeks leading up to the World Cup because the media are picking up everything you do. ``You are the focus of the whole country and if the players don't have the common sense to behave themselves and act in a reasonable manner it is absolutely nonsensical to think we have a chance of winning it.'' SHARES on the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange (KLSE) closed easier yesterday on selling of selected blue-chip counters. The market had earlier in the morning extended its uptrend as sentiment was encouraged by the country's positive trade surplus of RM12.4 billion from January to April this year, on the back of an increase of 43 per cent in exports. Gains were later erased when the market reacted cautiously to the announcement on funding for Asset Management Company (AMC) set up to manage non-performing loans (NPL). Volume will remain thin and any rebound on the bourse is expected to be transient on worries on the shrinking local and regional economies, analysts added. The KLCI was down 7.75 points to 518.61 compared with Wednesday's close of 526.36. The KLSE's Second Board dipped 0.92-point lower at 110.27 while the broader-based Emas Index slipped 1.63 points to close at 132.85. The scoreboard showed losers outpacing gainers 354 to 187 with 161 counters remaining unchanged. The broad-based BT Ordinaries closed 1.62 points lower to 125.97 while the 30-share New Straits Industrial Index lost 9.20 points to close at 3,041.76. On the KLSE yesterday total turnover was lower amounting to 98.413 million shares valued at RM241.104 billion yesterday compared with 126.150 million shares valued at RM267.512 billion previously. Lead products recycling company, Metal Reclamation made its debut on the KLSE Second Board at RM2.01 against its offer price of RM1.80 and ended the day at RM2.03 with 80 lots done. Maybank was the most active counter with 6.88 million shares, followed by Tenaga with 6.77 million and MBf Land with 4.18 million shares changing hands.

BC-Sports-Tennis-French Open-Women's Final
A ring and some memories added to women's final
By SALVATORE ZANCA Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ The ring dancing around her neck and the black outfit are signs it will be a special match for Monica Seles when she meets Arantxa Sanchez Vicario in the women's final Saturday. On May 14, Seles was at her father's side when he died in Sarasota, Fla., after a five-year battle with cancer. Now Seles is back in the final of the French Open, the tournament where she won her first Grand Slam title in 1990 with her father in the stands. After Seles beat Steffi Graf in the final eight years ago, Seles raced to the player's box and to her father, Karolj, who kissed the red tie he was wearing and handed it to his daughter. Now Seles is wearing another momento from her father, a ring that bounces around her neck on a chain as she hits the ball. She came to Paris to play in the French Open, her first tournament since her dad's death, because she couldn't bear staying in a house that holds memories of him in every corner. ``My dad just wanted me to do what I wanted to do. Tennis is one of the things that I love to do. He was the one who started me with it,'' Seles said. ``I miss him tremendously.'' Her father was with her when she won the title again in 1991 and 1992. But her career was interrupted when a crazed fan stabbed her during a match in Germany in 1993. Seles said it has been tough to concentrate on tennis since her return to competition in August 1995. ``When there's so many things going on outside your life it's difficult to keep my mind talking about life and things, then go on a tennis court and be really excited about hitting a ball,'' she said. She has had only patches of brilliance in the past two years, as her father's illness weighed on her. She missed this year's Australian Open, and advanced to the semifinals of only one of four tournaments this year before the French Open. At the French Open, though, Seles has seemed like her old dominating self. In the semifinals, she beat top-seeded Martina Hingis 6-3, 6-2. She credits new coach Gavin Hopper with changing her. Until shortly before his death, Karolj Seles was her only coach. ``Gavin has just helped me so much in my tennis game, my off-court game, just really mentally, too,'' Seles said. ``We just work very well together. We have the same goals, the same philosophy. He reminds me a lot of my dad, how he is with his two daughters.'' Seles is 14-2 against Sanchez Vicario, including a 6-3, 6-4 win in the 1991 French Open final. But Seles quickly points to the last time they played, at the WTA Championships in November, when Sanchez Vicario won in three sets. Sanchez Vicario advanced to Saturday's final with a victory over an error-plagued Lindsay Davenport. ``I knew we were both very nervous, but I did probably handled it better at the end. I was able to get the ball into the court and she made some mistakes,'' Sanchez Vicario said. Sanchez Vicario won the French title in 1989 and 1994. When she shocked Graf in 1989, the German's only Grand Slam loss between 1988 and 1989, the Spaniard was the youngest woman to win a major title at 17 years, five months. Seles eclipsed that the following year, winning the French Open title at 16 1/2. (sz/rg)

EDARAN Otomobil Nasional Bhd (EON) expects the current economic environment to be a temporary setback to the group's passenger car division as the business is highly resilient. In his annual statement, chairman Datuk Wira Mohd Saleh Sulong says although the Malaysian Motor Traders Association expects passenger cars to plunge by almost 60 per cent to 130,000 units for 1998, there are indications that the market will pick up in the coming months. He points out that ``in the motor business, our marquee is well established and needs no introduction as EON has the most extensive and modern sales network'', adding that this inherent strength will put EON in good stead to face the challenges ahead. Saleh says the EON group, being one of the largest conglomerates in the country, has the staying power to weather the economic downturn. On the group's other core business, he says government measures to regulate loan growth in the banking industry are expected to slow down growth in the group's banking and financial services sector. He also points out that on February 18 this year, there was a memorandum of understanding (MOU) between subsidiary EON Finance Bhd, Credit Corp (Malaysia) Bhd and Suria Mahsuri Sdn Bhd (Mahsuri) in relation to the proposed merger of the two finance companies; while on March 26, MOUs were signed between Mahsuri and the respective shareholders of Cempaka Finance Bhd and City Finance Bhd for the proposed acquisition of a 100 per cent equity stake in both the companies. Mahsuri has also signed a MOU with Safuan Group Bhd for the proposed acquisition of a 95.15 per cent equity interest in Perkasa Finance Bhd. Meanwhile for the year ended December 31 1997, EON's group pre-tax profit shed 4.9 per cent to RM669.66 million from RM704.05 million in the previous corresponding period. The drop in profit was attributed to the decline in pre-tax earnings of the group's motor operations to RM566.1 million from RM585.2 million previously and to the lower pre-tax profits recorded by EON's banking and financial services sector. Pre-tax profits of RM72.1 million registered by this sector during the year under review was 23.1 per cent lower than in 1996, as the EON Bank Group had to comply with the revised Bank Negara guidelines on loan provisions in the face of the prevailing economic conditions, Saleh says. The group's turnover for the year, however, rose 1.5 per cent to RM7.39 billion from RM7.28 billion the last time around. After-tax profit for the year dropped to RM442.87 million from RM476.03 million previously. Profit attributable to shareholders fell 5.5 per cent to RM429.20 million in 1997 against RM454.43 million recorded a year earlier. Accordingly, earnings per share fell to 1.89 sen from 2.01 sen the last time around. Directors have recommended a final dividend of 30 sen per share less tax to be paid on June 25, together with an interim dividend of 15 sen per share less tax which was paid on October 23 last year.

BC-Sports-Soccer-Norway-First Practice,0567
World Cup: Norwegians happy with first workout
By STEPHAN NASSTROM AP Sports Writer
LA BAULE, France (AP) _ High intensity and superb team spirit. With only one player not fully fit, Norway's World Cup squad staged its first training session Friday on a pitch surrounded by police and media. ``I've seen better practices by our team, but I also saw some that were a lot worse,'' Norwegian coach Egil ``Drillo'' Olsen said later after the 90-minute session during the ``Open House'' held at the team hotel. ``On a scale from one to 10, this was an eight or a nine when it comes to the quality of practice.'' Goalkeeper Frode Grodaas of Tottenham, one of the squad's 11 players based in England, agreed. ``It was a very good workout,'' he said. ``The atomosphere was very good. The team spirit is one of the biggest strengths on this side.'' Olsen, whose team has fellow World Cup sides Denmark, Mexico and Saudi Arabia by a combined 13-2 in its final World Cup exhibitions, arrived a day late to its training camp near Nantes. He watched Morocco, Norway's first Group A opponent, play Chile at a 1-1 draw Thursday in another exhibition in southern France. ``Morocco did not play well,'' Olsen said. ``Yet I think they were better than Chile.'' ``There are no easy matches in the World Cup, but I think we have a good schedule. If I had the chance to choose, I would never have picked Brazil in the opening game.'' Brazil, the defending champion, is Norway's last opponent. The other is Scotland. Norway is one of the few teams without a loss against Brazil, the last a stunning 4-2 victory in Oslo last year over Ronaldo and company. The other match, also played in Norway, ended 1-1 in 1988. Olsen said the loss of Romario _ the 32-year-old hero of the 1994 Cup who was cut from the team on Tuesday because of a calf injury _ probably wouldn't hurt the Brazilians that much. ``I don't think it will mean so much,'' Olsen said. ``The Brazilians have so many good players. And Romario has not played so well lately.'' Norway didn't make the second round four years ago in only its second trip to the World Cup finals. But with 12 veterans returning and most of the players based abroad in some of Europe's top leagues _ only five on the 22-man squad play in Norway _ the experience from high-level competition is there. Few teams can boast a better record than Norway, which went unbeaten through the qualifying stage and has nine victories and five draws since its last loss early in 1997 at Australia. Some people in neighboring Sweden even suggested that the Swedes' bronze medal in the '94 Cup would be a bigger surprise than if Norway finishes third in this tournament. ``I'm not so sure about that,'' Olsen said. ``We don't have the same soccer tradition. After all, Sweden has more tradition in soccer than Norway. I think it would be a big, big surprise if we win the bronze medal. ``I don't think it's impossible, but to achieve it we have to be lucky in the early going. In a potential knockout situation, we're very good and can beat any team in the world.'' Oyvind Leonhardsen, a midfielder who plays for Liverpool, sustained a strained leg muscle injury recently but took part in Friday's practice session.

BC-South Africa-Botha Trial, 1st Ld-Writethru,0536
Tutu asks Botha to apologize
Eds: RECASTS, UPDATES with comments by Tutu, Botha. DOUBLE use of ``deep'' in 3rd graf is cq. No pickup AP Photos GEO101-102 By PAUL HARRIS Associated Press Writer
GEORGE, South Africa (AP) _ Desmond Tutu made a final bid to extract an apology from apartheid's last hard-line president on Friday, ending a week of courtroom drama over ultimate responsibility for atrocities under South African white rule. The Nobel Laureate and retired Anglican archbishop, who was for decades the moral spokesman against apartheid, asked former President P.W. Botha to apologize for the bombings and killings of black activists. ``The government that he headed caused many of our people deep deep anguish and suffering,'' Tutu said. ``Can he bring himself to say he's sorry?'' Botha sat stonefaced during Tutu's speech, as he has during most of the week that saw a simple contempt case turn into a moral inquest. Since apartheid ended with the first democratic elections in 1994, Botha has insisted he has nothing to apologize for. Botha, 82, is charged with ignoring three subpoenas to appear before the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, which is probing atrocities committed during white rule. But the case has focused on allegations that Botha and the shadowy State Security Council he headed coordinated a crackdown on anti-apartheid activists and directly ordered bombings and killings during the 1980s. Grilling Tutu, who heads the Truth Commission, defense lawyer Lappe Laubscher said there were no direct assassination orders in any of the council's minutes, indicating the killings were the work of ``bad apples'' in the police and army who misunderstood orders. An angry Tutu objected. ``How many 'bad apples' are you going to concede?'' he asked. ``No, no. We cannot now say that these are 'bad apples.' They are people who were sitting on the State Security Council.'' The case was adjourned until June 15, when both sides will summarize their findings. Botha faces a hefty fine or even two years in prison if convicted. Afterward, Botha had an animated and angry conversation with prosecutor Bruce Morrison out of hearing distance of reporters. He then turned to reporters, citing three books they should read to understand his point of view, including his biography, ``Voice from the Wilderness.'' He refused further comment. Prosecution witnesses, including police death squad commander Eugene de Kock, testified earlier this week that the council's use of phrases like eliminate'' and ``neutralize'' sanctioned the murder of the white-run state's opponents. Botha and other top members of the SSC claim the words meant opponents should be arrested. Botha has been implicated by testimony elsewhere by top police officials, who have claimed he gave direct orders for violent acts. After Botha's 11 years as head of state, his successor, President F.W. de Klerk, negotiated with the group that spearheaded the anti-apartheid struggle, President Nelson Mandela's African National Congress. The talks culminated in the 1994 elections won by the ANC.

World Cup: Denmark's third defeat in a row when Cameroon defeats
them 2-1 at home
COPENHAGEN, Denmark (AP) _ Francois Omam Biyick's headers Friday gave Cameroon a 2-1 win over Denmark, which continued its string of losses in World Cup preparatory matches. Biyick opened the score in the 15th minute when he headed a long ball over goalie Peter Schmeichel. Eight minutes later he turned in a second goal on a corner shot. ``We are ready for the World Cup ... or maybe not totally ready,'' Denmark's coach Bo Johansson said after the entertaining and high-pace game. ``We need to strengten the defense,'' he added. Cameroon, which met the Danes for the first time, controlled the first half and had several opportunities to increase the score. While the Danish forwards had numerous chances, their defense was weak and disorganized. Struggling hard before 40,564 stunned fans, the Danes failed to score due to a combination of a tight Cameroonian defense, a flying Jacques Songo'o in goal, and sheer bad luck. Peter Moeller who came in as a substitute for Michael Laudrup, shot twice on the post. But it wasn't until his third attempt in the 90th minute that he managed to head a low ball past Songo'o. Laudrup, one of Denmark's best players, bid farewell to his fans at home _ he will quit soccer after the World Cup, his second in 16 years on the team. Schmeichel, who played his 100th game for the Danish side, was substituted in the second half because of a minor injury. He was replaced by Mogens Krogh. It was Denmark's third consecutive loss before flying to France. In the past two months, they lost 0-2 to Sweden and 0-2 to Norway. Jamaicans looking for quiet weekend
KINGSTON, Jamaica (AP) _ Police say it will be a quiet weekend in Jamaica. And if not, they'll hand out fines. A new Noise Abatement Act takes effect this weekend. Discos will have to turn down the volume, bars will have to quiet down at 2 a.m. and playing a musical instrument in the street is also prohibited within 100 meters (330 feet) of a home, hotel, hospital or other places where someone might be trying to get some sleep. Police say they are serious about enforcing the law and have set up a special phone lines so residents can call in with complaints. Special teams of police and soldiers will be patrolling. ``The drive will continue indefinitely,'' the Police Information Center said in a written statement. The new rules apply from 2 a.m. to 6 a.m. on weekends and from midnight to 6 a.m. the rest of the week. Penalties include fines of dlrs 20,000 Jamaica (dlrs 571 U.S.) to dlrs 50,000 Jamaica (dlrs 1,428 U.S.) and six to 12 months in jail.

Japanese military chief visits Far Eastern port
Eds: ADDS new penultimate graf with Russia to comment on Kuril Islands proposal.
MOSCOW (AP) _ The navies of Russia, Japan and the United States could in the future hold joint rescue and salvage exercises, the chairman of Japan's Joint Chiefs of Staff predicted Friday. Adm. Kazuya Natsukawa spoke in the Far Eastern port of Vladivostok, the main base of Russia's Pacific Fleet and the last stop on his eight-day trip to boost military cooperation. President Boris Yeltsin and Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto pledged last fall to increase military contacts as part of effort to conclude a peace treaty by 2000. Natsukawa said plans are already in the works for the first Russian-Japanese naval exercises, to be held in July. The Russian and U.S. navies have previously held joint exercises, and Natsukawa predicted the three countries could train together some time, the ITAR-Tass news agency said. In Vladivostok, Natsukawa was to meet with regional officials and visit the Admiral Vinogradov anti-submarine ship. On Saturday, he is scheduled to lay a wreath at the Pacific Fleet Combat Glory memorial to Russian victims of two wars fought against Japan this century. Russia and Japan have never signed a peace treaty formally ending World War II because of a dispute over four islands in the Kuril chain seized by Soviet troops at the end of the war. Russia will make a ``preliminary comment'' on Japanese proposals on the Kuril Islands dispute next month, Deputy Foreign Minister Grigory Karasin told the Interfax news agency. Japanese media say Tokyo proposes taking over the islands legally, but allowing Russian to retain control for some time. Natsukawa is scheduled to return to Japan on Sunday. (vi/mr/ls)

Pantani stays ahead while Fagnini wins 20th Giro stage
EDs: UPDATES with details, quotes
MENDRISIO, Switzerland (AP) _ Marco Pantani held onto his lead Friday in the Tour of Italy while fellow Italian Gian Matteo Fagnini clinched his first stage victory. Close on Pantani's heels, 1 minute, 28 seconds behind, is Russia's Pavel Tonkov, the 1996 Giro winner. The two rode together slightly behind the lead pack Friday to save energy for Saturday's 34-kilometer (21-mile) individual time trial. Tonkov is expected to defeat Pantani, who is a climbing specialist, in the time trial, and victory will come down to the final seconds. ``We are both already thinking of tomorrow's race which will be decisive,'' Pantani said. ``I am sure Tonkov will do all he can to win so it will be tough.'' In a slightly longer time trial last week, Tonkov beat Pantani by just over two minutes. However, both racers are now fatigued from 20 days of riding and Saturday is expected to be another scorching hot day. The 22-stage Giro ends Sunday in Milan. Fagnini won the day's stage -- 137 kilometers (85 miles) from Boario Terme, Italy, to Mendrisio, Switzerland -- in three hours, 31 minutes and 29 seconds. Fagnini pulled ahead in the final meters (yards) of the race with a powerful sprint, finishing just a bicycle-length ahead of the lead pack. Pantani, 28, who was sidelined for the entire 1996 season with a broken leg, took over the leader's pink jersey from Switzerland's Alex Zuelle during a mountain stage Tuesday and has held onto it ever since. ``The fact that I am the one wearing the pink jersey will certainly help me psychologically,'' Pantani said. ``But we'll just have to wait for tomorrow's verdict.'' NEW YORK (AP) _ Henry Akinwande has tested positive for hepatitis B and was ruled ineligible to fight heavyweight champion Evander Holyfield on Saturday. The finding came in two separate medical tests conducted by the New York State Athletic Commission, said Greg Fritz, a spokesman for Don King Productions, the promoter of the fight. ``The fight is off,'' Fritz said Friday. The commission does not allow infected boxers to fight because of the risk of transmitting the disease through blood during bouts. Hepatitis B and C cause serious liver problems. Heavyweight Ray Mercer, who was to fight on the undercard against Jerry Ballard, also was suspended for medical reasons, said Ralph Petrillo, medical coordinator for the athletic commission. Petrillo said Akinwande was under a medical suspension, but he declined to elaborate. They were the second and third medical suspensions to hit Saturday's card. On Friday, Mexican lightweight Maria de las Nieves Garcia was scratched from her undercard bout with Christy Martin because tests showed she was pregnant. Melissa Salamore was to have replaced Garcia, but Martin rejected her as an opponent and promoters were trying to find someone else to replace her. The Akinwande decision is yet another blow to his career. He was disqualified during a bout against WBC champ Lennox Lewis in July for repeated holding. That Akinwande was fighting for a piece of the title for the second time in less than a year was due more to his choice of promoter than anything else. Duran, like Akinwande, hardly earned his title shot, winning a decision in Panama in his last fight after getting knocked down in the first round.

BC-Spain-Garcia Lorca,0458
Federico Garcia Lorca: small-town poet with worldwide following
By MAR ROMAN Associated Press Writer
FUENTEVAQUEROS, Spain (AP) _ A torrential rain fell Friday over the white-painted village where 100 years ago Spain's most-translated poet Federico Garcia Lorca was born. The outdoor centennial gala was suspended, but the village has long remembered its most famous son without the need of official extravaganzas. ``Federico is like one of the family,'' said Celia Ramos, who has a portrait of Lorca hanging in her living room. The villagers claim a personal link to Lorca, who was killed in 1936 by Gen. Francisco Franco's Nationalist troops during the opening days of the Spanish Civil War. Here he is known simply as Federico. ``Federico was an excellent person with a very good sense of humor, although he was also a clumsy and rather fearful child,'' recalled Ramos, 58, repeating the words of her aunt and his nanny, Carmen Ramos. Like the majority of the 4,000 villagers, Ramos can recite some of Lorca's poems by heart. She has read little of his work. ``Because of Franco we didn't know about the great talent of Federico,'' said Amparo Garcia, 82, a distant relative, ``The foreigners who came to the town knew more than we did''. Relegated to the cultural shadows during Franco's 40-year regime, the first anniversary was not celebrated in Fuentevaqueros until 1976, a year after the dictator died. Residents recall police watching from the rooftops as the crowd wept when one of the poet's nephews shouted ``Federico lives! He is still with us.'' The Spanish cultural mainstream no longer fears the poet's compassion for the poor, and 1998 has been designated ``Lorca year.'' New and reprinted biographies fill the stores, while Lorca's plays dominate the country's theater programs. A member of the artistic vanguard _ a friend of surrealist painter Salvador Dali and filmmaker Luis Bunuel _ Lorca was fascinated by love, death, motherhood, cruelty, violence, simple humanity and sexuality. Lorca's own homosexuality, outcried by the Franco, is still controversial today among the villagers. ``I don't believe it'' said Ramos. Lorca frequently returned to Fuentevaqueros for inspiration and refuge, and on Friday, surviving relatives and friends gathered in the village surrounded by tobacco fields and orchards. His sister Isabel sent a telegram to the mayor apologizing for her absence caused by ``the emotion.'' Celebrations to mark the 100th anniversary of his death, 38 years from now, threaten to be even more emotional although less easy to organize. The exact date and place of his murder are still a mystery.

BC-UN-Iraq, 1st Ld-Writethru,0598
UN inspectors seek to rally Security Council support
Eds: LEADS to UPDATE with Iraq agreeing to work with UNSCOM but rejects ``road map,'' TRIMS By ROBERT H. REID Associated Press Writer
UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ Iraq agreed Friday to work with U.N. arms inspectors ``to finalize work quickly'' and end sanctions but rejected a ``road map'' of disarmanent steps which the chief inspector will carry to Baghdad next week. Chief inspector Richard Butler travels to Iraq next week to spell out specific measures Iraq must take so the U.N. Special Commission can certify that Iraq is free of illegal weapons. That is the main condition for the Security Council to lift sanctions imposed in 1990 after President Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait, touching off the Gulf War. Following a two-day briefing to the council, Butler said Thursday that experts have nearly accounted for all Iraqi chemical artillery shells but ``fairly large gaps'' remain in other weapons areas. He said he was taking along a ``road map'' of specific measures. They include release of documents pertaining to Iraq's long-range missiles as well as chemical and biological weapons production. During a press conference, Iraq's foreign minister, Mohammed Saeed al-Sahhaf, said Baghdad was prepared to work with the commission and the Security Council based on a ``professional, scientific and technical approach which confines itself to the requirements of disarmanent.'' But he said the inspectors ``keep insisting on the same `non-starter' approach of casting doubts, building their understanding on assumptions, suspicions and not on facts and figures,'' al-Sahhaf said. Iraq claims it has destroyed all illegal weapons but that the United States and Britain are manipulating the commission to maintain sanctions indefinitely. Al-Sahhaf's remarks indicate the Iraqis still insist that the inspectors should simply verify what Baghdad has already disclosed about its weapons programs, accepting Iraqi declarations as fact. The inspectors claim they have the authority to conduct more far-reaching inspections and not simply base their estimates of Iraqi capabilities on information Baghdad has supplied. ``A `road map' is something that shows the way from `Point A' to `Point B,''' said an Iraqi source on condition of anonymity. ``We say we are already at `Point B.''' That raises doubts whether the Iraqis will be prepared to provide new documentation when they meet Butler in Baghdad on June 13-14. ``It's really just an excuse to ask for a new slogan, that of access to documents,'' Amir al-Saadi, an Iraqi presidential adviser. ``All the documents relevant to disarmanent have been provided.'' Butler's two-day briefing to the council was aimed at easing pressure from France, Russia and China to justify his claims that Iraq may still be holding illegal weapons. U.S. Ambassador Bill Richardson said Butler's briefing proved that ``Iraq is deceiving ... the Security Council'' and ``this must stop if it expects to get sanctions lifted.'' U.N. sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the briefing was part of a ``power struggle'' within the council between the Americans and Britons _ who have been strongly critical of Iraq _ and the Russians, French and Chinese who have been sympathetic to Baghdad's position. Those five countries are permanent council members and have strongly entrenched positions regarding Iraq. Each faction is trying to win support among the 10 non-permanent members.

BC-EU-Euro,0505
Mixed reactions from euro ministers on deficit-reduction proposal
By PAUL AMES Associated Press Writer
LUXEMBOURG (AP) _ European Union finance ministers gave a mixed reaction Friday to a proposal for them to use the benefits of Europe's quickening economic recovery to finance further cuts in budget deficits. EU Finance Commissioner Yves-Thibault de Silguy made the call Thursday for the 11 nations that adopt the euro as their common currency on Jan. 1 to set an average deficit target of 2 percent of gross domestic product this year, and 1.5 percent in 1999. ``We have to take advantage of the favorable economic situation,'' de Silguy told reporters Friday. ``We are in a period of sustained growth in Europe ... don't relax the efforts to reduce public deficits.'' The 11 euro group ministers said they needed more time to digest the proposals and would look at them again in July. But as they met Friday with ministers from the four EU nations staying outside the euro-zone, reactions were luke warm. ``There is no room for maneuver,'' said French Finance Minister Dominique Strauss-Kahn. ``There is no change in the (French deficit) forecast.'' German Finance Minister Theo Waigel said de Silguy's proposal was ``very positive,'' but Germany officials said they had no plans to reduce the deficit from the 2.2 percent forecast for 1998 and the 2 percent expected next year. Belgian, Italian and Spanish ministers said their deficits could well be below current forecasts. But Belgian Finance Minister Philippe Maystadt insisted the EU's executive Commission could not expect them to use extra revenue coming from increased growth only for deficit reductions. He suggested instead that the money could go on promoting job-creation by reducing labor charges. Many EU nations made great efforts to get their deficit-to-GDP ratios below the 3 percent necessary for entry into the euro currency bloc and are already committed to still lower deficits. Figures released Thursday showed the EU's largest economies, Germany and France, picking up steam after prolonged slowdown. Germany's first-quarter growth was 3.8 percent on last year, the best performance since reunification in 1990. French first-quarter growth was up 3.5 percent. Other euro-group nations such as Ireland, Portugal and the Netherlands are doing even better. With results like that, de Silguy said deficits could be cut without further belt-tightening. There was a further blow for de Silguy when ministers approved a much diluted version of guidelines the Commission drew up for EU economic policies in 1999. ``I'm disappointed,'' de Silguy told reporters. ``The text is not satisfactory.'' The guidelines will be formally adopted by EU leaders at their summit in Cardiff, Wales, later this month. They urge EU nations to follow sound finances, low inflation and modernization of labor markets, but governments took out much of the Commission's toughest language.

Eds: UPDATES in 24th graf with session ending. By JOCELYN NOVECK Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ A French judge on Friday brought together for the first time the main parties in the Diana investigation, in an effort to finally clarify the role of photographers in the crash. Grouped together were the photographers under investigation in the case; eight witnesses to the crash; Mohamed Al Fayed; Diana's mother, Frances Shand Kydd, and the parents of driver Henri Paul. They were accompanied by a platoon of lawyers. The crash in a Paris traffic tunnel last Aug. 31 killed Diana, her companion Dodi Fayed, and driver Paul. Tests showed Paul was drunk at the time. But was it merely a case of a drunk driver, or was there responsibility on the part of the paparazzi trailing Diana's Mercedes that night? Nine photographers and one press motorcyclist have been placed under investigation _ a step short of being formally charged. They have remained in legal limbo for almost a year, continuing their work. In what was seen as a last-ditch effort to clarify their roles, Stephan was questioning each photographer one by one. Lawyers and witnesses emerging from the courtroom described the process. The judge asked each photographer to give an account of their role that night. He then questioned them, questioned witnesses as to what they had seen of the photographer's behavior, and opened questions to other lawyers. According to lawyers, photographer Romuald Rat was harshly questioned by lawyers for Al Fayed, who tried to establish that he pursued the Mercedes that night. ``I followed it. I did not pursue it,'' Rat responded. During an afternoon break, Al Fayed railed against the paparazzi. ``If I was not in a courtroom, I would hang them all,'' he said. ``The immorality, the inhumanity of what they did. They were like vultures around the bodies.'' Al Fayed also had harsh words for Diana's mother. ``She won't talk to me,'' he said. ``She thinks she's in the royal family. ``I'm just an ordinary guy, a working-class guy. It's snobbery.'' Mrs. Shand Kydd emerged from the courtroom during a break, but waved away journalists. She, Al Fayed, and Paul's family are civil parties in the case, meaning they have access to documents and proceedings. Ten witnesses were summoned, but only eight showed up. They included the first emergency doctor on the scene, Frederic Mailliez, and the first two policemen on the scene. ``It's so painstaking,'' Mailliez told The Associated Press of the meeting. ``It's thorough, but it's taking a long time.'' Lawyers said the policemen who spoke accused Rat of hindering their work. Another witness, private chauffeur Clifford Gooroovadoo, said he'd told the judge he saw Rat and another photographer, Christian Martinez, fighting just after the accident. He said Rat, after taking his own pictures, was telling Martinez to stop. The photographers are being investigated on two charges: manslaughter, and failing to come to the aid of a person in danger. Many close to the case believe they will soon be exonerated, at least on the manslaughter charge. Nikolas Arsov, of the Sipa photo agency, said the hearing was inconvenient, but he understood the need for it. ``It's the 40th time we have answered the same questions,'' Arsov told The AP. ``It's annoying, but what can you do? They have to do their job.'' In contrast to previous hearings, all cameras were kept outside the Palais de Justice. The gates were heavily guarded by police. The nine-hour session, including a lunch break, ended early Friday evening. In the morning, Al Fayed drew up to the main courthouse in a Mercedes, surrounded by four other cars and about 10 bodyguards. It isn't just his son's death that connects Al Fayed to the case. Driver Paul was an employee of the Ritz Hotel, which Al Fayed owns. ``I hope that God will find the truth for us,'' he said as he left the Ritz in the morning. Although the probe is not complete, investigators long have believed it was Paul's drunken condition and the Mercedes' excessive speed that probably caused the crash. They also are still looking for a white Fiat Uno believed to have brushed the Mercedes before it crashed. But they are said to have given up any real hope of finding the Fiat. Tests are still being conducted on the wrecked Mercedes Diana was traveling in, but aren't likely to be finished before October _ meaning the case can't be closed until then. One person who wasn't attending Friday's session: bodyguard Trevor Rees-Jones, the sole survivor of the crash. He was invited on an ``informational basis,'' but decided not to come. (jn-dgs)

BC-UN-Kosovo,0428
Annan condemns Serb ``atrocities'' in Kosovo
By ROBERT H. REID Associated Press Writer
UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ In an unusually blunt statement, Secretary-General Kofi Annan accused Serb military and paramilitary forces of ``atrocities'' in Kosovo and demanded Friday that ``this kind of aggression'' be confronted ``immediately and with determination.'' The statement, read by U.N. spokesman Juan-Carlos Brandt, was unusual because it specifically accused Serb forces of atrocities in a military action within areas which the international community recognizes as part of the Serbian republic. The United Nations is often reluctant to level such accusations against sovereign governments for actions within their borders. ``The secretary-general is deeply disturbed by the latest reports of an intensifying campaign against the unarmed civilian population in Kosovo,'' Brandt said. ``He reiterates in the strongest possible terms his condemnation of the atrocities committed by Serbian military and paramilitary forces.'' He said those forces ``must not be allowed to repeat the campaign of ethnic cleansing and indiscriminate attacks on civilians that characterized the war in Bosnia.'' ``If the world has learned anything from that dire chapter in history, it is that this kind of aggression must be confronted immediately and with determination,'' the statement added. In the statement, Annan said he was ``encouraged by NATO's resolve'' to prevent a further escalation of the fighting and repeated his call for a negotiated settlement between Kosovo's ethnic Albanians and the government in Belgrade. Brandt said U.N. refugee officials in northern Albania report that the influx of refugees from Kosovo appears to be slowing. He said 400 people crossed the border into Albania by dawn Friday. Brandt also said the United Nations was investigating reports that Serb forces in Kosovo are using an armored personnel carrier stolen from Dutch U.N. troops during the Bosnian war. He did not say whether the United Nations had first-hand evidence to substantiate the reports. More than 250 people have died since March 1 in escalating clashes between government forces and the Kosovo Liberation Army, the armed wing of the Albanian independence movement. Ethnic Albanians and officials chosen by Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic, who stripped Kosovo of its broad autonomy in 1989, opened talks under Western pressure last month. Agreement appears unlikely.
