BC-Yugoslavia-Kosovo, 2nd Ld-Writethru
Kosovo Albanians talk of 50 deaths, destroyed villages
Ed: AMs; UPDATES with report of mass grave, new shortages; recasts and trims. By ISMET HAJDARI Associated Press Writer
PRISTINA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ The latest Serbian offensive in independence-minded Kosovo province produced reports on Friday of 50 dead, 200 missing, villages destroyed and a mass grave containing 300 bodies. Hundreds more joined the thousands who have already fled the fighting in the week since the offensive began, with most of them heading for neighboring Albania. Some of them didn't make it. In Geneva, the United Nations refugee agency said some of the 400 or so who trekked into neighboring Albania overnight had reported five deaths en route _ two elderly people, said to have died of exhaustion, and three small children. About 10,000 refugees are now gathered around Tropoja in northern Albania, produced by the largest exodus since ethnic tensions erupted into large-scale violence in March. Reports from Serb and Albanian sources were often conflicting and proved impossible to verify. Still, together, they reflected the intensity of the conflict as Serbian government forces tried by force to destroy the Kosovo Albanian drive to secede. Osman Cacaj, an official of the Democratic League of Kosovo, the ethnic Albanians' main party, listed more than 50 dead and some 200 missing from the latest offensive, concentrated around Decani, some 70 kilometers (45 miles) west of Kosovo's capital, Pristina. Four villages populated by ethnic Albanians were destroyed, another eight badly damaged, and 16 others deserted by fleeing residents, Cacaj added. The Beta news in Belgrade quoted unnamed refugees from Decani, as saying a mass grave on the outskirts of the Serb-besieged town contained 300 bodies. There were no details. The Kosovo Information Center, close to the Albanian leaders in the province, said one Albanian was killed and two wounded in fighting around Orahovac, some 40 kilometers (25 miles) southwest of Pristina. It said Serb shelling continued in the Decani area and around the town of Djakovica in Kosovo's southwest. The pro-Serb Media Center reported an Albanian woman wounded Friday, when an armed Albanian shot at a bus on the road running between Pec, in the west, and Kosovska Mitrovica in the northeast. Ethnic Albanians form 90 percent of Kosovo's 2 million people and demand independence from Serbia and the Yugoslav federation it forms with tiny Montenegro. Accounts are impossible to verify independently, as both Serbian police forces and gunmen from the Kosovo Liberation Army _ fighting for independence _ block adequate access to journalists and even humanitarian workers. Pristina-based human rights groups on Friday warned that food and medicines in some blocked off areas was extremely short and asked for international aid, Cacaj described the area around Decani as a deserted wasteland, with some 45 bodies left unburied, farm animals roaming wild and several thousand civilians hiding in the woods, trying to cross the border into neighboring Albania or to Montenegro, which with Serbia, forms Yugoslavia. There were conflicting reports of Serb casualties, with Cacaj saying three policemen trying to loot a house had been shot dead by its Albanian owner, and the Serb Media Center denying any officers were killed or wounded. More than 250 people have died since March 1 in escalating clashes between government forces and the Kosovo Liberation Army, the armed wing of the Albanian independence movement, which Albanian political leaders say acts independently from them. The clandestine KLA, which first surfaced in 1996, says the peaceful principles of the top Kosovo Albanian leader, Ibrahim Rugova, are futile. A delegation picked by Rugova and officials chosen by Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic, who stripped Kosovo of its broad autonomy in 1989, opened a dialogue under Western pressure last month. Agreement appears unlikely. The ethnic Albanians canceled a meeting scheduled Friday in Pristina, saying they could not talk with the Serbs while the latest offensive lasts. The Serbs showed up anyway for the talks, to which Christopher Hill, U.S. ambassador to neighboring Macedonia, is serving as unofficial mediator. Hill noted that it is ``extremely difficult'' to get a true picture of events around Decani. (pvs/jg/gj)

BC-Sports-Soccer-Dienst-Obit
World Cup: Referee who okayed England's go-ahead goal, dead at 78
BASEL, Switzerland (AP) _ Soccer referee Gottfried Dienst, who ruled in favor of England's controversial ``third goal'' in the 1966 World Cup victory over Germany, has died. He was 78. Dienst died Monday in the Basel, Switzerland, Cantonal Hospital, after a ``short and severe illness,'' said a family announcement in the Baseler Zeitung. He was buried Friday. The term ``Wembley goal'' is still used in soccer to describe a ball that hits the underside of the crossbar and ricochets down to the goal line. When Geoff Hurst's ball bounced back into play in the 11th minute of overtime, English players celebrated but the Germans ran to Soviet linesman Tofik Bakhramov to protest. Dienst backed the linesman and awarded the goal which put England ahead 3-2. Hurst went on to score again, gaining the only World Cup final hattrick and giving England a 4-2 win. Bakhramov died in Azerbaijan in 1993. Television replays and photographs strongly suggested the ball failed to completely cross the goal line. ``We can now say that it probably was not a goal,'' British soccer chronicler Philip Evans wrote in 1990. ``But to establish that fact, it took a lot of people many hours of very hard work in cinema laboratories all over the world.'' Dienst told an interviewer in 1989 that strangers still asked him almost daily about the decision. ``I gladly respond,'' he said. ``I still don't know if the shot by Hurst in the 100th minute was in or not. ``I have to say that I was standing in a poor position for that shot, exactly head-on instead of diagonal to the goal. I wouldn't have allowed the goal if linesman Bakhramov hadn't pointed to the middle with his flag.'' Dienst is survived by two daughters. (agh-rjm)

BASEL, Switzerland (AP) _ Soccer referee Gottfried Dienst, who ruled in favor of England's controversial ``third goal'' in the 1966 World Cup victory over Germany, has died. He was 78. Dienst died Monday in the Basel, Switzerland, Cantonal Hospital, after a ``short and severe illness,'' said a family announcement in the Baseler Zeitung. He was buried Friday. The term ``Wembley goal'' is still used in soccer to describe a ball that hits the underside of the crossbar and ricochets down to the goal line. When Geoff Hurst's ball bounced back into play in the 11th minute of overtime, English players celebrated but the Germans ran to Soviet linesman Tofik Bakhramov to protest. Dienst backed the linesman and awarded the goal which put England ahead 3-2. Hurst went on to score again, gaining the only World Cup final hattrick and giving England a 4-2 win. Bakhramov died in Azerbaijan in 1993. Television replays and photographs strongly suggested the ball failed to completely cross the goal line. ``We can now say that it probably was not a goal,'' British soccer chronicler Philip Evans wrote in 1990. ``But to establish that fact, it took a lot of people many hours of very hard work in cinema laboratories all over the world.'' Dienst told an interviewer in 1989 that strangers still asked him almost daily about the decision. ``I gladly respond,'' he said. ``I still don't know if the shot by Hurst in the 100th minute was in or not. ``I have to say that I was standing in a poor position for that shot, exactly head-on instead of diagonal to the goal. I wouldn't have allowed the goal if linesman Bakhramov hadn't pointed to the middle with his flag.'' Dienst is survived by two daughters. (agh-rjm)

BC-BRF--Virgin Islands-Judge,0181
Caribbean regional court to get chief justice in six months
ROAD TOWN, British Virgin Islands (AP) _ A new chief justice of the Eastern Caribbean Supreme Court will be chosen by a special committee within the next six months, several national leaders said. The post has been filled by acting Justice Denis Byron of St. Kitts and Nevis for nearly two years. The Organization of Eastern Caribbean States heads of government appointed a committee to fill the vacancy at their meeting here May 27-29. Antigua Prime Minister Lester Bird said afterwards that the committee would make a recommendation before the next meeting of the heads of state at the end of November. Bird said the long impasse on naming a new chief justice was due to the lack of a clear procedure for choosing a candidate. But British Virgin Islands Bar Association President Michael Riegels said he was ``surprised and appalled that the only step taken was to set up a committee which is not to report for another six months.''

The term ``Wembley goal'' is still used in soccer to describe a ball that hits the underside of the crossbar and ricochets down to the goal line. When Geoff Hurst's ball bounced back into play in the 11th minute of overtime, English players celebrated but the Germans ran to Soviet linesman Tofik Bakhramov to protest. Dienst backed the linesman and awarded the goal which put England ahead 3-2. Hurst went on to score again, gaining the only World Cup final hattrick and giving England a 4-2 win. Bakhramov died in Azerbaijan in 1993. Television replays and photographs strongly suggested the ball failed to completely cross the goal line. ``We can now say that it probably was not a goal,'' British soccer chronicler Philip Evans wrote in 1990. ``But to establish that fact, it took a lot of people many hours of very hard work in cinema laboratories all over the world.'' Dienst told an interviewer in 1989 that strangers still asked him almost daily about the decision. ``I gladly respond,'' he said. ``I still don't know if the shot by Hurst in the 100th minute was in or not. ``I have to say that I was standing in a poor position for that shot, exactly head-on instead of diagonal to the goal. I wouldn't have allowed the goal if linesman Bakhramov hadn't pointed to the middle with his flag.'' Dienst is survived by two daughters. (agh-rjm)

Dienst died Monday in the Basel, Switzerland, Cantonal Hospital, after a ``short and severe illness,'' said a family announcement in the Baseler Zeitung. He was buried Friday. The term ``Wembley goal'' is still used in soccer to describe a ball that hits the underside of the crossbar and ricochets down to the goal line. When Geoff Hurst's ball bounced back into play in the 11th minute of overtime, English players celebrated but the Germans ran to Soviet linesman Tofik Bakhramov to protest. Dienst backed the linesman and awarded the goal which put England ahead 3-2. Hurst went on to score again, gaining the only World Cup final hattrick and giving England a 4-2 win. Bakhramov died in Azerbaijan in 1993. Television replays and photographs strongly suggested the ball failed to completely cross the goal line. ``We can now say that it probably was not a goal,'' British soccer chronicler Philip Evans wrote in 1990. ``But to establish that fact, it took a lot of people many hours of very hard work in cinema laboratories all over the world.'' Dienst told an interviewer in 1989 that strangers still asked him almost daily about the decision. ``I gladly respond,'' he said. ``I still don't know if the shot by Hurst in the 100th minute was in or not. ``I have to say that I was standing in a poor position for that shot, exactly head-on instead of diagonal to the goal. I wouldn't have allowed the goal if linesman Bakhramov hadn't pointed to the middle with his flag.'' Dienst is survived by two daughters. (agh-rjm)

BC-Afghanistan-Fighting,0288
Three killed in rocket attack on Kabul
KABUL, Afghanistan (AP) _ Nine rockets slammed into Afghanistan's capital Friday, killing three children and wounding six other civilians, officials of the Taliban religious government said. In retaliation, the Taliban sent warplanes on bombing missions over towns and military positions in territory held by the opposition alliance, said the officials on condition of anonymity. Fighting also raged in the far north of Afghanistan, where Taliban forces were trying to seize part of the 15 percent of Afghanistan that remains in the hands of the opposition, the officials said. Some 100 soldiers were captured in the Baghdis province, along with heavy and light weapons. Reports of the fighting could not be independently confirmed, and alliance commanders could not be reached for comment. The attack on Kabul was one of the heaviest in recent months. The nearest front line is barely 12 miles away from the city _ well within rocket range of opposition soldiers. Until recently, the opposition attempted to hit only the airport to stop the Taliban jets' daily bombing raids. Kabul, a city of about 750,000, had been fairly peaceful since the Taliban ousted former military chief Ahmed Shah Massood in September 1996. Between 1992 and 1996, when the capital was ruled by Massood and then-Afghanistan President Burhanuddin Rabbani, it was under almost constant siege by rival Muslim groups. In the 85 percent of territory under its control, the Taliban has imposed rigid Islamic laws that ban women from working, forbid girls from attending school, and force men to grow beards and pray five times daily at the mosque.

LONDON (AP) _ The realities of global commerce caught up with a grand remnant of British glory Friday as Volkswagen AG won approval to buy Rolls-Royce Motor Cars, infuriating small English investors. ``Should I call it now a Rolls-wagen?'' incredulous shareholder Rodney Crowe asked at a meeting called by Vickers PLC, the engineering group that is selling Rolls-Royce to the Germans. Vickers, an engineering group almost thrown out of business by Rolls-Royce's losses in the last recession, said the sale was the best way forward for all concerned. Rolls-Royce is financially healthy now, but the Vickers chairman, Sir Colin Chandler, said it needs a strong owner with automotive expertise to steer through an increasingly globalized and highly competitive industry. Volkswagen, the biggest carmaker in Europe, is an ideal match, Chandler said. Rolls-Royce managers had considered a buyout, one of many proposals to keep Rolls-Royce British, but they could not afford enough capital investment to secure the company's future. ``We would love to remain British, but we have to stay realistic,'' Rolls-Royce chairman Graham Morris said. Volkswagen is driving to the top of the luxury car market by purchasing one of the great motoring traditions of the century. Rolls-Royce makes its Rolls-Royce and Bentley cars entirely by hand, selling them for prices that begin at around dlrs 250,000 each. The very idea of Rolls-Royce going German had some investors sounding like they wanted to replay World War II. ``For God's sake, try and take a broad view for the country,'' said Desmond Lake, drawing cheers by referring to Volkswagen's origins in Nazi Germany. After getting an earful, Volkswagen now faces more hurdles. The jilted suitor, BMW, said Friday it will terminate a contract for supplying some engines to Rolls-Royce. BMW wouldn't say how long its engines will stay in the pipeline. Volkswagen is addressing the matter by agreeing to buy the British auto engine maker Cosworth, also from Vickers, for 120 million pounds (dlrs 196 million). Volkswagen might run into further difficulties with Rolls-Royce PLC, a separate company making jet engines. Rolls-Royce PLC controls the Rolls-Royce brand name and logo and favored a deal with BMW, its partner in an aerospace venture. Rolls-Royce PLC wouldn't say Friday whether it will try to block Volkswagen's use of the brand name. Chandler, the Vickers chairman, said a 25-year-old contract allowing Rolls-Royce PLC to veto the purchase of Rolls-Royce Motors Cars Ltd. by a foreign buyer is unenforceable under current European law. ``The trademark can't go anywhere else,'' Chandler said. ``We exclusively own the radiator, the flying lady and Bentley.'' The takeover was delayed by a Rolls-Royce enthusiasts group, called Crewe Motors after the English town where Rolls-Royce is based. Lawyer Michael Shrimpton runs the group that wants to keep Rolls-Royce British, and he claimed he was assembling a 500 million pound (dlrs 815 million) offer from mysterious private backers. Shrimpton had already tried but failed to bid for Rolls-Royce. After the Vickers board adjourned the meeting to talk privately with Shrimpton, Chandler said the latest proposal had no substance. A great-nephew of Rolls-Royce co-founder Sir Henry Royce tried to stop the deal by nitpicking at the paperwork. ``There are so many mistakes in this document that I'm sure it's illegal,'' Peter Royce said, his voice bellowing with anger. ``I think it's a sad day,'' lamented investor Rodney Timson. ``Rolls-Royce represents British engineering excellence and it won't be ours after this. BC-Sports-Tennis-French Open, 3rd Ld-Writethru,
Moya, Corretja reach men's final
Eds: UPDATES with Corretja defeating Pioline By ROB GLOSTER AP Sports Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Alex Corretja wore down Cedric Pioline on a muggy center court Friday to join Carlos Moya in an all-Spanish men's final at the French Open. Corretja took advantage of Pioline's exhaustion to win their semifinal 6-3, 6-4, 6-2, ending Pioline's hopes of becoming the first Frenchman to win at Roland Garros since Yannick Noah in 1983. In 28-degree C (82-degree F) heat and smothering humidity, Corretja took the first set in 53 minutes. It took him 50 minutes to capture the second set, and he finished off the drained Pioline _ who had played three five-setters to reach the semifinals _ in just 38 minutes in the final set. In the third set, with both players putting icepacks on their necks during changeovers, Pioline made consecutive double faults to help give Corretja a service break in the second game. Pioline was broken again for 4-1, slamming his racket into his chair, and again in the final game. ``Cedric, today, I saw he was very tired. It was very difficult for him, but for me it was very good,'' Corretja said as he came off the court. Moya, overcoming a patient fellow Spaniard, defeated Felix Mantilla 5-7, 6-2, 6-4, 6-2 in the other semifinal. Moya mixed his powerful groundstrokes with delicate drop shots to throw off Mantilla, who preferred to rally patiently from the baseline. The Spaniards split the first two sets and Mantilla took a 4-1 lead in the third set. But Moya won the next five games, losing just five points during that span, to take control of the match. ``I just decided to take more risks than I was taking before,'' Moya said. ``I decided there had to be a change, otherwise that set was for him. Two set to one down, it's tough to come back.'' Moya got to match point with a 127-mph serve that handcuffed Mantilla, then hit a 122-mph service winner to finish off the 2-hour, 42-minute match. On Thursday, Monica Seles advanced to the French Open final for the first time since 1992 and won for the first time against Martina Hingis, yet showed none of the giddy enthusiasm she had as a teen-ager. Though Seles flashed a big smile after her 6-3, 6-2 victory in the semifinals of the event she won three straight times in the early 1990s, her success was tempered by playing in her first tournament since her father died of cancer on May 14. ``I do feel happy. I mean, it's really great. But I've tried to keep a sense of balance,'' said Seles, who pumped her fist in triumph after Thursday's win over the world's top-ranked woman. ``I'm still going to be missing people. Some things in my life are not going to be better.'' She'll face Arantxa Sanchez Vicario in Saturday's final. Sanchez Vicario celebrated her 6-3, 7-6 (7-5) win over second-seeded Lindsay Davenport by blowing a kiss to her Yorkshire terrier in the VIP box. Seles is 14-2 against Sanchez Vicario, a two-time French Open champion. Seles is wearing her father's ring on a chain around her neck and has worn black throughout the French Open. Although the outfit was chosen before her father's death, she said the color is fitting. ``I'm really glad it's not a bright color, because it just feels more appropriate,'' Seles said. ``I try to give respect to Dad.'' Seles, who slammed two-handed winners within inches of the lines, lost all five previous matches against Hingis _ including a loss in the semifinals here last year. Hingis was overpowering in her run to the semifinals, not losing a set in the tournament and having little trouble with eighth-seeded Venus Williams in the quarterfinals. But the sixth-seeded Seles was in control throughout, moving Hingis all over the court with shots that skimmed just over the net. ``She just hits everything very hard and very aggressively from every place on the court,'' Hingis said. ``Usually she makes more mistakes or she gets a little bit tired, but today she just didn't.'' Seles was the aggressor from the start, showing her intensity by walking back on court first after every changeover. Hingis, normally composed, scolded herself and bounced her racket on the clay in frustration. ``I knew I had to come out and be really aggressive,'' Seles said. ``I knew I had that in me. I wasn't sure if I could do that today, but I really believed I could.'' Hingis won every Grand Slam tournament title last year except the French Open, losing in the final to Iva Majoli. She said Seles, who at 24 is seven years older than Hingis, ran her to exhaustion. ``I was probably getting a little bit tired. She just made me run, and she didn't make any mistakes,'' Hingis said. ``I guess she surprised everybody. ``I mean, she was around for quite a while, then all of a sudden she was gone for years,'' Hingis added. ``And here she is back, in better shape and probably better than ever.'' Seles was 17 when she won her first Grand Slam tournament title at the 1990 French Open, the first of three straight championships at Roland Garros. She ruled women's tennis in those years, her victories punctuated with high-pitched grunts. Off the court, she was a teen-ager with an infectious giggle. But all that changed in April 1993, when a spectator came out of the stands at a tournament in Hamburg, Germany, and stabbed her in the back. Seles didn't return to the tennis tour until August 1995, and even then she was subdued and emotionally strained. The last two years have been even tougher because of the failing health of her father, Karolj, who until shortly before his death was her only coach. She was at his side in Sarasota, Fla., when he died. ``Obviously, the last five years have been very difficult in terms of walking on the court, while before I only had to worry about winning or losing the tennis match,'' she said. ``It's not the same as it was before the stabbing. It never will be, and I don't want it to be.''

Belarus has made fewer market reforms than probably any other former Soviet republic, with most factories and businesses remaining under state control. UNITA _ a Portuguese acronym for the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola _ fought a two-decade civil war against the government following the southwest African nation's 1975 independence from Portugal. Since then, the U.N. has slapped sanctions on UNITA in an attempt to push it into compliance with the redrawn peace accord. EU-wide savings tax proposal divides ministers
LUXEMBOURG (AP) _ European Union finance ministers were divided Friday over plans to introduce an EU-wide tax on savings to prevent cross-border tax dodging. German Finance Minister Theo Waigal said the tax was essential to stop citizens hording their savings in low-tax accounts in other EU nations. Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown pledged to oppose the tax as a threat to national interests. The EU's executive Commission proposed an EU-wide tax of 20 percent on interest gained on savings accounts. The proposal was largely in reply to concerns from Germany, Austria, Belgium and others that citizens are evading taxes by keeping savings in other EU nations where there are low or no taxes on interest. Those countries, principally Luxembourg and Britain, are determined to resist such a proposal, fearing it will damage their financial sectors. ``We are not prepared to lose business as a result of these proposals,'' Brown said. ``We will not allow that to happen.'' Opponents of the taxes would seem to have the upper hand since, under EU rules, taxation is usually left up to national governments and EU-wide measures must be agreed unanimously by all 15 member nations. However, Waigel said Austria, which takes over the rotating presidency of the EU from Britain on July 1 and Germany, which follows Austria on Jan. 1, were determined to see the measure adopted. If not, the Germans and their supporters fear more money will flow out of the reach of their tax collectors after the introduction of a single currency, the euro, in 11 of the EU nations on Jan. 1.

PARIS (AP) _ The legal fight over World Cup tickets was settled Friday _ at least until the end of the tournament _ when the Tribunal de Grande Instance threw out a challenge from 32 European parliamentarians who claimed the sale unfairly favored the French. It noted that the largest part of the tickets was reserved for French citizens and groups and businesses, and that often a French address was needed. ``The distribution system is likely to affect the rights of the ensemble of citizens of the (European) Union,'' the court said. BC-Germany-Train Derails-Relatives
Long wait for answers fraying nerves in small town
BC-German-Train Derails By TONY CZUCZKA Associated Press Writer
ESCHEDE, Germany (AP) _ Edward Koenig knows his mother was supposed to travel by train to Hamburg on Wednesday and that she never arrived. Two days after a high-speed train derailed and slammed into a concrete overpass, killing at least 96 people, he still could only fear the worst. The severity of the disaster has made identifying victims a painstaking process involving forensic dentists, doctors, fingerprint experts and photographers. Some bodies and remains are so badly mangled that DNA tests will have to be ordered, a spokesman at the Hanover medical school hospital, Christian Jung, said Friday. The slow pace of identifying victims of the disaster, the worst to strike Germany's prized rail system since World War II, has amplified the distress of relatives anxious to know the fate of loved ones. In many instances, family members only suspect their relatives boarded InterCity Express 884 somewhere between Munich and Hanover. Unlike in an airline disaster, there are no passenger lists. People may buy a ticket on board, so the number of passengers who need to be accounted for cannot be determined. Koenig traveled 350 kilometers (210 miles) from his home in the Bavarian city of Nuremberg to Eschede early Thursday. With hopes that his 67-year-old mother survived rapidly diminishing, Koenig has been pressing authorities to allow him to view bodies to speed identification. But officials have refused, citing the mangled condition of many of the victims. They also have refused to release personal belongings that would place individuals on the train. Koenig said relatives of victims should have the choice of whether to view the gruesome remains, adding: ``It's up to me how I want to deal with my grief.'' The bearded, trim school teachers said he and the handful of other relatives staying in the town have received enormous support from residents, grief counselors and spiritual advisers. But only information, he said, will ease his frustration. Authorities, however, said the process of identifying the bodies is painstaking. By Friday, 19 victims had been identified. The 96 bodies, or remains, found at the site have been taken to a special morgue at the medical school hospital built in 1965 to handle disasters. The train crash is the first disaster that has filled capacity. Four teams of six experts are working around the clock to record distinguishing marks and personal belongings that might speed identification. People who suspect relatives died in the crash are asked to give police dental records. Four forensic dental experts are working with those. So far, visual identification by relatives has been ruled out. ``We don't want any relative to have to go from body to body because it is just unbearable,'' Jung said. ``It's arms and legs and heads. It's awful.'' (tc-aet-tsc-cb)

REPEATING for all needing
World Cup: Referee who okayed England's go-ahead goal, dead at 78
BASEL, Switzerland (AP) _ Soccer referee Gottfried Dienst, who ruled in favor of England's controversial ``third goal'' in the 1966 World Cup victory over Germany, has died. He was 78. Dienst died Monday in the Basel, Switzerland, Cantonal Hospital, after a ``short and severe illness,'' said a family announcement in the Baseler Zeitung. He was buried Friday. The term ``Wembley goal'' is still used in soccer to describe a ball that hits the underside of the crossbar and ricochets down to the goal line. When Geoff Hurst's ball bounced back into play in the 11th minute of overtime, English players celebrated but the Germans ran to Soviet linesman Tofik Bakhramov to protest. Dienst backed the linesman and awarded the goal which put England ahead 3-2. Hurst went on to score again, gaining the only World Cup final hattrick and giving England a 4-2 win. Bakhramov died in Azerbaijan in 1993. Television replays and photographs strongly suggested the ball failed to completely cross the goal line. ``We can now say that it probably was not a goal,'' British soccer chronicler Philip Evans wrote in 1990. ``But to establish that fact, it took a lot of people many hours of very hard work in cinema laboratories all over the world.'' Dienst told an interviewer in 1989 that strangers still asked him almost daily about the decision. ``I gladly respond,'' he said. ``I still don't know if the shot by Hurst in the 100th minute was in or not. ``I have to say that I was standing in a poor position for that shot, exactly head-on instead of diagonal to the goal. I wouldn't have allowed the goal if linesman Bakhramov hadn't pointed to the middle with his flag.'' Dienst is survived by two daughters. (agh-rjm)

TARE, Rwanda (AP) _ Hutu rebels killed four people, burned two trucks and looted a local health center along the main highway in northern Rwanda, witnesses said Friday. The attack on midnight Thursday at Tare, 47 kilometers (25 miles) north of Kigali on the main road to northwestern Rwanda, came a week after a shadowy rebel group warned of violence in areas previously untouched by attackers. Witnesses in Tare said a group of armed men ran shouting and firing guns down the hills, surrounding houses and a restaurant along the main road, before throwing petrol bombs at two parked trucks. The two drivers, who were apparently asleep inside, died instantly. Another man was shot dead, and a local health worker later died of gunshot wounds. ``It lasted maybe 10 minutes,'' said Gerard Minigashura, a local official. ``This is the first time they attacked here.'' Authorities in the capital, Kigali, were not available for comment. Last week, a rebel group calling itself People in Arms for the Liberation of Rwanda warned of more attacks in a previously unknown newspaper. Umucunguzi, or Savior, said the group was fighting the Tutsi occupiers of Rwanda and their allies and urged Hutus to take up arms. On Thursday, Shyaka Komeza, who identified himself as a PALIR spokesman, told the British Broadcasting Corp. Kinyarwanda Service that his group was fighting for the liberation of the Hutu people, and accused the Tutsi-led army of massacres. The government in Kigali reacted angrily to the interview, accusing the BBC of spreading hate propaganda. PALIR was first heard of in June 1996 when it issued a typewritten leaflet placing a bounty on the heads of Americans in Rwanda. Tutsi fighters took power in July 1994, ousting an extremist Hutu government responsible for the genocide of more than 500,000 minority Tutsis. Issue No. 4 of the Kinyarwanda language newspaper printed a map showing half of Rwanda as rebel-controlled and said attacks would spread to the central Gitarama and northeastern Byumba prefectures. Last week, attacks were reported in Gitarama, Byumba and the western Kibuye prefectures, but no details were available. On Sunday, rebels killed a Presbyterian pastor and his family of five in the northwestern Gisenyi region. Meanwhile, a U.N. commission of inquiry into the illegal flow of arms into the Great Lakes region arrived in Kigali. The four-man comission was reactivated in April to investigate how Hutu rebels were receiving weapons. The rebels are believed to be based in northeastern Congo from where they cross easily in and out of Rwanda. U.N. officials believe the rebels may be assisted by a network of Hutu exiles and businessmen in Africa and Europe. (hh/dmc)

WARSAW, Poland (AP) _ Parliament on Friday defeated a government plan to streamline the number of Poland's provinces, but Prime Minister Jerzy Buzek said the vote had little effect on a broad reform program. The 460-member lower house, or Sejm, voted 247-207 with four abstentions against the plan to reduce the number of provinces from 49 to 12. Some members of the Solidarity-led governing coalition, which called for all coalition members to support the plan, voted against it anyway. The chamber was to vote later Friday on alternative measures, possibly reducing the number of provinces to 15 or 17. Under the reform program, to be introduced Jan. 1, Poland would shed the remains of its communist-era bureaucratic system to give local governments more power. But people in cities that would lose their status as provincial capitals have protested the proposed reduction of provinces. While the protesters fear a loss of control over governing spending in their areas, they support the concept of administrative reform and the goal of transferring decision-making power from the central government to provincial and local authorities. Buzek, who had hoped for a narrow victory in the vote on 12 provinces, said the issue was only one part of the reform package. ``The number of provinces is the most spectacular issue, but it does not decide on the whole reform,'' he said. The reforms are part of Poland's efforts to transform itself into a market-oriented, openly democratic society as it prepares to enter NATO and negotiates for membership in the European Union after more than four decades of communist rule ended in 1990. Premier says crisis over, but Yeltsin says tax collection must
improve Eds: UPDATES with Yeltsin saying he spoke to G-8 leaders; TRIMS. AP Photos MOSB102-3,105-7 By MITCHELL LANDSBERG Associated Press Writer
MOSCOW (AP) _ Russia's new prime minister claimed Friday that the country had emerged from its economic crisis, but President Boris Yeltsin warned that renewed stability depended on his government's ability to collect taxes. The country's new tax chief announced plans for a crackdown on the country's 1,000 richest citizens, whose rapid accumulation of wealth since the Soviet period has been largely unimpeded by taxpaying. ``Well-known people should be examples for other citizens,'' Boris Fyodorov told the Kommersant daily. The government also ordered five large oil companies to pay their tax debts by July 1 or face confiscation of their property, the Interfax news agency said. Russian financial markets collapsed late last month, and only began to recover this week as rumors mounted of an emergency bailout by the International Monetary Fund or the Group of Eight industrial nations. Top officials, including the new prime minister, Sergei Kiriyenko, have repeatedly said there was no ``official'' request for such aid _ sometimes stressing the word ``official.'' At a conference in Ukraine on Friday, Kiriyenko insisted the financial crash was over. ``We have stopped the crisis and reached a turning point,'' he said, according to the Interfax news agency. But some Western investors said the markets had regained strength only on the assumption that a bailout was imminent. ``Russia needs an infusion of capital,'' said James Fenkner, managing partner of CentreInvest Capital Management in Moscow. ``If it gets a big bucket of money, everything will be OK.'' After regaining ground earlier in the week, stocks declined slightly Friday on extremely thin trading, with most investors lying low until next week. Many investors believe a bailout package will be unveiled Tuesday, when G-8 deputy finance ministers meet in Paris. ``If nothing is announced in Paris, you are going to see a little bit of panic here,'' said Alex Pitaleff, a trader at Creditanstalt Investment Bank. No one disagrees that Russia needs cash, but some Russian officials have been insisting the country could get by with commercial loans and an improvement in tax collection. Yeltsin said Friday that he had held phone conversations with G-8 leaders who reiterated their confidence in Russian officials. ITAR-Tass quoted him as saying that for the past year ``we have been begging for nothing, asking for no money, because we know we will have to repay it sometime.'' In a radio address, Yeltsin implored Russians to pay their taxes. The government says fewer than 3 percent filed income tax declarations last year. ``The time has come to demand and punish, including filing criminal charges,'' Yeltsin said. ``If we don't collect taxes, we can't pay salaries.'' Yeltsin called on parliament and Russian regional governments to trim their staffs to save money, and promised to shrink his own staff by 30 percent. Russia's top business tycoons, who met with Yeltsin earlier in the week to discuss ways out of the crisis, issued a statement saying they were ready to support ``all sensible steps'' to revive the economy, ITAR-Tass reported. BC-Angola-UNITA,0374
Angola's former rebels angered by U.N., say peace in peril
LISBON, Portugal (AP) _ Angola's former rebel movement Friday expressed dismay at a United Nations report accusing it of keeping a hidden army and warned that the claim could plunge the country back into civil war. UNITA Secretary-General Paulo Lukamba Gato said Friday's scheduled U.N. Security Council meeting on Angola ``means nothing'' and is part of ``an international conspiracy'' against the rebel movement. The U.N. special representative to Angola, Alioune Blondin Beye, was due to report to the council on the overdue implementation of the 1994 peace agreement between the government and UNITA. Beye said earlier this week that UNITA was hiding armed men in remote areas of the vast southwest African nation, despite the movement's pledge that it demobilized its 70,000-strong guerilla army. Speaking by telephone from UNITA's central highland stronghold at Bailundo, 290 kilometers (180 miles) south of Luanda, Paulo Lukamba Gato said Beye's report on the situation in Angola was ``a bad mistake'' and ``very dangerous'' for the peace process. He said reports that UNITA had armed men hidden in the bush was based on unreliable third-hand reports and ``could cost the peace process dearly'' by prompting the government to launch a military offensive. Gato said the government ``could take Bailundo in 30 minutes, but we'd flee and then what would happen?'' UNITA _ a Portuguese acronym for the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola _ fought a two-decade civil war against the government following the southwest African nation's 1975 independence from Portugal. A 1991 peace pact collapsed when UNITA rejected its defeat in the following year's elections and returned to the bush. Since then, the United Nations has slapped sanctions on UNITA in an attempt to push it into compliance with the redrawn peace accord. Gato complained the Security Council was ignoring the former rebel movement's legitimate concerns about handing over its four remaining strongholds to the government. ``We're not part of this (United Nations) club. We're guilty till proven innocent,'' he said.

SOFIA, Bulgaria (AP) _ Hristo Stoichkov scored from a free-kick in the 33th minute and gave the decisive pass in the 84th for the second goal to give Bulgaria a 2-0 victory over Algeria Friday in the last tune-up match for his World Cup-bound team. Company defends itself after boss accused of money laundering
GENEVA (AP) _ A firm whose managing director faces Swiss money-laundering charges in a case linked to former Pakistan Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto denied Friday that any of its employees violated any national or international laws. Geneva-based Cotecna Inspection said it was having to ``bear the brunt of internal political rivalries in Pakistan.'' A company statement accused the Pakistan government of doing nothing about customs fraud totaling more than dlrs 650 million, which Cotecna said it uncovered during a two-year contract in the mid-1990s. ``Cotecna Inspection SA confirms its determination to vigorously defend its interests,'' said the statement. Cotecna and its former parent company, Societe Generale de Surveillance, lost their contracts to inspect imports and exports from Pakistan after Bhutto was ousted from government in November 1996 on charges of corruption and misrule. Cotecna's managing director Robert Massey was one of three Swiss citizens indicted earlier this week on money laundering charges linked to Ms. Bhutto and her husband Asif Ali Zardari. The Swiss charges were initially announced by Pakistan's anti-corruption investigator Senator Saif-ur Rehman, who was present Tuesday when Judge Daniel Devaud announced the indictments. Devaud later confirmed the indictments. Cotecna said its five-year contract to inspect imports and exports from Pakistan was ``unilaterally and illegally terminated'' at the end of two years after a new Pakistani government took power. Rehman showed reporters documents he gave Devaud, saying they indicated kickbacks flowed to Ms. Bhutto and Zardari through companies based in the British Virgin Islands from Pakistani government contracts with Cotecna and SGS. Devaud confirmed he would indict Zardari and intended to indict Ms. Bhutto if he determines she cannot receive diplomatic or parliamentary immunity. Rehman said the Swiss conducted the investigation at the request of the Pakistani government. Rehman said he does not know the full scope of Devaud's case, but he believes more than dlrs 250 million are in Bhutto family accounts in Swiss banks, which the Swiss government has blocked at Pakistan's request. Swiss authorities said last October they had found about 20 million Swiss francs (dlrs 13.8 million) in accounts frozen in seven Geneva banks. Rehman said he expects to find another dlrs 250 million in banks in Britain and the United States. Pakistan also is working with authorities in France, the Netherlands and Spain in the Bhutto case, he said.

BC-Sports-Boxing-Holyfield-Akinwande, 3rd Ld-Writethru,0607
Akinwande-Holyfield fight called off
Eds: Recasts throughout to UPDATE with Akinwande testing positive for hepatitis B. Will be UPDATED after news conference, scheduled for 2000 GMT. By TIM DAHLBERG AP Sports Writer
NEW YORK (AP) _ Saturday night's fight between heavyweight champion Evander Holyfield and Henry Akinwande was called off Friday when it was discovered that Akinwande had tested positive for hepatitis B. Two separate medical tests on Akinwande by the New York State Athletic Commission showed he had hepatitis B, said Greg Fritz, a spokesman for Don King Productions, the fight's promoter. ``The fight is off,'' Fritz said. The commission does not allow infected boxers to fight because of the risk of transmitting the disease through blood during bouts. Hepatitis B and C cause serious liver problems. Hepatitis A is typically a food-borne disease that can pass quickly. Hepatitis B, often contracted through sex or dirty hypodermic needles, can be successfully treated, but not always. The Showtime network, which was to televise the bout from Madison Square Garden, also said in a statement that the main event had been canceled due to the commission's medical finding It was not immediately clear how the undercard bouts would be affected. The fight was supposed to top a card that included 46-year-old Roberto Duran fighting for a title nine years after he lost his middleweight crown to Sugar Ray Leonard. Duran first fought in the Garden in 1971, and is 6-1 in his career at the arena. Heavyweight Ray Mercer, who was to fight on the undercard against Jerry Ballard, also was suspended for medical reasons, said Ralph Petrillo, medical coordinator for the athletic commission. Petrillo said Akinwande was under a medical suspension, but he declined to elaborate. They were the latest medical suspensions to hit Saturday's card. On Thursday, Mexican lightweight Maria de las Nieves Garcia was scratched from her undercard bout with Christy Martin because tests showed she is pregnant. Melissa Salamore was to have replaced Garcia, but Martin rejected her as an opponent and promoters were trying to find someone else to replace her. The Akinwande decision is yet another blow to his career. He was disqualified during a bout against WBC champ Lennox Lewis in July for repeated holding. That Akinwande was fighting for a piece of the title for the second time in less than a year was due more to his choice of promoter than anything else. After the Lewis debacle, promoter Don King matched him against Orlin Norris, Jr., and Akinwande won a 12-round decision to become the mandatory contender. Holyfield was to have fought Lewis to unify the heavyweight championship for the first time since Riddick Bowe threw the WBC belt into a garbage can after his win over Holyfield in their first fight. But with Holyfield wanting dlrs 20 million for the fight and Lewis unwilling to give up his relationship with the HBO network, talks collapsed and Holyfield was left only with the option of taking a mandatory title defense to keep his WBA title. He was openly unenthusiastic about fighting Akinwande, who is 33-1-1. and almost nobody but Akinwande and the WBA wanted it. ``There's no other reason for this fight other than he's ranked No. 1,'' Holyfield said before the fight was canceled. ``That's just what the rules are.'' Duran, like Akinwande, hardly earned his title shot, winning a decision in Panama in his last fight after getting knocked down in the first round.

OWNERS of shops along Lorong Tuanku Abdul Rahman are crying foul over Kuala Lumpur City Hall's decision to reserve all parking lots along the stretch and at the nearby Coliseum Theatre car park for its staff which has robbed the traders of a place to load and unload goods. As a result of this, some traders have been receiving summonses every week from enforcement officers for loading and unloading of goods at undesignated areas. Carpet Plaza Sdn Bhd owner Jai Kishen Tekwani, one of those affected, said he had been busy attending court proceedings almost daily in connection with the summonses. ``We are not going to settle the summonses which I feel have been issued indiscriminately. We have been unfairly deprived of proper loading and unloading bays by City Hall,'' he said at a Press conference attended by Bukit BIntang MP Dr Lee Chong Meng. He said the lack of public parking lots had also caused business to drop by as 50 per cent, a fraction of which he felt was due to the economic slowdown. ``People prefer to shop at places where parking is available. Our customers normally have large items to carry back to their cars,'' he said. ``We have been forced on several ocassions to send our staff to carry carpets to customer's cars parked far away from the shop.'' He said on an average, 10 lorries loaded and unloaded goods at his shop. He said City Hall officers had also harassed his workers for displaying carpets at the entrance of the shop which was their property. Lee said the traders had been gradually deprived of loading and unloading bays after the City Hall Licensing Department moved into the vicinity about three years ago. ``All parking lots along Lorong Tuanku Abdul Rahman and in front of the Coliseum Theatre have been turned into reserved lots for City Hall staff and this is depriving the public and shop owners of strategic parking points,'' he said. Lee said there were paid parking lots along this stretch as well as in front of the Coliseum Theatre previously. City Hall Urban Transport Department senior engineer Sabudin Mohd Salleh, who was present, said a meeting between members of the Federal Territory Indian Chambers of Commerce and City Hall was held on Wednesday on the matter. ``We will give immediate attention to this matter and try to find an alternative loading and unloading point for the shopkeepers,'' he said.

BC-India-Nuclear, 4th Ld-Writethru,0588
India criticizes other nuclear powers for failing to curb
clandestine nuclear help Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Indian reaction, CHANGES byline. No pickup. With UN-India-Pakistan By KRISHNAN GURUSWAMY Associated Press Writer
NEW DELHI, India (AP) _ Stung by criticism that it set off a nuclear arms race in South Asia, India on Friday accused the five official nuclear powers of failing to curb clandestine transfer of technology that resulted in threats to Indian security. New Delhi also rejected any offer to help negotiate its dispute with Pakistan over the Himalayan territory of Kashmir. Foreign ministers of the United States, Britain, China, France and Russia hinted at such an offer Thursday in Geneva. ``There is no room for any outside involvement of any nature whatsoever in this process,'' the government said in a lengthy statement. India set off five underground nuclear tests last month, prompting Pakistan to retaliate with a series of tests two weeks later. India had to build a nuclear defense because the five declared nuclear powers did not meet their obligations under the Non Proliferation Treaty when they failed to curb the ``clandestine transfer'' of nuclear technology to its neighbors. Both India and Pakistan have fought two of their three wars over the disputed Himalayan state of Jammu-Kashmir, which is now divided between them. New Delhi has held several rounds of talks over the years with Pakistan to resolve the dispute, but little progress has been made. India says the dispute should be settled between the two nations. Pakistan, however, wants the issue to be taken up in an international forum, believing it is at a disadvantage in one-on-one talks with its larger and more powerful neighbor. A separatist movement erupted in 1989 in Kashmir, where some 18,000 people have been killed in frequent gun battles between Indian security forces and a dozen militant groups. In Geneva, representatives of the local government of Pakistan-held Kashmir welcomed the mention of Kashmir by the five foreign secretaries, saying in a resolution that ``without a permanent solution of the Kashmir issue peace in the region cannot be guaranteed.'' Syed Ali Shah Geelani, head of a group opposed to New Delhi's rule of its two-thirds share of Kashmir, also welcomed the Geneva declaration during a speech at Friday Muslim prayers in Srinagar, the capital of Indian-held Kashmir. Pakistan's national government said ``the bilateral dialogue needs to be supplemented by a broader multilateral process to promote durable peace and security in South Asia.'' The Indian statement also reiterated statements made by Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee that New Delhi will observe a moratorium on further nuclear tests, take part in discussions to ban the production of fissile materials _ plutonium and highly enriched uranium _ and sign an agreement not to be the first one to use its nuclear weapons. India refuses to sign the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty in its present form since it allows Britain, China, France, Russia and the U.S. to keep their nuclear arsenals. Pakistan says it will sign the CTBT only if India adhered to it. In a related development, India denied as fictitious and baseless local newspaper reports that it had struck secret deals with Israel to promote its nuclear program. It said both nations do not have any nuclear or missile technology cooperation.

GULLANE, Scotland (AP) _ Gifted 18-year-old Spaniard Sergio Garcia will face Craig Williams of Wales Saturday in the 36-hole match-play final of the British Amateur Championship. Garcia, schooled by Seve Ballesteros and billed as Spain's next great player, reached the final with a sudden-death victory Friday on the 23rd hole with a par-5 as Mark Hilton of England took a 6. Garcia also won his quarterfinal match Friday, beating Aran Wainwright of England 5 and 4. Williams won his semifinal 3 and 2 over Ben Mason of England. In the morning he took his quarterfinal 4 and 3 over over Geoff Ogilby of South Africa. In the day's other quarterfinals at Muirfield: Mark Hilton of England defeated Trevor Immelman of South Africa, 2 and 1; Ben Mason of England defeated Peter Hansson of Sweden, 1-up. (scw)

KUALA LUMPUR, Thurs. - DAP national vice-chairman Liew Ah Kim and treasurer Fung Ket Wing have been suspended indefinitely for criticising the party leadership, creating a major split in the party. National publicity secretary Wee Choo Keong has been relieved of his position. The action was taken against Liew, Fung and Wee by the party's central executive committee last night for criticising secretary-general Lim Kit Siang at several party meetings. The three, who walked out of the central executive committee meeting which made the decision at the party headquarters in Petaling Jaya last night, have been referred to the disciplinary committee for further action. Until the board convenes its meeting, they will remain as CEC members. In Malacca, Kit Siang told a Press conference the decision was taken following complaints from the Malacca and Perak State committees. He said the Perak committee, at its meeting on Saturday, had lodged a complaint against Wee for his remarks against the party leadership at a meeting with the committee members, branch chairmen, secretaries, treasurers and sub-committee chairmen. Kit Siang added that the Malacca committee, at an emergency meeting on Monday, unanimously censured Liew, Fung and Wee for abusing their CEC positions to convene a combined branches meeting on May 31 during which allegations were made against national and State party leaders. Kit Siang said the statements made by the three leaders were uncalled- for and had undermined party morale, created confusion and caused disharmony as well as disunity among members. Asked whether last night's decision was unanimous, he said: ``I do not have the details. I do not think we need to go into all that. What I could say is it was a majority decision.'' Party sources said the three had, among others, criticised Kit Siang's decisions and statements over his son Guan Eng's recent conviction by the Court of Appeal for printing false news and inciting the public. The three had also expressed dissatisfaction over the roadshow organised by Kit Siang to attract public sympathy for Guan Eng. Liew, Fung and Wee declined to comment when contacted.

IPOH, Thurs. - Tenaga Nasional Berhad will spend about RM500 million to improve electricity supply and prevent frequent power breakdowns. State Infrastructure and Public Utilities Committee chairman Datuk Ong Ka Chuan said the project would include the construction of 20 new intakes and replacing of overhead cables with a multiphase underground system. He said the project, to be completed by the year 2000, would ensure a more efficient supply of electricity. The new intakes will be built at among others, Pengkalan, Tasek, Menglembu, Tambun, Seri Iskandar, Gunung Rapat, Bercam, Greentown, Jelapang, Gopeng and Sitiawan. Ong said the project was a move to upgrade public amenities to cater to the rapid development in the State. Currently, he said electricity consumption in the State was 520 megawatts and this was expected to increase to 1,830 megawatts by 2000. With the underground multiphase cabling system, Ong said if a cable tripped, there would be back-up from another line. ``This way we have a contingency plan to overcome disruption to our supply,'' he said after opening the fifth World Chinwoo carnival at Wisma Chinwoo today. In another development, Ong assured that Perak had sufficient raw water from the State's many rivers. ``If the rivers are in danger of drying up, we can always ask Tenaga Nasional to release water from the dams to fill them up,'' he said.

EPSON Precision (Johor) Sdn Bhd, a member of the Seiko Epson Corporation of Japan, is willing to relocate more of its operations to Johor if such a move is feasible and reduces costs. ``Our research and development will be in Singapore. But whatever (facilities) we think can be transferred to Johor, we will transfer,'' said Seiko Epson Corporation of Japan deputy president Yuji Yamazaki. He was speaking at a Press conference, through an intepreter, after the launch of Epson Precision's 10th anniversary celebrations by Menteri Besar Datuk Abdul Ghani Othman at the company's premises in Johor Baru. Yamazaki was asked if the parent company in Japan had plans to shift more operations from Singapore to Johor in view of the high production costs in the republic as well as the group's vision to diversify its Johor's operations. Epson Precision, a subsidiary of Singapore Epson Industrial Pte Ltd, currently produces watch parts, complete watches (Seiko brand) and printer carriage shafts (Epson) for the export market. Incorporated in 1988, Epson Precision expanded its premises from a 0.8- hectare leased factory in Larkin industrial area to its own four-hectare lot in Kempas Baru within a few years. In June 1990, it set up its micro motor plant which subsequently received the ISO 9002 certification from the Standards and Industrial Research Institute of Malaysia in December 1993. Epson Precision opened three new divisions in 1997: rotor magnets (production), printer shaft (production) and complete watch (assembly plant). In the same year, the micro motor plant was relocated to China. In January this year, the new tool shop started production of tools and dies, jigs and fixtures, and machine tools. Epson Precision currently employs 1,200 workers compared to under 100 when it started 10 years ago, and 300 have been sent to Japan for training. Launching the anniversary celebrations earlier, the Menteri Besar said Johor was proud to play host to a company which operated value-added manufacturing and at the same time provided training for the local workforce. About 60 per cent of the parts and components for Epson Precision's production and assembly lines are locally sourced. Also present were Ghani's wife Datin Professor Dr Jamilah Ariffin, Seiko Epson Corporation deputy president Yuji Yamazaki and Epson Precision (Johor) managing director Sukenobu Koizumi. Ghani later received on behalf of the State Government donation of 20 Epson printers from Yamazaki. Jamilah received from Koizumi a donation of RM30,000 towards the Juita's (Association of the Wives of Johor State Assemblymen and MPs) Tabung Sinar Juita.

THE Government will maintain its policy on power purchase agreements (PPAs) between Tenaga Nasional Bhd and independent power producers (IPPs) but will not object to a review of the policy if both parties mutually agree to terminate the contract, Minister of Energy, Telecommunications and Posts Datuk Leo Moggie said yesterday. ``So far as the PPAs are concerned, they are contractual documents between two parties and it can only be reviewed if both parties agree to remove it. ``If the IPPs agree, yes, we will review the PPAs but other than that, any PPA has to be honoured and it is a policy that the Government has to be consistent with,'' Moggie said. He was speaking after opening Wisma City-Link in Shah Alam in response to a statement on Monday by Tenaga executive chairman Datuk Ahmad Tajuddin Ali that PPAs should be ``undone'' to allow for a free market scheme resulting possibly in lower tariffs for consumers. Ahmad Tajuddin had said that the practice of PPAs was ``unfair'' to Tenaga and was in the way of realising lower tariffs. Moggie said: ``For as long as both parties feel that it is necessary to maintain that contract, our position is that the contract has to be honoured. We have made similar assurances many times before that this policy has not changed.'' The IPPs will hold a meeting soon to discuss the issue and its association's honorary president, Ahmad Jauhari Yahya, had said a free market scheme would attract the best participants in the electricity generation industry but concerns remain on industry restructuring and reaction. Under the PPAs, Tenaga has to pay the IPPs an agreed amount for making their plants available for the generation of electricity. Tenaga forks out more than RM2 billion to buy about 30 per cent of the total electricity generated by the IPPs.

Print run of new Solzhenitsyn book to be doubled
MOSCOW (AP) _ The print run of a new book by Alexander Solzhenitsyn will be doubled to 10,000, his publisher said Friday. The decision was made after half of the first 5,000 copies of ``Russia in Collapse'' sold out on the first two days, Viktor Moskvin told the Interfax news agency. ``Russia in Collapse'' is Solzhenitsyn's second book since the Nobel laureate returned from exile in 1994. The lukewarm reception it received from the literary world was another indication of how far his reputation in Russia has fallen since the collapse of communism. The new book, like his last, ``The Russian Question at the End of the 20th Century,'' is largely an indictment of post-Soviet Russia, which he sees as dominated by greed, corruption and cultural decline. He calls for a return to tradition. (ls)

RUBBISH has always been a problem in Klang and unfortunately the royal town has been known for years to be a problematic area where this is concerned. It's hard to pinpoint at anyone as it is a collective responsibility of not only the Klang Municipal Council but also the public to resolve the problem. If the problem of rubbish is to be overcome in Klang, everyone has to play an important role - right from the council, houseowners, businessmen, petty traders and hawkers to virtually everyone in the town. Over the years the council has indeed improved the garbage collection in Klang. It has engaged 63 private contractors to collect rubbish on a ``three times a week'' basis from more than 150 housing estates in Klang North, Klang South, Port Klang, Meru, Kapar and, in fact, in all the areas that fall within its region. ``To ensure that private contractors do their job, the council kept track of their routine activities. The errant ones were fired,'' said council public relations officer Rosli Udin. Rosli said garbage collection in housing estates had improved and there were fewer complaints from house owners of rubbish piling up at their backyards. As for rubbish in town areas, Rosli said it was collected every morning by council garbage lorries. The biggest problem the council is facing is the rubbish thrown at unauthorised sites along the roadside which indeed had become an eyesore to commuters. Rosli said the council had placed big rubbish bins along roadsides for people to dispose of rubbish. Unfortunately, there are unscrupulous ones, including lorry drivers, who throw rubbish outside the bins and at unauthorised sites making it difficult for the council to keep track of the rubbish accumulated. Rosli said there were 12 rubbish bins placed at strategic locations in Kapar, Klang South (31), Pandamaran (10), Port Klang (seven), Klang North (13), and Meru (six). Rubbish in the bins are also cleared practically every day. Rosli said lorry drivers carrying domestic and industrial wastes had been repeatedly advised to throw them at the council's rubbish dump in Teluk Gong. However, he added, many did not comply with the directive and took the short cut out by throwing it at the bins placed along the roadsides. To keep Klang clean and free of rubbish, Rosli said the people had to play their part by discarding rubbish at the bins provided and not throw it into drains and along roadsides. Garden refuse should be discarded at authorised sites allocated in each housing estate and all rubbish must be put into proper garbage bags before disposal. Petty traders and hawkers at day and night markets should also throw away their rubbish at authorised sites and not into nearby drains and at the sites they operate. All rubbish from industries must be disposed of at the council's dump. With the Commonwealth Games just round the corner, it is important everyone play his or her role in keeping the royal town clean.

PENGURUSAN Danaharta Nasional Bhd (AMC), the national asset management company set up to take over the non-performing loans of the banking system, will be issuing quarterly reports of the total value of non- performing loans and assets acquired from financial institutions. However, it will not publicise information on every asset purchased. This will be the AMC's public disclosure policy to facilitate its commercial activities while abiding by existing banking confidentiality rules. ``But, when the assets acquired are that of shares in public-listed firms, we will make the appropriate announcements,'' said AMC chief executive officer and managing director Azman Yahya in Kuala Lumpur yesterday. He also said the AMC also has the option of acquiring loans and assets that are not yet classified as non-performing. ``If we see the potential for these loans becoming non-performing, we would like to take them on quickly before the situation worsens.'' The underlying guideline for the AMC is to see if the non-performing loan can be restructured, and then, if extra value can be added to the underlying assets via professional help and management. In a Press briefing at the Treasury, he said the AMC is envisioned to initially have two separate divisions to handle the NPLs and assets to be acquired. The property division will overlook acquired assets related to leasing, property management and construction management activities. The asset management division overlooks commercial asset management (industrial, retail and hotel), infrastructure and project finance, loan workout and restructuring, and non-real estate asset management. Asked if the AMC expects to have properties making up the bulk of the assets to be acquired, Azman said the asset portfolio will be balanced and the two divisions were just the initial set up. ``The AMC will be a relatively organic organisation, with professional expertise acquired as and when needed for different types of NPLs or assets acquired.'' Azman reiterated that all acquisitions will be made on commercial basis and not at fire-sale values. As to how long the AMC is expected to stay in operation, he said initial projections could be about 10 years as a number of infrastructure projects are expected to be part of the company's portfolio. On future funding for the AMC, Azman said several options are now being considered and it is expected to be a mixture of local and foreign funds. The AMC will be raising RM10 billion via the issue of bonds locally and abroad. Asked if the RM25 billion estimate for total funds required by the AMC was adequate, he said this was the conservative figure that was available now and could change later.

BC-Yemen-Clashes
Clashes between army and civilians leaves three people dead
SAN`A, Yemen (AP) _ The government sent tanks and troops into southern villages Friday when citizens rioted after a motorist was shot dead at a checkpoint, Yemeni security officials said. Three people were killed and at least four wounded in the clashes in villages near Ad-Dali, a town 250 kilometers (156 miles) southeast of the capital, San`a. The riots began after soldiers at a checkpoint near Ad-Dali opened fire on a passing car at 2:30 a.m. (23:30 GMT), killing one person and wounding another, the officials said. It was not clear why the soldiers opened fire. When soldiers tried to arrest people a few hours later, the riots began again and some rioters were armed with firearms. Weapons are not difficult to buy in Yemen, owing to the recent war and the government's weak authority. The army called in tanks and armored personnel carriers to take control of several villages, the officials said. Many civilians fled to the mountains. The local province of Lahij lies in south Yemen, which was a separate country until it united with north Yemen in 1990. The south tried to secede in 1994, provoking a brief civil war. The northern-based armed forces then took control of the south, but continue to be widely resented. str-bm-jbm

THE driving force for trade and investment flows in the region lies in an integration of Indochina economies into Asean, which will then hasten the region's integration into world economy. However, the founding members of Asean are going through a tough economic phase, and new as well as future members need to know how they fit into Asean's vision for the millennium. Asian Institute for Development Communications executive director Khairul Bashar said this at a seminar on ``New Members of Asean: Dismantling Barriers and Facing Economic Challenges'' here. ``What do they stand to gain from it, especially in these times of crisis for Asia? They also need to clarify the framework of Asean,'' he said. The Indochina countries which are the new members of Asean are Myanmar, Vietnam and Laos. The three-day seminar which started yesterday, is aimed at strengthening the media's role as a source of information on business development, economic and political trends, government regulations and corporate practice in the new member countries. It is also to enable their governments to understand the necessity of creating free market policies as a means of achieving growth. Khairul said there is resistance to radical reform as the process of promoting private enterprises and opening up of economy to competition, imports, and foreign investors is very uneven. In this regard, he said, Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar and Vietnam enjoyed a significant advantage since ``they are not the first to travel this road''. ``As such, they can analyse the diverse routes taken by other countries, and decide which features best suit their circumstances and objectives.'' He also said that to be efficient, effective and sustainable, Indochina's development efforts must centre on equally raising the economic and social potential of both men and women. The enduring strength of Asean families and societies is the region's greatest asset because it provides a firm base for thrift, hard work, educational success and social stability. Meanwhile, Malaysian Institute of Economic Research deputy director Dr Mohd Haflah Piei, in response to a point made by a Cambodian participant that the country was planning to increase tariffs on some 40 products said: ``The move was not appropriate as it would dampen the member countries' efforts to liberalise trade in the region by the year 2001''. He noted that Cambodia, which will be admitted as an Asean member in the near future, seemed to be wary of opening up its economy to other countries.

BC-Yugoslavia-Kosovo, 2nd Ld-Writethru
Protective repeat
Kosovo Albanians talk of 50 deaths, destroyed villages Ed: AMs; UPDATES with report of mass grave, new shortages; recasts and trims. By ISMET HAJDARI Associated Press Writer
PRISTINA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ The latest Serbian offensive in independence-minded Kosovo province produced reports on Friday of 50 dead, 200 missing, villages destroyed and a mass grave containing 300 bodies. Hundreds more joined the thousands who have already fled the fighting in the week since the offensive began, with most of them heading for neighboring Albania. Some of them didn't make it. In Geneva, the United Nations refugee agency said some of the 400 or so who trekked into neighboring Albania overnight had reported five deaths en route _ two elderly people, said to have died of exhaustion, and three small children. About 10,000 refugees are now gathered around Tropoja in northern Albania, produced by the largest exodus since ethnic tensions erupted into large-scale violence in March. Reports from Serb and Albanian sources were often conflicting and proved impossible to verify. Still, together, they reflected the intensity of the conflict as Serbian government forces tried by force to destroy the Kosovo Albanian drive to secede. Osman Cacaj, an official of the Democratic League of Kosovo, the ethnic Albanians' main party, listed more than 50 dead and some 200 missing from the latest offensive, concentrated around Decani, some 70 kilometers (45 miles) west of Kosovo's capital, Pristina. Four villages populated by ethnic Albanians were destroyed, another eight badly damaged, and 16 others deserted by fleeing residents, Cacaj added. The Beta news in Belgrade quoted unnamed refugees from Decani, as saying a mass grave on the outskirts of the Serb-besieged town contained 300 bodies. There were no details. The Kosovo Information Center, close to the Albanian leaders in the province, said one Albanian was killed and two wounded in fighting around Orahovac, some 40 kilometers (25 miles) southwest of Pristina. It said Serb shelling continued in the Decani area and around the town of Djakovica in Kosovo's southwest. The pro-Serb Media Center reported an Albanian woman wounded Friday, when an armed Albanian shot at a bus on the road running between Pec, in the west, and Kosovska Mitrovica in the northeast. Ethnic Albanians form 90 percent of Kosovo's 2 million people and demand independence from Serbia and the Yugoslav federation it forms with tiny Montenegro. Accounts are impossible to verify independently, as both Serbian police forces and gunmen from the Kosovo Liberation Army _ fighting for independence _ block adequate access to journalists and even humanitarian workers. Pristina-based human rights groups on Friday warned that food and medicines in some blocked off areas was extremely short and asked for international aid. Cacaj described the area around Decani as a deserted wasteland, with some 45 bodies left unburied, farm animals roaming wild and several thousand civilians hiding in the woods, trying to cross the border into neighboring Albania or to Montenegro, which with Serbia, forms Yugoslavia. There were conflicting reports of Serb casualties, with Cacaj saying three policemen trying to loot a house had been shot dead by its Albanian owner, and the Serb Media Center denying any officers were killed or wounded. More than 250 people have died since March 1 in escalating clashes between government forces and the Kosovo Liberation Army, the armed wing of the Albanian independence movement, which Albanian political leaders say acts independently from them. The clandestine KLA, which first surfaced in 1996, says the peaceful principles of the top Kosovo Albanian leader, Ibrahim Rugova, are futile. A delegation picked by Rugova and officials chosen by Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic, who stripped Kosovo of its broad autonomy in 1989, opened a dialogue under Western pressure last month. Agreement appears unlikely. The ethnic Albanians canceled a meeting scheduled Friday in Pristina, saying they could not talk with the Serbs while the latest offensive lasts. The Serbs showed up anyway for the talks, to which Christopher Hill, U.S. ambassador to neighboring Macedonia, is serving as unofficial mediator. Hill noted that it is ``extremely difficult'' to get a true picture of events around Decani. (pvs/jg/gj)

BC-Eritrea-Ethiopia, 5th Ld-Writethru
Eritreans down two Ethiopian jets that bombed airbase
Eds: AMS. RECASTS lede; DETAILS; EDITS; no pickup By JULIA STEWART Associated Press Writer
ASMARA, Eritrea (AP) _ Eritrean anti-aircraft guns shot down two Ethiopian MiG-23 fighter planes that had bombed an airbase outside Asmara as the border conflict between two of the world's poorest countries escalated Friday. Witnesses saw several injured people being transported in trucks, but it was not immediately possible to determine the number of wounded or the fate of the Ethiopian pilots. Two hangars were hit at 2:15 p.m. (1115gmt) at the airbase which is adjacent to Asmara's international airport. A commercial airliner on the tarmac was reportedle Ethiopian sOters (60 miles) north of Mekele, where both sides traded tank, artillery and mortar fire. Ethiopian fighters attacked Eritrean tanks that were moving towards Adigrat, about 20 kilometers (12 miles) west. Both armies use aircraft, tanks and artillery supplied to Ethiopia by the Soviet Union during the Cold War. The attacks came a day after Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi agreed to a four-point proposal put forth by the United States and Rwanda to end the conflict peacefully. But Meles warned that his country's patience with Eritrea was wearing thin because of Asmara's refusal to withdraw from territory Ethiopia claims it occupied a month ago. Eritrea vowed that it would never give in ``to the language of force and intimidation.'' ``They thought they would terrorize the Eritrean people, but it worked the opposite,'' said Yemane Kifle, a business consultant, as jubilant residents poured into the streets waving the blue, green and red flags of their young nation after the fighters were shot down. A Canadian aircraft chartered by the U.S. Embassy left Asmara for Frankfurt around 7 p.m. (1600gmt) with 191 people on board, nearly all U.S. citizens, dependents of government employees, non-essential embassy staff and Peace Corps volunteers, according to the husband of one of the women passengers who asked not to be further identified. Another charter was being arranged to ferry out Britons, Canadians and Australians, he said. Shortly before the bombing, the government of Eritrean President Isaias Afwerki had issued a statement expressing ``its firm commitment to a peaceful resolution of the crisis.'' But it said it would never ``acquiesce to the language of force and intimidation and will, if necessary, resolutely defend its hard-won right to live in peace and freedom.'' One of the recommendations of the U.S.-Rwandan proposal was that Eritrea withdrawn to positions held before May 6. The Eritrean government statement Friday characterized the four points as ``not controversial'' but said Eritrea believed there were ``still serious issues of detail and implementation to be worked out.'' Eritrea, which gained independence from Ethiopia in 1993, has always claimed it remains inside its own territory as determined by Italian colonial boundaries. Eritrean rebels under Isaias' command were instrumental in helping Mele's Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democractic Front overthrow a 17-year military regime in July 1991. (js/sl)
