BC-Germany-Spokesman's Woes
New German government spokesman blasted for untactful commentary
BONN, Germany (AP) _ On the job less than two weeks, German government spokesman Otto Hauser is quickly finding out what it's like to be in the hot seat. Hauser, a conservative parliament member and former journalist who replaced former spokesman Peter Hausmann on May 25, was blasted Friday by his own party for telling Germans in the new eastern states not to bite the hand that feeds them. Wolfgang Schaeuble, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's conservative faction leader in parliament, said Hauser should learn to formulate his comments better. Schaeuble also criticized Hauser comparing the PDS, east Germany's former communists, to the Nazis. In an interview with the Ulm-based Suedwest-Presse newspaper, Schaeuble said he is against comparing right and left extremists, because such debates ``can only lead to misery.'' Schaeuble was referring to Hauser's comments earlier in the week that east Germans should not overtax west German generosity and patience by voting for the former communists as they did in Saxony Anhalt state in April. Germans pay a solidarity tax equal to about 8 percent of their income tax to help rebuild east Germany's economy after four decades of communist mismanagement. Hauser said he was only repeating what he as a parliament deputy and many west Germans think. Schaeuble said Hauser's warning to the east Germans about their election stance could be misunderstood because of the way he worded it. Claiming to speak as a member of parliament rather than as government spokesman was a lame excuse, Schaeuble said. ``I am not for a parliament deputy being allowed to speak more nonsense that a government spokesman,'' he said. BC-UN-Angola,0522
Security Council threatening new measures in Angola
By ROBERT H. REID Associated Press Writer
UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ Alarmed at the prospect of renewed civil war in Angola, the Security Council agreed Friday to consider ``additional measures'' against the UNITA movement unless it fulfills all commitments under the 1994 peace agreement. The president of the council, Ambassador Antonio Monteiro of Portugal, said experts from the three countries overseeing the peace process _ the United States, Russia and Portugal _ would prepare a resolution for submission to the council ``as soon as possible.'' Monteiro said the resolution envisages ``adoption of additional measures if UNITA will not comply with its commitments.'' He did not specify what those measures might be or when they might take effect. Last October, the Security Council imposed air and travel sanctions against UNITA, in addition to an oil and weapons embargo in effect since 1993. He said the three observer countries had agreed among themselves on the proposed measures but he would not discuss them before the draft resolution was circulated to the full 15-member council. ``This is a very, very serious situation in Angola,'' Monteiro told reporters. ``We want very much to save the peace process.'' The U.N. special representative to Angola, Alioune Blondin Beye, briefed the council Friday on the much delayed implementation of the 1994 Lusaka peace agreement between the government and UNITA, a former rebel movement. Beye said earlier this week that UNITA was hiding armed men in remote areas of the vast southwest African nation, despite the movement's pledge that it demobilized its 70,000-strong guerrilla army. UNITA has denied the allegation. Before the council meeting, diplomatic sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Beye would insist on new sanctions against UNITA and threatened to resign if the parties did not fulfill terms of the peace plan. Beye made no statement to reporters after the meeting. Monteiro said Beye ``had mentioned that possibility'' but said the envoy ``decided with courage that he has to assume his responsibilities,'' meaning stay on. UNITA's secretary-general Paulo Lukamba Gato dismissed the council actions as part of ``an international conspiracy'' against the rebel movement. Speaking by telephone from UNITA's central highland stronghold at Bailundo, Paulo Lukamba Gato said Beye's report was ``a bad mistake'' and ``very dangerous'' for the peace process. He said reports that UNITA had armed men hidden in the bush was based on unreliable third-hand reports and ``could cost the peace process dearly'' by prompting the government to launch a military offensive. UNITA _ a Portuguese acronym for the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola _ fought a two-decade civil war against the government following the southwest African nation's 1975 independence from Portugal. A 1991 peace pact collapsed when UNITA rejected its defeat in the following year's elections and returned to the bush.

World Cup: English F.A. switches and backs Blatter
Eds: ADDS reaction from Johansson
LONDON (AP) _ The English Football Association, after early support for Lennart Johansson for the FIFA presidency, came out Friday behind his rival Sepp Blatter. On Monday, the FIFA Congress meeting in Paris will vote on a new president to succeed Brazilian Joao Havelange. ``After careful deliberation... England will cast its vote in favor of Sepp Blatter,'' F.A. chairman Keith Wiseman said in a brief statement. The English F.A. had initially backed Johansson, president of Europe's governing body of soccer UEFA, when he was the lone candidate. Blatter, the FIFA general secretary, declared his candidacy only a few months ago. Johansson lashed out at Wiseman after the announcement and said the F.A. had gone back on its word. ``I think this is a very personal decision by the chairman of the Football Association,'' Johansson said. ``Up until today, the F.A. assured me they would vote for me. Obviously Keith Wiseman did not keep his word.'' Johansson suggested a political motive for the change. ``The fact is that Keith Wiseman lost his election for the (UEFA) executive committee last April in Dublin and that he wants to become the representative of the British associations in the executive of FIFA,'' Johansson said. ``I am disappointed that a UEFA association did not keep its word due to personal ambition.'' Neither Blatter nor Johansson has backed England's bid to land the 2006 World Cup. Blatter, who believes he is the favorite to win Monday's vote, said earlier this week he wants Africa to host the 2006 World Cup. Johansson has favored Germany over England to be the European bidder for 2006. Johansson said he still had strong European support from Italy, Germany, Spain, Portugal, Russia and the Netherlands and added he expected to ``obtain the majority needed.'' (scw)

BC-Diana-Investigation, 7th Ld-Writethhru
Witnesses, paparazzi, Al Fayed converge on Paris courthouse
Eds: AMs. Recasts and adds quotes, detail AP Photos PAR107-110, PAR114-116, PAR126-128 By JOCELYN NOVECK Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Nine months after the death of Princess Diana, a French judge gathered witnesses, paparazzi and a platoon of lawyers under one roof Friday, trying to determine once and for all whether photographers were to blame for the crash. The all-day meeting wasn't expected to yield any immediate results. But it was a way for Judge Herve Stephan, who heads the massive investigation, to balance conflicting accounts in the case file. The high-speed crash in a Paris traffic tunnel last Aug. 31 killed Diana, her companion Dodi Fayed, and driver Paul. Tests showed Paul was drunk at the time, and investigators long have believed that is the main cause of the crash, in addition to speed. But Stephan still needs to determine the role of nine photographers and one press motorcyclist, who have been in legal limbo _ under investigation, but not formally charged _ for nearly a year. Many close to the case predict they will soon be exonerated. Friday's meeting may have been a way for the judge to show, for the last time, that he's thoroughly considered the charges. It also was a chance for Diana's mother, Frances Shand Kydd, and Dodi's father, Mohamed Al Fayed, to come face to face with the paparazzi. Al Fayed owns the Ritz Hotel, where driver Paul was employed. He long has blamed the paparazzi, and he railed against them when he emerged for an afternoon break. ``If I was not in a courtroom, I would hang them all,'' he said. ``The immorality, the inhumanity of what they did. They were like vultures around the bodies.'' He also had harsh words for Diana's mother, accusing her of snobbery. ``I'm an ordinary person. I'm a working-class guy,'' Al Fayed said. ``She thinks she's the Queen of Sheba. She didn't talk to me.'' But he praised the judge, who he called ``very compassionate and precise.'' ``He uncovered many things today,'' Al Fayed said. ``Now it's in God's hands.'' Mrs. Shand Kydd emerged from the courtroom during a break, but waved away journalists. Also present were driver Paul's parents. They, Al Fayed and Mrs. Shand Kydd had the right to attend because they have filed as civil parties in the case. According to lawyers and witnesses, the judge took each photographer one by one, asking him to describe his role that night. He then asked his own questions, asked witnesses what they had seen, and opened up questioning to all lawyers. In one exchange, photographer Romuald Rat was questioned harshly by lawyers for Al Fayed, who tried to establish that he pursued the Mercedes that night. ``I followed it. I did not pursue it,'' Rat insisted. Ten witnesses were summoned, but only eight showed up. They included the first emergency doctor on the scene, Frederic Mailliez, and the first two policemen on the scene. Lawyers said the policemen who spoke accused Rat of hindering their work. Another witness, private chauffeur Clifford Gooroovadoo, said he'd told the judge he had seen Rat and another photographer, Christian Martinez, fighting just after the accident. He said Rat, after taking his own pictures, yelled at Martinez to stop. The photographers are being investigated on two charges: manslaughter, and failing to come to the aid of a person in danger. Many believe that if anything, they will be formally charged only on the second offense _ and only a few of them. Nikolas Arsov, of the Sipa photo agency, said the hearing was inconvenient, but he understood the need for it. ``It's the 40th time we have answered the same questions,'' Arsov said. ``It's annoying, but what can you do? They have to do their job.'' In contrast to previous hearings, all cameras were kept outside the Palais de Justice. The gates were heavily guarded by police. Investigators are still looking for a white Fiat Uno believed to have brushed the Mercedes before it crashed. But they are said to have given up any real hope of finding the Fiat. And tests are still being conducted on the wrecked Mercedes Diana was traveling in, but aren't likely to be finished before October _ meaning the case can't be closed until then. One person who wasn't attending Friday's session: bodyguard Trevor Rees-Jones, the sole survivor of the crash. He was invited, but decided not to come. (jn-dgs)

Precede ROME
EU concerned about violence in Kosovo, studying options Eds: UPDATES with Blair comments in Vienna
VIENNA, Austria (AP) _ Escalating violence in the Yugoslavian province of Kosovo will be urgently addressed by the European Union, British Prime Minister Tony Blair said Friday. ``After what happened in Bosnia, it is important for us to act and act soon,'' Blair told reporters following a meeting with Austrian Chancellor Viktor Klima. Britain currently holds the rotating presidency of the EU, and has been discussing the Kosovo situation with allies, trying to determine what action to take. Many fear the explosive situation in Kosovo could lead to another Balkan war. After meeting earlier in the day in Rome with Italian Premier Romano Prodi, Blair said the EU intends to send ``a very clear and very strong message'' that it wants stability in the region. ``It would be a very serious mistake for people to underestimate our resolve and determination,'' he said. Tens of thousands of people have fled a fierce Serb offensive in Kosovo, a Serbian province where ethnic Albanians make up 90 percent of the population. About 12,000 refugees have already reached Albania and as many as 7,000 others have made it to Montenegro. More than 50 Kosovo Albanians were killed and about 200 are missing since Serb forces began an offensive in the province a week ago. During his Vienna visit, Blair and Klima also discussed priorities for the EU. Austria takes over the presidency July 1. A key concern is economic reform, particularly, ``how we create jobs and prosperity for our people for a new type of economy,'' Blair said. Along with job creation, topics such as organized crime, drugs, and the environment will be on the agenda at a summit June 15-16 in Cardiff, Wales, Blair said. The EU wants to ``help our citizens deal with some of the problems facing our world today,'' he said. In a visit designed to coordinate the hand-over of the EU presidency to Austria, the two also discussed EU enlargement talks, Klima said. Earlier this year, the EU opened negotiations with Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Slovenia, Estonia and Cyprus. (pvs/scl/gj)

Founder and chief executive officer of City-Link Express David Tan said the company expects to chalk up RM50 million in revenue this year, up RM10 million from RM40 million achieved last year. With 95 per cent of its revenue coming from the domestic market, City- Link Express will still focus on local services as the domestic market is still seeing growth despite the economic slowdown, he added. ``With the economic slowdown, the domestic market has experienced a five per cent shrinkage in terms of shipping volume. However, it is still a growing industry and remains an essential part of the communications infrastructure to spur business growth,'' Tan said. City-Link Express moves a daily shipment of 20,000 packages through an established network of 50 branches, two airport offices and 50 express centres nationwide. It also delivers to Southeast Asian countries through 50 overseas stations. Tan said the domestic market for courier services was estimated to be worth RM300 million with an expected growth of 20 to 25 per cent next year. To date, the company has invested a total of RM30 million in its operations including RM13 million for the new headquarters, he added. The company has also invested almost RM5 million since 1985 for its information technology system. Tan said City-Link Express would spend another RM1 million in upgrading all of its systems towards becoming Y2K-compliant, and would also soon offer customer direct on-line services and information accessibility via the Internet. City-Link Express, with a total staff strength of 1,000, delivers time- sensitive and fragile materials such as documents, stationery, pharmaceutical products, computer hardware and automobile parts.

MALAYSIA will resume borrowing from Japan in view of the depreciating yen to finance private sector and government projects in the country, Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad said today. ``This is a good time to borrow in yen. At one time, we stopped yen loans because the yen was appreciating but now the yen is actually depreciating and we have decided to once again accept loans in yen,'' the Prime Minister said at the end of his four-day working visit. Dr Mahathir discussed this with Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto when they met before attending a dinner hosted by Nihon Keizai Shimbun Inc. To a question, Dr Mahathir said the loans would be used to finance projects, in particular environmentally-friendly projects for which Japan provides special loans. He said details were being negotiated. Dr Mahathir said he also discussed with Hashimoto, the importance of Japanese investment in Malaysia during this time. Asked whether the Government, in reforming the country's banking system, would consider introducing a deposit insurance scheme, he said this was one of the many considerations. He added the Government might have to think of unorthodox ways of dealing with an unorthodox situation, including bail-outs. He cited the decision by the United States Government to nationalise Continental Illinois. For a country that believes in free trade, to nationalise a bank was a radical step, the Prime Minister said. ``But when they are faced with a problem that can destroy the whole banking system, they did not hesitate to use unconventional methods. We should learn from them.'' On the criticism by International Monetary Fund deputy managing director Stanley Fischer that Dr Mahathir's proposal for Malaysia to trade in the currencies of the country's trading partner was a retrogressive step, Dr Mahathir asked: ``What's wrong with going back to something that was good?'' He said he did not think that his proposal for a reform of the international financial system would be accepted by the powerful countries of the west which were the ones ``making a lot of money''.

BC-Yugoslavia-Kosovo, 2nd Ld-Writethru,0714
Kosovo Albanians talk of 50 deaths, destroyed villages
Ed: RECASTS, UPDATES with report of mass grave, new shortages. Trims By ISMET HAJDARI Associated Press Writer
PRISTINA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Some of the thousands fleeing the latest Serbian offensive in separatist Kosovo province have died of exhaustion. Other reports Friday said 50 people were dead, 200 missing, villages were destroyed and bodies were left unburied. In Geneva, the United Nations refugee agency said some of the 400 or so who trekked into neighboring Albania overnight reported five deaths en route _ two elderly people, said to have died of exhaustion, and three small children. About 10,000 refugees are now gathered around Tropoja in northern Albania, the largest exodus since ethnic tensions erupted into large-scale violence in March. Reports from Serb and Albanian sources were often conflicting and proved impossible to verify. Still, together, they reflected the intensity of the conflict as Serbian government forces tried to crush the Kosovo Albanian drive to secede. Osman Cacaj, an official of the Democratic League of Kosovo, the ethnic Albanians' main party, listed more than 50 dead and some 200 missing from the latest offensive, concentrated around Decani, some 70 kilometers (45 miles) west of Kosovo's capital, Pristina. Four villages populated by ethnic Albanians were destroyed, another eight badly damaged, and 16 others deserted by fleeing residents, Cacaj added. The Beta news in Belgrade quoted unnamed refugees from Decani, as saying a mass grave on the outskirts of the Serb-besieged town contained 300 bodies. There were no details. The Kosovo Information Center, close to the Albanian leaders in the province, said one Albanian was killed and two wounded in fighting around Orahovac, some 40 kilometers (25 miles) southwest of Pristina. It said Serb shelling continued in the Decani area and around the town of Djakovica in Kosovo's southwest. The pro-Serb Media Center reported an Albanian woman wounded Friday, when an armed Albanian shot at a bus on the road running between Pec, in the west, and Kosovska Mitrovica in the northeast. Ethnic Albanians form 90 percent of Kosovo's 2 million people and demand independence from Serbia and the Yugoslav federation it forms with tiny Montenegro. Accounts are impossible to verify independently, as both Serbian police forces and gunmen from the Kosovo Liberation Army _ fighting for independence _ block adequate access to journalists and even humanitarian workers. Pristina-based human rights groups on Friday warned that food and medicines in some blocked off areas was extremely short and asked for international aid, Cacaj described the area around Decani as a deserted wasteland, with some 45 bodies left unburied, farm animals roaming wild and several thousand civilians hiding in the woods, trying to cross the border into neighboring Albania or to Montenegro. There were conflicting reports of Serb casualties, with Cacaj saying three policemen trying to loot a house had been shot dead by its Albanian owner, and the Serb Media Center denying any officers were killed or wounded. More than 250 people have died since March 1 in escalating clashes between government forces and the Kosovo Liberation Army, the armed wing of the Albanian independence movement, which Albanian political leaders say acts independently from them. The clandestine KLA, which first surfaced in 1996, says the peaceful principles of the top Kosovo Albanian leader, Ibrahim Rugova, are futile. A delegation picked by Rugova and officials chosen by Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic, who stripped Kosovo of its broad autonomy in 1989, opened a dialogue under Western pressure last month. Agreement appears unlikely. The ethnic Albanians canceled a meeting scheduled Friday in Pristina, saying they could not talk with the Serbs while the latest offensive lasts. The Serbs showed up anyway for the talks, to which Christopher Hill, U.S. ambassador to neighboring Macedonia, is serving as unofficial mediator. Hill noted that it is ``extremely difficult'' to get a true picture of events around Decani.

ENTREPRENEURS are being encouraged to venture into the manufacture of machinery and equipment, currently produced abroad, as Malaysia is largely dependent on the import of such products. ``Total imports of various categories of machinery and equipment are estimated at RM38.7 billion in 1997,'' Deputy International Trade and Industry Minister Datuk Kerk Choo Ting said yesterday. He was speaking at the opening of the Industry Tradefair Malaysia 98 (ITM '98) and MachineTool Malaysia '98 (IMX '98) at The Malaysia International Exhibition and Showroom, or Mines, in Sri Kembangan, Selangor. Kerk said the bulk of the imports comprised process machinery, supporting services machinery, machine tools, laboratory/testing/quality control equipment, material handling equipment and packaging machinery. Exports of such products were still relatively insignificant. ``Machinery and equipment which are not produced locally will continue to be imported and this offers considerable business opportunities for local entrepreneurs.'' Investments in the machinery and equipment industry have been at a steady level over the last five years. For the period 1993 to April 1998, 475 projects were approved for the machinery manufacture and fabricated metal products industry, with investments totalling RM6.17 billion. Foreign investments accounted for 58.1 per cent of the total. Kerk said Malaysia would continue to maintain an open and liberal policy towards foreign investments and encourage joint ventures to facilitate technology transfer. ``Foreign manufacturers are welcome to examine the investment opportunities in the industry here.'' The ITM '98 and IMX '98, organised by Malaysia Exhibition Services Sdn Bhd, act as platforms for local and regional exhibitors to reach the international market. The events have attracted 553 companies from 29 countries, including China, Korea, Spain, Taiwan and the UK.

GROUND handling services company, KL Airport Services Sdn Bhd, yesterday signed on its fifth customer and first major passenger airliner, Emirates, the national carrier of the United Arab Emirates. Klas, which is a member of the DRB-Hicom Group, will begin providing its services to Emirates when the airline flies into the new KL International Airport in Sepang on June 30, a day after it opens. Emirates has been operating flights into Kuala Lumpur since October 1996 and now flies four times a week between Dubai and Kuala Lumpur. Apart from Emirates, Klas' other customers are sister company Air Asia, Kampuchea Airlines, Transmile Air and Federal Express. Under the agreement with Emirates, Klas will provide four main services such as inflight catering and passenger services (check-in, transfers and ticketing). It will also provide aircraft handling services (loading and unloading of baggage and cargo, freshwater and lavatory servicing, aircraft interior cleaning and aircraft pushback). Finally, the cargo handling services will involve acceptance, delivery, build-up and breakdown, transfer, storage and other matters related to cargo documentation. Klas director Datuk Maznah Abdul Jalil said the company was making good progress in signing up five customers so far and that it would continue to attract other foreign carriers. Malaysia Airlines' own ground handling company currently services all the national carrier's needs as well as for some foreign carriers. Klas was incorporated in 1995 as an alternative ground handling services company. It is 60 per cent owned by Hicom Holdings Bhd and 40 per cent by Mofaz Aerospace Holdings Sdn Bhd. Maznah said there would be 49 foreign carriers calling at the KLIA, so it was up to the company to compete for those airlines. She said that Klas' facilities at the KLIA was ready for operation. The company had moved to the KLIA since the middle of last month. It has a capacity to handle 150,000 tonnes of cargo a year, as well as an in-flight kitchen with capacity for 7,500 meals a day. Apart from the KLIA and the Sultan Abdul Aziz Shah International Airport in Subang, Klas has established offices in Penang which will be opened by year end. Plans to operate at the Kota Kinabalu and Johor Baru airports will depend on the economic situation, said Klas chief executive officer Sharifah Halimah Syed Ahmad.

METAL Reclamation Bhd registered a premium of 21 sen over its offer price of RM1.80 when it made its debut on the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange second board yesterday. By 9.06am, the counter, which opened at RM2.01, dropped to RM1.90. However, at mid-day the counter climbed back to RM2.01 with 64,000 shares traded. It ended its maiden day at RM2.03 after surging to a high of RM2.10 and reaching a low of RM1.90 on a turnover of 80,000 shares. Managing director Lim Sheng Seaw expressed satisfaction with the opening price. Metal Reclamation is involved in the reclamation, manufacture and sale of lead and lead alloy as well as the trading of metal scrap. It recycles lead mainly from lead-acid batteries. It is a holding company with two wholly-owned subsidiaries, namely Metal Reclamation (Industries) Sdn Bhd and Metal Reclamation Industries (Sabah) Sdn Bhd. Lim was speaking at a Press conference after Metal Reclamation's listing ceremony at the KLSE. At a time when most businesses are consolidating, Metal Reclamation is in the midst of building a RM63 million plant in Pulau Indah, Klang. Lim said the plant, which is expected to be on stream by the second quarter of next year, would enable Metal Reclamation to increase annual production capacity from 36,000 tonnes to 70,000 tonnes of pure lead and lead alloy. The plant would meet the Department of Environment's Malaysian Agenda for Waste Reduction (Mawar) programme specifications. ``When the plant is operational, we intend to increase the company's export from the current one per cent to between 20 and 25 per cent within the next five years.'' At present, Metal Reclamation exports to countries in the Middle East and Northern Asia. ``Before the regional economic problem began, we exported to Indonesia. In future, we plan to tap into India and South Africa.'' Malaysia churns out four million scrap batteries every year and Metal Reclamation controls close to 90 per cent of its recycling. For the year ended Dec 31, 1997, the company recorded a group pre-tax profit of RM6.95 million on the back of RM203.88 million turnover.

KL Monorail concessionaire, PRT Sdn Bhd, will complete some outstanding work before shutting down operations at the end of next month and resuming work in November. A company spokesman said the closure was to allow Kuala Lumpur City Hall to carry out beautification of roads in conjunction with 16th Commonwealth Games (Sukom '98) held between Sept 11 and 21. She said the other event requiring the company to cease its operations was the Asia Pacific Economic Co-operation (Apec) Summit to be held between Nov 14 and 17. She said the monorail project was far from being abandoned, with work including that for stations and piers going on at night. ``Opposite the Lot 10 Shopping Complex in Jalan Sultan Ismail, work is going on as we are putting up a station there,'' the spokesman said. ``There are several other areas where work on stations is being carried out, such as the Chow Kit station at the junction of Jalan Ipoh and Jalan Tuanku Abdul Rahman.'' She said some work was going on at the Wawasan station at the end of Jalan Sultan Ismail near the Vision City project on the fringe of Kampung Baru. Work is also ongoing at the P. Ramlee station near to the Concorde Hotel. ``The P. Ramlee station will be special because it will interface with the Putra-LRT where passengers can alight from the monorail and take the LRT at the Sultan Ismail (underground) station,'' she said. She said hoardings and barriers were still in place at Jalan Maharajalela and the junction where it met Jalan Hang Tuah as there was a station there. Work started in the areas in January last year. The spokesman said the rest of the work sites at Jalan Tuanku Abdul Rahman, Jalan Sultan Ismail and Jalan Hang Tuah (near the Pudu Jail) had been cleared. She said before halting work next month, the company would fill up all holes and remove hoardings at work sites as directed by City Hall. This is to allow the local authority to carry out resurfacing of the road. She added that when work resumed in November the company would decide on the new completion date for the RM1.9 billion project. The 16-km long monorail systemn will have 20 stations along the way. It begins at Jalan Tun Razak bus terminal passing through the city's Golden Triangle business dstrict and filling the ``gap'' between the LRT Sistem 1 and 2. The monorail will pass Jalan Tuanku Abdul Rahman, Jalan Sultan Ismail, Jalan Imbi, Jalan Hang Tuah, Jalan Maharajalela, Jalan Sultan Sulaiman, Jalan Tebing and follows the Sungai Klang alignment and ends at Kampung Pasir in Jalan Klang Lama. A section consisting of four PRT stations within the Golden Triangle is targetted for completion before the Commonwealth Games. The first phase consists of about eight kilometres between Jalan Tun Razak and Brickfields which will have 12 stations. Phase Two will have eight stations and a seven km track running from Brickfields to Kampung Pasir in Jalan Klang Lama. It is initially expected to be completed by the year 2000. The Government has agreed to give a RM300 million soft loan to KL-PRT Sdn Bhd, the concessionaire for the monorail system in Kuala Lumpur, to enable it to continue the project.

BC-South Africa-Ireland,0209
Mandela to visit both Irelands
PRETORIA, South Africa (AP) _ President Nelson Mandela said Friday that he would visit Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic after meeting with Ireland's foreign minister, David Andrews. ``I look forward to visiting ... to see for myself what has happened,'' Mandela was quoted on APTV video coverage as saying. Andrews said such a trip would be a ``wonderful boost'' to the peace process since the Irish benefited form South Africa's experience in dealing with a divided nation. On May 22, voters in Northern Ireland and in the Irish Republic overwhelmingly approved a peace settlement to end decades of strife between Protestants and Catholics. Leaders from both sides visited South Africa in the years leading up to the settlement to hear how South Africans are dealing with a society that used to be split along racial lines. Mandela's African National Congress officials were invited by Sinn Fein, the political wing of the rebel Irish Republican Army, in the month before the May referendum. They shared their experience in convincing grassroots supporters to accept the negotiated settlement that led to South Africa's first all-race elections in 1994.

DEPUTY Prime Minister and Finance Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim will announce the names of the members of the board of directors and management of Pengurusan Dana Harta Nasional (Danaharta) or Asset Management Co (AMC) soon. AMC chief executive officer Azman Yahya said the AMC will comprise a managing director (a portfolio that he will hold), a chairman and seven non-executive directors. Three of the seven non-executive directors will be from the private sector, two will represent the Government and the other two will come from the international community. ``The independent board and management of the AMC will be responsible and accountable for the agency's operations,'' he said in Kuala Lumpur yesterday. Azman was speaking at his first press conference since his appointment as AMC chief executive officer two weeks ago. Anwar had on May 20 announced the establishment of the AMC, an agency which will acquire non-performing loans (NPLs) and assets from financial institutions. Azman said the AMC's fundamental task will be the rehabilitation and value maximisation of the loan assets it acquires at a fair market value. The NPLs and other assets will be acquired from financial institutions following due diligence reviews to establish the quality of the assets and their estimated recoverability. It aims to have a balanced portfolio which will include property. Asked whether the portfolio will also include tolled road projects, Azman said: ``At this time we have not evaluated any such project.'' The due diligence review will ensure that only assets which need strict criteria are acquired by the agency, and that the price to be paid is set at a fair value reflecting existing specific conditions of the assets to be acquired. The due diligence process will also ensure that the agency has sufficient information to assume responsibility for effective management of the newly acquired assets. This means that assets will be segmented according to market-driven characteristics, such as special industrial sectors, project types and other characteristics, which will assist the agency in focusing the appropriate technical skills, experience and resources on the maximisation of asset values. Experts in reconstruction, rehabilitation and recovery of distressed borrowers will be recruited by the agency to match the composition of the acquired assets. The specific characteristics of the loans and assets acquired by the agency will drive, as in any market-focused enterprise, the resolution structure and timetable for the rehabilitation of the asset. The agency's asset disposal process will be implemented according to a planned and measured programme, guided by detailed soundings of purchaser requirements for fair and transparent resolution mechanisms. Azman said the AMC's life cycle will depend on the assets it acquires and on its asset specific resolution and workout plan. It is reasonable to expect a longer term of operation for the AMC, he said, adding that it can be operational for more than 10 years. He also said the AMC will have its own building in future. At present, the AMC operates out of Bank Negara.

BC-Salvador-Cuba,0294
Salvador government blocks sister city effort
By EDITH BELTRAN Associated Press Writer
SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador (AP) _ A plan to make sister cities of the Cuban and Salvadoran capitals has turned into more of a family feud. President Armando Calderon Sol announced Thursday that his government would not allow a visit by Havana Mayor Conrado Martinez, who was invited by San Salvador Mayor Hector Silva as part of a sister city project. Calderon Sol's party supported a war against pro-Cuban leftist rebels in the 1980s. Silva was elected in a coalition that includes those former leftists, now a political party. ``We are brothers of the Cuban people, but what impedes foreign relations is the line of the government'' of Cuba's President Fidel Castro, Calderon Sol said in remarks published by newspapers here Friday. The hard-line Interior Minister, Mario Acosta, was even more blunt earlier: ``No Cuban enters.'' The Foreign Ministry issued a statement saying the central government _ not the city's _ was responsible for foreign affairs and noting the El Salvador has ``asked the Cuban government to make advances toward democracy.'' ``We want to see a democratic government, not political prisoners,'' it said. That left former rebel commander Facundo Guardado, now a member of San Salvador's city council, sputtering Friday. The government behavior was outrageous, he said. ``They know that large Salvadoran investors are operating in Cuba. The position they are adopting now is absurd.'' City spokesman Juan Jose Dalton said the sister city agreement would go forward _ but would be signed in Havana instead. He insisted the pact is not diplomatic, merely cultural and social.

BC-South Africa-Botha Trial, 2nd Ld-Writethru,0632
Botha wrestled with old foe Tutu during past week
AP Photos GEO101-103 Eds: RECASTS with background. No pickup By PAUL HARRIS Associated Press Writer
GEORGE, South Africa (AP) _ Testimony from a member of South Africa's black liberation struggle ended a week of courtroom drama Friday in which a simple contempt case has turned into an inquest of ultimate responsibility for apartheid's atrocities. Nicknamed the ``Great Crocodile,'' P.W. Botha led the country during the worst reprisals of white minority rule that saw 30,000 black activists detained and thousands more killed. This week, he faced the moral might of an old foe _ Nobel laureate Desmond Tutu, head of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, the anti-apartheid leader who during decades of struggle rallied world support against minority white rule. Botha, 82, is charged with ignoring three subpoenas to appear before the Truth Commission, which is probing atrocities committed during apartheid. Since the first democratic elections in 1994, Botha has insisted he has nothing to apologize for. Testimony given by former underlings over the past week publicized events and behavior that Botha hoped to sidestep by refusing to appear before the panel. Death squad commander Eugene de Kock _ now serving 212 years in jail for murders committed while he was a security branch member _ scorned top officials like Botha for trying to wash their hands of the violence. ``They want to eat lamb but they don't want to see the blood and the guts,'' said de Kock, whose ruthlessness earned him the nickname Prime Evil. The prosecution focused on allegations that Botha and the shadowy State Security Council, which he headed, coordinated the crackdown on anti-apartheid activists and directly ordered bombings and killings. Cross examining Tutu, Botha's lawyer Lappe Laubscher said there were no direct assassination orders in any of the Council's minutes, indicating the killings were the work of ``bad apples'' in the police and army who misunderstood orders. An angry Tutu objected. ``How many `bad apples' are you going to concede?'' he asked. ``No, no. We cannot now say that these are `bad apples.' They are people who were sitting on the State Security council.'' At the end of his testimony Friday, Tutu make a final bid to extract an apology from Botha in his quest to help the country heal past divides. He directed the statement to the courtroom. ``Can he bring himself to say he's sorry?'' Tutu said. ``That would be a tremendous thing, and I appeal to him.'' For the Truth Commission, pursuing Botha has become a key issue in gathering information about the SSC and deflecting criticism from many blacks who say the panel is too soft on the former oppressor. However, after the adjournment, Tutu repeated his regret that the case had to come to court. ``There is no gloating,'' he said ``The TRC is not a vampire out for blood.'' Afterwards, Botha marched across the court chamber to have an animated and angry conversation in Afrikaans with prosecutor Bruce Morrison, out of hearing distance of reporters. His only comment for the media was that they should read three books, including his biography, to understand him. The case was adjourned until June 15, when both sides will summarize their findings. Botha faces a hefty fine or even two years in prison if convicted. Botha was forced to resign in 1989 after 11 years as head of state by ill health and National Party leaders who disagreed with his strong arm tactics. His successor, President F.W. de Klerk, freed Nelson Mandela after 27 years in prison. Mandela's African National Congress won the 1994 elections.

BC-Germany-Train Derails, 5th Ld-Writethru
What the passengers heard: crash probe focuses on broken wheel
EDS: AMs; UPDATES with statement from federal railway authority, 57 still hospitalized, half of trains back in service By TONY CZUCZKA Associated Press Writer
ESCHEDE, Germany (AP) _ The reason for the noise that rattled some passengers minutes before InterCity Express 884 smashed into a bridge is now clear: investigators confirmed Friday that a broken wheel was the most likely cause of derailment and disaster. The damaged wheel was located on the first car behind the locomotive. Investigators didn't have to go far to find the fractured steel rim that encircles the wheel, and helps keep the train on the tracks. It had flown off and was lodged in the bogie, the set of four wheels at each end of a car. Another clue: A still unidentified piece of the train was found on the tracks six kilometers (3.7 miles) from the concrete and steel bridge that the fifth car struck broadside. That piece _ and damage to both the rail and ties nearby _ corroborates passengers' recollections of noise and vibration two minutes before the derailed train starting breaking apart and crashed into supports for an overpass. At 200 kph (125 mph) the train would have traveled the distance in less than two minutes. ``There was an uncomfortable rattling and I had the feeling that maybe something was lying on the tracks,'' Wolf-Ruediger Shliebener recalled. ``People looked at each other, shocked.'' He said it stopped for a second. Then there was a crash. It still isn't clear what knocked down the bridge. A broadcast report suggested that the fifth car, the last to get past the falling bridge, had knocked down a support. But federal railway spokesman Jens Boehlke said it was conceivable that the first car had struck a support, and that the deck had not fallen down on the speeding train until several cars had gotten through.The seven remaining passenger cars and rear locomotive then jacknifed into each other, More than 1,200 rescuers using jackhammers, cranes and cutting tools worked around the clock to free survivors the first day, then increasingly victims as they worked their way deeper into the tangle of metal and shattered glass. A body was recovered Friday under a 10-meter piece of road that had fallen next to the train, raising the death toll to 96. Rescue workers said they could not rule out the possibility that other bodies would be found until the debris was cleared from the four-track line. By Friday evening, 19 victims had been identified and 57 people were still hospitalized. The wheel theory has not yet been proven, but is the focus of investigators' questions. Still unexplained is whether the wheel suffered metal fatigue, or some outside force. ``We are extremely interested in researching the cause for the break in the tire, and we will of course go after this with special intensity,'' authorities said in a statement. Boehlke said that in the seven years the high-speed InterCity Express trains have been in service, there has been no similar break or failure in the wheels. An investigation _ being conducted by a special commission of police, rail and other experts and supervised by prosecutors _ may take months to complete, he added. It will include interviews of surviving passengers and rail personnel as well as maintenance workers. The federal railway authority, which sets standards for safety and service, issued a statement that said sabotage has not been ruled out. However, no one has produced any evidence that suggests any tampering. ``Any suggestion of the cause of the accident at this point is speculative,'' the statement added. Joachim Haack, police spokesman at Eschede, said the findings pointed to a mechanical reason. The crushed train was one of the first generation of high-speed trains introduced in Germany in 1991. The other 59 trains in that group were taken out of service Thursday night for emergency inspections, and half had returned to duty by Friday evening. Steel tires require regular inspection and replacement because of wear. Typically, a new tire is expanded by heating it red hot, then it is slipped over the wheel disc and shrinks tightly to fit, said Richard Gibbon, curator of engineers at the National Railway Museum in York, England. British high-speed trains may clock 1.5 million miles a year, but the tires may wear out in 100,000 miles, Gibbon said. Trains in the United States use a solid wheel with no removable tire, he added. MALACCA, Thurs. - National Economic Action Council executive director Tun Daim Zainuddin today reminded State Governments to carry out development plans that could assist the Federal Government overcome the economic problems. He said proposals and programmes to enhance agricultural productivity and the tourism sector, for instance, should be implemented without delay. Daim, who is also Economic Adviser to the Government, said he did not want the plans ``to be on paper only'' but must be implemented immediately. Chief Minister Datuk Seri Abu Zahar Isnin said Daim touched on this during the State-level NEAC meeting here today. The two-hour meeting, chaired by Abu Zahar, was also attended by State executive councillors, heads of departments and industrialists. Abu Zahar said the State Government would revive the agriculture sector by giving grants to the relevant authorities and agencies to identify land for agricultural activity. ``Daim wants the Malacca Government to place emphasis not only on industrial development but also on tourism and agriculture sectors.'' Abu Zahar, who is also State NEAC chairman, said Daim wanted the State Government to re-develop agriculture land for commercial farming. ``I have directed the authorities to gazette agriculture land such as padi fields. No form of development, except agriculture, will take place on this land.'' To complement the effort, he said, a 300ha land in Selandar had been identified as the State's agriculture park. Aquaculture activity such as fish and prawn breeding will also be expanded. ``We will pay more attention to these activities by upgrading the infrastructure.''

JOCKEY Ng Kim Chor, whose suspension of six months was increased to one year after the Penang Turf Club (PTC)'s Racing Stewards' reviewed their own decision for second offenders, will be back in action in Ipoh this weekend. The Penangite has successful applied for an injunction three weeks ago and the additional six months suspension imposed by the PTC's Racing Stewards has been put aside until the case is heard by the court. The PTC's Racing Stewards reviewed Ng's case after he had completed four of his six months suspension for his handling of Imperial Scholar and suspended him for one year under Rule 39 for second offenders. The episode started in July when Ng was originally charged under Rule 144(a) and a 12-month disqualification was passed for his handling of Imperial Scholar. Ng was penalised for failing to ride the Charles Leck-trained Imperial Scholar on merit. The particulars of the charge being that from the top of the home straight, at appromimately the 400m mark until the 200m mark, he failed to make sufficient attempt to improve his horse's position when there were opportunities to do so. Furthermore, in the final stages of the race, he failed to ride with his normal vigour. Ng's appeal was heard in Ipoh on Aug 30 and after considering all the evidence and submissions, the Racing Stewards were of the opinion that a case under Rule 144(a) could not be made but there was a breach of Rule 144(b)(i) and as such amended the charge and found Ng guilty under the provisions of Rule 144(b)(i) and was suspended six months. The PTC reviewed Ng's case under Rule 39 after he had served four of the six months' suspension and the two-time champion jockey staged a sensational walkout, which was precipitated by the Racing Stewards' dismissal of several preliminary issues raised by his counsel, C.P. Mahendran.

BC-Sports-Golf-English Open
Patrik Sjoland, Stephen Leaney share lead
WARE, England (AP) _ Patrik Sjoland of Sweden and Australia's Stephen Leaney tied for the lead Friday after two rounds of the English Open, 9-under par on the 7,017-yard Marriott Hanbury Manor layout. Scotland's Colin Montgomerie, the first-round leader, slipped a stroke off the lead after shooting a par-72. Also in at 8-under was Ryder Cup teammate Lee Westwood of England and France's Fabrice Tarnaud. Westwood shot 68 and Tarnaud had a 66. Leaney, who finished with a 69, looked like he was going to take the lead outright but bogeyed the final hole and settled for the tie. Sjoland, who shot 67 to go with an opening 68, has been playing some of Europe's best golf lately. The 27-year-old Swede had five top-eight finishes in the last six tournaments of 1997 and in the past five weeks has won the Italian Open and tied for runner-up to Montgomerie in last month's Volvo PGA Championship. He has yet to play in a major and he's not playing in the U.S. Open, but on Sunday night he could be Europe's leading money winner. ``I feel more relaxed now I've got my first title and it's fun,'' said Sjoland, the latest in a steady stream of strong Swedish players. ``This is what I've been practicing for since I was a little kid and to finally get up there is great.'' BC-Sports-Cricket-England-South Africa, 2nd Ld-Writethru
England bowled out for 462
Eds: UPDATES with stumps score By IHITHISHAM KAMARDEEN Associated Press Writer
BIRMINGHAM, England (AP) _ England was bowled out for 462 one minute before stumps on day two in the first cricket test at Edgbaston when tail-ender Angus was caught by South African skipper Hanse Cronje. Fraser and Darren Gough, unbeaten on 16, frustrated the South Africans for 27 minutes and scored 25 runs. Medium paceman Gough, who took a painful blow to his right index finger while batting, went for a precautionary x-ray for a suspected break. South Africa's decision to put England into bat badly backfired. The Proteas now find themselves trying to save the game on a pitch that is beginning to produce the occasional low bounce. England's innings revolved around a brilliant century by former skipper Michael Atherton and some invaluable middle order contributions from Alec Stewart and Mark Ramprakash, who made 49 apiece, and Nasser Hussain (35). Resuming the day on 249 for one, England made painstakingly slow progress against an attack that had been culpable and costly on the first day, but showed more discipline Friday. England scored 72 before lunch and 61 in the second session. None of the batsmen could make much of the ginger-haired Shaun Pollock, who moved the ball alarmingly, but was rewarded with just two wickets for 92 from 35 overs. An outstanding delivery, a swinging yorker, accounted for Graham Thorpe, sending the left hander's middle stump cart-wheeling. England, 382 for six at tea, lost Ramprakash to the first ball with the third new ball taken in the 170th over. The score was at 411 for six. Fast bowler Allan Donald, sidelined for most of the day with a niggling ankle injury, clipped Ramprakash's off bail, after the right hander had held the middle order together. Ramprakash's 194-minute stay included a 55-run stand with Cork for the seventh wicket, after Mark Ealham (five) helped him add 27 runs for the sixth. Cork, fell to a top edged cut to third man after a 61-minute break for rain, before becoming first of Donald's two wickets in successive balls. Donald claimed Cork with the last ball of his 32nd over and had Robert Croft caught behind with the first ball of his next to finish with 4-95 in 35 overs. After losing Atherton to the 10th ball of the morning, Stewart and Nasser Hussain added 60 runs for the third wicket before a mini collapse checked England's progress. England lost 3-27 in 10 overs before and after lunch. In the space of five balls, Stewart and Hussain fell to medium paceman Lance Klusener and left-arm wrist spinner Paul Adams. Stewart, who had advanced swiftly from 28 to 40, suddenly became bogged down and he needed 30 deliveries to score just nine runs. An edge to first slip Cullinan off a Klusener delivery put him out of his misery. Adams was the pick of South Africa's bowlers claiming 3-73 in 35 overs, which included a 17-over spell that cost him 26 runs on either side of lunch when he claimed Hussain and Mark Ealham. Donald snared the wicket of Atherton, caught behind with his fourth ball of his first over. Atherton, having remained characteristically impassive on the first day, failed to add to his overnight 103, and edged a catch to wicket keeper Mark Boucher. According to South African team physiotherapist Craig Smith, Donald took the field after an injection on a troubled left ankle, a recurrence of an injury that had troubled him in Australia early this year. World Cup: Azzurri slip into France
GOUVEIUEUX, France (AP) _ Three-time World Cup champion Italy slipped into France relatively quietly Friday, whisked away from the Charles de Gaulle Airport by bus to their luxurious accommodation at a castle-turned-hotel about 45 kilometers (30 miles) from the French capital. One of the favorites for France '98, the Azzurri were bade farewell at Rome by a crowd of about 200, mostly teen-agers, and the players toasted themselves with spumante, wishing good luck. The 50-person delegation arrived by Alitalia charter and boarded a bus near the plane to a location to clear customs. Photograpers and other media members were kept away by police. The team then quickly moved onto their hotel, which the Italian federation is paying 1.1 billion lire (dlrs 611,000) to house the players during their stay. The chateau is surrounded by a large park and a forest, has security at the main entrance and offers a golf course, swimming pools and tennis courts. The team is scheduled to go through their accreditation process at the hotel Saturday morning before staging their first training session in the afternoon at the Sports Center of Senlis, about 30 kilometers (20 miles) from its hotel. The Italian team announced that it had cancelled a Sunday scrimmage with a local amateur team.

MALACCA, Thurs. - Two men, whose bodies were found in a car at a roadblock at the 100km Kuantan-Segamat highway on Tuesday, were believed to have been murdered over a failed business transaction with a group of Singaporean businessmen. One of the victims has been identified as Syarikat Latem Metal Industry Sdn Bhd manager Chai Cheon Keat Peter, 30. Police declined to identify the other victim - a Singaporean. The 30-year-old foreigner, who police initially thought was a local, was a director of the Malacca-based company. Police have arrested two Singaporeans, including another director of the company in connection with the killing, and have requested assistance from Interpol to facilitate investigations. State police chief Senior Assistant Commissioner I Arthur Edmonds said today initial investigations have revealed that Chai and the Singaporean were killed over business matters pertaining to their company. The victims may have had a falling out with their Singaporean partners over the company's operations before they were killed, he said. ``We are also intrigued and puzzled as to why the bodies of Chai and the Singaporean were taken on a 300km ride to Kuantan when there are indications they were murdered at a house in Taman Cheng Perdana in Malacca. ``Transporting the bodies of the murdered victims in a car in broad daylight is really puzzling,'' said Edmonds in a telephone interview. On Tuesday, a routine check at a police roadblock near the junction to Bandar Muadzam Shah led to the discovery of the bodies of the two men in a Kuantan-bound Toyota Corolla about 3.30pm. The body of one of the victims who had a stab wound in the chest, was found wrapped in a blanket in the boot of the Malacca-registered car while the other, believed to have been strangled, was found in the rear seat. Police arrested the car driver and a passenger, both Singaporeans. It is learnt that in a follow-up operation, two other cars were seized at a house in Taman Cheng Perdana, several hours after the bodies were discovered. Blood stains were believed to have been found at the house. The bodies are being kept at the Muadzam Shah Hospital in Pahang pending completion of police investigations.

STOCKS slid into the close on Wednesday, once again failing to sustain an early advance as the market remained handcuffed by worries about company profits. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 87.44 points - or one per cent - to 8,803.80, turning lower late in the session for the second straight day. Broader stock indexes also surrendered early gains and then fell sharply over the final 90 minutes. Without any major developments to clarify the uncertain outlook on company profits, analysts say it's unlikely the market will break out of its two-month rut any time soon. While demand for stocks has remained strong enough to interrupt any steep slide, the market has also been unable to build much momentum amid mounting worries over how much the economic problem in Asia is hurting US companies. The Standard and Poor's 500 fell 10.29 to 1,082.74, and the technology- heavy Nasdaq composite index fell 19.69 to 1,742.10. Declining issues outnumbered advancers by a 9-to-8 margin on the New York Stock Exchange, with 1,409 up, 1,594 down and 541 unchanged. NYSE volume totalled 576.52 million shares against 589.22 million in the previous session. The NYSE composite index fell 3.92 to 561.43, and the American Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.82 to 704.48.

ANKARA, Turkey (AP) _ A U.S. citizen arrested in connection with the smuggling of ancient Turkish artifacts was released on bail, the U.S. Embassy said Friday. Derek Fox, 42, was arrested Thursday along with four Turks, after one of the Turks tried to sell artifacts to undercover police posing as buyers, authorities said. Fox, a civilian employee at the Incirlik air base, paid a 200 million lira (dlrs 800) bail, according to the Anatolia news agency. Police said he is suspected of overseeing the smuggling to the United States, but the embassy said he had not been charged. Fox was initially identified as a U.S. Air Force major, but a U.S. Embassy official said he was working in Turkey as a civilian despite being a reserve major. His hometown was not available. More than 45 U.S. and British planes and 1,400 people are based in Incirlik as part of the ``Operation Northern Watch'' mission which patrols the no-fly zone north of Iraq's 36th parallel. (ht/djw)

IN his speech at the Conference on a Social Agenda for the Next Millennium, organised by the National Unity and Social Development Ministry, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim correctly criticised university-level economics education in the country. In the context of the conference he was opening, he could have highlighted the limited attention given to welfare and distribution issues. Unfortunately, his informants wrongly advised him when he went on yet another of his anti-Marxist tirades, attacking another ghost of their own imagination. Regardless of the renewed interest in many parts of the world in Marxist economic analysis, especially in the wake of recent economic developments, it is quite well known that there have never been courses on Marxist economics ever offered in this country's universities. In fact, there is little offered beyond rudimentary neo-classical economics. Even economist John Maynard Keynes has been effectively purged over the last couple of decades, much to our loss. Hence, there has been little intellectually-sound discussion in Malaysia articulated against the rising tide of economic neo-liberalism since the 1980s, in various guises, including Reaganomics, Thatcherism, supply-side economics, etc. Sadly, it has only been the painful trauma of the crisis since mid-1997 which has opened up new debates at the international level and forced us out of our previous smug self-satisfaction. Anwar is right that we have to keep up with the new thinking in economics, as in other areas. But if we refuse to learn from history, we will be condemned to repeat it. Keynes once noted that dead men continue to influence economic practices through their intellectual legacies. One might add that the fact that they are dead is rarely decisive in determining their contemporary relevance. Let us come to grips with our problems and not waste time fighting the windmills of some paranoid speech-writer's mind.

NEWS about Muslims the world over these days do not apparently present a true picture of Islam. Thus do they provide grist to the mill for such as Salman Rushdie and V.S. Naipaul, described as ``Uncle Tom'' writers by Dr Farish A. Noor. Once published in the Singapore Free Press in February 1951 was a news item translated from Utusan Melayu with the heading ``Muslims told not to draw living things''. The story: ``Drawings or paintings of humans and animals are against the teachings of Islam. This was stated by Maulana Abdul Alam Siddiqi, a Muslim theologian at the ninth general meeting of the Muslim Missionary Society recently, in reply to a question by a member who asked whether it was proper for Muslim pupils to draw living things. ``If drawing was taught in Muslim schools, the authorities there should be prevailed upon from including such drawings in the curriculum,'' the Maulana added. The advice was not heeded as even then comic books, cartoon films and comic strips in newspapers were enjoyed by everyone. No Muslims become idolatrous. Weightier matters crop up now. There is, for example, the allegation by the All Women's Action Society (Awam) of gender bias by the Syariah Court in Alor Star after sentencing on a 17-year-old boy and two girls, one 15 and the other 18. The boy was fined RM1,000 but the girls were sentenced to three years detention for ostensibly committing the same crime and in the same place. Zaiton Mohamad Kasim, the society's spokesperson, said the three years of detention during the formative years of the two girls would leave an indelible scar on them. There is then the serious issue of apostasy or murtad. Published in Harakah, the official organ of Pas, was a complaint that a private Bill which the party had drafted on the matter had not been tabled for debate in Parliament. The matter was cleared up later by Datuk Dr Abdul Hamid Othman, Minister in the Prime Minister's Department, who disclosed that a law on apostasy being drawn up would focus on rehabilitative and preventive measures. Quote: ``The law will not be punishment-oriented but lay emphasis on how to prevent apostasy and handle reported cases.'' The matter was being discussed at length by Federal and State authorities, and the proposed Bill would also clarify provisions in the constitution. In the meanwhile, Pusat Islam is taking measures to check apostate cases discreetly due to sensitivities as Malaysia is a multi-racial and multi- religious country, the Minister explained further. As mentioned by a noted Muslim scholar, Ziauddin Sardar, there is no mention at all in the Quran about punishment for apostasy. Surely to be considered is the position of the newly-converted, including those married to Muslims. How would the matter be resolved if, for example, the wife is divorced and then returns to her former religion? To be looked into also would be the status of Muslims in non-Muslim majority societies as in Thailand, the Philippines, Singapore or India. These and other matters help to explain why commentaries on Islamic issues in Malay newspapers, especially tabloids, are more pungent and emotional. And there are constant reminders about the wrath of God. Reported at length in Mingguan Malaysia recently was an incident in a Kuala Lumpur mosque before Friday prayers when a religious lecturer uttered the epithet kepala bapak (literal translation ``his father's head'') in reference to a persistent critic. The report was headlined ``Mosque used to sound off grudge...'' Apparently the critic had earlier on blamed ``mercenary lecturers'' for making facile commentaries on the economic woes facing the country and the water crisis affecting areas in the Klang Valley. One had even claimed that they were part of divine punishment following the dismissal of a senior religious official! But as is also known there is drought in certain areas in Kelantan too. No less controversial is the case of a Singapore couple, Abdul Rahim Salim, 39, and his French-born wife Rahimah Abdullah (formely Helen Vernet), 32. Both had demanded an apology from the Kelantan State Religious Department (Jabatan Agama Islam Kelantan or JAIK) following a raid by its officials on the premises which they had rented in Kota Baru despite giving prior notice on their marital status. Their visit to the State was because Rahimah wanted to study Islam, the syariah laws and their application in depth. ``She was advised that Kelantan is more Islam than any other State in Malaysia,'' one report explained. Kelantan Menteri Besar Datuk Nik Abdul Aziz Nik Mat was later quoted as saying that the State Religious Department had received incorrect information on the status of the Singapore couple. An apology was, therefore, in order. Reflected in all these, amid frequent reference to the wrath of the Almighty, is the officiousness of certain religious officials and the holier-than-thou attitude of some others towards fellow-Muslims. There is incessant emphasis on punishment now and in the hereafter when, in fact, in innumerable instances, the ordinary Muslim begins with Bismillah, in the name of God, Most Merciful and Most Compassionate. Helping to provide insight would be a visit to Afghanistan where the Taliban religious police have tightened regulations. Some 120 men have been punished for trimming their beards and 90 women for not veiling themselves properly. Punishments were meted by the Department for Prevention of Vice and Promotion of Virtues, according to the Taliban Voice of Syariah radio station in Kabul. Under the stringent regulations, women are forbidden from taking taxis unless accompanied by a male blood relative. They are also barred from wearing jewellery and high-heeled shoes. Violators are lashed with a leather strap and a Taliban policeman was seen to lash a woman five times for exposing an ankle and wearing high- heeled shoes. As officially proclaimed, Taliban authorities want to make Afghanistan the world's ``purest Islamic State''. But, as is also known, even Iran has expressed misgivings over the way the syariah laws are being applied there. Inferred too is whether what is being practised in really Islamic. More Afghans have been killed in the country's civil war than by the Soviets during their invasion. There are now some two million orphans in the country. Compounding problems are the natural disasters which have befallen the country and its people. Over 5,000 were killed in a massive earthquake earlier this week. Some 3,500 died in an earthquake last February and 1,500 more in February 1991. The despatch of food supplies, medicines and other necessities from several countries, including non-Muslim, has been swift and prompt. It would not do for us to merely extend condolences and sympathies, and talk about the wrath of God.

Akinwande-Holyfield fight called off
Eds: RECASTS throughout. Will be UPDATED after news conference, scheduled for 2000 GMT. By TIM DAHLBERG AP Sports Writer
NEW YORK (AP) _ Evander Holyfield never really wanted to fight Henry Akinwande. Now he won't have to. The heavyweight title fight was called off Friday, a day before the bout, because Akinwande tested positive for hepatitis B. Heavyweight Ray Mercer was also scratched from the card for undisclosed medical reasons, and Christy Martin's opponent can't fight because she's pregnant. Promoters scheduled a Friday afternoon news conference to discuss whether the card will go forward at all, with aging Roberto Duran the remaining attraction. Two separate medical tests on Akinwande by the New York State Athletic Commission showed he had hepatitis B, said Greg Fritz, a spokesman for Don King Productions, the promoter of the fight. ``The fight is off,'' Fritz said. The commission does not allow infected boxers to fight because of the risk of transmitting the disease through blood during bouts. Hepatitis B, often contracted through sex or dirty hypodermic needles, can cause serious liver problems. The disease can be treated successfully, but not always. Hepatitis A is typically a food-borne disease that can pass quickly. The Showtime network, which was to televise the bout from Madison Square Garden, also said in a statement that the main event had been canceled due to the commission's medical finding. The fight was supposed to top a card that included the 46-year-old Duran fighting for a title nine years after he lost his middleweight crown to Sugar Ray Leonard. Duran first fought in the Garden in 1971, and is 6-1 in his career at the arena. On Thursday, Mexican lightweight Maria de las Nieves Garcia was scratched from her undercard bout with Christy Martin because she's pregnant. Melissa Salamore was to have replaced Garcia, but Martin rejected her as an opponent and promoters were trying to find another fighter. The Akinwande decision is yet another blow to his once-promising career. He was disqualified in the fifth round of a fight last July against WBC champ Lennox Lewis for repeated holding. That Akinwande was even supposed to fight for a piece of the title for the second time in less than a year was due more to his choice of promoter than anything else. After the Lewis debacle, promoter Don King matched him against Orlin Norris Jr., and Akinwande won a 12-round decision to become the mandatory contender. Akinwande was to make dlrs 2.5 million to fight Holyfield, who was to get dlrs 10 million for the defense of the WBA title he won in his first fight with Mike Tyson. Holyfield had wanted to fight Lewis to unify the heavyweight championship for the first time since Riddick Bowe threw the WBC belt into a garbage can after his win over Holyfield in their first fight. But with Holyfield wanting dlrs 20 million for the fight and Lewis unwilling to give up his relationship with the HBO network, talks collapsed and Holyfield was left only with the option of taking a mandatory title defense to keep his WBA title. He was openly unenthusiastic about fighting Akinwande, who is 33-1-1, and almost nobody but Akinwande and the WBA wanted it. ``There's no other reason for this fight other than he's ranked No. 1,'' Holyfield said before the fight was canceled. ``That's just what the rules are.'' Duran, like Akinwande, hardly earned his title shot, winning a decision in Panama in his last fight after getting knocked down in the first round.

KUALA LUMPUR, Thurs. - Land and Co-operative Development Minister Datuk Osu Sukam will be appointed Sabah Deputy Chief Minister and Finance Minister. Confirming this today, Deputy Prime Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim said the appointment would take effect from Monday. Speaking at a Press conference to announce details of the Pengurusan Danaharta Nasional Bhd at the Finance Ministry, Anwar said Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad had agreed to the appointment. ``Datuk Osu will resign (from his Federal post) before Monday,'' he said when asked by reporters to confirm news report today that Osu had resigned. Osu is the Sabah Umno liaison committee chairman, MP for Papar as well as the Kawang State Assemblyman. He is taking up the post vacated by Datuk Ghapur Salleh who declined to be reappointed when the State Cabinet was reshuffled following the appointment of Tan Sri Bernard Dompok as Chief Minister of Sabah. On Osu's replacement, Anwar said the matter was the prerogative of Dr Mahathir as Prime Minister. He declined to comment on whether former Chief Minister and Kota Belud MP Datuk Salleh Said would replace Osu. Meanwhile, Bernama quotes Osu as saying he is returning to State politics to further strengthen the Barisan Nasional for the next State election. ``This is what the party leadership wants after taking into account what has happened and it is an important duty in the interests of the party and Sabah,'' he said in an interview. He said he would make full use of his 12 years' experience at the Federal level, including four as a Cabinet Minister, which had matured him, especially in viewing each issue from the national angle and not from the State or narrow angle. Osu said his experience as a Cabinet Minister under Dr Mahathir's leadership was valuable and an honour, and had honed his administrative skills and matured his thinking. ``Where previously, before to coming to Kuala Lumpur, I had thought only of what was good for Sabah, now I am more matured in looking at the needs of a multiracial society,'' he said. ``We must not be narrow-minded in thinking only what is good for ourselves, our community or race ... the interests of others must also be considered,'' he said.

THE Malaysian Handball Association were the only national association who have yet to register with the office of the Commissioner of Sports. Under the Sports Development Act 1997, all sports bodies who previously were registered with the Registrar of Societies had to transfer their registration to the Commissioner. Deadline for the new registration which was extended by two months ended on May 31. The other 72 national sports bodies were among the 761 or 65 percent of the sports bodies and associations in West Malaysia who registered with the Commisioner. Said Sports Minister Tan Sri Muhyiddin Yassin, ``Those who are not registered with the Commissioner are not allowed to oganise or compete in any activities. ``However, being sports friendly, these associations can still send their applications to the Commissioner. However, they must give concrete reasons for delaying their application.'' He said sports bodies and associations, who have failed to submit their applications to the Sports Commissioner's office, would be considered not in existence and not eligible to receive financial allocations from the Government. ``They will also be not allowed to organise, participate or represent Malaysia in any sporting event,'' he said after witnessing the handing over of files of sports organisations by the Registrar of Societies to the Sports Commissioner's Office. The Registrar of Societies, Mohiyaddin Mohamed Jan, the Commissioner of Sports, Datuk Ahmad Bakri Shabdin who is also Secretary General the Sports Ministry, and Deputy Home Minister Datuk Ong Ka Ting attended the function. Giving a breakdown of the registered sports bodies, Muhyiddin said 72 of them were national sports bodies, 358 state-level organisations while 331 were district sports associations and organisations. ``According to the law the associations who failed to register are not legitmate. We had already given sufficient reminders to them. Now we will establish their status,'' he said. Muhyiddin believed many of the sports associations and organisations took the registration requirement lightly and there were also those who had failed to hold their meetings and were inactive. The Act did not affect sports organisation in Labuan, Sabah and Sarawak. Muhyiddin said a national sports convention would be held as soon as possible to discuss the future direction and method of how the administration and development of sports in the country should be planned and implemented.

A COUNTRY'S competitive edge in the next millennium, as we have often been reminded, will no longer be determined by traditional elements such as natural resources and labour-capital ratio. Instead, it will depend much on the level of technological skills and research and development ability. Ingenuity and creativity will be the deciding factors in the era of information technology and globalisation. Thus, the importance of education and training cannot be overemphasised in Malaysia's effort to achieve industrialised nation status by the year 2020. It is heartening that while in the present difficult times a reduced national Budget poses a challenge to the authorities, there is awareness that the country cannot afford to neglect these two vital areas in the critical Seventh Malaysia Plan (1996-2000). This is taking cognizance of the fact that Malaysia is facing a shortage of technical and scientific manpower. The Education Ministry's Thursday announcement that a total of 42,584 government school candidates who sat for the Sijil Pelajaran Malaysia last year have been offered places in Form Six is undoubtedly a much welcomed move. While the sharp intake increase of almost 55 per cent over last year's figure is attributed to the large number of students opting to study locally and to better results, it is clear that the ministry is making every effort to accommodate as many eligible students as possible. All students who meet the minimum requirements will be allowed to enter Form Six. State education departments have been directed to co-ordinate the matter with schools. If necessary, adjustments will be made. With the rapid changes in the global environment, the ministry recognises the need to enhance the capability of the national education system to move in chorus with the demand of changes and new challenges, particularly in science and technology. The preponderance of science students over those in the Arts this time, 56.4 against 43.6 per cent, is in line with the effort to encourage more to enter this area of study. In the wake of the country's opening up of educational opportunities in both the public and private sectors, which is a right step in producing the skilled manpower required, it is imperative that quality be maintained at all times. Quality must never be sacrificed at the altar of quantity and pecuniary considerations. There can be no compromise in this if the nation wishes to turn its dream of making Malaysia an international centre of learning excellence into a reality. Malaysia must not go the way of some countries, including certain advanced ones, where the proliferation of worthless institutions of higher learning has tarnished otherwise fine reputations. Educationists are anxious to point out the significance of Form Six classes as they form the bridge between the secondary and tertiary levels of education. Besides adequate physical facilities and equipment, qualified and suitable teachers are essential in providing the students with the necessary foundation for higher studies. The Sijil Tinggi Persekolahan Malaysia examination is one of the toughest in our system and much is demanded of the teachers. There is a need to be well equipped through constant updating to ensure the essential breadth and depth for the challenging task of developing not just independent but critical thinking in their students. Therein lies the onerous task of the Education Ministry.
