Development of higher education system spurred more by profits, NEW STRAITS TIMES-MANAGEMENT TIMES
Development of higher education system spurred more by profits, NEW STRAITS TIMES-MANAGEMENT TIMES June 05, 1998 NEW STRAITS TIMES-MANAGEMENT TIMES MALAYSIA ENGLISH Rustam A. SaniASIA WorldSources, Inc. 201 PENNSYLVANIA AVENUE, S.E., 2nd Floor

OUR education system, especially at the post-school level, has become rather big, clumsy and unwieldy - and may have even grown out of hand. The administrative unit within the Ministry of Education that handles admissions to the local higher education institutions has just learned this. The variety of programmes available, the different entry level set for each programme, the types of entry qualifications recognised, the combination of subjects required, and other variables involved, are simply too much for the unit's sophisticated computers to handle. A debacle ensued in the process of offering places to students recently and the Minister of Education had to apologise publicly to applicants. For the moment, blame is conveniently placed at the door of the admissions unit for its ``lack of competence'' in dealing with the increase in the number of applicants and in managing the computer system - skills strangely enough it has increasingly mastered during at least two decades of doing the job. And it should be pointed out that the debacle took place just in the ``public'' portion of our higher education system. Admissions to the ``private'' portion - which I must add has become rather big in itself - are still left to each and every institution, without much interference from the ministry. The Minister of Education has also announced that the task of channelling candidates who failed to get a place in the recently completed admissions exercise to the private portion of the higher education system had been ``privatised'', and has been awarded to KUB. At this stage of co-ordination, another type of confusion may appear, that is disparities between the ``costs'' of public and private higher education. To clients who can afford private higher education, who purposely choose private over public education because of its ``quality'' and its links to foreign (therefore purportedly higher) standards, the disparities may not even be considered a problem. But with the amount of money available to the middle classes to throw around these days greatly reduced by the economic downturn and with the myth of the ``superiority'' of foreign higher education increasingly being questioned both on a theoretical level and at the performance level in the classrooms of the private colleges, the differences in costs could begin to appear much less justifiable. To those students who would be channelled into the private institutions because they could not be placed in the public higher education sector, the disparities in costs would certainly constitute a burden. Murmurs of protests are already heard, and Mara, among others, has already announced plans and additional allocations to help such students meet their financial obligations. The way that we have incorporated universities from other English- speaking countries of the world almost as an integral part of our own higher education system must have made us pioneers of sorts in the consumption of ``global education''. As demands for such global education continued to increase, backed by money made available by a robust economy, entrepreneurs as usual were quick to act to seize the opportunity to establish private colleges that would make such education locally available through a gamut of twinning and franchising arrangements. Today no less than 50 such ``colleges'' are in operation in this country - some large and impressive and backed by big capital, while others are more sekolah malam-like operations owned by smaller entrepreneurs but backed by strong political connections - offering a variety of degree programmes (no less than 200 in number) in conjunction with foreign universities, ranging from prestigious ones like London University to an unknown community college in some small town in Iowa. Burdened by the pressure of having to generate income under the privatisation and corporatisation policies of the Government, the local public universities too began to be involved in ``franchising'' their courses - more exactly in peddling their ``charter'' to award degrees - to similar private colleges. Initially it was mainly matriculation programmes that were franchised but these days even diploma and degree programmes are being peddled in the education franchising marketplace. It is claimed that some local universities have even franchised programmes that they do not offer themselves at their own campuses. That would be something akin to Macdonald's offering franchising for pesembor penang and yong tow foo to some local food stalls. All these unorthodox methods of peddling educational programmes raise a number of disquieting questions concerning standards - not only questions concerning the franchisees' ability to attain standards set by the franchisers, whose standards are themselves being questioned, but also questions of whether the franchisees are really getting the products that they are paying for and whether they themselves are really competent to resell the products. One interesting observation that can be made concerning all these ``educational'' developments is the predominance of purely business consideration - as opposed to some measure of social, intellectual and pedagogical considerations - in spurring them along. A highly prestigious foreign university has opened a branch campus in this country in co-operation with some local entrepreneurial interests. A local corporate group appears to be earnestly confident of its ability to replicate the educational and intellectual ambience of MIT of Boston in this country by simply pouring lots of money into establishing a college and by bringing over some of the institute's professors here for a short stay. Even the Government's stated desire to turn the country into a regional educational centre of excellence has been expressed mainly in business terms - to attract students from other countries in the region, and from outside the region too, to study here, pay their fees to our colleges in foreign currencies, and thereby help to develop our higher education infrastructure and our economy. The development of our higher education system which has become unnecessarily complex and unwieldy during the last few years has been basically spurred by the same profit motivation that encouraged housing and building developers to over-build, and thereby causing a glut in the property market. As the property market has often been used as an indicator of the state of our ``bubble'' economy before it burst under the impact of a global capital and financial market crisis earlier this year, it is therefore quite proper to consider the question: Did we also have an education bubble? Now that there is an marked increase in demands for ``public'' higher education and a widespread notion that the ``over-built'' private higher educational facilities do not actually produce the higher standards that they promised and that have become expected of them - and cost-wise they are generally becoming out-of-reach to the ordinary clients - one is also tempted to ask: Is the education bubble too about to burst? The writer, a former academic and researcher, is a sociologist and freelance writer.

KOTA BARU, Thurs. - Kelantan and Perak will join hands to curb smuggling and illegal transportation of undersized cockles. Kelantan Fisheries Department director Sani Mohd Isa said the Perak Fisheries Department had given its assurance to co-operate with Kelantan. He said the Perak Fisheries Department would intensify checks against vehicles, especially lorries, leaving the State. ``It is found that those involved in the smuggling and illegal transportation of the undersized cockles are lorry drivers,'' he said, adding that the cockles were brought to Kelantan before being smuggled into the neighbouring country. He said four cases were reported over the past three days and six people, four of them lorry drivers, were arrested in Jeli, Rantau Panjang and Tanah Merah during routine checks.Also 635 gunny sacks of undersized cockles were seized. The men, in their 30s, were released on police bail after paying a compound of RM500 each.

KUALA NERANG, Thurs. - The Education Ministry will review the current schooling system to encourage the development of fast learners and students who excel in sports. Deputy Education Minister Datuk Dr Fong Chan Onn said the Ministry would pay particular attention to the learning process and examination system in schools, beginning with Smart Schools. ``We are looking at changes to the system to ensure learning is more interesting and students are encouraged to pursue their own areas of interest. ``Students who are mathematically, musically or language-inclined should be given the opportunity to develop their skills and talents,'' he said when asked to comment on letters published in the New Straits Times recently. The writers claimed that the issue of fast learners in school was being mishandled by the Ministry. He said there was some flexibility in Government primary schools where fast learners and other talented students were allowed to complete their education earlier than the usual six-years. ``However, now through the Smart schools, we are trying to make secondary schools a little more flexible to the needs of exceptional students,'' he said. BC-UN-Woodrow Wilson Memorial
U.N. gets new home for human rights named for late U.S. president
AP Photos GEV101-2 By ALEXANDER G. HIGGINS Associated Press Writer
GENEVA (AP) _ The United Nations formally took possession Friday of the world's new ``home for human rights'' in a building named for U.N. ``grandfather'' U.S. President Woodrow Wilson. In handing over the Palais (pron. Pal'-ay) Wilson, Swiss President Flavio Cotti quoted Wilson as stressing more than 80 years ago: ``The world can only be at peace if human life is anchored to a solid foundation.'' That foundation requires ``a sense of justice, freedom and law,'' he added. The 19th-century building on the shores of Lake Geneva served as the original headquarters of the League of Nations, which was proposed by Wilson in his famous 1918 speech of Fourteen Points on how to restructure Europe to preserve the peace after World War I. The league took up quarters in the former hotel in 1920. The building was given Wilson's name when he died in 1924. The league stayed in the building until 1936, when it moved into the newly built and much larger quarters nearby that now house the European headquarters of the United Nations. Wilson's dream of United States membership in the league was never realized because of opposition from a Republican-controlled Senate, but his idea of a world body became the foundation of the United Nations itself when it was formed after World War II. The horrors of the Holocaust in that war fueled efforts to concentrate on protecting the individual that led to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, adopted by the United Nations 50 years ago. ``The greatest threat to peace and security anywhere is lack of regard for human dignity,'' said Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel Peace prize-winning opposition leader in Myanmar, formerly called Burma, in a message for the ceremony. ``It is from this basic lack that injustice and cruelty, extremism and violence erupt,'' she said. Cotti said he was convinced that giving a special headquarters to U.N. the s will help make the next 100 years ``the century of human rights.'' At the moment only lip service is paid to human rights in many nations, he said. ``Last year torture was used in over 120 countries,'' Cotti said. ``Arbitrary executions were reported in nearly 70 countries.'' The Swiss government spent over 73 million Swiss francs (dlrs 49 million) to renovate the building, which will be made available to the United Nations free of charge. Robinson will start moving into the Palais Wilson in September, officials said. Renovation of the Palais Wilson began in 1994, when it was expected to house several environmental organizations from around the globe, but other countries lured away those organization. (agh)

BC-Yugoslavia-Kosovo, 3rd Ld-Writethru
Kosovo Albanians talk of 50 deaths, destroyed villages
Ed: UPDATES with Serb police statement indicating end of offensive; comments by British prime minister; another reported death; Austrian foreign minister's comments; trims. By ISMET HAJDARI Associated Press Writer
PRISTINA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ The latest Serbian offensive in independence-minded Kosovo province produced reports on Friday of 50 dead, 200 missing, villages destroyed and a mass grave containing 300 bodies. A statement by Serb police issued late Friday indicated the offensive had ended, with the ``terrorist gangs'' who tried to block the key north-south Pec-Decani-Djakovica road being ``destroyed.'' Conditions had been fulfilled for civilians to return, it said. But traumatized ethnic Albanians continued to flee. Hundreds more joined the thousands who have already escaped the fighting in the week since the offensive began, with most of them heading for neighboring Albania. Some of them didn't make it. In Geneva, the United Nations refugee agency said some of the 400 or so who trekked into neighboring Albania overnight had reported five deaths en route _ two elderly people, said to have died of exhaustion, and three small children. About 10,000 refugees are now gathered around Tropoja in northern Albania, produced by the largest exodus since ethnic tensions erupted into large-scale violence in March. Thousands more are in neighboring Montenegro, which with Serbia, forms present-day Yugoslavia. British Prime Minister Tony Blair said the European Union will get involved in the Kosovo crisis, but offered no details while stopping in Rome, and Vienna, Austria. Austria's foreign minister, Wolfgang Schuessel, said that Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic had promised him that humanitarian organizations would have access to sealed off regions of Kosovo. Milosevic, who is thought to be behind the Serb crackdown in Kosovo, also told Schuessel that refugees would be allowed to return under U.N. control. But with similar promises made and often broken in the Bosnian war, the fate of refugees remained unclear. Reports from Serb and Albanian sources were often conflicting and proved impossible to verify. Still, together, they reflected the intensity of the conflict as Serbian government forces tried by force to destroy the Kosovo Albanian drive to secede. The Serb police statement said there were no civilian casualties in the fighting. It spoke of no Albanian dead or injured, but said two policemen were killed and five wounded. But Osman Cacaj, an official of the Democratic League of Kosovo, the ethnic Albanians' main party, listed more than 50 dead and some 200 missing from the latest offensive, concentrated around Decani, some 70 kilometers (45 miles) west of Kosovo's capital, Pristina. Four villages populated by ethnic Albanians were destroyed, another eight badly damaged, and 16 others deserted by fleeing residents, Cacaj added. The Beta news in Belgrade quoted unnamed refugees from Decani, as saying a mass grave on the outskirts of the Serb-besieged town contained 300 bodies. There were no details. The Kosovo Information Center, close to the Albanian leaders in the province, said one Albanian was killed and two wounded in fighting around Orahovac, some 40 kilometers (25 miles) southwest of Pristina. The pro-Serb Media Center spoke of an attack on a police station in the same region that sent police retreating. In separate reports, it said an Albanian woman was wounded Friday, when an armed Albanian shot at a bus on the road running between Pec, in the west, and Kosovska Mitrovica in the northeast, and a Serb villager was killed by a masked gunman in the central Drenica region. Ethnic Albanians form 90 percent of Kosovo's 2 million people and demand independence from Serbia and the Yugoslav federation it forms with tiny Montenegro. Accounts are impossible to verify independently, as both Serbian police forces and gunmen from the Kosovo Liberation Army _ fighting for independence _ block adequate access to journalists and even humanitarian workers. Pristina-based human rights groups on Friday warned that food and medicines in some blocked off areas was extremely short and asked for international aid. Cacaj described the area around Decani as a deserted wasteland, with some 45 bodies left unburied, farm animals roaming wild and several thousand civilians hiding in the woods, trying to cross the border into neighboring Albania or to Montenegro, which with Serbia, forms Yugoslavia. There were conflicting reports of Serb casualties, with Cacaj saying three policemen trying to loot a house had been shot dead by its Albanian owner, and the Serb Media Center denying any officers were killed or wounded. More than 250 people have died since March 1 in escalating clashes between government forces and the Kosovo Liberation Army, the armed wing of the Albanian independence movement, which Albanian political leaders say acts independently from them. I WAS overjoyed when my daughter was accepted to do her matriculation at University Malaya despite the earlier dukacita dimaklumkan permohonan anda tidak berjaya from the UPU Infoline. I was confident that she would be admitted to the main campus of this premier university as there was nothing mentioned about UM's franchise with private colleges at the time of application. However it was not to be. Upon checking with UM, my daughter was told that she had been placed at Inpens Kuala Selangor. She was to wait for the letter from Inpens for details regarding registration, tuition and other fees. No such letter ever came. Instead, three days before the registration date, a call came from Inpens stating that due to time constraints, no letter would be sent. Just report for registration and the tuition and other fees will be made known during registration, the caller said. The real shock for the parents came when we were given the list of fees to be paid, which came up to RM8,500 for two semesters. I wish our Minister of Education and his Ministry officials were present to witness the shocked faces of the parents there. However, I must express my appreciation for the understanding and sympathy shown by Inpens officials towards the predicament of these shocked parents by allowing us to pay whatever amount we could afford on that day. The balance could be paid in instalments. I later learned that the parents of students placed at IKIP in Kuantan had a bigger shock when told the total fees was a whopping RM11,000 plus. However, parents of students placed at the Mara College in Banting were relieved when they only had to pay RM450, with the rest borne by Mara. These high and different charges by different colleges are baffling and raise a number of questions which I would like to pose to our beloved the Minister of Education: Is higher education becoming the exclusive domain of the children of the rich and famous? Why are students placed in the private colleges (not through their own choice) burdened with much higher fees than those placed in the UM campus itself? Is this in line with the concept of social justice repeatedly expounded by our Deputy Prime Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim? Why do the costs vary from one college to another? Why are they not standardised? Why allow them to fix their own `price'? It must be pointed out that the students apply for admission to a public university which is more affordable, which in my case was the UM, and not to the private colleges. Their placement at these private colleges where UM has a franchise programme is not out of their own choice. Thus it is outrageously unfair to subject them to the higher fees charged by the private colleges. Even if students placed in these private colleges are provided with study loans, it simply means that their loans would be larger and require a longer repayment period, compared to those placed in the main UM campus. Is this fair? The conflicting statements made by the relevant authorities, particularly the Education and Entrepreneur Development Ministers, regarding financial aid to affected students further add to the confusion and uncertainty faced by the parents. The Minister of Education was quoted as assuring students allocated matriculation places at private colleges under the universities' franchise programme, not to worry about the high costs as Mara will provide sponsorship for them (NST, May 28). But the Minister of Entrepreneur Development on the same day came out with a statement that the additional money allocated to the Education Fund will be used to give financial aid to matriculation students sponsored by Mara. What about those students not sponsored by Mara? Thirty-six U.S. warplanes end mission in Gulf
MANAMA, Bahrain (AP) _ Thirty-six U.S. warplanes sent to this Gulf island during the recent Iraqi showdown have ended their mission, the official Gulf News Agency reported Friday. The warplanes _ 12 F-15 fighters, 18 F-16 fighters, two B-1 bombers and four KC135R refueling tankers _ arrived in Bahrain in November. They were deployed when it seemed likely that the United States might have to strike Iraq to force it to comply with U.N. Security Council resolutions which say U.N. inspectors must have access to suspected weapons sites. The threat of an attack receded in February when Iraq agreed to grant full access on condition that the inspectors be accompanied by diplomats in their visits to presidential compounds. The news agency gave no date for the departure of the aircraft, but said Bahrain's Sheik Isa Air Base held a farewell reception for the U.S. personnel on Friday. The planes have spent the past seven months enforcing the no-fly zone over southern Iraq and taking part in maneuvers. Bahrain, a close ally of the United States, hosts the headquarters of the U.S. 5th Fleet. The planes' departure is in line with President Bill Clinton's decision in May to cut back on U.S. forces in the Gulf region. am-jbm

KILLINGHALL (M) Bhd expects Southern Bank of Africa Ltd, which began operations in February this year, to contribute positively to the group's earnings in three to five years. The bank is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Southern Bank of Africa Investment Holdings Ltd, in which Killinghall has a 50 per cent stake. Killinghall chairman Datuk Dr Salim Cassim said the company is confident the bank will be a substantial contributor to the group earnings despite competition from other banks in Johannesburg, South Africa. Speaking to reporters after the company's annual meeting in Kuala Lumpur on Wednesday, Dr Salim said: ``We expect it to be tough initially as we will be competing against major banks in the country. ``However, we are confident that in the next three to five years, we will see positive results.'' Early last year Killinghall bought a 50 per cent stake in SBAIH comprising 50 million shares of Rand 1.00 each for a cash consideration of Rand 50 million (about RM30 million). Killinghall set up the bank jointly with National Empowerment Trust Investment Fund Pty Ltd of South Africa with an initial capital of RM150 million held in equal proportions by both parties. A major facet of the bank's business is assisting the flow and funding of direct and indirect Asean and Asian investments into South Africa. The bank is also expected to participate in housing programmes promoted by the South African government. During the year, Killinghall increased its interest in Southern Bank Bhd, an associate company, from 25.80 per cent to 26.27 per cent through its acquisition in the open market. Director Datuk Tan Teong Hean said the company is considering increasing its stake in Southern Bank in the near future. Elaborating on other future plans, Tan said the board of directors is exploring ways and means to weather the current financial problem. ``We are thinking of ways and means to reduce borrowings as increased borrowings will subsequently reduce the group earnings. ``Considering the current economic climate, we do not have any major plans but we are looking for investment opportunities.'' Killinghall's group pre-tax profit for the year ended Dec 31, 1997, was RM25.07 million, a decline of 39 per cent from the previous corresponding period. This was attributed to the decrease in profit of the associated company, Southern Bank and higher financial charges incurred in financing further investment in the bank. For the period reviewed, pre-tax profit of Southern Bank declined by 29.7 per cent to RM12.2 million from RM173.7 million previously due mainly to changes in loan classification, increased provision for doubtful debts and provision for diminution in value of assets.

KUALA LUMPUR, Thurs. - Singaporeans with outstanding traffic summonses may be detained when they are returning to the republic. This is among the proposals being considered by the police and the Road Transport Department to recover RM2 million in traffic fines owed by Singaporeans, Parliamentary Secretary to the Transport Ministry Datuk Chor Chee Heung said. Another proposal is to blacklist such vehicles and bar them from entering the country, he added. ``The drivers and passengers of the vehicles can be detained until they settle the summonses. ``The Johor Immigration Department will be asked to assist the police and the RTD.'' Chor was speaking after receiving Tokyo Metropolitan Police Department's International Criminal Investigation Division chief Inspector Eiji Miyamoto at Wisma MCA in Jalan Ampang. Miyamoto, who is on a private visit to the country, paid a courtesy call on Chor who is also head of the MCA's International Affairs Bureau. ``The ministry has also received many complaints from the public on the discourteous attitude of the republic's drivers on Malaysian roads,'' Chor said. The New Straits Times reported on May 24 that 36,941 traffic summonses were issued to Singaporean drivers last year. Of this number, only 9,258, or about 25 per cent, have paid the compound fines. Since 1994, more than RM2 million in compound fines involving errant Singaporean motorists had not been settled. Johor police recently launched an operation at the Causeway and Second Link to trace the offenders. Within four hours, police had traced 20 offenders and collected RM2,000 in fines.

BC-Salvador-Cuba,0299
Salvador government blocks sister city effort
By EDITH BELTRAN Associated Press Writer
SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador (AP) _ A plan to make sister cities of the Cuban and Salvadoran capitals has turned into more of a family feud. President Armando Calderon Sol announced Thursday that his government would not allow a visit by Havana Mayor Conrado Martinez, who was invited by San Salvador Mayor Hector Silva as part of a sister city project. Calderon Sol's party supported a war against pro-Cuban leftist rebels in the 1980s. Silva was elected in a coalition that includes those former leftists, now a political party. ``We are brothers of the Cuban people, but what impedes foreign relations is the line of the government'' of Cuba's President Fidel Castro, Calderon Sol said in remarks published by newspapers here Friday. The hard-line Interior Minister, Mario Acosta, was even more blunt earlier: ``No Cuban enters.'' The Foreign Ministry issued a statement saying the central government _ not the city's _ was responsible for foreign affairs and noting the El Salvador has ``asked the Cuban government to make advances toward democracy.'' ``We want to see a democratic government, not political prisoners,'' it said. That left former rebel commander Facundo Guardado, now a member of San Salvador's city council, sputtering Friday. The government behavior was outrageous, he said. ``They know that large Salvadoran investors are operating in Cuba. The position they are adopting now is absurd.'' City spokesman Juan Jose Dalton said the sister city agreement would go forward _ but would be signed in Havana instead. He insisted the pact is not diplomatic, merely cultural and social.

ATHENS, Greece (AP) _ A firebomb exploded Friday in a building housing offices of a television channel in Athens, leading to a fire which caused slight damage but no injuries, police said. The makeshift bomb consisting of propane gas canisters exploded at around 9:40 pm (1840 GMT) on the eighth floor of the New Channel building, outside the offices of the channel's accounting department and journalism school. An anonymous caller telephoned the Athens daily Eleftherotypia shortly before the blast, saying only ``New Channel will burn tonight,'' authorities said. The caller claimed to represent a shadowy group called ``Left-wing Cells.'' Similar firebombs have been used since late last year to torch more than 150 offices and cars, mostly in Athens, since January. They belonged to officials, politicians, Jewish and anti-Semitic groups, diplomats, journalists and foreigners. Most attacks have been claimed by shadowy groups little-known to authorities. (eb)

BC-Sports-Boxing-Holyfield-Akinwande, 5th Ld-Writethru,0685
Akinwande-Holyfield fight called off
Eds: UPDATES with Holyfield comments; Will be UPDATED after news conference, scheduled for 2000 GMT. By TIM DAHLBERG AP Sports Writer
NEW YORK (AP) _ Evander Holyfield never really wanted to fight Henry Akinwande. Now he won't have to. The heavyweight title fight was called off Friday, a day before the bout, because Akinwande tested positive for hepatitis B. ``I guess I'm the guy things happen to,'' said Holyfield, who was informed the fight was off when he arrived at Madison Square Garden for his final pre-fight workout. Holyfield went back to his hotel, saying he was still hopeful a last-minute opponent could be found for him. ``Seems kind of strange to wait to the last minute,'' Holyfield said. ``But I'm already in shape. If you don't fight, you don't get paid either.'' Promoters scheduled a Friday afternoon news conference to discuss whether the card will go forward at all. Ticket sales had been poor, with promoters saying only 6,000 tickets had been distributed in the days before the fight. Earlier, heavyweight Ray Mercer also was scratched from the card for undisclosed medical reasons and Christy Martin's opponent couldn't fight because she's pregnant. That left the aging Roberto Duran as the lone remaining attraction. Two separate medical tests on Akinwande by the New York State Athletic Commission showed he had hepatitis B, said Greg Fritz, a spokesman for Don King Productions, the promoter of the fight. The commission does not allow infected boxers to fight because of the risk of transmitting the disease through blood during bouts. ``It's disappointing,'' said Holyfield, who had made no secret of his lack of desire to fight the WBA's No. 1 contender. ``You prepare yourself for 13 weeks and then this happens.'' Hepatitis B, often contracted through sex or dirty hypodermic needles, can cause serious liver problems. The disease can be treated successfully, but not always. Hepatitis A is typically a food-borne disease that can pass quickly. The Showtime network, which was to televise the bout from Madison Square Garden, also said in a statement that the main event had been canceled due to the commission's medical finding. The fight was supposed to top a card that included the 46-year-old Duran fighting for a title nine years after he lost his middleweight crown to Sugar Ray Leonard. Duran first fought in the Garden in 1971 and is 6-1 in his career at the arena. On Thursday, Mexican lightweight Maria de las Nieves Garcia was scratched from her undercard bout with Christy Martin because she was pregnant. Melissa Salamore was to have replaced Garcia, but Martin rejected her as an opponent, and promoters were trying to find another fighter. The Akinwande decision is yet another blow to his once promising career. He was disqualified in the fifth round of a fight last July against WBC champ Lennox Lewis for repeated holding. That Akinwande was even supposed to fight for a piece of the title for the second time in less than a year was due more to his choice of promoter than anything else. After the Lewis debacle, King matched him against Orlin Norris Jr., and Akinwande won a 12-round decision to become the mandatory contender. Akinwande was to make dlrs 2.5 million to fight Holyfield, who was to get dlrs 10 million for the defense of the WBA title he won in his first fight with Mike Tyson. Holyfield had wanted to fight Lewis to unify the heavyweight championship for the first time since Riddick Bowe threw the WBC belt into a garbage can after his win over Holyfield in their first fight. But with Holyfield wanting dlrs 20 million for the fight and Lewis unwilling to give up his relationship with the HBO network, talks collapsed and Holyfield was left only with the option of taking a mandatory title defense to keep his WBA title. He was openly unenthusiastic about fighting Akinwande, who is 33-1-1, and almost nobody but Akinwande and the WBA wanted it.

TOKYO, Thurs: Malaysia will begin accepting yen loans again as the Japanese currency has depreciated against the US dollar, Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad said. He said while borrowing in the yen was once stopped because it had appreciated and cost more to repay, now is a good time to borrow yen since the currency has fallen to seven-year lows against the greenback. The yen was yesterday traded at 137.3 against the greenback. Speaking to Malaysian journalists here last night, Dr Mahathir said the Government is negotiating the rates for new yen loans. ``These loans can be used for many things. There are project financing and special loans for environmentally-friendly projects,'' he added. Only 15 per cent of Malaysia's external debt of RM166.29 billion last year was in yen. The bulk, or 76 per cent of the total debt, was in US dollar and the remaining 9 per cent in other currencies, according to Bank Negara Malaysia's annual report for 1997. Dr Mahathir is in Tokyo on a five-day working visit, during which he addressed two international-level conferences of economists. At these forums, the Prime Minister renewed his call for reform of the international financial system and for countries in which currency traders operate to regulate their activities. Asked about International Monetary Fund first deputy managing director Stanley Fischer's response that Dr Mahathir's proposal for bilateral balanced trade would slow progress and be a step back to pre World War arrangements, the Prime Minister said: ``What's wrong with going back to something that was good? I don't agree that we shouldn't go back. Sometimes we take the wrong turn and we have to go back. Even the West has gone back many times.'' On whether the developed countries would support his proposal for reform of the international financial system, he said, at the moment the rich countries are doing well and do not see any need for reform. ``They are not losing any money. In fact they are making a lot of money, so why should they reform? But one day they will lose money. Then maybe they will ask for reform,'' he said. Dr Mahathir said the currency traders too will eventually realise the mistake of attacking the currencies to the point of driving whole countries towards bankruptcy. ``I believe eventually they will destroy their market, and when they destroy the market, they will not get anything out of the market anymore. At that stage, they will realise their mistake. ``Yes, it will be too late but what is there we can do? They are powerful and very big. We are small. So we need to think about how we can probably get out of the system,'' he said. Asked how he envisioned the world then under such hopeless conditions, Dr Mahathir said: ``The world took 70 years to learn that Communism doesn't work. During that period, millions of people died. That's the price of making mistakes. That is the price for not recognising something that is bad early. ``Maybe the world will go through the same cycle. That is why I mentioned that although governments may comply and say, yes that is good, the people may not say so,'' he added. Dr Mahathir said the people might resent their own companies being taken over by foreigners, and may act against the foreigners. He said it will take a long time before Asia recovers from the present economic turmoil, for some countries longer than others. ``When it does recover, it will be quite a different kind of situation. I don't believe we can just go back to square one.'' He said Malaysia, through the National Economic Action Council, is studying the way other countries handle similar problems including taking extraordinary measures. ``People are learning to do things that may not be the standard method but nevertheless they are willing and brave enough to do it, and because of that they are safe. ``We ourselves must begin to think that there is no orthodox way of dealing with an unorthodox situation. We may have to think of unorthodox ways of dealing with the situation.''

BC-Sports-Tennis-French Open Notebook,
Soccer star Pele to hand over French Open trophy
By STEPHANIE VAN DEN BERG
PARIS (AP) _ Taking avantage of the upcoming World Cup soccer tournament in France, the French Tennis Federation has invited the Brazilian sports minister, Edson Arantes do Nascimento _ Pele, for short _ to hand out the Musketeers Cup to the men's singles champion. The triple World Cup winner for the Brazilian team in 1958, 1962 and 1970 will be joined in the ceremony by Donald Budge. Budge was the first tennis player to win a Grand Slam 60 years ago in 1938. The women's singles Suzanne Lengen Cup will be handed out Saturday by Virginia Ruzici, who won the women's tournament in 1978 and by Ilie Nastase, who was the 1973 men's winner. --- WORLD CUP FEVER: With the beginning of the World Cup just days away, the tennis crowd at Roland Garros is getting into the spirit of things. The Chilean fans were first in showing up in soccer jerseys to support their compatriot, Marcelo Rios. Dutch, Italian and Czechoslovakian fans also started wearing their teams' colors. Some players are not indifferent to the World Cup. No. 10 men's seed Richard Krajicek came on court for his third-round match against Cedric Pioline in an official Dutch team jersey with his name on the back. Mario Zabaleta of Argentina put on his nation's jersey after his first-round upset of No. 2 seed Petr Korda. But there are players who perhaps take their love for soccer a little bit too far. France's Fabrice Santoro announced that he will not play Wimbledon so he can stay in France and follow the World Cup. But there are still some fans who prefer rackets over soccer balls. Brazilian tennis lover Paolo Coutinho came to Paris especially for the French Open. ``I hate soccer and the madness that takes over my country every four years,'' he said. ``Still, I'm in France thanks to the cheap airline tickets to Paris in the period of the World Cup. Soccer helped my dream come true: to watch Guga (Gustavo Kuerten), (Jaime) Oncins and (Fernando) Meligeni play at Roland Garros.'' --- VIVA ESPANA: Thursday morning, before the gates to Roland Garros were opened, some lucky spectators saw a display of Spanish solidarity on center court. To warm up for her semifinal match against Lindsay Davenport, Arantxa Sanchez Vicario found an exclusive sparring partner in Carlos Moya, who'll be playing in the men's final on Sunday. One of the spectators at the warmup match was top seed Martina Hingis, who was Sanchez Vicario's most ardent supporter and applauded every good shot she made against Moya. All the support paid off as Sanchez Vicario beat Davenport in straight sets to advance to the finals. Hingis, though, lost to Monica Seles in the other women's semifinal. --- GENTLEMEN PREFER BLONDES: Felix Mantilla says he's sticking to blond for Wimbledon. The Spanish men's semifinalist was asked if he had a new color in mind for the next Grand Slam, but the answer was no. ``I think it will stay this color, because I lost today,'' he said after his semifinal loss to Carlos Moya on Friday. Mantilla dyed his hair blond on a bet with Argentinian player Luis Lobo during the German Open in May. ``I said that if I reach the semifinals, I must do it, I must change my color,'' said Mantilla. What do others think of the new hairdo? ``Some people like it, some people don't like it. But it doesn't matter because now I'm young, '' said Mantilla, whose hair is naturally dark brown. ``I like to do some things differently.''

KL AIRPORT Services Sdn Bhd (KLAS), a member of the DRB-Hicom Group, yesterday secured its fifth customer when it signed a ground handling agreement with Dubai-based Emirates. With the agreement, the ground handling operator will provide four main services to Emirates, including inflight catering services, passenger services, aircraft handling and cargo handling from its newly-completed facilities at KL International Airport (KLIA) in Sepang. DRB-Hicom Group senior group director Datuk Maznah Abdul Jalil signed the agreement on behalf of KLAS while Emirates was represented by its senior general manager (ground services), Mr Mohammed H. Mattar. Speaking to reporters after the signing ceremony, Maznah said being a new ground handling operator in the country, KLAS has made ``good progress'' by securing five customers. ``Of course, we will not stop at five. We have just completed our facilities at KLIA and we are now only starting to market our services. We have (set) our targets (of customers) and we are slowly getting there,''she said. Besides Emirates, KLAS is also the ground handling operator for Kampuchea Airlines, Federal Express, Transmile and DRB-Hicom's sister company, AirAsia. Maznah said all facilities of KLAS are ready for operation on the opening day of the airport at the end of this month. ``The operation of KLAS has moved to KLIA since the middle of last month. Besides KLIA and the Sultan Abdul Aziz Shah International Airport in Subang, we will also be operating in other airports namely Penang, Kota Kinabalu and Johor Baru,'' she said. KLAS is the one of the two ground handling operators in Malaysia. The other is Malaysia Airlines. KLAS chief executive officer Sharifah Halimah Syed Ahmad said there will be a total of 49 foreign carriers operating at the new airport. ``Of this total, we would like to have as many of them as our customers, but it will be tough because we are still new. ``Nonetheless, the customers that we are currently serving have expressed their satisfaction about our service. And we will continue to deliver what we have promised,'' she said. On its ground handling charges, she said ``they are value for money''. Sharifah Halimah also said at this point in time, it is not possible for KLAS to handle all of the 49 carriers which are flying into KLIA. ``We are just a two-year-old company. There is a limited capacity in dealing with cargo volume. Our maximum cargo capacity at KLIA is about 150,000 tonnes per year whereas we can prepare up to 7,500 inflight meals per day,'' she added. Meanwhile, Mohammed said the reason why Emirates chose KLAS as its ground handling operator at KLIA is that ``it shares our objectives of providing only the best to customers.'' ``In addition, because KLAS is a young and dynamic company like Emirates, we believe it can gives us the necessary service to serve our passengers,'' he said. Emirates now flies four times a week between Dubai and Kuala Lumpur. On AirAsia, Maznah said because the carrier is still small, it is able to adjust itself during the current economic situation. ``We are flexible enough to weave in and out in this current economic conditions, and certainly we (AirAsia) are still here,'' she said. To date, AirAsia has two 737-300s.

PARIS (AP) _ Jose Manuel Garcia Aranda of Spain, who officiated the 1996 Olympic tournament in Atlanta, will referee the World Cup opener between defending champion Brazil and Scotland, FIFA announced Friday. The 42-year-old Madrid physical education teacher has been a referee since 1974 and an international field official since 1993. He refereed the 1997 Toyota Cup final between Germany's Borussia Dortmund and Brazil's Cruzeiro and also has overseen European Champions League matches. FIFA announced the referees for 34 of their early round matches, with the remaining 14 games to be assigned referees by mid-June, FIFA said. The lowlands grudge match between longtime rivals Belgium and the Netherlands at St. Denis on June 13 will be handled by Pierluigi Collina, the internationally renown Italian who is easily identifiable by his shaven scalp. KL International Airport Bhd (KLIA Bhd) chairman Tan Sri Clifford Herbert yesterday denied allegations that air freight forwarders were forced into signing a bonded warehouse tenancy agreement. ``We never forced anybody. They all signed willingly. There was 100 per cent acceptance,'' Herbert said at the new airport yesterday. He had earlier accompanied Transport Minister Datuk Seri Dr Ling Liong Sik, who toured the airport and checked on the preparation for the opening of the airport by the Yang Di-Pertuan Agong on June 29. Business Times understands that 27 tenants have so far taken up warehouse space at KLIA. The high rental rate at the airport's cargo village has been on-going issue between the airport's cargo handling agents and the air freighters. The Airfreight Forwarders Association of Malaysia (AFAM) claimed that their members were forced to sign the agreement after Malaysia Airlines, one of the two ground handling agents, issued them the ultimatum early this week. The other ground handling agent is Kuala Lumpur Airport Services Sdn Bhd (KLAS). Malaysia Airlines is expected to offer 68 bonded warehouses while KLAS is expected to offer another 27. AFAM members claimed they were told to sign the agreement or risk losing their warehouse space at the airport. The association complained, among other things, of the high rental tariff at KLIA, which is said to be much higher than many other countries, and the inadequate warehouse space which is not up to international standards. The rental at KLIA has been proposed at RM5 per sq ft, plus a service charge of 25 sen. The rate at Singapore airport is RM2.78 per sq ft, Frankfurt (RM1.67 per sq ft) and New York (RM1.88 per sq ft). Dr Ling, meanwhile, said he was informed that the rate charged at KLIA is the same as those currently being charged at the Sultan Abdul Aziz Shah airport in Subang. ``It is the same charge. The rate for the facilities at Subang is also RM5.50, so there's no change. Furthermore all the warehouse space has been taken up and paid for already,'' he said. Asked if the air freight forwarders have no basis for complaining about high tariff, he said: ``Any airport operators should not outprice themselves and in the process, turn people away. PETALING JAYA, Thurs. - The Fisheries Department is drawing up a set of legislations for State Governments to adopt to conserve and protect endangered turtles and terrapins. The legislations which can help resolve the problem of fragmented and inadequate laws in the country will, among others, ban the consumption and collection of turtles, turtle eggs and terrapins in all States. Head of marine parks section Kevin W.P. Hiew said today the department was working with non-governmental organisations, particularly the Worldwide Fund for Nature Malaysia, on the legislations. The legislations are being drawn under the Fisheries Act 1985 which empowers State authorities to enact their own regulations to conserve and protect turtles and turtle eggs. The idea is to draft a model set of legislations for States to adopt in total or partially. If adopted in total, State authorities will have to repeal their existing laws. Otherwise, they can refer to the draft to improve their own laws. ``The existing laws are not adequate. Some do not offer protection for turtles, but emphasises on collection of turtle eggs. ``Some of the laws are also fragmented and different States have different laws. Our objective is to standardise the laws for more effective enforcement,'' Hiew said at the launch of WWF's Handbook on Integrated Coastal and Estuarine Zone Management. Conservationists and environmentalists have long expressed concern over the lack of protection for turtles. To date, only four States - Terengganu, Pahang, Sabah and Sarawak - have legislations on turtles. But they were inadequate. And only Terengganu bans collection of turtle eggs. The State's laws only protect leatherback turtles although other species such as hawksbill and olive ridley are also under threat. Federal legislations are also not much help. The Fisheries Act offers no clear definition of turtles while the Wildlife Protection Act 1972 does not provide protection to turtles. The Fisheries Department and WWF hope to overcome these problems with the model legislations. However, Hiew said the acceptance of the legislations was still the States' prerogative. WWF's Wildlife Ecologist and senior scientific officer Dr Dionysius S.K. Sharma said the new legislations would encompass all aspects of conservation for the different species of turtles and habitat protection. They will also provide for the incubation of turtle eggs in hatcheries. Work on the legislations began early this year and is expected to be completed by end of the year. Dionysius said the draft would be completed in about two months, after which it would be circulated to scientists and State authorities for feedback. Hiew said the main threat to turtles were egg collection and consumption. ``Since this is a 100-year tradition, we are willing to allow the villagers to collect the eggs and sell them to us for hatching purposes. ``However, villagers prefer to sell the eggs to the public as they can fetch better prices,'' he said.

HELSINKI, Finland (AP) _ Substitute striker David Trezeguet beat an offside trap and scored with seven minutes remaining to give France a 1-0 victory over Finland Friday night in its final prep match before the start of the World Cup. Didier Deschamps' pass from midfield found Trezeguet alone on the left flank, where he dribbled in and fired high over Finnish keeper Antti Niemi from about 8 meters. Finnish defenders raised their hands to signal that Zinedine Zidane was offside, but the linesman apparently felt that he was not a factor and let play continue. France squandered a chance to score in the 65th minute when Christophe Dugarry was set up in the middle by Youri Djorkaeff. After getting the cross from the right, the unmarked Dugarry managed only a meek, low shot from 6 meters that was easily grabbed Niemi. Finland quickly countered, getting a header from Tomi Kinnunen off a corner two minutes later that hit the post. French head coach Aime Jacquet chose to play a flat back four behind two defensive midfielders. Stephane Guivarc'h served as the lone striker in front of three offensive midfielders. The defense was caught in the fifth minute when Joonas Kolkka played a deep ball to Jonatan Johansson, whose low shot was blocked by a quickly advancing keeper Fabien Barthez, who had raced 10 meters off his line. ___ Lineups Finland: Antti Niemi; Harri Ylonen; Aarno Turpeinen, Sami Hyypia, Tomi Kinnunen; Aki Riihilahti, Jarkko Wiss, Juha Reini; Joonas Kolkka, Jonatan Johansson (Simo Valakari, 57th minute); Mika-Matti Paatelainen. PENGURUSAN Dana Harta Nasional, the national asset management company (AMC), will need about RM25 billion to acquire troubled loans and assets in the banking system. The AMC will initially raise RM10 billion through the issue of bonds locally and abroad. Of this, between US$1 billion and US$2 billion will be sourced from the international bond market. The bonds are Government-guaranteed. Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim announced details of the AMC yesterday, two weeks after the Government said it would form an asset management company to deal with banks' non- performing loans (NPLs), which stood at 9.3 per cent of total outstanding loans as in March. The establishment of the AMC is aimed at reviving still-viable assets and allowing banks to focus on their daily operations, both of which the Government hopes would assist in the economy recovery. Anwar told a press conference the Government will provide AMC an initial grant of RM50 million as seed money for its establishment. The company is expected to deal with its first NPL end-July. After Anwar announced the proposal to set up AMC on May 20 and the appointment of Amanah Capital Group executive director Azman Yahya as AMC chief executive officer the next day, the AMC appointed international consultants Arthur Andersen as its strategic and operational adviser and JP Morgan as the financial adviser. A legal and regulatory framework for the establishment of the agency is being worked out. ``Once the draft is completed, we will table it at the next Parliament sitting in July,'' Anwar said. The legislation is to ensure that there will be enough legal and regulatory capacity for the AMC to acquire the NPLs from banks. Anwar said the Government may even hold a special Parliament sitting later this month to speed up the legislative process. Although the draft on the proposed legislation has yet to be completed, Anwar said AMC can proceed to seek and study the viable NPLs that it can acquire. ``To do this, they do not need to wait for the legislation ... they can proceed, full steam, right away but when it comes to acquiring the NPLs and assets, this will be subjected to the proposed Act to be passed by Parliament,'' he said. It will operate in a rigorous transparent reporting regime, including quarterly reports of the management's stewardship to the stakeholders. Anwar also said the Government currently holds the controlling stake in AMC but this will be reduced gradually. ``If possible, we (Government) do not hold the majority stake. ``But based on the experience of other countries which have similar asset management companies of this nature, the Government will have to take the initiative. ``Sovereign guarantee needs to be there to give the sense of absolute support of the Government before this can take place. But once it operates, it must do this independently,'' he added. On participation of the private sector in the AMC, Anwar said, the present AMC team is currently negotiating with numerous interested parties. ``Certainly, the private sector has given the undertaking to participate. In fact, when a consortium of banks said that they were prepared to take up the majority or substantial stake in AMC, we said that we have to look into this matter first,'' he said. Anwar said based on the experience of other countries, there may be difficulties when banks hold a majority stake in AMC especially when the agency negotiates NPLs. ``There may be a conflict of interest. ``When they (banks) have a majority stake in the agency, they will have an advantage. ``If they want to participate, they should not hold a majority stake,'' he added. Anwar said the involvement of the private sector, including foreign investors, in the AMC will be increased gradually.

BC-UN-Drug Conference,0446
International leaders call drug war a failure, urge Annan to
rethink policy By ROBERT H. REID Associated Press Writer
UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ Saying the drug war has caused more harm than drug abuse itself, prominent world figures are calling for ``a truly open dialogue'' to shift drug control policies from punishment to public health issues. The call is being made in a letter to Secretary-General Kofi Annan from the Lindesmith Center, a private institute which conducts drug research, in advance of the U.N. General Assembly special session on drugs, which opens Monday. Dr. Ethan Nadelmann, director of the center, said the letter has been signed by more than 500 prominent people, including former Secretary of State George Shultz, former Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, former Greek President George Papandreou, former President Oscar Arias of Costa Rica and former German Justice Minister Sabine Leutheusser-Schnarrenberger. ``We believe that the global war on drugs is now causing more harm than drug abuse itself,'' the letter said. ``Human rights are violated, environmental assaults perpetrated and prisons inundated with hundreds of thousands of drug violators.'' The letter said scarce resources are being diverted ``on ever more expensive interdiction efforts'' while ``realistic proposals to reduce drug-related crime, disease and death'' are abandoned ``in favor of rhetorical proposals to create drug-free societies.'' ``Persisting in our current policies will only result in more drug abuse, more empowerment of drug markets and criminals and more disease and suffering,'' the letter said. It appealed to Annan ``to initiate a truly open and honest dialogue regarding the future of global drug policies _ one in which fear, prejudice and punitive prohibitions yield to common sense, science, public health and human rights.'' Nadelmann said the U.N. conference should consider the global drug policy as a public heath issue, using the resources of U.N. agencies such as the World Health Organization to devise policies to replace those based on ``interdiction and criminalization.'' Representatives of about 150 countries, including 35 heads of state and government, are to attend the three-day conference. President Clinton will deliver the opening address Monday. U.N. officials said the conference will focus on issues such as ways to combat money-laundering, reducing demand, strengthening judicial cooperation, regulating chemicals used to synthesize drugs and eliminating illegal cultivation of poppy, cocoa and cannabis crops.

Kosovo Albanians report 50 deaths, destroyed villages
Eds: UPDATES throughout with Serb police statement indicating end of offensive, comments by British prime minister and Austrian foreign minister, another reported death; EDITS to conform and tighten; ADDS photo numbers. AP Photos PRI104-106 By ISMET HAJDARI Associated Press Writer
PRISTINA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Some of the thousands fleeing the latest Serbian offensive in Kosovo don't make it, dying of exhaustion along the way. In villages wiped out by fighting, corpses lie unburied and farm animals roam wild. Reports said Friday that 50 people were killed and 200 were missing in the past week. Survivors were hiding in the woods, most trying to cross the border into neighboring Albania. A statement by Serb police Friday indicated the offensive had ended, having destroyed the ``terrorist gangs'' who tried to block Kosovo's key north-south road. It said civilians could safely return. Still, hundreds continued to flee. Most were ethnic Albanians, who make up 90 percent of Kosovo's 2 million people and demand independence from Serbia, the larger of two republics remaining in Yugoslavia. Serbian troops are trying to quash the separatist drive. In an unusually blunt statement, U.N. chief Kofi Annan accused Serb forces of ``atrocities'' in Kosovo and demanded Friday that ``this kind of aggression'' be confronted immediately. British Prime Minister Tony Blair said the European Union will get involved in the Kosovo crisis, but offered no details. Austria's foreign minister, Wolfgang Schuessel, said that Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic had promised him that humanitarian organizations would have access to sealed off regions of Kosovo. Milosevic, who is thought to be behind the Serb crackdown in Kosovo, also told Schuessel that refugees would be allowed to return under U.N. control. But with similar promises made and often broken in the Bosnian war, the fate of refugees remained unclear. Some of the 400 refugees who trekked into Albania overnight reported five deaths on the way _ two elderly people, said to have died of exhaustion, and three small children, the U.N. refugee agency in Geneva reported. Albania is ill-equipped to handle the influx, and the EU said Friday it will increase its dlrs 2.2 million aid package for Kosovo _ perhaps doubling it _ to help Albania cope. Most of the male refugees aren't staying out of danger for long, instead stocking up on arms in Albania then returning to fight the Serbs. Horses and mules loaded with guns, vans without license plates transporting men in camouflage uniforms and the sound of sporadic gunfire make Tropoja, a northern Albanian town swamped by 10,000 refugees in recent days, look like a military base. Teen-agers are being trained to shoot, and no attempt is being made to hide the military preparations. The reports of fighting in Kosovo were often conflicting and could not be verified. Both Serbian police forces and gunmen from the Kosovo Liberation Army block access to journalists and even humanitarian workers. The Beta news agency in Belgrade quoted unnamed refugees as saying a mass grave contained 300 bodies on the outskirts of from Decani, 70 kilometers (45 miles) west of Kosovo's capital, Pristina. There were no details. Osman Cacaj, an official of the Democratic League of Kosovo, the ethnic Albanians' main party, listed more than 50 dead and 200 missing from the latest offensive, concentrated around Decani. He described the area around Decani as a deserted wasteland, with 45 bodies left unburied and civilians hiding in the woods. Four ethnic Albanian villages were destroyed, eight badly damaged, and 16 others deserted, he said. The Kosovo Information Center, close to the Albanian leaders in the province, said one Albanian was killed in fighting around Orahovac, 40 kilometers (25 miles) southwest of Pristina. It said Serb shelling continued around Decani and in Kosovo's southwest. The Serb police statement said there were no civilian casualties. It said two policemen were killed and five wounded. The Serb forces in Kosovo are using an armored personnel carrier stolen from Dutch troops during the Bosnian war, the Dutch government said Friday. More than 250 people have died since March 1 in escalating clashes between Serb forces and the Kosovo Liberation Army, the armed wing of the Albanian independence movement, which Albanian political leaders say acts independently. Ethnic Albanians and officials chosen by Milosevic, who stripped Kosovo of its broad autonomy in 1989, opened talks under Western pressure last month. Agreement appears unlikely. The ethnic Albanians canceled a meeting scheduled Friday in Pristina, saying they could not talk with the Serbs while the latest offensive lasts.

JERUSALEM (AP) _ Fearing that government approval of a West Bank troop withdrawal is imminent, Jewish settlers on Friday took senior members of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's Likud Party on flights over the disputed land in hopes of scuttling a pullback. Settlers also threatened to establish at least two new Jewish settlements if Netanyahu accepts a U.S. withdrawal proposal that would leave 40 percent of the West Bank under Palestinian control and restrict settlement expansion. As a result of the withdrawal, ``the settlements are turning into enclaves in Palestinian areas and in our view, this is a life-and-death battle,'' said settler spokesman Aharon Domb. Under the American plan, Israel would withdraw from 13 percent of the West Bank over a 12-week period, in exchange for Palestinian security measures, such as collecting illegal weapons. Negotiations on a permanent peace agreement would begin with the first pullback. Two senior Palestinian negotiators were to brief Arafat later Friday on their talks with the U.S. Mideast envoy, Dennis Ross. Israel army radio said Ross asked the Palestinians to accept several changes in the original U.S. proposal, but that report could not be confirmed. A remaining sticking point is the scope of an additional pullback promised by Israel. Netanyahu wants assurances now that he will not have to hand over more than 2 percent at the time, a demand rejected by the Palestinians. Despite continued disagreements, both Netanyahu and Arafat seemed mildly optimistic in their assessments. Netanyahu said Thursday that ``some progress'' had been made, while Arafat said he was assured by U.S. mediators that a deal would be wrapped up by mid-June. Israeli Cabinet Secretary Dannny Naveh said a deal was likely soon. ``I hope that we can wrap up a deal in the next few days,'' Naveh told Israel TV. Netanyahu's senior, 9th graf pvs dl

BC-Sports-Soccer-Germany-Luxembourg
Germany routs Luxembourg part-timers 7-0
MANNHEIM, Germany (AP) _ After Germany's 7-0 victory Friday over Luxembourg's part-timers, the guessing game over who will start for Germany at the World Cup won't get any easier. Most of the players German coach Berti Vogts challenged to prove belonged in his starting lineup had no problems shining against the overmatched Duchey in the team's final World Cup tuneup. ``I'm happy I've got a team where I have two good players for each position,'' said Vogts, who refuses to name his starting lineup. Juergen Klinsmann, fighting for a striker position, headed in a 15th minute goal and assisted on a second. Midfielder Christian Ziege scored in the 85th and defender Thomas Helmer in the 28th minute as both strengthened their claim on a starting role. Midfielder Joerg Heinrich, who seemed to have misplayed himself onto the bank, launched a perfect seventh minute cross cross that a sliding Ulf Kirsten blasted in with an outstretched leg. Kirsten, Klinsmann's main rival, added a second goal in the 45th. Oliver Bierhoff, a sure bet to start alongside one or the other in France, struck twice in the 56th and 72nd and now has scored 17 goals in 27 caps. Luxembourg's players, with only one full-time professional, offered little resistance as the Germans strived to display their best side for Vogts. ``It was a good training session for us, nothing more,'' shrugged Bierhoff. The Germans had a much easier time with Luxembourg than Cameroon, another World Cup team, which struggled to a 2-0 victory Sunday. After a scoreless draw against Finland, Germany turned in an impressive 3-1 victory Saturday against Colombia. For Vogts, the last two outings are a clear sign the team is reaching its stride before the June 15 opener against the United States. ``There were too many loose passes as far as I'm concerned, but it's getting better and better,'' said Vogts. ``I wanted a clear improvement over Colombia and I got it.'' Luxembourg didn't have a real shot on goal until the 79th minute when Serge Thill found himself loose at the edge of the box but shot the ball straight into keeper Jens Lehmann's hands. As an indication of Luxembourg's nearly amatuer status, Thill had been inserted late in the match for Gordon Braun, a forward busy cramming for college exams. Klinsmann, who proved he's recovered from an injury, and Kirsten continued their fierce battle to claim the second forward start. Vogts has already called his striker foursome, which also includes FC Kaiserslautern's Olaf Marschall, the best the German team has boasted since the 1970 World Cup. Taliban denounces UN invitation to ousted government
UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ The Islamic Taliban on Friday condemned ``in the strongest terms'' a U.N. invitation to followers of ousted President Burhanuddin Rabbani to attend next week's U.N. drug conference. ``The Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan condemns in the strongest terms a United Nations invitation to the so-called northern alliance to represent Afghanistan'' at the conference, the Taliban's representation office in New York said in a statement. ``By receiving the northern alliance, the United Nations confers undue legitimacy and international status to these warlords,'' the statement said. The Taliban army drove Rabbani from the capital Kabul in 1996 and now controls about 85 percent of the country. Rabbani's northern-based alliance controls about 15 percent of the territory and has been battling the Taliban. Although Taliban holds the capital and most of the territory, the United Nations has never awarded the General Assembly seat to the Islamic movement. The seat remains in the hands of the previous government pending a final decision. Afghanistan is a leading source of opium-poppies, most of which are grown in Taliban-controlled areas. The Taliban has agreed to work with the United Nations to curb production and encourage farmers to grow alternate crops. But U.N. officials said so long as the General Assembly does not remove the seat, the former leadership will still be entitled to attend U.N. conferences as the legitimate government of Afghanistan.

BC-Germany-Train Wheel-Box
A closer look at the wheel that broke
By The Associated Press
Investigators confirmed Friday that wheel failure was the focus of their probe into Wednesday's high-speed train crash. CONSTRUCTION: A shock-absorbing rubber ring encases a steel disc, the actual wheel. The entire construction is encircled by a reinforced steel tire. The tire also functions as a rim that helps keep the wheels on the track. The wheel system, or bogie, is comprised of four wheels and brake discs and is located at each end of a car. Each ICE train rides on 80 to 100 wheels, depending on the number of cars, with eight wheels per carriage. WHAT INVESTIGATORS KNOW: A stray strip of steel, identified as part of the tire, was found wedged in the bogie. Damaged ties and a switchbox six kilometers (3.7 miles) from the accident suggest this is where the tire broke apart. Unidentified pieces of the train were found at the site. Investigators theorize that the train derailed 300 meters (985 feet) before reaching the overpass. WHO MAKES THE WHEELS: The Hamburg-based company Bochum produced the wheels and bogies for the 60 first-generation InterCity Express high-speed trains. Bochum spokesman Goetz-Peter Blumbach said a faulty wheel on an ICE would be unprecedented. The bogie system was designed especially for Germany's InterCity Express, and is not used on any other trains. However, other trains in Europe use the wheel design. (me/cb)

BC-Sports-Tennis-Williams vs Williams,
Williams wins, loses in mixed doubles final
By SALVATORE ZANCA Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ It was a bit confusing. The chair umpire kept announcing ``Game Mademoiselle Williams'' or ``Advantage Mademoiselle Williams'' throughout the match. But it was unclear who he was referring to. There were occasional bead-clearing breaks on the court. And the winner and the loser could both say ``Hi, Mom'' to the same person. That's what happens when the Williams sisters play on opposite sides. Venus Williams, with Justin Gimselstob, beat younger sister Serena, partnered by Luis Lobo, in the mixed doubles final of the French Open on Friday, 6-4, 6-4. It was the second consecutive Grand Slam victory for Venus and Gimselstob, having won the same event in January at the Australian Open. ``We're closer to a Grand Slam than a lot of other people,'' Venus said. No other singles players are in the running to win both titles.'' Venus knows why she wanted Gimelstob as a partner. ``I needed to play with someone with similar height so I can feel comfortable,'' said Venus, who is 6-foot-1 1/2 (1.83 meters). ``And the other person would also feel comfortable and not lose confidence or any manhood.'' Serena, with green beads, took the early advantage over her older sister, with blue beads, opening up a 4-1 lead and a few chances to make it 5-1, with points delayed because of bead pickup duty. Then Venus and her partner settled down and took the next five games to win the first set. The second set went on serve until the seventh game, when Serena double faulted at game point to put Venus ahead 4-3. Venus held her serve the next game to go up 5-3, and the winners maintainted their advatange the rest of the way. Next is the Wimbledon mixed doubles. ``We practiced together once this time and twice in Australia,'' Gimelstob said. ``Maybe we will practice at Wimbledon.'' The sisters have met in tournamentd only twice in their singles careers, in the second round of this year's Australian Open and in the quarterfinals of the Italian Open. Venus won both matches. Venus said she didn't play women's doubles here with Serena because of the slowness of the clay, but looks forward to a partnership with her eventually. Venus' share of the dlrs 58,000 mixed doubles prize and Serena's share of the dlrs 35,000 runner-up prize make a considerable donation to the Williams family, who were in the stands. (sz/rg)

A PETROL price war may be imminent if Petroliam Nasional Bhd (Petronas) decides to join the fray and reduce petrol prices to defend its market share. ``We are ready to do what needs to be done to protect our market share. However, before we do anything, we want to know how far everyone goes. ``As the national oil company, our subsidiary Petronas Dagangan is ready to push the button,'' Petronas president and chief executive Tan Sri Hassan Marican told reporters after the annual general meeting of Petronas Gas Bhd yesterday. Hassan alluded to a similar situation in the 1990s when one oil company provided gifts and incentives to its customers in a big way and this destabilised the industry. However, that was a non-petrol issue, he said. ``Even then, Petronas was the last company to join the price war. This is happening again and it has gone into the petrol business. It has created instability in the market place,'' he added. Hassan said Petronas will be proactive and is holding discussions with other oil companies to determine the type of environment for the petrol industry. ``We will have to assess how the industry wants to conduct its business from now on because once a particular type of environment takes place, there is no looking back,'' said Hassan. According to him, the national oil company's 30 per cent market share in the retail business has not been affected much. Major foreign oil companies have introduced gifts, incentives and price cuts to attract customers. Unleaded petrol is priced at RM1.10 a litre currently, while leaded is slightly higher at RM1.13 a litre. Petrol prices are regulated by the Government. Hassan who is also chairman of Petronas Gas, said the participation of Petronas Gas in the Centralised Utility Facilities (CUF) project is the group's biggest commitment so far. The project, which will come on stream between 1999 and 2000, will supply value-added utilities such as steam, electricity, oxygen, nitrogen, demineralised water, waste water treatment and compressed air to the Integrated Petrochemical Complexes in Kertih (Terengganu) and Gebeng (Kuantan) as well as other plants in the surrounding areas. Hassan said six contracts for the CUF are now being tendered out. A major portion of the financing for the project will come from internally-generated funds and the balance from local borrowings. The project will have an impact on the revenue of Petronas Gas only in the following financial year, he said. ``With the first production of the CUF in July 1999, Petronas Gas will slowly transform itself from a mere transporter and processor of gas to a utility-based group,'' Hassan said. However, he stressed that gas will still be the main contributor to the group's profits. On the performance of Petronas Gas during the current financial year, Hassan said the volume of gas to be transported is expected to increase. This is because 70 per cent of the group's customers are power companies, which include Tenaga Nasional Bhd and independent power producers, and growth in electricity consumption is expected to rise. Gas Processing Plants (GPP) Five and Six are expected to start operations in stages from the middle of this year. The company's production capacity will eventually increase to 2,000 million standard cubic feet per day (mmscfd) from 1,000 mmscfd currently. More than RM1 billion was invested in the two processing plants.
