IN PAULINE Hanson's One Nation party lies the danger of Australia drifting away from Asia. Although anti-Asian sentiment is not something shared by most Australians, the impression given through newspaper reports is that it has garnered quite a bit of support Down Under. Asians residing and working in Australia are living anxiously, even if the national elections will not be held until later this year. The prospect of Hanson sinking the Conservative Government of John Howard at the electiosn requires stretching the average imagination, but it is a daunting thought nonetheless. One Nation is seen by Asians living in Australia as a potential direct threat to their own future and security. To Asians in general, it is viewed as the advocate of an abominable dogma which could lead to very unpleasant relations between Canberra and its Asian neighbours. The saving grace, since Hanson first hit the headlines nearly two years ago, is that her anti-Asian feelings have not been matched by anti-Australian sentiments. But in some countries in Asia where races have lived and worked together peacefully for decades, people are only too aware of what racial tension could lead to. Should Hanson come to power, Australia's foreign policy towards countries like Malaysia would certainly change, and vice-versa. Anti-Pauline Hanson feelings could turn into something stronger and uglier. Like its neighbours, Malaysians are quite concerned with developments related to this issue in Australia. Some of us have children studying in universities there or relatives and friends who have settled down in that country. Bilaterally, there are genuine concerns that all that has been painstakingly built over the years could come to naught. Malaysia and Australia have seen improved relations over the past few years despite more than a few hiccups. Canberra's ties with other Asian countries have also been good, even after the region started feeling the pangs of the financial problems that hit it in July last year. The anti-Asian policy, for all intents and purposes, must be viewed as a time-bomb capable of destroying the spirit of cooperation between friendly nations. For decades, Canberra has also assumed quite a prominent role in matters relating to the Asia Pacific region. Australia's brainchild, the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec), is now an important forum to discuss economic matters involving countries in the Asia Pacific. Australia's trading and investment ties with countries in the Association of South- East Asian Nations (Asean) has also been significant. Last year alone, trade between Australia and Asean stood at about US$22 billion (US$1 3.92). Australian companies operating in Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia have performed well during the good times and many are staying put despite the downturn, reflecting their confidence and comfort in operating in these countries. Choosing the next Australian Prime Minister is the democratic right of Australians, something that democratic Asians will not even want to question. If Australians by and large want Hanson to lead them, then so be it. Australia's neighbours in Asia, however, are justified in feeling anxious about how the former chip-shop owner will strategise her foreign policy with regards to strengthening bilateral ties with other countries if she indeed became the premier. As Asia struggles with its economic problems, it is looking to its friends near and far to help make things easier. Australia, as an economic powerhouse, has quite some means to extend a helping hand to Asia although its own economy is already feeling the contagion effects of the region's financial turmoil. It could buy more from the countries in the region or even participate in barter or counter trade with the countries affected. By helping the Asian economies in trouble, Australia would be helping check the spread of the contagion effect. But Asia will certainly have to leave it to Australia to either swim nearer to this region in trouble, or drift farther away.

Optimising Cambridge's resources, BUSINESS TIMES
Optimising Cambridge's resources, BUSINESS TIMES June 04, 1998 BUSINESS TIMES MALAYSIA ENGLISH Jennifer JacobsASIA WorldSources, Inc. 201 PENNSYLVANIA AVENUE, S.E., 2nd Floor
WASHINGTON, D.C. 20003 Tel: 202-547-4512 Fax: 202-546-4194 COPYRIGHT 1998 BY WORLDSOURCES, INC., A JOINT VENTURE OF FDCH, INC. AND WORLD TIMES, INC. NO PORTION OF THE MATERIALS CONTAINED HEREIN MAY BE USED IN ANY MEDIA WITHOUT ATTRIBUTION TO WORLDSOURCES, INC. CAMBRIDGE 2020, the initiative that will bring together the divergent resources of the university town to create a region with the economic power of US' Silicon Valley, was sparked off by Malaysia's Multimedia Super Corridor. Dr David Cleevely, managing director of Analysys Ltd, a Cambridge-based telecommunications consultancy, told Business Times in an interview that the Malaysian visit to the UK last year to promote the MSC engendered a realisation in Cambridge that it would have to come up with an overall plan to put to the best use all its resources, or risk being left behind. He said in May last year, Analysys, which has an office in the MSC, organised a visit to Cambridge for about 60 members of the Malaysian delegation promoting the MSC. After the visit, some Cambridge companies, financiers and members of the faculty got together at a dinner hosted by the university to promote links between the university and local industry. Most of those who were at this dinner had either attended Dr Mahathir's presentation on the MSC at the Imperial College or met with the members of the Malaysian delegation. So, the conversation at most tables revolved around the MSC. After the dinner, Cleevely said, speaker after speaker stood up and talked about what the Malaysian delegates had said, pointing out that this was clearly the way forward and it would have to be taken seriously. They realised that while Cambridge, one of the oldest universities in the world, and the ``heartland for telecommunications'' was sitting on considerable resources, it lacked a cohesive plan to bring all these resources together. ``Each little enterprise is pursuing its own line without reference to the others and if countries like Malaysia is coming up with initiatives like the MSC, there is a chance that, despite its resources, Cambridge will get left behind,'' Cleevely pointed out. He added that during the dinner he (Cleevely), Cambridge University vice-chancellor Sir Alec Broers, Hermann Hauser who founded Acorn as well as 20 other companies and runs Microsoft's venture capital company, Amadeus, in Cambridge and Louis McCagg who is involved in Cambridge Futures, were sitting at the same table discussing what needed to be done to meet this challenge. ``This got confirmed by over a third of the entire dinner who stood up and said something about Malaysia,'' he said. Cleevely said there were two main areas for Cambridge to get right - marketing and an internal policy to encourage cohesion between the companies. ``Everybody is talking about what a fantastic job the Malaysians are doing marketing the MSC. ``Marketing Cambridge is crucial because people do not understand what is going on here. ``This is the heartland of telecommunications. You would be astonished at how much the world has changed because of things that have come out of Cambridge,'' he said. Among its many achievements are the development of the first optic fibre cable, most of research for the PCN and GSM handsets, the first data network and the first digital computer. He added that the idea of digital communications was also first propounded in Cambridge and the first packet switch network in the world was developed and constructed here. Hauser, Broers and Cleevely had breakfast some four weeks later and invited Professor Marcial Echenique of ME Partners Urban Planning to discuss the matter further and they began to get a clearer idea of what needed to be done. Later, Cleevely called up Alcatel's marketing director Peter Radley who agreed to sponsor a report looking at how to optimise the communications and information technology in Cambridge. Analysys came up with the report entitled Cambridge 2020. ``We're looking at a 20-25 year time scale. 2020 is a great number and the Malaysians used it first. We `filched' it because we don't see why we shouldn't borrow some ideas. ``Dr Mahathir started the whole process and if it hadn't been for him coming here, this would never have happened,'' he said. ``This'' would essentially be a comprehensive plan for the creation of a region similar in economic power to the Silicon Valley. ``Before, we never had a coherent policy to put in the kind of physical, economic and social infrastructure you would need to achieve this.'' At the moment, he said, though Cambridge hosts the highest concentration of high-tech activity in Europe, it is small compared to global rivals, notably the Silicon Valley. Giving some comparative figures, he said, Silicon Valley has a population of 2.3 million, employs 1.2 million in its high-tech industries, its exports are worth some E25 billion (E1 RM6.41) a year and it had 3,575 new start-ups in the 1994/1995 period. The average per annum wage in Silicon Valley is E30,000. Cambridgeshire, on the other hand, has a population of 694,000, employs 35,000 in its high-tech industries, its exports are worth some E744 million a year and it had 87 new business start-ups in the same period. The average wage there is E19,000 per annum. Cleevely added that the development fits in with the splitting up of the UK into a series of economic regions. Cambridge happens to be at the geographical centre of the Eastern region. ``If we take into account the whole Eastern region, instead of having a city of 100,000 people, we would have a region of 6 million people and can draw on a lot more resources and a lot of space. ``Encompassed in the region are the British Telecom (BT) research laboratories in Harlow, Northern Telecom's (Nortel) laboratories where all the early work on optical fibre cable transmission was done, also in Harlow. Cleevely said at the moment, the priority for getting Cambridge 2020 off the ground, is to get the information planning guidelines of the region approved within the next 12 months. Then over the next three to four years, it will need to implement the critical elements of infrastructure including housing, transport, communications and social infrastructure linking matters such as local government, health, medicine and learning. ``After that, it has to be self-sustaining because it is going to have to be obvious that growth is being generated to justify further investment,'' he pointed out. Analysys will be organising a seminar on regulating multimedia and telecommunications at the Legend Hotel on June 23.

Relentless bid to check irresponsible currency speculation, BUSINESS TIMES
Relentless bid to check irresponsible currency speculation, BUSINESS TIMES June 04, 1998 BUSINESS TIMES MALAYSIA ENGLISH Lokman Mansor in TokyoASIA WorldSources, Inc. 201 PENNSYLVANIA AVENUE, S.E., 2nd Floor
WASHINGTON, D.C. 20003 Tel: 202-547-4512 Fax: 202-546-4194 COPYRIGHT 1998 BY WORLDSOURCES, INC., A JOINT VENTURE OF FDCH, INC. AND WORLD TIMES, INC. NO PORTION OF THE MATERIALS CONTAINED HEREIN MAY BE USED IN ANY MEDIA WITHOUT ATTRIBUTION TO WORLDSOURCES, INC. TOKYO: Malaysia has begun to lobby for global support for its proposal to reform the present international financial system, particularly to curb the damaging activities of currency speculators. Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad, who has on many occasions been vocal on the subject, on Tuesday presented the case to an audience of businessmen and economists in Tokyo. Speaking at the Institute for International Monetary Affairs' symposium on ``Revitalisation of the Japanese Economy and the Future of Asia'', he said the present system is ``messy, unreliable and destructive''. Dr Mahathir said there should be a new system which will bring about stability of exchange rates, among other things. Fixed exchange rate is no longer possible or realistic since political, economic and social performance of a country will have an effect on the currency. He said to gauge the economy, various indices could be given points to indicate the strength of the economy and therefore the currency. Economists could, for example, devise a measurement of the economic performance of a country using the political, economic and social indicators and then determine the relative values of currencies. Dr Mahathir began his speech by criticising, among others, the International Monetary Fund (IMF), reminding the audience of how the world body had given Malaysia a clean bill of health and praised the country's economic fundamentals just two weeks before the ``currency hurricane'' struck the region. ``I cite all this in order to address all those extremist ``market fundamentalists'' who believe that the market is always right and that the reason why so many of us are in desperate straits today is because we mismanaged our economies and because all our ``fundamentals'' were rotten to the core. ``If all our fundamentals are wrong, why were the foreign investors so eager and so foolish as to pour billions upon billions of investment dollars in our region? If our fundamentals were rotten to the core, why did all the clever analysts not say so?'' he asked. Dr Mahathir said yet these same people continue to predict, to be believed in and to influence the market. If it is wrong for insiders to leak information which can affect share prices, he said, then it should also be wrong for forecasters to forecast something which influences the market to their advantage. When the Prime Minister was addressing the audience, seated no more than 2 metres away was IMF first deputy managing director Mr Stanley Fischer, who sat noticeably quiet throughout, taking notes. Dr Mahathir left the symposium during the coffee break after his speech as he had another appointment in his heavily scheduled five-day working visit here, including individual meetings with high-ranking Japanese businessmen. Fischer, the first to speak as the symposium resumed, was expected to respond to Dr Mahathir's speech and this he did. ``Before I begin, I would like to respond to some of the statements made in the earlier session,'' Fischer said as he took to the podium. While admitting that there should be work towards a better international financial system, he said any effort to do so should not impose restrictions on the currencies in which trade can take place. This would set the world back to ``pre-World War arrangements'' such as bilateral balanced trade, which he argued was the way to slow and not resume progress. ``Globalisation really has two aspects. One of them is opening to trade, and it is extraordinary to hear globalisation fiercely criticised in this region, which more than any other had benefited over the last 40 years from the opening of the world economy and the developing of international trade,'' Fischer said. He said the unprecedented gains seen in East Asia would not have been possible without the opening of the world economy. ``We should not, under no circumstances, ignore that fact or imagine that there is some solution that would benefit countries in this region or anywhere that seeks to withdraw from a globalised system,'' Fischer added. This is indeed a very weak response. First of all, who said anything about withdrawing from a globalised system? Malaysia has long accepted the fact that globalisation is inevitable. It is merely pointing out the dangers that globalisation poses to developing economies. Precisely for this reason, various measures are being taken in Malaysia and elsewhere to prepare domestic economies for even greater globalisation in the future. And what about ``restrictions on currencies in which trade can take place'' that Fischer speaks of. If one understands Dr Mahathir's position correctly, reform is an exact necessity to allow the use of currencies in world trade. As long as currency speculation continues unchecked, currencies can be appreciated and devaluated in the space of several minutes or seconds. How is that going to help trade? Malaysia's proposal for bilateral balanced trade, which has already been endorsed and practised within Asean, is a perfectly logical measure to minimise the effect of their respective currency depreciations against the US dollar. At least, they are doing something about it. If both parties agree to use their own currencies to trade, how can that be wrong? Isn't that their choice to make? Or is criticism against this practice based more on the currency in the critic's wallet than on economic principles?

Netherlands crushes Nigeria 5-1 in final World Cup warm-up
By MIKE CORDER Associated Press Writer
AMSTERDAM, Netherlands (AP) _ Marc Overmars led the Netherlands to a crushing 5-1 victory over Nigeria Friday, scoring one goal and setting up two as the Dutch tore apart the Olympic champion down both flanks. It was both teams' last tune-up before the World Cup finals which begin June 10 in France. The Netherlands dominated the match, playing a fluent and fast passing game that cracked open Nigeria's defense and left the African side little chance to build up attacks. Speedy left winger Overmars tormented Nigeria with explosive bursts of pace down the flank. Inevitably, it was Overmars who tore away from his marker and crossed to set up the Netherlands' opening goal. Striker Patrick Kluivert was muscled off the ball but Leeds United marksman Jimmy Hasselbaink was on hand at the far post to slam a shot high into Nigeria's net in the 32nd minute. Minutes earlier, the Dutch nearly capped a slick passing move with a goal but Hasselbaink's shot was saved by Nigerian goalkeeper Peter Rufai. Nigeria almost replied immediately as Victor Ikpeba cut inside Jaap Stam to create room for a shot but could only blast over the bar. The Dutch took a deserved 2-0 lead in the 38th minute through dangerman Overmars. Latching onto a long pass out of defense, Overmars saw Rufai rushing off his line and deftly lobbed the ball into the net. Shortly after the break Hasselbaink nearly netted his second goal and the Netherlands' third when a diagonal pass from Kluivert left him with only substitute goalkeeper William Okpara to beat. Hasselbaink delayed his shot until Okpara dived, but Okpara managed to stick out a hand and deflect the shot wide. But the Netherlands stretched its lead on the hour through Kluivert _ again following an Overmars cross from the left. Nigeria reduced the lead in the 64th minute, Nwankwo Kanu shooting a penalty past his former Ajax teammate Edwin van der Sar after Winston Bogarde had fouled Daniel Amokachi. The goal spurred Nigeria on and first defender Taribo West saw a shot deflected to safety and then Kanu badly sliced a shot after being released by Amokachi. But the Netherlands stretched ahead again in the 74th minute from a fast break with Clarence Seedorf crossing from the right and Kluivert lashing in his second goal from close range. Substitute Pierre van Hooijdonk made it 5-1 in the 77th minute, guiding in a cross from Overmars' replacement Boudewijn Zenden. The Netherlands takes on South Korea, Belgium and Mexico in qualifying Group E while Nigeria plays Spain, Bulgaria and Paraguay in Group D. Lineups: Netherlands: Edwin van der Sar, Jaap Stam (Winston Bogarde, 45), Frank de Boer, Arthur Numan, Ronald de Boer (Wim Jonk, 45), Patrick Kluivert, Clarence Seedorf, Phillip Cocu (Edgar Davids, 45), Marc Overmars (Boudewijn Zenden, 75), Aron Winter, Jimmy Hasselbaink (Pierre van Hooijdonk, 75). Nigeria: Peter Rufai (William Okpara, 45), Jero Shakpoke (Augustine Eguavoen, 21, Austin Okacha 45), Uche Okechukwu, Taribo West, Celestine Babayaro, Godwin Okpara, Sunday Oliseh, Finidi George (Tijani Babangida, 45), Nwankwo Kanu (Wilson Oruma, 81), Victor Ikpeba (Daniel Amokachi, 45), Garba Lawal. Reunited Bosnian soccer teams enter Europe
Eds: UPDATES with Zeljeznicar winning. AP Photo By SRECKO LATAL Associated Press Writer
SARAJEVO, Bosnia-Herzegovina (AP) _ Blowing horns and whistles, waving flags and banners, thousands of fans streamed towards Kosevo stadium Friday for the final of Bosnia's soccer championship. The duel featured eternal rivals Zeljeznicar and Sarajevo _ but the real prize was something Bosnia's disunited soccer teams have not known: a ticket to the European Championship League for the winner. ``This may not be a World Cup match, but it is incredibly important for the Bosnian football,'' said Liam McDowall, a U.N. spokesman. Almost all of the 40,000 tickets were sold out in a match that served as a final preparation for monitoring the World Cup from armchairs in front of TV screens. Zeljeznicar won 1-0, bringing tears _ of joy or disappointment - from both teams and five minutes of glorious fireworks after the match Neighboring Yugoslavia and Croatia are competing in France, but Bosnia's soccer has been as disunited as the country itself and the national team had no chance of qualifying. This year, for the first time since war erupted in 1992, soccer teams from Bosnian Croat- and Muslim-dominated regions competed for the national championship. Four from the Muslim regions and two Croat sides competed in two groups. Claiming security concerns, teams from the Bosnian Serb substate _ Republika Srpska _ refused to participate. But everybody expects them aboard in the next season. It has taken three years for international sports organizations and foreign diplomats charged with implementing peace to negotiate a solution for Bosnia's disunited sports. The 4-2 Muslim-Croat combination was also adopted for this year's Bosnian basketball championships _ which the Serbs are also expected to join in 1999. The Croat side Siroki Brijeg defeated Sarajevo's Bosna, former European champions, for the local basketball crown. In recent weeks, the two groups in soccer played in Sarajevo and the tense southwestern town of Mostar. Hundreds of fans traveled back and forth without incident _ to the delight of Western diplomats still trying to overcome ethnic tensions. ``Even a year ago ... it would have been very difficult to imagine such games take place in Mostar without any trouble,'' said Martin Garrod, senior international official in Mostar. Fearing ethnic riots, U.N. police closely monitored each game. Fans simply wanted to see the best players. ``There was the war, but it's over now,'' said Sead Beric, a Zeljeznicar fan, heading for the stadium. ``Now, without all good players, whether they are Bosnian Serbs, Croats, Muslims, Jews, Eskimos or others, we cannot hope to become something in world soccer and participate in the next World Cup.'' (sl/gj)

Vicor to buy Japan Tobacco's power supply assets
ANDOVER, Massachusetts. (AP) _ Vicor Corp. said Friday it agreed to acquire the principal assets of two money-losing power supply businesses owned by Japan Tobacco Inc. Terms of the transaction, expected to close this month, were not disclosed. Vicor, based in Andover, Massachusetts, manufactures power systems and modular power components. It had revenue of dlrs162 million in 1997. Japan Tobacco, based in Tokyo, is Japan's former tobacco and salt monopoly. It now makes tobacco products and is diversifying primarily in pharmaceuticals, food, agribusiness, real-estate and engineering. It had sales of 3.6 trillion yen (dlrs26 billion) in the year ended March 31. Vicor said it will purchase the customer lists of JT Electronics Corp. and all of the automated manufacturing equipment used by JT PowerCraft Corp. for manufacture of modular converter products, as well as its raw materials and finished goods inventories. Vicor will move JT PowerCraft's manufacturing operations, including equipment, to Andover. Japan Tobacco will close JT Electronics, and Vicor will establish a direct sales presence in Japan through a new company called Vicor Japan Co. Japan Tobacco expects losses of 8 billion yen from the sale of the businesses.

SHARES on the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange (KLSE) closed off its high yesterday, on selective buying interest on blue-chips. KLSE's key barometer gained momentum in the afternoon when it rose close to 14 points after closing three points higher by noon break. The gain was later trimmed as some index-linked stocks succumbed to selling pressure when local and foreign players sold to lock in profits. Analysts said shares extended its technical rebound on Tuesday on buying support by local and foreign funds which were seen covering short positions. However, trading is expected to remain thin and any rebound on the bourse is expected to be shortlived over concerns on the shrinking economy and corporate earnings. The KLCI was up 5.75 points to 526.36 compared with Tuesday's close of 520.61. The KLSE's Second Board closed 0.70 point higher to 111.19 while the broader Emas Index rose 1.47 points to close at 134.48. The scoreboard showed gainers outpacing losers 394 to 173 with 171 counters remained unchanged. The broad-based BT Ordinaries gained 1.31 to 127.59 while the 30-share New Straits Industrial Index lost 18.26 points to close at 3,050.96. MALAYSIAN Helicopter Services Bhd, soon to be known as Naluri Bhd, expects to reap some RM220 million from the divestment of its assets to partly cover its borrowings as well as bond repayment. Recently retired executive chairman of MHS Tan Sri Saw Huat Lye, said the company's immediate plans include downsizing efforts aimed at reducing its borrowings which currently stand at RM300 million. Some RM120 million from the divestment of its assets will be used to repay its borrowings while RM100 million will be used for bond repayment in mid June. ``We have the funds to meet this requirement given our divestment. So as far as our immediate future is concerned we are okay,'' Saw told reporters after the company's annual and extraordinary general meeting yesterday. As part of the plan, the group will dispose of its major asset - MHS Aviation to DRIR Equities Sdn Bhd - for RM160 million which Saw expressed will substantially reduce the group's borrowings. Also on the cards is the divestment of Pacific Pleasures Ltd which has yet to be concluded and is expected to result in ``favourable profits'' of US$5 million (US$1 RM3.92) while the company has sold a building in Petaling Jaya for RM50 million. Saw also stressed that although the share price on the local bourse is trading below par (it closed at 53 sen yesterday), the company's net tangible assets is well above par at RM2.70 and as such, the shares are under-valued. At a ``very pleasant and short'' meeting yesterday, Saw said the shareholders had generally appreciated what was being done by the company to face the difficult times ahead. Of particular concern to shareholders was the issue of borrowings which has increased substantially particulary given the high interest rates and tight liquidity environment, he said, adding that they had approved the name change to Naluri. Meanwhile, Saw said MHS' investment in Air Maldives Ltd and Royal Air Cambodge Co Ltd (RAC) which is ``not very large'' is beginning to turn around as both airlines have reduced their capacity to meet the market demand. ``In fact, Air Maldives has reported its first profitable quarter,'' said Saw, adding that although the profit chalked up was about US$100,000, it was a good start. Air Maldives begun operations in November 1994 with a Airbus A300-B4. Saw said since the airbus was too big, the airline was losing money. Since then, it has been replaced with a smaller Airbus A320 which is more realistic based on the market size and as such, is beginning to cover cost. Similarly, RAC - 40 per cent owned by MHS - which started with two B737s, only operates one now and seems to be faring well although the political situation in Cambodia still remains unstable. Meanwhile, newly appointed chairman of MHS Tan Sri Tajudin Ramli explained the group's repositioning strategy based on the convergence of technology. He said the new holding company - Naluri Bhd - will be involved in transportation, tourism and technology, and will undertake to divest some businesses ``that are not exciting in terms of profits''. To a question on whether Technology Resources Industries will be put under MHS, he replied, it will continue to remain under his personal holdings. Tajudin also declined to respond to any questions pertaining to Malaysian Airlines System Bhd's restructuring proposal saying the announcement will be made in a month's time.

BC-Eritrea-Ethiopia, 6th Ld-Writethru,0669
Eritreans down two Ethiopian jets that bomb air base
Eds: UPDATES throughout with comments from Washington, EDITS to tighten; ADDS photo numbers; STANDS as 4th Ld-Writethru for some points. AP Photos AMS101-103 By JULIA STEWART Associated Press Writer
ASMARA, Eritrea (AP) _ Ethiopian military planes bombed an air force base outside the Eritrean capital Friday before being shot down by Eritrean anti-aircraft guns in an escalating border dispute between two of the world's poorest countries. Two Ethiopian MiG-23 fighter planes on Friday afternoon bombed two hangars at an air base outside Asmara that is adjacent to the international airport. A commercial airliner on the tarmac was reported damaged. Eritrean guns then shot the planes down. Witnesses saw several injured people being transported in trucks, but it was not immediately possible to determine the number of wounded or the fate of the Ethiopian pilots. In the Ethiopian capital, Addis Ababa, the Foreign Ministry said the bombing was in retaliation for an Eritrean attack on Mekele, 200 kilometers (125 miles) north of Addis, on Friday that wounded five Ethiopians. Reliable Ethiopian sources said fighting continued for a third day Friday around the border town of Zala Ambassa, about 100 kilometers (60 miles) north of Mekele, where both sides traded tank, artillery and mortar fire. Ethiopian fighters attacked Eritrean tanks that were moving toward Adigrat, about 20 kilometers (10 miles) west. Both armies used aircraft, tanks and artillery supplied to Ethiopia by the Soviet Union during the Cold War. The attacks came a day after Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi agreed to a four-point proposal put forth by the United States and Rwanda to end the two countries' border conflict peacefully. But Meles warned that his country's patience with Eritrea was wearing thin because of Eritrea's refusal to withdraw from territory Ethiopia claims it occupied a month ago. The Eritrean government issued a statement Friday saying there were ``still serious issues of detail and implementation to be worked out'' with the proposal. It added that it would never ``acquiesce to the language of force and intimidation and will, if necessary, resolutely defend its hard-won right to live in peace and freedom.'' Jubilant Eritreans poured into the streets of Asmara waving the blue, green and red flags of their young nation after the Ethiopian fighters were shot down. ``They thought they would terrorize the Eritrean people, but it worked the opposite,'' said Yemane Kifle, a business consultant. The conflict prompted the U.S. State Department to order nonessential staff out of Eritrea and urge other Americans to leave. Peace Corp volunteers also were evacuated. In Washington, a State Department official said a plane carrying 122 Americans and 70 other foreigners, mostly Britons and Canadians, left Eritrea on Friday. The official said the plane was heading for Frankfurt, Germany, with an intermediate stop in Cairo, Egypt. The State Department called on Ethiopia and Eritrea to cease all hostilities while outside envoys seek a peaceful resolution of the dispute. At the United Nations in New York, U.S. Ambassador Bill Richardson said Friday that the United States is ``very concerned'' over the escalation of tension between Eritrea and Ethiopia and would initiate efforts in the Security Council to deal with the issue. One of the recommendations of the U.S.-Rwandan proposal was that Eritrea withdraw to positions held before May 6. Eritrea, which gained independence from Ethiopia in 1993, has always claimed it remains inside its own territory as determined by Italian colonial boundaries. Eritrean rebels under the command of President Isaias Afwerki were instrumental in helping Meles' Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front overthrow a 17-year military regime in July 1991.

BC-Colombia-Exile,0663
Colombian president offers rights workers ticket to safety
By JARED KOTLER Associated Press Writer
BOGOTA, Colombia (AP) _ Unable to shield Colombia's human rights workers from threats and violence, President Ernesto Samper is offering them tickets on the next plane out. A government fund will allow 30 to 40 threatened activists to live and study abroad until they feel safe returning home, Samper said. ``If they want to voluntarily go abroad until the circumstances clear up, I am obliged to find a way to help them,'' the Colombian leader told The Associated Press in an interview this week. While human rights monitors say the program could provide relief, some wonder about the president's motives. ``At one level it could be a useful program,'' said Coletta Youngers of the Washington Office on Latin America. ``But it's ironic that they're trying to get their critics out of the country.'' Last year, 27 Colombian human rights activists were assassinated, up from eight in 1996, according to Colombian Commission of Jurists. Two have been shot dead this year. Death threats have forced at least three provincial rights organization to shut down in the past year. Judicial investigators believe right-wing paramilitary groups and current or former security force members are behind the violence. One of the activists killed, Jesus Maria Valle Jaramillo, had accused the army and high-ranking politicians of sponsoring death squads. Amnesty International's secretary-general, Pierre Sane, last month called the government's failure to guarantee rights monitors' safety ``at best gross irresponsibility and at worst criminal negligence.'' The amount of the grant to each activist who decides to leave will depend on the cost of living in the country of refuge, but will be ``enough to assure a dignified existence,'' Samper said. Canada, France, Spain and Sweden were among countries that have indicated a willingness to receive the activists, the president said. The government is seeking additional money from foreign governments and private donors to augment the dlrs 550,000 it has pledged. Human rights groups will take advantage of the scholarships, said Carlos Rodriguez Mejia of the Colombian Commission of Jurists. But the best measure of protection would be to arrest and prosecute those responsible for the attacks on rights defenders, he added. ``What we really want are guarantees that we can live in Colombia and work here,'' Rodriguez said. Military officers frequently have accused rights groups of links with leftist guerrillas who have been waging war against the state for more than 30 years. Last month, prosecutors acting on an army request searched the Bogota office of a Roman Catholic Church-sponsored rights group, Justice and Peace. Terrified nuns were forced to their knees by soldiers in combat gear during the search, which outraged the international human rights community. Samper, who leaves office in August, is widely blamed for failing to prevent attacks on rights monitors, creating a climate of fear under which several leading activists already have fled Colombia. The government professes to have done its best to protect human rights workers. Samper has issued decrees recognizing human rights work as legitimate and instructing public officials to refrain from statements accusing rights workers of guerrilla ties. Last year, the government created a protection program for rights activists, offering courses on security as well as surveillance cameras, police bodyguards and armored cars. Human rights groups have complained that the protection program is inadequately funded and has drawn bodyguards from same security forces suspected of involvement in attacks. Samper's office promises to triple the budget to about dlrs 1.1 million this year, and select bodyguards from rosters provided by the human rights groups.

THE Government expects to earn RM24 billion from income tax this year, 29 per cent less than it had earlier projected. Deputy Finance Minister Datuk Wong See Wah said the Government had earlier forecast that the taxes collected by the Inland Revenue Board (IRB) could reach RM31 billion this year. ``This forecast has been revised to RM24 billion in view of the economic uncertainties,'' he told reporters after launching the board's new logo in Kuala Lumpur yesterday. Wong said the lower projection would be the result of among other things, the lower collection of corporate taxes as companies are not registering good performances during the economic slowdown. The Government has also introduced measures to boost investments and assist businesses. These include lowering certain taxes or abolishing them altogether. Wong said all these will have implications to the overall IRB's tax collections for this year. In his speech earlier, the Deputy Minister said during the present economic turmoil, the Government places high hopes on the Inland Revenue Board (IRB) to boost the country's earnings via direct taxes. He noted that ever since the board was corporatised on March 1, 1996, there have been numerous changes as well as achievements made by the IRB. Wong said the Government takes pride in the efficient manner of the board in its tax collection activities since the corporatisation took place. Last year, the IRB's tax collections amounted to RM30.47 billion compared with RM25.8 billion in 1996. For the first quarter of this year, the total tax collections amounted to RM10.33 billion compared with RM9.056 billion in the corresponding period a year ago. This was an improvement of some 14 per cent. Wong also said the IRB should be strict and yet fair in implementing the country's regulations tax payments, especially during the times of economic turmoil. He urged companies to complete their respective financial statements fast and immediately submit their account statements to the IRB so that tax assesments can be made. ``For those companies that need to reschedule their income tax payments, they can contact the board after the tax assessment notices are issued,'' he added. Wong said as of May 31, 232 companies had appealed for a reschedule in their rspective income tax payments.

BC-Sports-Boxing-Holyfield-Akinwande, 6th Ld-Writethru,0513
Akinwande-Holyfield fight called off
Eds: UPDATES with entire Saturday night card scrapped By TIM DAHLBERG AP Sports Writer
NEW YORK (AP) _ Henry Akinwande tested positive for hepatitis B and was ruled ineligible to fight heavyweight champion Evander Holyfield on Saturday. The finding came in two separate medical tests conducted by the New York State Athletic Commission, said Greg Fritz, a spokesman for Don King Productions, the promoter of the fight. ``The fight is off,'' Fritz said Friday. The commission does not allow infected boxers to fight because of the risk of transmitting the disease through blood during bouts. Hepatitis B, often contracted through sex or dirty hypodermic needles, can cause serious liver problems. The disease can be treated successfully, but not always. Hepatitis A is typically a food-borne disease that can pass quickly. The entire Saturday night card at Madison Square Garden was scrapped. Heavyweight Ray Mercer, who was to fight on the undercard against Jerry Ballard, also was suspended for medical reasons, said Ralph Petrillo, medical coordinator for the athletic commission. He also said Akinwande was under a medical suspension, but he declined to elaborate. They were the second and third medical suspension to hit Saturday's card. On Thursday, Mexican lightweight Maria de las Nieves Garcia was scratched from her undercard bout with Christy Martin because tests showed she is pregnant. Melissa Salamore was to have replaced Garcia, but Martin rejected her as an opponent and promoters were trying to find someone else to replace her. The Akinwande decision is yet another blow to his career. He was disqualified during a bout against WBC champ Lennox Lewis in July for repeated holding. That Akinwande was fighting for a piece of the title for the second time in less than a year was due more to his choice of promoter than anything else. After the Lewis debacle, promoter Don King matched him against Orlin Norris Jr., and Akinwande won a 12-round decision to become the mandatory contender. Holyfield was to have fought Lewis to unify the heavyweight championship for the first time since Riddick Bowe threw the WBC belt into a garbage can after his win over Holyfield in their first fight. But with Holyfield wanting dlrs 20 million for the fight and Lewis unwilling to give up his relationship with the HBO network, talks collapsed and Holyfield was left only with the option of taking a mandatory title defense to keep his WBA title. The fight was supposed to top a card that included 46-year-old Roberto Duran fighting for a title nine years after he lost his middleweight crown to Sugar Ray Leonard. Duran first fought in the Garden in 1971, and is 6-1 in his career at the arena. Duran, like Akinwande, hardly earned his title shot, winning a decision in Panama in his last fight after getting knocked down in the first round.

THE Cabinet approved yesterday public transportation fares between RM6.50 and RM85 (single journey) to the KL International Airport (KLIA) in Sepang, which is scheduled to be opened later this month. Entrepreneur Development Minister Datuk Mustapa Mohamed said the public has a choice of seven types of public transportation to KLIA. These include a combination of the KTM Komuter and stage buses, stage buses from the Tun Razak hockey stadium, the bus shuttle service which includes the semi-luxury and luxury express buses, Klang Valley taxis and the limousine service which includes the premier and budget taxis. Speaking to reporters in Kuala Lumpur yesterday after launching the Small Entrepreneur Service Centre at the National Entrepreneur Guidance Centre, Mustapa described the fares as ``reasonable''. ``If we look at the fare per km, the fares agreed upon are reasonable. Furthermore, we have to take into account that prices of new cars have increased and interest rates for loans to purchase cars have also increased,'' he said. Giving a comparison, Mustapa said the fare from the city centre to the Sultan Abdul Aziz Shah International Airport in Subang is RM25.60, which is RM1.14 per km, while the fare from the city centre to KLIA is RM0.75 a km. He added that the various companies involved in providing the public transport to the airport in Sepang will be carrying out trial runs on June 5 and 6. ``This is to see what are some of the problems that may arise,'' he said, adding that among the problems anticipated are traffic congestion and the frequency of transport. ``There must be a bus every 15 minutes and the response time for taxis has to be as minimal as possible. ``The trial run scheduled for the middle of June will be in full force and there will also be another trial run between three and four days before the opening of the airport,'' he added. For the option of taking a combination of the KTM Komuter and stage buses, the minister said users can take the commuter from the city to the Batang Benar station which is one-stop away from Nilai. ``From Nilai, they then take the stage buses to the airport and the fare for the combination of the commuter and stage buses is RM6.50,'' he said. One other option is the stage bus which will depart from the Tun Razak hockey stadium will cost RM7.70. This bus will make four stops and will mainly cater to those working at KLIA. ``The semi-luxury express bus fare is RM18 for one way while the luxury bus fare is RM25,'' he said. The bus shuttle service is overseen by Kuala Lumpur City Bus, a joint venture led by Intrakota and Parkmay. On the other hand, the metered taxi fare will cost RM46. This however, does not include the surcharge which is still being discussed. At present the surcharge imposed by metered taxis to the is RM3. For the limousine service, the fare for the budget taxis from the city centre to KLIA is RM55 while from KLIA to the city centre is RM65, he said. ``The consortium has also agreed to have a return ticket which will cost RM98 and these return tickets are valid for six months and are transferable,'' he said. Airport Limo (M) Sdn Bhd, the consortium awarded the KLIA limousine service, has also agreed to a lower fare for the premier taxi service, said Mustapa. From KLIA to the city centre, the fare is RM88 while from the city centre to KLIA is RM66 while the return fare is RM140, he added. The budget taxi service will see the use of the Proton Wira while the premier taxi service will use the Mercedes Benz, Proton Perdana and the Fiat Ulysses, a multi-purpose vehicle. The consortium, he added, will be using Proton Wira (350 units), Mercedes Benz (150 units), Proton Perdana (200 units) and Fiat Ulysses (100 units).

JERUSALEM (AP) _ Fearing that government approval of a West Bank troop withdrawal is imminent, Jewish settlers on Friday took senior members of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's Likud Party on flights over the disputed land in hopes of scuttling a pullback. Settlers also threatened to establish at least two new Jewish settlements if Netanyahu accepts a U.S. withdrawal proposal that would leave 40 percent of the West Bank under Palestinian control and restrict settlement expansion. As a result of the withdrawal, ``the settlements are turning into enclaves in Palestinian areas and in our view, this is a life-and-death battle,'' said settler spokesman Aharon Domb. Under the American plan, Israel would withdraw from 13 percent of the West Bank over a 12-week period, in exchange for Palestinian security measures, such as collecting illegal weapons. Negotiations on a permanent peace agreement would begin with the first pullback. Two senior Palestinian negotiators were to brief Arafat later Friday on their talks with the U.S. Mideast envoy, Dennis Ross. Israel army radio said Ross asked the Palestinians to accept several changes in the original U.S. proposal, but that report could not be confirmed. A remaining sticking point is the scope of an additional pullback promised by Israel. Netanyahu wants assurances now that he will not have to hand over more than 2 percent at the time, a demand rejected by the Palestinians. Despite continued disagreements, both Netanyahu and Arafat seemed mildly optimistic in their assessments. Netanyahu said Thursday that ``some progress'' had been made, while Arafat said he was assured by U.S. mediators that a deal would be wrapped up by mid-June. COMPANIES should use electronic commerce (e-commerce) in their business transactions especially now the country is experiencing an economic slowdown as its saves not only time but also money, Electronic Data Interchange Malaysia Sdn Bhd (EDIM) said. Its chief executive officer, Mr Indra Gunawan Alamshah, said the country is already saving RM100 million a year through the paperless form of transactions. Contrary to popular belief, EDIM not only is offering its services to the freighter forwarding industry at Port Klang but also complements the retail industry. He said large retail stores can better run their businesses by outsourcing the management of their inventories to companies like EDIM. ``By enabling us to take care of this aspect of the business for them they can then focus their efforts on other important areas, such as marketing, he told Business Times. Indra said this involves the proper management of shelf space and the smooth running of retailers' inventories. ``With e-commerce, we can track supply of stocks and automatically order more stock when that particular stock falls below a certain level. We are connected on-line with the retailers' suppliers,'' he said, adding that the objective is to manage shelf space right so as not to over order products which do not move fast enough. ``Managing shelf space efficiently is the key to businesses which aim to maximise their turnover.'' Jaya Jusco Stores Bhd is already operating the first phase of its e- commerce system, the ``Jaya Jusco Electronic Retail Community'', which was developed by EDIM, while Parkson is also looking into it. Users are already giving favourable feeback to the RM15 system at Jaya Jusco. They see a vast improvement over the manual procedures. The system elctronically transmits purchase orders to suppliers who immediately deliver the goods. E-commerce is a method of doing business over the computer network. It is estimated that by the year 2,000, the value of trade carried out using this method will be as much as US$200 billion. By that time, the US expects 25 per cent of its economy to be conducted that way. On the use of e-commerce in ports, Indra said the procedures in Customs clearance of goods are very complicated and long. ``It therefore justifies the need for a third party to offer its services to facilitate the clearance of goods,'' he said, adding that the company will very much like to expand beyond the Customs and forwarders, but are unable to do so. ``We tried to use the concession for the ports and Customs as a stepping stone to expand into other related businesses such as retail and managing the network services,'' he said.

Germany routs Luxembourg part-timers 7-0 to keep guessing game
alive EDS: ADDS quotes, RECASTS in parts, ADDS byline. By ROY KAMMERER Associated Press Writer
MANNHEIM, Germany (AP) _ Germany's 7-0 victory Friday over Luxembourg's part-timers will only keep alive the guessing game surrounding the three-time World Cup champion's likely starters in France. German coach Berti Vogts challenged several players before the match to prove they belong among his starting ll. None of them had problems shining against the overmatched Duchy in the team's final tuneup before France. ``I'm happy I've got a team where I have two good players for each position _ it's a long World Cup and we have a lot of choices,'' said Vogts, who refuses to name his starting lineup. Juergen Klinsmann, fighting for a striker position, drove in a 15th minute header from the edge of the box and midfielder Christian Ziege erased away some poor performances recently by scoring in the 85th. Thomas Helmer, who connected from short-range after scooping up Olaf Thon's long downfield pass, showed a recent knee injury may not stop the defender from reclaiming his starting job. Midfielder Joerg Heinrich, who recently seemed to have misplayed himself onto the bank, launched a perfect seventh minute cross that a sliding Ulf Kirsten blasted in with an outstretched leg. Kirsten, Klinsmann's main rival, added a second goal in the 45th. Oliver Bierhoff proved he's one of the few players with a lock on a starting role by connecting in the 56th and 72nd _ his 17th goal in 27 caps. Luxembourg's players, with only one full-time professional, offered little resistance as the Germans strived to display their best side for Vogts. ``It was a good training session for us, nothing more,'' shrugged Bierhoff. ``For us strikers it was good because we could fatten our goal total.'' On a sweltering night, the Germans had a much easier time with Luxembourg than Cameroon, another World Cup team, which struggled to a 2-0 victory Sunday. Germany looked dismal in a scoreless draw against Finland a two weeks ago, a performance which almost cost several players their starting jobs. But the team was impressive in a 3-1 victory Saturday against Colombia. For Vogts, the last two outings are a clear sign the team is reaching its stride before the June 15 opener against the United States. ``There were too many loose passes as far as I'm concerned, but it's getting better and better,'' said Vogts. ``I wanted a clear improvement over Colombia and I got it.'' Luxembourg didn't have a real shot on goal until the 79th minute when Serge Thill found himself loose in front of Jens Lehmann, but fired the ball straight into the keeper's hands. As an indication of Luxembourg's near amatuer status, Thill had been inserted late in the match for Gordon Braun, a forward busy cramming for college exams. Klinsmann, who outraced the slow Luxembourg defenders, showed he may have regained his former explosiveness as he and Kirsten continue their fierce battle to claim the second forward start. Vogts has already called his striker foursome, which also includes FC Kaiserslautern's Olaf Marschall, the best the German team has boasted since the 1970 World Cup. But Vogts isn't saying which striker will start along Bierhoff or who else will surface on top for starting roles. ``The coach has a clear idea of what he wants _ we'll just have to accept his decisions,'' said libero Lothar Matthaeus. Injured Torrence likely to miss USA and Goodwill 100s
By BERT ROSENTHAL AP Track Writer
BUFFALO, New York (AP) _ Gwen Torrence, the world's top-ranked women's 100-meter runner in 1994 and 1995, probably will miss the event at the national championships and Goodwill Games because of an injured left leg. Torrence was hurt about two weeks during a race at Georgia Tech and has not run during training since then. ``I'm so far behind as far as sprinting goes,'' she said Friday during a conference call from Atlanta. ``It doesn't look like I'll be able to run the 100.'' Torrence, also the 1995 world champion in the 100 and the 1992 Olympic gold medalist in the 200 meters, said that if she competed in the USA Championships June 19-21 at New Orleans or the Goodwill Games at Uniondale, New York, July 19-22, it probably would be in the 400, in which she was ranked No. 1 in the U.S. in 1992. ``It depends on how my quad heals,'' she said. ``I'm looking toward the 400 for the European season and the Goodwill Games. ``I want to run something. If I don't think I can run 10.8 (seconds for the 100), I will look toward something else. ``At this stage, I just want to go to the party. I don't know if I will be able to dance, but I just want to compete.'' Torrence, who will be 33 next week, said she her days of competing in the 200 probably are over, ``because it's too difficult to train for the 200. It's easier to train for the 400. To run the 200, you have to train like a quarter-miler.'' Last year was the first time since she became an elite runner in 1982 that Torrence did not compete in the 200. The past two years have been injury marred and frustrating for the highly competitive Torrence. After competing in two indoor races in 1997, she injured her left hamstring. After recuperating, she was into her second race outdoors when she was hurt again. ``I had strained my leg badly and I had dislocated something in my groin and my hip bone,'' Torrence said. She doesn't want surgery on her latest injury, preferring to let the injury heal by itself. ``If I have to go under the knife, I will have a very early retirement,'' she said. Torrence said her recovery is ``going well.'' ``I can jog, I can do stadium stairs, but when I try to lift (her leg while running), I have problems,'' she said. At the Goodwill Games, Torrence was supposed to compete in the 100 against 1997 world champion Marion Jones, two-time Olympic champion Gail Devers and two-time world 200 champion Merlene Ottey of Jamaica. Most likely, she will have to withdraw.

What the passengers heard: crash probe focuses on broken wheel
EDS: UPDATES with two victims dying at hospital, grafs 10-11. CHANGES number of hospitalized By TONY CZUCZKA Associated Press Writer
ESCHEDE, Germany (AP) _ The reason for the noise that rattled some passengers minutes before InterCity Express 884 smashed into a bridge is now clear: investigators confirmed Friday that a broken wheel was the most likely cause of derailment and disaster. The damaged wheel was located on the first car behind the locomotive. Investigators didn't have to go far to find the fractured steel rim that encircles the wheel, and helps keep the train on the tracks. It had flown off and was lodged in the bogie, the set of four wheels at each end of a car. Another clue: A still unidentified piece of the train was found on the tracks six kilometers (3.7 miles) from the concrete and steel bridge that the train struck broadside. That piece _ and damage to both the rail and ties nearby _ corroborates passengers' recollections of noise and vibration two minutes before the derailed train started breaking apart and crashed into supports of an overpass. At 200 kph (125 mph) the train would have traveled the distance in less than two minutes. ``There was an uncomfortable rattling and I had the feeling that maybe something was lying on the tracks,'' Wolf-Ruediger Shliebener recalled. ``People looked at each other, shocked.'' He said it stopped for a second. Then there was a crash. It still isn't clear what knocked down the bridge. A broadcast report suggested that the fifth car, the last to get past the falling bridge, had knocked down a support. But federal railway spokesman Jens Boehlke said it was conceivable that the destabilized first car had struck a support, and that the deck had not fallen down on the speeding train until several cars had gotten through. The seven remaining passenger cars and rear locomotive then jackknifed into each other. More than 1,200 rescuers using jackhammers, cranes and cutting tools worked around the clock to free survivors the first day, then increasingly victims as they dug deeper into the tangle of metal and shattered glass. The 93rd body was recovered Friday under a 10-meter piece of road that had fallen next to the train, and two more victims died at hospitals, raising the death toll to 98. Rescue workers said they could not rule out the possibility that other bodies would be found until the debris was cleared from the four-track line. By Friday evening, 19 victims had been identified and 55 people were still hospitalized. The wheel theory has not yet been proven, but is the focus of investigators' questions. Still unexplained is whether the wheel broke apart due to metal fatigue, or some outside force. ``We are extremely interested in researching the cause for the break in the tire, and we will of course go after this with special intensity,'' authorities said in a statement. Boehlke said that in the seven years the high-speed InterCity Express trains have been in service, there has been no similar break or failure in the wheels. An investigation _ being conducted by a special commission of police, rail and other experts and supervised by prosecutors _ may take months to complete. It will include interviews of surviving passengers and rail personnel as well as maintenance workers. The federal railway authority, which sets standards for safety and service, issued a statement that said sabotage has not been ruled out. However, no one has produced any evidence that suggests tampering. ``Any suggestion of the cause of the accident at this point is speculative,'' the statement said. Joachim Haack, police spokesman at Eschede, said the findings pointed to a mechanical reason. The crushed train was one of the first generation of high-speed trains introduced in Germany in 1991. The other 59 trains in that group were taken out of service Thursday night for emergency inspections, and half had returned to duty by Friday evening. Steel tires require regular inspection and replacement because of wear. Typically, a new tire is expanded by heating it red hot, then it is slipped over the wheel disc and shrinks tightly to fit, said Richard Gibbon, curator of engineers at the National Railway Museum in York, England. British high-speed trains may clock 1.5 million miles a year, but the tires may wear out in 100,000 miles, Gibbon said. Trains in the United States use a solid wheel with no removable tire, he added. UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ In an unusually strong statement, U.N. chief Kofi Annan accused Serb forces of ``atrocities'' in Kosovo and demanded Friday that ``this kind of aggression'' be confronted ``immediately and with determination.'' The Security Council discussed the deteriorating situation in Kosovo on Friday. More than 250 people have died since March 1 in escalating clashes between government forces and the Kosovo Liberation Army, the armed wing of the Albanian independence movement. The council president, Ambassador Antonio Monteiro of Portugal, said the 15 members ``expressed their grave concern'' and called for the ``immediate cessation'' of violence, especially ``the excessive use of force'' against civilians. ``We all, I think, share the view that unfortunately, Belgrade seems to be trying to impose a military solution upon the Kosovo issue,'' British Ambassador John Weston said. The United Nations is often reluctant to level such accusations against sovereign governments for actions within their borders. ``The secretary-general is deeply disturbed by the latest reports of an intensifying campaign against the unarmed civilian population in Kosovo,'' Brandt said. ``He reiterates in the strongest possible terms his condemnation of the atrocities committed by Serbian military and paramilitary forces.'' He said those forces ``must not be allowed to repeat the campaign of ethnic cleansing and indiscriminate attacks on civilians that characterized the war in Bosnia.'' ``If the world has learned anything from that dire chapter in history, it is that this kind of aggression must be confronted immediately and with determination,'' the statement added. At a news conference, Yugoslavia's acting U.N. ambassador, Vladislav Jovanovic, said the Serb government, which along with Montenegro forms the Yugoslav federation, was ``firmly committed'' to a ``serious and productive dialogue'' with Kosovo Albanians. ``But first of all, the terrorist activities and banditry should cease at once and those from the Albanian side and the outside world who are ambivalent about terrorism should make a very firm and very clear statement condemning the terrorism,'' Jovanovic said. Brandt said U.N. refugee officials in northern Albania report that the influx of refugees from Kosovo appears to be slowing. He said 400 people crossed the border into Albania by dawn Friday. WARSAW, Poland (AP) _ It took 10 hours of negotiations and two votes Friday for the lower chamber of parliament to endorse a government plan to reduce the number of Poland's provinces from 49 to 12. In a second ballot on the measure, the 460-member lower house, or Sejm, voted 246-202 with three abstentions to support one of the major components of a broad reform program pushed by the Solidarity-led governing coalition. The figures were roughly reversed from the first ballot, when some members of the coalition refused to support the plan despite pressure from government leaders. The chamber also rejected another proposal to establish 17 provinces. But after numerous recesses and negotiations among coalition members, the governing bloc managed to muster enough support for the 12 province measure. Prime Minister Jerzy Buzek said reducing the number of provinces to 12 was the best option, while Michal Kulesza, the plan's author, called the vote ``Poland's success because the most rational division won.'' The bill now goes to the upper chamber, or Senate, for approval and then needs to be signed by President Aleksander Kwasniewski, a former communist who is expected to approve it. Under the reform program, to be introduced Jan. 1, Poland would shed the remains of its communist-era bureaucratic system to give local governments more power. But people in cities that would lose their status as provincial capitals have protested the proposed reduction of provinces, causing discord among their representatives in parliament. While the protesters fear a loss of control over governing spending in their areas, they support the concept of administrative reform and the goal of transferring decision-making power from the central government to provincial and local authorities. The reforms are part of Poland's efforts to transform itself into a market-oriented, openly democratic society as it prepares to enter NATO and negotiates for membership in the European Union after more than four decades of communist rule ended in 1990. By CLIFF EDWARDS AP Business Writer
CHICAGO (AP) _ Corn futures prices fell Friday to their lowest in nearly a year on the Chicago Board of Trade, and wheat and soybeans also retreated, as good weather in major growing areas kept prices on the defensive amid fears of a supply glut. On other markets, gold futures fell, while copper rose. Rain and moderate temperatures in the Midwest growing regions were expected to aid what could be bumper corn and soybean crops, as well as the spring wheat crop. Meanwhile, scorching weather in Southern growing regions was being alleviated by rainfall, which was returning moisture to parched crops. U.S. crops in the Midwest so far have grown under ideal conditions, as evidenced by the U.S. Agriculture Department's weekly crop ratings. That has led to predictions of record crops at a time of weak world demand because of the Asian economic crisis. Both Brazil and Argentina also posted record harvests, and agricultural consultant Safras e Mercado boosted its Brazilian production estimate to 30.89 million metric tons from 30.37 million metric tons. Weak futures also were pressured after influential forecasting firm Sparks Cos. increased its winter wheat production estimate to 1.738 billion bushels from 1.719 billion. That number also is well above the Agriculture Department's 1.706 billion-bushel estimate. Rains currently were slowing the harvest in Texas and other states, but dry weather was expected to return early next week. Wheat for July delivery fell 2\ cents to dlrs2.80\ a bushel; July corn fell 2} cents to dlrs2.37 a bushel, the lowest since early July 1997; July oats fell 1 cent to dlrs1.29\ a bushel; November soybeans fell 4{ cents to dlrs5.82{ a bushel. Gold futures fell on the New York Mercantile Exchange as Australian producers sold large quantities of the metal to take advantage of a stronger U.S. dollar against their local currency. Prices also were pressured by continued fears the Swiss Central Bank will sell a large portion of that country's reserves, despite continued assurances that such a sale would not come for at least a year. August gold fell dlrs2 to dlrs293.60 an ounce. Copper futures finished modestly higher amid concerns about intensifying labor troubles in Chile, the world's largest copper producer. Union members at state-owned Codelco's Radomiro Tomic mine were scheduled to strike on Monday unless a last-minute agreement was reached. That would come on top of a continuing work slowdown at Codelco's massive 650,000 metric ton Chuquicamata mine that was slowing production. The output cuts were buoying hopes that supply will not outpace demand this year, as had been feared because of the Asia crisis has dimmed construction demand. BC-Back to Cuba,0503
Bahamas forces back last large group of Cubans, shutting off escape
route By JESSICA ROBERTSON Associated Press Writer
NASSAU, Bahamas (AP) _ The Bahamas put its last big group of Cuban refugees on a plane to Havana Friday, acting on a new policy that closes the last practical escape route for people fleeing the Communist country on makeshift rafts. Sixty-eight refugees flew home Friday, a senior government official confirmed on condition of anonymity. ``This is a tragic thing,'' said Jose Basulto, whose Miami-based organization, Brothers to the Rescue, flies planes to spot Cuban rafters. ``Now there is no escape for those people who want to leave Castro behind, and the dictatorship.'' Bahamian officials say their new policy is aimed at discouraging Cubans from using their territory as a way station to the United States. They cite the expense of housing and feeding hundreds a year. For the Cuban refugees, the policy is a disaster _ in effect shutting down their last path to possible freedom. In the 1980s and early 1990s, Cuban boat people who reached the United States were given automatic asylum because they were fleeing Fidel Castro's repressive Communist regime. Then came a massive flood in 1994 when Castro, under pressure from riots in Havana, threatened to drop border controls and swamp the region with refugees. After some 35,000 Cubans headed across the Straits of Florida, Washington signed an agreement with Havana to repatriate boat people in return for Havana allowing 20,000 Cubans a year to emigrate to the United States. Several Caribbean countries followed the U.S. lead, but without the proviso forcing Cuba to allow some of its people to emigrate freely. The Bahamas signed in 1996. That hasn't stopped would-be Cuban emigrants. Almost every week, rafters propelled by the strong currents of the Windward Passage land in the Bahamas. Those who didn't qualify for political asylum were routinely repatriated until December, when Cuba was angered by the much-publicized defection of baseball star Orlando ``El Duque'' Hernandez through the Bahamas. He was allowed to go to Costa Rica and signed a dlrs 6.6 million contract with the New York Yankees. Cuba stopped cooperating with Bahamian officials eager to deport boat people, and the refugee population in Nassau swelled to more than 200. Finally, Cuba agreed to cooperate, but apparently only after the Bahamians promised to send home all boat people. The Bahamas, meanwhile, rejected an offer from Nicaragua to give asylum to all its Cuban refugees. To accept ``would be opening the floodgates for more to come,'' Foreign Ministry official Luther Smith said. Undaunted, the Cuban boat people continue their attempts, although some have been sent home three and four times. ``I will just save up and buy a new boat,'' Javier Villalobos, a 26-year-old doctor from Havana, said through the fence of the Bahamian detention camp.

Investigators theorize that the train derailed 300 meters (985 feet) before reaching the overpass. WHO MAKES THE WHEELS: The Hamburg-based company Bochum produced the wheels and bogies for the 60 first-generation InterCity Express high-speed trains. Bochum spokesman Goetz-Peter Blumbach said a faulty wheel on an ICE would be unprecedented. The bogie system was designed especially for Germany's InterCity Express, and is not used on any other trains. However, other trains in Europe use the wheel design. (me/cb)

BC-Sports-Baseball-Obit-Povich,0496
Longtime U.S. sports columnist Shirley Povich dies at 92
By DOUGLAS KIKER Associated Press Writer
WASHINGTON (AP) _ America's capital awoke Friday for the last time to one of its longest running pleasures: a Shirley Povich baseball column gracing the sports pages of The Washington Post. It was vintage Povich, ruminating about baseball's past and present in grand style and skewering a fellow columnist's suggestion that Mark McGwire's recent feats outshine those of Babe Ruth. ``Whoa there. Give McGwire the last four years ... but don't confuse him with the guy who inspired such sobriquets as the Sultan of Swat and the King of Clout,'' the 92-year-old columnist said in the column he wrote Wednesday from home after a six-week absence due to illness. Povich died of a heart attack Thursday evening. The news of his death ran prominently on the Post's front page, and the final column, bordered in black, filled nearly half a page in the sports section. Alongside ran a tribute from Tom Boswell, the Post columnist that Povich had disagreed with. ``It's about baseball. His first love. In it, he needles me. Mark McGwire comparable to Babe Ruth? Such apostasy cannot be allowed to stand!'' wrote Boswell. ``Perfect. Shirley Povich died setting the record straight.'' Povich wrote more than 15,000 columns in seven decades with the Post. His column, ``This Morning,'' ran six days a week from 1926 to 1974. His insights and opinions on sports, most particularly his two true loves _ baseball and boxing _ kept generations of Washingtonians turning to the sports section first thing in the morning. ``Shirley Povich was why people bought the paper,'' said Ben Bradlee, retired executive editor of the Post. ``You got the Post for Shirley and the sports section. He was the sports section. For a lot of years, he carried the paper, and that's no exaggeration.'' Povich, a member of the writers' wing of the Baseball Hall of Fame and the father of TV personality Maury Povich, became the youngest sports editor in the country in 1926 at age 20. His columns could make Post readers fume in anger or double over in laughter. Povich was never afraid to criticize the Washington sports establishment, even when he had become a part of it. In the 1950s, Povich blasted Redskins owner George Preston Marshall for refusing to integrate the Redskins, the last whites-only team in the National Football League. Povich ``retired'' in 1974 and slowed his pace a bit _ only writing 50 columns a year. ``I retired, and I've been behind in my work ever since,'' Povich told The Associated Press last year. ``All I can say is that, for me, it's been a joyride. I really have been blessed.'' In 1983, he received the Red Smith Award from the Associated Press Sports Editors organization for his outstanding contribution to sports journalism.

BC-Sports-Soccer-Netherlands-Nigeria,0653
World Cup: Netherlands crushes Nigeria 5-1 in warmup
Eds: Repeating to some points By MIKE CORDER Associated Press Writer
AMSTERDAM, Netherlands (AP) _ Marc Overmars led the Netherlands to a crushing 5-1 victory over Nigeria on Friday, scoring one goal and setting up two as the Dutch tore apart the Olympic champion down both flanks. It was both teams' last tune-up before the World Cup which begin June 10 in France. The Netherlands dominated the match, playing a fluent and fast passing game that cracked open Nigeria's defense and left the African side little chance to build up attacks. ``We created chances and we scored chances, but still we gave a few chances away,'' said Dutch coach Guus Hiddink. ``All in all there was a great feeling in the stadium, but we still want to cut out sloppy mistakes.'' But he said the Dutch team would head for France ``greatly encouraged'' by its warm-up campaign. After a disappointing 0-0 draw with Cameroon, the Dutch beat Paraguay 5-1 Monday before repeating that score Friday. Speedy left winger Overmars tormented Nigeria with explosive bursts of pace down the flank. Inevitably, it was Overmars who tore away from his marker and crossed to set up the Netherlands' opening goal. Striker Patrick Kluivert was muscled off the ball but Leeds United marksman Jimmy Hasselbaink was on hand at the far post to slam a shot high into Nigeria's net in the 32nd minute. Minutes earlier, the Dutch nearly capped a slick passing move with a goal but Hasselbaink's shot was saved by Nigerian goalkeeper Peter Rufai. Nigeria almost replied immediately as Victor Ikpeba cut inside Jaap Stam to create room for a shot but could only blast over the bar. The Dutch took a deserved 2-0 lead in the 38th minute through dangerman Overmars. Latching onto a long pass out of defense, Overmars saw Rufai rushing off his line and deftly lobbed the ball into the net. Shortly after the break Hasselbaink nearly netted his second goal and the Netherlands' third when a diagonal pass from Kluivert left him with only substitute goalkeeper William Okpara to beat. Hasselbaink delayed his shot until Okpara dived, but Okpara managed to stick out a hand and deflect the shot wide. But the Netherlands stretched its lead on the hour through Kluivert _ again following an Overmars cross from the left. Nigeria reduced the lead in the 64th minute, Nwankwo Kanu shooting a penalty past his former Ajax teammate Edwin van der Sar after Winston Bogarde had fouled Daniel Amokachi. The goal spurred Nigeria on and first defender Taribo West saw a shot deflected to safety and then Kanu badly sliced a shot after being released by Amokachi. But the Netherlands stretched ahead again in the 74th minute from a fast break with Clarence Seedorf crossing from the right and Kluivert lashing in his second goal from close range. Substitute Pierre van Hooijdonk made it 5-1 in the 77th minute, guiding in a cross from Overmars' replacement Boudewijn Zenden. The Netherlands takes on South Korea, Belgium and Mexico in qualifying Group E while Nigeria plays Spain, Bulgaria and Paraguay in Group D. Nigeria: Peter Rufai (William Okpara, 45), Jero Shakpoke (Augustine Eguavoen, 21, Austin Okacha 45), Uche Okechukwu, Taribo West, Celestine Babayaro, Godwin Okpara, Sunday Oliseh, Finidi George (Tijani Babangida, 45), Nwankwo Kanu (Wilson Oruma, 81), Victor Ikpeba (Daniel Amokachi, 45), Garba Lawal.

BC-Sports-Cricket-England-Gough,0314
Gough ruled out of the test with a broken finger
By IHITHISHAM KAMARDEEN Associated Press Writer
BIRMINGHAM, England (AP) _ Darren Gough, will play no further part in England push victory in the first test against South Africa after x-rays confirmed a broken index finger in his bowling hand Friday. Gough, batting at No.10, was hit by fast bowler Allan Donald in fading light, during a stubborn last wicket stand with Angus Fraser in England's first innings 462. Gough, a medium paceman, carried hopes of England's victory in the first of the five tests, forming a three-man pace attack with Fraser and Dominic Cork. Gough, was rushed to the nearby Queen Elizabeth hospital in Edgbaston after the second day's play, and specialists confirmed the break. England's team physiotherapist Wayne Morton, who twice treated Gough on the field, said, ``He will be out for a period of three to four weeks at which point we will review his availability for selection for England.'' Gough's England career has been plagued by injuries for the past three years ever since he was forced to fly home from the Ashes tour in 1995 having broken a bone in his foot. The current Test against South Africa was his first since he played against Australia at Headingley in July 1997. ``The injury is a bitter disappointment as this is my comeback Test after a nine-month layoff,'' Gough said. ``It is enormously frustrating both personally and for the team as we are in a good position but I am confident the rest of the lads can help us take advantage of a promising situation. Alec Stewart, leading England since taking over from Mike Atherton said: ``It is tough luck on Darren and the team but luckily we have still got enough top quality bowlers to do the job required.''
