BC-Sports-Soccer-Bosnia-Reunited,0488
Reunited Bosnian soccer teams enter Europe
AP Photo By SRECKO LATAL Associated Press Writer
SARAJEVO, Bosnia-Herzegovina (AP) _ Blowing horns and whistles, waving flags and banners, thousands of fans streamed towards Kosevo stadium Friday for the final of Bosnia's soccer championship. The duel featured eternal rivals Zeljeznicar and Sarajevo _ but the real prize was something Bosnia's disunited soccer teams have not known: a ticket to the European Championship League for the winner. ``This may not be a World Cup match, but it is incredibly important for the Bosnian football,'' said Liam McDowall, a U.N. spokesman. Almost all of the 40,000 tickets were sold out in a match that served as a final preparation for monitoring the World Cup from armchairs in front of TV screens. Zeljeznicar won 1-0, bringing tears _ of joy or disappointment - from both teams and five minutes of glorious fireworks after the match Neighboring Yugoslavia and Croatia are competing in France, but Bosnia's soccer has been as disunited as the country itself and the national team had no chance of qualifying. This year, for the first time since war erupted in 1992, soccer teams from Bosnian Croat- and Muslim-dominated regions competed for the national championship. Four from the Muslim regions and two Croat sides competed in two groups. Claiming security concerns, teams from the Bosnian Serb substate _ Republika Srpska _ refused to participate. But everybody expects them aboard in the next season. It has taken three years for international sports organizations and foreign diplomats charged with implementing peace to negotiate a solution for Bosnia's disunited sports. The 4-2 Muslim-Croat combination was also adopted for this year's Bosnian basketball championships _ which the Serbs are also expected to join in 1999. The Croat side Siroki Brijeg defeated Sarajevo's Bosna, former European champions, for the local basketball crown. In recent weeks, the two groups in soccer played in Sarajevo and the tense southwestern town of Mostar. Hundreds of fans traveled back and forth without incident _ to the delight of Western diplomats still trying to overcome ethnic tensions. ``Even a year ago ... it would have been very difficult to imagine such games take place in Mostar without any trouble,'' said Martin Garrod, senior international official in Mostar. Fearing ethnic riots, U.N. police closely monitored each game. Fans simply wanted to see the best players. ``There was the war, but it's over now,'' said Sead Beric, a Zeljeznicar fan, heading for the stadium. ``Now, without all good players, whether they are Bosnian Serbs, Croats, Muslims, Jews, Eskimos or others, we cannot hope to become something in world soccer and participate in the next World Cup.''

BC-Brazil-Fetuses Found,0153
Five fetuses wash up on Brazil beach
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil (AP) _ A beach cleaner made a grisly discovery while making his early morning rounds Friday: five dead fetuses washed up in the surf. Natalino Cardoso Souza found the fetuses, wrapped in plastic bags, on Bica beach on Rio's northside near the international airport. Police suspect the fetuses, four male and one female, were dumped by a clandestine abortion clinic. Police were investigating. ``It wouldn't be very intelligent for those responsible to leave the fetuses close by,'' Rio de Janeiro policeman Eduardo Morreira said. Currents carry garbage thrown into Rio's rivers _ everything from plastic bottles to furniture _ across the heavily polluted Guanabara Bay to Bica beach. Abortion is illegal in Brazil under a 1945 law, except in cases of rape or when a woman's life is endangered.

BC-Sports-Boxing-Holyfield-Akinwande, 7th Ld-Writethru,0815
Akinwande-Holyfield fight called off
Eds: UPDATES with press conference By TIM DAHLBERG AP Sports Writer
NEW YORK (AP) _ Evander Holyfield never really wanted to fight Henry Akinwande. Now he won't have to. The heavyweight title fight was called off Friday, a day before the bout, because Akinwande tested positive for hepatitis B. A doctor said Akinwande was infectious and that his sparring partners should also be tested for the disease. ``I guess I'm the guy things happen to,'' said Holyfield, who was informed the fight was off when he arrived at Madison Square Garden for his final pre-fight workout. Holyfield went back to his hotel in hopes he would get a last-minute opponent, but the entire card was canceled a few hours later. ``Seems kind of strange to wait to the last minute,'' Holyfield said. ``But I'm already in shape. If you don't fight, you don't get paid either.'' Promoters officially said the fight was postponed indefinitely, and held out hope that a second set of tests conducted Friday could prove the first tests wrong and the fight could be rescheduled within a month or so. But if the tests simply confirm the earlier results _ which experts say are rarely wrong _ doctors said Akinwande could be infectious for several more months. Since Holyfield was fighting Akinwande only because it was a mandatory WBA title defense, it was unlikely he would get another title chance. ``It (the test) doesn't tell how he got it or how long he'll have it for,'' said Dr. Donald Kaminsky of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. ``It's very unpredictable.'' Akinwande was tested on Tuesday, and the New York State Athletic Commission said it got the results Friday morning. Ticket sales had been poor, but picked up in the last two days and promoters said that had nothing to do with the fight being called off. Earlier, a woman boxer was pulled off the card because she was 21 weeks pregnant, and veteran heavyweight Ray Mercer was also declared medically ineligible. ``It's just one of those things. There's nothing else I can say,'' promoter Don King said. ``I'm just very sorry for Henry Akinwande to lose this opportunity to fight for the crown at this time.'' Akinwande, after undergoing a second set of tests Friday, prepared to leave for Detroit to see a doctor there. He did not appear for the press conference held to formally call off the fight. ``He's really sorry he can't fight,'' Akinwande's manager, Jean Courreges, said. ``He looks to fight Evander again as soon as his physical condition allows him.'' Kaminsky said hepatitis B can be contracted through exchange of bodily fluids, blood, sexual activity or something such as a shared toothbrush. He said there are 300,000 new cases of the disease in the United States a year and that it is epidemic in certain parts of Africa. Kaminsky said the acute form of the disease runs its course in several weeks, but can become chronic in a small percentage of the population. He recommended that Akinwande's sparring partners also be tested. Akinwande, who was born in England but grew up in Nigeria, now fights out of Orlando, Florida. ``It's disappointing,'' said Holyfield, who had made no secret of his lack of desire to fight the WBA's No. 1 contender. ``You prepare yourself for 13 weeks and then this happens.'' Hepatitis B can cause serious liver problems. The disease can be treated successfully, but not always. Hepatitis A is typically a food-borne disease that can pass quickly. The fight was supposed to top a card that included 46-year-old Roberto Duran fighting for a title nine years after he lost his middleweight crown to Sugar Ray Leonard. On Thursday, Mexican lightweight Maria de las Nieves Garcia was scratched from her undercard bout with Christy Martin because she's pregnant. Promoters found Melissa Salamore to replace her and she was then replaced by Cheryl Nance after Martin rejected Salamore. Mercer was dropped because he also failed a blood test for undisclosed reasons. The Akinwande decision is yet another blow to a once promising career. He was disqualified in the fifth round of a fight last July against WBC champ Lennox Lewis for repeated holding. That Akinwande was even supposed to fight for a piece of the title for the second time in less than a year was due more to his choice of promoter than anything else. After the Lewis debacle, King matched him against Orlin Norris Jr. and Akinwande won a 12-round decision to become the mandatory contender. Akinwande was to make dlrs 2.5 million to fight Holyfield, who was to get dlrs 10 million for the defense of the WBA title he won in his first fight with Mike Tyson.

Council Eds: LEADS to UPDATE with Security Council calling for an immediate ceasefire in conflict By ROBERT H. REID Associated Press Writer
UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ The Security Council called Friday for an immediate cease-fire between Ethiopia and Eritrea following an air raid, and Secretary-General Kofi Annan appealed to both parties to ``give diplomacy a chance.'' At the request of the United States, the 15-member council met Friday afternoon to discuss the border conflict between the two African nations, which escalated Friday after Eritrean anti-aircraft guns shot down two Ethiopian attack planes that bombed an Eritrean air force base. ``The Security Council deplored this escalation and called for an immediate cease-fire'' and ``urged Eritrea and Ethiopia to affirm their commitment to resolve the dispute peacefully,'' council President Antonio Monteiro of Portugal said. In a separate statement, the United Nations noted that the attack came despite apparent progress by American and Rwandan mediators in attempting to resolve a border dispute between the two African countries. ``The secretary-general strongly appeals to both sides for an immediate cessation of hostilities so as to give diplomacy a chance to bridge the remaining differences and avoid any further escalation,'' the U.N. statement said. It said Annan ``will continue to do everything he can to help the parties find a peaceful solution to the dispute.'' U.S. Ambassador Bill Richardson said the United States, which had been playing a key mediation role, ``is seriously concerned about the recent escalation between Ethiopia and Eritrea. The situation is getting very serious.'' Richardson said the United States supports mediation efforts by the Organization of African Unity and ``we call on both sides to start talking with each other.'' The air raid, 10th graf pvs

BC-Sports-Auto Racing-Canadian GP,0709
More woes for Villeneuve in Montreal
By KEN BERGER AP Sports Writer
MONTREAL (AP) _ Jacques-mania has gripped Quebec. There are flags that say Jacques, voices that shriek ``Jacques!'' and headlines that scream about Jacques' love life. All the attention has done nothing to change Jacques Villeneuve's luck. Seeking to turn around a dreadful Formula One season in his hometown race, Villeneuve failed to finish the practice session Friday for the Canadian Grand Prix. As his Williams FW20 was pushed off the course named for his father, Villeneuve walked back to the garage waving his arms and shouting. He wanted desperately to prove this weekend that he is still what his loyal fans say he is _ ``champion du monde.'' The weekend couldn't have gotten off to a worse start. ``It just cut off, so I quickly took it to the side,'' said the Canadian-born Villeneuve, whose car coasted to a stop when the hydraulics failed about halfway through the afternoon practice session. ``It started very well in the morning, but then the few changes we made were the wrong ones.'' Michael Schumacher's Ferrari gave the McLarens something to think about, recording the second-fastest practice lap of 124.342 mph (198.947 kmph) on the 12-turn, 2.75-mile (4.4-kilometer) road course. Points leader Mika Hakkinen was fastest at 124.945 mph (199.912 kmph) in a McLaren Mercedes, followed by Sauber's Jean Alesi 123.950 mph () and Hakkinen's teammate, David Coulthard 123.851 mph (198.162 kmph). ``We are where I hoped we would be,'' Schumacher said. Villeneuve, the defending series champion, was 16th at 121.907 mph (195.051 kmph) on the best of his 26 laps. He missed the final 40 minutes of practice, a devastating setback for a team that needed time to figure out the setup for its new rear design before Saturday's qualifying. ``Those 40 minutes are lost,'' said Villeneuve, winless in eight races and sixth in the point standings. ``I'd expect our car to be more competitive than that.'' Villeneuve had barely heated the tires on Circuit Gilles Villeneuve when he had to pull into the pits for adjustments. Lifting his visor, he revealed a piercing glare that spoke volumes about restlessness and frustration. He wanted to be staring at pavement, not pit workers. ``It is very frustrating,'' Villeneuve said. ``We just have to catch up, that's all.'' In addition to broken hydraulics, Villeneuve had to answer questions about paparazzi photos published in a tabloid Friday _ another testament to his enormous fame here. They showed him with two women on a boat, beneath blue skies and the headline, ``Between races, time for love.'' A separate article speculated about Villeneuve's love life. ``It is very frustrating that you can't do anything that anybody would do on a normal day,'' Villeneuve said. ``There's nothing that needs to be caught. I don't have a girlfriend at this point, anyway.'' The adulation is dual-edged. Critics have seized on everything from his peroxide-dyed hair to his aloof nature and often untamed opinions. But he had returned to Canada optimistic, and in much better spirits than last year. That's when Formula One officials made him fly to Paris in the days before the race to be reprimanded for criticizing safety measures. Jet-lagged and throttled by the controversy, Villeneuve crashed on the second lap. ``I had good training last year, so this year can only be easier,'' he said. Taking issue with safety rules implemented after the tragic death of Ayrton Senna in 1994 was shocking for a driver still coping with his father's death. Gilles Villeneuve was killed during practice for the Belgian Grand Prix in 1982. Only 27, Villeneuve speaks matter-of-factly of danger and mortality. Hands clasped, lips shaped in neither smile nor frown, he constantly seems to be wrestling with weighty issues. Villeneuve on death: ``My father was never world champion. He died too soon.'' Villeneuve on fame: ``Since I've been famous, many people want to be my friends. I never know if they really like me for who I am.''

BC-Israel-Arab Expulsions ,0440
Cartoonist says he stopped 1967 Israeli attempt to deport Arabs
By DAFNA LINZER Associated Press Writer
JERUSALEM (AP) _ Syndicated cartoonist Ranan Lurie, a major in the Israeli army during the 1967 Mideast War, said Friday that he persuaded then-Prime Minister Levi Eshkol to stop generals from expelling thousands of West Bank Palestinians to Jordan. Historians lent credence to his claims and said that while there was no government expulsion policy, several commanders tried to force Palestinians out during the chaos of the six-day war. Lurie, who served as a field commander, said he refused to carry out orders by superiors to load Arab families onto buses and send them across the Jordan River. Instead, he appealed to Eshkol, a friend. ``I told Eshkol, 'We are doing something very bad here and it will affect our children and grandchildren. You can't uproot people who have lived here for 2,000 years and dump them,''' Lurie said in a telephone interview with The Associated Press from his Manhattan home. Meir Pa'il, an Israeli military historian and former lawmaker, said Lurie's story is consistent with events known to have taken place elsewhere in the West Bank. ``It wasn't government policy to expel anyone but there were generals who want it done,'' he said. Lurie, whose account was first published Friday in the Israeli daily Ha'aretz, said that when he saw Arab families in the West Bank village of Anabta being ordered on to buses bound for Jordan, he told a fellow officer, Shlomo Gonen, that ``I couldn't go through with this. ...This wasn't about combat, but about women and children.'' Lurie said Gonen volunteered to oversee the expulsion. Asked about Lurie's claims, Gonen refused to comment and accused the cartoonist of trying to paint a better picture of his past in order to boost his syndication. Lurie said Eshkol blamed his defense minister, Gen. Moshe Dayan, for the expulsions, and that the prime minister later thanked Lurie for raising the issue with him. Pa'il, the historian, said Palestinians were being rounded up in the city of Qalqilya and deported. But on the fourth day of fighting, Pa'il said an order came in to halt deportations and allow those forced out to return. ``I don't know why,'' he said. Lurie believes his conversation with a friend and prime minister was the reason. Lurie was born in Port Said, Egypt, before his family migrated to Israel. He moved to the United States in 1968. His cartoons appear in 1,100 newspapers worldwide.

BC-Colombia-Massacre,0255
Army and police accused in massacre
With Colombia-Exile
BARRANCABERMEJA, Colombia (AP) _ Army and police units abetted the kidnapping of 25 people taken from this oil-refining city and massacred by a right-wing paramilitary group, human rights activists said Friday. Outside city hall, families of the victims _ whose bodies were incinerated_ displayed 25 white wooden coffins with photos of the dead. The paramilitary group said Thursday it executed the men and women after trying and convicting them of membership in two leftist guerrillas fighting the government. The group says it burned the bodies, which have not been returned to authorities. The May 16 kidnapping by masked gunmen was carried out with the support of police and army units operating in the area, claimed Osiris Bayther of the Barrancabermeja-basedRegional Committee for the Defense of Human Rights. Local army and police chiefs have denied involvement in the crime. A government investigative commission has been appointed. Bayther called for an investigation into the role of the security forces, which witnesses placed at the scene of the assault moments before some 50 masked gunmen entered a poor neighborhood, killed seven people and carted away 25 others in trucks, she said. News of the executions ended a three-week hostage drama that riveted residents in this city of 240,000 located 165 miles (265 km) north of Bogota, which was paralyzed Friday by protests against the massacre.

BC-Sports-Golf-Kemper Open,0539
Funk hold lead as players batter Kemper course
By RON SIRAK AP Golf Writer
POTOMAC, Maryland (AP) _ Fred Funk broke the 36-hole scoring record in the Kemper Open with a 12-under-par 130 as he shot a 66 on Friday to take a three-stroke lead over Stuart Appleby, Craig Parry and Chris DiMarco into the weekend. The TPC at Avenel was virtually helpless on a windless day, rolling over feebly as player after player attacked. There were 21 eagles plus three holes-in-one. Brad Elder, playing in just his third event since turning pro, shot a course record-tying 63 and was at 8-under-par 134. Parry also matched the record with a 63. Brian Kamm made a hole-in-one on the 202-yard (184-meter) 17th hole with a 5-iron for his third eagle of the day, becoming just the 10th player since 1970 to make three eagles in a round. He shot a 66 and was among five players at 135, including defending champion Justin Leonard, who also had an ace. ``It's the kind of course that just sets up for dramatics,'' Funk said after he made five birdies and no bogeys and continued his remarkable play just days after laser eye surgery earlier this week to improve his vision. ``It is a golf course that gives you a lot of shots at birdie,'' Funk said after breaking the 36-hole record by one stroke. ``It funnels well.'' Virtually everyone took their shot and many found the funnel. Funk played what he called ``a good, patient round of golf'' and made a series of solid putts. Appleby's round sizzled early. Playing the back nine first, he rolled in a birdie putt on No. 11 and then hit a 1-iron from 240 yards (218 meters) to 12 feet (3 1/2 meters) on No. 13 and made it for an eagle. He followed that with three consecutive birdies. ``It wasn't very tough today because there was no wind,'' Appleby said. ``If you haven't got the wind you can hit the same shot over and over and over again. With no wind you take the guessing out of it.'' Parry managed a 66 for his 133 total despite two bogeys, closing with three birdies on the final final holes. DiMarco shot a 65 despite two bogeys to get a share of second place at 133. Kamm's first eagle came on the sixth hole when he hit a 5-iron to nine feet and the second was on No. 13. Elder, who finished his final exams at the University of Texas on May 12, played the back nine first and got his round going with an eagle on No. 13. He made three consecutive birdies beginning at No. 15 and birdied three out of four holes beginning on No. 5 as he matched the course record. ``Sixty-three is my best score ever,'' Elder said. ``It's hard for a college player to come out here and be ready to win.'' Funk has been on the PGA Tour full time since 1989 and has won four times. But he has never played well in the Kemper Open, which is virtually in the Maryland native's backyard. ``I just want to post a good number tomorrow and get into good position for Sunday,'' he said. ``And then we'll see what happens.'' If Friday was any indication, it will take a lot of birdies _ and perhaps an eagle or two _ to win on the weekend.

BC-Sports-Golf-Nationwide Senior PGA,0547
Player turns back the clock _ again
By PAUL NEWBERRY AP Sports Writer
ALPHARETTA, Georgia (AP) _ Gary Player keeps defying the calendar. Two months ago, the 62-year-old South African became the oldest golfer ever to make the cut at the Masters. On Friday, he was atop the leaderboard at the PGA Nationwide Championship, vying to become the second-oldest winner in the history of the Senior PGA Tour. Player, wielding a deft touch with his irons, shot a 5-under-par 67 to grab a share of the lead with 51-year-old Gil Morgan, one of the youngsters on the tour, relatively speaking. ``It's great to see him do that,'' Morgan said. ``He's such a competitor. He never gives up.'' Player, who will turn 63 on Nov. 1, was in position to become only the second 62-or-over golfer to win a Senior Tour event. Mike Fetchick won the 1985 Hilton Head Seniors Invitational on his 63rd birthday. If there was ever a candidate to make a run at Fetchick's record, it's Player. He still keeps himself in outstanding physical condition, despite a demanding travel schedule and a plethora of outside business interests that cut back his tournament schedule. ``I've looked after myself since I was a young person,'' Player said. ``I go to the gym, I work out, I watch what I eat. I'm being rewarded for that.'' Player clearly enjoyed himself Friday. He joked around with his playing partners (fellow South African John Bland and Raymond Floyd), wiggled his diminutive body as if trying to convince the ball to go where he wanted, chatted with the gallery and regaled the media with stories afterwards. ``Anytime you get near 63, this is quite a low round,'' Player said. ``I'd like to score my age some day, but I think that's going to take a while.'' The opening round at the Golf Club of Georgia in suburban Atlanta was delayed 2 hours, 40 minutes because of overnight and morning storms that saturated the grounds with more than three inches of rain. When Player finally got on the course, playing the back nine first, he had a bogey at No. 10 and threatened to go 2-over when his second shot at 14 landed 20 yards (18 meters) short of the green. His chip wasn't much better, plopping 8 feet from the hole, but he made the par putt. That sequence seemed to rejuvenate Player, who birdied the next hole. His irons were magnificent the rest of the way, setting up four birdie putts from 6 feet (1.8 meters) and in. ``I always wonder what I could have done on these type of courses when I was younger,'' Player said. ``The greens now are just perfect.'' As it is, he's doing just fine. In April, Player beat Sam Snead's record as the oldest player to make the Masters cut. The South African still marvels at being able to play on the weekend at Augusta National, while younger competitors like Tom Lehman, Tom Watson, Nick Faldo and Greg Norman went home. The Senior PGA Tour is normally dominated by 50-something players like Morgan and Hale Irwin, each with three victories this year. Morgan put himself in contention again by making three long putts, including a 25-footer (8 meters) for eagle at No. 1, his 10th hole of the day.

BC-Sports-Auto Racing-Detroit GP,0473
Papis leads rain-slowed qualifying session
By MIKE HARRIS AP Motorsports Writer
DETROIT (AP) _ The grid was practically turned upside down Friday when some of the lesser-known entries in the ITT Automotive Detroit Grand Prix, led by Max Papis, got the benefit of a dry track in the opening round of qualifying. The fastest qualifiers from the previous road race _ in April at Long Beach, Calif. _ went out for the first 30-minute session and found a very wet track at Belle Isle Raceway. In fact, CART FedEx Series chief steward Wally Dallenbach ordered the teams in the first session to start on grooved rain tires. By the time the rain stopped and the 2.346-mile, 14-turn street circuit began to dry, it was too late for the fast guys to take advantage. The slower qualifiers from Long Beach then went out for their 30-minute session and took the top 10 spots on the provisional grid for Sunday's race. Papis, driving a Reynard-Toyota, led the way with a lap of 1-minute, 17.990-seconds, or 108.291 mph (173.266 kmph) on the track that was reconfigured from 2.1 miles since last year. The Italian driver, whose best career starts have been 17th at Laguna Seca in 1996 and Homestead in 1997, understood that, thanks to the weather, his provisional pole status was suspect. But he was enjoying the moment. ``Satisfaction is really rare for us,'' Papis said with a wide grin splitting his face. ``The Toyota people got a gift from God and it's great satisfaction for one day. ``After a long struggle, this is where we belong. I wish we could be here all the time.'' Since Toyota, which powers four cars, entered its first engines in CART in 1996, they've had little success and no poles or race wins. ``This is a beginning,'' Papis said. ``This shows we're making progress. I hope today shows everybody we've got potential to be there.'' Jimmy Vasser, the winner last week at Milwaukee, also was among the slower cars from the Long Beach time trials and wound up second on Friday. ``I don't think today is going to be indicative of the grid we'll see after tomorrow,'' Vasser said. ``Really, the fast guys got rain out.'' The fastest driver in the opening session was Dario Franchitti, who wound up 11th in the provisional lineup. Series points leader Alex Zanardi, fast in the morning practice, was 22nd in qualifying. Only the top 10 drivers actually qualified on Friday because the CART rules stipulate that all drivers making a race field must be within 110 percent of the fastest qualifier. ``I guess we'll be OK,'' Zanardi said. ``I'm told the weather for Saturday and Sunday will be decent, with no rain. If that's true, everything will get back in order tomorrow.''

BC-Turkey-Emergency Landing,0196
French jet makes emergency landing after engine failure
ANTALYA, Turkey (AP) _ A French plane carrying 167 passengers made an emergency landing following an engine failure, shortly after takeoff from this southern Turkish city early Saturday, according to news reports. No injuries were reported. The France Lines' MD-80 plane touched down at 1.40 a.m. (1040 GMT) on its belly on the foam covered runway of the Ataturk airport of Antalya after dumping its fuel over the Mediterranean Sea, according to ATV television. It stopped after sliding almost the entire length of the runway. The Anatolia news agency said all passengers and six crew members were evacuated. ``We heard a big explosion following the takeoff,'' a French passenger, only identified by his first name Nicola, told ATV as he left the plane. ``Everybody is O.K.'' The plane was en route from Antalya's Ataturk Airport to Paris. ATV said the plane's rear landing gear blew up during takeoff and flying tire pieces stopped one of its two engines. ``Everything seems under control,'' Tourism Minister Ibrahim Gurdal said.

BC-Caribbean-Briefs,0693
A Package of Caribbean News Briefs
By The Associated Press BAHAMAS: Last big group of Cuban refugees sent home
NASSAU, Bahamas (AP) _ The Bahamas put its last big group of Cuban refugees on a plane to Havana Friday, acting on a new policy to slam shut the last practical escape route for people desperate enough to risk their lives on makeshift rafts. Sixty-eight refugees flew home Friday, a senior government official confirmed on condition of anonymity. ``This is a tragic thing,'' said Brothers to the Rescue head Jose Basulto, whose Miami-based organization flies planes to spot Cuban rafters. ``Now there is no escape for those people who want to leave Castro behind, and the dictatorship.'' Bahamian officials say their new policy is aimed at discouraging Cubans from using their territory as a way station to the United States. They cite the expense of housing and feeding hundreds a year. EL SALVADOR: Cuba and El Salvador ``sister cities'' cause dispute SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador (AP) _ A plan to make sister cities of the Cuban and Salvadoran capitals has turned into more of a family feud. President Armando Calderon Sol announced Thursday that his government would not allow a visit by Havana Mayor Conrado Martinez, who was invited by San Salvador Mayor Hector Silva as part of a sister city project. Calderon Sol's party supported a war against pro-Cuban leftist rebels in the 1980s. Silva was elected in a coalition that includes those former leftists, now a political party. ``We are brothers of the Cuban people, but what impedes foreign relations is the line of the government'' of Cuba's President Fidel Castro, Calderon Sol said in remarks published by newspapers here Friday. The hard-line Interior Minister, Mario Acosta, was even more blunt earlier: ``No Cuban enters.'' VIRGIN ISLANDS: Regulators urge negotiated settlement in barge-ferry spat CHARLOTTE AMALIE, U.S. Virgin Islands (AP) _ Government regulators reversed a ruling that would have stopped commercial barges from carrying passengers between St. Thomas and St. John and told the ferry and barge companies to try to settle their dispute by July 6. The dispute centers on the barges allowing passengers to ride in the cars they carry between the islands. The ferry companies said in a 1996 complaint that the practice had caused them to lose half a million dollars. Public Service Commission Chairman Walter Challenger said this week that he was going to give the companies one more chance to reach a negotiated settlement. If that fails, he warned, the commission will have to act. BRITISH VIRGIN ISLANDS: Committee to choose new regional Supreme Court chief ROAD TOWN, British Virgin Islands (AP) _ A new chief justice of the Eastern Caribbean Supreme Court will be chosen by a special committee within the next six months, several national leaders said. The post has been filled by acting Justice Denis Byron of St. Kitts and Nevis for nearly two years. The Organization of Eastern Caribbean States heads of government appointed a committee to fill the vacancy at their meeting here May 27-29. Antigua Prime Minister Lester Bird said afterwards that the committee would make a recommendation before the next meeting of the heads of state at the end of November. JAMAICA: Anti-noise law takes effect KINGSTON, Jamaica (AP) _ Police say it will be a quiet weekend in Jamaica. And if not, they'll hand out fines. A new Noise Abatement Act takes effect this weekend. Discos will have to turn down the volume, bars will have to quiet down at 2 a.m. and playing a musical instrument in the street is also prohibited within 100 meters (330 feet) of a home, hotel, hospital or other places where someone might be trying to get some sleep. Police say they are serious about enforcing the law and have set up a special phone lines so residents can call in with complaints. Special teams of police and soldiers will be patrolling.

BC-Colombia-Massacre, 1st Ld-Writethru,0271
Army and police accused in massacre
Eds: CORRECTS in last graf that riots paralyzed Barrancabermeja STED Bogota With Colombia-Exile
BARRANCABERMEJA, Colombia (AP) _ Army and police units abetted the kidnapping of 25 people taken from this oil-refining city and massacred by a right-wing paramilitary group, human rights activists said Friday. Outside city hall, families of the victims _ whose bodies were incinerated_ displayed 25 white wooden coffins with photos of the dead. The paramilitary group said Thursday it executed the men and women after trying and convicting them of membership in two leftist guerrillas fighting the government. The group says it burned the bodies, which have not been returned to authorities. The May 16 kidnapping by masked gunmen was carried out with the support of police and army units operating in the area, claimed Osiris Bayther of the Barrancabermeja-based Regional Committee for the Defense of Human Rights. Local army and police chiefs have denied involvement in the crime. A government investigative commission has been appointed. Bayther called for an investigation into the role of the security forces, which witnesses placed at the scene of the assault moments before some 50 masked gunmen entered a poor neighborhood, killed seven people and carted away 25 others in trucks, she said. News of the executions ended a three-week hostage drama that riveted residents and sparked riots in Barrancabermeja, paralyzing the city of 240,000, which is 165 miles (265 km) north of the capital, Bogota.

BC-Sports-Baseball-Roundup,0281
Cubs edge White Sox 6-5 in 12 innings
Eds: will be updated
CHICAGO (AP) _ Brant Brown hit a leadoff home run in the 12th inning to give the Cubs a 6-5 victory over the White Sox on Friday in the first official Wrigley Field game between the Chicago rivals. The last time the two met at a Cubs park in a game that counted was the 1906 World Series at West Side Grounds. The White Sox won that series 4-2. Brown hit his sixth homer of the season over the right-field wall off Tony Castillo (1-2) to give the Cubs their seventh straight victory. Terry Mulholland (2-1) allowed one hit in a scoreless 12th for the victory. The Cubs threatened in the 10th, loading the bases with one out, but Matt Karchner struck out Sammy Sosa, who homered in the fifth, and Jeff Blauser, who had three hits on the day. The White Sox lost a chance to take the lead in the eighth when Magglio Ordonez's line drive into the gap in right center was lost in the ivy for a ground-rule double, forcing Wil Cordero to stop at third base. The White Sox tied it at 5 with a three-run sixth off Steve Trachsel. Robin Ventura had an RBI single, Ordonez followed with a run-scoring groundout and Chad Kreuter hit a two-out, RBI single. Henry Rodriguez put the Cubs in front 3-2 with a three-run double in the third. Sosa made it 5-2 in the fifth with his two-run homer off rookie left-hander Jim Parque. The White Sox took a 2-0 lead in the first on Albert Belle's RBI double and Ventura's run-scoring single. The Cubs had 13 walks and had the bases loaded in the second, third, fifth and 10th innings.

BC-AP News Summary,0755
A summary of late news from The Associated Press. Some items have moved on this circuit in expanded form with ``i'' or ``f'' category codes: ESCHEDE, Germany (AP) _ The reason for a rattling that alarmed some passengers in the minutes before the crash of InterCity Express 884 now seems clear: Investigators said Friday that a broken wheel was the most likely cause of the disaster. The 93rd victim from Wednesday's crash was recovered Friday under a 33-foot (10-meter) piece of road that had fallen next to the high-speed train. That brought the death toll to 98, including five who died in hospitals _ two of them Friday. Rescue workers said they could not rule an increase in the death toll until all the debris was cleared from the four-track line. The damaged wheel that has become the focus of investigators' questions was located on the first car behind the locomotive. (GERMANY-TRAIN DERAILS) PRISTINA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Some of the thousands fleeing the latest Serbian offensive in Kosovo don't make it, dying of exhaustion along the way. In villages wiped out by fighting, corpses lie unburied and farm animals roam wild. Reports said Friday that 50 people were killed and 200 were missing in the past week. Survivors were hiding in the woods, most trying to cross the border into neighboring Albania. A statement by Serb police indicated the offensive had ended, having destroyed the ``terrorist gangs'' who tried to block Kosovo's key north-south road. It said civilians could safely return. Still, hundreds continued to flee. Most were ethnic Albanians, who make up 90 percent of Kosovo's 2 million people and demand independence from Serbia, the larger of two republics remaining in Yugoslavia. Serbian troops are trying to quash the separatist drive. (YUGOSLAVIA-KOSOVO) ASMARA, Eritrea (AP) _ Ethiopian military planes bombed an air force base outside the Eritrean capital Friday before being shot down by Eritrean anti-aircraft guns in an escalating border dispute between two of the world's poorest countries. Two Ethiopian MiG-23 fighter planes on Friday afternoon bombed two hangars at an air base outside Asmara that is adjacent to the international airport. A commercial airliner on the tarmac was reported damaged. Eritrean guns then shot the planes down. Witnesses saw several injured people being transported in trucks, but it was not immediately possible to determine the number of wounded or the fate of the Ethiopian pilots. In the Ethiopian capital, Addis Ababa, the Foreign Ministry said the bombing was in retaliation for an Eritrean attack on Mekele, 200 kilometers (125 miles) north of Addis, on Friday that wounded five Ethiopians. (ERITREA-ETHIOPIA) PARIS (AP) _ Nine months after the death of Princess Diana, a French judge gathered witnesses, paparazzi and a platoon of lawyers under one roof Friday, trying to determine once and for all whether photographers were to blame for the crash. The all-day meeting wasn't expected to yield any immediate ruling. But it was a way for Judge Herve Stephan, who leads the massive investigation, to try to balance conflicting accounts in the case file. The high-speed crash in a Paris tunnel Aug. 31 killed Diana, her companion, Dodi Fayed, and driver Henri Paul. Tests showed Paul was drunk at the time, and investigators long have believed that is the main cause of the crash, in addition to speed. But Stephan still needs to determine the role of nine photographers and one press motorcyclist who have been in legal limbo _ under investigation, but not formally charged _ for nearly a year. (DIANA-INVESTIGATION) BOGOTA, Colombia (AP) _ Unable to shield Colombia's human rights workers from threats and violence, President Ernesto Samper is offering them tickets on the next plane out. A government fund will allow 30 to 40 threatened activists to live and study abroad until they feel safe returning home, Samper said. ``If they want to voluntarily go abroad until the circumstances clear up, I am obliged to find a way to help them,'' the Colombian leader told The Associated Press in an interview this week. While human rights monitors say the program could provide relief, some wonder about the president's motives. Last year, 27 Colombian human rights activists were assassinated, up from eight in 1996, according to Colombian Commission of Jurists. Two have been shot dead this year. (COLOMBIA-EXILES)

BC-AP Top Financial News,0772
EDITORS:
A summary of financial and business news from The Associated Press at 0000 GMT. Stories carry ``f'' or ``i'' category codes and move on this circuit in expanded form: NEW YORK _ The Dow Jones industrial average shot back above 9,000 on Friday as new signs of a resilient U.S. economy eased concerns about the impact of Asia's financial crisis on American companies. The Dow rose 167.15 points to 9,037.71, the biggest gain in four months and the first close above 9,000 in two weeks. Most broad-market indicators also posted big gains, although the Nasdaq composite index rose only modestly as investors remained hesitant about the technology group's heavy exposure to the Asian economy. (US-CLOSING-STOCKS) WASHINGTON (AP) _ Unemployment in the United States held at a 28-year low of 4.3 percent in May as the economy churned out nearly 300,000 new jobs, overcoming fallout from Asia's economic turmoil. Stocks shot higher on Wall Street. The seasonally adjusted rate matched April's and was the lowest since February 1970. Many analysts had considered the April rate, down from 4.7 percent in March, a fluke. But Friday's report, from the Labor Department, underscores the labor market's strength. Economists said the stronger-than-expected report, which also showed healthy wage gains, raised the prospect that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates later this year to slow economic growth and thus pre-empt any acceleration in inflation. (US-ECONOMY) DETROIT (AP) _ General Motors Corp. and the United Auto Workers faced off Friday in another strike that pits the automaker's desire to become leaner and more competitive against the union's effort to save jobs. Nearly 3,400 workers at GM's Flint Metal Center north of Detroit, Michigan went on strike after talks failed to yield an agreement. It is the seventh strike at a GM plant in the United States since early 1997. A strike of more than a few days would lead to shortages of hoods, fenders, doors and other parts, forcing closures of GM assembly plants throughout North America. (US-GM STRIKE) LONDON (AP) _ The realities of global commerce caught up with a grand remnant of British glory Friday as Volkswagen AG won approval to buy Rolls-Royce Motor Cars, infuriating small English investors. ``Should I call it now a Rolls-wagen?'' incredulous shareholder Rodney Crowe asked at a meeting called by Vickers PLC, the engineering group that is selling Rolls-Royce to the Germans. Shareholders approved Volkswagen's 430 million pound (dlrs 700 million) deal over a 340 million pound (dlrs 554 million) offer from rival BMW, in a raucous session punctuated by outbursts of nationalism. Vickers, an engineering group almost thrown out of business by Rolls-Royce's losses in the last recession, said the sale was the best way forward for all concerned. (BRITAIN-ROLLS-ROYCE) NEW YORK (AP) _ Switzerland's three major banks met Friday with lawyers for Holocaust victims in an attempt to settle lawsuits claiming the banks failed to return assets from the victims' wartime accounts. Credit Suisse, the Union Bank of Switzerland and the Swiss Bank Corp. were expected to offer more than dlrs 1 billion to settle the lawsuits, a source close to the negotiations told The Associated Press Friday. Stuart Eizenstat, the Clinton administration's representative to the negotiations, contacted plaintiffs' lawyers Thursday to tell them of the pending offer, the source said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The two sides were expected to meet all day in New York, the source said, adding that it could take weeks to negotiate a final deal. In Zurich, a spokesman for the Credit Suisse Group denied reports of a settlement offer. (US-SWISS BANKS) CHICAGO (AP) _ Like El Nino, the Asian economic crisis has become a timely scapegoat for American companies set to report poor results, but analysts said Friday that Motorola Inc.'s problems extend back to strategic blunders made years ago. The Schaumburg, Illinois-based semiconductor and cellular telephone maker said late Thursday that it will slash 15,000 employees, or 10 percent of its work force, and could lose money in the second quarter even before it takes about dlrs 2 billion in charges. Asian competitors, particularly from South Korea, have been sharply cutting prices to weather the economic damage in their countries, taking business from Motorola. Demand in that region, meanwhile, has fallen sharply. (US-MOTOROLA LAYOFFS)

Friday, June 12
By The Associated Press
Today is Friday, June 12, the 163rd day of 1998. There are 202 days left in the year. Highlights in history on this date: 1672 - French Army crosses Rhine River at Talhoys. 1683 - Turks begin siege of Vienna; Plot to assassinate King Charles II of Britain and his brother James, Duke of York, is uncovered. 1691 - Ahmed II succeeds Suleiman III as Sultan of Turkey. 1798 - French forces capture island of Malta. 1882 - Anti-foreign riots break out in Alexandria, Egypt. 1900 - Second German Naval Act aims at fleet of 38 battleships by 1920. 1901 - Cuban Convention makes that nation virtually a protectorate of United States. 1917 - King Constantine of Greece abdicates making way for son Alexander. 1934 - Political parties are banned in Bulgaria. 1935 - Paraguay and Bolivia sign peace treaty ending three-year Chaco war. 1937 - Purge of Russian generals begins. 1940 - Japanese planes bomb Chungking, China. 1944 - Germans launch flying-bomb attacks against Britain. 1952 - First day without passports for Nordic nationals traveling in Scandinavia as part of the cooperation between the five Nordic countries. 1964 - Nelson Mandela, Walter Sisulu and other anti-apartheid leaders sentenced to life in prison. 1967 - Israel declares it will keep some of ground won from Egypt, Jordan and Syria in Six-Day Middle East War. 1976 - A military coup in Uruguay overthrows civilian president Juan Bordaberry, beginning a nine-year dictatorship. 1984 - U.S. Secretary of State George P. Shultz insists U.S. government has hard evidence that Nicaragua is providing war material to rebels in El Salvador. 1985 - Portugal signs the treaty of accession to the European Economic Community. 1987 - Central African Republic's former Emperor Jean-Bedel Bokassa is sentenced to death on conviction of murder, arbitrary arrest and embezzlement of public funds. 1988 - Demonstrations erupt over controversial constitutional amendment making Islam the state religion in Bangladesh. 1990 - Israel's new right-wing government vows to spend more money on new settlements in the Occupied Lands. 1991 - Boris Yeltsin is elected president of the Russian republic. 1992 - The Russian legislature declares a state of emergency in North Ossetia as troops are airlifted to the region. 1993 - U.N. Forces launch offensive against Somali warlord Mohamed Farrah Aidid. 1994 - Ruling parties in Britain and Spain are battered in votes for European Union's assembly, but German and Italian leaders win votes of confidence. 1995 - Bosnian Prime Minister Haris Silajdzic angrily rejects White House suggestions that his government wants to expand the war that has killed 200,000 Bosnians in the past three years. 1996 - In Brisbane, two Blackhawk army helicopters collide and burst into flames during training exercises, killing 18 commandos in Australia's worst peacetime military accident in three decades. 1997 - The United States announces its determination to limit the next wave of NATO expansion to Hungary, the Czech Republic and Poland, snubbing Slovenia and Romania. Today's Birthdays: Charles Kingsley, English author-social reformer (1819-1875); Sir Anthony Eden, English statesman (1897-1977); George Bush, Former U.S. President (1928--). Thought For Today: Don't use the conduct of a fool as a precedent _ The Jewish Talmud.

BC-Peru-Cabinet Shuffle,0199
Peru's finance minister resigns as cabinet shake-up continues
LIMA, Peru (AP) _ Finance Minister Jorge Camet, the most powerful free-market advocate in President Alberto Fujimori's cabinet, resigned Friday in the second day of a cabinet shake-up. He was replaced by Jorge Baca, the head of Peru's tax collection agency. Under Baca, the agency increased tax collection levels and established tough laws to crack down on violators. Camet, 73, had been in office since January 1993 and was the longest-serving member of Fujimori's cabinet. He had fought for Peru to maintain its free-market course and stick to its economic reform program. Camet's resignation came a day after Prime Minister Alberto Pandolfi, the head of cabinet, resigned and was replaced by the populist Javier Valle Riestra, a former senator with the Aprista party of disgraced former President Alan Garcia. Analysts said that with the cabinet shuffle Fujimori may be preparing to implement free-spending policies to shore up his sagging popularity to prepare for a re-election bid in 2000. No official reason was given for Camet's or Pandolfi's resignations.

BC-Latin American Briefs,0647
Eds: Contains items from Argentina, Mexico and Panama
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina (AP) _ A provincial governor in Argentina who faced impeachment following the discovery of an undisclosed Swiss bank account was cleared Friday by a legislative tribunal. The panel of provincial lawmakers voted 16-12 to absolve Antonio Bussi, governor of the northern Tucuman province, allowing him remain in office. A vote on impeachment would have required a two-thirds majority. The account, which Bussi failed to disclose as required by law, was discovered in February during investigations surrounding the 1976-83 Argentine military dictatorship. The former general, who governs the same province he ran during the military's rule, was accused of misconduct as an elected official. He was suspended for 60 days in April. He denied any wrongdoing, calling it an ``error of omission.'' Human rights groups charge the money was plundered from victims of the military's ``dirty war'' on leftists and dissidents, which left 9,000 dead or missing. The groups accuse Bussi of taking part in the executions. ___ BUENOS AIRES, Argentina (AP) _ Opposition lawmakers in Argentina said Friday they will launch impeachment proceedings against five Supreme Court judges, alleging poor performance on the bench. Left-of-center Frepaso Party Deputy Carlos Alvarez claimed ``more than sufficient'' evidence existed to seek the ouster of five of the court's nine judges, including its president. A Supreme Court spokeswoman said there would be no official comment Friday. The five judges have backed the government's stance in several recent high-profile cases. President Carlos Menem's allies are seeking ways around a constitutional provision barring the president from being elected to a third consecutive term. Lower courts have upheld the ban as valid, though analysts speculate Menem's allies have a better shot at the high court, which the president expanded in 1990 and then packed with his own appointees. ___ MEXICO CITY (AP) _ With pollution levels rising sharply once again, officials declared emergency anti-smog measures in Mexico's sprawling capital on Friday, a week after lifting a four-day emergency decree. Most cars with odd-numbered license plates will be barred from streets on Saturday and industries are ordered to cut back activity. Evening rains have helped cut the smoke from fires that had aggravated other recent smog problems. But stagnant air trapped pollution in the high-altitude valley. Similar restrictions were imposed due to high pollution levels four days last week. The new alert is the first declared under tougher new rules, which trigger alerts at 240 points of ozone on the smog index rather than 250. ___ PANAMA CITY (AP) _ Work began Friday on transforming a former U.S. military base into a luxury tourist and commercial center that Panama hopes will create thousands of jobs and help make up for the loss of U.S. military spending. A private Panamanian company, Constructora Urbana, will spend the next 18 months clearing buildings from the former Fort Amador, building new access roads and installing water and sewer lines. Construction on the new tourist resort will begin as soon as infrastructure work is completed. Plans call for seven hotels, a commercial center, cruise-ship docks and two marinas. Panama hopes the project will create an estimated 3,000 jobs. Just minutes away from Panama City, Amador is a 398-acre (160-hectare) peninsula extending into the Pacific Ocean at the entrance to the Panama Canal. It was built between 1911 and 1915 as an artillery installation to protect the canal. Under a 1977 treaty, the United States will turn over all its military posts and the canal to Panama by the end of 1999.

BC-Sports-Tennis-French Open,0660
Time for a Spanish sweep at Roland Garros?
Eds: RECAPS previous By JOCELYN NOVECK Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Spanish players have always excelled on clay courts, which they grow up on. This year, they have a chance to prove that with a sweep of the men's and women's French Open titles. Arantxa Sanchez Vicario gets the first shot. She won two of her three Grand Slam titles here, and is very comfortable on the red clay of Roland Garros. But she's up against someone who's done even better here. Monica Seles won three times, from 1990-92. Then came the horrible stabbing by a crazed fan in 1993, which kept her off the tour for two and a half years. Now, she's turned adversity into her ally. Her father's death May 14 seems to have given her new reason to excel; she says her dad would have wanted her to play here. She's looking like the old Monica again. Seles shook up the tournament Thursday, when she ousted top-seeded Martina Hingis, the overwhelming favorite, in the semifinals. Even more daunting for Sanchez Vicario, Seles is 14-2 against the Spaniard, including a 6-3, 6-4 win in the 1991 final. Then, Seles' father was watching from the players' box. This time, she'll be wearing his ring on a chain around her neck. Whatever happens on the women's side, the men's champion will be a guy from Barcelona. Carlos Moya went out with buddy Felix Mantilla for ice cream before clobbering him in the semifinals. Now Moya is making dinner plans with another close friend, Alex Corretja, whom he'll face in an all-Spanish men's final on Sunday. ``Maybe we can have dinner together. That's the most important thing, we're going to be friends even if I win or if he wins,'' Corretja said. ``We have to find our game on the court, and then just enjoy the party.'' Moya, Mantilla and Corretja all live in Barcelona and hang out together on the road. On a muggy center court Friday, Corretja defeated local hero Cedric Pioline of France in straight sets, 6-3, 6-4, 6-2, to join Moya in the final. Moya won 5-7, 6-2, 6-4, 6-2 over Mantilla, yet another Spaniard. It will be the second all-Spanish final in five years at the French Open. Sergi Bruguera defeated Alberto Berasategui for the 1994 title. ``Alex is a close friend of mine,'' Moya said. ``But when you get on the court, you fight like crazy, you run, you do everything, you try to step on him if necessary.'' Pioline, hoping to become the first Frenchman to win at Roland Garros since Yannick Noah in 1983, had played three five-setters in reaching the semifinals and appeared drained. ``I felt I did everything a bit slowly. On top of that, you're not as focused when you're tired. You don't make the right decisions,'' he said. Corretja noticed. ``I saw that Cedric was not feeling so well, he was struggling on the court,'' Moya mixed powerful groundstrokes with delicate drop shots to throw off Mantilla, who preferred to rally patiently from the baseline. Moya also served 10 aces. The Spaniards split the first two sets and Mantilla took a 4-1 lead in the third. But Moya won the next five games, losing just five points. ``I just decided to take more risks than I was taking before,'' Moya said. ``I decided there had to be a change, otherwise that set was for him. Two sets to one down, it's tough to come back.'' Moya got to match point with a 127-mph (203-kmph) serve, then hit a 122-mph (195-kmph) service winner to finish off the 2-hour, 42-minute match. He hit a ball into the stands, then tossed his white bandana to fans. Moya was runnerup at the 1997 Australian Open, but said he will be less awed in a final this time. ``In Australia, just to be in the final was a surprise for me. But here is different. ``I don't want to lose in the final again.''

BC-UN-Kosovo,0490
Annan uses strong language to denounce Serb ``atrocities'' in
Kosovo Eds: RECAPS previous By ROBERT H. REID Associated Press Writer
UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ In an language rarely used against a member state, the United Nations is accusing Serb military and paramilitary forces of ``atrocities'' in Kosovo, where fighting has driven thousands from their homes. ``(Secretary-General Kofi Annan) is deeply disturbed by the latest reports of an intensifying campaign against the unarmed civilian population in Kosovo,'' U.N. spokesman Juan-Carlos Brandt said Friday. ``He reiterates in the strongest possible terms his condemnation of the atrocities committed by Serbian military and paramilitary forces,'' Brandt added, reading from an official U.N. statement. ``They must not be allowed to repeat the campaign of ethnic cleansing and indiscriminate attacks on civilians that characterized the war in Bosnia,'' the statement added. ``If the world has learned anything from that dire chapter in history, it is that this kind of aggression must be confronted immediately and with determination.'' The statement was unusual because it specifically accused Serb forces of atrocities in a military action within areas which the international community recognizes as part of the Serbian republic. The United Nations is often reluctant to level such accusations against sovereign governments for actions within their borders. The Security Council discussed the deteriorating situation in Kosovo on Friday. More than 250 people have died since March 1 in escalating clashes between government forces and the Kosovo Liberation Army, the armed wing of the Albanian independence movement. The council president, Ambassador Antonio Monteiro of Portugal, said the 15 members ``expressed their grave concern'' and called for the ``immediate cessation'' of violence, especially ``the excessive use of force'' against civilians. ``We all, I think, share the view that unfortunately, Belgrade seems to be trying to impose a military solution upon the Kosovo issue,'' British Ambassador John Weston said. Weston said he expects the council to consider ``additional measures'' beyond the arms embargo imposed last March on Yugoslavia to urge a political solution. At a news conference, Yugoslavia's acting U.N. ambassador, Vladislav Jovanovic, said the Serb government, which along with Montenegro forms the Yugoslav federation, was ``firmly committed'' to a ``serious and productive dialogue'' with Kosovo Albanians. ``But first of all, the terrorist activities and banditry should cease at once and those from Albanian side and the outside world who are ambivalent about terrorism should make a very firm and very clear statement condemning the terrorism,'' Jovanovic said.

BC-UN-Angola,0537
Security Council threatening new measures in Angola
Eds: RECAPS previous By ROBERT H. REID Associated Press Writer
UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ Three nations overseeing the Angolan peace process will submit a draft resolution to the Security Council with ``additional measures'' against UNITA unless it fulfills commitments under a 1994 agreement, Portugal's U.N. ambassador says. Ambassador Antonio Monteiro of Portugal, president of the council for this month, said experts from the ``troika'' powers _ the United States, Russia and Portugal _ would submit the draft ``as soon as possible'' in hopes of preventing renewal of the civil war. Monteiro gave no details but said the resolution ``envisages adoption of additional measures if UNITA will not comply with its commitments.'' Last October, the Security Council imposed air and travel sanctions against UNITA, a former rebel movement, in addition to an oil and weapons embargo in effect since 1993. Monteiro said the three observer countries had agreed among themselves on the proposed measures but he would not discuss them before the draft resolution was circulated to the full 15-member council. ``This is a very, very serious situation in Angola,'' Monteiro told reporters. ``We want very much to save the peace process.'' The U.N. special representative to Angola, Alioune Blondin Beye, briefed the council Friday on the much delayed implementation of the 1994 Lusaka peace agreement between the government and UNITA, a former rebel movement. Beye said earlier this week that UNITA was hiding armed men in remote areas of the vast southwest African nation, despite the movement's pledge that it demobilized its 70,000-strong guerrilla army. UNITA has denied the allegation. Before the council meeting, diplomatic sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Beye would insist on new sanctions against UNITA and threatened to resign if the parties did not fulfill terms of the peace plan. Beye made no statement to reporters after the meeting. Monteiro said Beye ``had mentioned that possibility'' but said the envoy ``decided with courage that he has to assume his responsibilities,'' meaning stay on. UNITA's secretary-general Paulo Lukamba Gato dismissed the council actions as part of ``an international conspiracy'' against the rebel movement. Speaking by telephone from UNITA's central highland stronghold at Bailundo, Paulo Lukamba Gato said Beye's report was ``a bad mistake'' and ``very dangerous'' for the peace process. He said reports that UNITA had armed men hidden in the bush was based on unreliable third-hand reports and ``could cost the peace process dearly'' by prompting the government to launch a military offensive. UNITA _ a Portuguese acronym for the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola _ fought a two-decade civil war against the government following the southwest African nation's 1975 independence from Portugal. A 1991 peace pact collapsed when UNITA rejected its defeat in the following year's elections and returned to the bush.

BC-UN-India-Pakistan,0395
Security Council considers resolution against nuclear programs in
South Asia By ROBERT H. REID Associated Press Writer
UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ Hoping to curb the nuclear arms race in South Asia, the Security Council considered a Japanese resolution urging India and Pakistan to halt nuclear weapons programs and denying nuclear status to the two rivals. Friday's draft resolution also calls on India and Pakistan to exercise restraint and find ``mutually acceptable solutions'' to the ``root causes of those tensions, including Kashmir.'' Japan pushed for quick council action on the resolution as a followup to Thursday's meeting in Geneva of foreign ministers of the five longtime nuclear states _ the United States, Russia, Britain, France and China. Following the Geneva meeting, the five _ also permanent members of the council _ condemned Indian and Pakistani tests and pledged to cooperate closely ``to prevent a ``nuclear and missile arms race in the subcontinent.'' Council diplomats continued closed-door consultations late Friday trying to work out language acceptable to all 15 members _ especially the 10 non-permanent members who were not represented at the Geneva meeting. It was unclear whether the resolution, co-sponsored by Sweden and Costa Rica, would be put to a vote Friday night or possibly Saturday. The draft resolution repeated the position of the five that although India and Pakistan have exploded nuclear devices, they would not be accorded status as nuclear states. Under the 1970 Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, the five countries were the only ones allowed to maintain nuclear arsenals. India and Pakistan have refused to sign the treaty, pointing to that exemption as unfair. The Japanese resolution also welcomed an offer by Secretary-General Kofi Annan to encourage India and Pakistan to resume a high-level dialogue which broke down last year because of differences over Kashmir. India and Pakistan have fought three wars since 1947 _ two of them Kashmir which is divided between them. The resolution also ``encourages'' member states to prevent the export of materials, equipment and technology ``that could in any way assist programs in India or Pakistan for nuclear weapons.''

BC-FEA-Asia-Export Boom?,0686
Trade not the pick-me-up Asia was looking for
By PAULINE JELINEK Associated Press Writer
SEOUL, South Korea (AP) _ It was supposed to be the silver lining in Asia's financial crash. Currencies weakened by the meltdown would make Asian goods cheaper in the United States and elsewhere. Exports would surge, and that would give a lift to the battered economies of Thailand, South Korea and others. But that hasn't exactly happened, despite the predictions voiced widely in the United States and Asia. Instead, the overseas sales of some Asian nations are falling, and in others aren't rising enough to make a difference. So what happened to the hoped for export boom? ``It was unrealistic in the first place,'' said Dan Harwood, head of research at ABN Amro Asia Ltd. in Seoul. In the past, Asian tigers like Thailand, Indonesia and South Korea may have exported their way to rapid growth. But that was when investment was plentiful, credit was cheap and customers were abundant. Now, foreign investors have fled. Some of the nations' banking systems are failing and their interest rates are high. Many exporters are unable to get the credit they need to keep operating at a profit, to buy materials for manufacturing. And that's even when banks have the money to spare. A dlrs 575 million Bank of Thailand fund for exporters went undistributed by commercial banks last year. With their bad loans already estimated at 30 percent, Thai financial institutions were unwilling to risk making any more questionable loans. In Indonesia and elsewhere, if banks are willing to lend at all, it's at crushing interest rates, ratcheted up as part of conditions attached to International Monetary Fund bailouts last year. Then there's the problem of lower demand. Asian nations have traditionally been each other's trading partners _ and many of those partners are drastically cutting imports. ``Trade between Asian countries was good, but general (world) demand is slowing and suddenly you've got a lot of Asian countries that are competing with themselves,'' said Harwood. ``They have no domestic markets and suddenly they're competing for a finite part of (the market in) Europe, the United States, Africa.'' Profitability of exports also has been hit by falling prices. South Korea is thinking about cutting production of computer chips because a glut in the market has so weakened prices. Malaysia, with half of its market in the European Union and troubled Asia, was further hit by declining prices for key exports such as petroleum, palm oil and rubber. ``The economy is at risk of going nowhere,'' said Joanne Song, economist with PhileoAllied Securities in the capital, Kuala Lumpur. Indeed, prospects for the rest of the year don't look good. For as poor as Asian export performances have been, the picture for imports has been worse. Lackluster exports and severely reduced imports may have led to trade surpluses in South Korea and elsewhere. But import cutbacks have come from not only slumping consumer demand but also lowered demand for raw materials and capital goods such as machinery. And, again, that's because Asian businesses can't get the credit to buy those goods. ``Fewer imports of raw materials now means fewer exports in the future,'' said Lee Pil-sang, economics professor at Korea University. Further weighing on the future is the question of Japan. Some economists had hoped Japan would take a stronger role in spurring the region's economies by boosting domestic consumption and opening up its markets to more Asian goods. Instead, Japan bought 15 percent less from Asian exporters in April compared with a year ago _ and its weakening yen is making for even stiffer competition among Asian exporters of cars, steel, electronics and other goods. ``They're all in a difficult position,'' said Harwood. ``They've got to grow themselves out of this, kick-start their own internal economies.''

BC-Czech-Pensioners Party,0492
Czech pensioners fight for brighter political future
AP Photo PRA101 By NADIA RYBAROVA Associated Press Writer
PRAGUE, Czech Republic (AP) _ No one took it very seriously when a group of Czech pensioners fed up with the rising cost of living banded together to form a political party. But the Pensioners for Secure Life are becoming a political force that cannot be ignored _ an essential partner for the leading Social Democrats if they hope to form a government after next week's parliamentary elections. Founded in 1990, the party's agenda, focusing on the need for higher pensions, has not changed over the years. But with a high standard of living not coming as quickly as people had hoped, more of the Czech Republic's 2 million-plus pensioners seem to be listening. After two previous failures, the party looks set to finally clear the 5 percent threshold necessary to get into parliament. ``The pensioners' party is the only party offering something that can improve my standard of living,'' said Jarmila Pepichova, 70, a retired postwoman. ``They are the only ones who say something that makes sense to me.'' Some opinion polls give the party nearly 10 percent support, roughly three times its backing in 1996 elections. This has center-right politicians and analysts warning that the party, known by its initials DZJ, could become the third ``extremist'' party represented in parliament, along with the Communists and the nationalist Republicans. ``From the mud of Czech politics ... DZJ has emerged, a party with a program that has extreme populism as its leitmotif,'' liberal analyst Bohumil Dolezal wrote recently. ``But, unlike Communists and Republicans, Pensioners have the image of good old boys struggling for mere survival.'' The opposition Social Democrats, who lead the polls with 24 percent, say they would have no trouble forming a coalition with the Pensioners since the party focuses mainly on social issues. Eduard Kremlicka, the party's chairman, complains that pensions are too low and demands they be raised to at least 60 percent of an average monthly salary. About one-fifth of the country's 10.5 million people receive monthly pensions. Official figures show the average pension in the Czech Republic was $148, or 45 percent of a gross average salary in 1997, down from 51 percent in 1990. Kremlicka also wants the state to provide everyone with low-budget housing, health care and education. ``We are not a party for a secure life for pensioners, we are pensioners' party for a secure life for all,'' said the 68-year-old retired officer of the country's former communist army. The party's electorate, however, seems to be larger in the countryside than in cities, where the standard of living is higher. Only a dozen people attended a recent meeting in the capital.

BC-Germany-Train Derails,0582
As search for bodies nears an end, rescuers face the tragedy
AP Photos ESC101-102,107,111, TLK108,109, MUN101, FRA108, HBG108,105,107 By TONY CZUCZKA Associated Press Writer
ESCHEDE, Germany (AP) _ Rescue crews searching for survivors of a deadly high-speed train crash in Germany prepared for rest and reflection as they hoped by Saturday to finish clearing the site. ``I've never had to deal with so many dead people,'' said Dirk Winkler, a 25-year-old soldier whose tank battalion has been using its vehicles to pull back the wreckage from Wednesday's crash of the InterCity Express 884. Rescuers uncovered the 93rd body in the wreckage Friday afternoon, bringing the death toll to 98, including five who died in hospitals. By evening, rescuers prodding the sandy dirt with slow gentle care were finding only body fragments, coming close to the end of their search. Police expected to finish clearing the site of bodies by Saturday morning, although heavy rains overnight threatened to slow the work. While doctors working round the clock will continue to identify the victims over the weekend, the rescuers _ soldiers, firefighters and Red Cross volunteers _ should get some needed rest. But rest will also bring reflection, time to consider the grim impact of what they've been doing. By Friday, investigators had identified a likely cause of the disaster: A wheel broke on the first passenger car. Two minutes later, the derailed train started breaking apart and crashed into supports of an overpass. After recalling all the ICE trains for inspection, the German Rail company ordered trains returning to circulation to run slower, with a top speed of 160 kph (100 mph), rather than the usual maximum of 280 kph (175 mph). When the train hit the bridge, it was traveling at 200 kph (125 mph). With a huge yellow crane, rescuers on Friday lifted the last fragment of the collapsed bridge from the top of the smashed train. The cable creaked from the weight. Underneath, they found the body buried in the sand. Like all the other bodies, this one was taken to a hospital morgue in Hanover, 50 kilometers (30 miles) to the south. By Friday, only 19 victims had been identified because of the mangled conditions of many of the bodies. ``We don't want any relatives to have to go from body to body. because it's unbearable. It's arms and legs and heads. It's awful,'' said Christian Jung, spokesman for the Hanover medical school hospital. Rescuers, like the doctors, have worked almost continuously since arriving at the scene of the worst accident on Germany's railways since World War II on Wednesday. During a break on Friday, they seemed both dazed and animated, pumped up from stress and on automatic-pilot to cope with it. Some described little tricks _ everyday chit-chat at the site, silly jokes on the way home in the car. Anything to distract the mind from what the hands have been doing, and the eyes seeing. ``We have to be strong,'' said Birgit Aust, 25, a Red Cross volunteer. ``The worst moment was when I got there and saw the bridge on top of the train. Then I shut off. You have to suppress all that right now. Otherwise, you can't keep going.'' Aust said she expected to work through the weekend, recovering the remains of the dead and comforting the victims' relatives. Next week _ when the gravity hits _ she plans to seek comfort herself, through counseling.

Cocaine trafficking's third generation: Young, low-key and
thriving Eds: Special U.N. session on the world drug problem begins Monday With BC-FEA-Narcos-Laundering, BC-FEA-Narcos-Cooperation AP Photos NY375-376 By FRANK BAJAK Associated Press Writer
BOGOTA, Colombia (AP) _ Adapting to stepped-up pressure from law enforcement, a new breed of Colombian drug trafficker has abandoned the model of the huge narcotics cartel and is shunning ostentation in favor of a low-key lifestyle. Out are bodyguards and armor-plated Toyota Landcruisers. In are taxis and conservative business suits. ``Today's drug trafficker shelters himself in very small, subtle organizations,'' Colombia's national police chief, Gen. Rosso Jose Serrano, said in an interview. ``He doesn't go around anymore in fancy sneakers, with Rolex watch, gold chains and a revolver on his belt.'' The vast majority of today's traffickers in Colombia are virtual unknowns. But they are efficient, U.S. and Colombian officials agree. The flow of cocaine out of the world's leading producer nation, estimated at 500 metric tons a year, has not ebbed. Nor has business declined for Mexican drug lords, who have also adopted a quieter, more business-like style in recent months. One example is the Arellano Felix gang in Tijuana. Once known for violence and high visibility, the Arellano Felix brothers are no longer spotted in the upscale Tijuana nightclubs they once frequented. The shift is more evident in Colombia, however, where the business has become more diffuse. Gone are the days of the big drug cartels _ conglomerates that controlled the business each step of the way from crop cultivation to cocaine production in secret labs to sales on U.S. streets. ``This is more like after the breakup of AT and T. Now you have the Baby Bells,'' said a U.S. Embassy official, speaking on condition he not be quoted by name. ``Notwithstanding, there's still a lot of dope out there.'' And it keeps moving into new markets _ Russia, South Africa and Japan are now in vogue. Colombia's retooled cocaine trade is once again concentrated in Medellin, the city that the late Pablo Escobar made murderously notorious but was always a model of commercial efficiency. Authorities have identified 43 trafficking gangs in Colombia, nearly half of them in Medellin. Each has an average of 10 to 20 associates, compared to the hundreds of people who were on the payrolls of the old cartels. ``They are mostly people between the ages of 25 and 40 who have no criminal records and work through legitimate small businesses,'' said a Colombian police intelligence official, speaking on condition of anonymity. Some of the Medellin traffickers are former Escobar lieutenants, but most are sophisticated newcomers who employ the latest technologies, are Internet savvy, have a keen grasp of global finance and are deft money launderers. Colombia's first generation of traffickers, the ``cocaine cowboys'' typified by Escobar, trained legions of young assassins, kept mounds of cash in wicker baskets and concentrated operations in specific regions. Flaunting their wealth and defying authorities, they went down in flames in the early 1990s after waging a war on the state that killed hundreds. The successor Cali cartel fared well for a while, bribing police officers, judges, journalists and politicians to look the other way while hiding behind an intricate web of legitimate businesses like its Drogas la Rebaja pharmacy chain. But with the help of U.S. agents and intelligence, political pressure from Washington and a police anti-corruption purge by Serrano, brothers Miguel and Gilberto Rodriguez and the rest of the Cali cartel's pinstripe-suited principals were caught beginning in 1995, convicted and jailed. The new generation remains discreet, and harder to infiltrate. ``We know of very important traffickers in Medellin who don't even have cellular phones or beepers. They know that makes things difficult for us,'' said a police intelligence official. Witness to the self-destructiveness of the Medellin-Cali rivalry, today's Colombian traffickers tend to collaborate rather than compete. They sometimes pool resources, but are autonomous. And they work equally with right-wing paramilitary groups and leftist rebels, both of whom earn tens of millions of dollars a year from cocaine production. Medellin's main drug bosses _ nine are identified in an April 1 intelligence report by Colombia's equivalent of the FBI obtained by The Associated Press _ allegedly include a major shareholder in a local soccer team and Carlos Castano, a fugitive paramilitary leader who lives in a northern mountain hideout. ``The business is more dispersed. They don't send seven tons like before, but 100 kilos or 50 kilos at a time because that way it's much more difficult to identify the organization,'' Serrano said. The new traffickers are also less inclined to violence than their predecessors, although they have killed six judicial investigators in Medellin over the past year, riddling one with 23 bullets from a submachine gun, said a senior judicial official, requesting anonymity for security reasons.
