`Smurfing': How Colombians minimize risks of money laundering
With FEA-Colombia-The New Narcos By FRANK BAJAK Associated Press Writer
BOGOTA, Colombia (AP) _ Traffickers in the cocaine trade's Andean base bring home an estimated dlrs 5 billion a year earned from selling the drug in the United States. Among the schemes they use to hide the money trail is ``smurfing.'' Here's how it works: _The gangs amass U.S. dollars from drug sales in ``stash houses'' in the United States, then hire black market currency brokers to convert the dollars into Colombian pesos. _The brokers hire people in the United States to open checking accounts at U.S. banks with small deposits. One broker can employ dozens of people, who are known as ``smurfs'' after the diminutive blue cartoon characters. _The smurfs are given cash from the ``stash houses'' to deposit into the ``shell'' checking accounts. Those amounts rarely exceed the dlrs 10,000 limit that U.S. banks are required to report to the Treasury Department. _The smurfs sign sheafs of blank checks and give them to the brokers, who fill in dollar amounts but leave payee names blank. _Businesses in Colombia that need U.S. dollars to import goods buy the checks from the currency brokers with Colombian pesos, fill in the payee's name, and cash the checks. The businesses then ship or smuggle the goods _ most often computers, cars, appliances, liquor and cigarettes _ into Colombia. _The brokers, after taking their cut, turn the pesos over to the drug traffickers in Colombia. Variations on the scheme include the drug gangs using their dollars to buy goods such as computers in the United States and then smuggling them into Colombia to be sold for pesos. However, traffickers are able to repatriate only about half of their earnings through such means, Colombian and U.S. law enforcement officials say. They believe the traffickers are channeling the rest, billions of dollars, into the world's stock, bond and futures markets. Colombia has had a money-laundering law since 1995 and it was applied in the arrest of a bank manager in Cali. But no one has yet been convicted under the statute. Last month, U.S. authorities announced the arrest of Mexican and Venezuelan bankers in what was described as the largest drug-money laundering case in U.S. history. But while Washington said ``Operation Casablanca'' had exposed links between the arrested bankers and Colombian traffickers, police sources here said the effect on this country's drug gangs was likely minimal.

Money laundering case shows difficulty of international
cooperation With FEA-The New Narcos By KEN GUGGENHEIM Associated Press Writer
MEXICO CITY (AP) _ To the United States, it was a major blow to money launderers. To Mexico, it was a giant violation of its sovereignty. ``Operation Casablanca,'' the three-year U.S. money laundering sting that led to 160 indictments last month, has highlighted a sensitive issue in multinational criminal investigations: balancing a need for secrecy while respecting foreign laws. As officials from some 150 nations _ President Clinton and Mexican President Ernesto Zedillo among them _ meet beginning Monday at the United Nations to develop a common strategy for combating drugs, the fallout from the case shows how difficult that cooperation can be. Mexican officials from Zedillo on down have expressed anger over revelations that U.S. undercover agents investigating the laundering of drug money had operated in Mexican territory without their knowledge. They say they will try to extradite the agents for trial. Clinton's spokesman, Mike McCurry, said Clinton expressed regret to Zedillo that ``prior consultations had not been possible.'' But while U.S. officials said they were looking at how the case was handled, they also defended the tight secrecy as necessary to protect informants and agents. Both Clinton and Zedillo seemed unaware Mexico had been informed in 1996 that the investigation was taking place _ a fact the Mexican attorney general's office conceded Wednesday. But it insisted Mexican officials had not authorized U.S. agents ``to carry out actions on national territory.'' In the case of Mexico, U.S. law enforcement agencies tend to be particularly wary of sharing secrets. Longstanding fears of corruption were compounded when Mexico's drug czar, Gen. Jesus Gutierrez Rebollo, was arrested in 1997 and charged with being on the payroll of Mexico's top drug smuggler. ``The bottom line is anything you share with the Mexican government as it pertains to narcotics trafficking will immediately be found in the hands of the narcotics organizations in Mexico,'' said Phil Jordan, the former head of the Drug Enforcement Administration's intelligence center in El Paso, Texas. Generally, when investigations lead to Mexico, DEA agents try to find trustworthy Mexican counterparts to work with. But in some rare cases _ when a major operation may be compromised or an agent's life endangered _ U.S. agents have worked in Mexico without the Mexican government's knowledge, Jordan said. ``It's something you have to weigh at the time,'' he said. For Mexico, ``Operation Casablanca'' was only the latest example of the United States arrogantly violating its sovereignty. It considers the U.S. policy of ``certifying'' other nations' anti-drug efforts as hypocrisy on the part of the world's largest drug-consuming nation. Mexicans also were outraged when U.S.-paid agents in 1990 kidnapped a doctor suspected in the killing of an undercover U.S. drug agent and took him to the United States for trial. U.S.-Mexico drug cooperation had seemed to be improving. In a visit to Mexico in August, Clinton's top adviser on drugs, Gen. Barry McCaffrey, praised Mexican law enforcement. And last Tuesday, Mexican officials announced the arrest of two brothers believed to be top leaders of Mexico's largest methamphetamine cartel. Even with the anger over ``Casablanca,'' both Mexican and U.S. officials continue to stress the need to work together in the fight against drugs. At a briefing to discuss the U.N. anti-drug conference, Mexico's foreign secretary, Rosario Green, focused more on the need for nations to work together to fight narcotics than on criticism of the sting. Among the top issues for Mexico at the conference: declarations establishing international principles against money laundering ``stressing the need for a wide exchange of information and, of course, for respecting sovereignty and territorial jurisdictions,'' Green said.

Eritreans down two Ethiopian jets that bomb air base
Eds: RECAPS previous to UPDATE with the United Nations calling for an immediate cease-fire and more evacuation flights planned. AP Photos AMS101-108 By JULIA STEWART Associated Press Writer
ASMARA, Eritrea (AP) _ Ethiopian warplanes bombed an air force base outside Asmara, then were shot down by anti-aircraft guns, bringing the border dispute between the two East African nations right to Eritrea's capital. Ethiopian MiG-23s bombed two hangars Friday at an air base outside Asmara next to the international airport. A commercial airliner on the tarmac was reported damaged. Eritrean guns then shot the two jets down. Witnesses saw several injured people being transported in trucks, but it was not immediately possible to determine the number of casualties or the fate of the Ethiopian pilots. The escalating conflict prompted the State Department to order nonessential staff out of Eritrea and urge other Americans to leave. A plane flew out Friday with 122 Americans and 70 other foreigners, mostly Britons and Canadians, the State Department said. Peace Corp volunteers also were evacuated. Evacuation flights were being planned for Saturday by Britain, the United Nations and the European Union. Eritrea and Ethiopia are at odds over a border region that is claimed by both sides. In the Ethiopian capital, Addis Ababa, the Foreign Ministry said the bombing was in retaliation for an Eritrean attack on Mekele, 200 kilometers (125 miles) north of Addis, on Friday that wounded five Ethiopians. Ethiopian sources said fighting continued for a third day Friday around the border town of Zala Ambassa, about 100 kilometers (60 miles) north of Mekele, where both sides traded tank, artillery and mortar fire. Ethiopian fighters attacked Eritrean tanks that were moving toward Adigrat, about 20 kilometers (10 miles) west. Both nations _ two of the world's poorest _ used aircraft, tanks and artillery supplied to Ethiopia by the Soviet Union during the Cold War. The attacks came a day after Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi agreed to a proposal put forth by the United States and Rwanda to end the two countries' border conflict peacefully. But Meles warned that his country's patience with Eritrea was wearing thin because of Eritrea's refusal to withdraw from territory Ethiopia claims it occupied a month ago. The Eritrean government issued a statement Friday saying there were ``still serious issues of detail and implementation to be worked out'' with the proposal. Jubilant Eritreans poured into the streets of Asmara waving the blue, green and red flags of their young nation after the Ethiopian fighters were shot down. The State Department urged Ethiopia and Eritrea to cease all hostilities while outside envoys seek a peaceful resolution of the dispute. At the United Nations in New York, the Security Council on Friday called for an immediate cease-fire and Secretary-General Kofi Annan appealed to both sides to ``give diplomacy a chance.'' ``The Security Council deplored this escalation and called for an immediate cease-fire'' and ``urged Eritrea and Ethiopia to affirm their commitment to resolve the dispute peacefully,'' council President Antonio Monteiro of Portugal said. One of the recommendations of the U.S.-Rwandan proposal was that Eritrea withdraw to positions held before May 6. Eritrea, which gained independence from Ethiopia in 1993, has always claimed it remains inside its own territory as determined by Italian colonial boundaries. Eritrean rebels under the command of President Isaias Afwerki were instrumental in helping Meles' Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front overthrow a 17-year military regime in July 1991.

BC-FEA-US-Mormon Metamorphosis,0818
20 years after lifting priesthood ban, Mormon church flourishes in
Africa AP Photos SLC401-403 By MATTHEW BROWN Associated Press Writer
SALT LAKE CITY (AP) _ Jomo Oludipe is a Nigerian immigrant who joined the Mormon church in 1991 and now heads a mainly black congregation in Washington, D.C. He's seen many changes in the church that had excluded blacks from the clergy until two decades ago. And he foresees even more, in ``God's time.'' Someday, he believes a top Mormon leader visiting West African congregations will don colorful native dress instead of a business suit and hear hymns backed by African drums, a musical accompaniment forbidden by church elders now. ``It has nothing to do with spirituality, it is just what we are used to,'' Oludipe said. Mormonism, a faith founded in New York that grew among mainly white settlers in the American West, has been rethinking its views on race and inclusiveness for 20 years now. On June 8, 1978, The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints lifted its 126-year-old ban on blacks entering the priesthood. Spencer W. Kimball, then church president, explained the next day that he had received a revelation that all worthy males over age 11 could be ordained to the lay priesthood, regardless of race. Since that watershed, Mormonism has blossomed in Africa with 112,000 members in 27 countries. And while membership records don't indicate race, anecdotal evidence suggests increasing numbers of black conversions in America as well. ``As we leave the West ... and become a more global church with global involvement with cultures around the world, then we have to more carefully think through what is cultural and what is essential doctrine,'' said Alexander B. Morrison, a member of the First Quorum of the Seventy, a body that advises the church hierarchy. ``How to define that,'' he acknowledged, ``is not an easy task.'' Mormonism is by nature a centralized, top-down organization, its leader ordained as a prophet and seer, but Morrison said the church is trying to reach out and to listen. Earlier this year, Gordon B. Hinckley became the first church president to visit the Mormon faithful in West Africa. The Mormon church, with 10 million members, is not alone in trying to balance the various cultures within its membership. Even so, it has lagged behind some other mainstream Christian denominations. Some call Mormonism's past refusal to allow blacks to as priests merely a reflection of the times, and yet it was the only major religion attempting to theologically justify it, said Jan Shipps, professor emeritus of history and religious studies at Indiana-Purdue University, Indianapolis. Joseph Smith, who founded the church in 1830, is said to have ordained a black man. It was Smith's successor, pioneer leader Brigham Young, who as early as 1852 turned into policy the notion that blacks were cursed and inferior. Over the decades, Mormon theologians attempted to explain the policy by using the Bible and other scriptures to prove blacks were tainted by unrighteousness in a pre-mortal life. ``You talk to any black and they know,'' said David Jackson, a black Mormon living in Orange County, Calif. ``I had one guy I was trying to get involved in the church and he said, `You know, Dave, the Mormons are wonderful people until you find out what they really believe about us.''' Jackson, who said Mormonism's strict moral standards and organization are attractive to many blacks, is part of a group pleading for the church to publicly repudiate its ``racist legacy.'' In response, church leaders recently issued a statement saying the 1978 revelation speaks for itself. ``As far as I'm concerned, it's not clear in my mind,'' said Doris Backey, a black Mormon in Menlo Park, California. ``I know that God loves me and I decided not to question (God's) integrity because there must have been a time and place for all things.'' Backey, who had been a missionary with another Christian denomination, did not win early acceptance among Mormons. Some in the staid, upper-class congregation she worships with near Stanford University saw her as disruptive when she would belt out a boisterous, soulful solo or occasionally holler ``amen'' during services. ``I asked her once if she was being treated well and she told me that if people don't, then that's their problem,'' said fellow Mormon and friend Joleen Steck. ``But they've learned to adore her.... They now ask her to sing at weddings and funerals.'' Morrison said local lay leaders who oversee the congregations are urged to consider church members as individuals. ``We don't get to heaven in groups or cultures,'' he said. ``We get there one by one.''

The newspaper then said in an editorial that Al Fayed was an ``ill-mannered self-seeker with no regard for decency.'' ``Fayed Savages Diana's Mother,'' said the headline in the Daily Mail, the country's top selling mid-market tabloid. Al Fayed, multi-millionaire owner of the Hotel Ritz in Paris and the Harrods department store in London, made his outburst after he and Mrs. Shand Kydd joined others to attend a court meeting in Paris called by French judge Judge Herve Stephan. The judge is investigating the Aug. 31 crash in the French capital's Pont de l'Alma tunnel which claimed the lives of Diana, Dodi Fayed, and chauffeur Henri Paul. Al Fayed said he was offended that Shand Kydd refused to speak to him at the hearing. ``I'm an ordinary person. I'm a working-class guy,'' Al Fayed said. ``She thinks she's the Queen of Sheba. She didn't talk to me.'' Al Fayed's outburst made the front pages of almost all of Britain's national newspapers. Only The Financial Times, and The Mirror, a tabloid which has extensively carried Al Fayed's claims that the crash that killed Diana and Dodi was not an accident, did not carry the story on its front page in early editions Saturday. Several papers carried critical editorials. The Express, a mid-market tabloid, said in an editorial that Al Fayed had been responsible for upsetting both Diana's children and her wider family by pursuing conspiracy theories surrounding her death. Tests showed that chauffeur Paul was drunk at the time of the crash, and French investigators believe that is likely the main cause of the crash, in addition to high speed. ``Condemned by government inspectors as a liar, paranoid in his conspiracy theories and a persistent attention seeker, he is in danger of becoming one of the most odious men in Britain,'' The Express said of Al Fayed. ``Morally and personally repugnant to many, we hope he is never given British citizenship.'' Egyptian-born Al Fayed has had a strained relationship with Britain, his adopted country. Successive British governments have refused to give him citizenship, in part because a government report into his takeover of a department store chain in the 1980s concluded that he had misrepresented his background. Al Fayed's ``tenacity makes many observers feel queasy,'' wrote The Independent, a liberal broadsheet, ``for it appears to form just another stage in Mr. Fayed's long battle with the establishment. Any weapon will do, it seems, even the death of his beloved son.''

Scottish hopes; death of referee Dienst
Eds: includes items on Romario; Edmundo; Laudrup-Schmeichel;
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil (AP) _ Just days after being cut from Brazil's national team, Romario surpassed his physical therapist's expectations and appeared on Brazilian television kicking a soccer ball around a sand box Friday. ``Romario is much better than I had imagined,'' Nilton Petroni was quoted in O Globo newspaper. ``He wasn't supposed to go the sand box today but he felt so good after a work session this morning that we upped the training schedule.'' Petroni's office declined to comment to The Associated Press. Romario returned from France earlier this week after tests showed he had not recovered sufficiently from a muscle injury in his leg. ___ OZOIR-LA-FERRIERE, France (AP) _ Brazil's World Cup veterans are unanimous in calling unity the key to winning the tournament. But don't expect Edmundo to join in. The temperamental forward of Italy's Fiorentina has jarred the harmony of the group with his repeated complaints about teammates and his own status as a benchwarmer. With a history of causing uproars, Edmundo is known as ``the animal.'' Edmundo struck again on Friday. In an interview with a Rio de Janeiro radio station, he said he felt he deserved to get the starting berth opened with the loss of Romario, who was cut from the squad with a calf injury. Instead, the spot went to Bebeto. ``I thought the spot would be mine because I think that today I'm in better physical and technical shape and overall I'm better than Bebeto _ without causing any polemic,'' Edmundo said. ___ COPENHAGEN, Denmark (AP) _ For two of Denmark's top players, Friday's friendly against Cameroon had something special: Michael Laudrup said farewell to his fans at home after 16 years on the team and Peter Schmeichel marked his 100th game in goal. Laudrup, who also played on Denmark's 1986 World Cup side in Mexico, announced in May he will retire from soccer at age 33 after the World Cup finals. Cheered by some 37,000 fans at the national Parken stadium in Copenhagen, a visibly moved Laudrup, making his 98th appearance, kicked off his last game on Danish soil while supporters chanted ``Michael, Michael.'' His professional career took him to European powerhouses like Juventus, Barcelona, Real Madrid and Ajax Amsterdam. One of the world's top keepers, Manchester United's Schmeichel is the second Dane to reach the magic figure. Of the 100 games, he has managed to keep the ball out of the net 46 times. Schmeichel and Laudrup likely will beat former international Morten Olsen's record of 102 games as both been selected for the World Cup. ___ GLASGOW, Scotland (AP) _ Like a fighter who's been knocked out in the first round seven times in a row, Scotland's soccer team will celebrate if they finally reach round two of the World Cup. ``We have a great chance to make history, and the boys know that. We have got to dispel the notion of being brave losers,'' coach Craig Brown said Friday as the team departed for France ahead of the June 10 opening game against defending titlist Brazil. ``We will really be at the highest level,'' he added. ``We are one of 30 teams who have qualified to join the hosts and holders. ``There are some 142 countries who have not made it, like Portugal and Sweden. We are there and viewed as one of the underdogs, which is fine by us.'' ___ PARIS (AP) _ Gottfried Dienst, who controversially awarded England's third goal in the 1966 World Cup final with the Germans protesting the ball hadn't crossed the line, has died after a short illness. The Swiss referee's decision became part of World Cup history when Geoff Hurst's injury-time shot hit the underside of the crossbar, bounced down and out into play. English players celebrated a goal and the Germans ran to linesman Tofik Bakhramov to protest. Dienst ran to the linesman too, awarded the goal, England then led 3-2 and finally won 4-2.

BC-Sports-Soccer-US Team Arrives,0602
Guns and grapes as U.S. soccer team arrives in France
AP Photos XLF101-107 By RONALD BLUM AP Sports Writer
SAINT-JEAN D'ARDIERES, France (AP) _ For many tourists, France is a land of grapes and cheese, the Eiffel Tower and the Arc de Triomphe. When the U.S. soccer team arrived in Lyon on Friday, players came off a plane to find an airport filled with machine-gun toting soldiers, pistol-armed police and a bomb-sniffing dog. And when it arrived later in this tiny Beaujolais village, where the team will spend most of the next three weeks, there were gendarmerie patrolling the vineyards, plainclothes officers strolling among the roosters and geese, and dogs ready to attack upon command. ``I don't know, man, Dana Point is looking nice right now,'' forward Eric Wynalda said, thinking back to the Southern California beach resort where the Americans spent most of the 1994 tournament. Satolas Airport looked like a militarized zone when the Americans arrived shortly before noon on a chartered plane after the Air France pilots' strike led to cancellation of their original flight. Officials allowed French people to greet the team inside the terminal, but three dozen Americans who came to cheer their team were forced to wait outside behind barriers. About two dozen French children in red warmup suits with the name of a World Cup sponsor were brought inside for the official greeting while the somewhat peeved American fans tried to catch the team's attention as players walked to the bus. ``How about the American kids?'' yelled Bob Kennedy of Greenwich, Conn., head of the American Club of Lyon. After seeing the U.S. fans, some players and coach Steve Sampson walked over to the barriers, handed out team pictures and spent about 10 minutes signing autographs. Four soldiers with machine guns surveyed the crowd from the second floor of the terminal, and uniformed and plain-clothes police surrounded the team below. Four years ago, when the World Cup was in the United States for the first time, no weapons were visible when the U.S. team traveled, only private security guards. Still, the police presence was less that for the 1990 tournament in Italy, where every player was shadowed by a Carabinieri paramiliatary officer with a 9-millimeter Beretta machine gun. Players took all the security in stride. ``You don't notice unless you look at it,'' midfielder Chad Deering said. Officials hung American flags late Wednesday and Thursday, making it look like Flag Day in Saint-Jean D'Ardieres, a village of 1,200 near the Soane River. When the U.S. players worked out Friday night at Stade Marcel Giroud, the newly sodded field of the local amateur team, they were greeted by ``The Star-Spangled Banner,'' blared from a speaker on the balcony of an apartment complex next to the field. While weary from the long overnight flight from New York _ players sat in the back of the coach section _ the team was happy to finally arrive for soccer's biggest tournament. Players weren't happy with their isolated location, but Sampson told them they would be able to head into Lyons, which is about an hour's drive south, and perhaps could go north to Burgundy. ``It's got the atmosphere we were looking for, the history,'' Sampson said at the team hotel, Chateau de Pizay, a 12th century castle surrounded by a 130-acre vineyard and a 75-acre oak forest. ``It allows player to focus without a lot of distraction.''

BC-Sports-Golf-LPGA-Michelob Light,0605
Sorenstam tops in St. Louis _ again
ST. LOUIS (AP) _ Annika Sorenstam, overcoming rainy weather that transformed one of her favorite courses, shot a 5-under-par 67 on Friday for a one-stroke, first-round lead of the weather-shortened LPGA Michelob Light Classic. Sorenstam, who won the 1995 tournament by 10 strokes and won again in 1997, is searching for her first victory of 1998 after winning six tournaments and over dlrs 1.2 million last year. Rain washed out the first round on Thursday, which reduced the tournament to 54 holes. Wet, cool weather also caused a 2 1/2-hour delay in the start of Friday's round over the Forest Hills Country Club course. ``I love to come here knowing I play well,'' Sorenstam said. ``I come out on the first tee and I know where to hit it. It's almost like you have a home course when you play well. That really helps me here.'' One stroke behind Sorenstam was Caroline McMillan, whose 68 was the only over sub-70 round. Penny Hammel, Stephanie Lowe and Laurie Rinker-Graham shot 70s. Amateur Maria Baena, one of four players unable to finish, was 3-under through 16 holes. Hammel said that course was completely different on Friday than it was earlier in the week. ``When we came out Wednesday, I just couldn't imagine this course being that hard and that fast,'' Hammel said. ``I wasn't used to it. So, when I woke up yesterday, I was kind like, `All right, it's back to its normal self.' I was kind of happy to see the rain.'' ``It is really different from playing Wednesday, because it was really dry and the ball was rolling a lot,'' Sorenstam said. ``Today, it was just the opposite. You hit a shot and it sticks in your pitch mark.'' Sorenstam took charge immediately by making a birdie putt on the par-4 first hole. ``I told my caddie, `It's one of those good days,''' Sorenstam said. ``You make that first one and it gets you going.'' After three-putting the par-4, fourth hole, Sorenstam recorded four birdies in succession from the fifth through the eighth hole. She went out in 4-under 32. Cindy Figg-Currier, among a half-dozen players who shot 71, has seen that before here. ``I'm sure Annika is very comfortable and likes this,'' she said. `` I played with her here last year, and 20-footers (8 meters) to her were like 3-footers (0.9 meters) to the rest of us.'' That has not been the case this year. Sorenstam, who birdied the 11th hole on the back side and parred out the rest of the way, said her putting has been her downfall all year. ``I'm really happy with the way I played today, especially the way I putted. I think I have been hitting the ball really well the whole year, I just haven't made any putts. Today, I made some, and that's what you need.'' The Forest Hills course usually favors accuracy over distance, but Hammel said the longer hitters now have an advantage again. ``It definitely favors the longer players, because they carry it farther,'' she said. ``Shorter players like myself rely on a lot of roll, but you're not getting any roll out there.'' Thursday's rainout was the first in five years of the event, although play was suspended in the second round last year due to rain. The cut will now come Saturday after 36 holes. One player who is already out of contention is Janice Gibson. After carding a 38 on the back nine to start her round, Gibson was disqualified for violating Rule 15-3 when she played a ball from out of bounds on the par-3 No. 3 hole.

BC-Malaysia-King
Malaysian King: Don't let `foreign powers' dictate
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia (AP) _ While warning Malaysians not to allow ``foreign powers'' to subjugate their nation, Malaysia's king exhorted his people to remain civil toward each other during these troubling times. In his birthday speech televised live late Friday, Yang Di-Pertuan Agong Tuanku Ja'afar said foreigners were out to use their economic clout to ``cripple'' developing nations such as Malaysia and retard their economic progress. He exhorted Malaysians to remain united. ``This is not the time for the people to give up hope and to let foreign powers dictate the fate of the nation,'' the king said. Since Asia's economic crisis began last July, Malaysia has seen its currency, the ringgit, plunge more than 35 percent against the dollar. That led to heated comments by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, who blamed foreign currency speculators for rupturing the ringgit and precipitating an exodus of foreign funds. This in turn caused even more skittish foreign investors to pull out. In his speech, however, the king reiterated his support for Mahathir's leadership and affirmed the premier's ability to help the country's economy recover. ``I am very much satisfied with all the efforts being undertaken by the government under the leadership of the Prime Minister,'' he said. The king also said Malaysians must also do their part _ by spending less and saving more _ to help increase national savings and bolster the country's foreign reserves. ``Now it is not the time for us to be selfish,'' he said. ``We should be helping each other to go through the current hard times as we'll only be a strong society if we are all united.''

BC-Sports-Baseball-Mets-Nomo,0553
Mania over Nomo moves to new coast
By HOWARD ULMAN AP Sports Writer
BOSTON (AP) _ New team, same Nomo-mania. From the media to his manager to Mike Piazza, the pitcher with the 2-7 record and 5.05 ERA stirred excitement on his first day in a New York Mets uniform. Even Mookie Wilson, a Mets coach, wore a bemused smile as he sat in the dugout watching 10 minicams focused on the empty runway from the clubhouse for more than 15 minutes waiting for Hideo Nomo to come out. ``It's a little weird right now,'' Wilson said Friday night. Nomo was traded late Thursday night by the Los Angeles Dodgers, ending his successful career on the West Coast where he was very popular among Asian fans. On the East Coast, he's reunited with Piazza, who was traded May 22 to the Mets by Florida, which got him from the Dodgers seven days earlier. ``We think he's going to contribute a lot to this ballclub. It's going to be a lot of fun,'' Piazza said before the game with the Boston Red Sox. ``His pitching speaks for itself,'' manager Bobby Valentine said. ``I like his competitiveness. He's a tough cookie.'' Nomo showed up in the Mets' clubhouse 2 hours and 15 minutes before the game and quietly shook hands with Valentine. Then Dave Wallace, his former pitching coach with the Dodgers and now an adviser to Mets general manager Steve Phillips, saw him. ``Who's the new guy?'' Wallace said with a laugh. Then they embraced. During batting practice, Nomo stayed in the outfield while Piazza got more attention from fans. It was Nomo, however, who drew so much attention that he had to conduct his 11-minute, pregame news conference while sitting on top of the Mets dugout, legs dangling off the edge and five policemen in the stands behind him to keep fans away. In front were a dozen minicams, six boom mikes and a horde of reporters pressing against each other. The Red Sox received requests from 16 media outlets, including some from Japan, after the trade was announced. And Nomo won't even be pitching until Tuesday at home against Tampa Bay. Speaking through an interpreter, Nomo had nothing but good words for the latest upheaval in his life, starting with the Dodgers designating him for assignment Monday, which gave them 10 days to make a move. ``I needed a change of scenery,'' he said. ``I'm just glad this trade was finalized as quickly as it was.'' He wore a black Mets jacket with the number 16, Dwight Gooden's old number with the club, on his left sleeve. He joins a team that started the day in second place in the National League East with a 31-23 record, third best in the wild-card race. Nomo, 29, also was reunited with pitcher Masato Yoshii, a teammate with the Kintetsu Buffaloes in Japan. Nomo was one of baseball's best pitchers as a rookie in 1995 after signing as a free agent after five seasons in his native Japan. He was the NL's rookie of the year and led the league in strikeouts. Going into this season, he had a 43-29 record and 3.34 ERA. But he underwent arthroscopic surgery on his pitching elbow last fall and has struggled recently, losing his last four decisions while allowing 18 earned runs in 26 2-3 innings.

BC-Sports-Basketball-Women's World Championship,0628
U.S.-Brazil play in semifinal of Women's World Championship
BERLIN (AP) _ After watching his unbeaten team lose to the United States by 36 points, Russian coach Yevgeny Gomelsky was convinced. ``There is no real opponent for the Americans. No one can defeat the U.S. team, and they will surely win the world championship,'' Gomelsky said. Those who watched the Americans struggle to get past Japan in the first game of the World Championships in Karlsruhe had to wonder if Gomelsky was talking about the same U.S. team. That team, which barely beat the ninth-place finisher in the championships, looked helpless against the zone, couldn't handle switches and seemed vulnerable to any team with quickness and a plan. What happened? Why are the Americans now the heavy favorites to beat Brazil in the semifinals Saturday and, the next day take the gold _ which they last won in 1990?'' It starts with talent. The Americans may not have the most talented starting five in the tournament, though many might argue that they do, but they definitely have the deepest roster. ``It is very difficult to defense this team,'' said Slovakian coach Natalia Hejkova. ``They have 12 very good players.'' That may be true, but U.S. coach Nell Fortner really only uses 10 and they all contribute. ``Our depth definitely came into play last night,'' Fortner said about the 89-62 win over Slovakia in the first round of the single-elimination finals. Both Natalie Williams and Lisa Leslie, who have been the dynamos in the American attack, got into early foul trouble _ so Fortner brought in DeLisha Milton and Chamique Holdsclaw, and the U.S. juggernaut kept rolling. Another factor in the American resurgence has been a simple one: familiarity. Only five players in Germany played on the team that won the Olympic gold medal in 1996, and this is Fortner's first major competition as head coach. Fortner only had from March 18 to mold these 12 players into a team, and it took some time for all the parts to mesh. That zone attack that looked so helpless against Japan now produces open looks and layups because, Fortner said, the team has finally run it enough against live competition to get comfortable with it. Even so, the Americans have faced a zone only in about eight games, which still causes some problems. ``The hardest thing is get people cutting and moving,'' said Fortner, but in the last few games, it hasn't mattered much what defense has faced the U.S. At the other end of the floor, the Americans have made adjustments too _ and many of them are simply the result of more familiarity with the system. Fortner has installed a few simple rules about handling an on-ball screen, for example, but it takes time for even experienced players to react instinctively to game situations. And finally, there is Fortner herself. The 39-year-old had only one year of collegiate head coaching experience, though she had assisted Tara VanDerveer on the 1996 U.S. Olympic team, so there were questions about whether she was ready to run a team of elite athletes playing at the highest level in the world. ``She's been really positive with us, which has helped,'' said Jennifer Azzi, the team captain and one of the five returnees from the 1996 Olympic champions. ``Her game plans are really good.'' But Fortner has also helped mold this group of disparate individuals into a real team, a fact noted by Spanish center Elisabeth Cebrian when she was asked to compare the Americans to the Russians. ``The Russians have more technique,'' said Cebrian, ``but the U.S. is more of a team.''

BC-Sports-Baseball-US Roundup,0641
Cubs edge White Sox 6-5 as interleague play begins
Eds: will be updated
CHICAGO (AP) _ Brant Brown hit a leadoff home run in the 12th inning to give the Cubs a 6-5 victory over the White Sox on Friday in the first official Wrigley Field game between the Chicago rivals. The last time the two met at a Cubs park in a game that counted was the 1906 World Series at West Side Grounds. The White Sox won that series 4-2. Brown hit his sixth homer of the season over the right-field wall off Tony Castillo (1-2) to give the Cubs their seventh straight victory. Terry Mulholland (2-1) allowed one hit in a scoreless 12th for the victory. The Cubs threatened in the 10th, loading the bases with one out, but Matt Karchner struck out Sammy Sosa, who homered in the fifth, and Jeff Blauser, who had three hits on the day. Pirates 6, Twins 1 In Pittsburgh, Jermaine Allensworth hit a tiebreaking two-run single and rookie Jose Silva pitched a five-hitter as Pittsburgh won its sixth straight. Silva (6-3) struck out seven and didn't walk any to win for the fifth time in his last six decisions. Minnesota's Mike Morgan (2-2) continued to struggle against Pittsburgh, giving up eight hits and three runs in six innings. Morgan, who has pitched for a record-tying 10 clubs, is 5-17 lifetime against the Pirates. Reds 2, Indians 1 In Cincinnati, Pete Harnisch quieted a large Cleveland contingent with seven strong innings and Bret Boone had four hits as the Cincinnati Reds beat the Indians. The Indians' first game in Cincinnati was a box-office smash _ the Reds sold 43,532 tickets, their best gate since opening day. Thousands of fans made the four-hour drive from Cleveland, where Jacobs Field is sold out for the season, to root for the visiting team. Harnisch (6-1) quieted the visitors' fans and set up Cleveland's third loss in 11 games by allowing only four hits over seven innings, including Jim Thome's solo homer in the sixth. Expos 5, Devil Rays 2 In St. Petersburg, Florida, Brad Fullmer and Vladimir Guerrero hit two-run homers as Montreal beat Tampa Bay in an interleague matchup that drew the smallest crowd ever at Tropicana Field. After averaging 31,396 in their first 26 home games, the expansion Devil Rays drew only 24,025 for their first regular-season game against a National League opponent. Dustin Hermanson (4-4) pitched five shutout innings as Montreal won its third consecutive road game. Tampa Bay has lost four in a row. Orioles 3, Braves 2 In Baltimore, Scott Erickson pitched a seven-hitter and Baltimore hit three homers off Danny Neagle to beat Atlanta for the fourth straight time since interleague play began last season. The Orioles swept three games in Atlanta last year, and this time they made quick work of the Braves in 1 hour, 53 minutes. Eric Davis, Lenny Webster and Joe Carter homered off Neagle (7-3), who had not given up three homers in a game this season. That was enough offense for Erickson (6-6), who had won only two of his last eight decisions. Mets 9, Red Sox 2 In Boston, in their first meeting at Fenway Park since the 1986 World Series, the New York Mets hit four long homers off Pedro Martinez to beat the Boston Red Sox. The Mets welcomed pitcher Hideo Nomo, obtained Thursday night from the Los Angeles Dodgers, but lost catcher Mike Piazza, who sustained a contusion of his left hand after being hit by a pitch in the first inning. X-rays were negative and Piazza, who left the game after the top of the first, was listed as day-to-day. Martinez (6-2) had his worst outing of the season, giving up 400-foot plus homers to Alberto Castillo, John Olerud, Luis Lopez, and Bernard Gilkey.

BC-UN-India-Pakistan, 1st Ld-Writethru,0551
Security Council considers resolution against nuclear programs in
South Asia Eds: UPDATES with Indian letter denouncing council stand By ROBERT H. REID Associated Press Writer
UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ Hoping to curb the nuclear arms race in South Asia, the Security Council considered a Japanese resolution urging India and Pakistan to halt nuclear weapons programs and denying nuclear status to the two rivals. India accused the council of overstepping its authority and questioned why the members were tolerating ``the continued retention of nuclear weapons by the nuclear weapons states,'' who are all permanent members of the council. In a letter to council President Antonio Monteiro, India's U.N. ambassador, Kamalesh Sharma, said the resolution involved ``sovereign decisions taken by member states, not matters in which the council has any role.'' Sharma asked whether the Security Council can ``continue to ignore the overwhelming demand'' of the rest of the world ``for elimination of nuclear weapons'' when the most important council members refuse to dismantle their own arsenals. The draft resolution urges both countries to halt the development of missiles capable of carrying nuclear warheads and calls on them to sign nuclear arms control treaties. It also asks India and Pakistan to exercise restraint and find ``mutually acceptable solutions'' to the ``root causes of those tensions, including Kashmir.'' Japan pushed for quick council action on the resolution as a followup to Thursday's meeting in Geneva of foreign ministers of the five longtime nuclear states _ the United States, Russia, Britain, France and China. Following the Geneva meeting, the five _ also permanent members of the council _ condemned Indian and Pakistani tests and pledged to cooperate closely ``to prevent a ``nuclear and missile arms race in the subcontinent.'' Council diplomats continued closed-door consultations late Friday trying to work out language acceptable to all 15 members _ especially the 10 non-permanent members who were not represented at the Geneva meeting. It was unclear whether the resolution, co-sponsored by Sweden and Costa Rica, would be put to a vote Friday night or possibly Saturday. The draft resolution repeated the position of the five that although India and Pakistan have exploded nuclear devices, they would not be accorded status as nuclear states. Under the 1970 Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, the five countries were the only ones allowed to maintain nuclear arsenals. India and Pakistan have refused to sign the treaty, pointing to that exemption as unfair. The Japanese resolution also welcomed an offer by Secretary-General Kofi Annan to encourage India and Pakistan to resume a high-level dialogue which broke down last year because of differences over Kashmir. India and Pakistan have fought three wars since 1947 _ two of them Kashmir which is divided between them. The resolution also ``encourages'' member states to prevent the export of materials, equipment and technology ``that could in any way assist programs in India or Pakistan for nuclear weapons.''

BC-Sports-Ice Hockey-NHL Playoff Roundup,0510
Red Wings stop Stars 2-0 to advance to finals
DETROIT (AP) _ The Stanley Cup will go through Detroit _ again. Larry Murphy and Sergei Fedorov scored and Chris Osgood notched his fifth career playoff shutout as the Red Wings defeated the Dallas Stars 2-0 Friday night to wrap up the Western Conference title in six games. The defending Stanley Cup champions advanced to the finals for the third time in four years. Detroit will open the best-of-7 championship series Tuesday night against the Eastern Conference champion Washington Capitals at Joe Louis Arena. The Stars won the Presidents' Trophy for having the best record in the National Hockey League during the regular season (49-22-11), and had the best road record at 23-14-4. Still, the Red Wings were 2-1-2 against Dallas during the regular season and the Stars now are just 1-17-2 in their 20 visits to Joe Louis Arena since the franchise moved from Minnesota. Yet if any one thing did Dallas in during the conference finals, it probably was the disappearance of its power play. The Stars were just 1-for-30 with the man advantage during the series with Detroit, and 0-for-5 in the sixth and deciding game. And the Red Wings only added to Dallas' frustration by opening the scoring with a shorthanded goal, their second of the series. With a few seconds left in Kris Draper's roughing penalty, Steve Yzerman snared a loose puck and slid it over to Darren McCarty near center ice. McCarty hurried over the blue line, turned at the left circle and fed the puck to Murphy, who had a step on Dallas defenseman Sergei Zubov. Murphy faked Ed Belfour toward the right side of the net, then flipped a backhander over the goalie's stick for a shorthanded goal and 1-0 lead at 6:20 of the first period. Detroit, bidding to become the first team since the Pittsburgh Penguins in 1992 to repeat as Cup champion, kept the pressure on. Only the strong play of Belfour kept the score close as the Red Wings outshot Dallas 14-7 in the first period with several quality chances. Yzerman whizzed a shot past Belfour's glove early, but the puck hit the right post. McCarty, during another Dallas power play, broke in alone with 5:33 left in the first period, but Belfour closed off the right side by hooking his leg around the post to prevent another possible shorthanded goal. Fedorov scored his first goal in eight games, since the second-round series with St. Louis, on a no-look shot from the top of the slot. Fedorov, who leads the NHL with nine playoff goals, seemed to catch Belfour by surprise for a 2-0 lead 1:48 into the second period. The Stars came alive after that. But then it was Detroit goalie Chris Osgood's turn to shine. Dallas peppered Osgood, outshooting Detroit 11-7 in the second period. But Osgood, who also shut out Dallas in Game 1, came up with big saves to frustrate Mike Keane, Mike Modano, Jere Lehtinen and Pat Verbeek among others.

Phillies 8, Blue Jays 7

U.S. formalizes dlrs 25 million for Guatemalan peace
GUATEMALA CITY (AP) _ Guatemala hopes to strengthen its peace with a dlrs 25 million U.S. donation for development and reconciliation activities. The United States has pledged dlrs 260 million through 2000 to help Guatemalan implement its peace accords, U.S. Ambassador Donald J. Planty said Friday at a ceremony. Such international aid will help Guatemala strengthen its democracy and create sustainable economic growth that will benefit all levels of society, he said. The Guatemala military and leftist rebels signed peace accords in December to end a 36-year civil war. An estimated 140,000 people _ most of them civilians _ were killed in the conflict, and 40,000 disappeared.

BC-Mexico-Missing Money,0273
Mexico prosecutors think state money went to political party
GUADALAJARA, Mexico (AP) _ Some dlrs 20 million meant for charity was diverted from state coffers, much of it going to the governing political party, a Guadalajara newspaper reported Friday. Jalisco state officials confirmed the Publico report that the state Attorney General's office filed a court complaint about the missing money in November, though it had not been previously reported. ``All of this takes time,'' state spokeswoman Irma Pia Gonzalez said. ``In a few days we expect an indictment from the judge.'' The report raises a new scandal for the Institutional Revolutionary Party, known as the PRI, which has governed Mexico since 1929. The PRI lost control of Jalisco state in 1995 to the conservative National Action Party. Officials of the new administration discovered the apparent diversion of funds during an audit of accounts. According to Publico, state officials from 1991 to 1995 shifted almost 64 million pesos _ about dlrs 20 million at the time _ out of accounts meant for charity. In some cases, state checks were allegedly written to banks to which the government owed no money. Instructions written on the back of at least some checks directed the money be converted into cashiers checks for the PRI, Publico reported. It said that at least 23 million pesos went to the party. PRI state spokesman Gabriel Rivera said the party had no immediate comment on the report. Gonzalez said the complaint named about six former state officials of ``second or third level.''

BC-Sports-Basketball-NBA Finals Notebook,0658
Florida man makes dlrs 250,000 basket
By GREG BEACHAM Associated Press Writer
SALT LAKE CITY (AP) _ Maynard Trudeau has a quarter-million dollars more for his retirement. Trudeau, 74, won dlrs 250,000 Friday night by making a 3-point shot during halftime of Game 2 of the NBA Finals. He won't be spending it any time soon. ``I don't retire until I'm 80,'' said Trudeau, a carpet installer and part-time security guard from Florida. Trudeau got the chance to win dlrs 2 million after being selected from more than 1 million entrants in an AT and T promotional campaign. The World War II veteran had five shots _ the first four worth dlrs 250,000 each, the last a cool million. He shot them rapidly, each underhanded. The first went through perfectly. The others fell off. Trudeau, who hit about half of his warmup tosses on Friday afternoon, explained his success by saying ``You gotta concentrate.'' Trudeau and his wife are both big Bulls fans. ``Maybe,'' he said, ``the Jazz will give me a job.'' ___ DIALING 911: Even Utah's criminals are Jazz fans during the NBA playoffs. Valley Emergency Communications Center dispatchers usually can count on up to 200 calls for law enforcement assistance per hour on an average night. During Wednesday night's finals opener, however, calls dropped off sharply after the tipoff at the Delta Center. VECC assistant director Gary Lancaster said that by halftime, calls were down to about 100 per hour; by the end of the fourth quarter, it was less than a call per minute. A computer graphing of the call log showed about a 20 percent drop in calls per quarter. The Olympics, Brigham Young University football and not even Utah's trip to the NCAA basketball championship game this year had such an impact. Only the Super Bowl has a similar effect on the Wasatch Front, Lancaster told the Deseret News. ``It's about a 50 percent workload when the game is going,'' Lancaster said. ``Usually, as they (the Jazz) go further into the playoffs, and the games are more important, the workload drops off more.'' For instance, in the last Western Conference finals game against the Los Angeles Lakers on May 24, dispatchers received about three phone calls during the last seven minutes of play _ and that wasn't even a home game. ``The whole place died,'' Lancaster said. ``Like everything shut down while the game was on.'' ___ POPULAR GUY: Michael Jordan couldn't even finish the customary Bulls team shooting contest at the end of Friday's shootaround before dozens of reporters surrounded him on the court. ``Doesn't somebody else on this team talk?'' Jordan asked. But the pressure of the media crush doesn't bother the world's greatest player. ``I'm used to it,'' he said. ``It's not anything I'm not accustomed to. You guys are not going to ... change my approach to the game. I deal with it and separate it once I step on the court.'' Jordan said he intends to have a good time, especially since this championship round could prove to be his last. ``We don't know that, but it could very well be the last one, and I'm enjoying it with that purpose in mind,'' Jordan said. ``I should enjoy this. This is fun, actually.'' Most of Jordan's teammates sneaked out of the shootaround while the media clustered around Jordan. ``Just doing my part for the team,'' Jordan grinned. ___ MUCH ADO ABOUT RODMAN: Jordan says there's nothing wrong with Dennis Rodman's trips to Las Vegas, but there was something wrong with the Worm's performance in Game 1. ``I think he knows he didn't play particularly well,'' Jordan said. ``His thumb bothered him a little, but he's giving us an effort. A lot is being made of him going to Vegas, but he's been to Vegas many times before and come back and done his job. So I don't think that's a panic button.''
